[{"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"ganja ","formInput":"ganja%20"},{"value":"ndps act","formInput":"ndps%20act"},{"value":"seed","formInput":"seed"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Shiv Kumar Mishra vs State Of Goa Tr.Home Sec on 23 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33866","lastname":"________________j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-23","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Shiv Kumar Mishra vs State Of Goa Tr.Home Sec on 23 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ________________J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Cyriac Joseph</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n              CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n           CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 361______ OF 2009\n\n             (@ S.L.P. (Crl.) NO.8552 of 2008)\n\n\nShiv Kumar Mishra                             ...Appellant\n\n\n     Vs.\n\n\nState of Goa Through Home Secretary           ...Respondent\n\n\n\n                             O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">1.   Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.   The appellant was convicted under Section 20(b)\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">(ii)(B)     of    the   Narcotic   Drugs      and    <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_1\">Psychotropic\n\nSubstances Act</a>, 1985 (hereinafter referred to as\n\n`the <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_2\">NDPS Act</a>'), and sentenced to undergo rigorous\n\nimprisonment for three years and to pay a fine of\n\nRs.30,000/-       and   in    default    of   such    payment   to\n\nundergo simple imprisonment for three months.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                      2</span>\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.     On 9th December, 2004, the appellant was found\n\nin   possession       of   1.61    Kgs.   of    Ganja.       Under   the\n\nprovisions of the <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_3\">NDPS Act</a>, 1 Kg. of Ganja has been\n\ndefined    to    be    \"small     quantity\"     and     20    Kgs.   and\n\nabove has been defined as \"commercial quantity\".\n\nWhen the seized Ganja was analyzed on 15th December,\n\n2004, the weight thereof together with jute bag and\n\nplastic carrying bag was found to be 1.595 Kgs. The\n\nGanja    alone,       without     the    jute   bag     and    plastic\n\ncarrying bag, weighed 1.31 Kgs.                  Before the High\n\nCourt, it was contended on behalf of the appellant\n\nthat once the moisture content of the seized Ganja\n\nwas excluded, the actual weight of the contraband\n\nwould    weigh    less     than    1    Kg.,    which    would       have\n\nattracted a punishment of imprisonment for a term\n\nwhich could extend to six months or fine, which\n\ncould extend to Rs.10,000/-, or with both. It was\n\nalso    submitted      that     the     expression      `Ganja',       as\n\ndefined in <a href=\"/doc/233441/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 2(i)(b)</a> of the NDPS Act, does\n\nnot include seeds and leaves when not accompanied\n\nby the tops. It was also submitted that the expert\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                                   3</span>\n\n\n(PW.1) Mahesh Kaissare had not been able to specify\n\nthe weight of the flowery part alone or the leaves\n\nseparately.         It was prayed before the High Court\n\nthat in the circumstances since the appellant had\n\nalready undergone two months and six days out of\n\nthe     sentence,      the     same    be     considered     as    the\n\nsubstantive sentence and that the appellant would\n\ndeposit the fine in case the same has not been\n\ndeposited.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    The High Court rejected the submission made on\n\nbehalf     of    the    appellant,          but   considering      the\n\nquantity    involved         which    was    little   over    1   Kg.,\n\nreduced    the    sentence      from    three     years'     rigorous\n\nimprisonment to one year's rigorous imprisonment.\n\nThe fine was, however, not reduced.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">5.    Not being satisfied with the order of the High\n\nCourt reducing the sentence from three years to one\n\nyear,     the    appellant      has    moved      this   Court    for\n\nfurther relief.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                     4</span><p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">6.     In the present appeal, the same submission has\n\nbeen advanced on behalf of the appellant.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">7.     Learned     counsel    for     the    appellant      submitted\n\nthat having regard to the definition of \"Ganja\" in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/744415/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 2(iii)(b)</a> of the NDPS Act, the seeds and\n\nleaves     ought     not     to     have    been    included      while\n\nweighing the seized contraband since the same was\n\nnot     accompanied     by    tops.         It     was    urged     that\n\nexcluding the seeds and leaves the actual weight of\n\nthe seized Ganja would be below 1 Kg. which would\n\nattract a much lesser punishment of imprisonment\n\nfor a term which could extend to six months or with\n\nfine, which could extend to Rs.10,000/-, or with\n\nboth.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">8.     Learned     counsel    for     the    appellant      submitted\n\nthat    the   order    of     the    High    Court       reducing    the\n\nperiod of sentence to one year was erroneous since\n\nthe seized Ganja would be less than 1 Kg. and could\n\nnot,    therefore,     be     taken    to    comprise      commercial\n\nquantity.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                                    5</span><p id=\"p_14\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">9.     Despite several opportunities, the State did\n\nnot appear to contest the matter and the same was\n\ntaken up for final disposal in the absence of the\n\nState.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">10. <a href=\"/doc/744415/\" id=\"a_6\">Section        2(iii)(b)</a>      of    the    NDPS    Act   defines\n\n\"Ganja\" as follows :-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">       \"'ganja',      that     is,     the      flowering     or\n       fruiting     tops     of      the      cannabis     plant\n       (excluding the seeds and leaves when not\n       accompanied by the tops), by whatever name\n       they may be known or designated;\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_19\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">       An   attempt   has    been      made    on   behalf   of    the\n\nappellant to convince us that the seized Ganja was\n\nnot accompanied by flowering or fruiting tops and\n\nhence the weight of the seeds and the leaves would\n\nhave     to   be    excluded      on    account       of   the     said\n\ndefinition, which would reduce the weight of the\n\nseized Ganja considerably so as to exclude it from\n\nthe definition of commercial quantity and attract a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                     6</span>\n\n\nmuch lesser sentence than when the seized commodity\n\nwas treated to be of commercial quantity.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">11. The submissions made by learned counsel for the\n\nappellant      are   not     convincing         since    from     the\n\nevidence on record it has been established that the\n\nseized Ganja consisted of a greenish brown colour\n\nleafy   and    flowery     parts     of   the   plant   (in     moist\n\ncondition) which, in terms of the definition of the\n\nexpression     \"Ganja\",      would      include   the   seeds     and\n\nleaves of the cannabis plant since the seized Ganja\n\nwas accompanied by the flowery parts of the plant.\n\nAs far as exclusion of the moisture content of the\n\nseized Ganja is concerned, there is nothing in the\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_7\">NDPS    Act</a>   to   suggest    that      when    the   weight    of       a\n\nquantity      of   Ganja     is    to     be    ascertained,     the\n\nmoisture content has to be separately ascertained\n\nand excluded.        On the other hand, we are of the\n\nview that the weight of the contraband would be the\n\nweight taken at the time of seizure.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                 7</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">12. We, therefore, see no reason to interfere with\n\nthe judgment and order passed by the High Court and\n\ndismiss the appeal accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\"> Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33724","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Dhuk Singh vs State Of Rajasthan &amp; Anr on 9 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n              CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.                    OF 2009\n              (Arising out of S.L.P. (Crl.) No. 7460 of 2007)\n\n\nDhuk Singh                                               .....Appellant\n\n                                   Versus\n\nState of Rajasthan &amp; Anr.                                ....Respondents\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the grant of bail to respondent No.2 who\n\nhad applied for bail during the pendency of the proceedings relating to FIR\n\nNo.20/2007 Police Station, Syala, District Jalore.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    A learned Single Judge of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur\n\nallowed the bail application. The High Court stated that the question as to\n\nwhether respondent No.2 was to be added as an accused is the subject\n\fmatter of examination by the High Court, while considering the scope and\n\nambit of <a href=\"/doc/481610/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 169</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (in short\n\n`Code'). The High Court did not examine the case on merits and on that\n\nscore alone accepted the prayer for bail. It needs to be noted that learned\n\nSessions Judge, Jalore, had rejected the bail application on considering the\n\nnature of allegations against the present respondent No.2.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    The informant had filed the present appeal questioning grant of bail\n\nto respondent No.2. It is submitted that contrary to the view expressed by\n\nthis Court in a large number of cases, without indicating any reason the\n\norder granting bail was passed. Learned counsel for the State supported the\n\nstand of the appellant. On the contrary learned counsel for respondent No.2\n\nsubmitted that the scope and ambit of <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C. was elucidated by\n\nthis Court in <a href=\"/doc/1713684/\" id=\"a_3\">Dharam Pal &amp; Ors. v. State of Haryana &amp; Anr</a>. (2004 (13) SCC\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">9) and, therefore, the High Court was justified in granting bail.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">5.    The parameters to be kept in view while dealing with an application\n\nfor bail have been indicated by this Court in several cases; for example\n\n<a href=\"/doc/500640/\" id=\"a_4\">Anwari Begum v. Sher Mohd</a>. (2005 (7) SCC 325), <a href=\"/doc/1870696/\" id=\"a_5\">Chaman Lal v. State of\n\nU.P</a>. (2004 (7) SCC 525), <a href=\"/doc/427330/\" id=\"a_6\">Anil Kumar Tulsiyani v. State of U.P</a>. (2006 (9)\n\nSCC 425) and State represented by Inspector of Police, T.N. v. Eslian @\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\fJothi Basu (2006 (9) SCC 785). It has been held that the court considering\n\nthe bail application has to consider among other circumstances the\n\nfollowing:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      (i) the nature of accusations and the severity of punishment in case of\n\nconviction and the nature of supporting evidence; (ii) reasonable\n\napprehension of tampering with the witness or apprehension of threat to the\n\ncomplainant, and (iii) prima facie satisfaction of the court in support of the\n\ncharge.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">6.    In that view of the matter we set aside the impugned order of the High\n\nCourt and remit the matter to it for fresh consideration. Needless to say that\n\nthe High Court shall dispose of the matter by a reasoned order.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">7.    The appeal is disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">                                      ..........................................J.\n                                (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                ..........................................J.\n                                (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 09, 2009\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"341","formInput":"341"},{"value":"section 341","formInput":"section%20341"},{"value":"section 340","formInput":"section%20340"},{"value":"340","formInput":"340"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"section of,order","formInput":"section%20of%2Corder"},{"value":"suo motu","formInput":"suo%20motu"}],"firstname":null,"title":"K. Sudhakaran vs State Of Kerala on 5 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33691","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-05","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">K. Sudhakaran vs State Of Kerala on 5 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . Arijit Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n                   IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                   CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 452 OF 2002\n\n\nK. Sudhakaran                                           ..Appellant\n\n                                        Versus\n\nState of Kerala                                         ..Respondent\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">1.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a learned Single Judge\n\nof the Kerala High Court allowing the Revision Petition filed by the State.\n\nChallenge before the High Court was to the order dated 20.11.1998 in\n\nCriminal M.C. No.2081 of 1997 passed by learned First Additional Sessions\n\nJudge, Trivandrum. The issue related to the scope and ambit of <a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 341</a>\n\nof the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (in short the `Code'). The High\n\nCourt examined the question as to whether a person who had not filed an\n\napplication as required under <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 340</a> of Code could file an appeal\n\funder <a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 341</a> of the Code. The High Court held that a person who had\n\nnot filed complaint and the proceedings were initiated suo motu by the\n\nCourt could not file an appeal. But held that a revision petition was\n\nmaintainable. It is latter part of the revision petition order relating to\n\nmaintainability before the High Court which is under challenge.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.    Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that the scope and ambit\n\nof sub-section (2) of <a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 341</a> has been completely lost sight of by the\n\nHigh Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.    Learned counsel for the respondent on the other hand submitted that\n\nthe appellant is taking varying stands at different points of time and in the\n\norder impugned before the High Court not only the parameters of <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_5\">Section\n\n340</a> and <a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_6\">341</a> were under consideration but also the other relevant aspects.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">4.    <a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 341</a> reads as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">              \"341-Appeal-(1)- Any person on whose application any\n              Court other than a High Court has refused to make a\n              complaint under sub-section (1) or sub-section (2) of\n              <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_8\">section 340</a>, or against whom such a complaint has been\n              made by such Court, may appeal to the Court to which\n              such former Court is subordinate within the meaning of\n              sub-section (4) of <a href=\"/doc/875455/\" id=\"a_9\">section 95</a>, and the superior Court may\n              thereupon, after notice to the parties concerned, direct\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                      2</span>\n\f             the withdrawal of the complaint or, as the case may be,\n             making of the complaint which such former Court might\n             have made under <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_10\">section 340</a>, and if it makes such\n             complaint, the provisions of that section shall apply\n             accordingly.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">             (2) An order under this section and subject to any such\n             order, an order under <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 340</a>, shall be final, and\n             shall not be subject to revision.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">5.    A bare reading of the provisions makes it clear that an appeal under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 341</a> can be filed by any person on whose application the Court other\n\nthan the High Court refused to make a complaint under sub-section (1) or\n\nsub-section (2) of <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 340</a>. The other person who can file an appeal is\n\none against whom such a complaint has been made by such Court.\n\nUndisputedly, the present case was one where the initiation was suo motu\n\nby the High Court. The effect of decision of the Court which took suo motu\n\naction not to proceed further appears to have kept in mind by the legislature\n\nwhile enacting <a href=\"/doc/51872/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 341(1)</a>. Sub-section (2) of <a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 341</a> is relevant for\n\nthe purpose of this case. It states that an order under <a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 341</a> and subject\n\nto any such order, an order under <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 340</a> shall be final and shall not be\n\nsubject to revision. In other words there is legal embargo created on filing a\n\nrevision in respect of an order under <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 340</a> which cannot be the\n\nsubject matter of challenge. Undisputedly, what was challenged before the\n\nHigh Court was an order under <a href=\"/doc/908644/\" id=\"a_19\">Section 340</a> by the State of Kerala. The High\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fCourt was justified in holding that no appeal can be filed by the State under\n\nSection 341 of the Act. But its conclusions about maintainability of the\n\nrevision are indefensible in view of the clear language of sub-section (2) of\n\n<a href=\"/doc/661069/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 341</a>. It appears that the High Court has made certain observations\n\nagainst the officers which do not in our view warrant interference.\n\nTherefore, the impugned order of the High Court regarding the\n\nmaintainability of the revision stands set aside.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">6.     The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                           ........................................J.\n                                           (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                           ........................................J.\n                                           (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\n     New Delhi,\n     February 05, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                      4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":822880,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":908644,"url":null,"title":"Section 340 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"},{"tid":661069,"url":null,"title":"Section 341 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"},{"tid":51872,"url":null,"title":"Section 341(1) in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"},{"tid":875455,"url":null,"title":"Section 95 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"}]}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"firstname":null,"title":"Rohitash Prasad & Ors vs Saifuddin & Anr on 25 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33913","lastname":null,"secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-25","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Rohitash Prasad &amp; Ors vs Saifuddin &amp; Anr on 25 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: R.V. Raveendran, Markandey Katju</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                              IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                   CIVIL APPEAL NO.5115 OF 2007\n\n\n\nRohitash Prasad &amp; Ors.                                         ....... Appellant(s)\n\nVs.\n\nSaifuddin &amp; Anr.                                           ....... Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                                   O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">      The appeal arises out of an application filed by the\n\nappellants   under     <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_1\">section      11(6)</a>     of    the    Arbitration         and\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1306164/\" id=\"a_2\">Conciliation Act</a>, 1996, (`Act' for short). The Additional\n\nDistrict Judge No.2, Udaipur, as designate of the Chief\n\nJustice of   the     High   Court     of    Rajasthan,         heard   the    said\n\napplication and dismissed it on 16.2.2001. The said order\n\nwas challenged by the appellants in a writ petition (SBCWP\n\nNo.3959/2001). The said writ petition was dismissed by the\n\nHigh Court of Rajasthan on the ground that the remedy of\n\nthe   appellant    was      only     by    way     of     an     appeal      under\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                  2</span>\n\n<a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_3\">Article    136</a>    of   the    Constitution.    The     said   order    is\n\nchallenged in this appeal by special leave.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">2.    The matter is covered by the decision of this Court in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/963230/\" id=\"a_4\">Punjab    Agro   Industries    Corporation    Ltd.    vs.   Kewal   Singh\n\nDhillon</a> - 2008 AIR SCW 5745. Following the said decision,\n\nthis appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is\n\nset   aside.      Consequently,       the    writ    petition       (SBCWP\n\nNo.3959/2001) stands restored on the file of the High Court\n\nfor disposal in accordance with law. As the matter is old,\n\nthe High Court is requested to dispose of the writ petition\n\nexpeditiously.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">                                                     __________________J\n                                                      [R. (C) Nos.19770-19772 of 2007)\n\nUCO Bank and Anr.                                ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                        Versus\n\nPradeep Kumar                                               ...Respondent(s)\n\n                                     O R D E R\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">           Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">           After the case was heard at length, learned counsel appearing on behalf of\nthe respondent made a prayer that his client may be permitted to withdraw Writ\nPetition No. 11929 of 2007 filed by him before the Punjab and Haryana High Court to\nenable him to move the Debt Recovery Tribunal by filing an application under\nSection 17 of the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and\n<a href=\"/doc/198257891/\" id=\"a_1\">Enforcement of Security Interest Act</a>, 2002 [for short, `the Securitisation Act'].\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">           In our view, the request made by the learned counsel is reasonable and\ndeserves to be accepted. SINGHVI]\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 13, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":947348,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":198257891,"url":null,"title":"The Security Interest (Enforcement) Rules, 2002"}]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pillion rider","formInput":"pillion%20rider"},{"value":"kabir","formInput":"kabir"},{"value":"altamas kabir","formInput":"altamas%20kabir"},{"value":"motor accidents claims tribunal","formInput":"motor%20accidents%20claims%20tribunal"}],"firstname":"a","title":"Krishan Gopal & Anr vs Sandhya Devi & Ors on 18 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33852","lastname":"kabir","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-18","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Krishan Gopal &amp; Anr vs Sandhya Devi &amp; Ors on 18 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: A Kabir</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Cyriac Joseph</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                         IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n               CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n             CIVIL APPEAL NO. _______OF 2009\n      (Arising out of S.L.P.(Civil) NO.9944 of 2006)\n\n\nKrishan Gopal &amp; Anr.                    ...    Appellants\n\n\n                               Vs.\n\n\nSandhya Devi &amp; Ors.                   ...     Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                      J U D G M E N T\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">ALTAMAS KABIR, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.       Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.     The respondents herein are the parents of one\n\nJitender Sharma, who died in an accident on 21st\n\nDecember,     1998.    The   respondents    filed    a   claim\n\npetition, being No.39 of 1999, which was dismissed\n\nby the Motor Accidents Claims Tribunal, Kullu, on\n\n1st    December,   2001.   Against   the    said    order   of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                     2</span>\n\n\ndismissal of their claim, the respondents preferred\n\nan appeal, being FAO No.46 of 2002, in the High\n\nCourt      of    Himachal     Pradesh    at    Shimla,      which   was\n\nallowed in favour of the respondent nos.1 and 2\n\nherein on 29th November, 2005.                     By virtue of the\n\nsaid decision, the High Court held that Jitender\n\nSharma      had      died   due   to   the    rash    and   negligent\n\ndriving         of   Jitender     Thakur,     the    Appellant      No.2\n\nherein, while he was driving the scooter owned by\n\nthe Appellant No.1 (father of Appellant No.2) and\n\nthat both of them were jointly and severally liable\n\nto pay compensation of Rs.2 lakhs, together with\n\ninterest at the rate of 9 per cent per annum w.e.f.\n\n6th   October,        1999,     till   deposit      of   the   amount.\n\nThey were also directed to pay the costs of the\n\nappeal to the respondents assessed at Rs.3,000/-.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    The appellants have filed the instant appeal\n\nagainst the said decision of the High Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    In    order      to   appreciate       the    circumstances     in\n\nwhich the Tribunal dismissed the claim petition and\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                             3</span>\n\n\nthe High Court allowed the same, it is necessary to\n\nbriefly set out the facts leading to the filing of\n\nthe    claim      before   the     Motor    Accidents     Claims\n\nTribunal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">5.    On   21st   December,   1998,      while   the   Appellant\n\nNo.2 herein was riding a scooter belonging to the\n\nAppellant No.1, Krishan Gopal Thakur, there was an\n\naccident in which the said scooter and a Himachal\n\nRoad Transport Corporation bus which was proceeding\n\nfrom Kullu towards Manali, were said to have been\n\ninvolved.      According to the claimants, the accident\n\nhad   occurred      on   account    of   rash    and   negligent\n\ndriving of the driver of the bus as well as the\n\ndriver of the scooter.             As far as the owner and\n\ndriver of the bus are concerned, it was their case\n\nthat no collusion had at all taken place between\n\nthe scooter and the bus.             However, as far as the\n\nappellants are concerned, it is their case that the\n\nscooter was being driven by the deceased himself\n\nand the Appellant No.2 was the pillion rider on the\n\nscooter. According to them, the accident had taken\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                                 4</span>\n\n\nplace       due     to    rash       and    negligent          driving    of     the\n\ndriver of the bus in question.                            On the materials\n\nbefore it the Motor Accidents Claims Tribunal came\n\nto the conclusion that the claimants had failed to\n\nprove        that        the     accident         had     occurred       due     to\n\nnegligence          of     the      bus     driver       and    dismissed       the\n\nclaim petition accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">6.     In     appeal,          it    was     observed          that     the    main\n\nquestion which arose in the appeal was as to who\n\nwas     driving          the        scooter       at     the     time     of     the\n\naccident. In the FIR (FIR No.255 of 1998) it has\n\nbeen    shown        that        the       same    was    recorded        at     the\n\ninstance of Jitender Thakur son of Krishan Kumar,\n\nwho     is     the        Appellant          No.2       herein.          The     FIR\n\nindicates that the complainant, Jitender Thakur and\n\ndeceased Jitender Sharma, had gone to Haripur and\n\nwere,       thereafter,             coming        on    his     scooter        which\n\nskidded on some sand lying on the road.                                   At the\n\nsame time, one HRTC bus came from the opposite side\n\nwhich, however, did not hit the scooter and they\n\nhad    suffered           the       injuries       even       before     the    bus\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                               5</span>\n\n\nreached them. The accident was, however, witnessed\n\nby one Rewati Devi, who was examined as PW.5 and\n\ndeposed    that   while   she   was   drinking     tea    in   the\n\nDhaba   of    Milap    Chand,   she   saw    Jitender     Thakur\n\ndriving the scooter with Jitender Sharma sitting as\n\nthe pillion rider.           At the same time, a bus was\n\ncoming from the opposite side and collided with the\n\nscooter due to the fault of both the bus driver as\n\nalso the driver of the scooter.             She also deposed\n\nthat Jitender Sharma who was sitting at the pillion\n\nof the scooter, died as the handle of the scooter\n\npierced his stomach. She categorically stated that\n\nthe scooter did not skid on the spot as had been\n\nindicated in the First Information Report.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">7.   From what has been mentioned hereinabove, there\n\nappears to be two versions of the accident in which\n\nJitender Sharma died.         The version of the claimant\n\nis that the scooter in question was being driven by\n\nJitender     Thakur,   the   Appellant      No.2   herein,     and\n\nthat the deceased was the pillion rider.                 Jitender\n\nThakur, who was also the complainant, had, at the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                              6</span>\n\n\ninitial stage while lodging the First Information\n\nReport, stated that the scooter had slipped on a\n\npatch of sand and that the bus was not involved in\n\nthe accident and that injuries to the deceased had\n\nalready occurred before the bus reached the scene\n\nof the accident.        Subsequently, however, he changed\n\nhis     tune   and    contended     that   the    accident   had\n\noccurred       on    account   of   the    rash    driving   and\n\nnegligence of the bus driver.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8.    Apart from the said two conflicting versions of\n\nthe incident, as depicted by the Appellant No.2,\n\nthere is another dispute as to who was actually\n\ndriving    the      scooter    belonging   to     the   Appellant\n\nNo.1.     While it has been claimed by the Appellant\n\nNo.2 that it was the deceased who was driving the\n\nscooter and that he was the pillion rider and was\n\nnot, therefore, responsible for the accident, his\n\nversion has been contradicted by P.W.5 Rewati Devi,\n\nwho has categorically stated that she had witnessed\n\nthe accident and that it was the Appellant No.2 who\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                    7</span>\n\n\nwas driving the scooter and that the deceased was a\n\npillion rider.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">9.    The trial court accepted the version of the\n\nAppellant No.2 that he was the pillion rider while\n\nthe     deceased     was       driving     the       scooter        and\n\nconsequently came to a finding that the complainant\n\nhad not been able to prove that the Appellant No.2\n\nwas responsible for the accident in which Jitender\n\nSharma    died    and,   therefore,       rejected      the       claim\n\npetition of the respondents herein.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">10. The High Court, however, in appeal accepted the\n\nversion of the accident as narrated by P.W.5 Rewati\n\nDevi and has come to a definite finding that it was\n\nnot the deceased, but the Appellant No.2 who was,\n\nin    fact,   driving    the    scooter.       The    High    Court,\n\ntherefore,       disagreed     with      the   finding       of     the\n\nTribunal that the deceased was himself responsible\n\nfor the accident and held the Appellant No.2 to be\n\nthe only person responsible for the accident and\n\nthat since the Appellant No.1 was the owner of the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                                      8</span>\n\n\nscooter,        he        too     was     liable     for    payment   of\n\ncompensation          to         the    claimants,     who      are   the\n\nrespondents herein.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">11. From    the       facts        as    narrated    hereinabove,     the\n\nview   taken         by    the     High    Court,     relying    on   the\n\nevidence        of        P.W.5,        does   not    appear     to   be\n\nimprobable.          Apart from the fact that P.W.5 was the\n\nonly eye-witness to the actual accident, the High\n\nCourt has also disbelieved the version projected on\n\nbehalf     of        the        appellants     on    account     of   the\n\ndifferent stands taken by the Appellant No.2 as to\n\nhow the accident actually occurred.                        While at the\n\nvery initial stage it had been contended by the\n\nAppellant No.2 that the accident had occurred even\n\nbefore the bus had arrived at the scene, at a later\n\nstage it was contended that it was the bus driver's\n\nnegligence which had caused the accident.                       The High\n\nCourt also took note of the fact that the Appellant\n\nNo.2 had not come forward to be examined as to how\n\nthe accident had actually taken place.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                      9</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">12. The reversal of the Award of the Motor Accident\n\nClaims Tribunal by the High Court cannot be said to\n\nbe perverse or without any basis and we see no\n\nreason to interfere with the same.     The appeal is,\n\naccordingly,   dismissed,   with   costs   assessed   at\n\nRs.20,000/-.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                                    ________________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                       (ALTAMAS KABIR)\n\n\n\n                                    ________________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                       (CYRIAC JOSEPH)\nNew Delhi\nDated: 18.2.2009\n\f</p>","tid":1811769,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"janaki raman","formInput":"janaki%20raman"},{"value":"a. raman ","formInput":"a.%20raman%20"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"pondicherry","formInput":"pondicherry"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"illicit","formInput":"illicit"}],"firstname":null,"title":"State Rep.By ... vs M. Janakiraman & Anr on 9 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33722","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-09","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">State Rep.By ... vs M. Janakiraman &amp; Anr on 9 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n               CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n              CRIMINAL APPEAL NOS. 557-558 OF 2002\n\n\nState Rep. by Tahsildar-Cum-Sales\nOfficer                                                 ..Appellant\n\n                                        Versus\n\nM. Janakiraman and Anr.                                 ..Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in these appeals is to the judgment of acquittal recorded by\n\na learned Single Judge of the Madras High Court. The respondents were\n\naccused in C.C.No.195 of 1991 on the file of Chief Judicial Magistrate,\n\nPondicherry. Both of them were convicted for offences punishable under\n\nSections 31, 33, 37(a) and 38(1) of Pondicherry Excise Act, 1970 (in short\n\fthe `Act') and each of them were sentenced             to undergo rigorous\n\nimprisonment for six months under each head and the sentences were\n\nordered to run concurrently and fine of Rs.10,000/- with default stipulation\n\nwas imposed. Appeals were preferred by the accused persons and learned\n\nIInd Additional Sessions Judge, Pondicherry affirmed the conviction so far\n\nas offence punishable under Sections 31, 33 and 37(a) are concerned. But\n\nthe sentences were modified. The accused persons filed a Criminal Revision\n\npetitions before the Madras High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      On 28.4.1990 at 7.30 a.m. Tahsildar (Excise) Visanathan (PW-5)\n\nalongwith his officials and police party went on a routine raid and they\n\nreceived information that some people were indulging in manufacturing\n\nillicit Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMPL) at Aranganoor. They reached\n\nAranganoor and when they went near the unfinished house of accused No.1\n\nJanakiraman, they noticed the smell of arrack coming from that house. On\n\nseeing them, a person who was standing there, ran away and they found a\n\nlady there. On enquiry, they came to know that she was Vasantha @\n\nKumari, the daughter-in-law of Janakiraman and the person who ran away\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\ffrom there, was accused No.2 Settu another son of Janakiraman and the\n\nhouse belonged to accused No.1. Janakiraman. Excise Officer, Viswanathan\n\n(P.W.5) found a room in the house locked. When enquired, Vasantha told\n\nthem that the key was with accused No.2 who ran away from there.\n\nThereupon, the lock was broken and they went inside and saw 2000 bottles\n\ncontaining illicit   liquor (manufactured brandy) and they also found\n\napparatus and other items for manufacturing illicit brandy alongwith empty\n\nbottles. Viswanathan (P.W.5) seized the materials under cover of Mahazar\n\nin the presence of Vasantha and Assistant Inspector. P.W registered a case\n\nin Crime No.4 of 1990 under Sections 31, 33, 37(a) and 38(1) of the Act and\n\nsent the samples for chemical analysis. He examined the witnesses and\n\nmade the final report. The trial Court and the first Appellate Court found\n\nthe accused persons guilty.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      The High Court by the impugned order allowed the Revision\n\nPetitions.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">3.    In support of the appeals, learned counsel for the appellant-State\n\nsubmitted that the High Court's judgment is practically non-reasoned. It\n\ndoes not refer to the factual scenario or the evidence. Mere reference has\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                   3</span>\n\fbeen made to certain judgments of the High Court and this Court without\n\neven indicating as to how they are relevant for the purpose of this case.\n\nLearned counsel for the respondents supported the judgment of the High\n\nCourt.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">4.       We find that the only reason indicated by the High Court to direct\n\nacquittal reads as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">               \"Chapter VIII of Pondicherry Excise Act deals with\n               detection, investigation and trial of offences and its\n               empowers the excise officers to conduct search to seize\n               the articles liable for confiscation, to arrest without\n               warrant to conduct investigation and to complete it since\n               the excise officer is empowered to conduct search and is\n               also entitled to make investigation and complete the\n               same in accordance with law. The fact that the\n               complainant himself conducted investigation in the\n               present case would not vitiate the proceedings. The\n               contention of the petitioners that the procedure adopted\n               by PW-5 in filing the complaint and conducting the\n               investigation are vitiated by illegality cannot be\n               accepted.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_14\">5.       The evidence of the witnesses and the conclusions of the trial Court\n\nand the first Appellate Court have not been referred to at all. When two\n\ncourts had found the accused persons guilty, the High Court has even not\n\nindicated as to how the conclusions of the trial Court and the Appellate\n\ncourt were without any basis or not sustainable. The manner of disposal of\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                      4</span>\n\fthe Revision Petitions leaves much to be desired. Above being the position,\n\nwe set aside the impugned judgment of the High Court and remit the matter\n\nto the High Court for a fresh consideration and disposal by a reasoned order.\n\nNeedless to say that the factual scenario and the evidence has to be analysed\n\nby the High Court while deciding the revision petitions afresh.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">6.    The appeals are allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">                                         ........................................J.\n                                         (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                         ........................................J.\n                                         (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 09, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                    5</span>\n\f</p>","tid":626302,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"slp","formInput":"slp"},{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"sahara india","formInput":"sahara%20india"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Sahara India Commercial Corp.Ltd vs B.Jeejeebhoy Vakharia & Ors on 5 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33690","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-05","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Sahara India Commercial Corp.Ltd vs B.Jeejeebhoy Vakharia &amp; Ors on 5 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">\f2.          Though many points were urged in support of the appeals we dispose\n\nof the appeals with the following directions:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">     (i)          Let the suit No.3376 of 2005 on the file of the Bombay High\n\n                  Court be disposed of as expeditiously as possible preferably\n\n                  within a period of three months from today. The filing of documents, admission and denial thereof\n\n                  and framing of issues shall be completed within one month\n\n                  from today.</blockquote><p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">     (iii)        It appears that the plaintiff had filed an appeal (L) No.409 of\n\n                  2009 against the order dated 24.6.2008 on Chamber Summons\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                          2</span>\n\f            No.587 of 2007.
