It is submitted that by virtue of the order passed on the Chamber\n\nSummons on 24.6.2008, a learned Judge has observed that the suit is not\n\nmaintainable against defendant No.4. Since we have directed appeal against\n\nthis order to be disposed of within one month, liberty is given to defendant\n\nNo.4 to apply for variation and discharge of the undertaking upon disposal\n\nof the appeal in its favour. The Appeal Court will dispose of the said appeal\n\nuninfluenced by undertaking given by respondent No.4 herein. It is made\n\nclear that we have expressed no opinion on the merits of the case.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4.    The appeals are accordingly disposed of.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                         ........................................J.\n                                         (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                         ........................................J.\n                                         (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 05, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1062233,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"recognition","formInput":"recognition"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Haryana Judl.Court Employees ... vs Punjab & Haryana ... on 6 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33757","lastname":"...............","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-06","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Haryana Judl.Court Employees ... vs Punjab &amp; Haryana ... on 6 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . ...............</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: K.G. Balakrishnan, P. Sathasivam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                 1\n\n                      IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                     CIVIL APPEAL NO. 796 OF 2009\n           (@SPECIAL LEAVE PETITION (CIVIL)NO.26608 OF 2005)\n\n\nHARYANA JUDL.COURT EMPLOYEES ASSOCIATION(REGD.) Appellant(s)\n\n               VERSUS\n\nPUNJAB &amp; HARYANA H.C.THR.ITS REGISTRAR              Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                  ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">            Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.          The appellant is an association of members working in various\n\ncourts in the State of Haryana. The members include the subordinate staff\n\nof the various district courts and the Court of Civil Judge,Senior Division and\n\nJunior Division. The association has filed an application for recognition of\n\ntheir association by the High Court. The appellant association has filed a\n\nwrit petition before the High Court and the High Court, by the impugned\n\njudgment, rejected the same on the ground that there was no provision of\n\nlaw to give recognition to such an organisation.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">3.          Heard learned counsel for the appellant. The respondent is not\n\npresent when the matter was called.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">4.          Learned counsel for the appellant pointed out that there is no\n\nlaw which prohibits the forming of an association or giving recognition to\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                     2</span>\n\nsuch an association. It was argued\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                     3</span>\n\nthat this recognition is only for the purpose of giving their representation.\n\nWe do not find anything wrong in the High Court giving such recognition to\n\nthis association and the High Court, if necessary, may also frame some\n\nregulations in this regard.     The association is entitled to act as a\n\nrepresentative body for the members of the staff. The High Court may give\n\nrecognition to the association only for the purpose of giving any\n\nrepresentation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">5.          The appeal is disposed of accordingly. No costs.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                                ...............CJI.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                        (K.G. BALAKRISHNAN)\n\n\n\n                                                               .................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                                   (P. SATHASIVAM)\n\nNEW DELHI;\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">FEBRUARY 6, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":277909,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":18,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"last seen","formInput":"last%20seen"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"cumulative effect","formInput":"cumulative%20effect"},{"value":"tilak","formInput":"tilak"}],"citeList":[{"tid":75969,"url":null,"title":"Bodh Raj vs J And K Tourism Dev. Corp. And Ors. on 3 August, 2004"},{"tid":9122,"url":null,"title":"Bhagat Ram vs State Of Punjab on 9 February, 1954"},{"tid":1505859,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=9517","title":"Sharad Birdhi Chand Sarda vs State Of Maharashtra on 17 July, 1984"},{"tid":1597551,"url":null,"title":"Balwinder Singh Alias Dalbir ... vs State Of Punjab on 26 November, 1986"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Vithal Eknath Adlinge vs State Of Maharshtra on 27 February, 2009","publishdate":"2009-02-27","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":962262,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33929","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Vithal Eknath Adlinge vs State Of Maharshtra on 27 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 662 OF 2007\n\n\nVithal Eknath Adlinge                                    ...Appellant\n\n                                   Versus\n\nState of Maharashtra                                     ...Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nBombay High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant for offence\n\npunishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 302</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the\n\n`<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>').\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Prosecution version in a nutshell is as follows:\n\f      On 13.2.1986 Police Head Constable Dinkar Shankar Dumbre (PW-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">1) was attached to Railway Police Head Quarters at Ghatkopar. At the\n\nrelevant time, his nature of work was to receive the telephonic message\n\nfrom outside and convey the said message to the Railway Reserve Inspector.\n\nOn 13.2.1986 at about 1845 hrs. Mr. Gavade Head Constable came and\n\ninformed Dinkar Dumbre (PW1) that in Room No.41 of building No.24, one\n\nlady is lying in injured condition in a pool of blood. The said constable also\n\ninformed that he came to know about the said fact from the ladies residing\n\nin the said building. On receipt of this message Dinkar Dumbre (PW1)\n\nproceeded to the place of incident. He noticed one lady lying in pool of\n\nblood in the bath room of the house. Dinkar Dumbre (PW1) appointed one\n\npolice constable to guard the said place of incident and he proceeded to\n\ninform the said fact to RSI, Caze. Dinkar Dumbre (PW1) also informed the\n\nabove said fact to Tilak Nagar police station. The police from Tilak Nagar\n\npolice station arrived at the place of incident. The statement of PWI was\n\nrecorded by Tilak Nagar police which was treated as First Information\n\nReport. After investigation, charge sheet was filed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      Prosecution examined 12 witnesses to substantiate its accusations and\n\nthe trial was held as the accused pleaded innocence.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\f      The trial Court found the evidence to be sufficient to fasten the guilt\n\non the accused. Questioning the conviction and the sentence of\n\nimprisonment for life as awarded by learned Additional Sessions Judge,\n\nGreater Bombay, an appeal was filed before the Bombay High Court which\n\ncame to be dismissed by the impugned judgment. As the case rested on\n\ncircumstantial evidence the trial Court and the High Court analysed the\n\nevidence with great detail and held the accused guilty. The appeal did not\n\nbring any relief.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">3.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the appellant submitted\n\nthat the circumstances have not been established to find him guilty.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">4.    Learned counsel for the respondent-State on the other hand supported\n\nthe judgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">5.    The circumstances highlighted by the trial Court and the High Court\n\nto find the accused persons are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      (i)    That the accused and the victim were last seen together;\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">\f      (ii)    The victim was lying dead in the pool of blood and the\n\n      accused was not there.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">      (iii)   Previous enmity and therefore intention to kill is proved;\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">      (iv)    PWs 6 and 7 clearly refer to the conduct of the accused\n\n      for ill treating and harassing the victim prior to the date of\n\n      incident.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">6.    It has been consistently laid down by this Court that where a case\n\nrests squarely on circumstantial evidence, the inference of guilt can be\n\njustified only when all the incriminating facts and circumstances are found\n\nto be incompatible with the innocence of the accused or the guilt of any\n\nother person. (<a href=\"/doc/1204531/\" id=\"a_3\">See Hukam Singh v. State of Rajasthan</a> AIR (1977 SC 1063);\n\n<a href=\"/doc/444871/\" id=\"a_4\">Eradu and Ors. v. State of Hyderabad</a> (AIR 1956 SC 316); <a href=\"/doc/1945016/\" id=\"a_5\">Earabhadrappa v.\n\nState of Karnataka</a> (AIR 1983 SC 446); <a href=\"/doc/1585519/\" id=\"a_6\">State of U.P. v. Sukhbasi</a> and Ors.\n\n(AIR 1985 SC 1224); <a href=\"/doc/1597551/\" id=\"a_7\">Balwinder Singh v. State of Punjab</a> (AIR 1987 SC\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">350); <a href=\"/doc/425869/\" id=\"a_8\">Ashok Kumar Chatterjee v. State of M.P</a>. (AIR 1989 SC 1890). The\n\ncircumstances from which an inference as to the guilt of the accused is\n\ndrawn have to be proved beyond reasonable doubt and have to be shown to\n\nbe closely connected with the principal fact sought to be inferred from those\n\ncircumstances. <a href=\"/doc/9122/\" id=\"a_9\">In Bhagat Ram v. State of Punjab</a> (AIR 1954 SC 621), it was\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                      4</span>\n\flaid down that where the case depends upon the conclusion drawn from\n\ncircumstances the cumulative effect of the circumstances must be such as to\n\nnegative the innocence of the accused and bring the offences home beyond\n\nany reasonable doubt.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">7.    We may also make a reference to a decision of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/1718159/\" id=\"a_10\">C.\n\nChenga Reddy and Ors. v. State of A.P</a>. (1996) 10 SCC 193, wherein it has\n\nbeen observed thus:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                    \"In a case based on circumstantial evidence, the\n             settled law is that the circumstances from which the\n             conclusion of guilt is drawn should be fully proved and\n             such circumstances must be conclusive in nature.\n             Moreover, all the circumstances should be complete and\n             there should be no gap left in the chain of evidence.\n             Further the proved circumstances must be consistent\n             only with the hypothesis of the guilt of the accused and\n             totally inconsistent with his innocence....\".\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_24\">8.    <a href=\"/doc/307495/\" id=\"a_11\">In Padala Veera Reddy v. State of A.P. and Ors</a>. (AIR 1990 SC 79), it\n\nwas laid down that when a case rests upon circumstantial evidence, such\n\nevidence must satisfy the following tests:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">            \"(1) the circumstances from which an inference of guilt\n            is sought to be drawn, must be cogently and firmly\n            established;\n</blockquote>\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                    5</span>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\f            (2) those circumstances should be of a definite\n            tendency unerringly pointing towards guilt of the\n            accused;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">            (3) the circumstances, taken cumulatively should form\n            a chain so complete that there is no escape from the\n            conclusion that within all human probability the crime\n            was committed by the accused and none else; and\n\n            (4) the circumstantial evidence in order to sustain\n            conviction must be complete and incapable of\n            explanation of any other hypothesis than that of the guilt\n            of the accused and such evidence should not only be\n            consistent with the guilt of the accused but should be\n            inconsistent with his innocence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">9.    <a href=\"/doc/141148/\" id=\"a_12\">In State of U.P. v. Ashok Kumar Srivastava</a>, (1992 Crl.LJ 1104), it\n\nwas pointed out that great care must be taken in evaluating circumstantial\n\nevidence and if the evidence relied on is reasonably capable of two\n\ninferences, the one in favour of the accused must be accepted. It was also\n\npointed out that the circumstances relied upon must be found to have been\n\nfully established and the cumulative effect of all the facts so established\n\nmust be consistent only with the hypothesis of guilt.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">10.   Sir Alfred Wills in his admirable book \"Wills' Circumstantial\n\nEvidence\" (Chapter VI) lays down the following rules specially to be\n\nobserved in the case of circumstantial evidence: (1) the facts alleged as the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                    6</span>\n\fbasis of any legal inference must be clearly proved and beyond reasonable\n\ndoubt connected with the factum probandum; (2) the burden of proof is\n\nalways on the party who asserts the existence of any fact, which infers legal\n\naccountability; (3) in all cases, whether of direct or circumstantial evidence\n\nthe best evidence must be adduced which the nature of the case admits; (4)\n\nin order to justify the inference of guilt, the inculpatory facts must be\n\nincompatible with the innocence of the accused and incapable of\n\nexplanation, upon any other reasonable hypothesis than that of his guilt, (5)\n\nif there be any reasonable doubt of the guilt of the accused, he is entitled as\n\nof right to be acquitted\".\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">11.   There is no doubt that conviction can be based solely on\n\ncircumstantial evidence but it should be tested by the touch-stone of law\n\nrelating to circumstantial evidence laid down by the this Court as far back as\n\nin 1952.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">12.   In Hanumant Govind Nargundkar and Anr. V. State of Madhya\n\nPradesh, (AIR 1952 SC 343), wherein it was observed thus:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">                   \"It is well to remember that in cases where the\n             evidence is of a circumstantial nature, the circumstances\n             from which the conclusion of guilt is to be drawn should\n             be in the first instance be fully established and all the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                     7</span>\n\f             facts so established should be consistent only with the\n             hypothesis of the guilt of the accused. Again, the\n             circumstances should be of a conclusive nature and\n             tendency and they should be such as to exclude every\n             hypothesis but the one proposed to be proved. In other\n             words, there must be a chain of evidence so far complete\n             as not to leave any reasonable ground for a conclusion\n             consistent with the innocence of the accused and it must\n             be such as to show that within all human probability the\n             act must have been done by the accused.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_35\">13.   A reference may be made to a later decision in <a href=\"/doc/1505859/\" id=\"a_13\">Sharad Birdhichand\n\nSarda v. State of Maharashtra</a>, (AIR 1984 SC 1622). Therein, while dealing\n\nwith circumstantial evidence, it has been held that onus was on the\n\nprosecution to prove that the chain is complete and the infirmity of lacuna in\n\nprosecution cannot be cured by false defence or plea.           The conditions\n\nprecedent in the words of this Court, before conviction could be based on\n\ncircumstantial evidence, must be fully established. They are:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">             (1) the circumstances from which the conclusion of\n             guilt is to be drawn should be fully established. The\n             circumstances concerned `must' or `should' and not `may\n             be' established;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">             (2) the facts so established should be consistent only\n             with the hypothesis of the guilt of the accused, that is to\n             say, they should not be explainable on any other\n             hypothesis except that the accused is guilty;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">             (3) the circumstances should be of a conclusive nature\n             and tendency;\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                     8</span>\n<p id=\"p_36\">\f            (4) they should exclude every possible hypothesis\n            except the one to be proved; and\n\n            (5) there must be a chain of evidence so complete as\n            not to leave any reasonable ground for the conclusion\n            consistent with the innocence of the accused and must\n            show that in all human probability the act must have\n            been done by the accused.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_37\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">14.   These aspects were highlighted in <a href=\"/doc/154646541/\" id=\"a_14\">State of Rajasthan v. Raja Ram</a>\n\n(2003 (8) SCC 180), <a href=\"/doc/273747/\" id=\"a_15\">State of Haryana v. Jagbir Singh and Anr</a>. (2003 (11)\n\nSCC 261) and Kusuma Ankama Rao v State of A.P. (Criminal Appeal\n\nNo.185/2005 disposed of on 7.7.2008).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">15.   So far as the last seen aspect is concerned it is necessary to take note\n\nof two decisions of this court. <a href=\"/doc/1789800/\" id=\"a_16\">In State of U.P. v. Satish</a> [2005 (3) SCC 114]\n\nit was noted as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_41\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">            \"22. The last seen theory comes into play where the\n            time-gap between the point of time when the accused\n            and the deceased were seen last alive and when the\n            deceased is found dead is so small that possibility of any\n            person other than the accused being the author of the\n            crime becomes impossible. It would be difficult in some\n            cases to positively establish that the deceased was last\n            seen with the accused when there is a long gap and\n            possibility of other persons coming in between exists. In\n            the absence of any other positive evidence to conclude\n            that the accused and the deceased were last seen\n            together, it would be hazardous to come to a conclusion\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                    9</span>\n\f            of guilt in those cases. In this case there is positive\n            evidence that the deceased and the accused were seen\n            together by witnesses PWs. 3 and 5, in addition to the\n            evidence of PW-2.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_42\">16.   <a href=\"/doc/683472/\" id=\"a_17\">In Ramreddy Rajeshkhanna Reddy v. State of A.P</a>. [2006 (10) SCC\n\n172] it was noted as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_43\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">            \"27. The last-seen theory, furthermore, comes into play\n            where the time gap between the point of time when the\n            accused and the deceased were last seen alive and the\n            deceased is found dead is so small that possibility of any\n            person other than the accused being the author of the\n            crime becomes impossible. Even in such a case the\n            courts should look for some corroboration\".\n                (See also <a href=\"/doc/75969/\" id=\"a_18\">Bodh Raj v. State of J&amp;K</a> (2002(8) SCC\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">            45).)\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_44\">17.   Similar view was also taken in Jaswant Gir v. State of Punjab [2005\n\n(12) SCC 438], Kusuma Ankama Rao's case (supra) and Manivel and Ors.\n\nv. State of T.N. (Crl.A. No. 473 of 2001 disposed of on August 8, 2008),\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">18.   The cumulative effect of the circumstances, as highlighted above,\n\nwhen considered in the background of legal principles stated supra it is but\n\nclear that the accusations have been established by the prosecution. The\n\ncircumstances highlighted by the trial Court and the High Court to find the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                    10</span>\n\faccused guilty cannot be termed as perverse. Though the High Court's\n\njudgment is not very elaborate, but that cannot take away the effect of\n\nelaborate discussions made by the trial Court to find the accused persons\n\nguilty. The conduct of the accused cannot be also lost sight of. He was\n\nabsconding for 7 days. Above being the position, there is no merit in this\n\nappeal which is accordingly dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_46\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_47\">                                     .............................................J.\n                                     (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                     ..........................................J.\n                                     (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 27, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                   11</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":8,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"development charges","formInput":"development%20charges"},{"value":"highway","formInput":"highway"},{"value":"national highways ","formInput":"national%20highways%20"},{"value":"sirpurkar","formInput":"sirpurkar"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1379589,"url":null,"title":"Section 34 in The Insurance Act, 1938"},{"tid":1792838,"url":null,"title":"Section 6 in The Land Acquisition Act, 1894"},{"tid":1656199,"url":null,"title":"The Insurance Act, 1938"},{"tid":55378,"url":null,"title":"Section 23(2) in The Insurance Act, 1938"},{"tid":31609,"url":null,"title":"Section 23 in The Land Acquisition Act, 1894"}],"covers":[],"title":"C.R.Nagaraja Shetty vs Spl.Land Acq.Officer & Estate ... on 24 February, 2009","publishdate":"2009-02-24","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":701502,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"v","lastname":"sirpurkar","numcitedby":0,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33878","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">C.R.Nagaraja Shetty vs Spl.Land Acq.Officer &amp; Estate ... on 24 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: V Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Tarun Chatterjee, V.S. Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                             1\n\n                                                      \"REPORTABLE\"\n\n                IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO.1173 OF 2009\n             (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 8378 of 2008)\n\n\nC.R. Nagaraja Shetty                            .... Appellant\n\n                                Versus\n\nSpecial Land Acquisition Officer\nand Estate Officer &amp; Anr.                       .... Respondents\n\n\n\n                           JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">V.S. SIRPURKAR, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">2.    The present appeal has a slightly chequered history.          Land\n\nacquisition proceedings were initiated in respect of the land, bearing\n\nSurvey No. 4 of Beratana Agrahara Village, Begur Hobli, Bangalore South\n\nTaluk, measuring 35 guntas, belonging to the appellant.        Section 4\n\nNotification dated 29.11.1990 was published on 20.12.1990. After Section\n\n5-A enquiry, declaration under <a href=\"/doc/1792838/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 6</a> of the Land Acquisition Act\n\n(hereinafter referred to as `the Act') was published on 18.6.1992. In the\n\naward proceedings dated 9.12.1994, the compensation was determined at\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                   2</span>\n\nRs.10/- per square feet. An application for enhancement under <a href=\"/doc/1517117/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 18</a>\n\nof the Act was filed by the appellant and Reference Court partly allowed the\n\nReference and enhanced the compensation to Rs.27.50 per square feet.\n\nThe appellant was also held to be entitled to solatium at 30% of the market\n\nvalue and for additional amount at 12% p.a. under <a href=\"/doc/31609/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 23</a>(1-<a href=\"/doc/1656199/\" id=\"a_4\">A) of the\n\nAct</a>. The Reference Court accepted that this was non-agricultural land and\n\nwas situated adjacent to the Highway and thus, it had potential for being\n\nused for commercial purpose. The public purpose for which the land was\n\nacquired, was for widening of the National Highway.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.    Dissatisfied by the judgment of the Reference Court, an appeal was\n\nfiled before the High Court. The High Court set aside the order of the\n\nReference Court, enhancing the compensation and strangely enough held\n\nthat the Reference Court had erred in enhancing the compensation.\n\nAggrieved by the judgment of the High Court, the appellant filed a Special\n\nLeave Petition, being SLP (Civil) No. 8575 of 2006 before this Court. This\n\nCourt, by its order dated 26.2.2007, set aside the judgment and remanded\n\nthe matter to the High Court to consider the appeal afresh. Accordingly,\n\nthe High Court heard the matter again and partly allowed the appeal,\n\nenhancing the compensation amount at Rs.75/- per square feet. However,\n\nthe High Court deducted Rs.25/- per square feet for development charges.\n\nThe High Court also did not award the compensation towards yielding\n\ncoconut trees, barbed fencing wire etc.      Aggrieved by that order, the\n\nappellant, now, has come before us by way of the present appeal.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                   3</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">4.    The Learned Counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant urged\n\nthat considering that this land was on the outskirts of Bangalore City and\n\nhad the great commercial potential, the High Court was bound to give\n\nenhanced compensation, at least at the rate of Rs.100/- per square feet. It\n\nwas pointed out that the acquired land was on the National Highway and as\n\nsuch, had the potential for commercial purposes. The Learned Counsel\n\nfurther, by way of his second submission, urged that the High Court, at any\n\nrate, should not have deducted Rs.25/- per square feet, so as to limit the\n\ncompensation to Rs.50/- per square feet. The Learned Counsel pointed\n\nout that such deduction for development charges was completely\n\nunjustified, particularly, because there could be no development in the\n\nsmall piece of land.   The Learned Counsel relied upon the judgment\n\nreported in 2007 (9) SCC 447.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">5.    As against this, the Learned Counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nrespondent, supported the impugned judgment and contended that in fact,\n\nthe High Court had given much more compensation than what was actually\n\ndeserved by the appellant.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">6.    The High Court has increased the compensation from Rs.27.50/- per\n\nsquare feet to Rs.75/- per square feet. In the impugned judgment, the High\n\nCourt observed that the concerned land was abutting the National Highway\n\nand was within 15 kilometers from Bangalore City Corporation limit and\n\nfurther that all-round development has taken place as industries have come\n\nup thereby. In this, the High Court relied upon a Division Bench judgment\n\npassed by the same High Court, wherein, it was found that the value of the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                      4</span>\n\nnearby land was Rs.62.50/- per square feet. The High Court ultimately\n\nheld that since the said land referred to in the earlier judgment passed by it\n\nwas 25-30 kilometers away from Bangalore Bus Station, the present land\n\nwould deserve a better rate than the one given in the earlier judgment,\n\nsince it was only 15 kilometers away from the Bus Station. Accordingly,\n\nthe High Court recorded a finding that the rate of Rs.75/- per square feet\n\nwould be a proper rate. We are satisfied with this finding of the High Court,\n\nas the Learned Counsel has not been able to show anything from the\n\nrecord to hold that the concerned land would deserve a higher price than\n\nthe one awarded by the High Court. We are generally satisfied with the\n\nfinding of the High Court and would choose to confirm the same. Thus, we\n\nhold that the High Court was right in awarding the rate of Rs.75/- per\n\nsquare feet for the concerned land.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">7.    That leaves us with the other question of deduction ordered by the\n\nHigh Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">8.    The High Court has directed the deduction of Rs.25/- per square\n\nfeet. Unfortunately, the High Court has not discussed the reason for this\n\ndeduction of Rs.25/- per square feet nor has the High Court relied on any\n\npiece of evidence for that purpose. It is true that where the lands are\n\nacquired for public purpose like setting up of industries or setting up of\n\nhousing colonies or other such allied purposes, the acquiring body would\n\nbe entitled to deduct some amount from the payable compensation on\n\naccount of development charges, however, it has to be established by\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                    5</span>\n\npositive evidence that such development charges are justified.           The\n\nevidence must come for the need of development contemplated and the\n\npossible expenditure for such development.       We do not find any such\n\ndiscussion in the order of the High Court. As if this is not sufficient, when\n\nwe see the judgment of the Principal Civil Judge (Sr. Division), Bangalore,\n\nRural District, Bangalore in Reference proceedings, we find that there is no\n\ndeduction ordered for the so-called development charges.           We are,\n\ntherefore, not in a position to understand as to from where such\n\ndevelopment charges sprang up.          The Learned Counsel appearing on\n\nbehalf of the respondents was also unable to point out any such evidence\n\nregarding the proposed development. We cannot ignore the fact that the\n\nland is acquired only for widening of the National Highway. There would,\n\ntherefore, be no question of any such development or any costs therefor.\n\nIn the reported judgment in Nelson Fernandes and Others Vs. Special\n\nLand Acquisition Officer, South Goa and Others in 2007(9) SCC 447,\n\nthis Court has discussed the question of development charges. That was a\n\ncase, where, the acquisition was for laying a Railway line.      This Court\n\nfound that the land under acquisition was situated in an area, which was\n\nadjacent to the land already acquired for the same purpose, i.e., for laying\n\nRailway line.    In paragraph 29, the Court observed that the Land\n\nAcquisition Officer, the District Judge and the High Court had failed to\n\nnotice that the purpose of acquisition was for Railways and that the\n\npurpose is a relevant factor to be taken into consideration for fixing the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                    6</span>\n\ncompensation.      The Court relied on judgment in Viluben Jhalejar\n\nContractor Vs. State of Gujarat reported in 2005(4) SCC 789, where it\n\nwas held that the purpose for which the land is acquired, must also be\n\ntaken into consideration in fixing the market value and the deduction of\n\ndevelopment charges.     Further, in paragraph 30, the Court specifically\n\nreferred to the deduction for the development charges and observed:-\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">            \"30.   We are not, however, oblivious of the fact that normally\n                   1/3rd deduction of further amount of compensation has\n                   been directed in some cases. However, the purpose for\n                   which the land is acquired must also be taken into\n                   consideration.    In the instant case, the land was\n                   acquired for the construction of new BG line for the\n                   Konkan Railways...................... In the instant case,\n                   acquisition is for laying a railway line. Therefore, the\n                   question of development thereof would not arise.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_11\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      The Court made a reference to two other cases, viz., Hasanali\n\nKhanbhai &amp; Sons Vs. State of Gujarat and Land Acquisition Officer\n\nVs. Nookala Rajamallu reported in 1995 (5) SCC 422 and 2003(12) SCC\n\n334 respectively, where, the deduction by way development charges, was\n\nheld permissible. The situation is no different in the present case. All that\n\nthe acquiring body has to achieve is to widen the National Highway. There\n\nis no further question of any development. We again, even at the cost of\n\nrepetition, reiterate that no evidence was shown before us in support of the\n\nplea of the proposed development. We, therefore, hold that the High Court\n\nhas erred in directing the deduction on account of the developmental\n\ncharges at the rate of Rs.25/- per square feet out of the ordered\n\ncompensation at the rate of Rs.75/- per square feet. We set aside the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                   7</span>\n\njudgment to that extent. The claimant would, therefore, be entitled to the\n\ncompensation at the rate of Rs.75/- per square feet with all the statutory\n\nbenefits like solatium under <a href=\"/doc/55378/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 23(2)</a>, <a href=\"/doc/132249/\" id=\"a_6\">12</a>% interest under <a href=\"/doc/955646/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 23</a>\n\n(1-A) on the enhanced market value and interest at 9% and 15% as\n\nprovided under <a href=\"/doc/1379589/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 34</a> of the Act for one year and the rest of the period\n\nfrom the date of taking possession till the date of payment of the\n\ncompensation awarded in favour of the claimant. With this, we partly allow\n\nthe appeal and modify the order of the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                                            ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                            (Tarun Chatterjee)\n\n\n\n                                             ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">                                            (V.S. Sirpurkar)\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">February 24, 2009.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f8</span><p id=\"p_18\">\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":13,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"harjinder singh","formInput":"harjinder%20singh"},{"value":"joginder singh","formInput":"joginder%20singh"},{"value":" partisan","formInput":"%20partisan"},{"value":"jarnail singh","formInput":"jarnail%20singh"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"pohla singh","formInput":"pohla%20singh"},{"value":"sube singh","formInput":"sube%20singh"},{"value":"harbans","formInput":"harbans"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":137587,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=18813","title":"Gangadhar Behera And Ors vs State Of Orissa on 10 October, 2002"},{"tid":313314,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=6496","title":"State Of Punjab vs Jagir Singh And Ors on 6 August, 1973"},{"tid":674898,"url":null,"title":"Guli Chand And Ors. vs State Of Rajasthan on 30 November, 1973"}],"covers":[],"title":"Joginder Singh vs State Of Punjab on 27 February, 2009","publishdate":"2009-02-27","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":1354576,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33933","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Joginder Singh vs State Of Punjab on 27 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                  REPPORTABLE\n\n                   IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n             CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 406                OF 2009\n              (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 2315 of 2007)\n\n\nJoginder Singh                                       ...Appellant\n\n                                      Versus\n\nState of Punjab                                      ...Respondent\n\n\n\n                                 JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">\f2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nPunjab and Haryana High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant\n\nfor offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 302</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in\n\nshort the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') and sentencing him to imprisonment for life and fine of\n\nRs.2,000/- with default stipulation as recorded by learned District and\n\nSessions Judge, Ferozepur.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      A complaint under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a> IPC was filed by Harbans Singh son\n\nof Gurbachan Singh, resident of Chak Saidoke, Police Station Sadar\n\nJallalabad, Tehsil Fazilka against Joginder Singh stating therein that on\n\n18.1.1993 at about 9.00 AM. complainant, his brother Harjinder Singh alias\n\nInder Singh, Sube Singh son of Partap Singh, Jarnail Singh son of Mukhtiar\n\nSingh, Pohla Singh son of Aroor Singh all residents of village Chak Saidoke\n\nhad gone to the school of the village for the purpose of casting their votes in\n\nthe Panchayat Election. At about 9.45 or 10.00 a.m. he and his brother\n\nHarjinder Singh made a request to the voters to keep peace so that there may\n\nnot be any dispute in casting their votes for the people, who were already\n\nstanding in queue to cast their votes. In the meantime, Constable Joginder\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\fSingh No. 1421, PC Branch, office of the Senior Superintendent of Police,\n\nFerozepur, (the accused-appellant) challenged his brother Harjinder Singh\n\nand abused him and subsequently, he fired a shot from his rifle. The shot\n\nfired at Harjinder Singh hit on his head and he died at the spot. The\n\noccurrence was witnessed by the complainant along with Sube Singh son of\n\nPartap Singh, Jarnail Singh son of Mukhtiar Singh and Pohla Singh son of\n\nAroor Singh, all residents of village Chak Saidoke. Joginder Singh was\n\nrequested not to fire the shot, but he did not pay any attention and\n\ncommitted the murder of Harjinder Singh. He lodged a report with Inspector\n\nHarbans Lal, who recorded his statement and a case was registered vide FIR\n\nNo.5 dated 18.1.1993 under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_4\">section 304</a> IPC, but he was not arrested by the\n\npolice and no action was taken against him, notwithstanding the fact that he\n\nvisited the Police Station on number of times and this necessitated the filing\n\nof complaint.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">      The inquest report on the dead body of Harjinder Singh was prepared\n\nby Inspector Harbans Lal and he sent the dead body of Harjinder Singh to\n\nCivil Hospital, Fazilka, where post mortem on the dead body of Harjinder\n\nSingh was conducted. As per the post mortem report, cause of death was\n\ndue to shock and haemorrhage as a result of injuries Nos.1 and 2, which\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fwere on the vital part of the brain and were sufficient to cause death in the\n\nordinary course of nature and the injuries were caused with fire-arms.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">       After investigation was completed, charge sheet was filed. Since the\n\nappellant abjured guilt, trial was held.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      Stand of the accused appellant before the trial Court apart from the\n\nplea of denial was that some people tried to snatch away ballot boxes as a\n\nconsequence of which the law and order situation became bad. The police\n\nparty fired in the air to disburse the mob. The trial Court placing reliance on\n\nthe evidence of the eye witnesses recorded the conviction as noted above.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      In appeal the primary stand was that the so called eye witnesses were\n\nrelated to the deceased and, therefore, their evidence should not have been\n\nrelied upon. The High Court found that merely because the prime witnesses\n\nwere related to the deceased that did not in any event affect the credibility of\n\ntheir evidence. It was submitted that only one shot was fired and, therefore,\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 302</a> IPC has no application. It was also noted that there was no\n\nevidence that the voters had become uncontrollable or that there was\n\nsnatching of ballot boxes or ballot papers. The evidence clearly established\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                      4</span>\n\fthat the accused aimed at the head of the deceased and fired the shot.\n\nAccordingly, the High Court dismissed the appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">4.    The stand taken before the High Court was re-iterated by learned\n\ncounsel for the appellant in this appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">5.    Learned counsel for the State on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment of the trial Court as affirmed by the High Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">6.    Merely because the eye-witnesses are family members, their evidence\n\ncannot `per se' be discarded. When there is allegation of interestedness, the\n\nsame has to be established. Mere statement that being relatives of the\n\ndeceased they are likely to falsely implicate the accused cannot be a ground\n\nto discard the evidence which is otherwise cogent and credible. We shall\n\nalso deal with the contention regarding interestedness of the witnesses for\n\nfurthering the prosecution version. Relationship is not a factor to affect\n\ncredibility of a witness. It is more often than not that a relation would not\n\nconceal actual culprit and make allegations against an innocent person.\n\nFoundation has to be laid if plea of false implication is made. In such cases,\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                     5</span>\n\fthe court has to adopt a careful approach and analyse evidence to find out\n\nwhether it is cogent and credible.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">7.    <a href=\"/doc/1487227/\" id=\"a_6\">In Dalip Singh and Ors. v. The State of Punjab</a> (AIR 1953 SC 364) it\n\nhas been laid down as under:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"A witness is normally to be considered independent\n             unless he or she springs from sources which are likely to\n             be tainted and that usually means unless the witness has\n             cause, such as enmity against the accused, to wish to\n             implicate him falsely. Ordinarily a close relation would\n             be the last to screen the real culprit and falsely implicate\n             an innocent person. It is true, when feelings run high\n             and there is personal cause for enmity, that there is a\n             tendency to drag in an innocent person against whom a\n             witness has a grudge along with the guilty, but\n             foundation must be laid for such a criticism and the\n             mere fact of relationship far from being a foundation is\n             often a sure guarantee of truth. However, we are not\n             attempting any sweeping generalization. Each case must\n             be judged on its own facts. Our observations are only\n             made to combat what is so often put forward in cases\n             before us as a general rule of prudence. There is no such\n             general rule. Each case must be limited to and be\n             governed by its own facts.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_23\">8.    The above decision has since been followed in <a href=\"/doc/674898/\" id=\"a_7\">Guli Chand and Ors.\n\nv. State of Rajasthan</a> (1974 (3) SCC 698) in which <a href=\"/doc/406841/\" id=\"a_8\">Vadivelu Thevar v. State\n\nof Madras</a> (AIR 1957 SC 614) was also relied upon.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">\f9.    We may also observe that the ground that the witness being a close\n\nrelative and consequently being a partisan witness, should not be relied\n\nupon, has no substance. This theory was repelled by this Court as early as\n\nin Dalip Singh's case (supra) in which surprise was expressed over the\n\nimpression which prevailed in the minds of the Members of the Bar that\n\nrelatives were not independent witnesses. Speaking through Vivian Bose, J.\n\nit was observed:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">             \"We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the\n             High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses\n             requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an\n             observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are\n             women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their\n             testimony, we know of no such rule. If it is grounded on\n             the reason that they are closely related to the deceased\n             we are unable to concur. This is a fallacy common to\n             many criminal cases and one which another Bench of\n             this Court endeavoured to dispel in - `<a href=\"/doc/1420504/\" id=\"a_9\">Rameshwar v.\n             State of Rajasthan</a>' (AIR 1952 SC 54 at p.59). We find,\n             however, that it unfortunately still persists, if not in the\n             judgments of the Courts, at any rate in the arguments of\n             counsel.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_26\">10.   Again in <a href=\"/doc/32790580/\" id=\"a_10\">Masalti and Ors. v. State of U.P</a>. (AIR 1965 SC 202) this\n\nCourt observed: (p. 209-210 para 14):\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">             \"But it would, we think, be unreasonable to contend that\n             evidence given by witnesses should be discarded only\n             on the ground that it is evidence of partisan or interested\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                     7</span>\n\f             witnesses.......The mechanical rejection of such evidence\n             on the sole ground that it is partisan would invariably\n             lead to failure of justice. No hard and fast rule can be\n             laid down as to how much evidence should be\n             appreciated. Judicial approach has to be cautious in\n             dealing with such evidence; but the plea that such\n             evidence should be rejected because it is partisan cannot\n             be accepted as correct.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_28\">11.   To the same effect is the decisions in <a href=\"/doc/313314/\" id=\"a_11\">State of Punjab v. Jagir Singh</a>\n\n(AIR 1973 SC 2407), <a href=\"/doc/1829378/\" id=\"a_12\">Lehna v. State of Haryana</a> (2002 (3) SCC 76) and\n\n<a href=\"/doc/137587/\" id=\"a_13\">Gangadhar Behera and Ors. v. State of Orissa</a> (2002 (8) SCC 381).\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">12.   The above position was also highlighted in <a href=\"/doc/1033267/\" id=\"a_14\">Babulal Bhagwan\n\nKhandare and Anr. v. State of Maharashtra</a> [2005(10) SCC 404], <a href=\"/doc/1429015/\" id=\"a_15\">Salim\n\nSaheb v. State of M.P</a>. (2007(1) SCC 699) and Sonelal v. State of M.P.\n\n(SLP (Crl.) No.3220 of 2007 disposed of on 22.7.2008).\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">13.   In this case though one pellet was recovered and there was only one\n\ninjury. But that does not on the facts of the case take the offence out of the\n\npurview of <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 302</a> IPC. It cannot be laid down as a rule of universal\n\napplication that when there is one shot fired, <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 302</a> IPC is ruled out. It\n\nwould depend upon the factual scenario, more particularly, the nature of\n\nweapon, the place where the injury is caused and the nature of the injury. In\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                     8</span>\n\fthe instant case it has been clearly established that the accused aimed at the\n\nhead of the deceased and fired the shot which hit him on his head and that\n\ntoo was fired from a close range.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">14.   Above being the position the applicable offence is <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 302</a> IPC.\n\nWe do no find any merit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">                                         ........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">                                         (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                         .........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">                                         (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 27, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                     9</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":8,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"krishan lal","formInput":"krishan%20lal"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1440821,"url":null,"title":"Section 332 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":763672,"url":null,"title":"Section 148 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1682361,"url":null,"title":"Section 437 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":222396,"url":null,"title":"Section 427 in The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Krishan Lal & Anr vs State (U.T. Aggrieved by the order of conviction and sentence,\nthe   appellants    are   before      us   in   afore-mentioned   criminal\nappeals.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">                                                                   ....2/-\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">\f                                   -    2 -\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_4\">        The incident occurred in the year 1981 and nearly,\nthree decades have gone by.             At this stage, in our opinion,\nit is not necessary to go into the details of the merits of\nthe case pleaded by the learned counsel for the parties to\nthe lis.     In this view of the matter, without going into the\nmerits of the case, we feel that ends of justice would be met\nif the sentence is reduced to the period of sentence already\nundergone by the accused.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">        In    this   view    of   the    matter,   keeping     in   view   the\npeculiar facts and circumstances of the case, while disposing\nof   these   appeals,   we    reduce     the   sentence   to    the   period\nalready undergone.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">        The bail bonds of the appellants, who are on bail,\nare discharged.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">                                               ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                               [H.L. RADHAKRISHNAN]\nNew Delhi,\nApril 27, 2010.\n</p>\f"}, {"numcites":6,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"lathi","formInput":"lathi"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"molestation ","formInput":"molestation%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":415969,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=18606","title":"Bharosi & Ors vs State Of M.P on 12 September, 2002"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":37788,"url":null,"title":"Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":510098,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=27894","title":"S. Sudershan Reddy & Ors vs The State Of Andhra Pradesh on 20 July, 2006"},{"tid":1928406,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=19890","title":"Nathuni Yadav And Ors vs State Of Bihar And Anr on 20 December, 1996"}],"covers":[],"title":"State Of U.P vs Sheo Lal & Ors on 12 February, 2009","publishdate":"2009-02-12","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":1266179,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33784","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">State Of U.P vs Sheo Lal &amp; Ors on 12 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CRIMINAL APPEAL NOS. 362-363 OF 2002\n\n\nState of U.P.                                                 ..Appellant\n\n                                  Versus\n\nSheo Lal &amp; Ors.                                         ..Respondents\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in these appeals is to the judgment of a Division Bench of\n\nthe Allahabad High Court directing acquittal of the respondents. By the\n\nimpugned judgment two appeals were disposed of. The appellant-accused\n\nin each case had questioned correctness of the judgment rendered by learned\n\n9th Additional Sessions Judge, Kanpur in ST Case Nos. 190 of 1979 and 212\n\nof 1979. Each was convicted for offence punishable under Section 302 read\n\nwith Section 34 and Section 323 read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 34</a> of the Indian Penal\n\fCode,     1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') respectively. Additionally, accused\n\nSurender was convicted for offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/203036/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 354</a> IPC.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.      Prosecution version as unfolded during trial is as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">        In the evening of 20.3.1979 at about 6.00 pm Km. Sharmi (PW 4) was\n\ngoing to attend the call of nature. She was moving few steps ahead of Km.\n\nMunni. It is alleged that at the relevant moment Surendra and Suresh\n\naccosted Km. Sharmi. They told her to accompany them into Arhar field and\n\nwith that intent they also held her hands. On the alarm raised by her Km.\n\nMunni rushed to her rescue. At this, both the accused persons took to their\n\nheels. On her return to the house, Km Sharmi (P.W.4) narrated the incident\n\nto her maternal uncle Krishanapal, the deceased in the incident, and\n\nVijaypal (P.W.3). Both the brothers, went to the house of accused Sheo Lal,\n\nand made a complaint about the shameful behavior of his son and nephew.\n\nHaving made the complaint they came back to their house.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">         The deceased, Krishnapal, and his brother Vijayapal were relaxing\n\nand smoking Bidis on the Chabutara, which abuts their house. A burning\n\nlantern was also hanging near the grass-cutting machine. A lamp was also\n\nburning at the main door of the house.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                      2</span>\n\f      At about 8.00 P.M. Sheo Lal accompanied by Suresh and Surendra\n\ncame to the house of Krishanapal, deceased. Sheo Lal and Suresh were\n\narmed with Lathis and Surendra was armed with a knife. Immediately on\n\ntheir arrival near the deceased, they started hurling abuses and said that\n\nsince they are maligning his family, inflicted lathi injuries upon the\n\ndeceased and Surendra attacked him with knife. The hue and cry raised by\n\nthe deceased attracted Ratipal (P.W1), Chandrapal (P.W.2), Km. Sharmi\n\n(P.W.4) and some other family members to the spot. Ratipal was also\n\npossessing a torch in his hand. Chandrapal was also attacked with lathis\n\nwhen he tried to intercede. He had sustained lathi injuries. As a result of the\n\ninjuries sustained, Krishanapal fell down and died instantaneously. The\n\naccused persons withdrew thereafter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      The F.I.R. of the incident was lodged by Vijaypal (P.W.3). The\n\nwritten report is Ext. Ka.l. It was scribed by Rampal and was lodged at P.S.\n\nBidhnoo at 11.15 P.M. He was accompanied to the police station by\n\nRatipal, Chandrapal and Rampal. The chick is Ext. Ka. 2. It was prepared\n\nby P.W. Lallan Singh, Head Moharir.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\f       Chandrapal (P.W.2) was sent from the police station to the Primary\n\nHealth Center, Bidhnoo for medical examination of his injuries. He was\n\nescorted by constable Mahipal (P.W.5), for that purpose.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      After completion of investigation charge sheet was filed. As the\n\naccused persons pleaded innocence trial was held. The trial court recorded\n\nconviction. As noted above separate appeals were filed by each one of the\n\naccused persons which were disposed of by the common judgment directing\n\ntheir acquittal. The stand of the accused appellant before the High Court\n\nwas that the motive suggested is clearly unacceptable as the parties are\n\ninter-se related and it is improbable that the accused persons will tried to\n\nmolest their cousin (PW 4) in the manner as alleged by the prosecution. It\n\nwas submitted that the incident has not occurred in the manner alleged and\n\nthe FIR was ante dated. The trial court placed reliance on the evidence of\n\nfour eye witnesses PW 1 to PW4. The High Court noted that so far as the\n\nmotive is concerned the only witness is PW 4. The High Court accepted the\n\ndefence version that the motive was not established and the accusations\n\nwere also not established. Accordingly, it directed acquittal.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                     4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">\f3.    In support of the appeals, learned counsel for the appellant submitted\n\nthat the conclusions of the High Court are absolutely unsustainable. What\n\nappears to have weighed with the High Court to doubt versity of\n\nprosecution version is the introduction of a witness i.e. Munni Devi\n\nregarding the motive. The conclusions are based on presumption and\n\nsurmises. There were contradictory observations and no reason has been\n\nindicated to discard the version of the injured eye witnesses.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">4.    In response, learned counsel for the respondents supported the\n\njudgment of the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">5.    One of the prime reasons indicated by the High Court to discard the\n\nprosecution version is that in a dark night the possibility of identification\n\nwas not there. The source of light for identification was not mentioned in\n\nthe FIR. It is significant to note that there were four of the witnesses and\n\nsome of them were injured in the incidence. PW2 was an injured eye\n\nwitness. His evidence has been discarded on the ground that the injury\n\nsustained by him was a typical bruise. The following observations of the\n\nHigh Court show total non application of mind.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                     5</span>\n\f      \"Now we take up the testimony of Chandrapal\n\n(P.W.2), who, according to the prosecution, is an injured\n\nwitness. He has sustained these injuries while trying to\n\nintervene. His injury was examined on 20-3-1979 at\n\n11.30 p.m. His medical examination was conducted by\n\nDr. A.K. Shukla (P.W.8). This witness has sustained\n\nonly a solitary contusion. The injury is 21 cm.x 15 cm.\n\nOn the left side of back crossing the spine upto the right\n\nside at the level of fourth vertebral column. The injury\n\nwas simple and was fresh at the time of medical\n\nexamination. The Doctor has not noted the color of this\n\ninjury. He stated that by writing `fresh' he meant that the\n\ninjury was 2/3 hours old. He has made the entry with\n\nregard to this injury in the out door patients' register.\n\nWhen this doctor was examined in court, the injured was\n\nnot present before him. He has not noted down the depth\n\nof the bruise. He had admitted that these bruises could be\n\nmanaged with a chemical. He had stated in court that the\n\ninjury sustained by injured Chandrapal was a typical\n\nbruise. It was depressed in the middle and the edges were\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                        6</span>\n\f            slightly raised, but when probed further he admitted that\n\n            these facts, were not noted down by him in the injury\n\n            report or any where else.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">6.    Merely becasuse the colour of the injury was not noted and the doctor\n\nhas written that the injury was fresh, that is no ground to discard his\n\nevidence. The High Court has also attached unnecessary importance to the\n\nfact that one witness stated that the assault continued for 8 to 10 minutes\n\nwhile another said it was around three minutes. The doctor's evidence was\n\ndiscarded on the ground that his testimony was of poor quality and does not\n\ninspire confidence. The injury appeared to be manufactured one. The\n\njudgment is full of contradictions. As stated above, the High Court at one\n\nplace noticed that it is improbable that the accused person who was cousin\n\nof PW 4 tried to molest her. In the same breath the High Court in another\n\nplace has held that the accused persons to molest PW 4 at a particular\n\nmoment took her to the Arhar field and this was done with her prior\n\nconsent. The High Court goes further to say that there was no planning in\n\nthe act and had appeared to be chance meeting which led to it. The absurdity\n\nof the High Court's conclusions can be gauged from the fact that the High\n\nCourt found it unnatural that two girls of almost of the same age group were\n\nwalking and as to why one of them would move ahead and the other would\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                    7</span>\n\fcome behind is unnatural. The High Court further has held that PW 3 stated\n\nin Court that PW4 on her return told him that accused persons has teased\n\nher in the field. The High Court found fault with the statement on the\n\nground that he did not tell before the police that the girl did not tell PW 3\n\nthat the accused persons held her hands.         So far as the High Court's\n\nconclusions that there was non-mention of the source of light in the FIR it\n\nneeds to be noted that the accused persons were not strangers to the\n\nwitnesses. They were closely related.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">7.    <a href=\"/doc/1928406/\" id=\"a_4\">In Nathuni Yadav v. State of Bihar</a> [1998(9) SCC 238] this Court\n\nobserved that under what circumstances the lack of moonlight or artificial\n\nlight does not per se preclude identification of the assailants. It was noted as\n\nfollows: (SCC p. 242, para 9)\n\n                 \"Even assuming that there was no moonlight then, we have\n             to gauge the situation carefully. The proximity at which the\n             assailants would have confronted with the injured, the\n             possibility of some light reaching there from the glow of stars,\n             and the fact that the murder was committed on a roofless\n             terrace are germane factors to be borne in mind while judging\n             whether the victims could have had enough visibility to\n             correctly identify the assailants. Over and above those factors,\n             we must bear in mind the further fact that the assailants were\n             no strangers to the inmates of the tragedy-bound house, the\n             eyewitnesses being well acquainted with the physiognomy of\n             each one of the killers. We are, therefore, not persuaded to\n             assume that it would not have been possible for the victims to\n             see the assailants or that there was possibility for making a\n             wrong identification of them. We are keeping in mind the fact\n             that even the assailants had enough light to identify the victims\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                      8</span>\n\f            whom they targeted without any mistake from among those\n            who were sleeping on the terrace. If the light then available,\n            though meagre, was enough for the assailants why should we\n            think that the same light was not enough for the injured who\n            would certainly have pointedly focussed their eyes on the faces\n            of the intruders standing in front of them. What is sauce for the\n            goose is sauce for the gander.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">8.    The position was reiterated in <a href=\"/doc/415969/\" id=\"a_5\">Bharosi v. State of M.P</a>. [2002(7) SCC\n\n239] and <a href=\"/doc/510098/\" id=\"a_6\">S. Sudershan Reddy v. State of A.P</a>. [2006(10) SCC 163].\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">9.    The High Court's judgment therefore is clearly unsustainable and is\n\nset aside. The judgment of the trial court is restored. The respondents shall\n\nsurrender to custody forthwith to serve the remainder of sentence.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">10.   Appeals are allowed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                        .........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">                                                 (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                        .........................................J.\n                                        (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 12, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                    9</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":6,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"joginder
