Mohinder Singh &amp; Ors on 27 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                    REPORTABLE\n\n                   IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 1365 OF 2002\n\n\nState of Punjab                                       ..Appellant\n\n\n                                 Versus\n\n\nMohinder Singh &amp; Ors.                                 ..Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    State of Punjab has questioned the correctness of the judgment\n\nrendered by a Division Bench of the Punjab and Haryana High Court\n\ndirecting acquittal of the respondents. Each of the respondents was found\n\nguilty of offences punishable under Sections 302,450,324,148 read with\n\n<a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 149</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>'). Learned\n\fAdditional Sessions Judge Gurdaspur has found the accused guilty and\n\nsentenced them as aforestated.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Prosecution version in a nutshell is as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      At about 6 PM on October 31, 1995 Teja Singh (PW2) alongwith his\n\nson Joginder Singh and his daughter-in-law Paramjit Kaur(PW3) was\n\npresent in his haveli in Village china Railwala. His brother Fauja Singh and\n\nhis son Nirmal Singh (PW4) were living in an adjoining house and were\n\npresent therein. Soon thereafter accused Dalbir Singh alias Kala, Mohinder\n\nSingh and Swinder Singh, all armed with knieves, Baljit Singh alias Beeta\n\narmed with Dang, and Jasbir Singh alias Killa, Rachhpal Singh alias Pappu\n\nand Ramjit Singh alias Rana all empty handed came to the spot. Rachhpal\n\nSingh raised a lalkara that the complainant party be taught a lesson for\n\nhaving got Dalbir Singh arrested by giving false information to the police,\n\nRanjit Singh then caught hold of Joginder Singh from his long hair and\n\nDalbir Singh gave two blows with the knife he was carrying. The other\n\naccused also caused injuries to Joginder Singh with their respective\n\nweapons. Nirmal Singh and Paramjit Kaur tried to intervene but they too\n\nsustained injuries caused by the accused.      Fauja Singh raised an alarm\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                        2</span>\n\fhearing which all the accused ran away from the spot. Joginder Singh was\n\nremoved to the Civil Hospital Gurdaspur where he was declared dead\n\nwhereas the two injured eye witnesses, Nirmal Singh and Paramjit Kaur,\n\nwere medico-legality examined. Teja Singh (PW2) also left for the police\n\nstation but came across a police party headed by SI Sukhmohinder Singh\n\n(PW 9) and made his statement to the said officer at 10.55 PM and on its\n\nbasis the FIR was registered at police station, Dhariwal at 11PM. The\n\nspecial report was delivered to the Illaqa Magistrate at Gurdaspur at 7.22\n\nAM, on November 1, 1995. The accused persons were arrested in the course\n\nof the investigation and on its completion, were charged for offences\n\npunishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Sections 302</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1982060/\" id=\"a_4\">450</a>, <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_5\">324</a>, <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_6\">148</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 149</a> IPC.\n\nThey pleaded not guilty and were brought to trial.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      In order to establish the accusations prosecution examined eight\n\nwitnesses. Teja Singh, Parmjit Kaur and Nirmal Singh (PWs.2, 3 &amp; 4) were\n\nstated to be eye witnesses and the last two were injured eye witnesses. The\n\ntrial court placed reliance on their version and directed conviction as\n\naforestated.   Accused persons filed an appeal before the High Court.\n\nPrimary stand before the High Court was that there was delay in lodging the\n\nFIR and sending the special report and injuries on the accused were not\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                       3</span>\n\fexplained. It was also submitted that there was no mention in the FIR about\n\nthe injuries caused on Paramjit Kaur.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      It was pointed out that Kuljit Kaur had sustained injuries inflicted by\n\nKala when she tried to intervene was not mentioned in the FIR. The High\n\nCourt accepted the stand and directed acquittal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">3.    Learned counsel for the State submitted that the High Court's\n\njudgment is practically non-reasoned.       The trial court had analysed the\n\nevidence and noticed that there was no delay in either lodging the FIR or in\n\ndispatching a special report. Further the trial Court had categorically noted\n\nthat the injuries on the accused were superficial.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">4.    Learned counsel for the respondent on the other hand submitted that\n\nthe whole truth has not been disclosed and therefore the High Court was\n\njustified in directing acquittal. It is submitted that the scope for interference\n\nwith an order of acquittal is very limited and only where the judgment is\n\nperverse or contrary to evidence on record, the appellate court in a given\n\ncase may interfere.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                             4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">\f5.    It is to be noted that the High Court's judgment is practically non-\n\nreasoned and whatever reasons have been indicated are not only sketchy but\n\nalso are based on surmises and conjectures. There is also no discussion as\n\nto why the conclusions of the trial court have been found to be\n\nunsustainable. It is to be noted that the trial court found categorically that\n\nthere was no delay in lodging or despatching the FIR to Illqua Magistrate\n\nand the injuries on the accused persons were superficial. It is accepted that\n\nno report was lodged with the police about the accused person having\n\nsustained injuries. There is no counter case and interestingly no report\n\nappears to have been sent by the doctor who it was claimed by the accused\n\npersons to have treated the accused for the injuries sustained. The trial\n\ncourt noted that the occurrence took place around 6 PM. There were several\n\ninjured persons who were taken to the hospital. The trial court rightly noted\n\nthat it was but natural for Teja Singh whose son Joginder Singh had\n\nsustained injuries to take him to the hospital to save his life and the life of\n\nParamjit Kaur and Nirmal Singh, instead of going first to the police station.\n\nAll these aspects have not been dealt with by the High Court. There is also\n\nno discussion about evidence of PWs 2 &amp; 4 by the High Court.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                           5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">\f6.       In the aforesaid background we deem it proper to remit the matter to\n\nHigh Court for a fresh consideration and disposal of the appeal by a\n\nreasoned judgment. Since the matter is pending since long, we request the\n\nHigh court to explore the possibility of early disposal of the matter.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">7.       The appeal is disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">                                                .................\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">.............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                        .............................................J.\n                                       (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 27, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                                          6</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"madurai bench","formInput":"madurai%20bench"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Chinnaponnu vs State Of Tamil Nadu on 11 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33746","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-11","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Chinnaponnu vs State Of Tamil Nadu on 11 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n              CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 271                OF 2009\n              (Arising out of S.L.P. (Crl.) No. 4916 of 2007)\n\n\nChinnaponnu                                             .....Appellant\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of Tamil Nadu                                     ....Respondent\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a learned Single Judge\n\nof the Madras High Court, Madurai Bench, dismissing the appeal filed by\n\nthe appellant. Appellant was held guilty of offence punishable under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 304</a> Part II of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') and\n\nsentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for seven years by learned\n\nPrincipal Judge, Dindigul.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">\f3.    The factual position need not be gone into in detail in view of order\n\nproposed to be passed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.    The accused faced trial for alleged commission of offence punishable\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a> IPC. It was the prosecution version that in the course of\n\nsudden quarrel, the accused attacked Lakshmi (hereinafter referred to as the\n\n'deceased') who was stated to be the second wife of one Samuvel. On\n\n10.12.1994 the occurrence occurred. The accused faced trial and as noted\n\nabove was convicted by the trial court. The appeal before the High Court\n\nwas admitted considering the various grounds of challenge raised by the\n\nappellant. It appears from the impugned order of the High Court that the\n\nappellant's counsel did not appear when the matter was taken up and after\n\nhearing learned Additional Prosecutor, the appeal was disposed of.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">5.    It was pointed out learned counsel for the appellant that because of\n\nvarious difficulties the appellant's counsel could not appear and more\n\nparticularly neither the appellant nor his counsel had any knowledge that the\n\nmatter was to be taken up before the Madurai Bench of the High Court.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">\f6.       Learned counsel for the respondent-State on the other hand submitted\n\nthat the appellant and her counsel ought to have been more vigilant.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">7.       While issuing notice on 23.7.2007, it was indicated that the matter\n\nmay be remitted for fresh hearing because the appellant was not represented\n\nwhen the matter was taken up by the Madurai Bench of the Madras High\n\nCourt.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">8.       Considering the difficulties highlighted by the appellant to explain\n\nnon-appearance of the counsel we are satisfied that this is a fit case where\n\nthe High Court should re-hear the matter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">9.       We have not expressed any opinion on the merits of the case. We set\n\naside the impugned judgment and remit the matter to the High Court for\n\nfresh hearing.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">10.      The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">                                        ..........................................J.\n                                  (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                       3</span>\n\f                    ..........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">                    (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 11, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                         4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":402583,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":409589,"url":null,"title":"Section 304 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"}]}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"radio","formInput":"radio"},{"value":"tada","formInput":"tada"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Alistair & Ors vs State Of Tamil Nadu on 5 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33817","lastname":"...............","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-05","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Alistair &amp; Ors vs State Of Tamil Nadu on 5 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . ...............</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: K.G. Balakrishnan, P. Sathasivam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                 1\n\n                      IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                     CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                     CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.513 OF 1996\n\nALISTAIR &amp; ORS                        Appellant (s)\n\n                VERSUS\n\nSTATE OF TAMIL NADU                       Respondent(s)\n\n                                  WITH\n                     CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.663 OF 1996\n\nANTONY MARTIN &amp; ANR                        Appellant (s)\n\n                VERSUS\n\nSTATE OF TAMIL NADU                       Respondent(s)\n\n                                  ORDER\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">             These two appeals were filed against the judgment of the\n\nDesignated Court NO.II, Madras (now Chennai) under the Terrorist and\n\nDisruptive Activities (Prevention) Act, 1987 (hereinafter referred to as 'TADA\n\nAct').   The present six appellants were tried for the offences punishable\n\nunder Sections 451, 381 read with 120-B<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_1\"> of the Indian Penal Code</a> and\n\nunder Section 3(3) of TADA (P) Act. These appellants were acquitted of the\n\noffence under T.A.D.A. but they were found guilty of offences under <a href=\"/doc/513777/\" id=\"a_2\">Sections\n\n451</a> and <a href=\"/doc/436339/\" id=\"a_3\">381</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/1897847/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 120-B</a> of I.P.C. On both these counts, they\n\nwere sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of three\n\nyears each and the sentences were ordered to run concurrently.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">             These appellants were employees of Halliburton Offshore\n\nServices Inc.Company. They were carrying out the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                     2</span>\n\ncontract of offshore logging under the O.N.G.C.    There was some dispute\n\nbetween the employees and the management over the transfer of A-1 to\n\nBombay office and the appellants allege that PW 1, who was the Operations\n\nManager of the company, was inimically having disputes towards these\n\naccused. The company was in possession of certain radio active resources\n\nto find out the resource of natural gas.      The allegation against these\n\nappellants is that they have unlawfully trespassed into the workshop of the\n\ncompany and took away three radio active resources and thereby committed\n\nthe offences as charged.     On 23rd September, 1993 these radio active\n\nresources were found missing from the office premises. On 24th September,\n\n1993 PW 1 gave a complaint before the Station House Officer, Maduravayal\n\npolice station. The Sub- Inspector of Police -PW 20 took up the investigation\n\nand these appellants were arrested thereafter. Later on the investigation was\n\nhanded over to the C.B.C.I.D. and PW 26-Inspector of Police took over the\n\ninvestigation and he filed a report before the Court invoking the provisions\n\nof the TADA Act. The Superintendent of Police recorded the confessional\n\nstatement the appellants 2,3 and 4 and pursuant to the confessions, certain\n\nrecoveries were also effected and the three radio active resources were\n\nrecovered and later on the final report was filed in the case. On behalf of\n\nthe prosecution, 26 witnesses have been examined.       The appellants were\n\nfound guilty on the basis of their confessions and also the recovery made\n\npursuant to the statements made by the accused.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">            Heard both sides.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n            Learned counsel for the appellants contended that the materials\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                        3</span>\n\nadduced by the prosecution are not sufficient to find the appellants guilty.\n\nWe do not find any force in the contention and the Designated Judge was\n\njustified in holding that the appellants had committed the offence and\n\ntherefore, we confirm the conviction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">            Though the articles so stolen were of serious nature but there is\n\nno case that these appellants had any ulterior motive except to cause some\n\nnuisance to the employer. It appears that due to transfer of A-1 to Bombay\n\nthey had some grievance against the management.            There is also no\n\nevidence to show that these appellants had stored the articles for the\n\npurpose of gaining any financial benefit nor did they make any attempt to\n\nsell away these articles to some others. We are told that the appellants have\n\nalready undergone the sentence for more than 1 year and 9 months. Having\n\nregard to the facts and circumstances of the case, we feel that the period of\n\nimprisonment already undergone by the appellants is sufficient to meet the\n\nends of justice.   Therefore, we confirm the conviction but reduce the\n\nsentence to the period already undergone. The appellants are on bail and\n\ntheir bail bonds are discharged.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">            The appeals are disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                                ...............CJI.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                        (K.G. BALAKRISHNAN)\n\n\n\n                                                               .................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                                   (P. SATHASIVAM)\nNEW DELHI;\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5TH FEBRUARY, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":620891,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":513777,"url":null,"title":"Section 451 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":436339,"url":null,"title":"Section 381 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1897847,"url":null,"title":"Section 120B in The Indian Penal Code"}]}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"stage carriage","formInput":"stage%20carriage"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"subsidized","formInput":"subsidized"}],"firstname":null,"title":"A.Venkatakrishnan vs State Of T.Nadu & Ors on 19 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33856","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-19","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">A.Venkatakrishnan vs State Of T.Nadu &amp; Ors on 19 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n             CIVIL APPEAL NO.        1120         OF 2009\n\n                (Arising out of SLP (C) No.1693 of 2007)\n\n\n\n\nA. Venkatakrishnan                                          ....\n\n                       Appellant\n\n                                     versus\n\n\nState of Tamil Nadu and Ors.                        ....Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                               JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">\f2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nMadras High Court dismissing several Writ Petitions and Writ Appeals\n\nincluding Writ Petition Nos.18618/2003 to 18621/2003.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.    The short question which arises for determination in this Civil Appeal\n\nconcerns challenge to the Constitutional validity of Tamil Nadu Motor\n\nVehicles Taxation (Amendment) Act, 1998, by which initially the rate of tax\n\nin respect of contract carriage stood increased from Rs.1500/- per seat per\n\nquarter to Rs.2000/- per seat per quarter, and subsequently the said rate\n\nstood enhanced from Rs.2000/- per seat per quarter to Rs.3000/- per seat per\n\nquarter vide Notification No.1184 dated 30.11.2001 with effect from 1st\n\nDecember 2001.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    The basis of the challenge rests on the uneven burden placed on the\n\nowners of contract carriage vis-a-vis stage carriage. Broadly it is contended\n\nthat there is no rational in the imposition of the levy, that tax is imposed\n\nindiscriminately, that it is levied to cross-subsidize stage carriage and that\n\nuneven burden has been placed on the owners of contract carriage which\n\nhas no nexus with the services or amenities provided.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f5.      Generally, in a matter of this nature, the quantifiable data forms the\n\nbasis of the challenge. At the initial stage when the petition is filed in such\n\ncases there has got to be a precise formulation of the ground of challenge\n\nfrom the side of the appellant based on some statistical data as to\n\ndisproportionality of the rate of tax. It is only thereafter that the burden will\n\nshift on to the State to submit quantifiable and measurable data.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">6.        In the present case we find that the initial burden on the appellant\n\nitself has not been discharged in the sense that the petitions filed before the\n\nHigh Court were very sketchy. A challenge of this nature requires the\n\nappellant to furnish greater details before the State could be called upon to\n\nsubmit quantifiable and measurable data justifying the impugned rate.\n\nUltimately, it is the State which has to meet the allegations made in the writ\n\npetitions and if those allegations made in the writ petitions are vague,\n\ninaccurate or insufficient then it would not be possible for the State to\n\nsubmit its reply/data to the Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">7.       One more aspect in these cases also needs to be mentioned. It has\n\nbeen argued before us that the tax in question is a compensatory tax. Certain\n\njudgments of this Court are also relied upon in this regard, the latest being\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                      3</span>\n\fthe judgment in the case of Jindal Stainless Ltd. (2) and <a href=\"/doc/1937475/\" id=\"a_1\">Another vs. State of\n\nHaryana and Others</a> [(2006) 7 SCC 241].\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">8.          In our view, this repeated increase in the rate of tax, particularly the\n\nincidence of which is more on the contract carriage vis-`-vis. stage carriage\n\nraises question of public importance. At the same time the State can\n\ncertainly rely upon the data available to show cross subsidization, if it so\n\nexists in a given case, by which stage carriage gets subsidized in public\n\ninterest.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">9.          Keeping in mind the gamut of the dispute involved, we are of the\n\nview that the impugned judgment of the High Court cannot be interfered\n\nwith, particularly when the pleadings at the initial stage were insufficient.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">10.    Realizing this difficulty, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nappellant fairly stated that he would seek permission of this Court to\n\nwithdraw the Civil Appeal with liberty to file proper writ petition in the\n\nHigh Court giving requisite details and available data. Normally, we would\n\nnot have granted such permission. However, as stated above, questions of\n\npublic importance arises in these matters, particularly in the context of the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                         4</span>\n\fprinciples of proportionality under <a href=\"/doc/367586/\" id=\"a_2\">Article 14</a> of the Constitution and the\n\nlater development of law as indicated by this Court in the case of Jindal\n\nStainless Ltd. (Supra).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">11.   In the circumstances we permit the appellant herein to withdraw the\n\nCivil Appeal with liberty to file proper writ petition, if so advised. We make\n\nit clear that we do not find any infirmity in the impugned judgment of the\n\nHigh Court which is based on the petition originally filed by the petitioners.\n\nSubject to above, Civil Appeal stands dismissed with no order as to costs.\n\nWe make it clear that if a proper writ petition is filed giving requisite data to\n\nthe satisfaction of the High Court, then any observation made in the\n\nimpugned judgment will not come in the way of the appellant. All\n\ncontentions of both sides are expressly kept open.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">12.    Similar order was passed in a group of cases i.e. <a href=\"/doc/975119/\" id=\"a_3\">Tamil Nadu Omni\n\nBus Owners Association v. State of Tamil Nadu &amp; Anr</a>.( i.e. Civil Appeal\n\nNo.1177 of 2006 etc. disposed of on 28.11.2007).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                      5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">\f13.    Subject to the above, the Civil Appeal is dismissed with no orders as\n\nto costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                ..........................................J.\n                                (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                ..........................................J.\n
