2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33739","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-11","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">University Of Kerala vs Council,Principals',Colleges,Kerala ... on 11 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                     REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CIVIL APPEAL NO.                 OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP(C) 24295 of 2004)\n\n\nThe University of Kerala                               ......Appellant\n\n\n                                 Versus\n\n\nThe Council of Principals of                           ......Respondents\nCollege in Kerala &amp; Ors.\n\n\n\n                               JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">DR. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Ragging in educational institutions has been a matter of concern for\n\nthis Court since long. Noticing that notwithstanding a judgment of this\n\nCourt in Vishwa Jagriti Mission through <a href=\"/doc/40503/\" id=\"a_1\">President v. Central Government</a>\n\nthrough Cabinet Secretary &amp; Ors. (AIR 2001 SC 2793) few remedial\n\npractical measures have been taken to prevent the menace of ragging in\n\feducational institutions, by order dated 27.11.2006, a Committee was\n\nconstituted under the chairmanship of Mr. R.K. Raghvan, Ex-Director,\n\nC.B.I.    The Committee has submitted its report and suggested certain\n\nmeasures. Subsequently orders dated 16.5.2007 and 10.12.2007 were\n\npassed.    Further Status report has been submitted by Shri Gopal\n\nSubramanium, learned Amicus Curiae. Pursuant to the directions given by\n\nthis Court, the second and third reports of the Committee have been filed\n\nwhich read as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">            \"SECOND REPORT: The Committee under the chairmanship\n            of Dr RK Raghavan met at New Delhi on the 2nd April 2008 to\n            take stock of the situation and review the progress made by\n            different authorities, agencies and other stake holders who had\n            been directed by the Hon'ble Supreme Court to implement the\n            recommendations of this Committee's Report on ragging and\n            also of the Lyngdoh Committee on elections to student unions.</blockquote><p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">            2.     On the 10th December, 2007 the Supreme Court had\n            heard the matter and had passed certain orders. Accordingly,\n            on 4-1-2008, the Ministry conveyed to all the regulatory\n            institutions like UGC, AICTE, MCI, DCI, PCI, INC and ICAR,\n            the observations of the Court and its directions that in the\n            prospectus of the higher educational institutions it should be\n            mentioned that if any incident of ragging comes to the notice of\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                   2</span>\n\fthe authority concerned, the accused student will be given\nopportunity to explain and if his explanation is not satisfactory\nthe authority would expel him from the institution. The\nregulatory institutions were also requested to intimate from\ntime to time the progress being made and were also informed\nthat the reports being received from individual higher\neducational institutions be consolidated and analysed and only\nthe findings intimated to the Ministry for placing before the\nCommittee. For arousing public consciousness against ragging,\naudio video jingles/spots have been prepared by the Ministry\nwith the assistance of DAVP for release in the media. The\nCBSE has issued a letter to all institutions affiliated to it for\nimplementing an effective programme of counseling for\nstudents involving both parents and teachers, abolishing\ncorporal punishment, creating awareness about human rights\nand indicating the students behaviour pattern in the school\nleaving and character certificates. The Committee reviewed the\nprogress reported by the UGC, MCI and DCI. The absence of\nany report from NCI was noted. Thereafter the Committee also\nheard from the representative of UGC, AICTE, MCI and DCI\nthe measures taken and progress achieved by them.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">3.    The MCI informed that of the total 270 medical colleges\nin the country, 202 had reported the various measures taken.\nThese have constituted anti-ragging committees. They have\npublished names and telephone numbers of officials to be\ncontacted by freshers in case of ragging.       They have also\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                        3</span>\n\fconducted counselling sessions and orientation courses for\nsenior and fresh students. Punishments have been given to\nstudents found guilty of ragging, and the number of institutions\nreporting compliance has increased due to the efforts of the\nCouncil. The Dental Council of India also detailed the steps\nbeing taken to prevent ragging. Its representative said that all\nthe 127 dental colleges in India had constituted anti-ragging\ncommittees and squads to check ragging. These institutions\nhave reported compliance with publication of telephone\nnumbers and names of officials to be contacted in case of\nragging, besides conducting counselling and orientation\ncourses for seniors and juniors.       The AICTE's Member\nSecretary informed that the Council had issued advertisements\ninforming the higher technical educational institutions of the\ndirectives of the Supreme Court and had warned of deterrent\npunishment to institutions, like reduction in number of seats. If\nragging still took place in the institution. He said that the\nindividual compliance report received from each institution has\nbeen sent to the Ministry and that a significant reduction as\ncompared to last year in the number of cases of ragging has\nbeen achieved. He said that efforts were continuing and that it\nis hoped that incidents of ragging would be further reduced in\nthe new academic year.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">4.    Two cases of victimization of students who complained\nabout ragging had come to the notice of the Chairman who\npromptly took up the matter with the concerned institution,\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                         4</span>\n\fviz., Dr. MGR Educational &amp; Research Institute, Chennai (a\ndeemed university). It was only after two months, the Institute\ngave a reply. The two students have refuted the allegations\nmade against them in the Institute's reply. The Committee feels\nthat the whole episode needs to be probed in detail by the\nAICTE and a report obtained for further action.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">5.    The Committee noted that regarding student union\nelections the Secretary, Higher Education Department has\naddressed on 29.11.07 the State Chief Secretaries, for taking\nnecessary action. It thereafter took the following decisions:\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      (a)    the cases of harassment of two students for\n      complaining about ragging referred to by Chairman be\n      sent to the UGC for further action and this be mentioned\n      in the report to the Apex Court. The petition submitted\n      by the harassed student be enclosed;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">      (b)    along with the clause of punishment of expulsion\n      for ragging if found guilty, incorporated in the\n      prospectus of higher educational institutions, the latter\n      should also publish the number of cases of ragging and\n      punishments given by them in the previous academic\n      year. This may be mentioned in the report to the Apex\n      Court for its orders;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                        5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">\f(c)   regulatory agencies should put up the suggested\nanti-ragging measures before their council and get\napproval;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">(d)   the MCI should prepare draft regulation to prevent\nragging and send it to the Ministry for fast-tracking its\nadoption;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">(e)   where medical colleges and dental colleges are\nhaving same facilities/ campuses          the Councils\nconcerned should make combined efforts to be more\neffective;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">(f)   since the XI Plan Funding Committees of the UGC\nwill be visiting educational institutions to assess the\ngrant requirements and invite proposals, prevention of\nragging be made one of the focus items. Since the\nCommittees      will    have     representatives    from\nAICTE//MCI/DCI etc., it should convey the seriousness\nof the message to prevent ragging to the managements;\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">(g)   regulatory bodies should do more detailed analysis\nof the reports received to enable targeting regions and\ninstitutions where measures to prevent ragging are not\nproving to be very effective;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                 6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">\f      (h)   all institutions concerned should do whatever they\n      can by ensuring punishment to the students found guilty\n      of ragging, giving wide publicity to such punishments to\n      act as a deterrent, strict enforcement of the various\n      measures suggested by the Committee so that each\n      complement the other and the message goes down to the\n      grass roots;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">      (i)   socially active NGOs like CURE can be also\n      encouraged to help to prevent and sensitize public\n      opinion to prevent ragging;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">(j)   Committee should meet every month from June to\nAugust, and thereafter once in a month to review the situation ;\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">(k)   the next meeting of the Committee may be held in May\n2008 ( on dates other than 29-31st).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">THIRD       REPORT:        1.Two meetings of the Committee\nappointed by the Supreme Court under the chairmanship of Dr.\nR K Raghavan to monitor the various measures to prevent\nragging and to conduct student union elections in higher\neducational institutions were held on 11th June 2008 and 5th\nAugust 2008 in New Delhi.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                       7</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">\f2.    In both the meetings the Committee reviewed the actions\ntaken on the decisions of the Committee's previous meetings.\nIn the meeting held on 11th June 2008 the Committee expressed\nits disappointment over the helplessness shown by the\nregulatory bodies. It suggested to UGC to link release of grants\nunder various schemes to educational institutions with the\ncompliance by them with the directions of the Supreme Court\nof India. It directed educational institutions (through the\nregulatory agencies) to incorporate in their admission\nnotices/advertisements appropriate messages regarding `zero\ntolerence' towards ragging.    It decided that an audio video\ncampaign to prevent ragging should be undertaken at the\ncommencement of the new academic session. It noted that the\nMedical Council of India had not framed draft regulations to\nprevent ragging despite the Committee's advice. The request\nwas reiterated to the Council. It also requested the UGC to\ninvestigate the case of harassment of two students who\ncomplained about ragging, by the MGR Institute of Higher\nEducation &amp; Research. In its meeting held on 5th August 2008\nthe Committee noted that the advertisement and audio visual\ncampaign being undertaken by the Government of India at the\ncommencement of the new academic session to prevent ragging\nin higher educational institutions had good effect.           It\nappreciated that the advertisements of the Ministry have been\nexhibited in the Ministry's website for use by educational\ninstitutions in their local campaigns.   It also noted that in\naddition the Delhi Police had issued advertisements in the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                       8</span>\n\fnational capital region to prevent ragging and the need to\nprevent ragging was rieterated in the State Education\nMinisters' Conference held on 23rd and 24th July 2008 in the\ncapital. The Committee felt that the publicity effort must\npercolate to the institutional level and each campus should\nmake efforts to publicize and sensitize students regarding the\nmenace of ragging.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_37\">\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">3.    In its meeting held on 5th August 2008, the Committee\n\ndiscussed the work being done by several NGOs. Their work\n\nwas appreciated. The video on the website of CURE was\n\nspecially mentioned in addition to the compilation of data\n\nregarding ragging cases reported in various parts of the\n\ncountry. The NGO from West Bengal which is engaged in\n\nprevention of ragging was also referred to. The various\n\ncouncils were advised by the Committee to draw upon the\n\nefforts of NGOs where necessary.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">4.    The Committee felt that the audiovisual campaign has\n\nbeen successful in raising the level of awareness of the people\n\nabout the evil effects of ragging. The Committee felt that the\n\nadvertisements campaign should be continued to cover the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                       9</span>\n\fcommencement of professional courses. In the case of shortage\n\nof funds the campaign can be focused on medical colleges in\n\nregions more prone to ragging incidents.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_41\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">5.    Reviewing the number of cases reported in the current\n\nacademic session the Committee decided that the case of\n\nragging in the Rajkumari Amrit Kaur College of Nursing, New\n\nDelhi should be enquired into by the Nursing Council of India.\n\nThe Committee resolved that any incident as reported in the\n\npress should be presumed to be ragging unless on enquiry it is\n\nfound to be otherwise. The incidents of ragging reported are\n\npassed off as altercation or spats between students and this\n\nprecludes detailed enquiry and punishment of the guilty\n\nstudents. It therefore desired that the reported incidents should\n\nbe enquired into by the Nursing Council to ascertain the facts\n\nthereof. The Committee noted the ragging case reported at The\n\nGraphic Era Institute of Technology, UP. The AICTE was\n\nrequested to look into the matter to ascertain the facts regarding\n\nthe punishment given to the guilty students. The case of \"paid\n\nragging\" in Coimbatore reported in The Indian Express of\n\n5.8.2008, where the fresh students were forced to pay for the\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                        10</span>\n\fluxury trips of senior students in star hotels was referred to the\n\nAICTE for investigation and necessary action. The Committee\n\nemphasized the need to give exemplary punishment as directed\n\nby the Supreme Court to the students found guilty of ragging so\n\nthat the seriousness with which authorities view such incidents\n\nsink in.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_43\">\n</p><p id=\"p_44\">6.    Regarding the harassment case of two students by the\nMGR Institute of Higher Education &amp; Research, Chennai the\nCommittee was unhappy to note the slow progress. It directed\nthe UGC to conduct an enquiry by deputing a joint team of\nUGC and AICTE and submit its findings expeditiously.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">7.    The Committee discussed the problems being created by\n\nanonymous complaints, lack of definition of permissible modes\n\nof interaction of senior with junior students and the role of\n\nstudent unions in preventing ragging. The unwillingness of\n\ncomplainants to disclose their identity and details of ragging\n\nincidents and persons involved is posing a big problem in\n\ntaking action.   The Committee felt that ragging is a very\n\ncomplex phenomenon involving social, psychological and\n\nother dimensions. It would not be appropriate to face the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                        11</span>\n\f             problem from the angle of regulations and restrictions alone\n\n             because it is very difficult for educational administrators to\n\n             tackle demands of students' self governing institutions.\n\n             Generating awareness amongst students through student unions\n\n             about the bad effects of ragging can be tried as a method.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_46\">             8.    The Committee felt that more was needed to be done by\n\n             regulatory bodies to prevent ragging and the response of\n\n             educational institutions to efforts by the Councils lacked\n\n             promptness.       They should formulate regulations and give\n\n             directions. The Committee felt that the learned Additional\n\n             Solicitor General be requested to approach the Hon'ble Court\n\n             on the various other suggestions like dedicated wardens etc.,\n\n             contained in the Committee's report.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_47\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_48\">3.    Ragging is rationalised and justified as a way of \"Introduction or\n\ngetting familiar\" with the freshers at the starting of an academic session of\n\nany educational institution.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_49\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                                      12</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_50\">\f4.    In a very positive aspect, \"Ragging\" could not be considered as an\n\nabridgement between the seniors and the freshers, whereas \"Introduction\"\n\ncould be considered as genesis of relationship between the two.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_51\">5.     When any student is admitted in a particular institution he/she has\n\nto face certain problems and one of them which affects the most is staying\n\naway from home and especially away from the dear ones. Because of\n\nthese problems, the freshers expect some one to look after them, with\n\nwhom they can have homely environment as they were enjoying at their\n\nrespective homes. But nowadays the seniors have crossed the barriers, by\n\nwhich they have changed the meaning of \"Introduction\" into \"Ragging\".\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_52\">6.    \"Seniors\" under the garb of \"Introduction\" have started ragging the\n\nfreshers and due to which, in recent years, it has become the talk of the day\n\nthat the freshers who have faced severe ragging are leaving the educational\n\ninstitutions and some have attempted to commit suicide and even some\n\nhave committed it.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_53\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                     13</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_54\">\f7.    In modern era, \"Ragging\" has become to be known only as synonym\n\nof \"teasing\", \"terror\", \"harassment\", \"cruelty\", \"fear\" and \"physical and\n\nmental torture\".\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_55\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_56\">8.    By perusal of records and survey, it has come to be accepted that\n\n\"Ragging\" is a systematized form of Human Rights' abuse as embodied\n\nunder the Constitution of India as well as other Constitutions of the World.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_57\">9.     Over the years in all over the world and especially in South Asia,\n\nthe practice of \"Ragging\" has come to be meant as an extreme\n\n\"harassment\", \"terror\" and even \"physical and mental torture\" of freshers.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_58\">10.    Ragging is a set of undisciplined activities undertaken by the\n\nseniors to break the ice with the juniors, who have been suddenly thrown\n\ninto a totally new environment. The contention of seniors behind all such\n\nactivities is simply to bring the freshers down to earth, because in their\n\nopinion the freshers do not respect the seniors and by doing all such\n\ninhuman activities under the garb of \"Introduction\", the seniors rag the\n\nfreshers so that the freshers may respect them and be under their control.\n\nBut this act cannot be reasonable and just. The act by the seniors is a \"fist\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">                                    14</span>\n\fof steel against ice\" and likewise by doing so, they shatter the ambition,\n\naim and object of freshers and they become aloof in this practical world.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_59\">11.   To prohibit \"Ragging\", this Cour has given a series of guidelines to\n\nthe educational institutions whether being Central, State or Private Institute.\n\n[See: <a href=\"/doc/301513/\" id=\"a_2\">Vishva Jagriti Mission v. Central Government</a> (AIR 2001 SC 2793)].\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_60\">12.   Ragging in essence is a human rights' abuse. Ragging can be in\n\nvarious forms. It can be physical abuse or mental harassment. In present\n\ntimes shocking incidents of ragging have come to the notice. Sometimes\n\nviolence is used.    The student is physically tortured or psychologically\n\nterrorized. All human being should be free to claim, as a matter of right in\n\nthe society in which they live, for life of dignity but when it is intentionally\n\nor recklessly damaged or departed then the person's human right is abused;\n\nin that sense ragging is the best example of human rights' abuse.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_61\">13.   Everyman's Encyclopaedia (1938 Edition, Vol. II) and Random\n\nHouse Dictionary of the English Language (1967 Edition) have references\n\nabout ragging. The synonyms of ragging as racking, ducking, teasing, etc.\n\nare mentioned in detail in these reference books. In England the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                                      15</span>\n\fcredit/discredit goes to Duke of Exeter to introduce the practice of ragging.\n\nRacking was another form of ragging in which a special instrument called\n\n'rack' was used to torture the victim. Gradually it mixed up with the term of\n\nragging. Egyptian, Romans and Greeks were also not lagging behind. Some\n\nform or the other of ragging was found in their societies.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_62\">14.   Ragging is not a new phenomenon. It existed even in older times. It\n\nwas part of civilised societies. In ancient seats of learning, e.g., Berytus and\n\nAthens ragging was prevalent. In army schools of England ragging existed\n\nas a tradition. Later on this tradition took its root in medical and engineering\n\ncolleges. In English society ragging took the form of freshers being paraded\n\non street which caused much annoyance not only to freshers but even to\n\ngeneral public especially girls.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_63\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_64\">15.   Ragging is a form of systematic and sustained physical, mental and\n\nsexual abuse of fresh students at the college/university/any other\n\neducational institution at the hands of senior students of the same institution\n\nand sometimes even by outsiders. Although some form of ragging is present\n\nin every educational institution but serious abuses of human rights take\n\nplace generally in medical and engineering colleges and Armed Forces. The\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">                                      16</span>\n\fform and effect of ragging differ from institution to institution. It creates a\n\nsense of fear in the minds of first year students and they become\n\napprehensive of unforeseen incidents which later comes true and culminates\n\nin actual form of action.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_65\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_66\">16.   Ragging is \"display of noisy, disorderly conduct and great high spirits\n\nconsidered by perpetrators (raggers) as excellent fun and by many outsiders\n\nas a bloody nuisance\".\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_67\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_68\">17.   Another meaning of ragging is \"to question vigorously and jocularly,\n\nhorseplay or assail roughly and noisily\".\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_69\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_70\">18.   Yet another definition of ragging refers to popular Spanish game of\n\n\"Bull-Fight\", wherein Bull is shown red 'rag' and a person shouts which\n\ninfuriates the Bull in fighting.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_71\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_72\">19.   As noted above \"Ragging\" means display of noisy, disorderly conduct\n\nor doing any act which causes or is likely to cause physical or psychological\n\nharm or raise apprehension or fear or shame or embarrassment to a student\n\nin any educational institution and includes,\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">                                     17</span>\n\f      ( a ) teasing, abusing of, playing practical jokes on, or causing hurt to,\n\n          such students; or\n\n</p><p id=\"p_73\">      (b) asking the student to do any act or perform something which such\n\n          student will not, in the ordinary course, willingly do.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_74\">20.     \"Ragging\" means doing an act which causes or is likely to cause\n\ninsult or annoyance or fear or apprehension or threat or intimidation or\n\noutraging of modesty or injury to a student.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_75\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_76\">21.     \"Ragging\" means causing, inducing, compelling or forcing a student,\n\nwhether by way of a practical joke or otherwise, to do any act which\n\ndetracts from human dignity or violates his person or exposes him to\n\nridicule or to forbear from doing any lawful act, by intimidating, wrongfully\n\nrestraining, wrongfully confining, or injuring him or by using criminal force\n\nto him or by holding out to him any threat of such intimidation, wrongful\n\nrestraint, wrongful confinement, injury or the use of criminal force.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">                                        18</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_77\">\f22.   The word \"ragging\" colloquially means to tease or play practical\n\njokes on someone, specially on students who are the fresh entrants in the\n\nschools, colleges, Universities or any other educational institutions. In the\n\nbeginning, it was a way of introduction of the first year students in the\n\ninstitutions which gradually has become not only serious problem but also a\n\nsocial stigma. While in the age of a child in cradle, it was a harmless\n\npractice by senior students over their juniors. Regarding the origin or\n\ninitiative steps of the ragging, it can be traced back to the Seventh or Eighth\n\nCentury A.D.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_78\">23.   In 1828-1845, in United States' Colleges and Universities Campus,\n\nseveral student-organizations called 'fraternities' popped up. Freshers to\n\nthese fraternities were known as pledges. In its rudimentary form, it as\n\ncalled 'hazing' which was merely ritual to test the courage of the pledge.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_79\">24.   In ancient Greece, freshers to the sporting communities were\n\nsubjected to humiliation and teasing to inculcate team spirit. After the\n\npassage of time this type of activities were adopted by Armed Forces in\n\nwhich new entrants have to pass out by obeying the seniors in off-duty time.\n\nAs has been said above, in the age of child in cradle, the ragging was a\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">                                     19</span>\n\fharmless practice rather permissible in the society but it had taken shape of\n\nbrutality, humiliation and harassment after the First World War. In fact the\n\ntechnique, style or forms which the soldiers participating in the War had\n\nlearnt and faced in army atmosphere, were brought by them, when they re-\n\nentered in the colleges after returning from the War. Actually these forms\n\nwere devised to highlight the importance of the team. Gradually these\n\ntechniques and forms passed on those persons who did not know the real\n\nmeaning of the technical word 'hazing' or 'ragging'. Now the ragging has\n\nacquired a new heinous meaning which indicates any disorderly conduct\n\nwhether by words spoken or written or by an act which has the effect of\n\nteasing, treating or handling with rudeness any other student, indulging in\n\nrowdy or undisciplined activities which causes or is likely to cause\n\nannoyance, hardship or psychological harm or to raise fear or apprehension\n\nthereof in a fresher or a junior student or asking the student to do any act or\n\nperform something which such student will not do in the ordinary course\n\nand which has the effect of causing or generating a sense of shame or\n\nembarrassment so as to adversely affect the physique or psyche of a fresher\n\nor a junior student.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_80\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_81\">25.   A rare and strange case of ragging is as follows -Pyotr Ilyich\n\nTchaikousky was a renowned composer of Russia. It was reported in 1893\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">                                     20</span>\n\fthat he died due to cholera and cholera was caused due to drinking of\n\ncontaminated water. This was a blatant lie. However, this lie prevailed for\n\nabout a century. The truth was revealed by, Alexandra Orlova, the\n\nbiographer of the composer and that too when the composer died and the\n\nbiographer migrated to America. The biographer revealed that the Russian\n\ncomposer was a homosexual during his education period and this fact\n\nbecame known to college authorities and they decided to punish the\n\ncomposer and was likely to be expelled. The news of proposed punishment\n\nleaked to his old classmates and they thought that if the composer is\n\npunished it will bring a bad name to the institution. Therefore, the composer\n\nwas summoned before eight former classmates in the \"Court of Honour\" and\n\nwas asked to end his own life to \"preserve the good name of the school\".\n\nThe composer ended his life by consuming poison brought by one of the\n\nJudges and story of death by cholera was concocted.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_82\">26.   After consideration of the reports, we direct that the Government in\n\nthe States and the Union Territories and the University shall act in terms of\n\nthe guidelines formulated by the Constituted Committee. The MCI, BCI in\n\nconsultation with UGC shall frame the requisite regulations which shall be\n\nbinding on the institutions. They shall be indicated to the students at the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">                                    21</span>\n\ftime of admission by appropriate provision in the prospectus issued for\n\nadmission. The consequences which flow from not observing the guidelines\n\nshall also be indicated. Inquiries which are pending shall be completed and\n\nreport shall be submitted before this Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_83\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_84\">27.   A question raised was regarding giving opportunity to the offender\n\nbefore taking actions like expulsion etc. Delay in taking action in many\n\ncases would frustrate the need for taking urgent action. In such cases if the\n\nauthorities are prima facie satisfied about the errant act of any student, they\n\ncan in appropriate cases pending final decision, suspend the student from\n\nthe institution and the hostel if any and give opportunity to him to have his\n\nsay. Immediately, the police shall be informed and criminal law set into\n\nmotion. If it comes to the notice of the university or controlling body that\n\nany educational institution is trying to shield the errant students, they shall\n\nbe free to reduce the grants in aid and in serious cases deny grants in aids.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_85\">28.   The matter shall be listed in the month of March, 2009.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_86\">                                                                                      ...\n</p><p id=\"p_87\">                                 .................................................J\n                                          (DR. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_21\">                                       22</span>\n\f                     ......................................................J\n                     (DR. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 11, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_22\">                    23</span>\n\f</p>","tid":22178779,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":301513,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=20514","title":"Vishwa Jagriti Mission Through ... vs Central Govt, Through Cabinet ... on 4 May, 2001"},{"tid":40503,"url":null,"title":"Panineeya Law College, ... vs The Secretary To Government, ... on 29 September, 1992"}]}, {"numcites":2,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"slp","formInput":"slp"},{"value":"office memorandum","formInput":"office%20memorandum"},{"value":"transport department","formInput":"transport%20department"},{"value":"casual employees","formInput":"casual%20employees"},{"value":"viva voce","formInput":"viva%20voce"},{"value":"lda","formInput":"lda"},{"value":"viva","formInput":"viva"},{"value":"aftab alam","formInput":"aftab%20alam"},{"value":"work charge","formInput":"work%20charge"},{"value":"low what","formInput":"low%20what"}],"firstname":"a","title":"Jyotish Kaiborta & Ors vs State Of Assam & Ors on 25 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=34126","lastname":"alam","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-25","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Jyotish Kaiborta &amp; Ors vs State Of Assam &amp; Ors on 25 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: A Alam</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Tarun Chatterjee, Aftab Alam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                   IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                        CIVIL APPEAL NO.1252 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P(C) No.12129 of 2006)\n\n\nSri Jyotish Kaiborta &amp; Ors.                           ...... Appellants\n\n\n                                       Versus\n\n\nThe State of Assam &amp; Ors.                       ...... Respondents\n\n(With I.A.No.1 of 2007- for transposition of name of applicant)\n\n                                        WITH\n                        CIVIL APPEAL NO.1253 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P(C) No.17979 of 2006)\n\nSri Dip Borah &amp; Anr.                                              ...... Appellants\n\n\n                                       Versus\n\n\nState of Assam &amp; Ors.                                     ...... Respondents\n\n\n                                        AND\n                        CIVIL APPEAL NO.1254 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P(C) No.12766 of 2006)\n\nSri Dhaneswar Deka &amp; Anr.                             ...... Appellants\n\n\n                                       Versus\n\nState of Assam &amp; Ors.                                     ...... Respondents\n\n\n                                  JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">AFTAB ALAM,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.        I.A. No.1 of 2007 is allowed and Sanjib Das who was arrayed in SLP (C)\n\nNo.12129/2006 as one of the respondents is permitted to be transposed as a petitioner.\n\fConsequently, the number of petitioners in that case becomes eight. Apart from the\n\neight petitioners in SLP(C) No.12129/2006 there are two each in SLP(C) No. 12766 of\n\n2006 and SLP (C) No.17979 of 2006 and two more in I.A. No.5/2009 filed in SLP (C)\n\nNo. 17979/2006.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">2.         Leave granted in all the SLPs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">3.         The three appeals are directed against the judgment and order dated May\n\n17, 2006 passed by a full bench of the Guwahati High Court disposing of a large\n\ngroup of writ petitions. The appellants, however, are aggrieved by the decision only\n\nin so far as it found and held that the selections made for filling up the vacancies in\n\nthe posts of Lower Division Assistant (LDA) were bad and the select list, dated June\n\n24, 2003 was illegal and consequently set it aside.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">4.         The controversy relates to appointments to the vacant posts of Lower\n\nDivision Assistants in the Transport Department, Government of Assam for which\n\nthe concerned authorities, following a selection process, prepared the select list dated\n\nJune 24, 2003. The eight appellants in Civil Appeal arising from SLP(C) No.12129/\n\n2006 were among the 12 selected candidates in the select list that was set aside by the\n\nHigh Court. They are thus directly hit by the High Court judgment. The other six\n\nappellants in the other two Civil Appeals and I.A. No.5 of 2009 admittedly did not\n\nfigure in the select list dated June 24, 2003. According to them, they were in some\n\nearlier list dated November 20, 2001 on the basis of which the select list of June 24,\n\n2003 was finally drawn up. Their case is thus materially different from the case of the\n\neight appellants in Civil Appeal arising from SLP(C) No.12129 /2006.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">5.           For filling up the vacancies in the posts of LDA in the Transport\n\nDepartment, Govt. of Assam, the selection process commenced in October, 1998. As is\n\nnot uncommon these days, even before it was complete the selection process had to go\n\nthrough obstacles and face challenges in the Court. But having regard to the limited\n\nscope of these appeals it is not necessary to go into those details. Suffice it to note that\n\fon the basis of a written test held on November 14, 1999 and viva voce held on\n\nDecember 18, 2000 a select list was eventually prepared and in pursuance of the\n\ndirection of the Guwahati High Court dated October 10, 2001 in W.P.(C) No. 4431 of\n\n2001 it came to be finally published on June 24, 2003. It is not in dispute that the\n\neight appellants in Civil Appeal arising from SLP(C) No.12129/ 2006 were among the\n\n12 selected candidates in that list.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">6.          After the select list was published on June 24, 2003 appellants 1 &amp; 2 (along\n\nwith some others) filed W.P. (C) No.6139 of 2003 before the Guwahati High Court\n\nseeking direction for appointment on the basis of the select list. In that case the High\n\nCourt passed an interim order on August 8, 2003 directing that any existing vacancies\n\nshould be filled up from the select list and prohibiting any ad hoc appointments from\n\noutside that list. A similar order was passed by the High Court on March 5, 2004 in\n\nW.P. (C) No. 8815 of 2004 filed by one Inamul Hoque (who was at serial No.7 in that\n\nselect list). Earlier to that a writ petition being W.P. (C) No.66222 of 2003 was filed,\n\nthe petitioner's in which challenged the select list dated June 24, 2003 published by\n\nthe Joint Commissioner Transport, Government of Assam and sought direction for\n\ntheir appointment on the basis of some purported select list dated February 21, 2006.\n\nThis writ petition too was one of the batch of cases disposed of by the full bench\n\njudgment against which the present appeals are preferred. The High Court found\n\nand held that there was no such select list as claimed by the petitioners of that case\n\nand that part of the judgment is not under appeal before us. In yet another\n\nproceeding, in Contempt Case No. 314 of 2003 the Guwahati High Court gave\n\ndirections to the concerned authorities in the government to complete the process of\n\nappointment within six weeks in accordance with law.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">7.          The aforementioned were some of the matters relating to the select list\n\ndated June 24, 2003 and the claim of the selected candidates for appointment based\n\non that list.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">\f8.          As against that there was a counter claim for regularization as LDAs by\n\nsome casual employees working in the department. A writ petition being W.P. (C) No.\n\n1154 of 2004 came to be filed before the High Court on March 5, 2004 by some casual\n\nemployees seeking stay on the appointments from the select list and on the same day\n\n(March 5, 2004) the High Court directed the concerned authorities not to issue any\n\nappointment orders for the post of LDAs till the next date (March 11, 2004) fixed in\n\nthe case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">9.          Eventually all the writ petitions raising claims for appointment on\n\ndifferent grounds as LDA in the transport department came to be grouped together\n\nand in view of the conflicting orders passed in different writ petitions the entire\n\ngroup came to be heard by a full bench of the Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">10.         The full bench by a long and well considered judgment totally rejected the\n\nclaim of regularization raised by the casual employees but at the same time it found\n\nand held that the selection process was not fair and proper and consequently set aside\n\nthe select list of June 24, 2003. In paragraph 23 of the judgment the Court\n\nsummarized its decisions as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">            \"Our answers to the questions referred and also to the questions\n            incidentally arising are self-contained in the various paragraphs\n            of the present order. However, to dispel all doubts and avoid any\n            possible confusion we deem it appropriate to reiterate our\n            conclusions to follows:\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">       (1) The Office Memorandum dated 20.4.1995 does not reflect a Valid\n           policy decision of the State for regularization of Muster Roll/Work\n           Charge employees.</blockquote><p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">            No Muster Roll/Work Charge employee is entitled in law to seek\n            and claim regularization in terms of the aforesaid Office\n            Memorandum dated 20.4.1995,\n\n       (2) However, as a large number of regularisations of different\n           categories of employees have already been effected in terms of the\n           Office Memorandum dated 20.4.1995, considering the human\n           factor involved, the Court does not consider it necessary to pass\n           orders setting aside any of the said regularizations. However, there\n\f           will be no further regularization in terms of the aforesaid Office\n           Memorandum, dated 20.4.1995, and/or such other judicial order(s)\n           for regularization, passed, in this regard, but has not yet been\n           implemented.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">       (3) The Office Memorandum dated 20.4.1995 does not cover any\n           category of employees other than Muster Roll and Work Charge\n           employees. No policy decision has been taken by the State with\n           regard     to   regularization     of   different    categories   of\n           casual/contingent/adhoc employees working in the different\n           departments of the State Government. Such employees are,\n           therefore, not entitled to claim any regularization either under the\n           Office Memorandum dated 20.4.1995 or any other Office\n           Memorandum in force.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n       (4) Casual employees of the Transport department in Grade III posts\n           are not entitled to regularization in terms of the Office\n           Memorandum dated 20.4.1995 or any other Office Memorandum\n           in force.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">       (5) The selections held for filling up the vacant posts of L. D.\n           Assistants in the Transport department including the select list\n           dated 24.6.2003 is found to be illegal and therefore set aside.\n\n       (6) The Court expresses no opinion with regard to the validity of the\n           Cabinet decision dated 22.7.20005 or its implementation and\n           execution. The matter will be considered, if required, at the\n           appropriate time and stage.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">           All the writ petitioners shall stand disposed of as being answered\n           in terms our conclusions recorded above.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">11.        As noted above the appellants are aggrieved by the finding at serial No.5\n\nin regard to the select list and the direction to set it aside.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">12.        Mr. P.K. Goswami learned Senior Counsel appearing for the appellants in\n\nCivil Appeal arising from SLP(C) No.12129/2006 submitted that the manner in which\n\nthe High Court proceeded to examine the validity of the selection process and the\n\nreason assigned by it for holding the select list to be bad and invalid were quite\n\nunsustainable in law. Learned Counsel submitted that though the pleadings in the\n\nwrit petition challenging the select list were found by the High Court as scanty yet it\n\nproceeded to consider the select list by examining the official records summoned by it.\n\fMr. Goswami submitted that the only reason assigned for holding the select list to be\n\nbad was contained in paragraph 27 of the judgment which is as follows:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">           \"The unselected candidates have also raised a question with\n           regard to the validity of the selection process. Through the writ\n           petitions filed in this regard do not contain any elaborate\n           pleadings, as the records in original had been called for and\n           placed before the Court and the same has been duly perused, we\n           are of the view that it will only be correct for the Court to record\n           its views in the matter on the basis of the original records made\n           available for scrutiny of the Court instated of non-suiting the\n           petitioners on the ground of the scanty pleadings contained in the\n           writ petitions.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_23\">13.        Having examined the records the High Court recorded its reason for\n\nstriking down the select list as follows:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">           \"In this regard we have considered the marks awarded to the\n           candidates who had undergone the selection and on such\n           consideration we find that each of the selected candidates has\n           been given very high marks in the interview segment and it is only\n           on account of such high marks in the interview that the said\n           candidates have been selected. While it is correct that the selected\n           candidates have also secured equally high marks in the written test\n           we have also noticed that other candidates who had secured\n           equally high and even higher marks in the written test in that the\n           selected candidates have fared very poorly in the interview. The\n           scrutiny of the marks awarded to the successful and unsuccessful\n           candidates reveal a distinct pattern i.e. those who have been\n           selected have secured very high marks in the interview whereas\n           those unselected have secured very low marks in the interview\n           held. Such a uniform pattern, in our considered view, is unnatural\n           and in spite of our best efforts we have not been able to persuade\n           ourselves to accept the final result of the selection. We, therefore,\n           set aside the select list dated 24.6.2003 and direct the posts in\n           question to be readvertised. ..........\".\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_24\">14.        We are unable to appreciate or even follow the reason assigned by the\n\nHigh Court for condemning the select list. In case, in viva voce very high marks were\n\ngiven to candidates who secured low or very low marks in the written test that might\n\nbe a ground for suspicion. But if the candidates securing high marks in the written\n\ntest were able to secure equally high marks in viva voce we are unable to find any\n\nanomaly. After all there has to be some difference between the selected and the\n\funselected candidates. Unfortunately the High Court has not made clear the `distinct\n\npattern' it was able to discern from a scrutiny of the marks awarded to the\n\ncandidates. The selection records are not before us and we do not have the benefit of\n\nits perusal but we are clearly of the view that the approach of the High Court was\n\nquite contrary to law laid down by this Court. <a href=\"/doc/51922/\" id=\"a_1\">In Sadananda Halo and Others vs.\n\nMomtaz Ali Sheikh and Other</a>, 2008 (4) SCC 619 this Court, in Paragraph 49 of the\n\njudgment, observed as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">          \"49. Learned Single Judge in his judgment has observed that as\n          per the report of the amicus curiae the selected candidates got\n          higher marks in viva voce ranging between 30 and 41 marks. In\n          our opinion this has hardly any effect and merely because the\n          selected candidates got the higher marks ranging between 30 to 41\n          marks that by itself could be no reason to reject the selection. We\n          have extensively referred to the comments made by the learned\n          Single Judge in the earlier part of the judgment where the learned\n          Judge has in fact recorded his satisfaction for the printed charts\n          and more particularly about their authenticity. The learned Judge\n          has also expressed his satisfaction with the procedure adopted.\n          There is hardly any reason given by the learned Single Judge\n          excepting that the benchmark of 250 candidates had already been\n          crossed.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_26\">15.       Paragraphs 58 and 65 of the judgment are also relevant for the present\n\nand are reproduced below:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">          \"58. It is settled law that in such writ petitions a roving inquiry on\n          the factual aspect is not permissible. The High Court not only\n          engaged itself into a non-permitted fact-finding exercise but also\n          went on to rely on the findings of the amicus curiae, or as the case\n          may be, the scrutiny team, which in our opinion was\n          inappropriate. While testing the fairness of the selection process\n          wherein thousands of candidates were involved, the High Court\n          should have been slow in relying upon such microscopic findings.\n          It was not for the High Court to place itself into a position of a\n          fact-finding commission, that too, more particularly at the\n          instance of those petitioners who were unsuccessful candidates.</blockquote><p id=\"p_27\">\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">          The High Court should, therefore, have restricted itself for the\n          Selection Committee and also in the process assumed the role of\n          the respondents. Unfortunately, the High Court took it upon itself\n          the task of substituting itself for the Selection Committee and also\n          in the process assumed the role of an appellate tribunal which\n          was, in our opinion, not proper. Thus, the High Court converted\n          this writ petition into a public interest litigation without any\n\f           justification.\"\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">           \"65. We also do not approve of the approach adopted by the\n           learned Single Judge of the High Court as going all the way into\n           the facts and the microscopic details not via the pleadings of the\n           parties but on the basis of an unnecessary investigation. We also\n           disapprove of the logic of relying on the findings arrived at only\n           on the basis of sample survey. Such selection of large number of\n           candidates could not have been set aside on the basis of same\n           survey. NO evidence was available before us as to the proportion\n           of this so called \"sample survey\"\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_29\">16.        To the same effect are two earlier decisions of the Court in Madan Lal and\n\nOthers. vs. State of J &amp; K and Others, 1995 (3) SCC 486 Paragraphs 10 and 17 and in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/634160/\" id=\"a_2\">Ashok Kumar Yadav vs. State of Haryana</a> 1985 (4) SCC 417 Para.21.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">17.        In view of the discussion made above we are unable to sustain the decision\n\nof the High Court in so far as it held the select list dated June 24, 2003 as invalid.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">18.        We are informed that following the direction of the High Court a fresh\n\nselection process has been initiated to fill up the vacancies of LDAs in the Transport\n\nDepartment. But that may not affect the relief claimed by the appellants in Civil\n\nAppeal arising from SLP(C) No.12129/2006. On January 10, 2008 this Court directed\n\nthat 12 posts of LDA should be kept vacant until further orders. Civil Appeal arising\n\nfrom SLP(C) No.12129/2006 is accordingly allowed and the concerned authorities are\n\ndirected to fill up the 12 vacancies of LDAs in the Transport Department from the\n\nselect list dated June 24, 2003 strictly in order of merit ( six from the selected\n\ncandidates and six from the waiting list ). In case any of the candidates from the\n\nselect list dated June 24, 2006 does not turn up in response to the offer the vacancy\n\nwould be filled up from the fresh selection taken up as per the High Court direction.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">19.        The claim of the other six appellants is not based on the select list dated\n\fJune 24, 2003. Counsel appearing on their behalf referred to a list of November 20,\n\n2001 containing the names of 42 candidates. The names of the six appellants are at\n\nserial Nos. 20, 24, 26, 31, 34, and 39. The last two candidates are said to belong to\n\nOBC category. According to the six appellants, the select list dated June 24, 2003 was\n\ndrawn up on the basis of the earlier list of 2001 in which their names also figured. It\n\nwas submitted on their behalf that there are sufficient vacancies against which they\n\ntoo could be accommodated. We are unable to see how the six appellants can be\n\ngranted any relief. In the first place the counsel appearing for the State of Assam\n\ndenied the existence of any select list dated November 20, 2001. Secondly on their own\n\nshowing the appellants are much below even in that list and no direction for their\n\nappointment can be given in disregard of the candidates above them even in that list.\n\nThe claim of these six appellants thus has no merit or substance. The two appeals\n\narising from SLP(C) No.12766 of 2006 and SLP (C) No.17979 of 2006 and I.A. No.\n\n5/2009 (filed in SLP (C) No.17979/2006) are accordingly dismissed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">                                                                        ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">                                               [Tarun Chatterjee]\n\n\n\n                                                                        ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">                                               [Aftab Alam]\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 25, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":126854026,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":634160,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=9262","title":"Ashok Kumar Yadav And Ors. Sirpurkar, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                                   REPORTABLE\n           IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                      CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                                CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 502           OF 2002\n\n\n             STATE OF PUNJAB                         .. APPELLANT\n\n                       vs.\n\n             GINDER SINGH                            .. RESPONDENT\n\n\n                                                     JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">   Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">          The State of Punjab is in appeal against the judgment of the Punjab and\n\nHaryana High Court directing acquittal of the respondent who was convicted for\n\nalleged commission of offence punishable under Sec. 302 and Sec. 201<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_1\"> of the Indian\n\nPenal Code</a>, 1860 (in short `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>').\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">          The other accused Manjit Kaur was convicted for offences relatable to\n\nSec.302 read with Sec.34 <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">IPC</a> and 201 <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_4\">IPC</a>.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">          Learned Sessions Judge, Bathinda, directed acquittal of Balbir Singh and\n\nAngrez Singh. The State questioned their acquittal in Criminal Appeal No. 203-DBA\n\nof 1996 which was dismissed by the High Court. The two convicted accused persons\n\nalso filed Crl. Appeal No.308-DB of 1995 before the High Court.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                         -2-</span>\n\f          While issuing notice on 25/1/2002 this Court had dismissed the petition qua\n\nManjit Kaur, Balbir Singh and Angrez Singh and restricted the notice so far as the\n\npresent respondent Ginder Singh is concerned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">          The background facts as projected by the prosecution is as follows:\n\n\n\n          First Information Report with regard to murder of Bant Singh (hereinafter\n\nreferred to as `deceased') was lodged by his brother Maghar Singh on 21.5.1994 at 5.10\n\na.m., which was recorded by S.I. Piara Singh P.W.-5. Maghar Singh in his statement\n\nmade before S.I. Piara Singh stated that he was resident of village Mansa Khurd.\n\nThey were seven brothers eldest being Bant Singh who was residing at village Bhagi\n\nBander for the last 3 years. First marriage was solemnized with Jangir Kaur and\n\nsecond marriage (kareva) was performed with accused Manjit Kaur.         His first wife\n\nJangir Kaur gave birth to two sons and one daughter. Out of them,          eldest was\n\nAmarjit Kaur, whereas younger to her was Balbir Singh and youngest to all was\n\nJaswinder Singh. Amarjit Kaur was married with Nidhan Singh at\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                          -3-</span>\n\n\n\nBathinda and Jaswinder Singh was also doing labour work at Bathinda. Manjit Kaur\n\ngave birth to Virpal Kaur and accused Ginder Singh. Virpal Kaur was married with\n\nAngrez Singh. His brother Bant Singh did not have cordial relations with his younger\n\fson Ginder Singh. For this reason Ginder Singh was residing at Bathinda. On the day\n\nof Baisakhi his brother Bant Singh had given beatings to his wife Manjit Kaur and on\n\naccount thereof, there was a dispute in the house. A day before lodging the FIR he\n\nalongwith Makhan Singh Ex-Sarpanch had come to village Bhagi Bander at about 4\n\nP.M. in order to settle the dispute where the son-in-law of Bant Singh, namely Angrez\n\nSingh and Ginder Singh and Balbir Singh his nephews, his borther's wives Manjit\n\nKaur and Jangir Kaur were present in the house. Dut to old age, the eye sight of\n\nJangir Kaur had become weak. His brother Bant Singh came to the house at about 8\n\np.m. and inquired about his welfare. At that time an electric light in the courtyard was\n\non. They started talking about the settlement of the dispute. It was about 9.30 p.m.\n\nDuring the course of settlement Ginder Singh and Bant Singh exchanged hot words\n\nand his brother Bant Singh stood up and\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                          -4-</span>\n\nstarted going to his room. Ginder Singh picked up a Gandhali lying nearby and gave\n\ntwo blows with the same on the head of Bant Singh which hit his head. Thereafter\n\nAngrez Singh took Bant Singh in his grip and Balbir Singh picked up a soti lying there\n\nand gave soti blow on shin on right leg of Bant Singh. Ginder Singh gave one more\n\nblow with Gandhali to Bant Singh which hit him on the left ear and back side of the\n\near. Balbir Singh gave a soti blow which hit the right side of his head as a result of\n\nwhich his brother Bant Singh fell down. Makhan Singh and he himself raised an\n\falarm, \"Na Maro, Na Maro\" (don't kill, don't kill). When his brother Bant Singh was\n\nlying fallen, Angrez Singh continued twisting his left arm while Ginder Singh\n\ncontinued twisting his left knee. While Bant Singh was lying on the ground, Manjit\n\nKaur and Balbir Singh continued giving blows thrustwise with their respective sotis on\n\nthe left leg and back side of left knee and Manjit Kaur kept on saying loudly that he\n\nshould be taught a lesson for giving beatings to her. As a result thereof his brother\n\nsustained injuries on his left leg. They stepped forward to rescue him but the accused\n\ntried to attack them also. His brother Bant Singh succumbed to his injuries at the spot.\n\nOut\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                          -5-</span>\n\nof fear they ran away outside and informed Jangir Singh Sarpanch about this\n\noccurrence. After taking along Jangir Singh Sarpanch with them, they had come to\n\nlodge the report. The cause of grudge was that about a month back on the day of\n\nBaisakhi, his brother Bant Singh had given beatings to his wife Manjit Kaur and whole\n\nfamily was fed up with him. On account of this grudge, all the accused had connived\n\nwith one another and committed the murder of Bant Singh by inflicting injuries to him.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">          The first information report was lodged on 21/5/94 at 5.10 a.m. while the\n\nalleged offence took place on 20/5/1994 at about 9.30 p.m. The special report reached\n\nthe concerned Magistrate at Bathinda on 21.5.1994 at 7.30 a.m. Two witnesses were\n\npressed into service as eye witnesses. They were P.W. 3 and 4. The trial Court held\n\fthat the presence of these two witnesses at the time of occurrence was not established.\n\nNotwithstanding such conclusion as noted above two persons were convicted.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">             In appeal the stand of the accused persons was that the FIR was delayed;\n\nthe eye witnesses were disbelieved and, therefore, the question of holding the accused\n\npersons guilty does not arise.       The High Court accepted the stand and directed\n\nacquittal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                             -6-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">             In support of the appeal learned counsel for the appellant - State submitted\n\nthat it is a peculiar case where the deceased was allegedly killed by his wife and a son,\n\nand out of two eye witnesses who were there; one was his brother and the other was\n\nhis friend. That being so, there was obviously an attempt to protect the accused\n\npersons.     Learned counsel for the respondent on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment of the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">             Even though it is accepted that there were two eye witnesses; one was the\n\nbrother of the deceased and the other was friend and there was an attempt to protect\n\nthe accused there is no credible evidence to show involvement of the accused persons\n\nin the concerned crime. That being so, their conviction would not be proper. High\n\nCourt has precisely held so. That being the position, we are not inclined to interfere in\n\nthis appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">             Accordingly, the appeal is dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                                       ................ .J.\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                                          (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\f                                                ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">                    (V.S. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                           CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                         CIVIL APPEAL NO.1072 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.10348 of 2008)\n\nP.C. Markanda                                               ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                        Versus\n\nPanjab University &amp; Ors.                         ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                    O R D E R\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">           Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">           Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">           The appellant made an application for enrolment for Degree of Doctor of\nLaws on topic \"Adoption of UNCITRAL Model Law for International Commercial\nArbitrations by Commonwealth Countries - Impact, Emerging Trends and\nInterpretation\". Along with the application he annexed the papers presented by him\nat the National and International Forums and the books authored by him.             His\napplication was considered in the joint meeting of the Academic Committee and\nAdministrative Committee of the Department of Laws, Panjab University, held on 29th\nJuly, 2008, and was rejected. The High Court dismissed the writ petition filed by the\nappellant by observing that he does not have an enforceable right for consideration of\ndegree of Ph.D and the issue raised by him does not call for interference under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_1\">Article\n226</a> of the Constitution.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">           It is not in dispute that in terms of Regulations 1, 2 and 3 of the Panjab\nUniversity Calendar Volume-II, 1995 (for short `the Regulations'), the appellant's\ncase was required to be considered by the Research Degree Committee on\n                                                                                  ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                         -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">being recommended by the Faculty of Law.           It is also not in dispute that the\nappellant's case was not considered by the Faculty of Law for the purpose of being\nrecommended to the Research Degree Committee. The High Court overlooked this\npatent illegality in the rejection of the appellant's application and summarily\ndismissed the writ petition. In our view, the High Court should have considered the\nissue raised by the appellant in the light of the Regulations and decided the same on\nmerits. This having not been done, the decision taken in the joint meeting of the\nAcademic Committee and Administrative Committee as also the order passed by the\nHigh Court cannot be sustained.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           In the result, the appeal is allowed, impugned order rendered by the High\nCourt is set aside and it is directed that the appellant's application for enrolment for\nthe degree of Doctor of Laws shall be considered by the Faculty of Law and,\nthereafter, by the Research Degree Committee. This exercise must be completed\nwithin three months from the date of receipt of copy of this order by the University.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                               [B.N.
