SINGHVI]\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 16, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":958794,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1712542,"url":null,"title":"Article 226 in The Constitution Of India   1949"}]}, {"numcites":2,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"election commission","formInput":"election%20commission"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"suspend","formInput":"suspend"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"election commission of india","formInput":"election%20commission%20of%20india"},{"value":"infrastructure ","formInput":"infrastructure%20"},{"value":"pwd","formInput":"pwd"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Nandi Infrastructure ... vs Election Commission Of India & Anr on 4 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33732","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-04","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Nandi Infrastructure ... vs Election Commission Of India &amp; Anr on 4 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, V.S. Sirpurkar, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                          REPORTABLE\n\n                       IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                         CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                         CIVIL APPEAL NO. 867 OF 2009\n                         (Arising out of SLP(C)No.16717/2008)\n\nNandi Infrastructure Corr.Ent.Ltd. &amp; Ors.                      ...Appellant(s)\n\n                   Versus\n\nElection Commission of India &amp; Anr.                            ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                  JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">           Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">           Challenge in this appeal is to the order dated 8/5/2008 issued by the\n\n  office of the Chief Electoral, Karnataka, purporting to act in terms of the\n\n  directions of the Election Commission of India (in short `the Commission') under\n\n  <a href=\"/doc/950881/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 324</a> of the Constitution of India, 1950 (in short the `Constitution'). The\n\n  effect of the order was that no action was to be taken on the decision of the State\n\n  Government partially modifying the Government decision dated 30/4/2008 and\n\n  also not to take any further policy decision and action on the BMIC project\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        -2-</span>\n\n\n\ntill 28/5/2008, that is the date on or before which the Election process is to be\n\ncompleted. The Commission further directed the State Government to cancel the\n\nGovernment decision. On the basis of this directive the Government of Karnataka\n\nby Government order No. PWD 53 CRM 2007 Bangalore, dated 9.5.2008, passed\n\nthe following order:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">         \"PROCEEDING OF THE GOVERNMENT OF KARNATAKA\n\n         Sub:- Implementation of the Basngalore-Mysore\nInfrastructure Corridor Project (BMICP)\n             under BOOT concept\n\n         Read:- 1. G.O.No. PWD 53 CRM 2007 30.4.2008.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                   2Letter No. DPAR 4356 ELN MCC 2008 dated 8.05.2008\n                   from the office of the Chief Electoral Officer, Karnataka\n                   Bangalore.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">         GOVERNMENT ORDER NO. PWD 53 CRM 2007 BANGALORE\nDATED\n                                      09.05.2008\n\n         Pursuant to the directions of the Election\nCommission of India conveyed in the reference read at (2) above, the Government\nOrder dated 30.4.2008 at (1) above is hereby withdrawn with immediate effect.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">         By Order and in the name of the President of India\n                            (M.Deviprasad)\n                            Under Secretary to Government\n                   Public Works, Ports and IWT Department\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                        -3-</span>\n\f          By order dated 9.7.2008, this Court stayed the direction relating to\n\ncancellation of the decision.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">          The Election Commission of India has filed an affidavit dated 30/9/2008,\n\ninter alia, stating as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                    \"It is submitted that the use of the word `cancel' in paragraph\n          2 of its Order dated 8/5/2008 has been misread by the petitioners as it\n          was only intended to mean that the implementation of decision of\n          Government of Karnataka dated 30/4/2008 be cancelled and suspended\n          during the ongoing electoral process between the 8/5/208 (the date of\n          passing the Order by Election Commission) and the 28/5/2008 (the date\n          on which the election process was to get over.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_13\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">          It is surprising that by jugglery of words the use of the expression\n\n`cancel' in paragraph 2 of the order dated 8/5/2008 has been tried to be justified. If\n\nthat was the intention, the same should have been conveyed to the State\n\nGovernment after the order of cancellation was passed. The expressions \"cancel\"\n\nand \"suspend\" are conceptually different. At the same time there could not have\n\nbeen cancellation and suspension. \"Cancel\" means to destroy the force,\n\neffectiveness or validity of an order, a decision, to bring to nothingness.\n\n\"Suspend\" means to debar temporarily a privilege or make temporarily\n\nineffective. To \"suspend\" is to take a temporary measure while to \"cancel\" has an\n\nelement of permanency.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                         -4-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">          Mr. G.E.Vahanavati, appearing for the State of Karnataka stated that\n\f  the Government Order dated 9/5/2008 passed in line with the directives of the\n\n  Election Commission of India has been recalled and the Government desires to\n\n  implement the decision of the Karnataka High Court as upheld by this Court in\n\n  <a href=\"/doc/348205/\" id=\"a_2\">State of Karnataka &amp; Anr. vs. All India Manufacturers Organization &amp; Ors</a>.\n\n  (2006) 4 SCC 683. In view of this Statement nothing further survives to be done in\n\n  this appeal. In any event after 28/5/2008 the whole position has changed.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">           The appeal is disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">                                   ................ .J.\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">                                                      (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                    ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">                       (V.S.SIRPURKAR)\n\n\n                                         ....................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                       (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 4, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":595337,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":950881,"url":null,"title":"Article 324 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":348205,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=27655","title":"State Of Karnataka & Anr vs All India Manufacturers ... on 20 April, 2006"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"firstname":null,"title":"Krishna Kant Singh @ Baristar ... vs Sasaram Bhabua Central Coop.Bank ... on 10 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=34758","lastname":"....................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-10","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Krishna Kant Singh @ Baristar ... vs Sasaram Bhabua Central Coop.Bank ... on 10 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ....................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: D.K. Jain, R.M. Lodha</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">               IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n    CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n           CIVIL APPEAL No.5097 of 2002\n\nKrishna Kant Singh @ Baristar Singh                          .....Appellant(s)\n\n\n\n                           Versus\n\nSasaram Bhabhua Central Co-operative Bank Ltd. &amp; Ors.        .....Respondent(s)\n\n          ORDER\n</pre><p id=\"p_1\">            This appeal under <a href=\"/doc/271754/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 23</a> of the Consumer Protection Act, 1986 is\n\n   directed against the final order dated 10th July, 2002 passed by the National\n\n   Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (hereinafter referred to as                'the\n\n   Commission') in O.P. No.171 of 1996.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">               By the impugned order the complaint filed by the appellant has been\n\n   dismissed by the Commission on the ground that it was barred by limitation. The\n\n   Commission has noted that the claim made on the Bank was lastly on 16th May,\n\n   1994 and the complaint was filed on 26th August, 1996, which was obviously\n\n   beyond the period of limitation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">               We have heard learned counsel for the parties.       Mr. Shiv Pujan\n\n   Singh, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant has strenuously urged\n\n   that the Commission has erred in not condoning the delay in preferring the\n\n   complaint because there was sufficient cause for the delay. It is pleaded that the\n\n   appellant was arrested in some case on 5th June, 1994; he remained in custody for\n\n   a\n\n                                                                             ..2/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                       :2:</span>\n\n   period of about eight months and was released on bail only on 4th February, 1995\n\f       and therefore, he was prevented by a sufficient cause in not preferring the\n\n       complaint within time.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">                     In the light of the facts found by the Commission, we are not\n\n       persuaded to agree with the learned counsel. It is manifest that the Commission\n\n       was not oblivious of the fact that the appellant was in jail till 4 th February, 1995.\n\n       As a matter of fact, taking note of the factum of arrest of the appellant and his\n\n       release on bail on 4th February, 1995, the Commission has observed that since 19th\n\n       December, 2001 it had been asking the appellant to produce the evidence by\n\n       means of an affidavit to explain the delay in filing of complaint on 26th August,\n\n       1996 after his release on 4th February, 1995. However, no affidavit was filed on\n\n       behalf of the appellant. Under the circumstances, the Commission had no option\n\n       but to dismiss the complaint as barred by limitation.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                     We do not find any infirmity in the impugned order warranting our\n\n       to interference. The appeal is dismissed accordingly.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                                   ....................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                                            [ D.K. JAIN ]\n\n\n                                   ....................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">[ R.M. LODHA ]\n   NEW DELHI,\n   MARCH 26, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":171678443,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":271754,"url":null,"title":"Section 23 in the Consumer Protection Act, 1986"}]}, {"numcites":2,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"court of small causes","formInput":"court%20of%20small%20causes"},{"value":"order of remand","formInput":"order%20of%20remand"},{"value":"eviction order","formInput":"eviction%20order"}],"firstname":null,"title":"D.P.Kesari & Anr vs Board Of Dir.Of Allahabad ... on 6 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33714","lastname":"........................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-06","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">D.P.Kesari &amp; Anr vs Board Of Dir.Of Allahabad ... on 6 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ........................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Tarun Chatterjee, H.L. Dattu</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                1\n\n\n                                 NON\n                                 REPORTABLE\n\n\n            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n             CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n              CIVIL APPEAL NO.767 OF 2009\n           [Arising out of SLP{C] No.48 of 2009]\n\n\nD.P.Kesari &amp; Anr.                           ... Appellants\n\n     VERSUS\n\nThe Board of Director of Allahabad\nAgricultural Institute                      ...Respondent\n\n\n\n                         ORDER\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">1.   Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.   This appeal is directed against the final judgment and\n\n     order dated 23rd of October, 2008 passed by the High\n\n     Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Writ Petition\n\n     No.5158 of 1989. By the impugned final judgment, the\n\n     High Court had allowed the writ petition filed by the\n\n     landlord- respondent No.3 and the suit of the landlord\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                          2</span>\n\n\n     for eviction and for recovery of arrears of rent was\n\n     decreed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">3.   The writ petition arose in the following manner :-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">     A suit was filed by the landlord-respondent before a\n\nlearned Judge of the Small Causes Court at Allahabad for\n\neviction of the appellants and also for arrears of rent, inter\n\nalia, on the ground that the appellant No.1 was a defaulter\n\nin payment of rent in respect of No.39 B, Allahabad\n\nAgricultural Institute, Naini (hereinafter referred to as the\n\n`suit premises') and in view of Section 2(1)(b) read with\n\nSection 3(q) of the U.P. Urban Buildings Regulation of\n\nLetting, Rent and <a href=\"/doc/463150/\" id=\"a_1\">Eviction Act</a>, 1972 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1490821/\" id=\"a_2\">U.P. Act</a>'),\n\nthe appellant No.1 was not entitled to occupy the suit\n\npremises after termination of his employment. The learned\n\nJudge of the Small Causes Court came to a finding that the\n\nprovision of the <a href=\"/doc/1490821/\" id=\"a_3\">U.P. Act</a> were applicable to the suit\n\npremises and further the suit premises was not allotted to\n\nappellant No.1 as a part of contract of his employment and\n\nthat there was no default in payment of rent. It was also\n\nheld by the Small Causes Court that the tenancy was not\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                        3</span>\n\n\nvalidly terminated. Accordingly, the suit was dismissed on\n\nthe aforesaid grounds. Feeling aggrieved, the landlord-\n\nrespondent preferred a revision case before the District\n\nJudge, Allahabad. By an order dated 25th of January, 1989,\n\nthe said revision case was allowed and the matter was\n\nremitted back to the trial court to decide the case afresh\n\nstating that the finding was not recorded on a proper\n\nappraisal of the entire evidence on record and accordingly\n\nthe learned Judge of the Small Causes Court had acted\n\nillegally and with material irregularity in the exercise of his\n\njurisdiction. Against the aforesaid order of remand passed\n\nby the revisional court, the appellants filed a writ petition\n\nchallenging the aforesaid order of remand. Before the High\n\nCourt, it is an admitted position that the order of remand\n\nwas challenged at the instance of the appellants. The High\n\nCourt by the impugned order had set aside the order of the\n\nrevisional court and allowed the eviction petition by passing\n\na final order in the following manner :-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">         \"Accordingly, writ petition is disposed of.\n         Revision filed by landlord respondent No.3 is\n         allowed. Judgment and decree passed by the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                           4</span>\n\n\n         trial court is set aside. Suit of the plaintiff for\n         eviction and for recovery of arrears of rent is\n         decreed.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">4.   It is this order which was challenged by the\n\n     appellants by way of a special leave petition which\n\n     on grant of leave was heard in presence of the\n\n     learned counsel for the parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">5.   In our view, the judgment of the High Court needs\n\n     to be set aside on a very short point. It is an\n\n     admitted position that there was no order of\n\n     eviction either passed by the trial court or by the\n\n     revisional court. In fact the trial court by its final\n\n     order had rejected the application for eviction\n\n     against which revision was moved which set aside\n\n     the said order and directed remand on the ground\n\n     stated in the said order, therefore, the question of\n\n     decreeing or directing the eviction of the appellants\n\n     in the writ petition filed by the tenants could not\n\n     arise at all. It is also an admitted position, that the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                    5</span>\n\n\nrevisional   court   on   the   revisional   application\n\nremanded the matter to the trial court for fresh\n\ndecision. Feeling aggrieved by the said decision of\n\nthe revisional court, the appellants- tenants had\n\nfiled a writ petition. In such a writ petition, it was\n\nnot open to the High Court to direct the eviction of\n\nthe appellants when the landlord-respondent had\n\nnot moved against the order of remand and\n\nsecondly there was no order of eviction passed\n\neither by the trial court or by the revisional court.\n\nIn our view, this is not permissible. Since there was\n\nno order of eviction and when admittedly the\n\ntenants had moved a writ petition against an order\n\nof remand passed by the revisional court, the\n\nquestion of passing a decree or order of eviction on\n\na writ application, which was filed not by the\n\nlandlord but by the tenants, could not arise at all.\n\nThat being the position, we set aside the judgment\n\nof the High Court and the matter is remitted back to\n\nthe High Court for fresh decision on the question\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                6</span>\n\n\n     whether the order of remand passed by the\n\n     revisional court was justified in the facts and\n\n     circumstances of the case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">6.   For the reasons aforesaid the impugned order is set\n\naside. The appeal is allowed to the extent indicated above.\n\nThe High Court is requested to decide the writ petition on\n\nthe question indicated hereinabove at an early date\n\npreferably within four months from the date of supply of a\n\ncopy of this order. No order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                                              ........................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                              [Tarun Chatterjee]\n\n\nNew Delhi;                                  ..........................J.\nFebruary 06, 2009. Dattu</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                          CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                             CIVIL APPEAL NO. 58 OF 2005\n\n\nState of Haryana &amp; Anr.                                       ...Appellant(s)\n\n                    Versus\n\nShiv Lal &amp; Ors.                                               ...Respondent(s)\n\n                                       WITH\n\n                  CIVIL APPEALS NO.132, 97, 113, 145, 272, 116, 125,\n                           62-85, 127-131 &amp; 330 OF 2005\n\n                     CIVIL APPEALS NOS. 631 TO 677 OF 2009\n  (Arising out of S.L.P.(C) Nos.7723/2008, 6209/2007, 2302/2008, 18605/2008, 18606-\n                            18639/2008 &amp; 7066-7074/2008)\n\n                                     ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">         Delay condoned in S.L.P.(C) Nos.18606-639/2008.\n\n         Leave granted in Special Leave Petitions.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">         In this batch of Civil Appeals, the State has filed eleven appeals out of a\n\ntotal of 17 appeals. The remaining appeals have been filed by the claimants for\n\nenhancement of compensation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">         A short question which arises for determination is -      whether belting\n\nmethod is applicable to the acquired lands falling in municipal area abutting the\n\nabadi of Rewari?\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">                                                                  ...2/-\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">\fC.A.No.58/2005 etc...contd...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                           -2-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">           Facts in Civil Appeal No.58/2005 in the case of State of Harayana &amp; Anr.\n\nVs. Shiv Lal &amp; Ors.:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">           The learned Additional Judge had evolved and applied the belting system to\n\nthe lands in question categorising/dividing the said lands into three separate and\n\ndistinct categories. For category 'A', the learned Additional District Judge awarded\n\nthe rate of Rs.8,00,000/- per acre; for category 'B', he awarded the rate of\n\nRs.7,00,000/- per acre and for category 'C', he awarded the rate of Rs.4,00,000/- per\n\nacre. This was challenged by way of First Appeal in which the learned Single Judge\n\nof the High Court reduced the above three categories into two categories and,\n\nconsequently, awarded the rate of Rs.7,04,367/- per acre for category 'A' and\n\nRs.6,00,000/- per acre for category 'B'. Against the decision of the learned Single\n\nJudge of the High Court, the matter was carried in L.P.A. which stood dismissed,\n\nhence, this Civil Appeal by the State.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">           The main contention of the State is that the learned Single Judge had erred\n\nin reducing the number of categories from three to two. We do not find any merit in\n\nthis argument for the following reasons:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">                                                                     ...3/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\nC.A.No.58/2005 etc...contd...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                           -3-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">           Firstly, in the case of Pawan Kumar &amp; Anr. Vs. Land Acquisition Collector\n\n(L.P.A.No.387/2001 decided on 15.5.2006), it has been held by the High Court that\n\fbelting system is not applicable to municipal areas abutting the abadi. In the said\n\njudgment, the Division Bench has held that the land in question falling within the\n\nmunicipal area abutting the abadi had great potential.    As stated above, this decision\n\nhas not been challenged by the State by filing a special leave petition. It has become\n\nfinal.   Consequently, two sets of decrees would result - in one set of cases, the\n\nclaimants would get compensation on the basis of belting system (if the State succeeds\n\nin its Civil Appeal) and in the other set of cases, the claimants would get\n\ncompensation at higher rate on the basis that belting is not applicable. The judgment\n\nand decree passed by the High Court in Pawan Kumar's case has now become final\n\nas the State has not challenged the said judgment.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">           Before us, it was argued that if this Court upholds the applicability of the\n\nbelting system as done by the learned Additional District Judge in the case of State of\n\nHaryana Vs. Shiv Lal, then the law declared by the High Court\n\n                                                                        ..4/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\nC.A.No.58/2005 etc...contd...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                           -4-</span>\n\nin Pawan Kumar's case would need reconsideration. We do not find any merit in this\n\nargument for the simple reason that the judgment and decree passed by the High\n\nCourt in Pawan Kumar's case has become final. Lastly, it may be pointed out that\n\nunder the notification issued under the <a href=\"/doc/7832/\" id=\"a_1\">Land Acquisition Act</a>, in these cases,\n\ncompensation has been unconditionally paid to all the claimants in 2001 and\n\nonwards. In the circumstances, on account of inconsistent decrees coming into the\n\nfield, we do not wish to interfere in the Civil Appeal(s) filed by State of Haryana.\n\f           As regards appeal(s) filed by the claimant(s) for enhancement, we find no\n\nreason to interfere as the High Court has correctly applied the belting system of\n\nvaluation to the facts of the case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">           Accordingly, all the Appeals and cross appeals are dismissed, with no order\n\nas to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">                                      ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">                                                         (S.H. A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, V.S. Sirpurkar, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                          REPORTABLE\n\n                       IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                         CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                         CIVIL APPEAL NO. 867 OF 2009\n                         (Arising out of SLP(C)No.16717/2008)\n\nNandi Infrastructure Corr.Ent.Ltd. &amp; Ors.                      ...Appellant(s)\n\n                   Versus\n\nElection Commission of India &amp; Anr.                            ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                  JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">           Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">           Challenge in this appeal is to the order dated 8/5/2008 issued by the\n\n  office of the Chief Electoral, Karnataka, purporting to act in terms of the\n\n  directions of the Election Commission of India (in short `the Commission') under\n\n  <a href=\"/doc/950881/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 324</a> of the Constitution of India, 1950 (in short the `Constitution'). The\n\n  effect of the order was that no action was to be taken on the decision of the State\n\n  Government partially modifying the Government decision dated 30/4/2008 and\n\n  also not to take any further policy decision and action on the BMIC project\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        -2-</span>\n\n\n\ntill 28/5/2008, that is the date on or before which the Election process is to be\n\ncompleted. The Commission further directed the State Government to cancel the\n\nGovernment decision. On the basis of this directive the Government of Karnataka\n\nby Government order No. PWD 53 CRM 2007 Bangalore, dated 9.5.2008, passed\n\nthe following order:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">         \"PROCEEDING OF THE GOVERNMENT OF KARNATAKA\n\n         Sub:- Implementation of the Basngalore-Mysore\nInfrastructure Corridor Project (BMICP)\n             under BOOT concept\n\n         Read:- 1. G.O.No. PWD 53 CRM 2007 30.4.2008.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                   2Letter No. DPAR 4356 ELN MCC 2008 dated 8.05.2008\n                   from the office of the Chief Electoral Officer, Karnataka\n                   Bangalore.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">         GOVERNMENT ORDER NO. PWD 53 CRM 2007 BANGALORE\nDATED\n                                      09.05.2008\n\n         Pursuant to the directions of the Election\nCommission of India conveyed in the reference read at (2) above, the Government\nOrder dated 30.4.2008 at (1) above is hereby withdrawn with immediate effect.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">         By Order and in the name of the President of India\n                            (M.Deviprasad)\n                            Under Secretary to Government\n                   Public Works, Ports and IWT Department\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                        -3-</span>\n\f          By order dated 9.7.2008, this Court stayed the direction relating to\n\ncancellation of the decision.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">          The Election Commission of India has filed an affidavit dated 30/9/2008,\n\ninter alia, stating as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                    \"It is submitted that the use of the word `cancel' in paragraph\n          2 of its Order dated 8/5/2008 has been misread by the petitioners as it\n          was only intended to mean that the implementation of decision of\n          Government of Karnataka dated 30/4/2008 be cancelled and suspended\n          during the ongoing electoral process between the 8/5/208 (the date of\n          passing the Order by Election Commission) and the 28/5/2008 (the date\n          on which the election process was to get over.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_13\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">          It is surprising that by jugglery of words the use of the expression\n\n`cancel' in paragraph 2 of the order dated 8/5/2008 has been tried to be justified. If\n\nthat was the intention, the same should have been conveyed to the State\n\nGovernment after the order of cancellation was passed. The expressions \"cancel\"\n\nand \"suspend\" are conceptually different. At the same time there could not have\n\nbeen cancellation and suspension. \"Cancel\" means to destroy the force,\n\neffectiveness or validity of an order, a decision, to bring to nothingness.\n\n\"Suspend\" means to debar temporarily a privilege or make temporarily\n\nineffective. To \"suspend\" is to take a temporary measure while to \"cancel\" has an\n\nelement of permanency.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                         -4-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">          Mr. G.E.Vahanavati, appearing for the State of Karnataka stated that\n\f  the Government Order dated 9/5/2008 passed in line with the directives of the\n\n  Election Commission of India has been recalled and the Government desires to\n\n  implement the decision of the Karnataka High Court as upheld by this Court in\n\n  <a href=\"/doc/348205/\" id=\"a_2\">State of Karnataka &amp; Anr. vs. All India Manufacturers Organization &amp; Ors</a>.\n\n  (2006) 4 SCC 683. In view of this Statement nothing further survives to be done in\n\n  this appeal. In any event after 28/5/2008 the whole position has changed.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">           The appeal is disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">                                   ................ .J.\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">                                                      (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                    ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">                       (V.S.SIRPURKAR)\n\n\n                                         ....................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                       (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 4, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":104318729,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":950881,"url":null,"title":"Article 324 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":348205,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=27655","title":"State Of Karnataka & Anr vs All India Manufacturers ... on 20 April, 2006"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"firstname":null,"title":"Salig Ram Sharma vs State Of M.P on 27 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=34754","lastname":"....................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-27","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Salig Ram Sharma vs State Of M.P on 27 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ....................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: D.K. Dattu</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                     CIVIL ORIGINAL JURISDICTION\n\n                            WRIT PETITION (CIVIL) NO.411 OF 2008\n\n\nSANJAY KUMAR                                         .....PETITIONER (S)\n\n\n                     VERSUS\n\n\nUNION OF INDIA &amp; ORS.                                       ....RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n\n                                    O R D E R\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">       Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">       This petition has been filed under <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 32</a> of the Constitution.\n\nLearned counsel for the petitioner seeks permission to withdraw this petition. Permission as prayed\n\nfor is granted. The Writ Petition is accordingly dismissed as withdrawn.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">       However, it will be open to the petitioner to move the High Court under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_2\">Article 226</a> in\n\nrespect of his grievances raised before this Court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">       The questions of law raised by the petitioner in this petition can also be raised before the\n\nHigh Court which can be contested by the State Forest Corporation.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">                                      .............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">                                ( TARUN CHATTERJEE )\n\n\n\n\n                                       .............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                ( H.L.DATTU )\n\n\nNEW DELHI;\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">FEBRUARY 20, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1769582,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":981147,"url":null,"title":"Article 32 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":1712542,"url":null,"title":"Article 226 in The Constitution Of India   1949"}]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"firstname":null,"title":"State Of Orissa & Ors vs Khirod Kumar Nayak on 23 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33950","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-23","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">State Of Orissa &amp; Ors vs Khirod Kumar Nayak on 23 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                        REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                  CIVIL APPEAL NO.              OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 6405 of 2004)\n\n\nState of Orissa and Ors.                               ..Appellants\n\n                                        Versus\n\nKhirod Kumar Nayak                                     ..Respondent\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Delay condoned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Challenge in this appeal is to the order of a Division Bench of the\n\nOrissa High Court. Factual background can be adumbrated concisely as\n\nfollows:\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f4.    The responded no.1 filed a writ application being OJC No.6857 of\n\n1996 before the Orissa High Court claiming that he was appointed as\n\n\"fourth peon\" by the management of the concerned institution, which is an\n\n\"aided educational institution\" as defined under the Orissa Education Act,\n\n1969 (in short the `Act') and Orissa Education (Recruitment and Conditions\n\nof Service of Teachers and Members of the Staff of Aided Educational\n\nInstitutions) Rules, 1974 (in short `Recruitment Rules'). It is not in dispute\n\nthat if an institution is an aided educational institution, same is governed by\n\nthe Act and rules framed thereunder. The Recruitment Rules are framed\n\nunder the Act. As the functionaries of the State did not approve the\n\nappointment holding the same to be beyond the prescribed yardstick, writ\n\napplications were filed for direction to the concerned authorities to accord\n\napproval to the appointment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5.    The High Court by the impugned judgment in writ application came\n\nto hold that the functionaries of the State were not justified in refusing to\n\naccord approval. Stand of the State Government was that circular dated\n\n8.7.1981 contained yardstick for fixation of standard staff for the Non-\n\nGovernment Secondary Schools in supersession of earlier circulars. Under\n\nthe \"category of staff\" the number of peons who can be appointed was\n\nclearly spelt out. Only if the roll strength of the institution exceeded a\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\fparticular number, one post of \"Daftry\" was admissible. According to the\n\nState Government the post of \"Daftry\" is a promotional post and, therefore,\n\nthe concept of a \"fourth peon\" as sought to be canvassed by the writ\n\npetitioners is without any legal foundation. The position was further\n\nclarified by Circular dated 27.3.1992. The High Court on consideration of\n\nthe rival stands came to equate the \"fourth peon\" with \"Daftry\" and held the\n\nclaim of the writ petitioner warranted acceptance.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">6.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the State of Orissa\n\nsubmitted that the High Court missed to consider several vital aspects.\n\nFirstly, there is no prescription of a \"fourth peon\" in the yardstick\n\nprescribed. The post of \"Daftry\" is a promotional post and it carries higher\n\nscale of pay. That being the position, the last entrant cannot claim the post\n\nof the \"Daftry\".\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">7.    Per contra, learned counsel for the writ petitioner submitted that the\n\nHigh Court has considered the circulars and come to the right conclusion\n\nthat the claim for appointment as the \"fourth peon\" is legally enforceable.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8.    At this juncture it is to be noted that at different points of time\n\nyardsticks were formulated. Government of Orissa, Education &amp; Y.S.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fDepartment, issued Circular No. 28365-EYS dated 8.7.1981 fixing standard\n\nstaff for the non-government secondary schools. So far as peons are\n\nconcerned, the relevant portions of the circular read as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">      \"Category of staff           3 class     5class               7 class\n      ..............\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">      9.Peons (I) Office Peon 1                1            1</span>\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">      (ii) Office Attendant        1           1            1</span>\n\n      (iii) Night watcher cum\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">             sweeper          1                1            1</span>\n\n\n\n      Notes\n\n      ................\n</pre><p id=\"p_15\">      C)(ii) Where the roll strength of the school exceeds 100 one post of\n      Daftry is admissible.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">      .......\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">9.    Subsequently by another circular No.155000-XVIIEP-50/91-E, dated\n\n27th March, 1992 the position was further clarified as under:-\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                 \"I am directed to say that the question of fixation of\n                 revised yardstick for appointment of class IV employees\n                 in Non-government Secondary Schools was under\n                 consideration of Government for some time past. After\n                 careful consideration Government have been pleased to\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                       4</span>\n\f            decide that the yardstick for class IV employees of Non-\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">            Government Secondary Schools shall be as follows:\n</blockquote>\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">            Category of staff            3 class    5class              7</span>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">            class\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">            (i) Office Peon              1          1            1</span>\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">            (ii)Science Attendant        1          1            1</span>\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">            (iii)Night Watcher cum 1                1            1</span>\n                   Sweeper\n\n\n\n             Where the roll strength of 10 Class High School is 500\n      (five hundred) or more, one post of Daftry admissible.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">           For the schools running shift system for shortage of\n      accommodation one additional post of peon is admissible.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">            The yardstick will come into force with effect from the\n      Ist January 1992 and Government order referred to above\n      stands modified to the extent indicated above.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">10.   A comparison of the two circulars shows that under 1981 Circular the\n\nrequisite roll strength was 100, which was changed to 500 subsequently in\n\nthe 1992 Circular.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_19\">11.   It is fairly accepted by learned counsel for the writ petitioner that the\n\nexpression used in the two circulars is \"Daftry\" and not \"fourth peon\". The\n\nHigh Court seems to have fallen in error by proceeding on the basis as if the\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                                     5</span>\n\fcirculars referred to \"fourth peon\". This is clear from the reading of the\n\nvarious judgments impugned in this appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">12.   It is to be noted that post of \"Daftry\" carries higher scale of pay and is\n\na promotional post for class IV employees. That being the position, the High\n\nCourt was not justified in directing approval of the writ petitioner's services\n\nas \"fourth peon\". But one significant aspect cannot be lost sight of. If a\n\nschool was entitled to have a \"Daftry\", certainly the appointment was to be\n\nmade by promoting one of the three persons i.e. Office Peon, Office\n\nAttendant and Night Watcher-cum-Sweeper, there being no other class IV\n\npost in the institution. It is for the Managing Committee of the institution to\n\ndecide who is to be promoted and thereafter seek approval of the concerned\n\nauthorities. That way the claim of the writ petitioner could have been\n\nconsidered by the authorities, on being appropriately moved by the\n\nmanagement. It is undisputed that the writ petitioner was appointed by the\n\nmanaging committees', may be under a misreading of the relevant\n\ngovernment orders.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">13.   We, therefore, while allowing this appeal direct that the management\n\nof the concerned institution shall move the concerned authorities for\n\napproval to the promotional appointment of a class IV employee, as\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                     6</span>\n\f\"Daftry\". Simultaneously, it can also recommend for appointment to the\n\nclass IV post, in case approval is accorded to the recommendation for\n\nappointment of \"Daftry\" on promotion. The decision on both motions shall\n\nbe taken within three months from the date of submission of the\n\nrecommendation in accordance with law keeping in view the operative\n\nyardsticks in force at the time appointments were made. Even if there has\n\nbeen refusal earlier, the matter shall be reconsidered in the light of what has\n\nbeen stated above.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">14.   Before we part with this case we must indicate that undisputedly there\n\nwere several decision of the Division Bench rendered at earlier points of\n\ntime, taking a view contrary to the one taken in the impugned judgment.\n\nLearned counsel for the respondent (writ petitioner) fairly accepted that it is\n\nso. In fact, copy of one such decision dated 15.7.1996 in O.J.C. 5108/96\n\nwas placed on record and it has been brought to the notice of the learned\n\nJudges hearing the writ petition.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">15.   The appeal is allowed in the aforesaid terms, leaving the parties to\n\nbear their respective costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">                                         ........................................J.\n                                            (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">                                     7</span>\n\f                        ........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 23, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                    8</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1335773,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"bhandari","formInput":"bhandari"},{"value":"dalveer bhandari","formInput":"dalveer%20bhandari"}],"firstname":"d","title":"Vinodan vs Vishwanathan on 12 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33762","lastname":"bhandari","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-12","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Vinodan vs Vishwanathan on 12 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D Bhandari</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Dalveer Bhandari, Harjit Singh Bedi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                              REPORTABLE\n\n\n               IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO.881 OF 2001\n\nVinodan                                         .. Appellant\n\n            Versus\n\nVishwanathan                                    ..Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                         JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dalveer Bhandari, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">1.   This appeal is directed against the judgment dated 21st\n\nMay, 1998 passed by the High Court of Kerala at Ernakulam in\n\nA.S. No.254 of 1990.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.   This is an unfortunate litigation regarding partition of a\n\nbuilding constructed on a small piece of land between the\n\nbrothers.   It is not disputed that the land is jointly owned by\n\nboth the brothers.     The dispute is restricted over the building\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                               2</span>\n\n\nwhich has been constructed on the part of the land.   The matter\n\nhas travelled from the Subordinate Court, Trichur to this Court.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.   A serious endeavour has been made by this Court to\n\namicably settle the matter. On 6.8.2008, the following order was\n\npassed by this Court\"\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">           \"In the present case, the dispute is between two\n     brothers. The ownership of the land is admittedly\n     joint. The short controversy is regarding the cost of\n     construction over that plot.        The case of the\n     respondent is that he has spent the entire cost of\n     construction whereas the case of the appellant is that\n     he has also contributed equally to the cost of\n     construction.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">           In our considered view, this controversy can be\n     easily sorted out by the parties. We have requested\n     the learned counsel for the parties to ensure that the\n     matter may be amicably settled between the parties\n     and for that purpose, we adjourn this matter for four\n     weeks.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">The dispute could not be resolved despite efforts of this court\n\nand now we have been called upon to give our judgment in the\n\nmatter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.   Vinodan and Vishwanathan in the suit were the plaintiff\n\nand defendant before the trial court.   The suit was filed before\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                  3</span>\n\n\nthe trial court with the prayer that the property described in the\n\nplaint schedule was purchased jointly by the parties as per the\n\ndocument no. 806/77 and the appellant before this court\n\nVinodan is entitled to the half share of the property.      The trial\n\ncourt framed the following issues:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">     \"(1)   Whether the plaint schedule property was\n            acquired by the plaintiff and defendant jointly or\n            whether it was acquired by the defendant\n            exclusively?\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">     (2)    Whether the house was constructed by both the\n            parties or by any of them exclusively?\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">     (3)    Whether plaintiff is entitled to claim partition?\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">     (4)    What is the quantum of mesne profits, if to be\n            paid?\n</blockquote>\n<pre id=\"pre_2\">     (5)    Equities and reservations?\n\n     (6)    Reliefs and Costs?\"\n\n\n</pre><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">     The trial court after examining the evidence and hearing the\nparties came to the following finding on Issues no.1&amp;2:\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">     \"I have absolutely no hesitation to hold that the\n     plaintiff and defendant had supplied funds for the\n     construction of the house and the house had been\n     constructed with that amount and so the house\n     belonged to them jointly. Similarly the property had\n     also been purchased with the funds of both and so it\n     also belongs to them jointly.\"\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                               4</span>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">5.   Regarding Issue no. 3, the trial court came to the finding\n\nthat it had to be divided into two equal shares and one such\n\nshare was allotted to the plaintiff/appellant herein and the other\n\nshare was allotted to the defendant/respondent herein.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_9\">6.   Regarding Issue no.4 pertaining to mesne profits, the trial\n\ncourt held that the plaintiff/appellant was entitled to get mesne\n\nprofits from the defendant/respondent from the date of suit till\n\npossession.   The trial court further held that the quantum of\n\nmesne profits can be a matter which could be decided in the final\n\ndecree proceedings after the Commissioner would submit his\n\nreport.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">7.   The trial court directed that the property described in the\n\nplaint schedule has to be divided into two equal shares and one\n\nsuch share was allotted to the plaintiff/appellant and the other\n\nto the defendant/respondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">8.   The defendant/respondent Vishwanathan aggrieved by the\n\nsaid order of the Subordinate Court, Trichur filed an appeal\n\nbefore the High Court of Kerala at Ernakulam.      The finding of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                5</span>\n\n\nthe High Court is that the plaintiff/appellant had been regularly\n\nsending money for the construction of the building during the\n\nperiod 1977-78.    Exhs. B-36 and B-37 go to show that the\n\nappellant had sent Rs.55,000/- during the period 1976-77 for\n\nthe construction of the building.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">9.    On a close scrutiny of all the documents available on record\n\nand the oral evidence, the High Court came to the conclusion\n\nthat on construction of the building the appellant had spent\n\nRs.55,000/- and the balance amount had been spent by the\n\nrespondent.    The High Court allowed the appeal and set aside\n\nthe order and the preliminary decree passed by the trial court. In\n\nthe impugned judgment, the High Court directed that the\n\nplaintiff/appellant was not entitled to divide the house and could\n\nonly claim Rs.55,000/- from the respondent which will be a\n\ncharge on the property of the respondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">10.   The appellant, aggrieved by the said judgment of the High\n\nCourt, preferred this appeal before this court.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                6</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">11.   We have heard learned counsel for the parties at length.\n\nThe parties have been litigating for more than 20 years and\n\nbecause of the bitter and long litigation it may not be conducive\n\nfor the parties to stay in the same building, particularly when\n\nthey have option of residing separately because of the available\n\nland with each one of them. During the course of hearing, the\n\nlearned senior counsel appearing for the appellant gave an offer\n\nthat his client is willing to pay Rs.5,50,000/- in lieu of the share\n\nof the respondent. No offer was given by the respondent despite\n\nopportunity granted by this court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">12.   In the facts and circumstances of the case, while balancing\n\nthe equities and for keeping peace and happiness in the family,\n\nwe think it would be just and proper to direct the appellant to\n\npay Rs.5,50,000/- to the respondent within a period of four\n\nmonths. On receiving the said amount, the respondent may\n\nconstruct a suitable house in his portion of the land and for that\n\npurpose we grant one year's time from the date of payment of\n\nRs.5,50,000/- to the respondent to vacate the portion of the\n\nbuilding which is presently in his possession and give vacant\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                7</span>\n\n\nand peaceful possession of his portion of building to the\n\nappellant in lieu of payment of Rs.5,50,000/-. We are granting\n\nlong time to the respondent to vacate the portion of the building\n\nin his possession to avoid any inconvenience to the respondent.\n\nIn case the respondent after one year of receiving the entire\n\namount of Rs.5,50,000/- does not vacate the portion of the\n\nbuilding in his possession, in that event, the Subordinate Court\n\nis directed to ensure that the possession is taken from the\n\nrespondent and handed over to the appellant.               Perhaps this\n\nsolution may lead to ultimate peace between the families of two\n\nbrothers.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">13.   With these observations, this appeal is accordingly disposed\n\nof leaving the parties to bear their own costs.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                           .................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                         (Dalveer Bhandari)\n\n\n\n                                           .................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                         (Harjit Singh Bedi)\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">February 12, 2009.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f8</span><p id=\"p_27\">\n\f</p>","tid":1909810,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"Amrita shergill marg","formInput":"Amrita%20shergill%20marg"},{"value":"n.d.m.c. By filing these applications, the applicants have\n\n     prayed to clarify the concept of `mother plot' and of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                     2</span>\n\n     the word `adjoining' appearing in LBZ guidelines\n\n     dated February 08, 1988 so that fresh plans can be\n\n     submitted by them to the NDMC in accordance with\n\n     law and strictly within the four corners of judgment\n\n     dated August 28, 2008 rendered by this Court in\n\n     Civil Appeal No. 5292 of 2008 and Civil Appeal No.\n\n     5293 of 2008.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.   The Learned Counsel for applicants submitted that\n\n     applicants   are   proposing   to construct only    a\n\n     building with two storeys (ground and first floor) in\n\n     the plot in question which will not exceed the height\n\n     of the buildings on either side, on Amrita Shergil\n\n     Marg.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n     From the record of the case, it is evident that Plot\n\nNo. 47 belonging to the applicants faces Amrita Shergil\n\nMarg.   From the decision rendered in Civil Appeal\n\nNos.5292-5293 of 2008, it is clear that the concept of\n\n`mother plot' would not be applicable so far as Plot No.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                                  3</span>\n\n47 is concerned because of bifurcation of original plot\n\nwhich had taken place pursuant to a decree of Court. In\n\nthe judgment which is sought to be clarified, it is held\n\nthat even if the concept of `mother plot' is not made\n\napplicable to the facts of the case, the appellants would\n\nbe entitled to construct a building of the height of the\n\nbungalow which is the lowest on the adjoining plots. It is\n\nalso clear from the clarification relating to the LBZ\n\nguidelines issued on 09.05.1997, that to have uniformity,\n\nthe height of the main building on the adjoining plots on\n\nAmrita   Shergil   Marg    will   have     to    be    taken       into\n\nconsideration and not of any building on a different road,\n\nthat is Prithvi Raj Road which is on the rear of the plot in\n\nquestion.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3. Appellant(s)\n\n\n          Versus\n\nNATIONAL COOP.GROUP HOUS.SOCIEY LTD.&amp;ORS                            ...   Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                     ORDER\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">         Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">         This appeal is directed against the order dated 16th September, 2008, passed\n\n   by the Delhi High Court in C.M. No.12650 of 2008, filed in writ petition(C) No.6934\n\n   of 2007, wherein the appellant had prayed for an order to treat the said application\n\n   as part of the main writ petition and to set aside the further demands raised in\n\n   paragraphs 7 and 8 of the application. For the sake of convenience, the order of the\n\n   High Court dated 16/09/2008 is reproduced hereinbelow:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                     \"As on date, a sum of Rupees 5,42,596/- is claimed\n                     by the Respondent Society against the Petitioner\n                     upto June, 2007. The flat in question has not been\n                     completed/finished.     In order to expedite\n                     possession of the Flat being handed-over to the\n                     Petitioner th respondents(Petitioner) submits that\n                     a sum of Rupees 1,50,000/- may be deducted from\n                     the amounts due since this would be the amount\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                            2</span>\n\n                   defrayed by the Society towards completion of the\n                   Flat.          Learned      counsel      for     the\n                   respondents(Petitioner) states, on instructions,\n                   that the Society would be willing to adjust the sum\n                   of Rupees 1,50,000/- from the amounts due and\n                   payable by the Petitioner under various heads,\n                   which, as stated above, stood at Rupees 5,42,596/-\n                   upto June, 2007.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                          Mr. Chetan Sharma, learned Senior\n                   Counsel for the Petitioner states, on instructions,\n                   that the sum of Rupees 2,92,596/- arrived at by\n                   adjusting Rupees 1,00,000/- already deposited in\n                   these proceedings, shall be paid to the Respondent\n                   Society within four weeks from today. On the\n                   payment of the said sum possession of the Flat in\n                   question, namely A-35, shall be handed over to the\n                   Petitioner forthwith. The claims of the rival\n                   parties shall be adjudicated in the final hearing of\n                   this Petition.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">                          This arrangement pertains to demands that\n                   have been raised upto June, 2007. Demands\n                   arising thereafter shall be paid by the Petitioner\n                   diligently. The said arrangement is without\n                   prejudice to the rights and contentions of either\n                   parties.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">                          Application is disposed of.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_3\">\n\n\n       Mr. Ranjit Kumar, learned senior counsel appearing for the appellant, points\n\nout that the order impugned relates to handing over of possession of the flat in\n\nquestion to the appellant, subject to payment of certain dues, which had been agreed\n\nupon and at the same time there was also a direction that demands raised by the\n\nrespondent-society after June, 2007, would also have to be paid, but without\n\nprejudice to the rights and contentions of the parties.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">       Having heard Mr. Ranjit Kumar, learned senior counsel for the appellant,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                            3</span>\n\nand learned counsel for the respondent-society, and having regard to the fact that\n\nthe appellant has been waiting for possession of the flat in question since 2003, we\n\nare of the view that the order impugned has to be given a pragmatic meaning so that,\n\non the one hand, the appellant is able to obtain possession of the flat and at the same\n\ntime the demands of the society are also paid subject to the final decision in the writ\n\npetitions pending before the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">       However, before we proceed to do so, it should also be kept in mind that the\n\npayment of demands raised after June, 2007, has been linked by the society to\n\npossession being made over to the appellant. We must also keep in mind the fact\n\nthat the appellant has also not paid the amounts, as was directed by the order of the\n\nHigh Court, within the time specified. It is because of these two reasons that the\n\nmatter is now before us.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">       Having considered the submissions made and the facts as indicated above, we\n\nare inclined to modify the order of the High Court to the extent of extending the time\n\nfor   depositing the balance amount of Rs.2,92,596/- payable, after adjustment of\n\nRs. one lakh, which has already been deposited.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">       We, therefore, extend the time for making the deposit of the said balance\n\namount till 16th March, 2009. On payment of the said amount, the society shall\n\nforthwith hand over possession of the flat in question to the appellant.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">       As far as payment, with regard to the demands raised after June, 2007 is\n\nconcerned, it is made clear that such payments shall be made by the appellant\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                   4</span>\n\n      without prejudice to her rights and contentions and such payment would be subject\n\n      to the final decision of the High Court in the pending writ petitions.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">             The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                                           ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                               (ALTAMAS KABIR)\n\n\n\n                                               ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                          (CYRIAC JOSEPH)\n\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 25, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1016280,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"Amrita shergill marg","formInput":"Amrita%20shergill%20marg"},{"value":"n.d.m.c. PANCHAL)\nNEW DELHI\nFebruary 20, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1388680,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"zoo","formInput":"zoo"},{"value":"zoo authority","formInput":"zoo%20authority"},{"value":"animal","formInput":"animal"},{"value":" guidelines ","formInput":"%20guidelines%20"},{"value":"recognition","formInput":"recognition"}],"firstname":null,"title":"People For Ethical Treatment Of ... vs Central Zoo Authority & Ors on 10 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33799","lastname":null,"secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-10","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">People For Ethical Treatment Of ... vs Central Zoo Authority &amp; Ors on 10 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: R.V. Raveendran, Markandey Katju</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                     1\n\n                    IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                    CIVIL ORIGINAL JURISDICTION\n\n                               I.A.NO.3 IN I.A.NO.1\n                                         IN\n\n                    WRIT PETITION (C) NO.195 OF 2006\n\nPEOPLE FOR ETHICAL TREATMENT\nOF ANIMALS                                             ... PETITIONER\n\n                               VERSUS\n\nCENTRAL ZOO AUTHORITY &amp; ORS.                                                       ...\nRESPONDENTS\n\n\n\n                               ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          This writ petition was filed by the petitioner seeking a direction to the\n\nvarious State Governments to stop operation of zoos which have been refused\n\nrecognition by the Central Zoo Authority and to to take over animals of the\n\nunrecognised/de-recognised zoos. The petitioner has also sought certain consequential\n\ndirections in regard to the protection of animals and endangered species of animals\n\napart from providing better and more natural habitat for animals in        zoos and\n\nenclosures.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">2.        This Court on 9.10.2006 directed that no zoo shall permit any breeding of\n\nanimals beyond the number specified by the Central Zoo Authority in its directive\n\ndated 7.2.1995. By order dated 6.12.2007, this Court directed the Central Zoo\n\nAuthority to come up with comprehensive guidelines as to (i) how it will deal with\n\napplications for revival of recognition; (ii) the manner in which the animals in de-\n\nrecognised zoos should be dealt with. As the Court was of the view that unless there\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                            2</span>\n\nwas a direction to stop exhibiting the animals in de-recognised zoos, the zoos will not\n\nbe motivated to rectify the shortcomings and provide the up-gradation required as\n\nper the guidelines provided by the Central Zoo Authority, the said Authority is\n\ndirected to come up with proper suggestions in that regard.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">3.           In pursuance of it, the Central Zoo Authority came up with guidelines and\n\nsuggestions in its affidavit filed in February, 2008 and placed before this Court on\n\n11.3.2008. This Court was informed that 509 applications were received by the\n\nCentral Zoo Authority from different zoos, rescue centres and circuses for\n\nrecognition; that the Central Zoo Authority rejected 291 applications and granted\n\nother applications. Pursuant to such rejection of 291 applications, 260 zoos/rescue\n\ncentres/circuses were closed/wound up. In view of it, this Court directed action in\n\nregard to the remaining 31. On 31.07.2008, it was reported that out of 31, 15 have\n\napplied for fresh recognition and the same was under consideration and in regard to\n\nthe remaining 16, Central Zoo Authority will write to the respective States to take\n\nappropriate action in accordance with law and provisions of the Wildlife Protection\n\nAct, 1972.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">4.           We thus find that by and large the purpose of filing the writ petition has\n\nbeen achieved. The un-recognised/de-recongnised zoos/circuses/rescue centres have\n\nbeen closed, guidelines have been issued, State Governments have been notified of the\n\nneed to comply with the provisions of the Act, Rules and the guidelines issued by the\n\nCentral Zoo Authority from time to time. In view of the above, we are of the view that\n\nthis petition can be disposed of reserving liberty to the concerned authorities to take\n\nappropriate action in accordance with law if there is violation of the Wildlife\n\n(Protection) Act, 1972 and the Rules thereunder in the respective States/Union\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                              3</span>\n\n   Territories. We dispose of this petition and the pending applications accordingly.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">   5.          Action was taken against the erring zoos      and implementation of the\n\n   provisions of the Act and the Rules could be made a reality to a reasonable extent by\n\n   the interest shown and steps taken by Shri Raj Panjwani, Advocate who assisted the\n\n   Court. The Court places its appreciation on record for the service rendered by Mr.\n\n   Panjwani.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                                                     ............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                        ( R.V. RAVEENDRAN )\n\n\n\n                                                                     ............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                  ( MARKANDEY KATJU )\n  NEW DELHI,\nFEBRUARY 10, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":844361,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"what is an accessory","formInput":"what%20is%20an%20accessory"},{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"slp","formInput":"slp"},{"value":"interpretation","formInput":"interpretation"}],"firstname":null,"title":"M/S Addison & Co.Ltd vs State Of Karnataka Rep By Commr ... on 26 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33917","lastname":"...................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-26","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">M/S Addison &amp; Co.Ltd vs State Of Karnataka Rep By Commr ... on 26 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.H. Kapadia, Aftab Alam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                      IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                            CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                             CIVIL APPEAL NO. 1311 OF 2009\n                            (Arising out of S.L.P.(C) No.5190/2008)\n\n\nM/s Addison &amp; Co. Ltd.                                            ...Appellant(s)\n\n                       Versus\n\nState of Karnataka rep. by Commr., Com.Taxes                      ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                        ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">          The short question which arises for determination in this Civil Appeal is:\n\nWhether the subject tools are in the nature of accessories to machines and, therefore,\n\nliable to entry tax?\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">          The main submission of the appellant before us was that the said tools are\n\nconsumables and, therefore, they cannot be part(s) of the machine nor can they be\n\ntermed as \"accessories\". It was submitted that machines like lathe machines and\n\ndrilling machines are not capable of performing any functions without the subject\n\ntools. Before us, it was further submitted that the subject tools are rendered useless\n\nafter they are used for certain number of times. It is also pointed out that in the past,\n\nprior to Assessment Year 2000-2001, the Department has accepted that the test of\n\nwhether the subject tools constituted consumables was applied by the Department as\n\nthe relevant test in interpreting Entry 52 of the First Schedule to the Karnataka Tax\n\non Entry of Goods Act, 1979.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">          On the other hand, it is argued on behalf of the Department that the subject\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                            1</span>\n\ftools are part of the machine and that, in any event, they are accessories. It is also\n\ncontended that the test of an item being consumable is not relevant in interpreting the\n\nsaid Entry 52.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">          We quote herein-below Entry 52 of the First Schedule to the 1979 Act:\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">                    \"52. Machinery (all kinds) and parts and accessories\n          thereof but excluding agricultural machinery.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n          On going through the pleadings, particularly at pages 51, 59 and 105 of the\n\nS.L.P. paper book, we find that all throughout it was argued before the Authorities\n\nbelow, in this case, that without subject tools the lathe and drilling machines are non-\n\nfunctional.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">          As repeatedly stated in our earlier judgments, in matters of interpretation\n\nof taxing laws, this Court     must first find out whether a proper foundation is\n\nestablished by the assessee/Department before the adjudicating authority. This test\n\nhas not been complied with by the assessee in the present case. For example, assessee\n\nhas stated at page 59 of the S.L.P. paper book that \"the subject tools cannot be\n\ntermed as parts of the machine since the machine can very well function without the\n\nsaid tools, though the machine may not be in a position to carry out the specific jobs\n\nfor which these tools would be necessary. It is further stated that the subject tools are\n\nnecessary for a machine to carry out specific jobs but that fact would not make them\n\nparts of the machine.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">          As stated, what was argued before us was that lathe and drilling machines\n\nare non-functional without subject tools whereas in the above paras before the\n\nAuthorities below, the assessee submitted that lathe and drilling machines can\n\nfunction without the subject tools. We may also note that the assessee has not led\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                            2</span>\n\fevidence before the adjudicating authority to show whether the lathe and drilling\n\nmachines were non-functional in the absence of the subject tools.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">         For the aforestated reasons, we find no infirmity in the impugned judgment\n\nof the High Court and the Tribunal and, accordingly, we dismiss this Civil Appeal\n\nwhich, as stated above, relates to Assessment Year 2000-2001.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">         Be that as it may, we are of the view that it would be open to the assessee\n\nherein to raise the contention as to whether the subject tools are consumables and not\n\naccessories/parts of machine in an appropriate case(s). The reason being that\n\nAuthorities need to decide as to what distinguishes a consumable from an accessory.\n\nIf the assessee raises such a contention as is raised before us in this Appeal, the\n\nauthority shall consider the contention in accordance with law, uninfluenced by the\n\nobservations made in the impugned judgment of the High Court and the Tribunal in\n\nthis case. We also make it clear that in such an event, it would be open to the assessee\n\nherein and to the Department to raise all such contentions which are necessary for\n\ndeciding this dispute, including the contentions mentioned hereinabove.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">         Subject to above, Civil Appeal is dismissed. No order as to costs.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                   ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                                                      (S.H. KAPADIA)\n\n\n\n                                           ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                        (AFTAB ALAM)\nNew Delhi,\nFebruary 26, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                           3</span>\n\f</p>","tid":16295,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"transfer petition","formInput":"transfer%20petition"},{"value":"cheque is out of date","formInput":"cheque%20is%20out%20of%20date"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"transfer petition(civil)","formInput":"transfer%20petition%28civil%29"},{"value":"transfer of civil petition","formInput":"transfer%20of%20civil%20petition"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"firstname":"d","title":"Alok Mishra vs Garima Mishra on 27 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33922","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-02-27","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Alok Mishra vs Garima Mishra on 27 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, D.K.
