Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">2.   This appeal is directed against the judgment and\n\n     decree dated 12th of December, 2007 passed by a\n\n     learned Judge of the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi\n\n     in RSA No.136 of 2004. By the impugned judgment,\n\n     the High Court had reduced the mesne profits granted\n\n     by the courts below from Rs.70,000/-per month to\n\n     Rs.40,000/- per month, to that extent the orders of\n\n     the courts below were modified.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                          2</span><p id=\"p_3\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">3.   It is an admitted position, the eviction order has not\n\n     been challenged. It is only against the reduction of\n\n     mesne    profits   per    month      from   Rs.70,000/-   to\n\n     Rs.40,000/- being challenged before us which on\n\n     grant of leave was heard in the presence of the learned\n\n     counsel for the parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">4.   In our view, the judgment of the High Court needs to\n\n     be set aside on a simple ground. That while reducing\n\n     and modifying the order of the courts below regarding\n\n     the   rate   of   mesne    profits   from   Rs.70,000/-   to\n\n     Rs.40,000/- per month, the High Court had not dealt\n\n     with the evidence         adduced    by the    parties and\n\n     considered the materials on record to come to a\n\n     conclusion that the orders of the courts below\n\n     directing Rs.70,000/- per month as mesne profits be\n\n     modified to the extent of Rs.40,000/- per month\n\n     payable to the landlord. We do not find from the\n\n     judgment that any consideration was made by the\n\n     High Court to reduce the rate of mesne profits from\n\n     Rs.70,000/- to Rs.40,000/- per month. That being the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                              3</span>\n\n\n     position, we set aside the judgment of the High Court\n\n     and send the case back to it for fresh disposal in\n\n     accordance with law after giving hearing to the parties\n\n     and after passing a reasoned order. We request the\n\n     High Court to dispose of the second appeal within\n\n     three months from the date of supply of a copy of this\n\n     order to it.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">5.   For the reasons aforesaid, the impugned order is set\n\n     aside and the appeal is allowed to the extent indicated\n\n     above. There will be no order as to costs.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">6.   We make it clear that we have not gone into the merits\n\n     on the question of fixing the rate of mesne profits\n\n     which shall     be   decided   by the     High     Court       in\n\n     accordance with law after hearing the parties at\n\n     length.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                     ..............................J.\n                                     [Tarun Chatterjee]\n\n\nNew Delhi;                           ..............................J.\nFebruary 06, 2009.                   [H.L.Dattu]\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":58225316,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"adducing evidence","formInput":"adducing%20evidence"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Mahanagarpalika vs Sureshbhai Bhanubhai Thakkar & ... on 27 February, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33980","lastname":"......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-02-27","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Mahanagarpalika vs Sureshbhai Bhanubhai Thakkar &amp; ... on 27 February, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: B.N. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                         CIVIL APPEAL NO.1328 OF 2009\n                      (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.5313 of 2004)\n\nMahanagarpalika                                              ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                         Versus\n\nSureshbhai Bhanubhai Thakkar &amp; Anr.               ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                      O R D E R\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">           Delay condoned.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">           Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">           The predecessor of the plaintiffs-respondents filed Special Civil Suit\nNo.204 of 1990 for recovery of Rs.2,03,300/- with interest @ 18% from the date of\nnotice i.e. 20th August, 1988. He also prayed for grant of a declaration that the\ndefendant-Mahanagarpalika, Bhavnagar (appellant herein) is bound to allot shop\nNo.40-I to him at the upset price. After 13 years of the institution of suit, the evidence\nof the plaintiffs-respondents was closed on 6.1.2003 and the case was adjourned to\n21.2.2003 for the evidence of the defendant-appellant. As no witness was produced on\nthat day, the trial Court closed the evidence of the defendant-appellant. The suit was\ndecreed on 31.3.2003. When the matter was taken to the High Court in first appeal,\nthe same was dismissed summarily.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">           We have heard learned counsel for the parties. In our view, in the facts\nand circumstances of the case, the trial Court was not justified in closing the evidence\nof the defendant and passing a decree in favour of the plaintiffs-respondents only on\nthe ground that the High Court had\n                                                                                     ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">required it to expedite disposal of the suit. The trial Court should have, after taking\nnote of the fact that the plaintiffs had taken long time to adduce their evidence, given\nfurther opportunity to the defendant-appellant to adduce evidence and then decided\nthe matter. Its failure to do so has resulted in miscarriage of justice.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">            While dismissing the first appeal, the High Court observed that in-spite of\nsufficient opportunity having been given, the appellant did not adduce evidence in\nsupport of its case.    This must be treated as clearly erroneous because it is an\nundisputed fact that only one opportunity was given to defendant-appellant to adduce\nevidence.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">            For the reasons stated above, the appeal is allowed, the impugned orders\nare set aside and the trial Court is directed to decide the suit afresh in accordance\nwith law after giving opportunity to defendant-appellant to adduce evidence.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">                                                                           ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                 [B.N. Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.   This appeal is directed against an order dated 3rd\n\n     of January, 2007 passed by a Division Bench of\n\n     the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad,\n\n     Lucknow Bench in Special Appeal No.489 of\n\n     2003 by which the appeal was dismissed with the\n\n     following directions:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">     \"We, therefore, while dismissing the writ petition\n     as having lost its significance, after the\n     retirement of the appellant, direct that since the\n     appellant had throughout discharged the duties\n     of Principal as official Principal, he shall be paid\n     the salary of the given pay scale, after adjusting\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                       1</span>\n\f     the amount already paid. Such arrears shall be\n     paid within a maximum period of three months\n     from the date of receipt of a certified copy of this\n     order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">           The petitioner shall also be given all\n     consequential benefits accordingly, as per\n     rules.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.   From a reading of the order including the\n\n     directions made in the impugned order as noted\n\n     herein above, it would be clear that the High\n\n     Court had dismissed the appeal only on the\n\n     ground that since the appellant had retired as an\n\n     ad    hoc   principal,   the   appeal   had   become\n\n     infructuous. In our view, it is true that the High\n\n     Court had granted relief to the appellant to which\n\n     he otherwise could not get, by directing payment\n\n     of salary for the period he continued as an ad hoc\n\n     principal on the strength of the interim order. In\n\n     our    view,   the   appeal,    in   the   facts   and\n\n     circumstances of the present case, ought to have\n\n     been decided on merits after giving proper\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                        2</span>\n\f     hearing to the parties. That being the position,\n\n     we set aside the impugned order and restore the\n\n     special appeal, which shall be decided by the\n\n     Division Bench of the High Court at an early date\n\n     preferably within three months from the date of\n\n     supply of a copy of this order to it and after\n\n     passing a reasoned order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">4.   The   appeal    is   thus   allowed   to   the     extent\n\n     indicated above. There will be no order as to\n\n     costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                       .........................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                       [Tarun Chatterjee]\n\n\n\nNew Delhi;                             .........................J.\nFebruary 16, 2009. Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">2.   This appeal is directed against the judgment and\n\n     decree dated 12th of December, 2007 passed by a\n\n     learned Judge of the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi\n\n     in RSA No.136 of 2004. By the impugned judgment,\n\n     the High Court had reduced the mesne profits granted\n\n     by the courts below from Rs.70,000/-per month to\n\n     Rs.40,000/- per month, to that extent the orders of\n\n     the courts below were modified.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                          2</span><p id=\"p_3\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">3.   It is an admitted position, the eviction order has not\n\n     been challenged. It is only against the reduction of\n\n     mesne    profits   per    month      from   Rs.70,000/-   to\n\n     Rs.40,000/- being challenged before us which on\n\n     grant of leave was heard in the presence of the learned\n\n     counsel for the parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">4.   In our view, the judgment of the High Court needs to\n\n     be set aside on a simple ground. That while reducing\n\n     and modifying the order of the courts below regarding\n\n     the   rate   of   mesne    profits   from   Rs.70,000/-   to\n\n     Rs.40,000/- per month, the High Court had not dealt\n\n     with the evidence         adduced    by the    parties and\n\n     considered the materials on record to come to a\n\n     conclusion that the orders of the courts below\n\n     directing Rs.70,000/- per month as mesne profits be\n\n     modified to the extent of Rs.40,000/- per month\n\n     payable to the landlord. We do not find from the\n\n     judgment that any consideration was made by the\n\n     High Court to reduce the rate of mesne profits from\n\n     Rs.70,000/- to Rs.40,000/- per month. That being the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                              3</span>\n\n\n     position, we set aside the judgment of the High Court\n\n     and send the case back to it for fresh disposal in\n\n     accordance with law after giving hearing to the parties\n\n     and after passing a reasoned order. We request the\n\n     High Court to dispose of the second appeal within\n\n     three months from the date of supply of a copy of this\n\n     order to it.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">5.   For the reasons aforesaid, the impugned order is set\n\n     aside and the appeal is allowed to the extent indicated\n\n     above. There will be no order as to costs.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">6.   We make it clear that we have not gone into the merits\n\n     on the question of fixing the rate of mesne profits\n\n     which shall     be   decided   by the     High     Court       in\n\n     accordance with law after hearing the parties at\n\n     length.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                     ..............................J.\n                                     [Tarun Chatterjee]\n\n\nNew Delhi;                           ..............................J.\nFebruary 06, 2009. In terms of the agreement, the parties were required to\nperform their respective obligations by 31st March, 1992. By an order dated 3rd April,\n2007, the trial Court, after taking note of the fact that the suit could have been filed\nwithin a period of three years from 31st March, 1992, when the cause of action is said\nto have accrued to the plaintiff but the suit was filed in the year 2006 held that the\nsame is barred by limitation and accordingly rejected the plaint under Order VII\nRule 11(d) of the Code of Civil Procedure. The High Court allowed the revision filed\nby the petitioner and set aside the order of the trial Court only on the ground that the\nsame was passed without requiring the defendant to file written statement.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">           We have been taken through the plaint. A perusal thereof makes it clear\nthat the cause of action for filing the suit for specific performance accrued to the\nplaintiff on\n                                                                                   ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">31st March, 1992. The limitation for filing such suit is three years. Therefore, the\nplaintiff could have filed the suit by 31st March, 1995. However, the fact of the matter\nis that the suit was filed in the year 2006 i.e. after 11 years of the expiry of the period\nof limitation. In this view of the matter, the trial Court was justified in rejecting the\nplaint on the ground of limitation and the High Court committed an error in\nreversing the order of the trial Court.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned order of the High Court is\nset aside and the one passed by the trial Court is restored.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">                                                                           ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                 [B.N. Since that course has not been adopted in the\n                                                                                    ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">present case, the impugned order allowing the second appeal is liable to be set aside.\nWhile dismissing the civil revision petition, the High Court has not assigned any\nreason whatsoever. The Revision Petition is\n           dismissed.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_3\">           A perusal of the above order shows that no reasons have been given\ntherein. In our opinion, even in an order of affirmance, some reasons ought to be\nrecorded, which need not be as elaborate as orders passed by the District Forum or\nthe State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission.            Hence, we set aside the\nimpugned order and remand the matter to the National Commission for decision\nafresh after hearing the parties in accordance with law as expeditiously as possible.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">           The civil appeal is, accordingly, allowed.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_5\">                                                                 ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">                                                 [MARKANDEY KATJU]\n\n\n\n                                                                          ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                                 [G.S. Jain and Anr.                                     ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                       Versus\n\nDelhi Development Authority                     ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                                    O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">          Heard learned counsel for the appellants.\n          In spite of service of notice, nobody has appeared on behalf of the\nrespondent to contest the prayer made in this appeal.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">          The appellants filed a complaint before the State Consumer Disputes\nRedressal Commission, New Delhi, [for short, `the State Commission'], claiming total\ncompensation to the tune of Rupees thirty five lakhs and four thousand. The State\nCommission, instead of deciding the complaint on merits, transferred the same to the\nDistrict Forum, as in its opinion, the amount of compensation was astronomically\nhigh. It was not at all justified in transferring the\ncomplaint to the District Forum on an assumed ground that the amount of\ncompensation claimed was astronomically high.        The National Commission also\ncommitted serious error by approving the legally unsustainable order passed by the\nState Commission.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned orders are set aside and the\nmatter is remitted to the State Commission to decide the complaint afresh after giving\nopportunity of hearing to the parties.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">                                                                       ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                               [B.N. Dattu</div>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">           2.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">     1</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">\f5.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">     2</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f3</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f4</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f5</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f6</span>\n\f</p>","tid":513704,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":4,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"limitation act 1963","formInput":"limitation%20act%201963"},{"value":"limitation act citedby:100581","formInput":"limitation%20act%20citedby%3A100581"},{"value":"review application ","formInput":"review%20application%20"},{"value":"application of review application","formInput":"application%20of%20review%20application"},{"value":"delay in filing","formInput":"delay%20in%20filing"},{"value":" s h kapadia","formInput":"%20s%20h%20kapadia"},{"value":"crp ","formInput":"crp%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":100581,"url":null,"title":"Section 5 in The Limitation Act, 1963"},{"tid":427855,"url":null,"title":"Article 136 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":1317393,"url":null,"title":"The Limitation Act, 1963"},{"tid":1940266,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=16304","title":"Kunhayammed & Ors vs State Of Kerala & Anr on 19 July, 2000"}],"covers":[],"title":"R.B.Ramlingam vs R.B.Bhvaneswari on 13 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-13","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":850010,"url":null,"title":"Heirs vs Ravjibhai on 11 January, 2010"},{"tid":1758468,"url":"http://bombayhighcourt.nic.in/generatenew.php?path=.%2Fdata%2Faurjudgements%2F2009%2F&fname=CCA505808.pdf&smflag=N","title":"-C) Santosh vs Madhavrao Alias Mahadev Tukaram on 6 August, 2009"},{"tid":585375,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/VBG/judgement/04-12-2009/VBG03122009FAO3822007.pdf","title":"Smt. Shiv Kumari vs Choudhary Prem Singh & Ors. on 3 December, 2009"},{"tid":736906,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chattisgarh/qrydisp.aspx?filename=954","title":"Dineshwar Prasad Chandrakar vs The State Government Of ... on 31 August, 2010"},{"tid":1494323,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=141468","title":"State Of Kerala vs M.A.Aboobacker on 18 February, 2010"}],"tid":125563128,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"..........................j.","numcitedby":130,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33512","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">R.B.Ramlingam vs R.B.Bhvaneswari on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ..........................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.H. Kapadia, H.L. Dattu</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                               REPORTABLE\n                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                     CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                     S.L.P.(C)..../2008 (CC 15251-15252/2008)\n\n\n\nR.B. RAMLINGAM                                                             ..PETITIONER\n\n                                VERSUS\n\nR.B. BHVANESWARI                                                 ..RESPONDENT\n                             WITH\n                     IA1(C/DELAY IN FILING SLP )\n\n                                ORDER\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          The present special leave petition has been filed by the petitioner (original\n\nplaintiff) against the judgment and final Order dated 18.9.2006 passed by the Madras\n\nHigh Court in CRP(NPD) No. 896/06. Subsequent to the passing of the impugned Order\n\ndated 18.9.2006 in CRP No. 896/06, the petitioner herein filed Review Application No.\n\n85/07. This application was filed in time prescribed for filing the Review Petition under\n\nthe <a href=\"/doc/1317393/\" id=\"a_1\">Limitation Act</a>, 1963. However, vide Order dated 27.3.2008 the said Review\n\nApplication No. 85/07 stood rejected. This special leave petition is filed against the main\n\njudgment and final Order dated 18.9.2006 in CRP No. 896/06 on 7.7.2008. In the process,\n\nthere is a delay of 568 days in filing the special leave petition against the main judgment\n\nand order dated 18.9.2006. The delay, therefore, in filing this special leave\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                           -2-</span>\n\npetition was on account of pendency of Review Application No. 85/07 before the Madras\n\fHigh Court. Consequently, vide I.A. No.\n\n1 of 2008, the petitioner herein prays for condonation of delay of 568 days in filing this\n\nSLP against the main judgment and final Order dated 18.9.2006.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">          When this special leave petition came for hearing before the earlier Division\n\nBench on 25.11.2008, a query was raised by the Court as to whether prosecution of\n\nReview Proceedings would be sufficient cause for purposes of <a href=\"/doc/100581/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 5</a> of the Limitation\n\nAct, 1963. This query was raised by the Court because in numerous matters, this Court\n\nfinds enormous delay in the filing of special leave petitions on the ground that the\n\npetitioner has been prosecuting review proceedings on which count there was delay in\n\nfiling the special leave petition. There is one more reason why this Court raised the above\n\nquery. There is divergence of opinion among Courts whether the prosecution of Review\n\nProceedings would be sufficient cause at all for purposes of <a href=\"/doc/100581/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 5</a> of the Limitation\n\nAct, 1963. For this purpose we requested Shri Shyam Diwan, learned senior counsel, to\n\nassist us in answering the query raised hereinabove.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">          On the question as to whether the prosecution of a Review Application would\n\nbe a sufficient cause for not filing the special leave petition in time for the purposes of\n\n<a href=\"/doc/100581/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 5</a> of the Limitation Act, 1963 we are of the view that there is\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                           -3-</span>\n\na dichotomy between the appellate jurisdiction of this Court and discretionary\n\njurisdiction under <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_5\">Article 136</a> of the Constitution (See: <a href=\"/doc/1940266/\" id=\"a_6\">Kunhayammed and Ors. v. State\n\nof Kerala and Anr</a>. reported in (2000) 6 SCC 359). Reading the said judgment, it also\n\nbecomes clear that filing of Review Petition is no impediment to the filing of the special\n\nleave petition. Large number of judgments were cited before us by learned counsel. It is\n\fnot necessary at this stage to discuss each and every judgment cited before us for the\n\nsimple reason that <a href=\"/doc/100581/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 5</a> of the Limitation Act, 1963 does not lay down any standard\n\nor objective test. The test of \"sufficient cause\" is purely an individualistic test. It is not an\n\nobjective test. Therefore, no two cases can be treated alike. The statute of Limitation has\n\nleft the concept of \"sufficient cause\" delightfully undefined, thereby leaving to the Court\n\na well-intentioned discretion to decide the individual cases whether circumstances exist\n\nestablishing sufficient cause. There are no categories of sufficient cause. The categories of\n\nsufficient cause are never exhausted. Each case spells out a unique experience to be dealt\n\nwith by the Court as such.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           For the aforestated reasons, we hold that in each and every case the Court has\n\nto examine whether delay in filing the special leave petition stands properly explained.\n\nThis is the\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                            -4-</span>\n\nbasic test which needs to be applied. The true guide is whether the petitioner has acted\n\nwith reasonable diligence in the prosecution of his appeal/petition. In exercise of\n\ndiscretion under <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_8\">Article 136</a> to decide whether delay should be condoned or not, this\n\nCourt is not bound by considerations applicable to an Appellate Court but nonetheless\n\ngeneral principles which would weigh with the Appellate Court in determining sufficient\n\ncause can be the guiding factor/guideline. Therefore, it cannot be stated as a proposition\n\nper se that the prosecution of Review Proceedings would not be a sufficient cause at all\n\nfor purposes of <a href=\"/doc/100581/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 5</a> of the Limitation Act, 1963.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">\f          In the present case, as stated above, what is challenged is the main judgment\n\nand Order dated 18.9.2006. As stated above, I.A. No. 1 of 2008 is for condonation of\n\ndelay in filing the special leave petition. It is important to note that the Review\n\nApplication was filed within time in April, 2007, therefore, it was duly numbered. The\n\nHigh Court re-examined the entire case after issuing notice to the respondent herein\n\n(defendant).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">          In view of what is stated above, we now direct the office to list the present\n\nmatter for admission along with I.A.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                        -5-</span>\n\nNo. 1 of 2008 on 16.2.2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">          We hereby record our appreciation for the assistance rendered by learned\n\nAmicus Curiae, Shri Shyam Diwan.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                                              ..........................J.</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\n                                              [S.H. KAPADIA]\n\n\n\n\n   NEW DELHI;                                 .........................J.\n   JANUARY 13. 2009. on 23 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-23","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":56559285,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/Judis_Kerala/list_new2.asp?FileName=445453","title":"Anil M.J vs State India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33587","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Vakil Prasad Singh vs State Of Bihar on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D Jain</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: D.K. Jain, R.M. Lodha</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                         REPORTABLE\n\n                        IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                       CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                        CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 138 OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of S.L.P. (Criminal) No. 6887 of 2007)\n\n\nVAKIL PRASAD SINGH                                   --    APPELLANT (S)\n\n\n                                     VERSUS\n\n\nSTATE OF BIHAR                                      --    RESPONDENT (S)\n\n\n\n                                         JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">D.K. JAIN, J.:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">      Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2. Challenge in this appeal is to the order dated 9th July, 2007 passed by the\n\n   High Court of Judicature at Patna in Criminal Miscellaneous No.17513 of\n\n   1998.    By the impugned order, the High Court has dismissed the petition\n\n   preferred by the appellant under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 482</a> of the Code of Criminal\n\n   Procedure, 1973 (for short `the <a href=\"/doc/445276/\" id=\"a_2\">Cr.P.C</a>.'), seeking quashing of proceedings\n\n   pending against him in Special Case No. 29 of 1987 before the Special Judge,\n\n   Muzaffarpur for allegedly committing offences under <a href=\"/doc/447673/\" id=\"a_3\">Sections 161</a> (before its\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                                  1</span>\n\f   omission by Act 30/2001), 109 and 120B<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_4\"> of the Indian Penal Code</a>, 1860 (for\n\n   short `the <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_5\">I.P.C</a>.') and <a href=\"/doc/1420677/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 5(2)</a> of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947\n\n   (for short `the Act').\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3. The case has a chequered history and, therefore, in order to appreciate the\n\n   rival stands of the parties, it would be necessary to notice the background\n\n   facts in a little greater detail.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">         The genesis of the case dates back to 8th April, 1981 when a search\n\noperation was conducted by the office of the Superintendent of Police, Crime\n\nInvestigation Department, (Vigilance), Muzaffarpur, on the basis of a complaint\n\nlodged by a civil contractor against the appellant, an Assistant Engineer in the\n\nBihar State Electricity Board (Civil) Muzaffarpur, for allegedly demanding a sum\n\nof Rs.1000/- as illegal gratification for release of payment for the civil work\n\nexecuted by him. In the trap laid to catch the culprit, the chemically treated\n\ncurrency notes are stated to have been recovered from appellant's pocket. As a\n\nfollow up action, after investigation by an Inspector of Police, a chargesheet for\n\nthe afore-mentioned offences was filed against the appellant on 28th February,\n\n1982.    The Magistrate took cognizance on 9th December, 1982.           Nothing\n\nsubstantial happened till 6th July, 1987 except for dismissal of an application,\n\ndated 30th June, 1983 filed by the prosecution for reinvestigation of the case,\n\nwhen the case was transferred from Muzaffarpur to Patna.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                                     2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">\f4. On 7th December, 1990, the appellant filed a petition under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 482</a>\n\n   Cr.P.C. before the Patna High Court against the order passed by the Special\n\n   Judge, Muzaffarpur taking cognizance of the said offences, on the ground\n\n   that the Inspector of Police, who had conducted the investigations, on the\n\n   basis whereof the chargesheet was filed, had no jurisdiction to do so.\n\n   Accepting the plea of the appellant, the High Court, vide order dated 7th\n\n   December, 1990 quashed the order of Magistrate taking cognizance, with a\n\n   direction to the prosecution to complete the investigation within a period of\n\n   three months from receipt of the order, by an officer of the rank of a Deputy\n\n   Superintendent of Police or any other officer duly authorised in this behalf.\n\n   No further progress was made in the case and the matter rested there till the\n\n   year 1998, when the appellant filed yet another petition under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 482</a>\n\n   Cr.P.C., giving rise to the present appeal, seeking quashing of the entire\n\n   criminal proceedings pending against him mainly on the ground that re-\n\n   investigation in the matter had not been initiated even after a lapse of seven\n\n   and a half years of the order passed by the High Court on 7th December, 1990\n\n   and in the process the appellant had suffered undue harassment for over\n\n   eighteen years. On 20th November, 1998, the petition was admitted to final\n\n   hearing.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">5. Ultimately, when the matter was called out for final hearing after almost nine\n\n   years, on 11th May, 2007, counsel for the vigilance department sought time to\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                                    3</span>\n\f  seek instructions in regard to the stage of investigations.             In furtherance\n\n  thereof, an affidavit was filed on behalf of the prosecution, inter alia, stating\n\n  that the Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarpur vide his letter dated 22nd\n\n  February, 2007 had directed the Deputy Superintendent of Police to complete\n\n  the   investigations.   In    pursuance   of     the   said   direction,    the   Deputy\n\n  Superintendent started investigations on 28th February, 2007 and ultimately\n\n  filed a fresh chargesheet on 1st May, 2007.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">6. As noted earlier, the High Court has dismissed the petition. Acknowledging\n\n  that there has been substantial delay in conclusion of proceedings against the\n\n  appellant and some prejudice may have been caused to the appellant in his\n\n  professional career on account of continuance of criminal case against him as\n\n  he was deprived of the promotion in the meantime, the learned Judge finally\n\n  concluded that this reason by itself was not sufficient to quash the entire\n\n  criminal   proceedings       against   him,    particularly   keeping      in   view   the\n\n  seriousness of the allegations. The learned Judge, however, directed the trial\n\n  court to conduct the trial in the matter on a day to day basis and complete\n\n  the same within a period of four months. The Court also directed that if the\n\n  sanction of the State Government had not yet been obtained, the question of\n\n  grant of sanction shall be considered by the State Government within a period\n\n  of six weeks from the date of the order.               Being aggrieved by the said\n\n  decision, the appellant has preferred the present appeal.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                                               4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">\f7. Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant vehemently submitted\n\n  that though a period of about twenty eight years, since the registration of the\n\n  case against the appellant, has elapsed, the trial according to law is yet to\n\n  commence and thus, the appellant has been deprived of his constitutional\n\n  right to speedy investigation and trial flowing from <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_9\">Article 21</a> of the\n\n  Constitution.     It was pleaded that having regard to the prevailing\n\n  circumstances and the fact that it is still not clear whether the requisite\n\n  sanction to prosecute the appellant has been granted or not, this is eminently\n\n  a fit case where the chargesheet against the appellant ought to be quashed.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">8. Per contra, learned counsel for the State contended that in view of the\n\n  seriousness of the offences alleged against the appellant, the High Court was\n\n  fully justified in dismissing the petition by applying the correct principles to\n\n  be kept in view while exercising its inherent powers under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 482</a>\n\n  Cr.P.C. The learned counsel also submitted that the delay in trial was also, to\n\n  some extent, attributable to the appellant because it was he who had\n\n  belatedly questioned the jurisdiction of the investigating officer.         Learned\n\n  counsel also urged that the prosecution could not be held responsible for\n\n  delay in trial on account of transfer of the case from Muzaffarpur to Patna\n\n  and again from Patna to Muzaffarpur.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">9. Before   adverting   to   the   core   issue,   viz.   whether   under   the   given\n\n  circumstances the appellant was entitled to approach the High Court for\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                                          5</span>\n\f    getting the entire criminal proceedings against him quashed, it would be\n\n    appropriate to notice the circumstances and the parameters enunciated and\n\n    reiterated by this Court in a series of decisions under which the High Court\n\n    can exercise its inherent powers under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_11\">Sections 482</a> Cr.P.C. to prevent abuse\n\n    of process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. The power\n\n    possessed by the High Court under the said provision is undoubtedly very\n\n    wide but it has to be exercised in appropriate cases, ex debito justitiae to do real\n\n    and substantial justice for the administration of which alone the courts exist.\n\n    The inherent powers do not confer an arbitrary jurisdiction on the High Court\n\n    to act according to whim or caprice. It is trite to state that the said powers\n\n    have to be exercised sparingly and with circumspection only where the court\n\n    is convinced, on the basis of material on record, that allowing the\n\n    proceedings to continue would be an abuse of the process of the court or\n\n    that the ends of justice require that the proceedings ought to be quashed.\n\n    [See: Kurukshetra University &amp; Anr. Vs. State of Haryana &amp; Anr.1, Janata Dal Vs. H.S.\n\n    Chowdhary &amp; Ors.2, and State of Haryana &amp; Ors. Vs. Bhajan Lal &amp; Ors.3]\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">10. In Bhajan Lal's case (supra), while formulating as many as seven categories of\n\n    cases by way of illustration, wherein the extra-ordinary power under the\n\n    afore-stated provisions could be exercised by the High Court to prevent\n\n    abuse of process of the court, it was clarified that it was not possible to lay\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">1</span>\n  (1977) 4 SCC 451\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">2</span>\n  (1992) 4 SCC 305\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">3</span>\n  1992 Supp (1) SCC 335\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                                                            6</span>\n\f      down precise and inflexible guidelines or any rigid formula or to give an\n\n      exhaustive list of the circumstances in which such power could be exercised.\n\n      This view has been reiterated in a catena of subsequent decisions.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">11. We are of the opinion that having regard to the factual scenario, noted above,\n\n      and for the reasons stated hereafter, it is a fit case where the High Court\n\n      should have exercised its powers under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 482</a> Cr.P.C.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">12. Time and again this Court has emphasized the need for speedy investigations\n\n      and trial as both are mandated by the letter and spirit of the provisions of the\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/445276/\" id=\"a_13\">Cr.P.C</a>. (In particular, <a href=\"/doc/1331755/\" id=\"a_14\">Sections 197</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1331755/\" id=\"a_15\">173</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1331755/\" id=\"a_16\">309</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1331755/\" id=\"a_17\">437</a> (6) and 468 etc.) and the\n\n      constitutional protection enshrined in <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_18\">Article 21</a> of the Constitution. Inspired\n\n      by the broad sweep and content of <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_19\">Article 21</a> as interpreted by a seven-Judge\n\n      Bench of this Court in Maneka Gandhi Vs. Union of India &amp; Anr.4, in Hussainara\n\n      Khatoon &amp; Ors. Vs. Home Secretary, State of Bihar5, this Court had observed that\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_20\">Article 21</a> confers a fundamental right on every person not to be deprived of\n\n      his life or liberty except according to procedure established by law; that such\n\n      procedure is not some semblance of a procedure but the procedure should\n\n      be 'reasonable, fair and just'; and therefrom flows, without doubt, the right to\n\n      speedy trial. It was also observed that no procedure which does not ensure a\n\n      reasonably quick trial can be regarded as 'reasonable, fair or just' and it\n\n      would fall foul of <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_21\">Article 21.</a>   The Court clarified that speedy trial means\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">4</span>\n    (1978) 1 SCC 248\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">5</span>\n    (1980) 1 SCC 81\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                                                                         7</span>\n\f      reasonably expeditious trial which is an integral and essential part of the\n\n      fundamental right to life and liberty enshrined in <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_22\">Article 21.</a>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">13. The exposition of <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_23\">Article 21</a> in Hussainara Khatoon's case (supra) was\n\n      exhaustively considered afresh by the Constitution Bench in Abdul Rehman\n\n      Antulay &amp; Ors. Vs. R.S. Nayak &amp; Anr.6. Referring to a number of decisions of this\n\n      Court and the American precedents on the Sixth Amendment of their\n\n      Constitution, making the right to a speedy and public trial a constitutional\n\n      guarantee, the Court formulated as many as eleven propositions with a note\n\n      of caution that these were not exhaustive and were meant only to serve as\n\n      guidelines. For the sake of brevity, we do not propose to reproduce all the\n\n      said propositions and it would suffice to note the gist thereof. These are: (i)\n\n      fair, just and reasonable procedure implicit in <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_24\">Article 21</a> of the Constitution\n\n      creates a right in the accused to be tried speedily; (ii) right to speedy trial\n\n      flowing from <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_25\">Article 21</a> encompasses all the stages, namely the stage of\n\n      investigation, inquiry, trial, appeal, revision and retrial; (iii) in every case\n\n      where the speedy trial is alleged to have been infringed, the first question to\n\n      be put and answered is -- who is responsible for the delay?; (iv) while\n\n      determining whether undue delay has occurred (resulting in violation of right\n\n      to speedy trial) one must have regard to all the attendant circumstances,\n\n      including nature of offence, number of accused and witnesses, the work-load\n\n      of the court concerned, prevailing local conditions and so on--what is called,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">6</span>\n    (1992) 1 SCC 225\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                                                                                          8</span>\n\fthe systemic delays; (v) each and every delay does not necessarily prejudice\n\nthe accused. Some delays may indeed work to his advantage.             However,\n\ninordinately long delay may be taken as presumptive proof of prejudice. In\n\nthis context, the fact of incarceration of accused will also be a relevant fact.\n\nThe prosecution should not be allowed to become a persecution. But when\n\ndoes the prosecution become persecution, again depends upon the facts of a\n\ngiven case; (vi) ultimately, the court has to balance and weigh several relevant\n\nfactors--'balancing test' or 'balancing process'--and determine in each case\n\nwhether the right to speedy trial has been denied; (vii) Ordinarily speaking,\n\nwhere the court comes to a conclusion that right to speedy trial of an accused\n\nhas been infringed the charges or the conviction, as the case may be, shall be\n\nquashed.     But this is not the only course open and having regard to the\n\nnature of offence and other circumstances when the court feels that quashing\n\nof proceedings cannot be in the interest of justice, it is open to the court to\n\nmake appropriate orders, including fixing the period for completion of trial;\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">(viii) it is neither advisable nor feasible to prescribe any outer time-limit for\n\nconclusion of all criminal proceedings. In every case of complaint of denial of\n\nright to speedy trial, it is primarily for the prosecution to justify and explain\n\nthe delay.   At the same time, it is the duty of the court to weigh all the\n\ncircumstances of a given case before pronouncing upon the complaint; (ix) an\n\nobjection based on denial of right to speedy trial and for relief on that\n\naccount, should first be addressed to the High Court. Even if the High Court\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">                                                                                    9</span>\n\f    entertains such a plea, ordinarily it should not stay the proceedings, except in\n\n    a case of grave and exceptional nature. Such proceedings in the High Court\n\n    must, however, be disposed of on a priority basis.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">14. Notwithstanding elaborate enunciation of <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_26\">Article 21</a> of the Constitution in\n\n    Abdul Rehman Antulay (supra), and rejection of the fervent plea of proponents of\n\n    right to speedy trial for laying down time-limits as bar beyond which a\n\n    criminal trial shall not proceed, pronouncements of this Court in \"Common\n\n    Cause\" A Registered Society Vs. Union of India (UOI) &amp; Ors.7, \"Common Cause\", A\n\n    Registered Society Vs. Union of India &amp; Ors.8, Raj Deo Sharma Vs. State of Bihar9 and Raj\n\n    Deo Sharma II Vs. State of Bihar10 gave rise to some confusion on the question\n\n    whether an outer time limit for conclusion of criminal proceedings could be\n\n    prescribed whereafter the trial court would be obliged to terminate the\n\n    proceedings and necessarily acquit or discharge the accused. The confusion\n\n    on the issue was set at rest by a seven-Judge Bench of this court in P.\n\n    Ramachandra Rao Vs. State of Karnataka11. Speaking for the majority, R.C. Lahoti,\n\n    J. (as his Lordship then was) while affirming that the dictum in A.R. Antulay's\n\n    case (supra) as correct and the one which still holds the field and the\n\n    propositions emerging from <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_27\">Article 21</a> of the Constitution and expounding\n\n    the right to speedy trial laid down as guidelines in the said case adequately\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">7</span>\n  (1996) 4 SCC 33\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">8</span>\n  (1996) 6 SCC 775\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">9</span>\n  (1998) 7 SCC 507\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">10</span>\n   (1999) 7 SCC 604\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">11</span>\n   (2002) 4 SCC 578\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_21\">                                                                                                10</span>\n\f   take care of right to speedy trial, it was held that guidelines laid down in the\n\n   A.R. Antulay's case (supra) are not exhaustive but only illustrative. They are not\n\n   intended to operate as hard and fast rules or to be applied as a strait-jacket\n\n   formula. Their applicability would depend on the fact-situation of each case\n\n   as it is difficult to foresee all situations and no generalization can be made. It\n\n   has also been held that it is neither advisable, nor feasible, nor judicially\n\n   permissible to draw or prescribe an outer limit for conclusion of all criminal\n\n   proceedings. Nonetheless, the criminal courts should exercise their available\n\n   powers such as those under <a href=\"/doc/1645292/\" id=\"a_28\">Sections 309</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1780550/\" id=\"a_29\">311</a> and <a href=\"/doc/729109/\" id=\"a_30\">258</a> of Cr.P.C. to\n\n   effectuate the right to speedy trial. In appropriate cases, jurisdiction of the\n\n   High Court under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_31\">Section 482</a> Cr.P.C. and Articles 226 and 227 of the\n\n   Constitution can be invoked seeking appropriate relief or suitable directions.\n\n   The outer limits or power of limitation expounded in the aforenoted\n\n   judgments were held to be not in consonance with the legislative intent.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">15. It is, therefore, well settled that the right to speedy trial in all criminal\n\n   persecutions is an inalienable right under <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_32\">Article 21</a> of the Constitution. This\n\n   right is applicable not only to the actual proceedings in court but also\n\n   includes within its sweep the preceding police investigations as well.        The\n\n   right to speedy trial extends equally to all criminal prosecutions and is not\n\n   confined to any particular category of cases. In every case, where the right to\n\n   speedy trial is alleged to have been infringed, the court has to perform the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_22\">                                                                                        11</span>\n\f  balancing act upon taking into consideration all the attendant circumstances,\n\n  enumerated above, and determine in each case whether the right to speedy\n\n  trial has been denied in a given case.       Where the court comes to the\n\n  conclusion that the right to speedy trial of an accused has been infringed, the\n\n  charges or the conviction, as the case may be, may be quashed unless the\n\n  court feels that having regard to the nature of offence and other relevant\n\n  circumstances, quashing of proceedings may not be in the interest of justice.\n\n  In such a situation, it is open to the court to make an appropriate order as it\n\n  may deem just and equitable including fixation of time frame for conclusion\n\n  of trial.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">16. Tested on the touchstone of the broad principles enumerated above, we are\n\n  convinced that in the present case appellant's constitutional right recognised\n\n  under <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_33\">Article 21</a> of the Constitution stands violated. It is manifest from the\n\n  facts narrated above that in the first instance investigations were conducted\n\n  by an officer, who had no jurisdiction to do so and the appellant cannot be\n\n  accused of delaying the trial merely because he successfully exercised his\n\n  right to challenge an illegal investigation. Be that as it may, admittedly the\n\n  High Court vide its order dated 7th September, 1990 had directed the\n\n  prosecution to complete the investigation within a period of three months\n\n  from the date of the said order but nothing happened till 27th February, 2007\n\n  when, after receipt of notice in the second petition preferred by the appellant\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_23\">                                                                                    12</span>\n\fcomplaining about delay in investigation, the Superintendent of Police,\n\nMuzaffarpur directed the Deputy Superintendent of Police to complete the\n\ninvestigation. It was only thereafter that a fresh chargesheet is stated to have\n\nbeen filed on 1st May, 2007. It is also pertinent to note that even till date,\n\nlearned counsel for the State is not sure whether a sanction for prosecuting\n\nthe appellant is required and if so, whether it has been granted or not. We\n\nhave no hesitation in holding that at least for the period from 7th December,\n\n1990 till 28th February, 2007 there is no explanation whatsoever for the delay\n\nin investigation. Even the direction issued by the High Court seems to have\n\nhad no effect on the prosecution and they slept over the matter for almost\n\nseventeen years. Nothing could be pointed out by the State, far from being\n\nestablished to show that the delay in investigation or trial was in any way\n\nattributable to the appellant.    The prosecution has failed to show any\n\nexceptional circumstance which could possibly be taken into consideration\n\nfor condoning a callous and inordinate delay of more than two decades in\n\ninvestigations and the trial. The said delay cannot, in any way, be said to be\n\narising from any default on the part of the appellant. Thus, on facts in hand,\n\nin our opinion, the stated delay clearly violates the constitutional guarantee\n\nof a speedy investigation and trial under <a href=\"/doc/1199182/\" id=\"a_34\">Article 21</a> of the Constitution. We\n\nfeel that under these circumstances, further continuance of criminal\n\nproceedings, pending against the appellant in the court of Special Judge,\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_24\">                                                                                   13</span>\n\f   Muzaffarpur, is unwarranted and despite the fact that allegations against him\n\n   are quite serious, they deserve to be quashed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">17. Consequently, the appeal is allowed and the proceedings pending against the\n\n   appellant in Special Case No. 29 of 1987 are hereby quashed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">                                        .................................................J.\n                                (D.K. JAIN)\n\n\n\n                                       ................................................J.\n                                (R.M. LODHA)\nNEW DELHI;\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">JANUARY 23, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_25\">                                                                                              14</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":10,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"selection committee ","formInput":"selection%20committee%20"},{"value":"viva voce","formInput":"viva%20voce"},{"value":"viva","formInput":"viva"},{"value":"waiting list","formInput":"waiting%20list"},{"value":"selection process","formInput":"selection%20process"},{"value":"169","formInput":"169"},{"value":"the director general of police ","formInput":"the%20director%20general%20of%20police%20"},{"value":"vacancies to be filled up","formInput":"vacancies%20to%20be%20filled%20up"},{"value":"private respondents","formInput":"private%20respondents"},{"value":"raju ramachandran","formInput":"raju%20ramachandran"},{"value":"\\\"ramachandran\\\"","formInput":"%5C%22ramachandran%5C%22"},{"value":"chandran","formInput":"chandran"},{"value":"advertised post","formInput":"advertised%20post"},{"value":"future vacancy","formInput":"future%20vacancy"},{"value":"direct recruitment","formInput":"direct%20recruitment"},{"value":"oral interview","formInput":"oral%20interview"}],"citeList":[{"tid":45406500,"url":null,"title":"Gujarat State Dy.
