Chaman Lal vs Municipal Corporation Of Delhi on 13 January, 2010"},{"tid":92516905,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=39180","title":"K.Vijayaraj vs K.Kumaran on 27 September, 2012"},{"tid":93936830,"url":"http://jhr.nic.in/hcjudge/data/50-5900-2011-02082012.pdf","title":"Ranjeet Singh & Ors vs State Of Jharkhand & Ors on 2 August, 2012"},{"tid":62574539,"url":null,"title":"Biswajit Maji & Anr vs Coal India Ltd. & Ors on 31 March, 2014"},{"tid":90479048,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=35620","title":"K.Kumaran vs The Government Of Tamil Nadu on 6 March, 2012"}],"tid":1297488,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"s","lastname":"sinha","numcitedby":72,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33581","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Amlan Jyoti Borooah vs State Of Assam &amp; Ors on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: S Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, V.S. Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                     REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 387             OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP (C) No.10726 of 2006)\n\n\nAmlan Jyoti Borooah                                     ... Appellant\n\n                                   Versus\n\nState of Assam &amp; Ors.                                   ... Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. Sinha, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    This appeal is directed against a judgment and order dated 5.5.2006\n\npassed by a Division Bench of the Guwahati High Court in Writ Appeal\n\nNo.54 of 2004 whereby and whereunder the judgment and order dated\n\n12.2.2004 passed by a learned Single Judge of the said Court was modified.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    The basic fact of the matter is not in dispute.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                    2</span><p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      The Director General of Police, Assam published an advertisement\n\ninviting applications for 112 vacancies which were likely to arise in the post\n\nof Sub-Inspector of Police on or about 6.9.1997, the relevant clauses laying\n\ndown the procedures therefor, were as under :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"On selection candidates will be put through a\n             prescribed course of training for one year at the\n             Assam Police Training College. Dergaon and\n             during the period of training they will be treated as\n             cadre S.I. of Police. The cadets who fail in the\n             final examination after training at the Police\n             Training College will be liable to be discharged.\n             The candidates securing top positions in the final\n             Examination will be considered for U.B. and the\n             rest for A.B. subject to the 20 points Roster.\n             All candidates possessing necessary qualification\n             will appear in a written test which will comprise of\n             one paper of 3 (three) hours duration. Questions\n             will be on subjects like General Knowledge,\n             History      Science,       Basic      Mathematics,\n             Comprehension etc. Venue of the test will be\n             decided by the Supdt. Of Police of the Districts in\n             which candidates are presently residing as shown\n             in the application form. They will contact Police\n             Reserve of the Districts for the purpose and\n             ascertain dates.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">             Those candidates who qualify in the written test\n             will be required to appear in a physical test and\n             interview to be conducted centrally for which date\n             will be notified later.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">             The candidates will have to appear in the written\n             test, physical test and interview at their own\n             expenses.\"\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                     3</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_10\">4.    Pursuant thereto or in furtherance thereof, appellant as also the\n\nprivate respondents applied therefor. They were asked by a call letter dated\n\n18.3.1998 to appear at the written test on 25th/26th April, 1998 and physical\n\nability test on 27th/28th April, 1998. Indisputably, the written test was held\n\non 26.4.1998.    It, however, appears that despite laying down the said\n\nprocedures in the advertisement, a decision was taken by the Selection\n\nCommittee to call such candidates for interview only who had acquired 40%\n\nin the written test. Call letters were issued accordingly, a sample copy\n\nwhereof is as under :\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">             \"You are requested to appear in the interview to be\n             held in the venue noted below alongwith original\n             certificates.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">                   No TA/DA would be paid for appearing in\n             the above interview.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">                    In case you are selected in the interview you\n             will be called for physical test for final selection.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_11\">5.    Appellants as also the private respondents amongst others appeared in\n\nthe interview before the duly constituted Interview Boards. The Selection\n\nCommittee short listed 1803 candidates in order of merit. The said select\n\nlist is said to have been published and hung on the notice board of the office\n\nof the Director General of Police on 1.2.2000. Appellant's position in the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                       4</span>\n\nselect list was 750. He obtained 32 points in the interview and 92 in the\n\nwritten test, total being 124 marks.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      It is stated that the life of the said select list was two years.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">6.    Allegedly, on 2.3.2000, the Inspector General of Police requested the\n\nHome Department of the Government of Assam to obtain sanction of the\n\nState Level Empowered Committee for appointment of 174 Sub-Inspector\n\nof Police pursuant whereto the Home Department accorded sanction\n\ntherefor.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">7.    Those candidates who were found eligible to be called for physical\n\nability test were asked to appear therein which was held on 19.2.2000. On\n\nor about 4.7.2000, 169 candidates who had cleared the physical test/medical\n\ntest were appointed on the post of Sub-Inspector of Police.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">      The said order, appointing the aforementioned 169 posts was not the\n\nsubject matter of the challenge before the High Court. However, it appears\n\nthat during the currency of the life of the select list, the Director General of\n\nPolice, by a letter dated 21.12.2000, addressed to the Commissioner-\n\nSecretary to the Home Department, Dispur, asked for sanction of the State\n\nLevel Empowered Committee (SLEC) to fill up 77 additional vacancies that\n\nhad arisen from the aforementioned select list, stating :\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                    5</span>\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">             \"I am writing to inform you that presently, there\n             are 2154 number of vacancies in the rank of\n             constables (Battalion 1136, District AB 504,\n             District UB 514) and 77 Nos. of vacancies in the\n             rank of S.Is in the Assam Police. These are all\n             functional posts. In the context of insurgency\n             situation obtained in the state and that there will\n             be Assembly Election within the next four months,\n             we will need to mobilize all the manpower. In\n             view of this, it is requested that permission of the\n             State Level Empowered Committee may be\n             conveyed to us to fill up these vacancies by direct\n             recruitment from the results of the records of the\n             previous recruitment rallies already available with\n             us. Government orders on the same may kindly be\n             issued immediately.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_18\">8.    Allegedly, urgency and compelling reasons for which the said\n\nvacancies were to be filled up was vast deteriorating law and order situation\n\nin the State as also sudden spurt of extremists related incidents of violence.\n\nIt was furthermore stated that in the Brahmaputra vally, the ULFA and the\n\nNDFB had intensified their subversive activities and resorted to widespread\n\nkilling and extortion spree in the hill district of Karbi Anglong and the NC\n\nHills where the UPDS and DHD had already been active.                 It was\n\nfurthermore contended that the NSCN (IM) and the Kuki militants also\n\nresorted to sporadic acts of violence in the said two districts. According to\n\nthe State, during the period 1.7.2000 to 31.12.2000 356 extremists related\n\nincidents took place and between the period 1.1.2001 to 30.6.2001, 259\n\nsuch incidents took place wherein a large number of civilians, force\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                    6</span>\n\npersonnel and extremists were killed. It was contended that the number of\n\nkidnapping which took place during the aforementioned period was 70.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">9.     An office note was thereafter put up for consideration of the Director\n\nGeneral of Police in respect of 88 vacancies which had arisen by that time in\n\nthe rank of Sub-Inspector of Police. Approval was sought for from the\n\nDirector General of Police as to whether the said vacancies be filled up from\n\namongst the candidates whose names appear in the aforementioned select\n\nlist from Serial No.175 onwards as the list had already been acted upon upto\n\nserial No.174. The Director General of Police is said to have accorded the\n\nnecessary approval.     Pursuant thereto, the Home Commissioner was\n\nrequested to sanction 80 posts in the existing vacancies in the State in place\n\nof 77 vacancies. The said select list was again published on 8.1.2001. 84\n\ncandidates out of the said select list were asked to appear in the physical\n\nability test on 22.1.2001. Three candidates failed to appear in the physical\n\ntest and four others failed to clear the physical test and therafter 77\n\ncandidates were called to appear for the medical test on 25.1.20001 out of\n\nwhich 75 candidates were found suitable for appointment. The Deputy\n\nSecretary to the Government of Assam, Home Department, thereafter by a\n\nletter dated 20.2.2001 conveyed the sanction of the SLEC for direct\n\nrecruitment in respect of 80 vacancies to the post of Sub-Inspector of Police,\n\nstating :\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                    7</span><p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">            \"In inviting a reference to your letter cited above, I\n            am directed to inform you that the Personnel (B)\n            Department has obtained and conveyed the\n            clearance of the SLEC for direct recruitment of 80\n            (UB) Sub-Inspector of Police by observing\n            necessary formalities as required in this regard.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">                  This issue as per endorsement of the\n            Personnel (B) Department communicated vide\n            their consulted U/O No.141/2001, dated\n            17.2.2001.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_21\">10.   Appellant herein and some other candidates thereafter filed a writ\n\npetition before the High Court impuging the selection of 84 candidates to\n\nthe post of Sub-Inspector of Police in February 2001.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">11.   Indisputably, during pendency of the said writ petition, posts were\n\nfilled up as 75 persons who had been found suitable were offered\n\nappointment to the post of Sub-Inspector of Police on 2.3.2001.       The\n\nrespondents who were 74 in number had accepted the said offer of\n\nappointment on 3.3.2001; one of them, however, did not join the post. They\n\nwere sent for and completed their training. Indisputably, they have been\n\nworking in the said post.     By reason of a judgment and order dated\n\n12.2.2004 a learned Single Judge of the said Court, however, set aside the\n\nappointment of 54 candidates, opining :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">            \"Surely, if the physical test constituted a\n            competitive component of the selection process,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                    8</span>\n\n            calling the 84/76 persons for the physical test on\n            the basis of the marks secured by them in the\n            written test and oral interview and in ignoring the\n            petitioners was fatal. All the candidates were not\n            judged by a uniform process; those appointed and\n            those left out were assessed by two different\n            yardsticks, discrimination, therefore, is writ large.\n            The possibility of the petitioners, who were not\n            appointed being placed higher than those\n            eventually appointed had the petitioners also been\n            assigned marks in the physical test cannot be ruled\n            out, particularly, when the records produced reveal\n            that the difference of the total marks secured by\n            the candidates in the written test and oral\n            interview was exceedingly small. Illustratively,\n            note may be taken of the fact that not only a large\n            number of candidates secured the same marks, the\n            first of the 84 candidates called for the physical\n            test had secured 147 marks in the written test and\n            oral interview whereas the last candidate out of the\n            group of 84/76 called for the physical test had\n            secured 146 marks. The petitioner in WP (C)\n            No.628/01, who secured the 750th position,\n            secured 124 marks, i.e., a difference of only 22\n            marks in comparison to the last of the candidate\n            appointed. The possibility of an entirely different\n            picture emerging, if the petitioners have been\n            called for the physical test, therefore, looms large.\n            For the aforesaid reasons, this Court has no\n            hesitation in reaching the conclusion that the\n            fundamental rights of the petitioners under\n            Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution have been\n            infringed by the procedure adopted. The yardstick\n            applied did not result in a correct determination of\n            the inter se merit of all the candidates for the\n            purpose of securing appointment.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_24\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">      Contention of the respondents herein that on equitable grounds, their\n\nappointment should not be interfered with, was rejected, stating :\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                   9</span>\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">            \"Equity must not be equated with compassion.\n            Equitable principles must emanate from facts\n            which by themselves are unusual and peculiar. A\n            balance has to be struck and the Court must be\n            cautious to ensure that its endeavour to do equity\n            does not amount to judicial benevolence or\n            acquiescence of established violation of\n            fundamental rights and the principles of Rule of\n            law.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">      It was directed :\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_13\">            \"For all the aforesaid reasons, this Court is unable\n            to save any of the appointments of the 84/76 Sub-\n            Inspectors of Police made on 1.3.2001. All such\n            appointments, therefore, shall stand interfered\n            with. In view of the conclusion reached, no relief\n            to the petitioners by directing consideration of\n            their cases afresh, will also be possible. However,\n            in the totality of the facts and circumstances of the\n            case, it is considered appropriate to direct that in\n            the fresh selection process that will now have to be\n            initiated by the State, if any of the candidates, who\n            had taken part in the earlier selection process, opts\n            to apply for the posts that may be advertised,\n            suitable relaxation of age, if required will be made\n            by the authorities.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_14\">12.   Three Writ Appeals were preferred thereagainst. By reason of the\n\nimpugned judgment dated 5.5.2006, a Division Bench of the High Court,\n\nwhile upholding the appointment of the private respondents, set aside the\n\njudgment of the learned Single Judge directing them to fill up remaining 14\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                    10</span>\n\nvacancies by holding physical and medical test of the candidates from the\n\nselect list containing the names of 1803 candidates.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_26\">13.   Appellant herein filed Special Leave Petition on 3.7.2006. However,\n\neven prior thereto, i.e. on 24.6.2006 in terms of the judgment of the Division\n\nBench of the High Court, an advertisement was issued in a local daily \"The\n\nAssam Tribune\".      Indisputably, appellant with others appeared in the\n\nphysical test, of course, without prejudice to his rights and contentions\n\nherein. He secured only 20 marks (144 marks in aggregate) in the physical\n\ntest which was lower than the marks secured by the last general category\n\ncandidate who had secured 153.5 marks.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">14.   Mr. Raju Ramachandran, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf\n\nof the appellant, would submit that the Division Bench of the High Court\n\ncommitted a serious error in passing the impugned judgment in so far as it\n\nfailed to take into consideration the importance of holding a physical test\n\nbefore preparation of the select list.     The learned counsel urged that\n\narbitrariness on the part of the Selection Committee is apparent from the\n\nfact that the order of holding tests kept on changing as the physical ability\n\ntest was pushed to the background. It was furthermore submitted that the\n\nDivision Bench of the High Court did not assign sufficient and cogent\n\nreasons for interfering with the well considered judgment of the learned\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                    11</span>\n\nSingle Judge and proceeded to modify the same without any applicant of\n\nmind.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">        Our attention was moreover drawn to the fact that the purported\n\nreasons for modification which were enumerated in paragraph 12 of the\n\nimpugned judgment really contain the statement of facts and, thus, the same\n\nis wholly unsustainable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">15.     Mr. P.K. Goswami, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nprivate respondents and Mr. Phukan, appearing on behalf of the State, on\n\nthe other hand, would contend that the appellant, in the facts and\n\ncircumstances of this case, must be held to be estopped and precluded from\n\nraising any contention with regard to the validity or otherwise of the\n\nprocedure for selection adopted by the Selection Committee as he had\n\nparticipated in the Selection process without any demur whatsoever.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">16.     Mr. Manish Goswami, learned counsel appearing on behalf of\n\nrespondent No.157, Rajesh Kumar Das, would draw our attention to the fact\n\nthat the said respondent was an NCC candidate and as such was entitled to a\n\npreferential treatment. He, having been ignored, filed a writ petition being\n\nWP(C) No.1757 of 2000 and by an order dated 7.4.2000, a learned Judge of\n\nthe High Court passed an interim order to the following effect :\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                    12</span>\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_15\">             \"Mr. Uzir, learned counsel for the petitioner\n             submitted that an advertisement was published\n             inviting applications for filling up of vacant posts\n             of Sub-Inspector (UB), Assam Police Force and it\n             was clearly stated in the advertisement that\n             preference will be given to those candidates who\n             possess N.C.C. `C' certificate. The petitioner also\n             possesses N.C.C. `C' certificate and yet he did not\n             get preference to the selection. The petitioner had\n             therefore, challenged the selection to the post of\n             Sub-Inspector of Police (UB).\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_16\">             As an interim measure, I direct that one post of\n             Sub-Inspector (UB) out of the 31 posts advertised\n             shall be kept vacant till pendency of the writ\n             petition.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_34\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">      The said writ petition was allowed by a judgment and order dated\n\n10.8.2000, directing :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_17\">             \"While issuing a notice of motion, this Court by an\n             order dated 7.4.2000 passed an interim order\n             directing that one post of Sub-Inspector (UB) out\n             of the 31 such posts advertised shall be kept\n             vacant till the disposal of this writ petition.\n             This writ petition is finally disposed of with a\n             direction to the respondent No.2, the Director\n             General of Police, Government of Assam, to\n             consider the case of the petitioner for appointment\n             against the post of Sub-Inspector (UB) directed to\n             be kept vacant by this Court's interim order dated\n             7.4.2000, as a special case subject to verification\n             as to his antecedents in view of the fact that the\n             advertisement categorically mentioned that the\n             candidates possessing NCC certificate would be\n             given preference and the petitioner is the only\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                    13</span>\n\n             candidate who possesses NCC certificate to be\n             precise, the highest NCC `C' certificate.\n             The petitioner shall furnish a certified copy of this\n             order along with a copy of this writ petition and\n             the annexures thereto to the respondent No.2, the\n             Director General of Police, Assam, who shall\n             comply with the above direction of this court\n             within 10 (ten) days from the date of receipt of the\n             same.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_37\">17.   It is stated that pursuant thereto and in furtherance thereof only the\n\nsaid respondent had been appointed and had been working since then. Our\n\nattention was furthermore drawn to the fact that against the order of the\n\nlearned Single Judge, a writ appeal had been filed by him which is pending.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">18.   Indisputably in the advertisement, the candidates were required not\n\nonly to qualify in the written test but also the physical ability test. A plain\n\nreading of the advertisement clearly goes to show that the interview was to\n\nbe conducted only after holding of the said two tests.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">19.   In tune with the said requirements only, the candidates were asked to\n\nappear in the written test on 25/26.4.1998 and in the physical test on\n\n27/28.4.1998.   There cannot, however, be any doubt whatsoever that a\n\nSelection Committee in a given situation, may lay down a procedure for the\n\npurpose of short listing the candidates but that does not mean that for the\n\nsaid purpose the order of holding a requisite test would be changed. In\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                    14</span>\n\nterms of a decision which was taken on 7.4.1999, the Selection Committee\n\nthought to take interview prior to holding of the physical ability test.\n\nPhysical ability test keeping in view the nature of the job required to be\n\nperformed by the candidates was an extremely important one. Passing in\n\nthe physical ability test is a sine qua non for selection of the candidates in\n\nthe post of Sub-Inspector of Police. It was indeed a competitive test. The\n\nmerit list, thus, should have been prepared not only on the basis of the\n\nwritten test and interview but also the physical ability test. The Selection\n\nCommittee, in our opinion, committed a serious error in changing the order\n\nof holding the tests. The learned Single Judge, therefore, was correct in\n\narriving at a conclusion that physical ability test should have been held prior\n\nto holding of the interview.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_40\">\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">20.   The question which, however, arises for consideration is as to\n\nwhether despite the same, we, in exercise of our jurisdiction under <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_1\">Article\n\n136</a> of the Constitution of India, should interfere with the impugned\n\njudgment. Appellant concededly did not question the appointment 169\n\ncandidates. It is idle to contend that he was not aware thereof.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">      If he was to challenge the validity and/or legality of the entire select\n\nlist in its entirety, he should have also questioned the recruitment of 169\n\ncandidates which took place as far back as on 4.7.2000.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">\f                                      15</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">       Appellant was aware of his position in the select list. He was also\n\naware of the change in the procedure adopted by the Selection Committee.\n\nHe appeared at the interview without any demur whatsoever although was\n\nnot called to appear for the physical ability test prior thereto.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_44\">       Appellant chose to question the appointment of 77 candidates not\n\nonly on the premise that the procedure adopted by the Selection Committee\n\nwas illegal but also on the premise that no new vacancy could have been\n\nfilled up from the select list.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_45\">21.    Appellant, in our opinion, having accepted the change in the selection\n\nprocedure sub silentio, by not questioning the appointment of 169\n\ncandidates, in our considered opinion, cannot now be permitted to turn\n\nround and contend that the procedure adopted was illegal. He is estopped\n\nand precluded from doing so.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_46\">       <a href=\"/doc/634160/\" id=\"a_2\">In Ashok Kumar Yadav and Others v. State of Haryana and Others</a>\n\n[(1985) 4 SCC 417], a Constitution Bench of this Court has stated that a\n\nviva voce examination plays an important role in the matter of selection of\n\ncandidates in responsible posts. So far as the post of a Sub-Inspector is\n\nconcerned, he not only must have educational qualification as prescribed in\n\nthe advertisement but also must have a good presence of mind and other\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">\f                                     16</span>\n\nqualities to meet the exigencies of situation. It, however, does not mean\n\nthat the physical ability test should be relegated to a back seat.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_47\">      The question came up for consideration again in <a href=\"/doc/42575583/\" id=\"a_3\">State of U.P. v.\n\nRafiquddin and Others</a> [(1987) Supp. SCC 401], wherein it was held :\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_18\">                 \"...Commission is required to judge the\n             suitability of a candidate on the basis of\n             sufficiently high marks obtained by a candidate in\n             the viva voce test, it has to fix some percentage of\n             marks which in its opinion may be sufficient to\n             assess the suitability of a candidate. In the absence\n             of a fixed norm, there could be no uniformity in\n             assessing suitability of candidates in the viva voce\n             test. The Commission had therefore power to fix\n             the norm and in the instant case it had fixed 35 per\n             cent minimum marks for viva voce test. The viva\n             voce test is a well recognised method of judging\n             the suitability of a candidate for appointment to\n             public services and this method had almost\n             universally been followed in making selection for\n             appointment to public services. Where selection is\n             made on the basis of written as well as viva voce\n             test, the final result is determined on the basis of\n             the aggregate marks. If any minimum marks either\n             in the written test or in viva voce test are fixed to\n             determine the suitability of a candidate the same\n             has to be respected. Clause (ii) of the proviso to\n             Rule 19 clearly confers power on the Commission\n             to fix minimum marks for viva voce test for\n             judging the suitability of a candidate for the\n             service. We do not find any constitutional legal\n             infirmity in the provision.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_48\">\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">\f                                   17</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_49\">      <a href=\"/doc/946842/\" id=\"a_4\">In Union of India and Others v. S. Vinodh Kumar and Others</a> [(2007)\n\n8 SCC 100], this Court held :\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_19\">               \"18. It is also well settled that those candidates\n            who had taken part in the selection process\n            knowing fully well the procedure laid down\n            therein were not entitled to question the same.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_50\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_51\">      The matter again came up for consideration before this Bench in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/51922/\" id=\"a_5\">Sadananda Halo and Others v. Momtaz Ali Sheikh and Others</a> [(2008) 4\n\nSCC 619], wherein this Bench held :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_52\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_20\">               \"59. It is also a settled position that the\n            unsuccessful candidates cannot turn back and\n            assail the selection process. There are of course\n            the exceptions carved out by this Court to this\n            general rule.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_53\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_54\">      [See also <a href=\"/doc/308891/\" id=\"a_6\">H.V. Nirmala v. Karnataka State Financial Corporation &amp;\n\nOrs</a>. [2008 (8) SCALE 315]\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_55\">22.   Submission of Mr. Raju Ramachandran that new vacancies created\n\nshould not have been filled up from the select list may now be considered.\n\nArticles 14 and 16 of the Constitution of India provide for equality in the\n\nmatter of recruitment. A large number of posts of Sub-Inspector of Police\n\nfell vacant. Advertisement was issued in the year 1997. Effective steps for\n\nfilling up the said posts by holding written examinations and interview were\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">\f                                     18</span>\n\ntaken only in 1998 onwards.         Appointments could be made of 169\n\ncandidates only on or about 4.7.2000. It is not in dispute that for filling up\n\nthe post of 112 vacancies about 6,000/- candidates applied. Processing of\n\ntheir applications and holding of written examination, viva voce\n\nexamination and physical ability test took a long time. At the first stage of\n\nthe recruitment process, 57 posts more than advertised 112 posts were filled\n\nup. Appellant did not question the legality and/or validity thereof. He\n\nshould have done the same at the earliest possible opportunity. Having\n\nregard to the emergent situation, in regard whereto we have taken note of\n\nearlier, proposal was made to increase the number of vacancies from time to\n\ntime.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_56\">\n</p><p id=\"p_57\">23.     The State in an emergent situation would subject to constitutional\n\nlimitations is entitled to take a decision which subserve a greater public\n\ninterest.   While saying so, we are not unmindful of the fact that the\n\nConstitution also demands that candidates who had acquired eligibility for\n\nrecruitment to the post in the meantime should also be given opportunities\n\nto participate in the selection process. This Court times without number had\n\nlamented the lackadaisical attitude on the part of the State to treat the matter\n\nof selection for appointment to services in a casual and cavalier manner. If\n\nno appointment could be made from 1997 to 2001, it is the State alone who\n\ncould thank itself therefor, but, unless there exists a constitutional or a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">\f                                    19</span>\n\nstatutory interdict so as to compel the Superior Court to set aside the\n\nselection which has otherwise been validly made; in exercise of their power\n\nof judicial review the same would not ordinarily be interfered therewith.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_58\">24.   Mr. Raju Ramachandran has strongly relied upon a judgment of this\n\nCourt in <a href=\"/doc/45769/\" id=\"a_7\">Union of India and Others v. B. Valluvan and Others</a> [(2006) 8\n\nSCC 686]. This Court therein opined that the life of a panel ordinarily is\n\none year.   Therein this Court noticed this Court's earlier's decision in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1574135/\" id=\"a_8\">Surinder Singh v. State of Punjab</a> [(1997) 8 SCC 488] to hold:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_21\">                \"17. The life of a panel ordinarily is one year.\n            The same can be extended only by the State and\n            that too if the statutory rule permits it to do so.\n            The High Court ordinarily would not extend the\n            life of a panel. Once a panel stands exhausted\n            upon filling up of all the posts, the question of\n            enforcing a future panel would not arise. It was for\n            the State to accept the said recommendations of\n            the Selection Committee or reject the same. As has\n            been noticed hereinbefore, all notified vacancies\n            as also the vacancy which arose in 2000 had also\n            been filled up.     As the future vacancy had\n            already been filled up in the year 2000, the\n            question of referring back to the panel prepared in\n            the year 1999 did not arise. The impugned\n            judgment, therefore, cannot be sustained.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_22\">      In that case, however, it was held:\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_23\">               \"11. The Review Bench of the High Court\n            posed unto itself a wrong question. It did not say\n            how an error apparent on the face of the record\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">\f                                     20</span>\n\n             had been committed. It did not assign sufficient or\n             cogent reason to hold as to how the original\n             application before the Tribunal would have been\n             maintainable if the petitioners had no existing\n             legal right. The 1st respondent did not have any\n             legal right to be appointed. He filed an application\n             pursuant to the said advertisement. It is not his\n             case that his application had not been considered.\n             He did not raise any plea of unfair treatment. No\n             mala fide was also alleged.\"\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_24\">      In that case, the posts more than advertised were filled up.\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_59\">25.   Yet again in <a href=\"/doc/406742/\" id=\"a_9\">State of Bihar and Others v. Amrendra Kumar Mishra</a>\n\n[(2006) 12 SCC 561], this Court took the same view, stating:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_25\">                \"Life of a panel, it is well known, remains valid\n             for a year. Once it lapses, unless an appropriate\n             order is issued by the State, no appointment can be\n             made out of the said panel.\"\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_26\">      It was furthermore held:\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_27\">                 \"13. The decisions noticed hereinbefore are\n             authorities for the proposition that even the wait\n             list must be acted upon having regard to the terms\n             of the advertisement and in any event cannot\n             remain operative beyond the prescribed period.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_28\">26.   In this case, however, the life of panel was two years. The process of\n\nfilling up the posts out of the said select list started within one year from the\n\npreparation thereof.\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">\f                                    21</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_60\">27.   <a href=\"/doc/45406500/\" id=\"a_10\">In Gujarat State Dy. Executive Engineers' Association v. State of\n\nGujarat and Others</a> [1994 Supp (2) SCC 591], this Court while opining that\n\nthe future vacancies should ordinarily not be filled up from the waiting list,\n\nhowever, observed:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_29\">                 \"Appointment in future vacancies from waiting\n             list prepared by the Commission should be\n             exception rather than the rule. It has many\n             ramifications. ... There was no contingency nor the\n             State Government had taken any decision to fill\n             the vacancies from the waiting list as it was not\n             possible for it to hold the examination nor any\n             emergent situation had arisen except the claim of\n             some of the candidates from the waiting list that\n             they should be given appointment for vacancies\n             which arose between 1980 and 1983 and between\n             1983 and 1993. ... The direction of the High Court,\n             therefore, to appoint the candidates from the\n             waiting list in the vacancies which, according to\n             its calculation, arose between the years 1980 to\n             1983 and between 1983 to 1993 cannot be\n             upheld.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_61\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_62\">      Therein, the State Government had taken any decision to fill the\n\nvacancies from the waiting list as it was not possible for it to hold the\n\nexamination nor any emergent situation had arisen except the fact that some\n\ncandidates claimed that from the waiting list they should be given\n\nappointment in the vacancies which arose between 1980 and 1983 and\n\nbetween 1983 and 1993. Exception therein had been made out in respect\n\nthereof in an emergent situation.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_21\">\f                                        22</span><p id=\"p_63\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_64\">      This case meets the said criteria.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_65\">\n</p><p id=\"p_66\">28.   Mr. Raju Ramachandran would point out that even some appointees\n\nhad got zero marks in 100 meter race. Such a question had not been raised\n\nbefore the courts below. Had such a question been raised, the respondents\n\ncould have dealt with the same. Furthermore, they were not found to be\n\nphysically handicapped of holding the post of Sub-Inspector of Police.\n\nTheir overall performance in all the events had been taken into\n\nconsideration for the purpose of finding them physically fit for appointment.\n\nThose candidates who were absent in the interview or in the physical ability\n\ntest had not been selected. It is not a case where the appellants had given a\n\ngo-by to the physically ability test.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_67\">\n</p><p id=\"p_68\">29.   For the reasons aforementioned, there is no merit in this appeal which\n\nis dismissed accordingly. However, in the facts and circumstances of this\n\ncase, there shall be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_69\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_70\">                                             ...............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_71\">                                             [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n                                             ................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_72\">                                             [V.S. Sirpurkar]\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_73\">January 23, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":11,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"anticipated vacancy","formInput":"anticipated%20vacancy"},{"value":"state of kerala ","formInput":"state%20of%20kerala%20"},{"value":"similarly situated","formInput":"similarly%20situated"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1604894,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=28040","title":"Pitta Naveen Kumar & Ors vs Raja Narasaiah Zangiti & Ors on 14 September, 2006"},{"tid":982107,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=12736","title":"Shankarsan Dash vs Union Of India on 30 April, 1991"},{"tid":470118,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=6519","title":"State Of Haryana vs Subash Chander Marwaha And Ors on 2 May, 1973"},{"tid":1734503,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=4036","title":"Supreme Court Reports [1962] ... vs The Governing Body Of The Nalanda ... on 15 December, 1961"},{"tid":211089,"url":null,"title":"Article 16 in The Constitution Of India   1949"}],"covers":[],"title":"S.S. Balu And Anr vs State Of Kerala And Ors on 13 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-13","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":155242892,"url":null,"title":"Sunny Paul, Kurian'S Cottage And ... vs The Revenue Divisional Officer ... on 23 February, 2007"},{"tid":1555220,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=9168","title":"Sunny Paul vs The Revenue Divisional Officer on 23 February, 2007"},{"tid":27992964,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=330524","title":"Shyju vs State Of Kerala"},{"tid":160749017,"url":"http://phhc.gov.in/pdf/fo/LPA_2154_2013_09_10_2015_FINAL_ORDER.pdf","title":"Union Of India vs Rajesh Sethi on 9 October, 2015"},{"tid":977805,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=184822","title":"Muraleedharan.C. vs The State Of Kerala on 13 December, 2010"}],"tid":1957971,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"s","lastname":"sinha","numcitedby":83,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33499","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">S.S. Balu And Anr vs State Of Kerala And Ors on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: S Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                     REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 104            OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 8586 of 2006)\n\n\nS.S. BALU &amp; ANR.                                    ... APPELLANTS\n\n                                  Versus\n\nSTATE OF KERALA &amp; ORS.                               ... RESPONDENTS\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. Sinha, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">2.    Appellants herein are before us aggrieved by and dissatisfied with a\n\njudgment and order dated 5.10.2005 passed by a Division Bench of the High\n\nCourt of Kerala at Ernakulam in Writ Appeal No. 53 of 2005 (A) and others\n\nwhereby and whereunder the Writ Appeals preferred by the State of Kerala\n\nfrom a judgment and order dated 25.8.2004 passed by a learned single judge\n\nof the said Court in O.P. No. 28082 of 2002 and others were allowed.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                     2</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.    Appellants herein pursuant to or in furtherance of a requisition made\n\nby the State of Kerala before the Kerala Public Service Commission (for\n\nshort, \"the Commission\") applied for the post of Lower Primary/Upper\n\nPrimary School Assistants. On 5.6.1997, the Commission prepared a rank\n\nlist, which was in force from 5.6.1997 to 5.6.2000.       Appellants' name\n\nfigured therein.    The vacancies, however, were not filled up. However, as\n\nno vacancy was filled up by the Deputy Director of Education, writ petitions\n\nwere filed before the Kerala High Court praying for issuance of a writ of\n\nmandamus or any other writ or order directing the Deputy Director of\n\nEducation to report all the vacancies to the Commission so as to enable it to\n\nadvise the respective candidates pursuant whereto and in furtherance\n\nwhereof the appointing authority may issue offers of appointment. It is\n\nstated that the appellants were parties therein.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">4.    On or about 3.6.2000, pursuant to the direction of the High Court,\n\ndated 22.5.2000, the Deputy Director of Education reported 125 vacancies\n\nand on or about 5.6.2000, he reported further 50 vacancies just before the\n\nexpiry of the rank list with a note that they were anticipated vacancies.\n\nHowever, as the vacancies were shown as anticipated vacancies, the\n\nCommission could not issue letter of advise against those 175 vacancies\n\nreported by the Deputy Director of Education.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                    3</span><p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">5.       On or about 24.10.2001, the said writ petitions were heard and\n\ndisposed of by the Division Bench of the High Court, holding:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">              \"We are of the view since there is controversy\n              between the parties with regard to the number of\n              vacancies it would be appropriate that a direction\n              be given to first respondent to take a decision on\n              the dispute raised in this proceeding.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_9\">6.      In compliance of the said judgment, the State of Kerala issued a\n\nGovernment Order dated 15.1.2002 reporting that there was no vacancy.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">7.      Another writ petition marked as O.P. No. 28082 of 2002 was filed by\n\na few candidates praying for quashing of the said Government Order dated\n\n15.1.2002 upon grant of a declaration that 175 vacancies reported by the\n\nDeputy Director of Education should be filled from amongst the candidates\n\nwhose names find place in the select list and for consequential directions.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">8.      By reason of a judgment and order dated 25.8.2004, the High Court\n\nheld:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">              \"26. At this stage, I consider it necessary to\n              advert to the contention of the standing counsel of\n              the Commission that after the expiry of Ext. P1\n              rank list a new list has come into operation and\n              therefore candidates included in Ext. P1 rank list\n              cannot be advised for appointment. I cannot agree\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                    4</span>\n\n            to the above argument of the learned counsel. 175\n            vacancies were reported to the Commission before\n            the expiry of Ext. P1 rank list. Since those\n            vacancies were wrongly described as anticipated\n            vacancies the Commission did not advise\n            candidates against those vacancies. Thereupon,\n            aggrieved candidates approached this Court. A\n            Division Bench of this Court directed the 1st\n            respondent to report the vacancies correctly. The\n            1st respondent, however, issued Ext. P3 order\n            without taking into account all relevant aspect. As\n            I have found that 175 vacancies already reported\n            were not anticipated vacancies but vacancies\n            which had, in fact, occurred prior to the expiry of\n            Ext. P1, candidates included in Ext. P1 are entitled\n            to be advised for appointment against those\n            vacancies. The legitimate claim of the petitioners\n            cannot be denied for the reason that during the\n            pendency of the writ petitions a new list has come\n            into operation. I am clearly of the view that what\n            is legitimately due to the candidates in Ext. P1\n            should be given to them.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">      Appellants were not parties to the said writ petitions.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_13\">9.    The State of Kerala preferred an appeal thereagainst before the\n\nDivision Bench of the said Court, which was marked as Writ Appeal No. 53\n\nof 2005.   Before the High Court, however, appellants got themselves\n\nimpleaded as respondents 5 and 6 respectively. The said Writ Appeal was\n\nallowed by reason of the impugned judgment directing the Commission to\n\nadvise in respect of 18 of the original petitioners who had filed the writ\n\npetition bearing O.P. No. 28082 of 2002 to quash the Government Order\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                    5</span>\n\ndated 15.1.2002. No direction was issued in respect of those who got\n\nthemselves impleaded as parties therein including the appellants herein.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">10.   Appellants are, thus, before us, contending that as their names\n\nappeared in the `rank list' and they being seniors to some of the original writ\n\npetitioners they should also be directed to be appointed.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">11.   Ms. Malini Poduval, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nappellants would submit:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">      i.     the High Court committed a serious error of law in passing the\n\n             impugned judgment insofar as it failed to take into\n\n             consideration that as the appellants are similarly situated with\n\n             that of the original writ petitioners to whom the State\n\n             Government agreed to give appointment.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">      ii.    There was absolutely no reason as to why they should have\n\n             been discriminated against particularly when they had also got\n\n             themselves impleaded as respondents in the writ appeal.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_17\">12.   Mr. Vipin Nair, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nrespondents, on the other hand, would urge that the respondents having filed\n\nno writ petition and keeping in view of the fact that not only the rank list in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                    6</span>\n\nquestion but also the 2nd rank list for the period between 16.9.2002 and\n\n15.9.2005 are exhausted, the impugned judgment is wholly unassailable.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">13.   The legality and/or the validity of Government Order dated\n\n15.1.2002, as noticed hereinbefore, was questioned, inter alia, on the\n\npremise that the actual vacancy position had been suppressed by the State.\n\nA finding of fact to that effect appears to have been arrived at by the learned\n\nsingle judge of the High Court in his judgment and order dated 25.8.2004,\n\nholding:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">             \"24. Respondents 1 and 2 have got a contention\n             that 65% of the N.J.D. vacancies alone shall be\n             reckoned as reportable vacancies. I do not agree.\n             As rightly submitted by the petitioners, vacancies\n             had been reported based on the 65% set apart for\n             direct recruitment and once those vacancies fall\n             vacant consequent on the non joining duty of the\n             candidates advised for appointment, a further\n             deduction of 35% from the N.J.D. vacancies is not\n             justified.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">             25. It is not disputed that total vacancies\n             including N.J.D. vacancies reported to the\n             Commission after 5.12.1997 was 580 (barring 175\n             vacancies described as anticipated vacancies).\n             Therefore the number of unreported vacancies will\n             come to 208. When state of affairs stood as above,\n             the 2nd respondent reported 125 vacancies on\n             3.6.2000 and 50 vacancies on 5.6.2000 as directed\n             by this Court. The reporting was done with the\n             rider that the above 175 vacancies were only\n             anticipated vacancies. As I have found that there\n             were, at any rate, 208 reportable vacancies, I have\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                      7</span>\n\n             no hesitation to hold that the 2nd respondent was\n             not justified in informing the Commission that 175\n             vacancies were anticipated vacancies. Ext. P3 is\n             therefore unsustainable.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_20\">14.   The matter might have been different, had the learned single judge as\n\nalso the Division Bench come to a conclusion that in fact there existed 125\n\nvacancies wherefor requisition was sent to the Commissioner.               The\n\nexistence of actual number of vacancies being in dispute, it is difficult for us\n\nto opine as has been contended by the learned counsel that all such\n\nvacancies existed. Before the Division Bench of the High Court, the State\n\nconceded that 18 original writ petitioners may be appointed stating that they\n\nwere the actual beneficiaries of the judgment. Such a stand on the part of\n\nthe State was accepted. The Division Bench of the High Court did not go\n\ninto the other contentions raised by the parties thereto. No factual\n\nfoundation, therefore, has been laid before us for arriving at the conclusion\n\nthat all the 125 vacancies existed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">15.   There is another aspect of the matter which cannot also be lost sight\n\nof. A person does not acquire a legal right to be appointed only because his\n\nname appears in the select list. [<a href=\"/doc/1604894/\" id=\"a_1\">See Pitta Naveen Kumar &amp; ors. vs. Raja\n\nNarasaiah Zangiti &amp; ors</a>. (2006) 10 SCC 261].\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                    8</span><p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">16.   The state as an employer has a right to fill up all the posts or not to\n\nfill them up. Unless a discrimination is made in regard to the filling up of\n\nthe vacancies or an arbitrariness is committed, the concerned candidate will\n\nhave no legal right for obtaining a writ of or in the nature of mandamus.\n\n[<a href=\"/doc/109755/\" id=\"a_2\">See Batiarani Gramiya Bank vs. Pallab Kumar &amp; ors</a>. (2004) 9 SCC 100]\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/982107/\" id=\"a_3\">In Shankarsan Dash vs. Union of India</a> [(1991) 3 SCC 47], a\n\nConstitution Bench of this Court held:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">             \"7. It is not correct to say that if a number of\n             vacancies are notified for appointment and\n             adequate number of candidates are found fit, the\n             successful candidates acquire an indefeasible right\n             to be appointed which cannot be legitimately\n             denied. Ordinarily the notification merely amounts\n             to an invitation to qualified candidates to apply for\n             recruitment and on their selection they do not\n             acquire any right to the post. Unless the relevant\n             recruitment rules so indicate, the State is under no\n             legal duty to fill up all or any of the vacancies.\n             However, it does not mean that the State has the\n             licence of acting in an arbitrary manner. The\n             decision not to fill up the vacancies has to be taken\n             bona fide for appropriate reasons. And if the\n             vacancies or any of them are filled up, the State is\n             bound to respect the comparative merit of the\n             candidates, as reflected at the recruitment test, and\n             no discrimination can be permitted.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_25\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">      <a href=\"/doc/470118/\" id=\"a_4\">In State of Haryana vs. Subash Chander Marwaha</a> [(1974) 3 SCC\n\n220], this Court held:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                    9</span><p id=\"p_27\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">             \"The mere fact that a candidate's name appears in\n             the list will not entitle him to a mandamus that he\n             be appointed. Indeed, if the State Government\n             while making the selection for appointment had\n             departed from the ranking given in the list, there\n             would have been a legitimate grievance on the\n             ground that the State Government had departed\n             from the rules in this respect...\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">             11. It must be remembered that the petition is\n             for a mandamus. This Court has pointed out in <a href=\"/doc/1734503/\" id=\"a_5\">Dr\n             Rai Shivendra Bahadur v. Governing Body of the\n             Nalanda College</a> that in order that mandamus may\n             issue to compel an authority to do something, it\n             must be shown that the statute imposes a legal\n             duty on that authority and the aggrieved party has\n             a legal right under the statute to enforce its\n             performance. Since there is no legal duty on the\n             State Government to appoint all the 15 persons\n             who are in the list and the petitioners have no legal\n             right under the rules to enforce its performance the\n             petition is clearly misconceived.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_28\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">      <a href=\"/doc/1604894/\" id=\"a_6\">In Pitta Naveen Kumar vs. Raja Narasaiah Zangiti</a> [(2006) 10 SCC\n\n261], this Court held:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">             \"....A candidate does not have any legal right to\n             be appointed. He in terms of <a href=\"/doc/211089/\" id=\"a_7\">Article 16</a> of the\n             Constitution of India has only a right to be\n             considered therefor. Consideration of the case of\n             an individual candidate although ordinarily is\n             required to be made in terms of the extant rules but\n             strict adherence thereto would be necessary in a\n             case where the rules operate only to the\n             disadvantage of the candidates concerned and not\n             otherwise...\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_30\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">      <a href=\"/doc/1755546/\" id=\"a_8\">In State of Rajasthan &amp; ors. vs. Jagdish Chopra</a> [(2007) 8 SCC 161],\n\nthis Court held:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                   10</span><p id=\"p_32\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">            \"9. Recruitment for teachers in the State of\n            Rajasthan is admittedly governed by the statutory\n            rules. All recruitments, therefore, are required to\n            be made in terms thereof. Although Rule 9(3) of\n            the Rules does not specifically provide for the\n            period for which the merit list shall remain valid\n            but the intent of the legislature is absolutely clear\n            as vacancies have to be determined only once in a\n            year. Vacancies which arose in the subsequent\n            years could be filled up from the select list\n            prepared in the previous year and not in other\n            manner. Even otherwise, in absence of any rule,\n            ordinary period of validity of select list should be\n            one year. <a href=\"/doc/406742/\" id=\"a_9\">In State of Bihar v. Amrendra Kumar\n            Mishra</a> (2006) 12 SCC 561, this Court opined:\n            (SCC p.564, para 9)\n                   \"9. In the aforementioned situation, in\n                   our opinion, he did not have any legal\n                   right to be appointed. Life of a panel,\n                   it is well known, remains valid for a\n                   year. Once it lapses, unless an\n                   appropriate order is issued by the\n                   State, no appointment can be made\n                   out of the said panel.\"</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_13\">            It was further held: (SCC p.565, para 13)\n                   \"13.     The      decisions     noticed\n                   hereinbefore are authorities for the\n                   proposition that even the wait list\n                   must be acted upon having regard to\n                   the terms of the advertisement and in\n                   any event cannot remain operative\n                   beyond the prescribed period.\"\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_14\">                   xxx           xxx         xxx\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_15\">            11. It is well-settled principle of law that even\n            selected candidates do not have legal right in this\n            behalf. (<a href=\"/doc/982107/\" id=\"a_10\">See Shankarsan Dash v. Union of India</a>\n            (1991) 3 SCC 47, and <a href=\"/doc/1254499/\" id=\"a_11\">Asha Kaul v. State of J&amp;K</a>\n            (1993) 2 SCC 573)\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_33\">17.   Furthermore, the rank list was valid for a period of three years. Its\n\nvalidity expired on 5.6.2000. Another Select List was published for the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                    11</span>\n\nperiod from 16.9.2002 to 15.9.2005. Vacancies in terms of the said Select\n\nList have also been filled up.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">18.   It is also well settled principle of law that \"delay defeats equity\".\n\nGovernment Order was issued on 15.1.2002. Appellants did not file any\n\nwrit application questioning the legality and validity thereof. Only after the\n\nwrit petitions filed by others were allowed and State of Kerala preferred an\n\nappeal thereagainst, they impleaded themselves as party respondents. It is\n\nnow a trite law that where the writ petitioner approaches the High Court\n\nafter a long delay, reliefs prayed for may be denied to them on the ground of\n\ndelay and laches irrespective of the fact that they are similarly situated to\n\nthe other candidates who obtain the benefit of the judgment. It is, thus, not\n\npossible for us to issue any direction to the State of Kerala or the\n\nCommission to appoint the appellants at this stage.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">      <a href=\"/doc/670840/\" id=\"a_12\">In New Delhi Minicipal Council v. Pan Singh and Ors</a>. (2007) 9 SCC\n\n278, this Court held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_37\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_16\">             \"16. There is another aspect of the matter which\n             cannot be lost sight of. The respondents herein\n             filed a writ petition after 17 years. They did not\n             agitate their grievances for a long time. They, as\n             noticed herein, did not claim parity with the 17\n             workmen at the earliest possible opportunity. They\n             did not implead themselves as parties even in the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                    12</span>\n\n            reference made by the State before the Industrial\n            Tribunal. It is not their case that after 1982, those\n            employees who were employed or who were\n            recruited after the cut-off date have been granted\n            the said scale of pay. After such a long time,\n            therefore, the writ petitions could not have been\n            entertained even if they are similarly situated. It is\n            trite that the discretionary jurisdiction may not be\n            exercised in favour of those who approach the\n            court after a long time. Delay and laches are\n            relevant factors for exercise of equitable\n            jurisdiction.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_38\">{See also <a href=\"/doc/56321/\" id=\"a_13\">Virender Chaudhary vs. Bharat Petroleum Corporation &amp; Ors</a>.\n\n[2008 (15) SCALE 67]}\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">19.   For the reasons aforementioned, there is no merit in this appeal. It is\n\ndismissed accordingly. No costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_40\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">                                            ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">                                                      [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n\n\n                                             ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">                                                [Dr. Mukundakam Sharma]\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_44\">JANUARY 13, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":16,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"section India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33467","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Brindaban Das &amp; Ors vs State Of West Bengal on 7 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: A Kabir</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                          1\n\n\n             IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n            CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n             CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 9 OF 2009\n            @ S.L.P. (Crl.) NO.6853 of 2006\n\n\nBrindaban Das and others                       ...Appellants\n\n\n\nVs.\n\n\n\nState of West Bengal                           ...Respondent\n\n\n                     J U D G M E N T\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">ALTAMAS KABIR,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    On     an    application   filed   by    the     defacto\n\n      complainant under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 319</a> of the Code of\n\n      Criminal Procedure, the Additional District\n\n      and     Sessions     Judge,   Fast      Track     Court,\n\n      Jhargram,       by   his   order   dated       14.6.2006\n\n      directed the appellants to appear before the\n\n      Court on 22.6.2006 in connection with S.T.\n\n      Case    No.XXIX/February,     2006      under    <a href=\"/doc/915147/\" id=\"a_2\">Section\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                            2</span></a>\n\n\n     <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">302</a>   of      the     Indian          Penal    Code      (G.R.       case\n\n     No.450 of 2002).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">3.   The     complainant,             Ashok        Kumar      Pattanayak,\n\n     lodged        the     First           Information        Report       at\n\n     Gopiballabhpur             PS     on    29.11.2002           at     about\n\n     8.25 a.m. alleging that on the same date at\n\n     about      7.30/8.00            a.m.      while        his        father,\n\n     Ramesh Chandra Pattanayak, was                           supervising\n\n     the work in his brick field known as Hena\n\n     Brick,      he      was    assaulted          on   the    head      from\n\n     behind with a spade (kodal),                           as a result\n\n     whereof he died instantly. The driver of the\n\n     truck to whom the deceased was speaking at\n\n     the time of assault and the khalasi of the\n\n     truck, as well as other labourers, raised a\n\n     alarm.        The police also arrived at the spot\n\n     and apprehended the assailant, Laxman Murmu.\n\n     In    the     FIR     it        was    alleged        that        besides\n\n     Laxman      Murmu,        several        other     persons         could\n\n     also have been behind the incident. The said\n\n     FIR     was      written         by     Ila     Pattanayak,           the\n\n     sister of the de-facto complainant, and on\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                                   3</span>\n\n\n     the      basis        of     the      said         complaint,\n\n     Gopiballabhpur PS Case No.48 of 2002 dated\n\n     29.11.2002,      was       started    against       the     said\n\n     Laxman Murmu      under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 302</a> IPC.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.   During the investigation of the above case,\n\n     the appellants herein filed an application\n\n     under <a href=\"/doc/1783708/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 438</a> of the Code of Criminal\n\n     Procedure before the Sessions Judge and such\n\n     prayer for anticipatory bail was allowed on\n\n     14.8.2003. The appellants were directed to\n\n     appear    before       the    Sub-Judicial         Divisional\n\n     Magistrate,           Jhargram,       and       on         their\n\n     appearance before the learned Magistrate on\n\n     16.8.2003, the appellants were released on\n\n     temporary bail with a direction to them to\n\n     bring    appropriate         orders    from     the       higher\n\n     Court. Subsequently, on an application under\n\n     <a href=\"/doc/1290514/\" id=\"a_6\">Section    439</a>        Cr.P.C.   the     Sessions       Judge,\n\n     Paschim    Midnapur,          granted       bail      to     the\n\n     appellants       on     23.9.2003.           The     de-facto\n\n     complainant      thereupon      filed    an     application\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                         4</span>\n\n\n     under    <a href=\"/doc/116391/\" id=\"a_7\">Section         439(2)</a>     Cr.       P.C.    before       the\n\n     Sessions Judge praying for cancellation of\n\n     the bail granted to the appellants but the\n\n     same     was    rejected           on     16.12.2003.          After\n\n     completion          of    investigation              the      police\n\n     submitted      charge-sheet             against      the    accused\n\n     Laxman    Murmu.         As    there          was    no     material\n\n     against       the     appellants          herein       they       were\n\n     neither shown in the charge-sheet nor were\n\n     they sent up for trial and on the prayer\n\n     made     by     the       Investigating              Officer       the\n\n     appellants were discharged from the case by\n\n     order dated 30.6.2004.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">5.   Two years later on 22.6.2006 the trial Court\n\n     issued     warrants           of    arrest           against       the\n\n     appellants       for      their         alleged       refusal      to\n\n     receive       summons      which        had    been       issued    to\n\n     them earlier under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C. The\n\n     said order was challenged in the High Court\n\n     in its revisional             jurisdiction            and    it    was\n\n     submitted that once the appellants had been\n\n     discharged on the prayer made on behalf of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                                  5</span>\n\n\n     the Investigating Officer, the trial Court\n\n     erred in issuing the summons under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_9\">Section\n\n     319</a> of the Code on the same materials.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">6.   The High Court came to the conclusion that\n\n     there had not been any wilful defiance of\n\n     the summons which necessitated the issuance\n\n     of   warrant    of    arrest    and      disposed     of   the\n\n     revision application with a direction to the\n\n     appellants     herein      to   surrender       before     the\n\n     Court within 3 weeks from the date of the\n\n     order and thereafter to apply for bail. The\n\n     execution      of    the   warrant        of    arrest      was\n\n     stayed for a period of four weeks for the\n\n     said purpose.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">7.   It is against the said order of the High\n\n     Court that the present appeal has been filed.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">8.   Mr. Pradip Ghosh, learned senior advocate,\n\n     appearing for the appellants, submitted that\n\n     in   the   instant     case     there     was    no   direct\n\n     evidence against the appellants which could\n\n     have   formed        the   basis      for      issuance     of\n\n     summons    under      <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_10\">Section      319</a>    Cr.P.C.     Not        a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                      6</span>\n\n\nsingle    eye-witness            had     been      cited       in    the\n\ninstant    case       and    the       entire      evidence          was\n\nhear-say      in    nature.            Mr.    Ghosh       submitted\n\nthat even the complaint had been lodged by\n\nthe   daughter        of    the    deceased         who    had      not\n\nseen the incident and had come to the place\n\nof    occurrence        after      the       offence      had       been\n\ncommitted      on     being       informed         of    the    same.\n\nMr.    Ghosh       submitted       that       as    provided          in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1681167/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 60</a> of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872,\n\noral evidence must in all cases, be direct\n\nand    when    an       accused        is    discharged         under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1568411/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 245</a> Cr.P.C., in the absence of any\n\nfresh material, summons under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 319</a> of\n\nthe Code could not be issued on the same\n\nevidence.          It      was    submitted        that     in       the\n\ninstant       case,        nothing          new    had     surfaced\n\nduring the trial and the evidence that was\n\navailable before the Court at the stage of\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1830754/\" id=\"a_14\">Sections 244</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1568411/\" id=\"a_15\">245</a> of the Code continued\n\nto be the only evidence available when the\n\napplication under <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 319</a> had been made.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                            7</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">     Mr. Ghosh submitted that the trial Court had\n\n     committed          an         error         in         allowing      the\n\n     application            of     the        de-facto        complaintant\n\n     under        <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_17\">Section           319</a>         and     summoning          the\n\n     appellants in               the     absence       of    any   evidence\n\n     against them within the meaning of <a href=\"/doc/1681167/\" id=\"a_18\">Section\n\n     60</a> of the Evidence Act.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">9.   In this regard, Mr. Ghosh firstly referred\n\n     to the oft-repeated decision of this Court\n\n     in    the    case       of        <a href=\"/doc/1335414/\" id=\"a_19\">Michael        Machado      vs.    CBI</a>,\n\n     [2000       (3)    SCC        262]       where         the    essential\n\n     conditions for the exercise of power under\n\n     <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 319</a> of Cr.P.C. had been considered\n\n     and it was held that the power under <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_21\">Section\n\n     319</a>    vested          in     the     Court       should      be     used\n\n     sparingly and the evidence on which the same\n\n     was     to        be        invoked        should        indicate          a\n\n     reasonable         prospect           of     conviction         of    the\n\n     persons to be summoned.                      This Court went on\n\n     to    hold         that           mere      suspicion          of     the\n\n     involvement of the person concerned in the\n\n     offence was not enough, particularly when a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                                              8</span>\n\n\n      large number of witnesses had been examined\n\n      and no evidence on which conviction could be\n\n      secured had been adduced on behalf of the\n\n      prosecution.              It     was     ultimately             observed\n\n      that    in        such    a     case     there       could        be    no\n\n      justification             for    proceeding           against          the\n\n      persons       summoned          under       <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_22\">Section        319</a>     which\n\n      would        entail            recommencing               the     whole\n\n      proceedings against the newly-added persons\n\n      and     re-examining             the        witnesses           already\n\n      examined.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">10.   Mr. Ghosh also referred to the decision of\n\n      this     Court       in        <a href=\"/doc/1945016/\" id=\"a_23\">Krishnappa           vs.     State      of\n\n      Karnataka</a>,          [2004       (7)     SCC    792]        wherein          a\n\n      similar question fell for consideration and\n\n      again    a    note        of    caution       was    sounded        with\n\n      regard       to    invocation          of     the    extraordinary\n\n      and discretionary powers under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_24\">Section 319</a>\n\n      of     the        Code.
