Their        Lordships,          while\n\n      observing that a person can be summoned even\n\n      though proceedings had earlier been quashed\n\n      as far as he was concerned, held that the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                     9</span>\n\n\n      invocation of          the    power     under    <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_25\">Section      319</a>\n\n      should not have been resorted to, since the\n\n      chances of conviction on the basis of the\n\n      evidence on record was remote.                   Holding that\n\n      the Trial Court was right in rejecting such\n\n      prayer, since the case against the appellant\n\n      had     been     quashed        nine     years        prior    to\n\n      issuance       of     summons        under      <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_26\">Section       319</a>\n\n      Cr.P.C., this Court held that the High Court\n\n      had erroneously             reversed    the     order    of   the\n\n      Trial    Court        even     though     the     chances      of\n\n      conviction       on    the     basis     of     the     evidence\n\n      adduced was very remote.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">11.   The same view was reiterated in the case of\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/1776925/\" id=\"a_27\">Kuvuluri Vivekananda Reddy vs. State of A.P</a>.\n\n      [2005     (12)        SCC     432)      where     a     similar\n\n      challenge       to     the      summons       issued      under\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_28\">Section 319</a> of the Code was repelled on the\n\n      ground that the statement of the witnesses\n\n      examined was only general in nature on the\n\n      basis of which summons under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_29\">Section 319</a> of\n\n      the Code ought not to have been issued. Once\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                                                        1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                                                        0</span>\n      again a note of caution was sounded that the\n\n      provisions of <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_30\">Section 319</a> are required to be\n\n      used very sparingly and the summoning of the\n\n      appellants after the expiry of eight years,\n\n      on the facts and circumstances of the case\n\n      and     having    regard        to    the    nature       of     the\n\n      deposition of the witnesses, was not called\n\n      for.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">12.   Mr. Ghosh finally referred to the decision\n\n      of this Court          in      <a href=\"/doc/1860679/\" id=\"a_31\">Municipal      Corporation        of\n\n      Delhi vs. Ram Kishan Rastogi</a>, [1983 (1) SCC\n\n      1], which is one of the earlier cases where\n\n      the scope of <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_32\">Section 319</a> had been dealt with\n\n      and     thereafter     followed        in     the     subsequent\n\n      cases,     wherein        it    had     been       observed      as\n\n      follows:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">                \"In these circumstances, therefore, if\n\n        the    prosecution      can   at    any   stage    produce\n\n        evidence which satisfies the Court that the\n\n        other    accused   or     those    who    have    not   been\n\n        arrayed as accused against whom proceedings\n\n        have    been   quashed    have     also   committed      the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                                                           1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                                                           1</span>\n        offence    Court      can    take       cognizance    against\n\n        them    and    try    them        along    with     the    other\n\n        accused.       But, we would hasten to add that\n\n        this is really an extraordinary power which\n\n        is conferred on the Court and should be used\n\n        very     sparingly         and     only     if     compelling\n\n        reasons exist for taking cognizance against\n\n        the other person against whom action has not\n\n        been taken.          More than this we would not\n\n        like to say anything further at this stage.\n\n        We leave the entire matter to the discretion\n\n        of the Court concerned so that it may act\n\n        according to law.               We would, however, make\n\n        it     plain   that        the     mere    fact     that    the\n\n        proceedings         have         been     quashed     against\n\n        respondents     2     to    5     will    not     prevent   the\n\n        Court from exercising its discretion if it\n\n        is fully satisfied that a case for taking\n\n        cognizance against them has been made out on\n\n        the additional evidence led before it.'\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">13.   On the basis of his aforesaid submissions,\n\n      Mr. Ghosh urged that the Trial Court ought\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                                               1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                                                               2</span>\n      not   to   have   issued    summons        against      the\n\n      appellants herein under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_33\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C.\n\n      without    recording     satisfaction       as    to    the\n\n      sufficiency of     the   evidence     on    record     for\n\n      securing a conviction against the appellants.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">14.   Appearing for the State of West Bengal, Mr.\n\n      Avijit     Bhattacharjee         referred        to     the\n\n      decision of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/1319831/\" id=\"a_34\">Rajender Singh vs.\n\n      State of U.P</a>. [2007 (7) SCC 378] where it\n\n      was reiterated that        although    a    person     may\n\n      not   have     been      charge-sheeted          by     the\n\n      Investigating     Agency     or     may     have       been\n\n      discharged at     an   earlier     stage,    the      Court\n\n      could summon such person to face trial if it\n\n      appeared to the Court that an offence had\n\n      been committed by such person.              It was held\n\n      that while the decision to proceed or not to\n\n      proceed against a person under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_35\">Section 319</a>\n\n      of the Code was in the discretion of the\n\n      Trial Court, the said decision would have to\n\n      be taken after the Court applied its mind to\n\n      the evidence before        it.     Disagreeing         with\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">\f                                                                          1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">                                                                          3</span>\n      the earlier views expressed by this Court,\n\n      it was held that the Court's powers under\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_36\">Section      319</a>      Cr.P.C      could       not    be    fettered\n\n      either      by    calling        it    extraordinary          or    by\n\n      stating that it could be exercised only in\n\n      exceptional circumstances.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">15.   Mr.    Bhattacharjee             submitted          that    in     the\n\n      light of the aforesaid decision there could\n\n      not    be    any      controversy            that    the     Court's\n\n      powers      under         <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_37\">Section        319</a>        Cr.P.C.        was\n\n      discretionary              and         unfettered,            though\n\n      dependent        on    the      quality       of    the    evidence\n\n      adduced          by       the         prosecution.                 Mr.\n\n      Bhattacharjee            submitted       that       no     case    had\n\n      been   made        out     for    interference             with    the\n\n      order of the High Court and the appeal was\n\n      liable to be dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">16.   The same submissions                  were    advanced       by    Mr.\n\n      Puri appearing for the de-facto complainant,\n\n      Ashok Pattanayak, who had been impleaded as\n\n      respondent No.2 in the present appeal. Mr.\n\n      Puri referred to the decision of this Court\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">\f                                                                           1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">                                                                           4</span>\n      in <a href=\"/doc/581087/\" id=\"a_38\">Bholu Ram vs. State of Punjab</a> [2008 (9)\n\n      SCC       140]    wherein     it       had    been     held        that\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_39\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C. empowered the Court to\n\n      proceed against any person not shown to be\n\n      an accused, if it appeared from the evidence\n\n      that such person            had    committed          an    offence\n\n      for which he could be tried along with the\n\n      accused.          It was further observed that when\n\n      in    a    case     against      one    or     more    accused           a\n\n      Magistrate finds from the evidence adduced\n\n      that some person other than the accused was\n\n      also involved in that very offence, it was\n\n      only proper that the Magistrate should have\n\n      power to summon by joining such person as an\n\n      accused in the case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">17.   It    was    further      observed           that    the    primary\n\n      object of <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_40\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C. is that the\n\n      whole case against all the accused should be\n\n      tried        and         disposed            of       not       only\n\n      expeditiously, but also simultaneously.                            The\n\n      power       under      <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_41\">Section     319</a>       Cr.P.C.        must     be\n\n      regarded         and   considered        as       incidental       and\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">\f                                                                          1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">                                                                          5</span>\n      ancillary       to        the    main      power        to        take\n\n      cognizance as part of the normal process in\n\n      the administration of justice and that the\n\n      same    could        be     exercised       either           on     an\n\n      application      made       to   the      Court    or    by        the\n\n      Court suo moto and it was in the discretion\n\n      of the Court to take action under the said\n\n      Section     having         regard    to     the     facts          and\n\n      circumstances of each case.                  Mr. Puri also\n\n      urged that the decision of the High Court\n\n      could   not     be    faulted       and    the     appeal          was\n\n      liable to be dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">18.   The common thread in most matters where the\n\n      use of discretion is in issue is that in the\n\n      exercise of such discretion each case has to\n\n      be considered on its own set of facts and\n\n      circumstances.              In    matters         relating         to\n\n      invocation of powers under <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_42\">Section 319</a>, the\n\n      Court is not merely required to take note of\n\n      the fact that the name of a person who has\n\n      not been named as an accused in the F.I.R.\n\n      has surfaced during the trial, but the Court\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_21\">\f                                                                             1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_22\">                                                                             6</span>\n      is also required          to    consider           whether        such\n\n      evidence would be sufficient to convict the\n\n      person being summoned.                 Since          issuance         of\n\n      summons under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_43\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C. entails a\n\n      denovo trial and a large number of witnesses\n\n      may     have     been    examined           and        their          re-\n\n      examination could prejudice the prosecution\n\n      and delay the trial, the Trial Court has to\n\n      exercise such discretion with great care and\n\n      perspicacity.            Although,                a         somewhat\n\n      discordant       note     was        struck           in    Rajender\n\n      Singh's case (supra) the views expressed in\n\n      the majority of decisions of this Court on\n\n      the   point    subscribe        to    the     view         that       the\n\n      power    under    <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_44\">Section       319</a>    Cr.P.C.             is    to   be\n\n      invoked, not as a matter of course, but in\n\n      circumstances where the invocation of such\n\n      power    is    imperative       to     meet       the       ends       of\n\n      justice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">19.   The   fulcrum       on    which        the    invocation               of\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_45\">Section    319</a>    Cr.P.C.       rests        is       whether         the\n\n      summoning of       persons      other        than          the   named\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_23\">\f                                                                         1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_24\">                                                                         7</span>\n      accused would make such a difference to the\n\n      prosecution as would enable it not only to\n\n      prove   its       case      but     to     also    secure         the\n\n      conviction of the persons summoned.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">20.   In the instant case, on the quality of the\n\n      evidence adduced by the prosecution as far\n\n      as   the    appellants            are     concerned,         it    is\n\n      difficult        to     hold       with     any     amount         of\n\n      certainty        that       the     same     would          in    all\n\n      probability secure a conviction against the\n\n      appellants.           The    evidence       which       seeks      to\n\n      connect the appellants with the commission\n\n      of   the     offence         are    hearsay        in       nature.\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_46\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C. contemplates a situation\n\n      where      the        evidence           adduced        by        the\n\n      prosecution       not       only    implicates          a    person\n\n      other      than       the      named       accused          but    is\n\n      sufficient for the purpose of convicting the\n\n      person to whom summons is issued.                           The law\n\n      in this regard was explained in Ram Kishan\n\n      Rastogi's case (supra) and as pointed out by\n\n      Mr. Ghosh, consistently followed thereafter,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_25\">\f                                                                        1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_26\">                                                                        8</span>\n      except    for     the    note     of    discord       struck      in\n\n      Rajender Singh's case (supra).                      It is only\n\n      logical        that     there     must       be     substantive\n\n      evidence against a person in order to summon\n\n      him for trial, although, he is not named in\n\n      the charge-sheet or he has been discharged\n\n      from     the    case,     which        would      warrant       his\n\n      prosecution thereafter with a good chance of\n\n      his conviction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">21.   Since    in     the     present    case,       except       for       a\n\n      statement in the F.I.R. that the complainant\n\n      strongly       believed     that       the    murder       of   her\n\n      father was pre-planned and there were many\n\n      conspirators          involved,    there       is     no   direct\n\n      evidence of the complicity of the appellants\n\n      in the incident, it would not be proper to\n\n      subject the appellants to trial by invoking\n\n      the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_47\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">22.   We,    therefore,        allow     the       appeal    and      set\n\n      aside the order           dated    14.6.2006          passed      by\n\n      the Additional District and Sessions Judge,\n\n      F.T.C.,       Jhargram,     issuing          summons       to   the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_27\">\f                                                               1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_28\">                                                               9</span>\n      appellants under <a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_48\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C. and the\n\n      impugned     order    of   the     High    Court     dated\n\n      22.11.2006     directing         the   appellants        to\n\n      surrender    before    the   Trial        Court    and   to\n\n      apply for bail.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">23.   The appeal is accordingly allowed.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">                                         ________________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">                                            (ALTAMAS KABIR)\n\n\n                                         ________________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">                                        (MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi\nDated: 07.01.2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":14,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"multiplier","formInput":"multiplier"},{"value":"permanent disablement","formInput":"permanent%20disablement"},{"value":"ram prasad ","formInput":"ram%20prasad%20"},{"value":"interest rate","formInput":"interest%20rate"}],"citeList":[{"tid":609788,"url":null,"title":"Section 1 in The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":946665,"url":null,"title":"Section 2 in The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":136948773,"url":null,"title":"Section 166 in The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":785258,"url":null,"title":"The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":1113485,"url":null,"title":"the Competition Act, 2002"}],"covers":[],"title":"Oriental Insurance Co.Ltd vs Ram Prasad Varma & Ors on 13 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-13","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":1823190,"url":null,"title":"Oriental Insurance Co. Ltd. vs Puni Devi And Ors. on 28 December, 1994"},{"tid":25112597,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=62922","title":"The United India Insurance Co. Ltd vs S.Muniandi Santha (Died) on 27 June, 2013"},{"tid":108220,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=57730","title":"Tamilkumaran ... 3Rd Respondent/ vs Senthilkumar ... Petitioner on 19 November, 2010"},{"tid":145068642,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/GPM/judgement/10-01-2012/GPM03012012MACA2642005.pdf","title":"Uttaranchal Transport ... vs Navneet Jerath on 3 January, 2012"},{"tid":180472625,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/GPM/judgement/25-02-2012/GPM13022012FAO2002000.pdf","title":"Om Prakash vs Amitabh Khosla & Ors. on 13 February, 2012"}],"tid":916566,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"s","lastname":"sinha","numcitedby":31,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33500","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Oriental Insurance Co.Ltd vs Ram Prasad Varma &amp; Ors on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: S Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Cyriac Joseph</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                     REPORTABLE\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n              CIVIL APPEAL NO. 106      OF 2009\n       [ARISING OUT OF S.L.P. (CIVIL) NO. 16785 OF 2006]\n\n\nORIENTAL INSURANCE CO. LTD.                         ... APPELLANT\n\n                                 Versus\n\nRAM PRASAD VARMA &amp; ORS.                            ... RESPONDENTS\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. SINHA, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Ram Prasad Varma, respondent No. 1, an Assistant Executive\n\nEngineer, was employed with Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC) at\n\nRajahmundry. On or about 9.9.1998, while he was going to the workshop,\n\nhe was hit by a lorry bearing registration No. AP-16-W-5839. The lorry ran\n\nover his legs. He was admitted in the hospital. Indisputably, both his legs\n\nwere amputated. The fact that an accident had taken place owing to rash\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           2</span>\n\nand negligent driving on the part of the driver of the said lorry is not in\n\ndispute. It is also not in dispute that, at the relevant time, respondent was\n\naged 55 years and his annual income was Rs.2,27,471.00.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.     Respondent having suffered permanent disability filed a Claim\n\nPetition in terms of <a href=\"/doc/136948773/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 166</a> of the Motor Vehicles Act claiming\n\ncompensation of a sum of Rs.20 lakhs; Rs.50,000/- towards extra\n\nnourishment; Rs. 50,000/- towards compensation for mental agony, pain and\n\nsuffering; Rs. 50,000/- for loss of amenities in life and Rs.2 lakhs for the\n\nexpenditure of attendant throughout the life and Rs.16.50 lakhs towards loss\n\nof future earnings.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.     The Motor Accidents Claims Tribunal awarded a sum of\n\nRs.19,63,000/- with interest at the rate of 12% per annum from the date of\n\nfiling of the petition till realization.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5.     An appeal preferred thereagainst by the Insurance Company before\n\nthe High Court in terms of <a href=\"/doc/147367599/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 173</a> of the Act has been dismissed by\n\nreason of the impugned judgment. The High Court, however, considering\n\nthe prevailing rate of interest reduced the rate of interest from 12% per\n\nannum to 9% per annum.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                      3</span><p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">6.    Mr. Pankaj Seth, learned counsel appearing on behalf of appellant\n\nwould contend:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">      (i)     The learned Tribunal, and consequently the High Court,\n\n              committed a serious error in applying multiplier of eight\n\n              although respondent would have retired from services on\n\n              attaining the age of sixty.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      (ii)    The Tribunal in determining the amount of compensation\n\n              should have deducted the amount of income tax from his gross\n\n              salary as compensation has been granted on the basis of the\n\n              structured formula.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">      (iii)   The Tribunal in determining the said amount of compensation\n\n              should have deducted one-third from the total amount of his\n\n              income by way of miscellaneous expenses.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_14\">7.    Indisputably, the respondent was an Assistant Executive Engineer.\n\nHe was an income tax payee. He had submitted income tax return for the\n\nyear 1998-99 showing his gross salary at Rs.2,27,471.40 and the amount of\n\nincome-tax deducted at source was Rs.30,748.00.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                    4</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">8.    A claimant who had suffered injuries in a motor vehicle accident\n\nresulting in amputation of both legs is entitled to 100% compensation in\n\nterms of the First Schedule appended to the Workmen's <a href=\"/doc/1113485/\" id=\"a_3\">Compensation Act</a>,\n\n1923. The amount of compensation which represents the loss of income can\n\nbe calculated either in terms of the structured formula as contained in the\n\nSecond Schedule appended to the <a href=\"/doc/785258/\" id=\"a_4\">Motor Vehicles Act</a> or on the basis of the\n\nother materials brought on record. It is not in dispute that in a case of this\n\nnature, the Tribunal cannot be said to have committed any illegality in\n\napplying the structured formula.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">9.    The Second Schedule as such may not have any application as the\n\nmaximum annual income of a deceased or an injured which could be taken\n\ninto consideration therefor is Rs.40,000/- per annum. However, keeping in\n\nview the peculiar factual circumstances of the case, the proper multiplier\n\nwhich, in our opinion, should be adopted is eight for the purpose of\n\ndetermining fair compensation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">10.   Indisputably, he was to retire within a few years, but in view of the\n\ninjuries suffered he had to give up his job. The life expectancy of an Indian\n\ncitizen is about 62 years. A person on retirement, in the event if pension\n\nscheme is applicable, would be entitled to pensionary benefits. Had the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                    5</span>\n\nrespondent worked for five years more, the amount of pension calculated on\n\nthe basis of last pay drawn would have been more than what might have\n\nbecome payable in the year 1998.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">11.   One-third amount is deducted from computation of compensation\n\nfrom the total income on the premise that some expenses were necessary for\n\none's own survival. Incidentally, we may notice that in the note appended\n\nto the Second Schedule, the amount of compensation arrived in the case of\n\nfatal accident claims is required to be reduced by one-third in consideration\n\nof the expenses which the victim would have incurred towards maintaining\n\nhimself had he been alive. A person, although alive, but when he is not in a\n\nposition to move and even for every small thing he has to depend upon the\n\nservices of another, in our opinion, a direction to deduct 1/3rd of the amount\n\nfrom his total income need not always be insisted upon.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">12.   Our attention, however, has been drawn to a decision of this Court in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1332665/\" id=\"a_5\">New India Assurance Co. Ltd. v. Charlie and Anr</a>. [(2005) 10 SCC 720]\n\nwherein 1/3rd was directed to be deducted towards personal expenditure, we\n\ndo not find that any legal principle was laid down therein. It also does not\n\nappear that the premise on which such deduction is allowed and what would\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                     6</span>\n\nhappen in a case, where such a premise does not exist, did not fall for\n\nconsideration.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">      In Charlie (supra), this court itself opined that in a case, where the\n\ninjured had suffered 100% disability, the legal principle for determination of\n\ncompensation applicable to a deceased can, in appropriate cases, taking note\n\nof all relevant factors be reasonably applied even in a case of totally\n\npermanent disabled person.      This Court referred to Halsbury's Laws of\n\nEngland, Volume 34, para 98 wherein it was held that the multiplier may be\n\nincreased where the plaintiff is a high tax payer. That principle is also\n\napplicable in this case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">      In Halsbury (supra), it was stated that in applying the structured\n\nformula it is assumed that the return on fixed interest bearing securities is so\n\nmuch higher than 4 to 5 per cent that rough and ready allowance for\n\ninflation is thereby made.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">      It was stated:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">             \"14.   The multiplier method involves the\n             ascertainment of the loss of dependency or the\n             multiplicand having regard to the circumstances of\n             the case and capitalizing the multiplicand by an\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                   7</span>\n\n            appropriate multiplier. The choice of the multiplier\n            is determined by the age of the deceased (or that of\n            the claimants whichever is higher) and by the\n            calculation as to what capital sum, if invested at a\n            rate of interest appropriate to a stable economy,\n            would yield the multiplicand by way of annual\n            interest. In ascertaining this, regard should also be\n            had to the fact that ultimately the capital sum\n            should also be consumed-up over the period for\n            which the dependency is expected to last.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_30\">13.   Our attention has also been drawn to a recent decision of this Court in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1989786/\" id=\"a_6\">Sunil Kumar vs. Ram Singh Gaud &amp; Ors</a>. [2007 (12) SCALE 792] wherein\n\na Division Bench has opined as under:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">            \"9. Taking into consideration the present\n            income of the appellant as Rs.4,000/- per month;\n            and the permanent disability of 45% suffered by\n            him, we are of the view that the capacity of the\n            appellant to earn in future would be reduced by\n            Rs.1,800/- per month approximately. If 1/3rd is\n            deducted towards miscellaneous expenses, the loss\n            of income comes to Rs.1,200/- per month which,\n            in turn, comes to Rs.14,400/- per annum.\n            Appellant was 29 years of age at the time of\n            accident. Taking the multiplier to be 18 [as per the\n            Second Schedule to <a href=\"/doc/22871263/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 163A</a> of the Act], the\n            total loss of income comes to Rs.2,59,200/-.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_32\">\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                   8</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">       In that case, the injured suffered permanent disability of 45%. Even\n\ntherein the multiplier of 18 was applied. It was held that by reason of\n\ndisability suffered by the claimant his earning capacity would be reduced.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">      In the instant case, respondent has become totally immobile.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">14.   Our attention has also been drawn to a decision of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/35549/\" id=\"a_8\">Bijoy\n\nKumar Dugar v. Bidyadhar Dutta and Ors</a>. [(2006) 3 SCC 242]. In that\n\ncase, multiplier of 12 was applied. However, some observations were made\n\nthat in regard to future prospects of income in the course of employment or\n\nbusiness or profession, as the case may be, some cogent and reliable\n\nevidence have to be led.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">15.   In this case, respondent was a highly placed employee in a prestigious\n\npublic sector undertaking. By reason of termination of service, he is not\n\nonly deprived of his salary but also various other allowances to which he\n\nwas otherwise entitled to. His family members could have taken benefit of\n\nsome of the allowances.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_38\">\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">16.   We may, however, notice that in <a href=\"/doc/1683465/\" id=\"a_9\">General Manager, Kerala State Road\n\nTransport Corporation, Trivandrum vs. Susamma Thomas (Mrs.) &amp; ors</a>.\n\n[(1994) 2 SCC 176], this Court held:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                        9</span><p id=\"p_40\">\n\n\"9. The assessment of damages to compensate\nthe dependants is beset with difficulties because\nfrom the nature of things, it has to take into\naccount many imponderables, e.g., the life\nexpectancy of the deceased and the dependants,\nthe amount that the deceased would have earned\nduring the remainder of his life, the amount that he\nwould have contributed to the dependants during\nthat period, the chances that the deceased may not\nhave lived or the dependants may not live up to\nthe estimated remaining period of their life\nexpectancy, the chances that the deceased might\nhave got better employment or income or might\nhave lost his employment or income altogether.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">10. The manner of arriving at the damages is to\nascertain the net income of the deceased available\nfor the support of himself and his dependants, and\nto deduct therefrom such part of his income as the\ndeceased was accustomed to spend upon himself,\nas regards both self-maintenance and pleasure, and\nto ascertain what part of his net income the\ndeceased was accustomed to spend for the benefit\nof the dependants. Then that should be capitalised\nby multiplying it by a figure representing the\nproper number of year's purchase.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_42\">\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">11. Much of the calculation necessarily remains\nin the realm of hypothesis \"and in that region\narithmetic is a good servant but a bad master\"\n</p><p id=\"p_44\">since there are so often many imponderables. In\nevery case \"it is the over-all picture that matters\"\nand the court must try to assess as best as it can the\nloss suffered.\"\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                   10</span><p id=\"p_45\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_46\">17.   This aspect of the matter has also been considered in <a href=\"/doc/271657/\" id=\"a_10\">U.P. State Road\n\nTransport Corporation and Ors. v. Trilok Chandra and Ors</a>. [(1996) 4 SCC\n\n362] by a Three-Judge Bench of this Court in the following terms:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">            \"9. The compensation to be awarded has two\n            elements. One is the pecuniary loss to the estate of\n            the deceased resulting from the accident, the other\n            is the pecuniary loss sustained by the members of\n            his family for his death. The Court referred to\n            these two elements in the Gobald Motor Seivice's\n            [AIR 1962 SC 1] case. These two elements were to\n            be awarded under <a href=\"/doc/609788/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 1</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1837174/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 2</a> of the\n            Fatal Accidents Act, 1855 under which the claim\n            in that case arose. The Court in that case cautioned\n            that while making the calculations no part of the\n            claim under the first or the second element should\n            be included twice. The Court gave a very lucid\n            illustration, which can be quoted with profit:\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">                  `An illustration may clarify the position. X\n                  is the income of the estate of the deceased,\n                  Y is the yearly expenditure incurred by him\n                  on his dependents (we will ignore the other\n                  expenditure incurred by him). X-Y i.e. Z, is\n                  the amount he saves every year. The\n                  capitalised value of the income spent on the\n                  dependents, subject to relevant deductions,\n                  is the pecuniary loss sustained by the\n                  members of his family through his death.\n                  The capitalised value of his income, subject\n                  to relevant deductions, would be the loss\n                  caused to the estate by his death. If the\n                  claimants under both the heads are the same,\n                  and if they get compensation for the entire\n                  loss caused to the estate, they cannot claim\n                  again under the head of personal loss the\n                  capitalised income that might have been\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                    11</span>\n\n                   spent on them if the deceased were alive.\n                   Conversely, if they got compensation under\n                   <a href=\"/doc/609788/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 1</a>, representing the amount that the\n                   deceased would have spent on them, if\n                   alive, to that extent there should be\n                   deduction in their claim under <a href=\"/doc/946665/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 2</a> of\n                   the Act in respect of compensation for the\n                   loss caused to the estate. To put it\n                   differently if under <a href=\"/doc/609788/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 1</a> they got\n                   capitalised value of Y, under <a href=\"/doc/946665/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 2</a> they\n                   could get only the capitalised value of Z, for\n                   the capitalised value Y + Z = X would be\n                   the capitalised value of his entire income.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">{See also Bangalore Metropolitan Transport Corporation. vs. Sarojamma\n\nand Anr. [(2008) 5 SCC 142]}\n\n\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_47\">18.   Following the aforementioned precedents, we are of the opinion that\n\nin the peculiar facts and circumstances of this case, it is not necessary to\n\ninterfere either with the application of multiplier of eight or non-deduction\n\nof 1/3rd from his net salary. However, what was the net salary of the\n\nrespondent for the said purpose should have been determined. An employee\n\nwhen not in employment is not to pay his tax. Income tax payable from the\n\nsalary, therefore, was required to be deducted. It was so held in <a href=\"/doc/1895620/\" id=\"a_17\">National\n\nInsurance Company Ltd. v. Indira Srivastava and Ors</a>.         [(2008) 2 SCC\n\n763], stating:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                              12</span><p id=\"p_48\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">      \"17. This Court in Asha (supra) did not address\n      itself the questions raised before us. It does not\n      appear that any precedent was noticed nor the term\n      'just compensation' was considered in the light of\n      the changing societal condition as also the perks\n      which are paid to the employee which may or may\n      not attract income tax or any other tax. What\n      would be 'just compensation' must be determined\n      having regard to the facts and circumstances of\n      each case. The basis for considering the entire pay\n      packet is what the dependents have lost due to\n      death of the deceased. It is in the nature of\n      compensation for future loss towards the family\n      income.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">                   xxx           xxx          xxx\n\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">      19. The amounts, therefore, which were\n      required to be paid to the deceased by his\n      employer by way of perks, should be included for\n      computation of his monthly income as that would\n      have been added to his monthly income by way of\n      contribution to the family as contradistinguished\n      to the ones which were for his benefit. We may,\n      however, hasten to add that from the said amount\n      of income, the statutory amount of tax payable\n      thereupon must be deducted.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_49\">Incidentally, we may notice that in that case also this Court held:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">      \"21. If the dictionary meaning of the word\n      'income' is taken to its logical conclusion, it should\n      include those benefits, either in terms of money or\n      otherwise, which are taken into consideration for\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                      13</span>\n\n             the purpose of payment of income-tax or\n             profession tax although some elements thereof\n             may or may not be taxable or would have been\n             otherwise taxable but for the exemption conferred\n             thereupon under the statute.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_13\">                    xxx         xxx          xxx\n\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_14\">             25. The expression 'just' must also be given its\n             logical meaning. Whereas it cannot be a bonanza\n             or a source of profit but in considering as to what\n             would be just and equitable, all facts and\n             circumstances must be taken into consideration.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_50\">19.   The High Court has directed payment of interest at the rate of 9% per\n\nannum. We do not think that any case has been made out for interference\n\nwith the rate of interest. The appeal is dismissed subject to the modification\n\nthat from the gross income of the respondent, the amount of income tax as\n\nwas applicable at the relevant time should be deducted. The Tribunal is\n\ndirected to redetermine the amount of compensation in the light of this\n\njudgment. However, in the facts and circumstances of this case, there shall\n\nbe no order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_51\">\n</p><p id=\"p_52\">                                              .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_53\">                                                    [S.B. Sinha]\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                   14</span>\n\n\n                        .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_54\">                        [Cyriac Joseph]\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_55\">JANUARY 13, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":6,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"income of the deceased","formInput":"income%20of%20the%20deceased"},{"value":"multiplier","formInput":"multiplier"},{"value":"income tax returns ","formInput":"income%20tax%20returns%20"},{"value":"loss of dependency","formInput":"loss%20of%20dependency"},{"value":"future prospects","formInput":"future%20prospects"}],"citeList":[{"tid":136948773,"url":null,"title":"Section 166 in The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":785258,"url":null,"title":"The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":594667,"url":null,"title":"The Fatal Accidents Act, 1855"},{"tid":427855,"url":null,"title":"Article 136 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":41160316,"url":null,"title":"Section 168 in The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"}],"covers":[],"title":"Syed Basheer Ahamed & Ors vs Mohd. Jameel & Anr on 6 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-06","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":120548285,"url":null,"title":"Branch Manager National ... vs Bijay Kumar Pandey & Ors on 5 August, 2010"},{"tid":811978,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=55376","title":"New India Assurance Co Ltd vs Muthu Karuppan on 2 July, 2009"},{"tid":4317570,"url":null,"title":"Vijay Kumar Pandey & Ors vs Praveen Kumar Singh & Ors on 5 August, 2010"},{"tid":124581456,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=60389","title":"A.Dorairaj vs K.Karumbukonar on 11 April, 2012"},{"tid":189010067,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/GPM/judgement/04-08-2012/GPM25072012RVPET3102012.pdf","title":"Seema Madaan & Ors vs Balwant Singh & Ors on 25 July, 2012"}],"tid":918831,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"d","lastname":"jain","numcitedby":33,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33462","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Syed Basheer Ahamed &amp; Ors vs Mohd. Jameel &amp; Anr on 6 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D Jain</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: R.V. Raveendran, D.K. Jain</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                    REPORTABLE\n\n            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n               CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n          CIVIL APPEAL NO.             10 OF 2009\n         (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.18001 of 2006)\n\n\nSYED BASHEER AHAMED &amp; ORS.                     -- APPELLANTS\n\n\n                                VERSUS\n\n\nMOHD. JAMEEL &amp; ANR.                            --   RESPONDENT\n                                                    S\n\n\n\n                          JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">D.K. JAIN, J.:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">     Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2. Challenge in this appeal, by special leave, is to the\n\n  judgment and order dated 26th June, 2006 passed by the\n\n  High Court of Karnataka at Bangalore, holding that the\n\n  appellants     herein   are    entitled   to a compensation    of\n\f  Rs.3,56,000/- along with interest at the rate of 6% per\n\n  annum from the date of filing of the claim petition till the\n\n  date of actual deposit of the compensation under the <a href=\"/doc/785258/\" id=\"a_1\">Motor\n\n  Vehicles Act</a>, 1988 (for short `the Act'), as against the\n\n  compensation of Rs.6,08,000/- with interest at the rate of\n\n  6% per annum, awarded by the Motor Accident Claims\n\n  Tribunal, Mysore (for short `the Tribunal') vide order dated\n\n  19th April, 2002.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3. The appellants are the unfortunate parents and the three\n\n  sisters of the deceased. The first respondent is the owner of\n\n  the lorry, which was involved in the accident and the second\n\n  respondent is the insurance company with which the lorry\n\n  was insured. According to the appellants, on 3rd June, 1999\n\n  at about 10.00 a.m., the deceased aged about 20 years, was\n\n  riding on a luna moped when the lorry dashed against it\n\n  and ran over the deceased, killing him on the spot. It was\n\n  claimed that the deceased was engaged in his own business\n\n  under the name and style of Bharath Packing Cases\n\n  Industry, and was also dealing in cut size timber.\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                            2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f4. The appellants filed a petition under <a href=\"/doc/136948773/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 166</a> of the Act\n\n  for award of compensation on account of the death of the\n\n  deceased. In the petition, it was pleaded that the deceased\n\n  had   lucrative   business   and   was     earning   a   sum     of\n\n  Rs.20,000/- per month.         A claim for compensation of\n\n  Rs.68,30,000/- was made. Upon consideration of the\n\n  evidence adduced by the parties, in particular the Income\n\n  Tax Return filed by the deceased for the assessment year\n\n  1998-1999, wherein the total income from business was\n\n  declared at Rs.43,000/, the Tribunal rejected the stand of\n\n  the appellants/claimants that the earnings of deceased\n\n  were Rs.20,000/- per month. The Tribunal took the\n\n  monthly income of the deceased at Rs.7,000/- per month.\n\n  Deducting therefrom half of the said income towards\n\n  personal and living expenses of the deceased and taking the\n\n  age of the younger of the parents as the basis for\n\n  determining the multiplier as 14, the Tribunal quantified\n\n  the compensation at loss of dependency as Rs.5,88,000/-.\n\n  By adding Rs.10,000/- towards loss of expectation of life\n\n  and   Rs.10,000/-    towards     funeral    expenses     etc.,   it\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                   3</span>\n\f  determined the total compensation as Rs.6,08,000/-.         As\n\n  noted above, interest at the rate of 6% per annum was also\n\n  awarded.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5. Being aggrieved, the owner of the vehicle, respondent No.1\n\n  in this appeal, preferred appeal to the High Court.\n\n  Rejecting the plea of the owner of the vehicle that his lorry\n\n  was not involved in the accident, the High Court came to\n\n  the conclusion that on the basis of the Income Tax Return\n\n  the income of the deceased could not be more than\n\n  Rs.40,000/- per annum.         The High Court, however,\n\n  calculated   the   monthly   income   of   the   deceased   as\n\n  Rs.4,000/-. The High Court, however, did not interfere with\n\n  the deduction towards the personal expenses and the\n\n  multiplier applied by the Tribunal as also the other\n\n  amounts awarded to the claimants. The High Court, thus,\n\n  chose to reduce the compensation amount awarded to the\n\n  appellants   by    the   Tribunal   from   Rs.6,08,000/-    to\n\n  Rs.3,56,000/- on the ground that the monthly earnings of\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                              4</span>\n\f  the deceased had been taken on the higher side at\n\n  Rs.7,000/-. Feeling aggrieved, the claimants are before us.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">6. We have heard learned counsel for the parties.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">7. Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellants\n\n  submitted that the High Court, while taking the monthly\n\n  income of the deceased at Rs.4,000/- per month, has\n\n  ignored other evidence brought on record by the claimants,\n\n  namely, the sale figures of his business from M/s Bharath\n\n  Packing Cases Industry for the period from 1st April, 1998 to\n\n  31st March, 1999 as reflected in the ledger accounts of one\n\n  M/s Vasu Agarbathi (Ex.P-23), one of the customers of the\n\n  deceased. It was also contended that the High Court has\n\n  also failed to take into account the future prospects of the\n\n  deceased, whose business was bound to grow with the\n\n  passage of time. In support of the proposition that rise in\n\n  income of the deceased by way of promotion or otherwise\n\n  should be taken into consideration for determining his\n\n  income earning capacity, reliance was placed on the\n\n  decision of this Court in National Insurance Co. Ltd. Vs.\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                            5</span>\n\f    Indira Srivastava &amp; Ors.1       It was also pleaded that\n\n    deduction towards personal and living expenses of the\n\n    deceased should have been restricted to only one-third of\n\n    his monthly income.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8. Per contra, learned counsel appearing for the contesting\n\n    respondents submitted that in view of the fact that no oral\n\n    evidence was adduced by the claimants/appellants to prove\n\n    the income earning capacity of the deceased, reliance on the\n\n    Return of Income, filed by the deceased himself, for\n\n    determining his monthly income, could not be faulted and\n\n    the compensation determined by the High Court cannot be\n\n    said to be arbitrary and, therefore, no intervention in\n\n    exercise of power under <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_3\">Article 136</a> of the Constitution is\n\n    called for.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">9. <a href=\"/doc/41160316/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 168</a> of the Act enjoins the Tribunal to make an\n\n    award determining \"the amount of compensation which\n\n    appears to be just.\" However, the objective factors, which\n\n    may constitute the basis of compensation appearing as just,\n\n    have not been indicated in the Act. Thus, the expression\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">1</span>\n       (2008) 2 SCC 763\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                             6</span>\n\f    \"which appears to the just\" vests a wide discretion in the\n\n    Tribunal in the matter of determination of compensation.\n\n    Nevertheless, the wide amplitude of such power does not\n\n    empower the Tribunal to determine the compensation\n\n    arbitrarily, or to ignore settled principles relating to\n\n    determination of compensation. Similarly, although the Act\n\n    is a beneficial legislation, it can neither be allowed to be\n\n    used as a source of profit, nor as a windfall to the persons\n\n    affected nor should it be punitive to the person(s) liable to\n\n    pay compensation.     The determination of compensation\n\n    must be based on certain data, establishing reasonable\n\n    nexus between the loss incurred by the dependents of the\n\n    deceased and the compensation to be awarded to them. In\n\n    nutshell, the amount of compensation determined to be\n\n    payable to the claimant(s) has to be fair and reasonable by\n\n    accepted legal standards.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">10.In General Manager, Kerala State Road Transport\n\n    Corporation, Trivandrum Vs. Susamma Thomas (Mrs.)\n\n    &amp; Ors.2, M.N. Venkatachaliah, J. (as His Lordship then\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">2</span>\n       (1994) 2 SCC 176\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                              7</span>\n\f  was) had observed that the determination of the quantum\n\n  must answer what contemporary society \"would deem to be\n\n  a fair sum such as would allow the wrongdoer to hold up\n\n  his head among his neighbours and say with their approval\n\n  that he has done the fair thing\". The amount awarded must\n\n  not be niggardly since the \"law values life and limb in a free\n\n  society in generous scales\". At the same time, a misplaced\n\n  sympathy, generosity and benevolence cannot be the\n\n  guiding factor for determining the compensation.                 The\n\n  object of providing compensation is to place the claimant(s),\n\n  to the extent possible, in almost the same financial position,\n\n  as they were in before the accident and not to make a\n\n  fortune out of misfortune that has befallen them.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">11.As   noted   earlier,   in   the   matter   of    computation    of\n\n  compensation, there is no uniform rule or formula for\n\n  measuring the value of a human life.              Though a special\n\n  provision for assessment of compensation on structured\n\n  formula basis for the purpose of a claim petition under\n\n  <a href=\"/doc/22871263/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 163A</a> of the Act has been inserted in the Act with\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                                    8</span>\n\f    effect from 14th November, 1994, but no such formula has\n\n    been laid down for determination of compensation in a\n\n    claim petition under <a href=\"/doc/136948773/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 166</a> of the Act, though there is\n\n    no bar in taking the said schedule as a guiding factor while\n\n    determining the just compensation by applying multiplier\n\n    method. In fact, in Managing Director, TNSTC Ltd. Vs.\n\n    K.I. Bindu &amp; Ors.3, it has been observed that the second\n\n    schedule to the Act may serve as a guide but cannot be\n\n    used as an invariable ready reckoner.       In a catena of\n\n    decisions of this Court, certain broad principles which could\n\n    be applied for assessing just compensation have been\n\n    highlighted. It has been observed that in a fatal accident\n\n    action, the accepted measure of damages awarded to the\n\n    dependents is the pecuniary loss suffered and likely to be\n\n    suffered by them as a result of abrupt termination of life.\n\n    The question as to what factors should be kept in view for\n\n    calculating pecuniary loss to a dependent came up for\n\n    consideration before a three-Judge Bench of this Court in\n\n    Gobald Motor Service Ltd. &amp; Anr. Vs. R.M.K. Veluswami\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">3</span>\n       (2005) 8 SCC 473\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                                                              9</span>\n\f    &amp; Ors.4, with reference to a case under the <a href=\"/doc/594667/\" id=\"a_7\">Fatal Accidents\n\n    Act</a>, 1855, wherein, K. Subba Rao, J. (as His Lordship then\n\n    was) speaking for the Bench observed thus:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">            \"In calculating the pecuniary loss to the\n            dependants many imponderables enter into\n            the calculation. Therefore, the actual extent of\n            the pecuniary loss to the dependants may\n            depend upon data which cannot be\n            ascertained accurately, but must necessarily\n            be an estimate, or even partly a conjecture.\n            Shortly, stated, the general principle is that\n            the pecuniary loss can be ascertained only by\n            balancing on the one hand the loss to the\n            claimants of the future pecuniary benefit and\n            on the other any pecuniary advantage which\n            from whatever source comes to them by\n            reason of the death, that is, the balance of loss\n            and gain to a dependant by the death must be\n            ascertained.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_20\">12.Taking note of the afore-extracted observations in Gobald\n\n    Motor Service Ltd. (supra) in Susamma Thomas (supra), it\n\n    was   observed       that   the   assessment    of   damages   to\n\n    compensate         the dependents    is beset   with difficulties\n\n    because from the nature of things, it has to take into\n\n    account many imponderables, e.g. the life expectancy of the\n\n    deceased and the dependants, the amount that the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">4</span>\n       AIR 1962 SC 1\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">                                                                   1</span>\n\f  deceased would have earned during the remainder of his\n\n  life, the amount that he would have contributed to the\n\n  dependants during that period, the chances that the\n\n  deceased may not have lived or the dependants may not live\n\n  upto the estimated remaining period of their life expectancy,\n\n  the chances that the deceased might have got better\n\n  employment or income or may have lost his employment or\n\n  income altogether.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">13.Thus, for arriving at just compensation, it is necessary to\n\n  ascertain the net income of the deceased available for the\n\n  support of himself and his dependents at the time of his\n\n  death and the amount, which he was accustomed to spend\n\n  upon himself. This exercise has to be on the basis of the\n\n  data, brought on record by the claimant, which again\n\n  cannot be accurately ascertained and necessarily involves\n\n  an element of estimate or it may partly be even a\n\n  conjecture. The figure arrived at by deducting from the net\n\n  income of the deceased such part of income as he was\n\n  spending upon himself, provides a datum, to convert it into\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                                                            1</span>\n\f  a lump sum, by capitalising it by an appropriate multiplier\n\n  (when multiplier method is adopted).        An appropriate\n\n  multiplier is again determined by taking into consideration\n\n  several imponderable factors.    Since in the present case\n\n  there is no dispute in regard to the multiplier, we deem it\n\n  unnecessary to dilate on the issue.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">14.In the instant case, the main grievance of the appellant is\n\n  that the High Court erred in reducing the monthly income\n\n  of the deceased from Rs.7,000/- to Rs.4,000/-.     More so,\n\n  when the claim of the appellants was that the deceased was\n\n  earning about Rs.20,000/- per month.         It needs little\n\n  emphasis that insofar as the question of earnings of the\n\n  deceased is concerned, the onus lies on the claimants to\n\n  prove this fact by leading reliable and cogent evidence\n\n  before the Tribunal. A bare assertion in the claim petition\n\n  in that behalf is not sufficient to discharge that onus. In\n\n  the present case, as noticed earlier, the deceased was\n\n  carrying on a business. The Return of Income filed by him\n\n  for the assessment year 1998-1999 (Ex.P-34) was brought\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">                                                           1</span>\n\fon record along with his monthly turnover and tax paid\n\nstatements submitted to the Commercial Tax Officer (Ex.P-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">27). Copies of the current account (Ex.P-38) showing the\n\nmoney deposited in the bank maintained by the deceased\n\nhave also been brought on record. The Return of Income\n\nfiled on 15th April, 1998 and the accompanying document,\n\nnamely, trading and profit and loss account for the period\n\nending 31st March, 1998 show a net profit of Rs.42,996/-.\n\nTaking into consideration the said documents, the Tribunal\n\ntook the monthly income of the deceased at Rs.7,000/- per\n\nmonth. However, the High Court felt that in the light of the\n\nIncome Tax Return, declaring income from the business\n\ncarried on by the deceased, the yearly income of the\n\ndeceased was not more than Rs.40,000/- and, therefore,\n\nthe Tribunal was not justified in adopting the monthly\n\nincome of the deceased at Rs.7,000/- per month to work\n\nout the loss of dependency. According to the High Court,\n\nthe monthly income of the deceased should have been\n\ntaken at Rs.4,000/- per month.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">                                                         1</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">\f15.In our view, though the entries in the current account\n\n  (Ex.P-38) of the deceased and his transactions with his\n\n  client, namely, Vasu Agarbathi (Ex.P-23) may not per se be\n\n  cogent evidence to determine the yearly or monthly income\n\n  of the deceased from the business(s) he was carrying on, yet\n\n  we feel that these are some indicators in support of the\n\n  appellants' plea that the business income of the deceased in\n\n  the succeeding years could be more than what was declared\n\n  for the year ended 31st March, 1998. But it is again in the\n\n  realm of speculation, particularly when, unlike income from\n\n  salaries, earnings in a business may increase with the\n\n  buoyancy in business and at the same time may diminish\n\n  with a recession in trade.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">16.As regards the future prospects of the deceased, as noted\n\n  above, except for copies of account of the deceased in the\n\n  books of account of his client, after the death, no other\n\n  reliable evidence has been brought on record to show the\n\n  future plans of the deceased regarding expansion or\n\n  diversification of his business.    In our view, a bare\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">                                                           1</span>\n\f  argument by learned counsel for the appellants that the\n\n  deceased had a potential of expanding his business, cannot\n\n  be accepted as sufficient material to determine the future\n\n  prospects of the deceased.     The decisions of this Court\n\n  relied upon by learned counsel for the appellants do not lay\n\n  down any abstract proposition of law in this regard, which\n\n  are otherwise distinguishable on facts.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">17.In the circumstances, having regard to the material on\n\n  record, in our opinion, ends of justice would be met if the\n\n  income of the deceased is taken at Rs.5,500/- per month or\n\n  Rs.66,000/- per annum.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_32\">\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">18.On the question of deduction on account of personal\n\n  expenses by the deceased, there is no set formula which\n\n  could be applied in every case to determine as to what\n\n  should be the deduction on this account.    The contention\n\n  that deduction on that count cannot exceed one-third on\n\n  the ground that there is some statutory recognition in the\n\n  Second Schedule to the Act for such deduction, is\n\n  untenable.   The said deduction would depend upon the\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">                                                           1</span>\n\f  facts and circumstances of each case. In the present case,\n\n  no evidence was led on this point as well. In the absence of\n\n  any evidence to the contrary, the practice is to deduct\n\n  towards personal and living expenses of the deceased, one-\n\n  third of the income in case he was married and one-half\n\n  (50%) if he was a bachelor. Thus, there is no material on\n\n  record warranting interference with the consistent view of\n\n  both the courts below on the point.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">19.In view of the above discussion, the loss of dependency is\n\n  determined as Rs.33,000/- per annum and by applying a\n\n  multiplier of 14, the total loss of dependency is arrived at\n\n  Rs.4,62,000/-.   Adding Rs.20,000/- awarded under other\n\n  heads, the quantum of compensation is determined at\n\n  Rs.4,82,000/-. The amount shall also carry an interest at\n\n  the rate of 6% per annum, as awarded by the Tribunal, from\n\n  the date of the filing of the claim petition till the date of\n\n  actual payment. If any amount has already been paid or\n\n  deposited in terms of order passed by the Tribunal, the\n\n  same shall be adjusted from the amount now being\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">                                                            1</span>\n\f  awarded.   The interest element shall also be worked out\n\n  after the said adjustment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">20.In the result, the appeal succeeds in part and the judgment\n\n  of the High Court stands modified to the extent indicated\n\n  above. No order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_38\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">                                 ...........................................J.\n                                 ( R.V. RAVEENDRAN )\n\n\n\n\n                                 ...........................................J.\n                                 ( D.K. JAIN )\n\nNEW DELHI,\nJANUARY 6, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_40\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">                                                                           1</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":1,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"review petitions","formInput":"review%20petitions"},{"value":"review of review petition","formInput":"review%20of%20review%20petition"},{"value":"increment","formInput":"increment"},{"value":"chhabra","formInput":"chhabra"},{"value":"punjab state electricity board","formInput":"punjab%20state%20electricity%20board"},{"value":"kabir","formInput":"kabir"},{"value":"altamas kabir","formInput":"altamas%20kabir"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Er.Gurcharan Singh Grewal & Anr vs Punjab State Electricity Board & ... on 9 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-09","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":102086611,"url":null,"title":"Unknown vs Union Of India Through The ... on 2 July, 2012"},{"tid":175646118,"url":null,"title":"Abdulla.C vs (Jt 1997 (7) Sc 111) on 4 October, 2011"},{"tid":46385365,"url":null,"title":"Karunakaran.A.V vs Others (Jt 1997 (7) Sc 111) on 4 October, 2011"},{"tid":65894170,"url":null,"title":"K.S.Rajendra Kumar vs O.P. Saxena 1997 (6) Scc 36 on 25 September, 2012"},{"tid":162892537,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/Judis_Chennai/list_new2.asp?FileName=296579","title":"In The High Court Of Judicature At ... vs The State Of Tamil Nadu on 17 October, 2016"}],"tid":919896,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"a","lastname":"kabir","numcitedby":51,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33472","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Er.Gurcharan Singh Grewal &amp; Anr vs Punjab State Electricity Board &amp; ... on 9 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: A Kabir</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Markandey Katju</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                    1\n\n\n            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n             CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n         CIVIL APPEAL NOS. 65-67_____ OF 2009\n         @ S.L.P. (C) NOS.12512-12514 of 2007\n\n\nEr. Gurcharan Singh Grewal &amp; Anr.            ...Appellants\n\n\n\nVs.\n\n\nPunjab State Electricity Board &amp; Ors.        ...Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                    J U D G M E N T\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">ALTAMAS KABIR, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.     These three appeals arise out of orders dated\n\n       23rd September, 2005, 21st April, 2006 and 23rd\n\n       February,    2007,   relating    to    Civil     Writ\n\n       Petition No.16811 of 2003 and Review Petitions\n\n       filed therein before the High Court of Punjab\n\n       and Haryana at Chandigarh.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                          2</span><p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    The appellants herein filed the aforesaid writ\n\n      petition,         inter     alia,       for      the    following\n\n      relief:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">     \"(iv) Quashing the order no. 202 dated 9.7.2002\n\n     (Annexure<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_1\">     Indian     Penal    Code</a>-3)    passed     by    the\n\n     respondent No.3 withdrawing the benefits of pay\n\n     fixation already granted to petitioners Satinder\n\n     Singh and directing the respondent to step-up the\n\n     pay of the petitioners to that of their junior\n\n     Sh. Ram Prakash Shori and the petitioners may be\n\n     granted all arrears of Pay, retiral benefits and\n\n     other consequential benefits with interest @ 18%\n\n     per annum.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">4.    In    the       written     statement/counter           affidavit\n\n      filed      on     behalf    of    the      respondent,        Punjab\n\n      State Electricity Board, and its officers, it\n\n      was   stated       in     Paragraph     7     that     the   relief\n\n      claimed      by    the     petitioner       had   already          been\n\n      granted.         When the writ petition came up for\n\n      final       hearing        the     High       Court         on     23rd\n\n      September,         2005,    disposed        of    the       same     by\n\n      passing the following order :-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                                       3</span><p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">           \"In view of the averments made in paragraph\n\n           7    of    the   written      statement,      the    writ\n\n           petition has been rendered infructuous.\n\n           Disposed of as such.\"\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">\n\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_12\">5.   Subsequently,          a    review    petition       came    to   be\n\n     filed by the writ petitioners before the High\n\n     Court      claiming         that    the    statement      made    in\n\n     paragraph          7    of     the        written     statement,\n\n     concerned only the writ petitioner No.2, and\n\n     without considering the case of the respondent\n\n     No.1 on a separate footing he too was denied\n\n     relief, although he was not covered by such\n\n     statement.          When the Review Petition came up\n\n     for       hearing      on    21st    April,      2006,      learned\n\n     counsel for the petitioners was not present\n\n     and on the submissions made on behalf of the\n\n     respondents that no relief had been claimed in\n\n     the writ petition on behalf of the petitioner\n\n     No.1,      the    High      Court    dismissed       the     review\n\n     petition by passing the following order:-\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                   4</span>\n\n       \"Learned counsel for the respondent submits that\n\n       the relief claimed in the review petition is not\n\n       claimed in the main petition for petitioner No.1.\n\n       Therefore,      the    review        petition   is    not\n\n       maintainable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">       Dismissed.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">6.      On dismissal of the review petition in the\n\n        absence of the counsel for the petitioners, a\n\n        miscellaneous        application         was    filed      for\n\n        modification of the order passed in the review\n\n        petition, which was also dismissed by the High\n\n        Court on 23rd February, 2007.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">7.     It is against the said three orders of the High\n\nCourt that these appeals have been filed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">8. Appearing for the appellants, Mr. Nidesh Gupta,\n\nlearned senior advocate, submitted that when the\n\nwrit    petition       was   filed     on    behalf    of   both   the\n\nappellants, it was only natural that the reliefs\n\ntherein had been claimed in respect of both and it\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                                 5</span>\n\n\ncould not be confined to the appellant No.2 alone,\n\nas was done in the instant case, merely on account\n\nof the statement made in the written statement of\n\nthe respondents that the grievance of the appellant\n\nNo.2   had    already    been    addressed.            Mr.     Gupta\n\nsubmitted     that    the     appellants     were       similarly\n\nsituated and it was their common ground that they\n\nwere   receiving     lesser   salary     than     their      junior.\n\nMr. Gupta submitted that Paragraph 7 of the writ\n\npetition     was   absolutely    clear     that    it     was   the\n\ncommon case of the appellants that since they were\n\nreceiving lesser pay than their junior, Shri Ram\n\nPrakash Shori, who was receiving a higher salary,\n\ntheir salaries were also required to be stepped up\n\nto that of Shri Shori.          Mr. Gupta also urged that\n\nthe position would be further clarified from the\n\nquestion of law formulated in Paragraph 9 of the\n\nwrit   petition.        It    was   urged       that      it    was,\n\ntherefore, wrong to say that no case had been made\n\nout on behalf of the appellant No.1 and hence no\n\nrelief could be granted in his favour.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                        6</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">9.   Referring to prayer (iv) in the writ petition,\n\n     Mr.    Gupta    urged      that    specific      reference         had\n\n     been     made     to    the      appellant      No.2,      Satinder\n\n     Singh, since his pay had been stepped up but\n\n     was, thereafter, reduced by an order dated 9th\n\n     July,     2002,      passed       by     the   respondent         No.3\n\n     withdrawing the benefit of pay fixation which\n\n     had already been given to him.                  Mr. Gupta urged\n\n     that the prayer, however, was not confined to\n\n     the appellant No.2 alone, but to the appellant\n\n     No.1 also, as otherwise the very purpose of him\n\n     being made petitioner No.1 in the writ petition\n\n     would be meaningless.              Mr. Gupta submitted that\n\n     the High Court was             misled into relying on the\n\n     statement made in paragraph 7 of the written\n\n     statement filed by the respondent in dismissing\n\n     the writ petition as far as the appellant No.1\n\n     was     concerned.         Even    while       considering        the\n\n     review    petition,         in    the     absence     of    learned\n\n     counsel     for      the      appellants,       the     Court      was\n\n     persuaded       to     accept      the     statement       made     on\n\n     behalf of the respondent that relief claimed in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                    7</span>\n\n\n      the review petition had not been claimed in the\n\n      writ petition itself as far as the appellant\n\n      No.1 is concerned and the review petition was\n\n      not,    therefore,      maintainable.                Mr.    Gupta\n\n      submitted that the orders passed on the writ\n\n      petition and review petitions were passed on an\n\n      erroneous understanding that the appellant No.1\n\n      had    not   prayed   for   any    relief       in    the    writ\n\n      petition and he was not therefore entitled to\n\n      the reliefs prayed for by the appellants.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">10.     Mr. Jagdish Singh Chhabra, who appeared for\n\n      the    Punjab   State   Electricity        Board       and    its\n\n      authorities,     reiterated       the    submissions         made\n\n      before the High Court that in the absence of\n\n      any case being made out or any relief being\n\n      claimed on behalf of the appellant No.1 in the\n\n      writ    petition      the   High        Court        had    quite\n\n      correctly dismissed the writ petition on the\n\n      ground that no relief could be given to the\n\n      appellant No.1 and the relief prayed for by the\n\n      appellant No.2 had already been given to him.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                                     8</span>\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">11.   Mr.   Chhabra     also     attempted       to    justify       the\n\n      disparity in the pay of Shri Shori and the\n\n      appellant No.1 by urging that the appellant No.\n\n      1 had been granted the promotional scale with\n\n      effect     from    1st    January,       1996,     where       the\n\n      benefits of increment in the scale were lower.\n\n      On the other hand, Shri Shori who joined the\n\n      services of the Board in 1974, was granted the\n\n      promotional       scale    on     17th    May,     2006,      with\n\n      effect    from     1st    September,       2001,       when    the\n\n      increments and the pay-scales were higher.                     Mr.\n\n      Chhabra submitted that it is the disparity in\n\n      the   incremental         benefits       that    led    to     the\n\n      anomaly of the appellant No.1 getting a lower\n\n      salary in the promotional scale.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">12.
