Having regard to the submissions made on behalf\n\nof    the      respective       parties,        we     have      little\n\nhesitation      in   accepting        Mr.   Gupta's      submissions\n\nthat since the writ petition had been jointly filed\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                       9</span>\n\n\non behalf of the appellants, whose interest was\n\ncommon, the prayer therein should not have been\n\nconfined to the appellant No.2 alone and that the\n\nHigh     Court    should        have    granted        relief    to    the\n\nappellant No.1 also by directing that his pay also\n\nbe stepped up to that of his junior, Shri R.P.\n\nShori.       Although, this question does not appear to\n\nhave    been     gone    into      by   the    High    Court     for   the\n\nsimple reason that the writ petition was disposed\n\nof only on the averments contained in paragraph 7\n\nof     the    written     statement           filed    on     behalf    of\n\nrespondents       that    the      grievance      of    the     appellant\n\nNo.2 duly addressed, there ought to have been at\n\nleast some discussion in the judgment of the High\n\nCourt regarding the claim of the appellant No.1.\n\nUnfortunately, the case of the appellant No.1 was\n\nnot considered at all by the High Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">13.    Something        may   be    said      with     regard     to   Mr.\n\nChhabra's        submissions        about       the    difference       in\n\nincrement in the scales which the appellant No.1\n\nand Shri Shori are placed, but the same is still\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                                              10</span>\n\n\ncontrary to the settled principle of law that a\n\nsenior    cannot    be   paid    lesser     salary    than    his\n\njunior. In such circumstances, even if, there was a\n\ndifference in the incremental benefits in the scale\n\ngiven to the appellant No.1 and the scale given to\n\nShri    Shori,   such    anomaly     should    not   have    been\n\nallowed    to    continue      and   ought     to    have    been\n\nrectified so that the pay of the appellant No.1 was\n\nalso stepped up to that of Shri Shori, as appears\n\nto have been done in the case of the appellant\n\nNo.2.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">14. We are unable to accept the reasoning of the\n\n   High Court in this regard or the submissions\n\n   made in support thereof by Mr. Chhabra, since\n\n   the very object to be achieved is to bring the\n\n   pay scale of the appellant No.1 at par with that\n\n   of his junior.         We are clearly of the opinion\n\n   that    the     reasoning    of    the     High   Court    was\n\n   erroneous       and   the    appellant     No.1    was    also\n\n   entitled to the same benefits of pay parity with\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                                         11</span>\n\n\n   Shri Shori as has been granted to the appellant\n\n   No.2.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">15.We, accordingly, allow the appeals and set aside\n\n   the judgment of the High Court.           Consequently,\n\n   the     writ   petition   is   also   allowed   and   the\n\n   respondents are directed to extend the benefits\n\n   of pay parity with Shri Shori to the appellant\n\n   No.1, as was done in the case of the appellant\n\n   No.2.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                                        12</span><p id=\"p_29\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">16.     The writ petition is allowed to the aforesaid\n\n      extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">17.There will, however, be no order as to costs.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">                                     _____________________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">                                         (ALTAMAS KABIR)\n\n\n                                     _____________________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">                                      (MARKANDEY KATJU)\nNew Delhi\nDated: 09.01.2009\n\f</p>"}, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-09","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":1239882,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=35421","title":"Chikkarangaiah & Ors vs State Of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33468","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Rajender Singh &amp; Anr vs State Of Haryana on 9 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: L S Panta</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Lokeshwar Singh Panta, B. Sudershan Reddy</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                              Reportable\n             IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n             CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n        CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 1662-1663 OF 2005\nRajender Singh &amp; Anr.                                     .....\nAppellants\n                            Versus\nState of Haryana                           .....   Respondent\n\n                          WITH\n             CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 355 OF 2006\nSuraj Bhan                                                .....\nAppellant\n                            Versus\nState of Haryana                                          .....\nRespondent\n                          WITH\n             CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 615 OF 2008\nRam Niwas                                                 .....\nAppellant\n                            Versus\nState of Haryana                                          .....\nRespondent\n\n\n                      JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Lokeshwar Singh Panta, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1. Seven accused, namely, Suraj Bhan (A-1), Balraj (A-2), Ram\n\nNiwas (A-3), Rajender Singh (A-4), Dharambir (A-5), Sube Singh\n\n(A-6) and Sajjan Singh (A-7) were tried by Learned Additional\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                 2</span>\n\n\nSessions Judge, Rohtak, in Sessions Case No. 119 of 2002 for\n\ncommitting the murder of Dinesh aged about 20 years.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.     By judgment and order dated 06.02.2003, the Learned\n\nTrial Judge convicted (A-1), (A-2), (A-3), (A-4), (A-5) and (A-7)\n\nunder Section 302 read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 34</a> of the Indian Penal\n\nCode and <a href=\"/doc/1243353/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 342</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 34</a> of the Indian Penal\n\nCode   (for   short   `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_4\">IPC</a>')   and   sentenced   each   to   undergo\n\nimprisonment for life and a fine of Rs. 10,000/- each and in\n\ndefault of payment of fine, to undergo rigorous imprisonment for\n\nthree years and under <a href=\"/doc/1243353/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 342</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_6\">34</a> IPC, they were sentenced\n\nto undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of six months\n\nwith a fine of Rs. 1,000/- each and in default of payment of fine,\n\nto undergo rigorous imprisonment for one month.              All the\n\nsentences were, however, ordered to run concurrently. Out of\n\nfine if realized, 90 per cent thereof was ordered to be paid to the\n\nlegal representatives of the deceased Dinesh. The Learned Trial\n\nJudge acquitted (A-6).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">3. The accused filed three sets of appeals before the High Court\n\nof Punjab &amp; Haryana at Chandigarh. (A-1), (A-4) and (A-5) filed\n\nCriminal Appeal No. 194-DB of 2003 whereas Criminal Appeal\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                                    3</span>\n\n\nNo. 207-DB of 2003 was filed by (A-2) and Criminal Appeal No.\n\n224-DB of 2003 was filed by (A-3) and (A-7). The High Court by\n\na common judgment and order dated August 16, 2005 modified\n\nthe judgment of the Trial Court. It upheld the conviction and\n\nsentence of (A-1), (A-2), (A-3) and (A-4). It, however, acquitted\n\n(A-5) and (A-7).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">4.   (A-1), (A-2), (A-3) and (A-4) have now approached this Court\n\nin these appeals. These appeals were heard together and shall\n\nstand disposed of by this common judgment.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">5.    The incident leading to the prosecution of the appellants\n\noccurred on 29.05.2002.      Dinesh, son of Dharambir (PW-1)\n\ncomplainant, had gone to Delhi for ascertaining the date of his\n\ninterview   for    recruitment   to   the   Police   Force   of    Delhi\n\nGovernment, but till late night he did not return to his village\n\nSundana, Tehsil Kalanaur, District Rohtak.           On the following\n\nday, i.e. 30.05.2002, at about 4.00 a.m. Randhir Singh (PW-10)\n\nelder brother of PW-11 told PW-1 that Dinesh was wrongfully\n\nconfined in the house of appellant-Suraj Bhan (A-1).              It was\n\nJagbir (PW-9), a jeep driver, who disclosed this fact to PW-10.\n\nOn coming to know the fact of confinement of his son by A-1,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                               4</span>\n\n\nPW-1 alongwith his father Sube Singh (PW-11) and uncle\n\nRaghbir Singh rushed to the house of A-1, where they found the\n\nouter door of the house bolted from inside. They all heard the\n\nshrieks of Dinesh \"maar diya, maar diya\".       Thereupon, they\n\npeeped through the window and saw that all the appellants\n\nincluding A-6 (since acquitted) had made Dinesh to lie down on\n\nthe floor of the room, his hands and legs were tied with a rope.\n\nIn the electric bulb light and within their sight, A-1 inserted a\n\n\"danda\" (wooden stick) in the anus of Dinesh, who cried loudly\n\nin pain. On seeing the occurrence, PW-1, PW-11 and Raghbir\n\nSingh raised an alarm and forcibly broke open the door of the\n\nroom. On seeing them, the appellants fled away and took\n\n\"danda\" and piece of rope with them. They attended Dinesh, but\n\nhe succumbed to his injuries at the spot.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">6.   Motive behind the alleged occurrence was that about a\n\nyear prior to the incident in question, i.e. 28.04.2001, A-1 got a\n\ncase registered against Dinesh under <a href=\"/doc/1279834/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 376</a> IPC for\n\ncommitting sexual intercourse with his daughter.      In the said\n\ncase, Dinesh was acquitted by the trial court on 18.03.2002.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                             5</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">7.   PW-1 requested his father Sube Singh (PW-11) and uncle\n\nRaghbir Singh to safe guard the dead body of Dinesh at the\n\nplace of occurrence and himself rushed to the Police Station for\n\nlodging a report.   On the way, Om Parkash, ASI (PW-14) met\n\nPW-1 at the curve of Beri Road, where, he made statement\n\n(Ex.PA) at 9.00 a.m. narrating the entire incident. PW-14 then\n\nmade his endorsement (Ex.PA-2) on the said report and sent the\n\nsame to the Police Station through Constable Krishan Kumar,\n\non the basis of which formal FIR (Ex. PJ) was recorded by MHC\n\nMohinder Singh (PW-6) at 11.00 a.m. on the same day.         The\n\nSpecial Report thereof was sent to the Illaqa Judicial Magistrate\n\nthrough Constable Udham Singh (PW-4), which was received at\n\nhis residence at 2.35 p.m. at Rohtak.        Thereafter, PW-14\n\nalongwith PW-1 rushed to the place of occurrence and got the\n\ndead body photographed from Gobind Ram, Photographer\n\n(PW-7).   PW-14 prepared the inquest report (Ex. PM) and then\n\nsent the dead body for post mortem examination. From the spot,\n\nPW-14 lifted blood stained earth, pair of sport shoes (Exs. P11\n\nand P12) and jute rope (Ex.P13).         They were taken into\n\npossession vide recovery memos (Ex. PB to Ex. PD) and sealed in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                             6</span>\n\n\nseparate parcels.   At the spot, rough site plan (Ex.PR) of the\n\nplace of occurrence was also prepared by the Investigating\n\nOfficer. On the same day, investigation of the case was taken\n\nover by Sub-Inspector Rohtas Singh (PW-12). He recorded the\n\nstatements of PW-1, Randhir, Zile Singh, Jagbir (PW-9), a jeep\n\ndriver, and other witnesses. Thereafter, PW-12 searched for the\n\naccused in the village but they were found missing. The Deputy\n\nSuperintendent of Police had also visited the place of occurrence\n\nand verified the investigation of the case. Naresh Kumar,\n\nConstable (PW-3), took the dead body of deceased Dinesh to the\n\nHospital for post mortem examination.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">8.   On 01.06.2002, A-1, A-2, A-3 and A-4 were produced\n\nbefore PW-12 by Zile Singh.         After their arrest by the\n\nInvestigating Officer, A-1 during interrogation made disclosure\n\nstatement (Ex.PQ) to the effect that he had kept concealed\n\n\"danda\" and \"rope\" under an iron box in his house and in\n\npursuance thereof, he got recovered \"danda\" (Ex. P-18) (broken\n\ninto two pieces) and \"rope\" (Ex. P-19), which were taken into\n\npossession vide recovery memo (Ex.PQ/4). The entire recovered\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                            7</span>\n\n\narticles were sealed and deposited with MHC of Police Station,\n\nKalanaur.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">9.    On    12.06.2003,    Ajit      Singh        ASI    (PW-13)   made     an\n\napplication (Ex.PN) to Dr. Paramjeet (PW-8) for obtaining his\n\nopinion whether recovered \"danda\" could cause fatal injury to\n\nthe deceased or not, and Doctor opined in the affirmative. After\n\ntaking his opinion Ex.PO, pieces of \"danda\" were resealed. After\n\ncompletion of the investigation and receipt of the post mortem\n\nreport and other material on record, charge sheet came to be\n\nfiled against the accused.        At the initial stage, A-1, A-2, A-3 and\n\nA-4 were challaned for commission of offences punishable under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1243353/\" id=\"a_8\">Sections    342</a>/<a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_9\">302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_10\">34</a>     IPC.         Later      on,    vide   order    dated\n\n30.09.2002, A-5, A-6 and A-7 were also summoned under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/435819/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 319</a> Cr.P.C. All the accused persons pleaded not guilty\n\nto the charges and claimed to be tried.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">10.   The   prosecution,     in     order    to    substantiate     its   case,\n\nexamined as many as 14 witnesses, namely, Dharmabir\n\n(PW-1), who lodged the complaint (Ex.PA); Sumit Kumar,\n\nDraftsman (PW-2), prepared the scaled site plan (Ex.PE) of the\n\nplace of occurrence; Naresh Kumar, Constable (PW-3) placed his\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                               8</span>\n\n\naffidavit (Ex.-PF) on record regarding taking the dead body for\n\npost mortem examination; Udam Singh, Constable (PW-4) filed\n\nhis affidavit (Ex.-PG) regarding taking the Special Report to the\n\nIllaqa Judicial Magistrate; Jagbir Singh Constable (PW-5), took\n\nthe case property to Forensic Science Laboratory, Madhuban;\n\nMohinder Singh, Head Constable (PW-6),      recorded the formal\n\nFIR (Ex.-PJ); Gobind Ram, Photographer (PW-7), proved on\n\nrecord photographs (Exs. P-1 to P-5) and negatives thereof\n\n(Exs.P-6 to P-10); Dr. Paramjit (PW-8), conducted the post\n\nmortem and proved on record the post mortem report (Ex.PK);\n\nJagbir Singh (PW-9) a Jeep Driver; Randhir Singh (PW-10), who\n\nafter being informed by PW-9 regarding the fact of confinement\n\nof Dinesh at the house of Suraj Bhan (A-1) had disclosed the\n\nsaid fact to PW-1; Sube Singh (PW-11), an eye witness of the\n\noccurrence; Rohtas Singh SI (PW-12), the Investigating Officer of\n\nthis case; Ajit Singh ASI (PW-13) and Om Parkash ASI (PW-14),\n\nwho had also completed the formal investigation of the case.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">11.   The accused in their statements recorded under <a href=\"/doc/767287/\" id=\"a_12\">Section\n\n313</a> Cr.P.C denied the incriminating evidence appearing against\n\nthem. They pleaded that they have been implicated in a false\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                 9</span>\n\n\ncase and they claimed to be innocent. They examined three\n\ndefence witnesses, namely, Suraj Mal (DW-1), who deposed\n\nregarding disconnection of the electric connection at the house\n\nof A-1; Rajinder Singh, DSP (DW-2), on whose verification three\n\npersons, namely, Sajjan, Dharambir and Sube Singh were found\n\ninnocent in this case and Jagbir (DW-3) who was married to\n\nPoonam, daughter of Suraj Bhan (A-1) on 26.05.2002. DW-3\n\nstated    that   on   the   evening   of   25.09.2002   Dinesh   had\n\nmisbehaved with his wife at his Village Kohla.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">12.    The trial court, on appraisal of the entire evidence on\n\nrecord, held A-1, A-2, A-3, A-4, A-5 and A-7 guilty of the charges\n\nand convicted them under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/1243353/\" id=\"a_14\">342</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_15\">Section\n\n34</a> of Indian Penal Code. However, learned trial judge acquitted\n\nA-6.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">13.      Being aggrieved, the accused filed three sets of separate\n\nappeals before the High Court. The High Court dismissed the\n\nappeals of A-1, A-2, A-3 and A-4.          It, however, allowed the\n\nappeals of A-5 and A-7 and accordingly acquitted them.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                                                  10</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">14.   Feeling   aggrieved   thereby   and   dissatisfied   with   the\n\njudgment of the High Court, the above-said appeals have been\n\nfiled in this Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">15. Ms. Garima Prashad, learned counsel appearing on behalf of\n\nthe appellants, contended that the evidence produced in this\n\ncase is not sufficient and convincing to warrant the conviction of\n\nthe appellants. She contended that the evidence of PW-1 and\n\nPW-11 could not be accepted as they are both interested\n\nwitnesses related to the deceased.      She next contended that\n\nPW-1, PW-9 and PW-10 in their deposition have given a\n\nconcocted version which casts severe doubts about truthfulness\n\nof the prosecution case.    The learned counsel also contended\n\nthat the evidence appearing on record against the appellants is\n\nverbatim version which was taken into consideration by the trial\n\ncourt with regard to the acquittal of A-5, A-6 and A-7 and,\n\ntherefore, the case of the appellants cannot be decided on any\n\nother scale and should have been treated at par for giving\n\nbenefits of doubt to the appellants as it was considered for the\n\nacquittal of A-5, A-6 and A-7. The learned counsel then\n\ncontended that as per the post mortem report (Ex. PK), as many\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                                                   11</span>\n\n\nas 12 injuries were found on the dead body of Dinesh which\n\nwould support the defence version of DW-3 that the deceased\n\nwas given beatings by the village people of his village Kohla,\n\nwhen Dinesh misbehaved with his wife at their residence on\n\n29.05.2002. It was also argued that there is no reliable evidence\n\nbrought on record to prove that the appellants also shared\n\ncommon intention to murder Dinesh and in the absence of such\n\nevidence, the appellants could not be convicted for offence\n\npunishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 302</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 34</a> IPC.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">16.   Mr. Sandeep Chaturvedi, Advocate, appearing on behalf of\n\nthe appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 615/2008, has adopted\n\nand supported the arguments made by Ms. Garima Prashad,\n\nAdvocate.     As against that, Mr. Rajiv Gaur Naseem, Advocate\n\nappearing on behalf of the State, has canvassed for the\n\ncorrectness of the view taken by the trial judge which was\n\nconfirmed by the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">17.   In order to appreciate the aforesaid rival contentions of the\n\nlearned     counsel   for   the   parties,   we   have   independently\n\nscrutinized the oral and documentary evidence appearing on\n\nrecord.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                                            12</span><p id=\"p_20\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">18. PW-1, father of the deceased Dinesh, at the relevant time\n\n   was serving in the Police Department. On 29.05.2002 he was\n\n   on leave for a period of one month. He stated that his son\n\n   Dinesh had applied for recruitment in the Police of Delhi\n\n   Government. On 29.05.2002 Dinesh had gone to Delhi to\n\n   confirm about the date of interview to be held for the post.\n\n   He did not return to his house till late in the night.    On\n\n   30.05.2002 at about 4.00 a.m., Randhir Singh, elder brother\n\n   of his father Sube Singh (PW-11), came to his house and\n\n   disclosed that Dinesh was wrongfully confined by A-1 in his\n\n   house. This information was given to Randhir Singh by\n\n   Jagbir (PW-9), a jeep driver. On receipt of this information,\n\n   he alongwith his father (PW-11) and uncle Randhir Singh\n\n   went to the house of A-1. The outer door of the house of A-1\n\n   was found bolted from inside. They peeped through the\n\n   window and noticed that Dinesh was made to lie facing his\n\n   face towards the floor of the room. At that time, an electric\n\n   bulb was burning inside the room. A-1 inserted \"danda\" in\n\n   the anus of Dinesh in their presence and his hands and both\n\n   legs were tied by a piece of rope. Dinesh was crying in pain.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                                             13</span>\n\n\nThey raised cry and in the process they broke open the door\n\nand entered the room.      All the accused ran away carrying\n\n\"danda\" and \"rope\" with them. As per his version, in spite of\n\ntheir best efforts, Dinesh could not be survived. He also\n\nstated that about one year prior to the present incident, A-1\n\ngot a false case registered against Dinesh under <a href=\"/doc/1279834/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 376</a>\n\nIPC in which his son was acquitted by the Court and as a\n\nresult thereof, A-1 was nursing a grudge against his son. He\n\ntestified the contents of the repot (Ex.PA) lodged to the Police,\n\non the basis of which FIR (Ex. PJ) came to be registered by\n\nPW-6 at the Police Station. This witness has corroborated the\n\nversion of PW-12, the Investigating Officer, in regard to\n\ntaking into possession blood stained earth, a pair of sports\n\nshoes belonging to deceased Dinesh and preparation of the\n\nparcels containing the seized articles affixed with seals. He\n\nshowed his knowledge of ignorance about the marriage of the\n\ndaughter of A-1 with Jagbir (DW-3) son of Om Prakash,\n\nresident of village Kohlapur, District Sonipat. A suggestion\n\nthat on 29.05.2002 Dinesh had gone to village Kohlapur and\n\nthere he misbehaved with Poonam, as a result thereof he was\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                                               14</span>\n\n\n  given beatings by the village people, has been emphatically\n\n  denied by him. He has identified two pieces of \"danda\"\n\n  (Exs.P-18 and P-19), which were used by A-1 in the\n\n  commission of the crime. He categorically stated that there\n\n  was sufficient electric bulb light inside the room when they\n\n  saw accused persons giving beatings to Dinesh. A suggestion\n\n  of the defence that on receiving telephonic information from\n\n  Jagbir (DW-3) son-in-law of A-1, he alongwith his father PW-\n\n  11 and A-1 went to village Kohla in a hired jeep and brought\n\n  his injured son in the said jeep and then they threshed\n\n  Dinesh at bus stand of village Sundana and as a result\n\n  whereof Dinesh died on 30.05.2002 at about 8.00 p.m., has\n\n  been denied by him.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">19.PW-11,   the   second   eyewitness   of   the   incident,   has\n\n  corroborated the entire testimony of PW-1.       He was cross-\n\n  examined at length but nothing could be elicited from his\n\n  statement which casts any doubt about the truthfulness of\n\n  his testimony. Jagbir PW-9, the jeep driver, deposed that on\n\n  29.05.2002 at about 8.30 a.m. Ballu (A-2) alongwith four\n\n  other persons, who were identified in the Court, came to his\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">\f                                                          15</span>\n\n\nhouse and asked him to take them to village Kohla. They\n\nhired his jeep and he took them to village Kohla. They left\n\nhim with his jeep on the village street. On hearing alarm, he\n\nrushed to the place where he found son of PW-1 present. All\n\nthe five accused persons then asked him to take the son of\n\nPW-1 to village Sundana, but initially he refused to oblige\n\nthem as he apprehended danger to the life of the son of PW-\n\n1, but later on from the village Kohla he took the son of PW-1\n\nalongwith A-1 and six more persons in the jeep and left them\n\nexcept Sube Singh (A-6) at bus stand of village Sudana. He\n\ndisclosed this incident to Randhir Singh Subedar uncle of\n\nPW-1 on the same night.         This witness in the cross-\n\nexamination has stated that village Kohla is at a distance of\n\n15-16 KMs from Gohana and Gohana is at a distance of\n\nabout 25-30 KMs from Rohtak, whereas village Kohla is at a\n\ndistance of about 60 KMs from village Sundana. He stated\n\nthat A-1 and son (Deceased) of PW-1 had met him at the\n\nhouse of the daughter of A-1 in village Kohla. He admitted\n\nthat A-1 told him that prior to this incident Dinesh had\n\nteased his daughter and on the day of incident Dinesh had\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">\f                                                             16</span>\n\n\n   gone to the house of DW-3, son-in-law of A-1. A suggestion of\n\n   the defence that Dinesh was assaulted by the people of\n\n   village Kohla and as a result thereof, he could not walk\n\n   properly has been denied by him. He also denied the\n\n   suggestion that he had brought injured Dinesh in his jeep\n\n   and left him at Sundana Bus Stand. A further suggestion\n\n   that   PW-1    and   PW-11   grandfather   of   Dinesh,   had\n\n   accompanied him in the jeep while going to village Sundana,\n\n   has been denied by him.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">20.Randhir Singh (PW-10) deposed that on 30.05.2002 at about\n\n   2.30 a.m. while he was sleeping in his house, Jagbir (PW-9)\n\n   came there and disclosed that A-1 had confined Dinesh in\n\n   his house.    He immediately rushed to the house of PW-1,\n\n   woke him up and thereafter passed on the said information\n\n   to PW-1.     He stated that on the next morning, he came to\n\n   know about the murder of Dinesh in the house of A-1.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">21. In the teeth of the evidence of eyewitnesses PWs 1 and 11,\n\n   corroborated by the testimony of PW-9 and PW-10 discussed\n\n   above, it is established beyond any shadow of doubt that in\n\n   fact the occurrence had taken place at the given time in the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">\f                                                           17</span>\n\n\nhouse of A-1 where the dead body of Dinesh was found lying\n\nby the Police which was sent to the Doctor for post mortem\n\nexamination. PW-1 immediately lodged complaint (Ex. PJ) of\n\nthe incident to                   Om Prakash, ASI (PW-14) who\n\nmet him on the way leading to the Police Station. The names\n\nof all the accused were specifically mentioned in the said\n\ncomplaint. The accused persons were not found present in\n\nthe village when the Investigating Officer visited the place of\n\noccurrence. A-1, A-2, A-3 and A-4 were produced before\n\nRohtas Singh S.I. (PW-12) by Zile Singh, who is the resident\n\nof the same village. Recovery of two pieces of \"danda\" (Exs.P-\n\n18 and P-19) and \"rope\" (Ex. PQ/3) taken into possession by\n\nPW-12 pursuant to the disclosure statement (Ex.PQ) made by\n\nA-1 during the course of interrogation, has been proved\n\nwhich were used by the appellants in the commission of the\n\noffence.   The ocular version of PW-1 and PW-11, the\n\neyewitnesses, has been further corroborated by Dr. Paramjit,\n\nwho found as many as 12 injuries on the dead body of\n\nDinesh. Dr. Paramjit in his post mortem report (Ex.PK) had\n\nnoticed the following injuries:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">\f                                                      18</span><p id=\"p_25\">\n\n\n   i. There was bruise contusion about 6 x\n           2 cm present in left supra scapular\n           area with blurred margins;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">  ii. There was contusion 2 x 1 cm on     right\n      shoulder with blurred margins. On\n      dissection, extra vestation of blood into\n      true skin and subcutaneous tissues with\n      infiltration     was present;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\"> iii. There was bruise 2 x 2 cm on right\n      elbow with discoloration of skin with\n      blurred margins;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\"> iv. Multiple bruises 5 x 5 cm present on both\n     hands on dorsal aspect.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">             Margin blurred with discoloration of\n        skin present. On dissection, extra\n        vestation of blood into skin and\n        subcutaneous with infilteration.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">  v. There was bruise 2 x 1 cm on left        lower\n     arm with margins blurred;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\"> vi. Another bruise 1 x 1 cm on the left      wrist\n     joint below the above mentioned\n     wound;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_32\">vii. A bruise 5 x 1 cm on the left side on\n     interior abdominal wall with margin\n     blurred and discoloration of skin;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">viii.     Bruise 3 x 2 cm on the left thigh with\n              blurred margins;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\"> ix. An lacerated wound 2 x 1 cm on the left\n     leg with margins blurred and   extra\n     vestation blood into skin discoloration;\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">\f                                               19</span>\n\n\nx. A lacerated would 5 cm below the\n   above mentioned wound;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">xi. Bruise swelling on ankle joint (right) 2\n         x 2 cm with discoloration of skin;\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">\f                                                       20</span><p id=\"p_36\">\n\n\nxii. There was lacerations present around\n           the anal opening at 3rd, 7th and 10th o\n           clock position of size 2 cm, 1 cm, 3\n           cm respectively. Blood was coming\n           out from anus. Anal opening was\n           distorted and dilated. On dissection,\n           blood was present in anal canal and\n           rectum with rupture (through and\n           through) of posterior lateral aspect of\n           rectal wall with perforation of\n     intestinal coils in the right side alongwith\n     through and through           laceration     of\n     right kidney with       lacerations of right\n     lob of liver,     extending through and\n     through of        liver. Large amount of\n     blood was         present      in    peritoneal\n     cavity. On        dissection of skull, large\n     scalpel      haemotoma        present      with\n     multiple laceration        on     brain    with\n     subdural haemotoma. Walls, ribs and\n           cartilages externally healthy. On\n           dissection, blood was present in\n           plural      cavity with haemothorax\n     with laceration of right lung present in\n           lower lobe just above the diapharam\n           right dome of dipharam ruptured in\n           posterior half. Left lung healthy. In\n           heart both chambers were empty.\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">           Abdominal wall as described above.\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">           Peritorium haemoperitome present.</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">           Mouth pharnix and esophagus\n     healthy, stomach and its contents         was\n     healthy. Small intestines and       large\n     intestines and liver already        described.\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">     Spleen was healthy. Bladder was empty.\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">     Organ of generation was healthy.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">\f                                                                    21</span><p id=\"p_42\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">22.     In the opinion of Dr. Paramjit, the cause of death of Dinesh\n\nwas shock and haemorrhage due to multiple injuries to the vital\n\norgans which were ante-mortem in nature and sufficient to\n\ncause death in ordinary course of nature.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_44\">23.          On reappraisal and scrutiny of the evidence discussed\n\n      hereinabove, we find no particular reason as to why the two\n\n      eyewitnesses PW-1 and PW-11 should falsely depose against\n\n      the appellants. It is difficult to believe that the relatives of\n\n      deceased Dinesh would spare his real assailants and falsely\n\n      involve other persons responsible for committing the offence.\n\n      It is well settled that if the witness is related to the deceased,\n\n      his evidence has to be accepted if found to be reliable and\n\n      believable because he would inter alia be interested in\n\n      ensuring that real culprits are punished. The trial court as\n\n      well as the High Court have rightly held that there was a\n\n      motive for the accused to commit murder of Dinesh because\n\n      as per the prosecution evidence,     A-1 was nursing a grudge\n\n      against the deceased because he allegedly sexually assaulted\n\n      his daughter, for which offence Dinesh was acquitted by the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_21\">\f                                                                  22</span>\n\n\n      trial court on 18.03.2002 whereas the prosecutrix was later\n\n      on married to DW-3 on 26.05.2002. Dinesh was murdered on\n\n      the intervening night of 29/30.05.2002 in the house of A-1 in\n\n      village Sundana.   The evidence of PWs 1 and 11 has been\n\n      found to be satisfactory, reliable, consistent and creditable\n\n      by the trial court as well as by the High Court.       Both the\n\n      witnesses have been cross-examined at length by the\n\n      defence, but nothing tangible has been extracted from their\n\n      evidence to create any shadow of doubt that they are not\n\n      truthful witnesses. They have given reliable and consistent\n\n      version of the crime and their evidence inspires confidence.\n\n      On our examination of the judgment given by the trial court\n\n      and confirmed by the High Court, we find that both the\n\n      Courts have properly and rightly appreciated and re-\n\n      appreciated the entire evidence on record and there is no\n\n      infirmity or perversity in the findings recorded by the Courts\n\n      below to interfere with the well-reasoned judgments.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">24.    The ratio of the judgment in <a href=\"/doc/1039791/\" id=\"a_19\">Prem Singh v. State of Punjab</a>\n\n      [AIR 1977 SC 673] relied upon by the learned counsel is of\n\n      no help to the appellants in the facts and circumstances of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_22\">\f                                                             23</span>\n\n\nthe present case. In that case, the evidence of two\n\neyewitnesses who were brother of the deceased with regard\n\nto participation of four other accused was found unreliable\n\nand in the peculiar facts and circumstances of that case, the\n\nconviction of those accused was held illegal by the Supreme\n\nCourt. In the present case, no reliable and clinching evidence\n\nwas found by the trial court and by the High Court against A-\n\n5, A-6 and A-7 who also participated in the commission of\n\nthe offence, therefore, they were rightly acquitted by the\n\nCourts. Therefore, the contention that the appellants shall\n\nbe held entitled to the benefit of doubt in the same manner\n\nas A-5, A-6 and A-7 have been acquitted cannot be accepted.\n\nThe occurrence as spoken by the eyewitnesses is fully\n\nestablished,   therefore,   all   the   appellants    will    be\n\nconstructively liable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 302</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 34</a>\n\nIPC for the commission of the crime, though the fatal injury\n\nwas inflicted by A-1, only as the other appellants participated\n\nin giving beatings to the deceased which caused injuries on\n\nother part of his body.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_23\">\f                                                                         24</span><p id=\"p_46\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_47\">25.No other point has been raised by the appellants. We thus,\n\n   find no merit and substance in any of the submission made\n\n   on behalf of the appellants.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_48\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_49\">26.In the result, for the afore-stated reasons, there is no merit\n\n   in these appeals and these are, accordingly, dismissed.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_50\">                                    ........................................J.\n                                   (Lokeshwar Singh Panta)\n\n\n\n                                    ........................................J.\n                                   (B. Sudershan Reddy)\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 09, 2009.\n</p>\f"}, {"numcites":6,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"kailash chand sharma","formInput":"kailash%20chand%20sharma"},{"value":"kailash chand ","formInput":"kailash%20chand%20"},{"value":"kailash","formInput":"kailash"},{"value":"bonus marks","formInput":"bonus%20marks"},{"value":"merit list","formInput":"merit%20list"},{"value":"obc tambat: supremecourt,bombay","formInput":"obc%20tambat%3A%20supremecourt%2Cbombay"},{"value":"state of rajasthan","formInput":"state%20of%20rajasthan"},{"value":"duli chand","formInput":"duli%20chand"},{"value":"dulichand ","formInput":"dulichand%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":500307,"url":null,"title":"Article 142 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":1254499,"url":null,"title":"Asha Kaul (Mrs) And Anr. vs State Of Jammu And Kashmir And Ors. on 15 April, 1992"},{"tid":94231062,"url":null,"title":"Kailash Chand Sharma Etc. Etc. vs State Of Rajasthan And Ors. on 30 July, 2002"},{"tid":406742,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=28081","title":"State Of Bihar & Ors vs Amrendra Kumar Mishra on 26 September, 2006"},{"tid":1755546,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=29485","title":"State Of Rajasthan & Ors vs Jagdish Chopra on 30 August, 2007"}],"covers":[],"title":"Girdhar Kumar Dadhich & Anr vs State Of Rajasthan & Ors on 23 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-23","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":62107360,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chattisgarh/qrydisp.aspx?filename=1519","title":"Dushyant Singh Sonwani & Others vs State Of Chhattisgarh & Others on 6 May, 2010"},{"tid":1823348,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=34256","title":"B.S.N.L. & Ors vs Abhishek Shukla & Anr on 8 April, 2009"},{"tid":74023298,"url":null,"title":"Yogesh Mahajan vs Director on 24 February, 2010"},{"tid":198228256,"url":null,"title":"Mr. Prabhat Kumar vs New Delhi Municipal Committee on 9 March, 2010"},{"tid":85289048,"url":null,"title":"Kaptan vs Union Of India on 6 September, 2010"}],"tid":993174,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"s","lastname":"sinha","numcitedby":45,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33582","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Girdhar Kumar Dadhich &amp; Anr vs State Of Rajasthan &amp; Ors on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: S Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CIVIL APPEAL NO. 388              OF 2009\n              [Arising out of SLP (Civil) No. 10570 of 2006]\n\n\n\nGirdhar Kumar Dadhich and another                        .... Appellants\n\n\n            Versus\n\n\nState of Rajasthan and others                            .... Respondents\n\n\n\n                                JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. SINHA, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Interpretation of a decision of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/94231062/\" id=\"a_1\">Kailash Chand Sharma v.\n\nState of Rajasthan and others</a>, [ (2002) 6 SCC 562 ] is in question in this\n\nappeal which arises out of a judgment and order dated 14th February, 2006\n\npassed by the High Court of Judicature of Rajasthan. Jaipur Bench, Jaipur in\n\nD.B. Civil Special Appeal (W) No. 147 of 2006.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">\f3.    Indisputably an advertisement was issued on 9th August, 1998 for\n\nfilling up 10 posts of Physical Education Teacher Grade-III. 10 Bonus\n\nmarks were to be granted for candidates who were resident of a particular\n\ndistrict, while 5 bonus marks to the candidates belonging to rural areas.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    Validity and/or legality of the said provision for grant of bonus marks\n\nwas questioned before the said High Court by filing writ petition in the year\n\n1999. The question was referred to a Full Bench. A Full Bench of the said\n\nCourt by a judgment and order dated 18th November, 1999 held the said\n\nprovision to be unconstitutional.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">5.    Upon declaration of the said law by the Full Bench of the High Court,\n\nappellants herein filed two writ petitions being No. 1818/2001 and\n\n1802/2001 before the said High Court inter alia contending that in view of\n\nthe said Full Bench decision, their position would be at serial Nos. 6 and 9\n\nin the merit list. The said writ petitions remained pending.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">6.    This Court in Kailash Chand Sharma (supra) while upholding the\n\ndecision of the Full Bench to the effect that grant of such bonus marks was\n\nunconstitutional, in exercise of its jurisdiction under <a href=\"/doc/500307/\" id=\"a_2\">Article 142</a> of the\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                            2</span>\n\fConstitution of India, thought it fit and proper to invoke the doctrine of\n\nprospective over-ruling, stating :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">             \"      The appointments made up to 17.11.1999\n             need not be reopened and reconsidered in the light\n             of the law laid down in this judgment\".\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">7.    Allegedly the State of Rajasthan appointed Bhanwar Lal Gosar\n\n(Mothsar) by an order dated 12th June, 2003. Two writ petitions were filed\n\nby the appellants. However, in the meanwhile one Duli Chand had filed a\n\nwrit application being S.B. Civil Writ Petition No.1401 of 2003 before the\n\nHigh Court. A learned Single Judge of the High Court dismissed the said\n\nwrit petition on 17th February, 2003 opining that the same was barred by\n\ndelay and latches.      Following Duli Chand (supra) the appellants' writ\n\napplications (Civil Writ Petition Nos. 5510/2003; 1818/2001 and\n\n1802/2002) were also dismissed by the same learned Judge by an order\n\ndated 5th December, 2003.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">8.    Aggrieved by and dissatisfied therewith, the appellants filed an intra-\n\ncourt appeal being D.B. Special Appeal (W) No. 103 of 2004 which was\n\ndisposed of by a Division Bench of the High Court giving liberty to the\n\nappellants to make a representation to the concerned authority within ten\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                         3</span>\n\fdays with a direction to the authority to dispose of the same within three\n\nmonths thereafter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">9.    Appellants submitted their representations on 10th July, 2005 which\n\nwere rejected by the respondents by an order dated 30th September, 2005.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">10.   Appellants challenged the said order before the High Court by filing\n\nyet another writ application being S.B. Civil Writ Petition No.9253 of 2005,\n\nwhich was dismissed by a learned Single Judge of the said Court following\n\nthe order passed in Duli Chand (supra).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">11.   Appellants preferred an intra court appeal thereagainst. A Division\n\nBench of the High Court, however, by reason of the impugned judgment\n\nand order refused to interfere in the matter on the premise that the issue\n\nstands squarely covered by the decision of this Court in Kailash Chand\n\nSharma (supra).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">12.   Mr. M.R. Calla, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nappellants, would submit :-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                        4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">\f      (i)      The Division Bench of the High Court misread and misinterpreted\n\n               the decision of this Court in Kailash Chand Sharma (supra) in so\n\n               far as it failed to take into consideration that the same covered the\n\n               cases of only those employees who were appointed on or before\n\n               18th November, 1999.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">      (ii)     Bhanwar Lal Mothsar having been appointed only in the year 2003\n\n               against the vacancy which remained to be filled up, Kailash Chand\n\n               Sharma (supra) cannot be said to have any application whatsoever.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">      (iii)    The contention of the respondents that two vacancies filled in the\n\n               year 2003 - one against the OBC quota and another against the\n\n               general quota by the persons who were placed higher in the select\n\n               list than the appellants was valid in law, cannot be accepted as the\n\n               respondents had already appointed four persons against the OBC\n\n               quota in the year 1999 itself.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">      (iv)     As a vacancy still exists, even without disturbing the existing\n\n               appointees, the appellant(s) can be accommodated.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">13.          Mr. Navin Singh, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nrespondents, on the other hand, would contend:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                                5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">\f      (i)       Contention raised by the appellants having not been raised before\n\n                the High Court, the same should not be allowed to be raised for\n\n                the first time before this Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">      (ii)      Appellants having not filed any writ petition in the year 1998-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">                1999 the High Court had rightly dismissed the writ petition as\n\n                being barred by delay and latches.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">      (iii)     Appointments having been made on the vacant posts only in\n\n                relation to the candidates of the reserved category and/or who had\n\n                obtained higher position in the select list, appellants cannot be\n\n                directed to be appointed at this stage.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">14.          Before adverting to the rival contentions raised by the parties we may\n\nnotice that according to the appellants even today their exists two vacancies.\n\nThe purported chart prepared by the appellants and the records placed\n\nbefore us show some discrepancy. At this stage, thus, it is not possible for\n\nus to go into the details thereof particularly when the candidates already\n\nappointed are not parties before us.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">15.          The select list was prepared in the year 1998. In our opinion it would\n\nbe difficult to issue any direction for appointment of the appellants herein at\n\nthis stage.        Select list was prepared keeping in view the rules as they\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                               6</span>\n\fexisted.   The said Rules might have been declared ultra vires but as\n\nindicated hereinbefore this Court in exercise of its jurisdiction under <a href=\"/doc/500307/\" id=\"a_3\">Article\n\n142</a> of the Constitution of India though it fit to give a prospective effect\n\nthereto. It did so inter alia for the purpose of protecting the services of those\n\nteachers who had already been appointed and had been in service for a few\n\nyears. Out of ten posts, eights teachers were appointed on or before 18th\n\nNovember, 1999 which was the cut off date.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_38\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">16.   Indisputably the merit list was modified in terms of the dicta laid\n\ndown by this Court in Kailash Chand Sharma (supra).\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">17.   The question as to whether the fresh appointees who are, having\n\nregard to the said modification, required to be appointed on the premise that\n\nthey are placed higher in the select list than the appellants or not, in our\n\nopinion, cannot be gone into by us for the first time since such a contention\n\nhad never been raised before the High Court. The entire record of the\n\nmatter, furthermore, are not before us.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_41\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">18.   It is stated that two appointments were made in the year 2003 - one\n\nagainst OBC quota and another against General quota. It is not possible for\n\nus to go into the question as to whether the entire quota for appointment in\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                            7</span>\n\fthe category of OBC was filled up in the year 1998-1999 itself and thus\n\nappointment made against the vacant post from the said quota is illegal or\n\nnot. The concerned respondents are not parties before us.        We have not\n\nbeen informed as to whether any other person has been left out from the\n\noriginal merit list\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">19.   Furthermore the select list would ordinarily remain valid for one year.\n\nWe fail to understand on what basis appointments were made in 2003 or\n\nsubsequently. Whether the validity of the said select list was extended or\n\nnot is not known. Extension of select list must be done in accordance with\n\nlaw. Apart from a bald statement made in the list of dates that the validity\n\nof the said select list had been extended, no document in support thereof has\n\nbeen placed before us.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_44\">\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">      <a href=\"/doc/1755546/\" id=\"a_4\">In State of Rajasthan &amp; ors. vs. Jagdish Chopra</a> [(2007) 8 SCC 161],\n\nthis Court held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_46\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"9. Recruitment for teachers in the State of\n             Rajasthan is admittedly governed by the statutory\n             rules. All recruitments, therefore, are required to\n             be made in terms thereof. Although Rule 9(3) of\n             the Rules does not specifically provide for the\n             period for which the merit list shall remain valid\n             but the intent of the legislature is absolutely clear\n             as vacancies have to be determined only once in a\n             year. Vacancies which arose in the subsequent\n             years could be filled up from the select list\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                                         8</span>\n\f             prepared in the previous year and not in other\n             manner. Even otherwise, in absence of any rule,\n             ordinary period of validity of select list should be\n             one year. <a href=\"/doc/406742/\" id=\"a_5\">In State of Bihar v. Amrendra Kumar\n             Mishra</a> (2006) 12 SCC 561, this Court opined:\n             (SCC p.564, para 9)\n                   \"9. In the aforementioned situation, in\n                   our opinion, he did not have any legal\n                   right to be appointed. Life of a panel,\n                   it is well known, remains valid for a\n                   year. Once it lapses, unless an\n                   appropriate order is issued by the\n                   State, no appointment can be made\n                   out of the said panel.\"</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">             It was further held: (SCC p.565, para 13)\n                   \"13.     The     decisions     noticed\n                   hereinbefore are authorities for the\n                   proposition that even the wait list\n                   must be acted upon having regard to\n                   the terms of the advertisement and in\n                   any event cannot remain operative\n                   beyond the prescribed period.\"\n                   xxx           xxx          xxx\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">             11. It is well-settled principle of law that even\n             selected candidates do not have legal right in this\n             behalf. (<a href=\"/doc/982107/\" id=\"a_6\">See Shankarsan Dash v. Union of India</a>\n             (1991) 3 SCC 47, and <a href=\"/doc/1254499/\" id=\"a_7\">Asha Kaul v. State of J&amp;K</a>\n             (1993) 2 SCC 573)\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_47\">20.   For the reasons aforementioned, we do not find any merit in this\n\nappeal, which is dismissed accordingly.         However, in the facts and\n\ncircumstances of the case there shall be no order as to costs.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                                     9</span>\n\f                   ...............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_48\">                   [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n\n                   ................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_49\">                   [J.M. Panchal]\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_50\">January 23, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                        10</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"firstname":null,"title":"Maruti Udyog Ltd vs Asst.Commnr.Central Excise ... on 28 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=34765","lastname":"................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-28","citedbyList":[{"tid":1767111,"url":null,"title":"Ennore Foundries Ltd. vs Commissioner Of Central Excise on 11 December, 2006"},{"tid":8387113,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=209173","title":"M/S. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                                   REPORTABLE\n                       IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NO.4154 OF 2000\n\n\n\nFomento Resorts and Hotels Ltd. and another ...Appellant(s)\n\n\n                                        Versus\n\nMinguel Martins and others                       ...Respondent(s)\n\n                                        WITH\n\n                       Civil Appeal Nos.4155 and 4156 of 2000\n\n\n                                     JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">SINGHVI, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.         The above noted appeals are directed against order dated 25.4.2000 passed\n\nby Goa Bench of the High Court of Bombay in Writ Petition No.330 of 1991 <a href=\"/doc/548160/\" id=\"a_1\">Shri\n\nMinguel Martins vs. M/s Sociedade</a> e Fomento Industries Pvt. Ltd. and others, Writ\n\nPetition No.36 of 1992 <a href=\"/doc/1409295/\" id=\"a_2\">Goa Foundation and another vs. Fomento Hotels and Resorts\n\nLimited and others and Writ Petition No</a>.141 of 1992 Shri Gustavo Renato de <a href=\"/doc/1651526/\" id=\"a_3\">Cruz\n\nPinto vs. State of Goa and others</a> whereby directions have been given for demolition\n\nof construction made in survey No.803 (new No.246/2) within the area of Gram\n\nPanchayat, Taleigao, for resumption of the land acquired on behalf of appellant No.1,\n\nFomento Resorts and Hotels Limited, earlier known as M/s. Gomantak Land\n\nDevelopment Pvt. Ltd. and keeping public access to the Vainguinim beach from point\n\n`A' to point `B' shown in plan Exhibit-A open without any obstruction of any kind.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.         For deciding the questions arising in the appeals, it will be useful to notice\n\nthe relevant facts:\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">\f(i)        Dr. Alvaro Remiojo Binto owned several parcels of land in Village\n\nTaleigao, District Tiswadi, Goa. He sold plots bearing survey Nos.803 and 804 (new\n\nNos.246/2 and 245/2) to Gustavo Renato da Cruz Pinto and plots bearing survey\n\nNos.787 and 805 (new Nos.246/1 and 245/1) to M/s. Sociedade e Fomento Industries\n\nPvt. Ltd. (appellant No.2 herein).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">(ii)       After purchasing the land, appellant No.2 leased out the same to appellant\n\nNo.1. The latter submitted an application to Gram Panchayat Taleigao (for short `the\n\nGram Panchayat') for grant of permission to construct hotel complex near\n\nVainguinim beach.     On a reference made by the Gram Panchayat, Chief Town\n\nPlanner, Government of Goa, Daman and Diu vide his letter dated 1.8.1978 informed\n\nthat the plans submitted by appellant No.1 are in conformity with the regulations in\n\nforce in the area but observed that right of the public to access the beach must be\n\nmaintained by providing necessary footpath. Paragraph 2 of that letter reads as\n\nunder:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">           \"The road leading to the hotel complex is at present used by\n           general public to approach the Vainguinim Beach which is\n           popular picnic spot for the people of Panaji, as well as other parts\n           of Goa. It will need to be ensured that the right of access to the\n           beach is maintained by the applicant by providing the necessary\n           footpath to the beach at an appropriate place. The parking\n           facilities provided will also have to take care of the parking of\n           vehicles of such members of the public in an appropriate manner.\n           This will ensure that the beach remains open to public as it is at\n           present and that the public is not deprived of this beautiful and\n           frequently used beach.\"\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                                                             [emphasis added]\n\n\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">(iii)      Thereafter, the Gram Panchayat issued letter dated 22.8.1978, whereby\n\nappellant No.1 was permitted to lay access road linking Dona-Paola-Bambolim Road\n\nto the construction site and construct the hotel subject to the conditions specified in\n\nthe letter including the one relating to public access to the beach. This was reiterated\n\nby the Sarpanch of the Gram Panchayat in his letter dated 1.12.1978.\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_8\">\f(iv)      In furtherance of the permission granted by the Gram Panchayat,\n\nappellant No.1 commenced construction of the hotel, which is now known as Hotel\n\nCidade de Goa on the land forming part of survey No.787 (new No.246/1) and\n\ncompleted the same by May, 1983 in different stages, the details of which are given\n\nbelow:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\"Period              Physical Progress        Expenditure Ex\n\nUpto Dec. Site Development.    Approx. Rs.15 lakhs\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">1978</span>\n\nJan. 79 to Site Development and plinth Approx. Rs.20 lakhs\nDec. 79    level construction works of\n              Central Facility area and first\n        Cluster\n\nJan.80 to Site Development and shell       Approx Rs.40 lakhs\nDec.80      work of Central Facility areas\n            and first cluster of rooms.\n\nJan.81 to Complete structural works       Approx.Rs.160 lakhs\nDec. 81     Complete civil works.\n\n            Complete interiors, complete\n            Air-conditioning, water supply,\n            and sanitation and electrical\n            works of central Facility areas\n            and first cluster of rooms.\n\nJan.82 to Complete air-conditioning,     Approx. Rs.210 lakhs\nDec.82      water supply and sanitation,\n            and electrical works and\n            civil works and interiors of\n            second and third clusters of\n            rooms.\n\nUpto May Complete air-conditioning        Approx. Rs.65 lakhs\"\n1983     water supply and sanitation\n         and electrical works and\n         civil works and interiors\n         of fourth cluster of rooms.\n\n\n\n(v)       During construction of the hotel building, appellant No.1 made an\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_10\">application dated 29.9.1979 to the Sarpanch of the Gram Panchayat, for permission\n\nto change the location of the footpath and parking area by stating that in view of\n\finstallation of 10,000 Kg. gas tank (poisonous gas at high pressure), pressurized\n\nwater tank and high voltage electric transformer near the hotel building, it will not\n\nbe in public interest to locate the footpath and parking area at the sanctioned site.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">(vi)       The Sarpanch of the Gram Panchayat neither forwarded the application\n\nof appellant No.1 to the Town and Planning Department for eliciting its views nor\n\nplaced the same before the Gram Panchayat. Instead he, on his own, wrote letter\n\ndated 29.9.1979 to appellant No.1 giving an impression that the Gram Panchayat\n\ndoes not have any objection to the change of location of the footpath and parking\n\narea. Thereafter, appellant No.1 is said to have shifted access to the beach from the\n\nlocation originally sanctioned.    However, the maps produced before this Court\n\nduring the course of hearing show that the footpath is still near the gas tank.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">(vii)      In the meanwhile, Shri Gustavo Renato da Cruz Pinto, Smt. Surana\n\nPepfira Pinto and Miss Befta Sara Da Costa Pinto filed Special Civil Suit\n\nNo.313/1978/A in the Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division, at Panaji against\n\nappellant No.2, Dr. Alvaro Remiojo Binto and four others for a decree of possession\n\nby pre-emption in respect of the land comprised in survey Nos.787 and 805 and also\n\nto restrain the defendants, their agents, servants, etc. from changing, alienating or\n\nraising any construction on the suit land by alleging that they were owners of\n\nproperty bearing survey Nos.803, 804, 806, 807, 788 and 789 situated at Taleigao and\n\nsince time immemorial they and their predecessors were using footpath passing\n\nthrough survey Nos.787, 805 and 769 for going to Panaji-Dona Paola-Bambolim\n\nroad, which was sought to be obstructed. Defendant No.1 in the suit (appellant No.2\n\nherein) filed written statement to contest the suit. After some time, the parties\n\ncompromised the matter in terms of which the plaintiffs gave up their claim for pre-\n\nemption in respect of plot bearing survey Nos.787 and 805 and defendant No.1\n\nagreed to exchange the plot bearing survey No.790 with plots bearing survey Nos.788\n\nand 789 belonging to the plaintiffs and also that it will have no right of access\n\fthrough any of the properties of the plaintiffs. As a sequel to this, the plaintiffs\n\napplied for withdrawal of the suit. By an order dated 20.12.1978, the Civil Judge\n\npermitted them to do so.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">(viii)     Soon after withdrawal of the suit for pre-emption, appellant No.1 made an\napplication dated 15.11.1978 to Shri Shankar Laad, Minister of Revenue,\nGovernment of Goa for acquisition of land comprised in survey Nos.788, 789, 803,\n804, 806 and 807 (new Nos.246/3, 246/4, 246/2, 245/2, etc.) of Village Taleigao, Dona\nPaula for construction of Beach Resort Hotel Complex by highlighting its benefit to\nthe State. Paragraphs 3 to 6 of the application, which have bearing on the decision of\nthese appeals, read as under:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">           \"3.        It is proposed to put up a hotel complex in the two\n           phases, in the first phase it is proposed that a hotel building is put\n           up in Plot No. 787 in the second phase it is proposed that a Yoga\n           Centre, Health Club and Water Sports facilities for promoting\n           tourism are put in Plot No. 805. Our Hotel Project which is\n           estimated to cost Rs.150 lakhs and will have 100 rooms in its first\n           phase will add to meeting the much needed demand for\n           accommodation by the international tourists.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_15\">4.         In the first phase of the hotel complex it is necessary to develop plot\nNo.787 and to immediately proceed to construct the Hotel Building thereon. The\nland in plot No.787 consists of hilly and rocky area and the land abutting on the\nbeach is also of different levels. In order to put up a hotel building in this plot it\nwould be necessary to undertake cutting of rock which would disturb the topography\nof the area entailing considerable expense. It is, therefore, necessary that the lay-out\nfor the hotel building is finalized in a manner that the rock cutting is minimized and,\nat the same time, the natural surroundings of the rock and foliage is maintained.\nExclusive cutting of rock is also likely to result in land-slides and may pose danger to\nthe foundation of the hotel buildings and its residents. It is, therefore, necessary to\nconstruct the hotel building as near the beach as possible, i.e. on the lowest level of\nthe land abutting the beach.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">5.         There are two small plots bearing No.788 and 789 area abutting the beach.\nThose two small plots fall almost midway along the beach frontage of our said plot\nNo.787 and project into the said plot. Those two small plots are in the lowest level of\nthe land and as such are most suited for including in the lay-out plan of the hotel.\nThese two small plots being closest to the beach it is essential for us to install a first\naid post and a medical aid centre for providing safety measures to the people using\nthe beach facilities. Besides it is a precondition for a beach resort hotel giving\n\fcomforts to provide those facilities both for the residents and for public at large.\nKeeping in view those factors it is necessary that these two small plots of land are\nimmediately acquired and included in the lay-out plan of the hotel. It is also\nnecessary that the acquisition of these two small plots of land is urgently completed\nand possession handed over to enable the lay out plan of the hotel building to be\nreadjusted at this initial stage itself, on the ground prepared by proper leveling and\nterracing before the actual construction work could begin. It is, therefore, necessary\nthat the two plots of land be urgently acquired in the first instance so that there is no\ndelay whatsoever in implementing the first phase of the hotel project.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">6.           In order to take in hand the second phase of the hotel complex it would be\ndesirable to acquire plot Nos. 803 and 804 which intervene between our second Plot\nNo. 805 and our first plot No. 787 and plot Nos. 806 and 807 which adjoin our second\nplot No. 805. This would enable us to undertake the second phase of the project as\ndescribed above. The entire complex will then become one composite unit and these\nfacilities could then be easily availed of by the hotel residents and the resident of this\nterritory. The facilities provided by the hotel will be open for use on membership to\nnon-residents also. Such facilities are not readily and easily available to the people of\nthis.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">(ix)       Acting on the application made by the developer, the Government of Goa\n\nissued notification No.HD/LQN/315/78 dated 29.10.1980 under <a href=\"/doc/169774/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 4(1)</a> of Land\n\nAcquisition Act, 1894 (for short `the 1894 Act') for acquisition of the plots comprised\n\nin survey No.803 (new No.246/2) and survey No.804 (new No.245/2).\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">(x)        After holding enquiry under <a href=\"/doc/85678/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 5A</a> of the 1894 Act, the State\n\nGovernment issued declaration under <a href=\"/doc/1792838/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 6</a>, which was published in Gazette\n\ndated 27.10.1983.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">(xi)       Gustavo Renato da Cruz Pinto and some others filed Writ Petition\n\nNo.8/1984 for quashing the aforementioned notifications on various grounds\n\nincluding the one that before acquiring the land, government did not make enquiry\n\nas per the requirement of Rule 4 of the Land Acquisition (Companies) Rules, 1963\n\n(for short `the Rules').     The writ petitioners also highlighted discrepancies in\n\ndifferent notifications issued by the State Government. Respondent No.2 in the writ\n\npetition (appellant No.1 herein) filed reply affidavit stating therein that Rule 4 of the\n\nRules is not mandatory and non compliance thereof did not affect legality of the\n\facquisition. In paragraphs 67 and 76 of the reply affidavit, it was averred that part\n\nof the project i.e. hotel is complete and has started functioning. In paragraph 79, it\n\nwas averred that besides the hotel project, cottages were proposed to be constructed\n\non plot bearing survey No.805 and the acquired land in survey Nos.803 and 804 will\n\nbe used for putting up health club, yoga centre, water sports and other recreational\n\nfacilities, which are integral part of the project.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">(xii)      By an order dated 26.6.1984, Goa Bench of the High Court of Bombay\n\nallowed the writ petition and quashed the impugned notifications only on the ground\n\nof non compliance of Rule 4 of the Rules. That order was reversed by this Court in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/303393/\" id=\"a_7\">M/s. Fomento Resorts and Hotels Ltd. vs. Gustavo Renato Da Cruz Pino and Others</a>\n\n[(1985) 2 SCC 152] and the case was remitted to the High Court for deciding other\n\ngrounds of challenge. It, however, appears that after the judgment of this Court, the\n\nparties compromised the matter and the writ petition was withdrawn on 26.3.1985.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">(xiii)     In the meanwhile, appellant No.1 entered into an agreement with the\n\ngovernment as per the requirement of <a href=\"/doc/1759624/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 41</a> of the 1894 Act. The agreement was\n\nsigned on 26.10.1983. The opening three paragraphs and Clauses 3, 4 and 6 of the\n\nagreement read as under:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\"WHEREAS the principal objects for which the Company is established are, inter\nalia, construction of a tourism development project, etc. etc.\n\nAND WHEREAS for the purpose of the construction of this tourism development\nproject comprising of a hotel at Curla, Vainguinim, Dona Paula, Goa, the Company\nhas applied to the Government of Goa. Daman and Diu (hereinafter referred to as\n\"The Government\") for acquisition under the provisions of the <a href=\"/doc/7832/\" id=\"a_9\">Land Acquisition Act</a>,\n1894 (hereinafter referred to as \"the said Act\") of the pieces of land containing 19,114\nsquare metres, situated in the District of Tiswadi and more particularly described in\nthe Schedule appended hereto and delineated in the Plan hereunder annexed\n(hereinafter called \"the said land\") for the following purpose, namely -Tourism\nDevelopment Project - construction of hotel at Curla, Vainguinim, Taleigao.\n\nAND WHEREAS the Government being satisfied by an enquiry held under <a href=\"/doc/1694707/\" id=\"a_10\">Section\n40</a> of the said Act that the proposed acquisition is needed for the aforesaid purpose\nand the said work is likely to prove useful to the public, has consented to acquire on\n\fbehalf of the company the said land, hereinbefore described.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">3.         The said land, when so transferred to and vested in the Company shall be\nheld by the Company as its property to be used only in furtherance of and for the\npurpose for which it is required subject nevertheless to the payment of the\nagricultural, non-agricultural or other assessments and cesses, if any, and so far as\nthe said land is or may from time to time be liable to such assessments and cesses\nunder the provisions of the law for the time being in force.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">4.(i)      The Company shall not use the said land for any        purpose other than\nthat for which it is acquired.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">             (ii)    The Company shall undertake the work of creation of sports\n                     and other recreational facilities/amenities within one year from\n                     the date on which the possession of the said land is handed to\n                     the Company and complete the same within three years from\n                     the aforesaid date.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">             (iii)   Where the Government is satisfied after such enquiry as it may\n                     deem necessary that the Company was prevented by reasons\n                     beyond its control from creating the sports and other\n                     recreational amenities within the time specified in the\n                     Agreement, the Government may extend the time for that\n                     purpose by a period not exceeding one year at a time so however\n                     that the total period shall not exceed six years.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">(iv)      The Company shall keep at all times and maintain the said land and the\namenities created thereon, in good order and condition to the satisfaction of the\nGovernment or any Officer or Officers authorized by the Government.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">(v)        The Company shall maintain all records of the Company properly and\nsupply to the Government punctually any information as may from time to time be\nrequired by the Government.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">      (vi)   The company shall not use the said land or any amenities created\n             thereon for any purpose which in the opinion of the Government is\n             objectionable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">(vii)    The Company shall conform to all the laws and the rules and guidelines\nmade by the Government from time to time regarding preservation of ecology and\nenvironment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">(viii)    The Company shall never construct any building or structures in the\nacquired land. Prior approval of Eco-Development Council of the Government of\nGoa, Daman and Diu will be obtained before undertaking activities for its\ndevelopment, besides other statutory requirements under the existing laws.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">      (ix)   The public access/road to the beach shall not be affected or obstructed\n             in any manner.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_37\">6.        In case the said land is not used   for the purposes for which it is acquired\nas hereinafter recited or is used for any     other purpose or in case the Company\ncommits breach of any of the conditions       hereof, the said land together with the\nimprovements, if any, affected thereon,       shall be liable to resumption by the\n\fGovernment subject however, to the condition that the amount spent by the\nCompany for the acquisition of the said land or its value as undeveloped land at the\ntime of resumption, whichever is less, but excluding the cost or value of any\nimprovements made by the Company to the said land or any structure standing on\nthe said land, shall be paid as compensation to the Company.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_38\">           Provided that the said land and the amenities, if any, created thereon shall\nnot be so resumed unless due notice of the breach complained of has been given to the\nCompany and the Company has failed to make good the breach or to comply with\nany directions issued by the Government in this behalf, within the time specified in\nthe said notice for compliance therewith.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">                                                                    [Emphasis added]\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">(xiv)      Although, the agreement was signed on 26.10.1983, possession of the\n\nacquired land was given to appellant No.1 only after withdrawal of Writ Petition\n\nNo.8 of 1984 for which permission was granted on 26.3.1985.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_42\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">(xv)       After delivery of possession of the acquired land, Smt. Anju Timblo,\n\nDirector of appellant No.1, made an application to Panjim Planning and\n\nDevelopment Authority (hereinafter referred to as `the Development Authority')\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/889229/\" id=\"a_11\">Sections 44(1)</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/1980025/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 49(1)</a> of the Goa, Daman &amp; Diu Town and\n\nCountry Planning Act, 1974 (hereinafter described as `Town &amp; Country Planning\n\nAct') for grant of permission for extension of the existing hotel building on survey\n\nNos.246/1, 246/3 and 246/4 (old survey Nos.787, 788 and 789). The applicant did not\n\nseek extension of hotel building to survey No.246/2 apparently because of the express\n\nembargo contained in Clause 4(viii) of the agreement that the company shall never\n\nconstruct any building or structure in the acquired land.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_44\">\n\n(xvi)      The aforementioned application was considered by the EEC in its 23rd\n\nmeeting held on 11.6.1987 and was favourably recommended subject to the condition\n\nthat pedestrian path along the beach may be made available by constructing an\n\naccess from the jetty so that public can reach the beach during the high tide period.\n\fThereafter, the matter was considered in the meeting of the EDC held on 11.9.1987\n\nand it was decided to accept the recommendations of the EEC, subject to the\n\ncondition regarding pedestrian path. The decision of the EDC was communicated to\n\nSmt.
