Universal Petro Chemicals ... on 12 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . M Sharma</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Tarun Chatterjee, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                         IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n               CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n             CIVIL APPEAL NOS. 5430-5431 OF 2002\n\n\nRajasthan State Electricity Board                       ...Appellant\n\n                                       Versus\n\nM/s. Universal Petrol Chemicals Ltd.                 ...Respondent\n\n\n                           JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. Mukundakam Sharma, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1. Being aggrieved by the common judgment and order dated\n\n   17.04.2001 passed by the Division Bench of the High Court of\n\n   Calcutta in Appeal Number 462 and 463 of 1992, allowing the\n\n   appeals filed by the respondent against the judgment of a learned\n\n   Single Judge, these civil appeals have been preferred where\n\n   special leave was granted.       Since both these appeals involve\n\n   similar questions of law and facts and arise out of the same\n\n   impugned order, we propose to dispose of both these appeals by\n\n   this common judgment and order.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">\f2. The appellant Board which is having its base and operation at\n\n  Jaipur placed an order for supply of 50 kiloliter of transformer oil\n\n  with the respondent Company which is having its registered office\n\n  and manufacturing unit at Calcutta vide purchase order No.\n\n  RSEB/SE/Proc.I/TN-1261/U/Petrochemical/937 dated 23.9.1985\n\n  for an amount of Rs. 6,09,144/-. In terms of clause 5 of the said\n\n  purchase order, the respondent was required to deposit security in\n\n  the form of bank guarantee for an amount equivalent to 2 per cent\n\n  of the contract value.     In addition, the respondent was also\n\n  required to furnish a performance guarantee equivalent to 5 per\n\n  cent of the contract value for satisfactory performance and due\n\n  execution of the said contract.      Subsequent to the aforesaid\n\n  purchase order, an agreement was also entered into between the\n\n  parties on 16.10.1985 at Jaipur.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3. Subsequently the appellant Board placed another purchase order\n\n  vide No. RSEB/SE/Proc.I/TN-1312/202 dated 02.12.1987 for\n\n  supply of 150 kiloliter of transformer oil for an amount of Rs.\n\n  19,50,000/-. Similar to the previous purchase order, in the present\n\n  purchase order also the respondent was required to furnish the\n\n  bank guarantee equivalent to 2 per cent of the contract value\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                            Page 2 of 23</span>\n\f     towards security deposit and equivalent to 5 per cent of the\n\n     contract value towards performance guarantee. Accordingly an\n\n     agreement was also entered into between the parties on 16.12.1987\n\n     at Jaipur.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">4. In terms of the abovesaid two purchase orders and agreements\n\n     thereon the respondent was required to furnish bank guarantee to\n\n     the tune of Rs. 1,79,200/-. In compliance to the said condition\n\n     with respect to the bank guarantee the respondent furnished four\n\n     bank guarantees for amounts of Rs. 12200/-, Rs. 30500/-, Rs.\n\n     39000/- and Rs. 97500/-. These guarantees were executed by the\n\n     Allahabad Bank at Jaipur Branch on behalf of their Main Branch\n\n     at Calcutta.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">5.    Before we proceed further it would be appropriate for us to\n\n     extract herein the relevant clauses with respect to adjudication of\n\n     the disputes, if any, which were common in both the agreements.\n\n     Clause 30 of the General Conditions of the Contract inter alia\n\n     stipulates as under:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n        \"30.....The contract shall for all purposes be construed\n        according to the laws of India and subject to jurisdiction\n        of only at Jaipur in Rajasthan Courts only...........\"\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                               Page 3 of 23</span>\n\f      Clause 31 of the General Conditions of the Contract, which is\n\nan arbitration clause, reads as under:-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">      \"31.   ARBITRATION\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      (a)        If at any time any question, dispute to\n             difference whatsoever which may arise between\n             the Purchaser and the Supplier upon or in relation\n             to Contract, either party may forthwith to the order\n             a notice in writing of the existence of such\n             question(s)/dispute(s) differences and the same\n             shall be referred to the Chairman, RSEB, Jaipur or\n             any person appointed by him for the purpose\n             (herein referred to the `Arbitrator').         Such\n             reference shall be deemed to be a submission to\n             the arbitration within the meaning of the <a href=\"/doc/1052228/\" id=\"a_1\">Indian\n             Arbitration Act</a>, 1940 and the statutory\n             modifications made thereof.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">      (b)       The award of the Arbitrator shall be final and\n             binding on both the parties.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">      (c)       Upon every or any such reference, the cost\n             incidental to such reference and an award shall be\n             in the discretion of the Arbitrator who may\n             determine the amount thereof and direct the same\n             to be borne and paid.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">      (d)        Work under the Contract shall, if reasonably\n             possible, continue during the arbitration\n             proceedings and no payment due or payable by the\n             Purchaser shall be withheld on account of such\n             proceedings.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                              Page 4 of 23</span>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\f      In the second purchase order which is dated 02.12.1987, in\n\naddition to the above mentioned clauses, a clause was also\n\nincorporated which is with respect to the jurisdiction of the Court in\n\ncase of disputes:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">      \"DISPUTES\n\n      All disputes, differences or questions whatever which\n      may arise between the Purchaser and the Supplier upon\n      or in relation with or in connection with the contract\n      shall be deemed to have arisen at Jaipur (Rajasthan) and\n      no Court other than the Court at Jaipur (Rajasthan) shall\n      have jurisdiction to entertain or try the same.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      A clause, namely, Clause 7 was also incorporated in the bank\n\nguarantee which is with respect to the jurisdiction of Courts for\n\nadjudication of disputes arising under the bank guarantee. The said\n\nclause reads as under:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">      \"All disputes arising in the said Bank Guarantee between\n      the Bank and the Board or between the supplier or the\n      Board pertaining to this guarantee shall be subject to the\n      courts only at Jaipur in Rajasthan.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_16\">6. Somehow the disputes arose between the parties. The appellant\n\n   alleged that the respondent has failed to perform his part of the\n\n   contract inasmuch as the respondent has supplied defective\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                             Page 5 of 23</span>\n\f  transformer oil and as such on receipt of such supply, the same\n\n  was rejected by the Board requiring the respondent to replace the\n\n  same. Thereafter the appellant took steps for invocation of the\n\n  bank guarantees in view of the fact that the respondent has failed\n\n  to adhere to the aforesaid requirement and also neglected to\n\n  replace the defective transformer oil.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">7. The respondent being aggrieved by the actions taken by the\n\n  appellant filed a petition under <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 20</a> of The Arbitration Act,\n\n  1940 (for short the \"Act\") in the nature of a suit in the High Court\n\n  at Calcutta being Special Suit No. 70 of 1990. In the said suit, the\n\n  respondent also moved an application under <a href=\"/doc/28932/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 41</a> of the Act\n\n  seeking interim reliefs.     The appellant herein contested the\n\n  aforesaid suit. By an Order dated 06.03.1991, the learned Single\n\n  Judge of the High Court dismissed the petition and also vacated\n\n  the interim order which was passed earlier.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">8. On appeal being filed by the respondent, the said order of\n\n  06.03.1991 passed by the learned Single Judge was set aside and\n\n  the matter was remanded back for fresh consideration.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                             Page 6 of 23</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">\f9. Consequent upon the aforesaid order of remand, the learned Single\n\n   Judge again heard the suit and passed a similar order dismissing\n\n   the petition filed by the appellant under <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 20</a> of the Act.\n\n   Being aggrieved by the said final order passed by the learned\n\n   Single Judge, two appeals were filed before the Division Bench\n\n   which were heard together and the same were allowed by the\n\n   Division Bench under the impugned order dated 17.04.2001.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">10.The said impugned judgment and order is under challenge in both\n\n   the appeals on which we heard the learned counsel appearing for\n\n   the parties who had taken us through the relevant documents. By\n\n   the impugned order, the Division Bench of the Calcutta High\n\n   Court held that the forum selection clause as appearing in the\n\n   agreements between the parties would not operate in view of the\n\n   specific prohibition under <a href=\"/doc/1684349/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 31(4)</a> of the Act. It was also\n\n   held that since the respondent had made an application before the\n\n   Calcutta High Court having competent jurisdiction to try and\n\n   decide the proceedings, the said Calcutta Court would be entitled\n\n   to exercise jurisdiction and that all subsequent applications would\n\n   be made to that Court only as first application was made in that\n\n   Court by the respondent. Consequently, the appeals were allowed\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                             Page 7 of 23</span>\n\f  and the judgment of the learned Single Judge was set aside. The\n\n  matter was directed to be listed before the Single Judge for passing\n\n  consequential orders in terms of the directions issued by the\n\n  Division Bench.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">11.Contentions that were raised on behalf of the appellant in the\n\n  present appeals before us, revolves around the issue of territorial\n\n  jurisdiction of the Calcutta High Court in entertaining the said\n\n  petition under <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 20</a> of the Act.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">12.According to the appellant, the Calcutta High Court would have\n\n  no jurisdiction to entertain and decide the aforesaid petition under\n\n  <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 20</a> of the Act and that it is only the Court at Jaipur which\n\n  would have territorial jurisdiction to entertain and decide any such\n\n  petition filed by any of the party, in view of the specific intention\n\n  of the parties as disclosed from the stipulations in the purchase\n\n  order and agreements entered into between the parties.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">13.The learned counsel for the respondent, on the other hand\n\n  submitted before us that the provision of <a href=\"/doc/1882318/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 31</a> of the Act is\n\n  clear and in terms thereof and in view of the specific prohibition\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                            Page 8 of 23</span>\n\f   therein any proceeding between the parties would have to be\n\n   instituted within the jurisdiction of the Calcutta High Court and\n\n   therefore the impugned judgment and order passed by the High\n\n   Court of Calcutta is legal and valid.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">14.In the light of the aforesaid submissions made by learned counsel\n\n   for both the parties, we proceed to decide the issues as to whether\n\n   or not the Calcutta High Court had territorial jurisdiction to\n\n   entertain the petition filed by the respondent under <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 20</a> of\n\n   the Act as also the application filed under <a href=\"/doc/28932/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 41</a> of the Act\n\n   seeking interim orders and also as to whether it is the Jaipur Court\n\n   only which will have territorial jurisdiction to entertain any such\n\n   request. For proper appreciation of the points at issue, it would be\n\n   appropriate to set out the abovementioned legislative provisions of\n\n   the Act, which are as under:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">      20. Application to file in Court arbitration agreement.\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">      -(1) Where any persons have entered into an arbitration\n      agreement before the institution of any suit with respect\n      to the subject matter of the agreement or any part of it,\n      and where a difference has arisen to which the agreement\n      applies, they or any of them, instead of proceeding under\n      Chapter II, may apply to a Court having jurisdiction in\n      the matter to which the agreement relates, that the\n      agreement be filed in Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                              Page 9 of 23</span>\n\f(2) The application shall be in writing and shall be\nnumbered and registered as a suit between one or more\nof the parties interested or claiming to be interested as\nplaintiff or plaintiffs and the remainder as defendant or\ndefendants, if the application has been presented by all\nthe parties, or, if otherwise, between the applicant as\nplaintiff and the other parties as defendants.\n\n\n(3) On such application being made, the Court shall\ndirect notice thereof to be given to all parties to the\nagreement other than the applicants, requiring them to\nshow cause within the time specified in the notice why\nthe agreement should not be filed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n(4) Where no sufficient cause is shown, the Court shall\norder the agreement to be filed, and shall make an order\nof reference to the arbitrator appointed by the parties,\nwhether in the agreement or otherwise, or, where the\nparties cannot agree upon an arbitrator, to an arbitrator\nappointed by the Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">\n(5) Thereafter the arbitration shall proceed in accordance\nwith, and shall be governed by, the other provisions of\nthis Act so far as they can be made applicable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">41. Procedure and powers of Court. - Subject to the\nprovisions of this Act and of rules made there under-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">(a) the provisions of - the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908,\n(5 of 1908.) shall apply to all proceedings before the\nCourt, and to all appeals, under this Act, and\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">(b) the Court shall have, for the purpose of, and in\nrelation to, arbitration proceedings, the same power of\nmaking orders in respect of any of the matters set out in\nthe Second Schedule as it has for the purpose of, and in\nrelation to, any proceedings before the Court:\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                      Page 10 of 23</span>\n\f      Provided that nothing in clause (b) shall be taken to\n      prejudice any power which may be vested in an arbitrator\n      or umpire for making orders with respect to any of such\n      matters.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">15.There is no dispute with regard to the fact that the parties entered\n\n   into various agreements which are referred to above. The said\n\n   agreements admittedly also contained forum selection clauses\n\n   between the parties whereby and whereunder the parties agreed\n\n   that the said contracts and agreements, in relation to any dispute or\n\n   difference would be subject to the jurisdiction of courts at Jaipur\n\n   in Rajasthan.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_41\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">16. Therefore, the issues which we are required to address here is\n\n   whether the ouster clause in the agreement between the parties will\n\n   also be applicable in ascertaining the competent court for making\n\n   an application for reference under <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_11\">section 20</a> of the Act. As per\n\n   <a href=\"/doc/28932/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 41</a> (1) of the act the provisions of the Code of Civil\n\n   Procedure, 1908, (for short \"the Code\") shall apply to all\n\n   proceedings before the Court, and to all appeals, under the Act.\n\n   Section 20 of the Code, which is with respect to the jurisdiction of\n\n   courts for institution of suit, reads as under:\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                              Page 11 of 23</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">\f      20. Other suits to be instituted where defendants\n      reside or cause of action arises.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_44\">      Subject to the limitations aforesaid, every suit shall be\n      instituted in Court within the local limits of whose\n      jurisdiction-\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">(a) the defendant, or each of the defendants where there are\n    more than one, at the time of the commencement of the\n    suit, actually and voluntarily resides, or carries on\n    business, or personally works for gain; or\n</p><p id=\"p_46\">(b) any of the defendants, where there are more than one, at\n    the time of the commencement of the suit actually and\n    voluntarily resides, or carries on business, or personally\n    works for gain, provided that in such case either the leave\n    of the Court is given, or the defendants who do not reside,\n    or carry on business, or personally work for gain, as\n    aforesaid, acquiesce in such institution; or\n</p><p id=\"p_47\">        (c) the cause of action, wholly or in part, arises.\n\n\n      Explanation.-A corporation shall be deemed to carry on\n      business at its sole or principal office in India or, in\n      respect of any cause of action arising at any place where\n      it has also a subordinate office, at such place.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_48\">17. There are number of decisions of this Court wherein it was held\n\n   that where there may be two or more competent courts which can\n\n   entertain a suit consequent upon a part of the cause of action\n\n   having arisen therein, if the parties to the contract agree to vest\n\n   jurisdiction in one such court to try the dispute which might arise\n\n   as between themselves, such agreement would be valid and\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                              Page 12 of 23</span>\n\f  binding. <a href=\"/doc/997135/\" id=\"a_13\">In A.B.C. Laminart (P) Ltd. v. A.P. Agencies</a> [(1989) 2\n\n  SCC 163], this Court stated thus;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_49\">\n     \"21. From the foregoing decisions it can be reasonably\n     deduced that where such an ouster clause occurs, it is\n     pertinent to see whether there is ouster of jurisdiction of\n     other courts. When the clause is clear, unambiguous and\n     specific accepted notions of contract would bind the\n     parties and unless the absence of ad idem can be shown,\n     the other courts should avoid exercising jurisdiction. As\n     regards construction of the ouster clause when words like\n     \"alone\", \"only\", \"exclusive\" and the like have been used\n     there may be no difficulty. Even without such words in\n     appropriate cases the maxim \"expressio unius est\n     exclusio alterius\" -- expression of one is the exclusion\n     of another -- may be applied. What is an appropriate\n     case shall depend on the facts of the case. In such a case\n     mention of one thing may imply exclusion of another.\n     When certain jurisdiction is specified in a contract an\n     intention to exclude all others from its operation may in\n     such cases be inferred. It has therefore to be properly\n     construed.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_50\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_51\">18. The said decision also referred to and relied upon an earlier\n\n  decision of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/1548537/\" id=\"a_14\">Hakam Singh v. M/s. Gammon (India)\n\n  Ltd</a>. [1971 (1) SCC 286]. The said decision was rendered in the\n\n  light of facts of a similar contract where clause 12 of the tender\n\n  provided for arbitration whereas clause 13 provided;\n\n     \"Notwithstanding the place where the work under this\n     contract is to be executed, it is mutually understood and\n     agreed by and between the parties hereto that this\n     Contract shall be deemed to have been entered into by\n     the parties concerned in the city of Bombay and the court\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                            Page 13 of 23</span>\n\f      of law in the city of Bombay alone shall have jurisdiction\n      to adjudicate thereon.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_52\">\n\n      The question which fell for consideration of this Court in the\n\nsaid case was whether the Court at Bombay alone had jurisdiction\n\nover the dispute. In that context, it was held that the Code in its\n\nentirety applied to proceedings under the <a href=\"/doc/1052228/\" id=\"a_15\">Arbitration Act</a> by virtue of\n\n<a href=\"/doc/28932/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 41</a> of that Act and that the jurisdiction of the Court under the\n\nAct to entertain a proceeding for filing an Award was accordingly\n\ngoverned by the provisions of the Code. Reference was made to the\n\nprovisions of Section 20 of the Code, with all the terms of <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 20</a>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_53\">(a) of the Code read with explanation thereto, the respondent\n\nCompany which had its principal place of business at Bombay was\n\nliable to be sued at Bombay.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_54\">      It was further held that where two or more courts have\n\njurisdiction to try a suit or proceeding, an agreement between the\n\nparties that the dispute between them shall be tried in one of such\n\ncourts was not contrary to public policy and that such an agreement\n\ndid not contravene the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/1224074/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 28</a> of the Contract Act.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">                               Page 14 of 23</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_55\">\f19. Similar view was also reiterated in <a href=\"/doc/518433/\" id=\"a_19\">Angile Insulations v. Davy\n\n   Ashmore India Ltd. and Another</a> [(1995) 4 SCC 153].\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_56\">20. <a href=\"/doc/1923755/\" id=\"a_20\">In Hanil Era Textiles Ltd. v. Puromatic Filters (P) Ltd</a>. [(2004)\n\n   4 SCC 671], it was held by this Court that where two or more\n\n   courts have jurisdiction under the Code, it is permissible to have\n\n   an agreement between the parties restricting the place of suing to\n\n   any one of them and if such restriction is placed in the agreement,\n\n   the same cannot be said to be contrary to public policy and does\n\n   not contravene <a href=\"/doc/1224074/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 28</a> of the Contract Act. It was however,\n\n   made clear that such restriction cannot be made and the parties\n\n   cannot by agreement confer jurisdiction on a court which\n\n   otherwise it does not possess under the Code.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_57\">      This Court also considered the scope of Section 20 of the Code\n\nin the said case and by referring to the said provision it was held that\n\nwhen ouster clause is clear, unambiguous and specific, accepted\n\nnotions of contract would bind parties and unless absence of ad idem\n\ncan be shown courts should avoid exercising jurisdiction.        While\n\narriving at the said finding this Court followed the ratio laid down in\n\nA.B.C. Laminart (P) Ltd. (supra).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_58\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                             Page 15 of 23</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_59\">\f21.The aforesaid legal proposition settled by this Court in respect of\n\n   territorial jurisdiction and applicability of Section 20 of the Code\n\n   to <a href=\"/doc/1052228/\" id=\"a_22\">Arbitration Act</a> is clear, unambiguous and explicit. The said\n\n   position is binding on both the parties who were contesting the\n\n   present proceeding. Both the parties with their open eyes entered\n\n   into the aforesaid purchase order and agreements thereon which\n\n   categorically provide that all disputes arising between the parties\n\n   out of the agreements would be adjudicated upon and decided\n\n   through the process of arbitration and that no court other than the\n\n   court at Jaipur shall have jurisdiction to entertain or try the same.\n\n   In both the agreements in clause 30 of General Conditions of the\n\n   Contract it was specifically mentioned that the contract shall for\n\n   all purposes be construed according to the laws of India and\n\n   subject to jurisdiction of only at Jaipur in Rajasthan Courts only\n\n   and in addition in one of the purchase order the expression used\n\n   was that the Court at Jaipur only would have jurisdiction to\n\n   entertain or try the same.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_60\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_61\">22.In the light of the aforesaid facts of the present case, the ratio of all\n\n   the aforesaid decisions which are referred to hereinbefore would\n\n   squarely govern and apply to the present case also.            There is\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">                                Page 16 of 23</span>\n\f  indeed an ouster clause used in the aforesaid stipulations stating\n\n  that the courts at Jaipur alone would have jurisdiction to try and\n\n  decide the said proceedings which could be initiated for\n\n  adjudication and deciding the disputes arising between the parties\n\n  with or in relation to the aforesaid agreements through the process\n\n  of arbitration. In other words, even though otherwise the Courts at\n\n  Calcutta would have territorial jurisdiction to try and decide such\n\n  disputes, but in view of the ouster clause it is only the courts at\n\n  Jaipur which would have jurisdiction to entertain such proceeding.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_62\">23.The Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court was aware of the\n\n  clauses and stipulations in the agreements and was also aware of\n\n  the abovementioned decisions of this Court, but the Division\n\n  Bench held that the said forum selection clause agreed to and\n\n  entered into between the parties would not apply in view of the\n\n  specific provision of <a href=\"/doc/1684349/\" id=\"a_23\">Section 31(4)</a> of the Act. The said provision\n\n  as well as sub-Section (3) are extracted below:-\n\n\n     \"31. Jurisdiction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_63\">\n     (1).....................\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_64\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">                                Page 17 of 23</span>\n\f     (2).....................\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_65\">     (3) All applications regarding the conduct of arbitration\n     proceedings or otherwise arising out of such proceedings\n     shall be made to the Court where the award has been, or\n     may be, filed, and to no other Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_66\">     (4) Notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in\n     this Act or in any other law for the time being in force,\n     where in any reference any application under this Act has\n     been made in a Court competent to entertain it, that\n     Court alone shall have jurisdiction over the arbitration\n     proceedings and all subsequent applications arising out\n     of that reference, and the arbitration proceedings shall be\n     made in that Court and in no other Court.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_67\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_68\">24.Having noticed the aforesaid provision of <a href=\"/doc/1684349/\" id=\"a_24\">Section 31(4)</a>, the\n\n  Division Bench held that since the aforesaid provision starts with a\n\n  non-obstantive clause, the said provisions would only apply and\n\n  would come into operation. The Division Bench finally held thus:\n\n\n     \"The said argument cannot be sustained after a plain\n     reading of <a href=\"/doc/1684349/\" id=\"a_25\">Section 31(4)</a> of the Act. It is clear from the\n     language used therein that where in any application has\n     been made in a court, competent to entertain, in that case\n     that court alone shall have jurisdiction. The requirement\n     is not that the application should be allowed. Since in\n     the instant case admittedly an application under <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_26\">Section\n     20</a> has been made, which is an application in a reference,\n     Calcutta High Court will have jurisdiction.\"\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">                                Page 18 of 23</span>\n\f      The said findings were rendered by the Division Bench\n\nupsetting the findings of the learned Single Judge who had held that\n\nthe non-obstantive clause appearing in sub-Section (4) of <a href=\"/doc/1882318/\" id=\"a_27\">Section 31</a>\n\nwould not be attracted in the present case where the parties by an\n\nagreement had agreed to a particular forum having jurisdiction over\n\nthe dispute between the parties for adjudication.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_69\">25. Section 20 of the Code will apply in respect of deciding the issue\n\n   with regard to territorial jurisdiction of a court in respect of a\n\n   matter relating to arbitration also, for in Hakam Singh (supra), it\n\n   was held that the jurisdiction of the court under the Act to\n\n   entertain the proceeding for filing an Award was governed by the\n\n   provisions of the Code. We also at this stage may appropriately\n\n   refer to the definition of the word \"Court\" as appearing in <a href=\"/doc/105873/\" id=\"a_28\">Section\n\n   2(c)</a> of the Act wherein the expression \"Court\" is defined to mean\n\n   \"a Civil Court having jurisdiction to decide the questions forming\n\n   the subject matter of the reference if the same had been the subject\n\n   matter of a suit, but does not except for the purpose of arbitration\n\n   proceedings under <a href=\"/doc/157537/\" id=\"a_29\">Section 21</a>, include a Small Cause Court.\"\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">                             Page 19 of 23</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_70\">\f26.Sub-section (3) precedes sub-Section (4) of <a href=\"/doc/1882318/\" id=\"a_30\">Section 31</a> of the Act.\n\n   The said sub-Section provides that all applications regarding the\n\n   conduct of arbitration proceedings or otherwise arising out of such\n\n   proceedings shall be made to the Court where the Award has been\n\n   or may be filed and to no other court. Sub-Section (4) on the other\n\n   hand states that where in any reference any application under the\n\n   <a href=\"/doc/1052228/\" id=\"a_31\">Arbitration Act</a> has been made in a Court competent to entertain,\n\n   then that Court alone would have jurisdiction over the arbitration\n\n   proceedings and all subsequent applications arising from that\n\n   matter and arbitration proceedings shall be made in that court and\n\n   in no other court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_71\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_72\">27.An analytical look at the provisions of sub-Sections (3) and (4)\n\n   will make it explicitly clear that any application in any reference,\n\n   meaning thereby even an application under <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_32\">Section 20</a> of the Act\n\n   could or should be filed in a court competent to entertain such\n\n   proceeding and having jurisdiction to decide the subject of the\n\n   reference. Such jurisdiction would or could be restricted by the\n\n   agreements entered into by and between the parties. The parties\n\n   have clearly stipulated and agreed that no other court, but only the\n\n   court at Jaipur will have jurisdiction to try and decide the\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">                            Page 20 of 23</span>\n\f   proceedings arising out of the said agreements, and therefore, it is\n\n   the Civil Court at Jaipur which would alone have jurisdiction to\n\n   try and decide such issue and that is the court which is competent\n\n   to entertain such proceedings. The said court being competent to\n\n   entertain such proceedings, the said Court at Jaipur alone would\n\n   have jurisdiction over the arbitration proceedings and all\n\n   subsequent applications arising out of the reference. The\n\n   arbitration proceedings have to be made at Jaipur Court and in no\n\n   other court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_73\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_74\">28.In our considered opinion, the learned Division Bench of the\n\n   Calcutta High Court misread and misinterpreted the provisions of\n\n   sub-Sections (3) and (4) of <a href=\"/doc/1882318/\" id=\"a_33\">Section 31</a> of the Act and thereby\n\n   arrived at a wrong finding to the effect that by virtue of the\n\n   aforesaid provision of <a href=\"/doc/1611649/\" id=\"a_34\">Section 31(4)</a> the Calcutta High Court\n\n   would have jurisdiction in the matter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_75\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_76\">29.In view of the aforesaid findings and conclusions arrived at by us\n\n   holding that it is only the Court at Jaipur which will have\n\n   jurisdiction to try and decide the arbitration proceedings between\n\n   the parties and also entertain a petition of the aforesaid nature i.e.\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">                             Page 21 of 23</span>\n\f   <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_35\">Section 20</a> of the Act, we set aside and quash the judgment and\n\n   order of the Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court. Both the\n\n   appeals are allowed to the aforesaid extent. The Registry of the\n\n   Calcutta High Court is directed to transfer the petition filed by the\n\n   respondent under <a href=\"/doc/811701/\" id=\"a_36\">Section 20</a> of the Act alongwith all the records\n\n   to the District Judge, Jaipur, as expeditiously as possible but not\n\n   latter than four weeks from the date of receipt of this order. The\n\n   District Judge, Jaipur on receipt of the said petition alongwith the\n\n   transmitted records shall allocate it to the competent and\n\n   appropriate Court, which would thereafter issue Notice to both the\n\n   parties. The concerned Court shall thereafter deal with the matter\n\n   in accordance with law.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_77\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_78\">30.The registry of this Court is directed to send a copy of this order to\n\n   the Registrar, Calcutta High Court and also to District Judge,\n\n   Jaipur for necessary action.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_79\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_80\">                                                .............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_81\">                                                         (Tarun Chatterjee)\n\n                                                .............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_82\">                                             (Dr. Mukundakam Sharma)\n\nNew Delhi,\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_21\">                             Page 22 of 23</span>\n\fJanuary 12,2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_22\">                  Page 23 of 23</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":4,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"contempt petition","formInput":"contempt%20petition"},{"value":"article 32","formInput":"article%2032"},{"value":"recall petition","formInput":"recall%20petition"}],"citeList":[{"tid":981147,"url":null,"title":"Article 32 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":182170,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=28711","title":"All Bengal Excise Licensees ... vs Raghabendra Singh & Ors on 9 March, 2007"},{"tid":1353689,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=8342","title":"A.R. Antulay vs R.S. Lodha</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                          ORIGINAL JURISDICTION\n\n        WRIT PETITION (CIVIL) NO(s). 110 OF 2008\n\nASIT KUMAR KAR                            Petitioner(s)\n\n            VERSUS\n\nSTATE OF WEST BENGAL &amp; ORS.                        Respondent(s)\n\nWITH W.P(C) NO. 118 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 119 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 144 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 146 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 147 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 148 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 149 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 150 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 151 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 152 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 153 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 154 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 155 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 156 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 157 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 158 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 159 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 160 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 161 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 162 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 163 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 164 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 272 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 273 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 274 of 2008\nW.P(C) NO. 275 of 2008\n                                   ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">                These writ petitions have been filed under <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 32</a> of the Constitution\n    of India.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">                It appears that the All Bengal Excise Licensees Association had filed a\n    writ petition in the High Court of Calcutta challenging the policy of the State of\n    West Bengal\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                      -2-</span>\nof granting additional licences for foreign liquor and country made spirit. That\npetition was filed through the General Secretary of the Association. Subsequently,\nthe writ petition was withdrawn.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">             During the pendency of the writ petition, and before it was withdrawn,\nan interim order had been passed by the High Court staying the grant of licences. A\ncontempt petition was filed before the High Court alleging that licences were granted\nin violation of the stay order of the High Court, but that contempt petition was\ndismissed.   Against that order dismissing the contempt petition, a special leave\npetition was filed in this Court which was decided by this Court in the judgment\nreported as <a href=\"/doc/182170/\" id=\"a_2\">All Bengal Licensees Association v. Raghabendra Singh &amp; Ors</a>. [2007 (11)\nSCC 374.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">             In that contempt petition, the Court accepted the apology of the alleged\ncontemnors, but having done so, in paragraph 40 of the judgment it directed\ncancellation of the licences for the auctions held on 20.03.2005, 21.03.2005 and\n22.03.2005 and directed that their businesses shall be stopped forthwith.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">             The aforesaid direction in paragraph 40 of the judgment was passed\nwithout hearing the persons whose licences were ordered to be cancelled. In fact even\nthe impleadment applications of such persons were rejected.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">             It is a basic principle of justice that no adverse orders should be passed\nagainst a party without hearing him. This is the fundamental principle of natural\njustice and it is a basic canon of jurisprudence.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                     -3-</span>\n<p id=\"p_7\">            In the Seven Judge Constitution Bench of this Court, <a href=\"/doc/1353689/\" id=\"a_3\">A.R. Antuley v. R.S.\nNayak &amp; Anr</a>. 1988 (2) SCC 602] it has been observed in paragraph 55 thereof:\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">            \"so also the violation of the principles of natural justice renders the act a\nnullity\".\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">            One of the counsel relied upon another Five Judge Constitution Bench\ndecision in <a href=\"/doc/123456797/\" id=\"a_4\">Rupa Ashok Hurra v. Ashok Hurra</a> [2002 (4) SCC 388]. It is true that in\nparagraph 9 of the said judgment it has been observed that this Court under <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_5\">Article\n32</a> of the Constitution cannot hold as invalid a judgment of this Court by treating it as\na nullity. However, the aforesaid judgment does not say that we cannot pass a recall\norder when that order has been passed without hearing a party.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">            There is a distinction between a petition under <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_6\">Article 32</a>, a review\npetition and a recall petition. While in a review petition the Court considers on merits\nwhere there is an error apparent on the face of the record, in a recall petition the\nCourt does not go into the merits but simply recalls an order which was passed\nwithout giving an opportunity of hearing to an affected party. We are treating this\npetition under <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_7\">Article 32</a> as a recall petition because the order passed in the decision\nin <a href=\"/doc/182170/\" id=\"a_8\">All Bengal Licensees Association v. Raghabendra Singh &amp; Ors</a>. [2007 (11) SCC 374]\ncancelling certain licences was passed without giving opportunity of hearing to the\npersons who had been granted licences.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                          -4-</span>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_11\">                In these circumstances, we recall the directions in paragraph 40 of the\n    aforesaid judgment.     However, if anybody has a grievance against the grant of\n    licences or in the policy of the State Government, he will be at liberty to challenge it in\n    appropriate proceedings before the appropriate Court.\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                The writ petitions are disposed of with these directions.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_13\">                                                              ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                                                [MARKANDEY KATJU]\n\n\n\n                                                    .....................J\n                          [R.M. LODHA]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 21, 2009.\n</p>\f"}, {"numcites":2,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"Legal services","formInput":"Legal%20services"},{"value":"sec 35a","formInput":"sec%2035a"},{"value":"award on costs","formInput":"award%20on%20costs"},{"value":"r. v. raveendran ","formInput":"r.%20v.%20raveendran%20"},{"value":"raveendran ","formInput":"raveendran%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":427855,"url":null,"title":"Article 136 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":26738839,"url":null,"title":"The Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987"}],"covers":[],"title":"Ashok Kumar Mittal vs Ram Kumar Gupta & Anr on 9 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-09","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":185277830,"url":"http://lawcommissionofindia.nic.in/reports/report240.pdf","title":"240Th Report On Costs In Civil Litigation"},{"tid":179509211,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/ddir/dhc/GMI/judgement/26-08-2015/GMI03082015RFAOS1622014.pdf","title":"Harish Relan vs Kaushal Kumari Relan & Ors on 3 August, 2015"},{"tid":160832835,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/ddir/dhc/GMI/judgement/26-08-2015/GMI26082015RFAOS1272014.pdf","title":"M/S Sicpa India Private Limited vs Mr. Kapil Kumar & Ors on 26 August, 2015"},{"tid":159630057,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=203429","title":"N.Hiriyan vs B.Sivakumar on 9 September, 2014"},{"tid":146108805,"url":"http://judgmenthck.kar.nic.in/judgments/bitstream/123456789/874282/1/WP8155-12-24-04-2013.pdf","title":"Vishwanath Swami vs Bar Council Of India on 24 April, 2013"}],"tid":1228923,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"_________________j.","numcitedby":15,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33479","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Ashok Kumar Mittal vs Ram Kumar Gupta &amp; Anr on 9 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: _________________J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: R.V. Raveendran, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                            Reportable\n\n                    IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                     CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n      SPECIAL LEAVE PETITION [CIVIL] NOS.30991-30992/2008\n\n\n\nASHOK KUMAR MITTAL                                           PETITIONER\n\nVS.\n\nRAM KUMAR GUPTA &amp; ANR.                                       RESPONDENTS\n\n\n\n                                 O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">R. V. Raveendran J.,\n\n\n\n       Mrs.   Amita     Gupta,        learned     counsel,     appears       for\n\nrespondents and waives notice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.     The petitioner filed a suit for specific performance\n\nof an alleged agreement of sale dated 15.7.2003. The trial\n\ncourt    dismissed     the    suit     by   judgment     and   decree     dated\n\n19.5.2008. The High Court dismissed the petitioner's appeal\n\non    29.9.2008.    Both     courts    held     that   petitioner     had    not\n\napproached    the     court    with    clean     hands   and   that     he   had\n\nfailed to prove any concluded contract for sale. High Court\n\nfound that the defendants in the suit were also not above\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                         2</span>\n\nboard    in    their   conduct.      It       found   that     both    sides    were\n\nguilty    of     having      lied    on       oath    and      deserved    to    be\n\nprosecuted. On the ground that courts were over-burdened\n\nwith litigation, the High Court decided that instead of\n\ndirecting prosecution, heavy costs should be levied on both\n\npetitioner and respondents \"to be paid to the state which\n\nspends money on providing the judicial infrastructure.\" It\n\nthen proceeded to impose exemplary costs of Rs.1,00,000/-\n\non the petitioner and Rs.1,00,000/- on the respondents, and\n\ndirected that the costs should be deposited with the Delhi\n\nHigh Court Legal Services Committee.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.    Feeling aggrieved by the dismissal of his appeal, the\n\npetitioner is before this Court. On merits, we find that\n\nthe concurrent findings of the trial court and the High\n\nCourt do not warrant interference and therefore this is not\n\na fit case for grant of leave.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that\n\nlevying costs of Rupees one lakh against the petitioner was\n\nnot warranted. He submitted that as the appeal before the\n\nHigh Court arose out of a civil suit, costs were governed\n\nby   section     35    and   35A    of       the   Code   of   Civil    Procedure\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                           3</span>\n\n(`Code' for short) and cannot exceed what is leviable under\n\nthose provisions.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">5.    Under    section         35    of    the       Code,   award     of    costs   is\n\ndiscretionary but subject to the conditions and limitations\n\nas may be prescribed and the provisions of any law for the\n\ntime being in force. Under section 35A, compensatory costs\n\nfor   vexatious          claims     and        defences      may     not    exceed   to\n\nRs.3,000/-.    Further         the    primary         object    of    levying    costs\n\nunder sections 35 and 35A CPC, is to recompense a litigant\n\nfor the expense incurred by him in litigation to vindicate\n\nor defend his right. It is therefore payable by a losing\n\nlitigant to his successful opponent. When an appellant or a\n\nplaintiff     has    already        paid       the    prescribed      court    fee   in\n\nregard to the appeal or suit, to the state at the time of\n\ninstitution,        it    is   debatable          whether      any    costs    can   be\n\nawarded to the state by way of penalty, in a litigation\n\nbetween two private parties. Courts will have to act with\n\ncare while opening new frontiers.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">6.    One view has been that the provisions of sections 35\n\nand 35A CPC do not in any way affect the wide discretion\n\nvested in by High Court in exercise of its inherent power\n\nto award costs in the interests of justice in appropriate\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                      4</span>\n\ncivil cases. The more sound view however is that though\n\naward of costs is within the discretion of the court, it is\n\nsubject    to    such       conditions    and   limitations    as   may    be\n\nprescribed and subject to the provisions of any law for the\n\ntime being in force; and where the issue is governed and\n\nregulated by sections 35 and 35A of the Code, there is no\n\nquestion    of    exercising       inherent     power    contrary   to    the\n\nspecific provisions of the Code. Further, the provisions of\n\nsection 35A seems to suggest that even where a suit or\n\nlitigation is vexatious, the outer limit of exemplary costs\n\nthat can be awarded, in addition to regular costs, shall\n\nnot exceed Rs.3000/-. It is also to be noted that huge\n\ncosts of the order of Rs. Fifty thousand or Rs.One lakh,\n\nare normally awarded only in writ proceedings and public\n\ninterest litigations, and not in civil litigation to which\n\nsections   35    and    35A     are   applicable.   The    principles     and\n\npractices relating to levy of costs in administrative law\n\nmatters    cannot      be    imported     mechanically    in   relation   to\n\ncivil litigation governed by the Code.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">7.   The present system of levying meagre costs in civil\n\nmatters (or no costs in some matters), no doubt, is wholly\n\nunsatisfactory and does not act as a deterrent to vexatious\n\nor luxury litigation borne out of ego or greed, or resorted\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                         5</span>\n\nto   as     a    `buying-time'       tactic.       More       realistic        approach\n\nrelating to costs may be the need of the hour. Whether we\n\nshould      adopt      suitably,     the     western         models       of   awarding\n\nactual and more realistic costs is a matter that requires\n\nto be debated and should engage the urgent attention of the\n\nLaw Commission of India.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">8.     We do not however propose to examine or decide the\n\nabove issues here, except to observe that courts should not\n\nexceed or overlook the limitations placed by the Code with\n\nreference to costs in civil litigation. In so far this case\n\nis concerned, even though the order relating to costs may\n\nnot strictly be correct, we do not propose to interfere\n\nwith      the    same,      in   exercise     of       our    jurisdiction          under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_1\">Article         136</a>,   as    the   order         has    not    resulted        in     any\n\ninjustice. It is stated that the respondents have already\n\ndeposited the costs. The time for deposit of costs by the\n\npetitioner        is   extended     at     his    request      by     a    month    from\n\ntoday.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">9.     We would however like to refer to two aspects of the\n\norder of the High Court relating to costs. The first is,\n\nwhether a court, having reached a conclusion that a party\n\ndeserves to be prosecuted for perjury, should let him off\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                         6</span>\n\nwith what it considers to be a stiff penalty by way of\n\ncosts,    on    the     ground    that       courts       are    overburdened        with\n\nwork.    We     propose    to     leave      open       for     the    present,      this\n\nquestion involving moral and ethical issues.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">10.   The      second    aspect    relates         to     the    recipient      of    the\n\ncosts. In para 38 of the impugned judgment, the High Court\n\nspecifically       stated       that    it     had      decided       to   saddle     the\n\nparties with heavy costs to be paid to the state which\n\nspends money on judicial infrastructure. Having said so, in\n\npara 39, the High Court directed that the costs should be\n\npaid to the Delhi High Court Legal Services Committee. The\n\nHigh Court Legal Services Committee, a statutory authority\n\nunder the <a href=\"/doc/26738839/\" id=\"a_2\">Legal Services Authorities Act</a>, 1987, is not the\n\n`state'        that      spends        money         on       providing       judicial\n\ninfrastructure,         referred       in    the     earlier          para.   Once   the\n\nCourt held that costs had to be paid to the state, it\n\nshould have directed payment of the costs to the state and\n\nnot the High Court Legal Services Committee. No litigant\n\nshould be made to feel that heavy costs are being levied in\n\nsome cases by Judges to create a corpus or expense fund for\n\nthe High Court Legal Services Committee or the State Legal\n\nServices Authority. While levy of an uniform token sum, as\n\ncosts payable to the Legal Service Authority/Committee by\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                        7</span>\n\nway of a deterrent fine, in regard to non-compliance with\n\nprocedural      requirements,           delays       in    re-presentation        of\n\npapers etc. may not be objectionable, levy of huge amounts\n\nas    costs   in    selected       cases,     made    payable      to    the   Legal\n\nService Authorities, may invite adverse comments and evoke\n\nhostility to legal services in general. We have also come\n\nacross cases of costs being levied and made payable to some\n\nnon-party      charitable         organizations.          Levy   of     such   costs\n\nshould be avoided.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">11.    The Delhi High Court Legal Services Committee when it\n\nreceives      the   sum     of    Rs.   Two    Lakhs       as    costs    from   the\n\nparties, shall make over the same to the state government\n\nas directed in para 38 of the impugned judgment. Let a copy\n\nof    this    order    be        sent   to    the     Delhi      Legal     Services\n\nCommittee, for compliance.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">12.    With the above said observations regarding costs, the\n\nspecial leave petitions are dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                                           _________________J.</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\n                                                           (R V Raveendran)\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                   8</span>\n\n\n\n\nNew Delhi;             _________________J.\nJanuary 9, 2009. State Electricity Board &amp; Anr vs Aziz Ahmad on 20 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . M Sharma</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 318            OF 2009\n             (Arising out of S.L.P. (Civil) No. 6019 of 2007)\n\n\nU.P. State Electricity Board &amp; Anr.                   .... Appellants\n\n                                 Versus\n\nAziz Ahmad                                            .... Respondent\n\n\n                              JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">1.   Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.   The issue which arises for consideration in this appeal is\n\nwhether the post of Boiler Overhauling Mechanic is equivalent to that\n\nof the post of Boiler Mistry or Fitter so as to enable the workman,\n\nrespondent herein to draw higher pay scale than what is being given\n\nto him. There is no dispute with regard to the fact that the post of\n\nBoiler Overhauling Mechanic is a different post than that of the post of\n\nBoiler Mistry which is equivalent to that of Fitter in `Skilled - A'\n\nCategory.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                  2</span><p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.      The workman, respondent herein was appointed as coolie in the\n\nservice of the appellant Board with effect from 1.4.1969 in the pay\n\nscale of Rs. 55-90. He was thereafter designated as Helper in the\n\nsame pay scale of coolie and worked in the said post till 13.9.1977.\n\nThereafter he appeared before the Selection Committee No. 2 for\n\nbeing promoted to the post of Boiler Overhauling Mechanic. In the\n\nsaid selection, by order dated 13.9.1977 the respondent was declared\n\nsuccessful consequent upon which he was offered the post of Boiler\n\nOverhauling Mechanic in the then pay scale of Rs. 80-145. The\n\naforesaid pay scale, however, has been revised with the passage of\n\ntime.     He joined the duties of Boiler Overhauling Mechanic on\n\n14.9.1977 and since then he performed his duties accordingly. It is\n\nstated that he was also looking after the work of Fitter in addition to\n\nthe work of Boiler Overhauling Mechanic. In terms of the policy his\n\nemployment in the Board was confirmed as against the post of coolie\n\nwith effect from 1.4.1976 under order issued by the competent\n\nauthority on 14.9.1978.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.      The allegation was that one Shri Jogeshwar Prasad, who was\n\nworking at Sohawal Power House, Faizabad as Boiler Mistry was\n\ngiven the status of `Skilled-A' worker and was given the pay scale of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                                    3</span>\n\nRs. 150-285 with effect from 1.4.1969.       The respondent-workman\n\nclaimed that the same pay scale which has been given to Jogeshwar\n\nPrasad should also be given to him. In terms thereof he raised an\n\nindustrial dispute contending inter alia that since the work of Boiler\n\nOverhauling Mechanic and Boiler Mistry are identical and the nature\n\nand responsibilities are also similar, he is entitled to get the same pay\n\nscale on the principle of equal pay for equal work. He claimed that his\n\npay should be fixed in the pay scale of Rs. 150-285 with effect from\n\n1.4.1977, as revised from time to time.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5.   The aforesaid industrial dispute raised by the Union on behalf of\n\nthe respondent-workman was referred to the Tribunal for adjudication\n\nunder the following terms:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">       \"Whether the employers should give pay scale of Skilled\n       Category -A to Shri Aziz Ahmad, son of Shri Rashid\n       Mohammad, Boiler Overhauling Mechanic? If yes, then\n       from which date and with what other details?\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_11\">6.   The Tribunal, on receipt of the aforesaid reference, issued\n\nnotices to the parties upon which the parties appeared and filed their\n\nrespective pleadings. The evidence was also led by the parties by\n\nproducing witnesses in support of their case.       The Tribunal, after\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                    4</span>\n\nhearing the parties, passed an award on 17.2.1999 holding that the\n\nwork being done by the workman Aziz Ahmad as Boiler Overhauling\n\nMechanic is the same as the work of Fitter and that the pay scale of\n\nthe posts of Boiler Mistry and the fitter was Rs. 150-285 and that on\n\nthe settled principle of equal pay for equal work, workman Aziz Ahmad\n\nis entitled to the same pay scale as that of the Fitter. The Tribunal\n\nheld that the said workman Aziz Ahmad would be entitled to the pay\n\nscale of `Skilled-A' category as admissible to Fitter with effect from\n\n14.9.1977, but however, as he appeared before the Conciliation Board\n\nin 1989, it was held that he would be entitled to the benefit of the\n\naforesaid pay scale only with effect from 1.1.1989.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">7.    Being aggrieved by the aforesaid award passed by the Industrial\n\nTribunal, the appellant Board preferred a writ petition in the High Court\n\nof Allahabad which was entertained and was heard on merit. The\n\nlearned Single Judge by his judgment and order dated 27.10.2005\n\ndismissed the writ petition holding that no interference was called for.\n\nIt was held by the learned Single Judge that the Tribunal rightly came\n\nto the conclusion that the workman had actually worked as Boiler\n\nMistry and had discharged superior functions of the post which was\n\nequal to that of Fitter.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                                   5</span><p id=\"p_13\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8.    The appellant being aggrieved by the order passed by the\n\nlearned Single Judge and award passed by the Tribunal filed the\n\npresent appeal on which notice and stay order were issued.\n\nConsequent thereupon this appeal was listed for hearing.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">9.    Mr. Pradeep Misra, learned counsel appearing for the appellant\n\nBoard submitted before us that the respondent-workman was made\n\naware of his status and position through the appointment letter issued\n\nto him making it clear that he had been appointed to the post of Boiler\n\nOverhauling Mechanic in the pay scale of Rs. 80-145 which he\n\naccepted and had also received all the benefits on the basis of the\n\nsaid pay scale. It was submitted that having accepted the aforesaid\n\nposition the respondent cannot turn back and claim for change in his\n\npay scale on the ground of equal pay for equal work. It was also\n\nsubmitted by him that the duties and responsibilities attached to the\n\npost of Fitter or Boiler Mistry are much more higher than that of the\n\nduties and responsibilities attached to the post of Boiler Overhauling\n\nMechanic, and therefore, the Tribunal as also the learned Single\n\nJudge were not justified in holding that the duties and responsibilities\n\nof the aforesaid posts are similar.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                        6</span><p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">      It was further submitted that there is no evidence or material\n\nplaced on record to substantiate that duties and responsibilities\n\nattached with the post of Fitter or Boiler Mistry are similar and identical\n\nin all respects to that of the duties and responsibilities attached to the\n\npost of Boiler Overhauling Mechanic and in absence of clear evidence\n\nin that regard it was inappropriate on the part of both the learned\n\nSingle Judge of the High Court as also of the learned Industrial\n\nTribunal to pass an award in favour of the workman.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">10.   Mr.   A.P.   Mohanty,    learned    counsel    appearing    for   the\n\nrespondent-workman, however, sought to justify both the award as\n\nalso the judgment and order of the learned Single Judge upholding the\n\naward contending inter alia that from the pleadings of the parties and\n\ndepositions recorded by the Labour Court, if it is possible to come to\n\nthe conclusion that both the posts carry the same duties and\n\nresponsibilities or identical responsibilities and status, then the\n\nTribunal could have and accordingly has rightly passed the award in\n\nfavour of the workman.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">11.   In order to appreciate the aforesaid contentions we have\n\ncarefully scrutinised the records including the documents and the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                     7</span>\n\ndepositions. We have carefully analysed the findings recorded by the\n\nTribunal in paragraph 12 of the award.       In the said paragraph the\n\nTribunal recorded that the issue to be determined is whether the\n\nworkman Aziz Ahmad is doing similar work as that of the work of Fitter\n\nor Boiler Mistry.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">12.   Having framed the aforesaid issue for consideration, the\n\nTribunal immediately went on to record a finding that it was\n\nunfortunate that none of the parties had filed an objective data with\n\nregard to the work assessment of the aforesaid posts. The learned\n\nTribunal put the burden on the employer to record the job\n\nrequirements of the aforesaid posts and to prove and establish that\n\nthey are not identical. The aforesaid findings of the learned Tribunal\n\nwere also upheld by the learned Single Judge.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">13.   In our considered opinion the aforesaid findings are incorrect\n\n      and cannot be upheld. The burden to prove a particular fact is\n\n      always on the person who alleges the same. In the present\n\n      case it was the contention of the respondent-workman, who\n\n      claimed that the job requirements, nature and responsibilities of\n\n      the post of Boiler Mistry/Fitter are identical and similar with that\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                                     8</span>\n\n      of the Boiler Overhauling Mechanic. The burden, therefore, was\n\n      on the workman to prove and establish the aforesaid facts by\n\n      leading cogent and reliable evidence. He was required to place\n\n      documentary evidence in support of the same.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">14.   The principle that the burden of proof is on a person who alleges\n\n      it has been reiterated by this Court innumerable times. For\n\n      reference we may extract the following passages from the\n\n      judgment of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/1176691/\" id=\"a_1\">State of M.P. v. Pramod Bhartiya</a>,\n\n      [(1993) 1 SCC 539]:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">      \"13...............It must be remembered that since the plea\n      of equal pay for equal work has to be examined with\n      reference to <a href=\"/doc/367586/\" id=\"a_2\">Article 14</a>, the burden is upon the petitioners\n      to establish their right to equal pay, or the plea of\n      discrimination, as the case may be. This burden the\n      original petitioners (respondents herein) have failed to\n      discharge.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\nFurther in <a href=\"/doc/734107/\" id=\"a_3\">Union of India v. Tarit Ranjan Da</a> [(2003) 11 SCC 658]\n\nwherein one of us (Dr. Arijit Pasayat) was a member this Court held:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      \"9................ Further, the Tribunal and the High Court\n      proceeded as if it was the employer who was to show that\n      there was no equality in the work. On the contrary, the\n      person who asserts that there is equality has to prove it.\n      The equality is not based on designation or the nature of\n      work alone. There are several other factors like\n      responsibilities, reliabilities, experience, confidentiality\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                        9</span>\n\n      involved, functional need and requirements commensurate\n      with the position in the hierarchy, the qualifications required\n      which are equally relevant.\"\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_29\">The said principle was retreated subsequently in <a href=\"/doc/1330629/\" id=\"a_4\">State of Haryana v.\n\nCharanjit Singh</a>, (2006) 9 SCC 321 wherein it was held:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">      \"19......In any event, the party who claims equal pay for\n      equal work has to make necessary averments and prove\n      that all things are equal. Thus, before any direction can be\n      issued by a court, the court must first see that there are\n      necessary averments and there is a proof.......\"\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">      20.........In each case the court must satisfy itself that the\n      burden of proving that the work and conditions are equal is\n      discharged by the aggrieved employee\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_30\">15.   The Tribunal as also the High Court while affirming the award\n\n      changed the rule of the game by placing the entire burden of\n\n      proof on the management that the posts are not identical.\n\n      Whether the aforesaid posts are identical and whether the\n\n      persons holding the post of Boiler Overhauling Mechanic, Boiler\n\n      Mistry or Fitter are doing identical or similar nature of work and\n\n      discharge the same functions and responsibilities are required to\n\n      be adjudicated upon and decided by making an analysis of their\n\n      nature of duties, responsibilities, pay scales and other factors\n\n      which are required to be considered for deciding such an issue.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                                                   10</span>\n\nThis Court in a number of decisions has laid down the guiding\n\nfactors and principles as to how the issue with regard to\n\nequation of posts is to be considered and analyzed. In Secy.,\n\nFinance Deptt. v. W.B. Registration Service Assn., 1993\n\n[Supp (1) SCC 153] this Court enumerated the factors to be\n\ntaken into consideration for job evaluation:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\"12. We do not consider it necessary to traverse the case\nlaw on which reliance has been placed by counsel for the\nappellants as it is well settled that equation of posts and\ndetermination of pay scales is the primary function of the\nexecutive and not the judiciary and, therefore, ordinarily\ncourts will not enter upon the task of job evaluation which is\ngenerally left to expert bodies like the Pay Commissions,\netc. But that is not to say that the Court has no jurisdiction\nand the aggrieved employees have no remedy if they are\nunjustly treated by arbitrary State action or inaction. Courts\nmust, however, realise that job evaluation is both a difficult\nand time consuming task which even expert bodies having\nthe assistance of staff with requisite expertise have found\ndifficult to undertake sometimes on account of want of\nrelevant data and scales for evaluating performances of\ndifferent groups of employees. This would call for a\nconstant study of the external comparisons and internal\nrelativities on account of the changing nature of job\nrequirements. The factors which may have to be kept in\nview for job evaluation may include (i) the work programme\nof his department (ii) the nature of contribution expected of\nhim (iii) the extent of his responsibility and accountability in\nthe discharge of his diverse duties and functions (iv) the\nextent and nature of freedoms/limitations available or\nimposed on him in the discharge of his duties (v) the extent\nof powers vested in him (vi) the extent of his dependence\non superiors for the exercise of his powers (vii) the need to\nco-ordinate with other departments, etc. We have also\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                                                        11</span>\n\nreferred to the history of the service and the effort of\nvarious bodies to reduce the total number of pay scales to\na reasonable number. Such reduction in the number of pay\nscales has to be achieved by resorting to broadbanding of\nposts by placing different posts having comparable job\ncharts in a common scale. Substantial reduction in the\nnumber of pay scales must inevitably lead to clubbing of\nposts and grades which were earlier different and unequal.\nWhile doing so care must be taken to ensure that such\nrationalisation of the pay structure does not throw up\nanomalies. Ordinarily a pay structure is evolved keeping in\nmind several factors, e.g., (i) method of recruitment, (ii)\nlevel at which recruitment is made, (iii) the hierarchy of\nservice in a given cadre, (iv) minimum educational/technical\nqualifications required, (v) avenues of promotion, (vi) the\nnature of duties and responsibilities, (vii) the horizontal and\nvertical relativities with similar jobs, (viii) public dealings, (ix)\nsatisfaction level, (x) employer's capacity to pay, etc. We\nhave referred to these matters in some detail only to\nemphasise that several factors have to be kept in view\nwhile evolving a pay structure and the horizontal and\nvertical relativities have to be carefully balanced keeping in\nmind the hierarchical arrangements, avenues for\npromotion, etc. Such a carefully evolved pay structure\nought not to be ordinarily disturbed as it may upset the\nbalance and cause avoidable ripples in other cadres as\nwell. It is presumably for this reason that the Judicial\nSecretary who had strongly recommended a substantial\nhike in the salary of the Sub-Registrars to the Second\n(State) Pay Commission found it difficult to concede the\ndemand made by the Registration Service before him in his\ncapacity as the Chairman of the Third (State) Pay\nCommission. There can, therefore, be no doubt that\nequation of posts and equation of salaries is a complex\nmatter which is best left to an expert body unless there is\ncogent material on record to come to a firm conclusion that\na grave error had crept in while fixing the pay scale for a\ngiven post and Court's interference is absolutely necessary\nto undo the injustice.\"\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                                                      12</span><p id=\"p_32\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">16.   Moreover in <a href=\"/doc/1246624/\" id=\"a_5\">Gyan Prakash v. Union of India</a> [(1997) 11 SCC\n\n      670] it was held that application of the principle of equal pay for\n\n      equal work cannot be claimed merely because there was\n\n      delegation of certain powers. The ratio of the aforesaid decision\n\n      is applicable to the facts of the present case as the claim of the\n\n      Respondent for a higher pay scale is also on the ground that he\n\n      was discharging the duties of a higher post also, without\n\n      however, giving any factual details in that regard.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">17.   Being conscious of the aforesaid legal position we are of the\n\n      considered    opinion   that   the   learned   Industrial   Tribunal\n\n      committed a manifest error of law and of fact initially by placing\n\n      the burden on the employer to prove and establish the job\n\n      requirements of the said three posts, and thereafter, again\n\n      committed an error in coming to the conclusion that the posts\n\n      are identical on the basis of the pleadings of the parties alone.\n\n      Pleadings are required to be proved and so long evidence is not\n\n      led in support of the pleadings no reliance can be placed only on\n\n      the pleadings without there being any cogent evidence in\n\n      support of the pleadings. Pleadings are required to be proved\n\n      by leading evidence.      The Tribunal expressly stated in its\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                                                   13</span>\n\n      findings that none of the parties have filed any objective data in\n\n      regard to the work assessment of the posts of Boiler\n\n      Overhauling Mechanic, Boiler Mistry or Fitter.     In absence of\n\n      such evidence the Tribunal was not justified in coming to a\n\n      conclusion that the nature, duties and responsibilities of the\n\n      three posts are identical and similar.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">18.   Therefore, we have no other option but to remand this matter to\n\n      the Industrial Tribunal for fresh adjudication in accordance with\n\n      law.   We, however, allow the parties an opportunity to lead\n\n      further evidence in support of their claims and counter claims\n\n      regarding the status and position of the aforesaid three posts.\n\n      The Tribunal should see to it that the claims and the rebuttal of\n\n      the said claim should be supported by cogent and reliable\n\n      evidence.     For that matter the Tribunal shall render an\n\n      opportunity to the parties to lead their evidence in support of\n\n      their case and on the basis of the records, as available, the\n\n      Tribunal would decide afresh the issue whether the nature,\n\n      duties and responsibilities of the said three posts are identical,\n\n      and thereafter, the Tribunal should answer the reference.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                                                           14</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">19.   Consequently, we set aside both the award passed by the\n\n      Tribunal as also the judgment passed by the learned Single\n\n      Judge and remit back the matter to the Industrial Tribunal for\n\n      decision in terms of the aforesaid observations. It is needless to\n\n      say that since it is an old matter, the Tribunal should render a\n\n      priority in hearing of this matter and would make all endeavour to\n\n      decide the matter, preferably within a period of six months.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">20.   The appeal is disposed of in terms of the aforesaid order.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">                                         .................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">                                         (Dr. Arijit Pasayat)\n\n\n\n                                         .................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">                                         (Dr. Mukundakam Sharma)\n\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">January 20, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":13,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"highway","formInput":"highway"},{"value":"national highways ","formInput":"national%20highways%20"},{"value":"kurnool","formInput":"kurnool"},{"value":"village land","formInput":"village%20land"},{"value":"market value of land","formInput":"market%20value%20of%20land"},{"value":"escalation","formInput":"escalation"},{"value":"development charges","formInput":"development%20charges"},{"value":"industrial infrastructure corporation limited","formInput":"industrial%20infrastructure%20corporation%20limited"}],"citeList":[{"tid":169774,"url":null,"title":"Section 4(1) in The Land Acquisition Act, 1894"},{"tid":1500467,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=26934","title":"Viluben Jhalejar Contractor (D) ... vs State Of Gujarat on 13 April, 2005"},{"tid":1716456,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=18750","title":"Kasturi & Ors vs State Of Haryana on 12 November, 2002"},{"tid":909226,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=10683","title":"M/S.
