Sudershan Reddy</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n               CIVIL APPEAL NOS. 8984-8985 OF 2003\n\nREVENUE DIVISIONAL OFFICER-CUM-\nL.A.O.                                                  ... APPELLANT\n                       Versus\n\nSHAIK AZAM SAHEB ETC. ETC.                              ... RESPONDENTS\n\n[with C.A. No. 8733-8736/2003, C.A. No. 8987-9001/2003,\nC.A. Nos. 108-115/2009 (@ SLP (C) Nos. 4463-4470/2004),\nC.A. Nos. 116-121/2009 (@ SLP (C) Nos. 12200-12205/2007)\nC.A. No. 130/2009         (@ SLP (C) Nos. 12215/2007),\nC.A. Nos. 122-129/2009 (@ SLP (C) Nos. 12206-12213/2007)].\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. SINHA, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">1.    Leave granted in Special Leave Petition (Civil) Nos. 4463-4470 of\n\n2004, 12200-12205 of 2007, 12215 of 2007 and 12206-12213 of 2007.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.    These appeals by special leave involving common questions of law\n\nand fact were taken up for hearing together and are being disposed of by\n\nthis common judgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.    The basic fact of the matter is not in dispute.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                    2</span><p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      A notification under <a href=\"/doc/169774/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 4(1)</a> of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894\n\nwas issued (hereinafter referred to for the sake of brevity as, \"the said Act\")\n\nexpressing the intention of the State to acquire land to the extent of 87\n\nAcres 96 cents situated in Pasupula and B. Thandrapadu villages for the\n\npurpose of establishing a Post Graduation Centre of Sri Krishna Devaraya\n\nUniversity.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4.    Out of the said 87 Acres 96 cents of land, we are concerned only with\n\n25 acres of land of which respondents were owners. The Land Acquisition\n\nOfficer made an award on or about 20.12.1995 fixing the market value of\n\nthe lands at the rate of Rs.15,000/- per acre for the lands situated in B.\n\nThandrapadu village and Rs.16,000/- per acre for the lands situated in\n\nPasupula village.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.    Dissatisfied with the quantum of compensation awarded by the Land\n\nAcquisition Officer, the respondents sought for reference from the Collector\n\nbefore the Civil Court in terms of <a href=\"/doc/1517117/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 18</a> of the said Act.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      The learned Principal Senior Civil Judge, Kurnool by a judgment and\n\naward dated 28.03.2001 enhanced the market value thereof from\n\nRs.15,000/- to Rs.90,000/- per acre for the lands situated in B. Thandrapadu\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                     3</span>\n\nvillage and from Rs.16,000/- to Rs.1,00,000/- per acre for the lands situated\n\nin Pasupula village. Appeals and cross-objections were filed thereagainst\n\nby the parties hereto.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">6.    By reason of judgments and orders dated 18.3.2002 and 28.3.2003, a\n\nDivision Bench of the Andhra Pradesh High Court enhanced the market\n\nvalue of the land to Rs.1,90,000/- per acre uniformly for the lands situated\n\nin both the villages.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">7.    Parties thereto are, thus, before us.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">8.    The High Court in support of its judgment, inter alia, relied upon a\n\nregistered deed of sale dated 12.11.1987, which was marked as Exhibit B-3\n\nwhereby and whereunder four cents of land was sold for a sum of\n\nRs.10,000/-. On that premise, it was contended that the value of the land\n\nper acre would be Rs.2,50,000/-. The High Court furthermore relied on its\n\nearlier judgment and order passed in A.S. No. 1095 of 1996 (Exhibit B-6)\n\nwherein market value of the lands acquired therein was fixed at the rate of\n\nRs.2,70,000/- per acre.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">      In respect of the land covered by Exhibit B-6, a notification under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/169774/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 4(1)</a> of the Act was issued on 30.06.1992 for the purpose of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                   4</span>\n\nestablishing Bharat Gas Power Station. It was noticed that the lands which\n\nwere acquired for the said Bharat Gas Power Station being situated at a\n\ndistance of about 8 kilometers from Kurnool Town whereas the acquired\n\nlands were situated about 4-5 kilometers away from Kurnool Town.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">      It was stated:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">            \"As can be seen from Ex.B6, this court has fixed\n            the rate of compensation at Rs.2,70,000/- and the\n            notification was issued in June 1992 whereas in\n            the present cases notification was issued in May\n            1995. In such an event, if escalation is given at\n            10% on the value fixed by this Court, it would be\n            around Rs.3,24,000/- per acre. Let us test the\n            value from the other angle. Ex. B3 is a small\n            extent of 4 cents and the purchase took place in\n            the year 1997. The reference court correctly\n            observed that as the purchase was made about 7\n            years earlier to the notification, the purchase was\n            not made with a view to have an undue advantage\n            of higher compensation. As per Ex. B3 the value\n            per acre is Rs.4,00,000/- if 10% escalation is given\n            for 7 years, the same comes to Rs.6,80,000/- and\n            even if we take 60% of the amount by keeping in\n            view the small extent sold under Ex.B3 and also\n            giving discount for developmental activities, it\n            would be Rs.2,72,000/- per acre. Therefore, we\n            follow the safest method for arriving at the\n            compensation with reference to Ex.B6 which is in\n            an extent of 27 and the area covered by the batch\n            of appeals is also almost same, and the notification\n            was issued for 87.96 cents, granting of escalation\n            by deduction 40% of the amount and fixing the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                  5</span>\n\n            compensation at Rs.1,90,000/- would be just and\n            reasonable. Therefore, we have taken the course\n            of resorting to 40% of the amount as the land\n            acquired was for the University Buildings,\n            wherein internal roads have to be laid and other\n            open spaces have to be left out. Thus, keeping in\n            view the above facts, we feel that granting\n            compensation at Rs.1,90,000/- is just and\n            reasonable.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_23\">9.    Mr. R. Sundarvardhan, learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of\n\nappellant would contend:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      i.    As this Court in Civil Appeal No. 5206-5228 of 1997 (A.P.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">            Industrial Infrastructure Corporation Limited vs. G. Mohan\n\n            Reddy &amp; ors.) interfered with the judgment and order passed in\n\n            A.S. No. 1095 of 1996 and batch to hold that the market value\n\n            of the land in question should be fixed at Rs.1,35,000/-,\n\n            Rs.90,000/- and Rs.70,000/- per acre for different survey nos.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">            on the premise that the situation of the land keeping in view\n\n            their distance from the National Highway play a vital role as\n\n            the land which is near the Highway would definitely get a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                   6</span>\n\n            higher price than the land which is away therefrom, the\n\n            impugned judgment cannot be sustained.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">      ii.   Exhibit B-3 being the registered sale deed dated 12.11.1987\n\n            could not have been relied upon as only 4 cents of land was the\n\n            subject matter of transfer in terms thereof whereas the\n\n            notification had been issued for acquisition of land measuring\n\n            87 Acres 96 cents.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_25\">10.   Mrs. K. Amareswari, learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of\n\nthe respondents, on the other hand, would contend:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">      i.    It is not correct to contend that an exemplar in terms whereof\n\n            only a small portion of land had been transferred can never be\n\n            taken into consideration.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">      ii.   Keeping in view the fact that the market rate in terms of\n\n            Exhibit B-3 would come to Rs.2,50,000/- per acre, even if 50\n\n            per cent is deducted therefrom, the market value may be\n\n            determined at Rs.1,25,000/- to which increase therein at the\n\n            rate of 10 per cent per year should be added and as the lands in\n\n            question were acquired on 5.5.1994, that is, 7 years after the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                    7</span>\n\n             said deed of sale was executed, the market value thereof would\n\n             come to Rs.2,12,500/- per acre.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">      iii.   So far as the judgment of this Court passed in Civil Appeal No.\n\n             5206-5228 of 1997 (A.P. Industrial Infrastructure Corporation\n\n             Limited vs. G. Mohan Reddy &amp; ors.) is concerned, the\n\n             notification therein having been issued on or about 30.6.1992\n\n             whereas the notification in the instant case having been\n\n             published on 5.5.1994, no reliance can be placed thereupon as\n\n             admittedly the lands were situated 8 kilometers away from the\n\n             National Highway whereas the lands in question are situated\n\n             only 4 kilometers away from the Highway.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_26\">11.   Determination of market value of a land acquired in terms of the\n\nprovisions of the said Act depends upon a large number of factors; the first\n\nbeing the nature and quality of the land, i.e., whether agricultural land or\n\nhomestead land. Apart from nature and quality of land in the event the\n\nagricultural lands are acquired the other factors relevant therefor are also\n\nrequired to be considered, namely, as to whether they are irrigated or non-\n\nirrigated, extent of facilities available for irrigation, location of the land,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                    8</span>\n\ncloseness thereof from any road or highway, the evenness of land, its\n\nposition in different seasons particularly in rainy season, existence of any\n\nbuilding or structure as also the development in and around the area. A host\n\nof other factors will also have a bearing on determining the valuation of\n\nland.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">12.     The mode and manner in which determination of such valuation are to\n\nbe carried out would also depend upon the facts and circumstances of each\n\ncase, namely, whether any deed of sale executed in respect of similarly\n\nsituated land near about the date of issuance of notification under <a href=\"/doc/43654/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 4</a>\n\n(1) of the Act is available, or in absence of any such exemplars whether the\n\nclaim can be determined on yield basis or in case of an orchard on the basis\n\nof the number of fruit bearing trees and the yield therefrom.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">13.     One other important factor which also should be borne in mind is that\n\nit may not be safe to rely only on an award involving a neighbouring area\n\nirrespective of the nature and quality of the land. For determination of\n\nmarket value again, the positive and negative factors germane therefor\n\nshould be taken into consideration, as laid down by this Court in <a href=\"/doc/1500467/\" id=\"a_5\">Viluben\n\nJhalejar Contractor vs. State of Gujarat</a> [(2005) 4 SCC 789], namely:\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                    9</span>\n\n</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">           Positive factors                        Negative factors\n\n(i)    Smallness of size                (i)    Largeness of area\n\n(ii)   proximity to a road              (ii)   situation in the interior at a\n                                               distance from the road\n\n(iii) frontage on a road                (iii   narrow strip of land with very\n                                        )      small frontage compared to\n                                               depth\n\n(iv)   Nearness to developed area       (iv) lower level requiring the\n                                             depressed portion to be filled\n                                             up\n\n(v)    regular shape                    (v)    Remoteness from developed\n                                               locality\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_30\">(vi)   Level vis-`-vis land under (vi) Some special disadvantageous\n       acquisition                     factors which would deter a\n                                       purchaser\n\n(vii   Special value for an owner of\n)      an adjoining property to\n       whom it may have some very\n       special advantage.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">14.    Before determination of the market value of the land, we may notice\n\nthat the town of Kurnool is the District Headquarter of Kurnool district.\n\nThe acquired lands are situated about 4 kilometers away from the said town\n\nabutting National Highway No. 18. The lands in question have been held to\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                   10</span>\n\nhave the requisite potential value as building site as also for constructing\n\nindustrial complexes. The learned Reference Judge noticed that there are\n\neducational institutions like Pulla Reddy Engineering College, Don Bosco\n\nSchool, St. Mary's Residential School etc. surrounding the acquired lands.\n\nG. Pulla Reddy Engineering College is said to be situated just on the other\n\nside of the road of the lands acquired. As on the date of acquisition, it was\n\nfound that the vicinity surrounding the land was well developed.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">15.   Indisputably, a big chunk of lands, namely, 87 Acres 96 cents were\n\nacquired for the purpose of establishing an institution known as Sri Krishna\n\nDevaraya University. The award of the Land Acquisition Collector was\n\naccepted by most of the persons. Only the respondents before us objected\n\nthereto.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">16.   The lands are situated in two different villages. The plan showing the\n\nlocation of the land vis-`-vis the National Highway No. 18 had not been\n\nplaced before us. From the award of the learned Reference Judge, it appears\n\nthat the lands situated in Pasupula village are better placed than the lands\n\nsituated in B. Thandrapadu village. Such a distinction had also been kept in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                    11</span>\n\nmind not only by the Land Acquisition Collector but also by the Reference\n\nCourt.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">17.      We agree with the judgment of this Court in Civil Appeal No. 5206-\n\n5228 of 1997 (A.P. Industrial Infrastructure Corporation Limited vs. G.\n\nMohan Reddy &amp; ors.) that the market value of the land would also depend\n\nupon the situation thereof.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_38\">\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">18.      Applying the said formula, if we rely on Exhibit B-3, the market\n\nvalue of the land in question would come to about Rs.1,25,000/- per acre. It\n\nis, however, not possible to agree with the submissions of Mrs. Amareswari\n\nthat we should determine the market value only on that basis upon addition\n\nof 10 per cent enhancement of the market value each year. It must be bear\n\nin mind that the lands in question were agricultural lands whereas the lands\n\nwhich were the subject matter of the said deed of sale was a homestead land,\n\nthus, some amount, therefore, will have to deducted towards the\n\ndevelopment cost.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_40\">\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">19.      Indisputably while comparing the market value of developed lands\n\nwith that of undeveloped lands, the court has to make suitable deductions\n\ntowards the cost of development.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                  12</span><p id=\"p_42\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">      We, however, may notice that this Court, at different times, has\n\nspoken in different voices.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_44\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">      <a href=\"/doc/1169518/\" id=\"a_6\">In P.S. Krishna and Co. Pvt. Ltd. v. The Land Acquisition Officer,\n\n(Deputy Collector) Hyderabad</a> [(1991) 2 SCALE 1186], this Court refused\n\nto interfere with the judgment of the High Court which had given a\n\ndeduction of 20% towards development charges. Recently, a Division\n\nBench of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/537773/\" id=\"a_7\">Mummidi Apparao v. Nagarjuna Fertilizers and\n\nChemicals Ltd</a>. [2008 (16) SCALE 226] did not interfere with the decision\n\nof the High Court which had given a direction for deduction of 50% as\n\ndevelopment charges. However, we are not oblivious of the fact that this\n\nCourt had observed in <a href=\"/doc/1500467/\" id=\"a_8\">Viluben Jhalejar Contractor (D) v. State of Gujarat</a>\n\n[(2005) 4 SCC 789]:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_46\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">            \"28. <a href=\"/doc/909226/\" id=\"a_9\">In Hasanali Khanbhai &amp; Sons v. State of Gujarat</a>\n            [(1995) 5 SCC 422] and <a href=\"/doc/105580756/\" id=\"a_10\">Land Acquisition Officer v.\n            Nookala Rajamallu</a> (2003) 12 SCC 334: (2003) 10\n            SCALE 307 it has been noticed that where lands are\n            acquired for specific purposes deduction by way of\n            development charges is permissible.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">            29. We are not, however, oblivious of the fact that\n            normally one-third deduction of further amount of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                    13</span>\n\n            compensation has been directed in some cases. (<a href=\"/doc/1716456/\" id=\"a_11\">See\n            Kasturi v. State of Haryana</a> [(2003) 1 SCC 354],\n            <a href=\"/doc/1868919/\" id=\"a_12\">Tejumal Bhojwani v. State of U.P</a>., [(2003) 10 SCC\n            525], <a href=\"/doc/686974/\" id=\"a_13\">V. Hanumantha Reddy v. Land Acquisition\n            Officer &amp; Mandal R. Officer</a> (2003) 12 SCC 642,\n            <a href=\"/doc/237802/\" id=\"a_14\">H.P. Housing Board v. Bharat S. Negi</a> (2004) 2 SCC\n            184 and <a href=\"/doc/1866334/\" id=\"a_15\">Kiran Tandon v. Allahabad Development\n            Authority and Anr</a>. (2004) 10 SCC 745).\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_47\">20.   In the facts and circumstances of the present case, one-third\n\ndeduction, in our opinion, should be made towards development costs for\n\nthe lands situated both in Pasupala village as also B. Thandrapadu village.\n\nKeeping in view the fact that the lands are abutting National Highway and\n\nnear the district town, where a large number of educational institutions have\n\ncome up, 10 per cent escalation per year has to be added. Thus, Rs.\n\n1,41,666.66 per acre may be fixed for the lands in Pasupala village.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_48\">      The lands in another village B. Thandrapadu Village being situated\n\naway from the NH 18, another 10 per cent from the amount fixed for the\n\nlands in Pasupala village must be deducted. Thus, Rs. 1,27,499.99 per acre\n\nmay be fixed for the lands in B. Thandrapadu village.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_49\">      We have adopted the same method which had been adopted by the\n\nReference Judge inasmuch as the Reference Judge had fixed market value\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                   14</span>\n\nfor the lands situated in Pasupala village at Rs. 1,00,000/- per acre and\n\nRs.90, 000/- per acre in respect of B. Thandrapadu village.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_50\">21.   The appeals are allowed to the aforementioned extent. No costs.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_51\">                                            ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_52\">                                                   [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n\n                                            .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_53\">                                            [Lokeshwar          Singh      Panta]\n\n\n\n                                             .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_54\">                                                [B. Sudershan Reddy]\n\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_55\">JANUARY 13, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":11,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"ndps India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33586","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Union Of India vs Rattan Mallik @ Habul on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D Jain</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: D.K. Jain, R.M. Lodha</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                             REPORTABLE\n\n                       IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                      CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                       CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 137 OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of S.L.P. (Criminal) No.1057 of 2008)\n\n\nUNION OF INDIA                                        --   APPELLANT\n\n\n                                    VERSUS\n\n\nRATTAN MALLIK @ HABUL                                --    RESPONDENT\n\n\n                                        JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">D.K. JAIN, J.:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">         Delay condoned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2. Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3. Challenge in this appeal, by the Union of India, is to the order dated 13th\n\n   November, 2006, passed by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad\n\n   suspending the sentence awarded by the trial Court to the respondent for having\n\n   committed offences under <a href=\"/doc/704277/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 8</a>/<a href=\"/doc/935721/\" id=\"a_2\">27A</a> and <a href=\"/doc/704277/\" id=\"a_3\">8</a>/<a href=\"/doc/1252855/\" id=\"a_4\">29</a> of the Narcotic Drugs and\n\f   <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_5\">Psychotropic Substances Act</a>, 1985 (for short `the <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_6\">NDPS Act</a>') and granting him\n\n   bail.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4. Since in this appeal we propose to deal with the short question, viz. whether the\n\n   High Court, while accepting the prayer for grant of bail, had kept in view the\n\n   parameters of <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act, we deem it unnecessary to advert to\n\n   the facts of the case against the respondent in greater detail. It would suffice to\n\n   note that the case of the prosecution against the respondent was that he was\n\n   involved in financing and trading in 14.900 kilograms of heroin, recovered from\n\n   a specially made cavity above the cabin of a truck. Upon consideration of the\n\n   evidence adduced, the Trial Court came to the conclusion that the prosecution\n\n   had successfully proved the charges against the respondent and three others.\n\n   On conviction, the Trial Court sentenced the respondent to undergo rigorous\n\n   imprisonment for ten years and to pay a fine of Rs.1 lac under <a href=\"/doc/935721/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 27A</a> of\n\n   the NDPS Act and undergo rigorous imprisonment for ten years and a fine of\n\n   Rs.1 lac under <a href=\"/doc/1252855/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 29</a> of the NDPS Act, with default stipulation.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5. Being aggrieved, the respondent preferred an appeal to the High Court along\n\n   with an application for suspension of sentence and grant of bail till his appeal\n\n   was finally decided. The High Court, by the impugned order, has allowed the bail\n\n   application and has ordered that the respondent shall be released on bail on his\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                                     2</span>\n\f  executing a personal bond and furnishing two sureties each in the like amount\n\n  to the satisfaction of the concerned Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">6. The considerations which weighed with the High Court for suspension of\n\n  sentence and grant of bail are brief and for the sake of ready reference are\n\n  extracted below:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">              \"The appellant has been convicted under <a href=\"/doc/704277/\" id=\"a_10\">Sections 8</a>/<a href=\"/doc/935721/\" id=\"a_11\">27-A</a> and\n     <a href=\"/doc/704277/\" id=\"a_12\">8</a>/<a href=\"/doc/1252855/\" id=\"a_13\">29</a> N.D.P.S. Act for ten years R.I and also fine. Nothing has been found\n     from his possession. Besides the appellant is in jail since 5.9.2003. Three\n     years have already lapsed. There is no chance of the appeal being heard\n     within a period of seven years.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">  7. Aggrieved thereby, the Union of India has preferred this appeal.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">  8. Mr. A. Sharan, learned Additional Solicitor General of India, strenuously urged\n\n     that the High Court has committed a grave error of law in granting bail to the\n\n     respondent, ignoring the mandatory provisions of <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS\n\n     Act. The learned counsel contended that the High Court lost sight of the\n\n     restrictions and limitations imposed by <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act.\n\n     According to the learned counsel, the grant of bail to the respondent, without\n\n     recording any finding on the conditions as stipulated in <a href=\"/doc/1199025/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 37(1)(b)(ii)</a> of\n\n     the NDPS Act, the order suspending the sentence is ex facie illegal and\n\n     therefore deserves to be set aside, with a direction to the respondent to\n\n     surrender to custody forthwith. In support of the proposition that suspension\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                                    3</span>\n\f         of sentence by the appellate Court has to be within the parameters of law,\n\n         prescribed by the Legislature, the learned senior counsel placed reliance on a\n\n         three judge Bench decision of this Court in Dadu alias Tulsidas Vs. State of\n\n         Maharashtra1.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">      9. Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent, on the other hand,\n\n         supported the impugned order and submitted that if the impugned order is\n\n         read as a whole, it can be inferred therefrom that the learned Judge was\n\n         conscious of the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act. It is, thus, urged\n\n         that the order granting bail to the respondent being discretionary, this Court\n\n         should be loath to interfere with it in exercise of its jurisdiction under <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_18\">Article\n\n         136</a> of the Constitution.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">      10. Having carefully gone through the impugned order, we are constrained to\n\n         observe that while dealing with the application for bail, the learned Judge\n\n         appears to have lost sight of the mandatory requirements of <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_19\">Section 37</a> of\n\n         the NDPS Act and thus, the impugned order is clearly unsustainable.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">      11. The broad principles which should weigh with the Court in granting bail in a\n\n         non-bailable offence have been enumerated in a catena of decisions of this\n\n         Court and, therefore, for the sake of brevity, we do not propose to reiterate\n\n         the same. However, when a prosecution/conviction is for offence(s) under a\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">1</span>\n    (2000) 8 SCC 437\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                                          4</span>\n\f   special statute and that statute contains specific provisions for dealing with\n\n   matters arising thereunder, including an application for grant of bail, these\n\n   provisions cannot be ignored while dealing with such an application. As\n\n   already noted, in the present case, the respondent has been convicted and\n\n   sentenced for offences under the <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_20\">NDPS Act</a> and therefore, while dealing with\n\n   his application for grant of bail, in addition to the broad principles to be\n\n   applied in prosecution for offences under<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_21\"> the Indian Penal Code</a>, 1860 the\n\n   relevant provision in the said special statute in this regard had to be kept in\n\n   view.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">12.<a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_22\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act, as substituted by Act 2 of 1989 with effect from\n\n   29th May, 1989 with further amendment by Act 9 of 2001 reads as follows:\n\n\n  \"37. Offences to be cognizable and non-bailable.-- (1) Notwithstanding anything\n  contained in<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_23\"> the Code</a> of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (2 of 1974)--\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">  (a) every offence punishable under this Act shall be cognizable;\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">  (b) no person accused of an offence punishable for offences under <a href=\"/doc/128102/\" id=\"a_24\">Section\n      19</a> or <a href=\"/doc/1373137/\" id=\"a_25\">Section 24</a> or <a href=\"/doc/935721/\" id=\"a_26\">Section 27A</a> and also for offences involving\n      commercial quantity shall be released on bail or on his own bond\n      unless--\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">       (i)   the Public Prosecutor has been given an opportunity to oppose the\n               application for such release, and\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">       (ii) where the Public Prosecutor opposes the application, the court is\n             satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that he\n             is not guilty of such offence and that he is not likely to commit\n             any offence while on bail.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                                    5</span>\n\f  (2) The limitations on granting of bail specified in clause (b) of sub-section\n  (1) are in addition to the limitations under<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_27\"> the Code</a> of Criminal Procedure,\n  1973 (12 of 1974), or any other law for the time being in force on granting\n  of bail.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">13.It is plain from a bare reading of the non-obstante clause in the Section and\n\n   sub-section (2) thereof that the power to grant bail to a person accused of\n\n   having committed offence under the <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_28\">NDPS Act</a> is not only subject to the\n\n   limitations imposed under <a href=\"/doc/1290514/\" id=\"a_29\">Section 439</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure,\n\n   1973, it is also subject to the restrictions placed by sub-clause (b) of sub-\n\n   section (1) of <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_30\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act. Apart from giving an opportunity to\n\n   the Public Prosecutor to oppose the application for such release, the other\n\n   twin conditions viz; (i) the satisfaction of the Court that there are reasonable\n\n   grounds for believing that the accused is not guilty of the alleged offence;\n\n   and (ii) that he is not likely to commit any offence while on bail, have to be\n\n   satisfied.   It is manifest that the conditions are cumulative and not\n\n   alternative. The satisfaction contemplated regarding the accused being not\n\n   guilty, has to be based on \"reasonable grounds\". The expression `reasonable\n\n   grounds' has not been defined in the said Act but means something more\n\n   than prima facie grounds. It connotes substantial probable causes for believing\n\n   that the accused is not guilty of the offence he is charged with. The\n\n   reasonable belief contemplated in turn points to existence of such facts and\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                                   6</span>\n\f         circumstances as are sufficient in themselves to justify satisfaction that the\n\n         accused is not guilty of the alleged offence. [Vide Union of India Vs. Shiv\n\n         Shanker Kesari2] Thus, recording of satisfaction on both the aspects, noted\n\n         above, is sine qua non for granting of bail under the <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_31\">NDPS Act</a>.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">      14. We may, however, hasten to add that while considering an application for bail\n\n         with reference to <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_32\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act, the Court is not called upon to\n\n         record a finding of `not guilty'.   At this stage, it is neither necessary nor\n\n         desirable to weigh the evidence meticulously to arrive at a positive finding as\n\n         to whether or not the accused has committed offence under the <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_33\">NDPS Act</a>.\n\n         What is to be seen is whether there is reasonable ground for believing that\n\n         the accused is not guilty of the offence(s) he is charged with and further that\n\n         he is not likely to commit an offence under the said Act while on bail. The\n\n         satisfaction of the Court about the existence of the said twin conditions is for\n\n         a limited purpose and is confined to the question of releasing the accused on\n\n         bail.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">      15. Bearing in mind the above broad principles, we may now consider the merits\n\n         of the present appeal. It is evident from the afore-extracted paragraph that\n\n         the circumstances which have weighed with the learned Judge to conclude\n\n         that it was a fit case for grant of bail are : (i) that nothing has been found\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">2</span>\n    (2007) 7 SCC 798\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                                                        7</span>\n\f  from the possession of the respondent; (ii) he is in jail for the last three years\n\n  and (iii) that there is no chance of his appeal being heard within a period of\n\n  seven years. In our opinion, the stated circumstances may be relevant for\n\n  grant of bail in matters arising out of conviction under<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_34\"> the Indian Penal Code</a>,\n\n  1860 etc. but are not sufficient to satisfy the mandatory requirements as\n\n  stipulated in sub-clause (b) of sub-section (1) of <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_35\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act.\n\n  Merely because, according to the Ld. Judge,       nothing was found from the\n\n  possession of the respondent, it could not be said at this stage that the\n\n  respondent was not guilty of the offences for which he had been charged and\n\n  convicted. We find no substance in the argument of learned counsel for the\n\n  respondent that the observation of the learned Judge to the effect that\n\n  \"nothing has been found from his possession\" by itself shows application of\n\n  mind by the Ld. Judge tantamounting to \"satisfaction\" within the meaning of\n\n  the said provision. It seems that the provisions of the <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_36\">NDPS Act</a> and more\n\n  particularly <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_37\">Section 37</a> were not brought to the notice of the learned Judge.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">16. Thus, in our opinion, the impugned order having been passed ignoring the\n\n  mandatory requirements of <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_38\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act, it cannot be\n\n  sustained. Accordingly, the appeal is allowed and the matter is remitted back\n\n  to the High Court for fresh consideration of the application filed by the\n\n  respondent for suspension of sentence and for granting of bail, keeping in\n\n  view the parameters of <a href=\"/doc/496325/\" id=\"a_39\">Section 37</a> of the NDPS Act, enumerated above. We\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                                                   8</span>\n\f     further direct that the bail application shall be taken up for consideration\n\n     only after the respondent surrenders to custody. The respondent is directed\n\n     to surrender to custody within two weeks of the date of this order, failing\n\n     which the High Court will take appropriate steps for his arrest.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">  17. The appeal stands disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_37\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">                                       ..................................................J.\n                              (D.K. JAIN)\n\n\n\n                                      .................................................J.\n                              (R.M. LODHA)\nNEW DELHI;\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">JANUARY 23, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_40\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                                                                              9</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":7,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"article 32","formInput":"article%2032"},{"value":"inordinate delay ","formInput":"inordinate%20delay%20"},{"value":"balco","formInput":"balco"}],"citeList":[{"tid":981147,"url":null,"title":"Article 32 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":1712542,"url":null,"title":"Article 226 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":124778,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=1902","title":"Durga Prashad vs Chief Controller Of Imports & ... on 22 November, 1968"},{"tid":95685,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=1987","title":"Maharashtra State Road ... vs Shri Balwant Regular Motor ... on 22 August, 1968"},{"tid":96294865,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=21257","title":"Moon Mills Ltd vs Industrial Court Bombay (M.R. ... on 28 February, 1967"}],"covers":[],"title":"Yunus (Baboobhai) A. Hamid ... vs State Of Maharashtra & Ors on 28 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-28","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":510653,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chattisgarh/qrydisp.aspx?filename=577","title":"Suresh Yadav vs 5 Area Manager on 11 September, 2009"},{"tid":1862383,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chattisgarh/qrydisp.aspx?filename=595","title":"Hariram Naik vs 3 The Sub Divisional Officer on 25 June, 2009"},{"tid":727665,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chattisgarh/qrydisp.aspx?filename=783","title":"Tulsiram Sahu & Others vs State Of Chhattisgsarh & Others on 23 April, 2010"},{"tid":33049941,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chattisgarh/qrydisp.aspx?filename=1734","title":"Avinash Chandra Sondhi & Another vs State Of Chhattisgarh & Another on 7 December, 2011"},{"tid":51918,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chattisgarh/qrydisp.aspx?filename=945","title":"Shyam Lal Bhimte vs Madhya Pradesh Audhyogik Vikas on 20 September, 2010"}],"tid":1684754,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":20,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33602","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Yunus (Baboobhai) A. Hamid ... vs State Of Maharashtra &amp; Ors on 28 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                        REPORTABLE\n\n                    IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                     CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 486               OF 2009\n                  (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 1160 of 2005)\n\n\nYunus (Baboobhai) A Hamid Padvekar                        ...Appellant\n\n\n                                        Versus\n\nState of Maharashtra\nThrough its Secretary and Ors.                            ...Respondents\n\n\n\n                                  JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the order passed by a Division Bench of\n\nthe Bombay High Court dismissing the Writ Petition filed by the appellant\n\non the ground that it was highly belated. It also noted that the appellant had\n\nreceived compensation in respect of the land which was acquired.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">\f3.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">      In the year 1971 Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation (in\n\nshort `MIDC') acquired about 1250 acres of agricultural land situated at\n\nfour villages in Ratnagiri district of Maharashtra. Thirty eight acres of land\n\nbelonging to the appellant were acquired. It is the stand of the appellant that\n\nout of the acquired area, about 50% was under paddy cultivation and 25%\n\nwas under cultivation of mango crops. In the appellant's land about 175\n\nmango trees were there. In the year 1973, the Revenue and Forest\n\nDepartment of the Maharashtra Government passed a resolution inter-alia\n\ndeciding to take steps in respect of surplus acquired land which remained\n\nunutilized for a period of three years from the date of taking over possession\n\nfor resumption of such lands in accordance with the applicable rules and\n\norders. In 1974, a Writ Petition was filed by the appellant challenging the\n\nNotification for acquisition and an arrangement was worked out in which 20\n\nacres of appellant's land out of 38 acres were released. The lands were\n\nacquired for a Govt. company-Balco for setting up a manufacturing unit.\n\nSince Balco did not set up any unit, license issued to it was cancelled. In the\n\nyear 1982, appellant claims to have made representations alongwith\n\nsimilarly situated land owners for restoration of the acquired land to the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\foriginal owners. In the year 1983, compensation was paid to 686 land\n\nowners. In 1984, again the appellant made a representation to the Collector\n\nof Ratnagiri for release of the land. On 20.7.1989 a Committee was\n\nappointed by the Legislative Assembly for consideration of the proposal for\n\nhanding back the acquired land to the original owners.               Certain\n\nrecommendations were made by the said Committee. On 20.8.1992 the land\n\nacquired for Balco was allotted to another industrial group. Subsequently,\n\nthe State Government asked the industrial group not to continue the\n\nconstruction activities in view of pendency of cases. On 12.11.2002,\n\nrepresentations were again made to hand back the land not utilized. It was\n\nthe specific stand of the appellant that in view of Section 39(2a) of the\n\nMaharashtra Industrial Development Act, 1961 (in short the `Act') the land\n\nshould be restored. The High Court dismissed the writ petition on the\n\nground that it was highly belated.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the appellant stated that\n\nthe appellant was all through representing to the authorities and because of\n\nthe recommendations by the Committee, the appellant waited for some time\n\nand ultimately when no worthwhile action was taken, he filed the writ\n\npetition.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">\f5.    Learned counsel for the respondent on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment of the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">6.    It is pointed out that the recommendations made in terms of the\n\nresolution were not accepted by the Government. It was decided that since\n\ndefinite policy has been formulated the land is to be utilized for the\n\nindustrial development, the same cannot be surrendered to the original\n\nowners for cultivation purposes. It is also pointed out that the so called\n\nrepresentations do not in any way assist the appellant to explain the long\n\ndelay in filing the writ petition.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">7.    It is also pointed out that Section 39(2a) is applicable only in respect\n\nof the undeveloped land, and in the instant case the land in question is\n\ndeveloped land.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">8.    Delay or laches is one of the factors which is to be borne in mind by\n\nthe High Courts when they exercise their discretionary powers under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_1\">Article\n\n226</a> of the Constitution of India, 1950 (in short the `Constitution'). In an\n\nappropriate case the High Court may refuse to invoke its extraordinary\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                     4</span>\n\fpowers if there is such negligence or omission on the part of the applicant to\n\nassert his right as taken in conjunction with the lapse of time and other\n\ncircumstances, causes prejudice to the opposite party. Even where\n\nfundamental right is involved the matter is still within the discretion of the\n\nCourt as pointed out in <a href=\"/doc/124778/\" id=\"a_2\">Durga Prasad v. Chief Controller of Imports and\n\nExports</a> (AIR 1970 SC 769). Of course, the discretion has to be exercised\n\njudicially and reasonably.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">9.    What was stated in this regard by Sir Barnes Peacock in Lindsay\n\nPetroleum Company v. Prosper Armstrong Hurde etc. (1874) 5 PC 221 at\n\npage 239 was approved by this Court in <a href=\"/doc/96294865/\" id=\"a_3\">Moon Mills Ltd. v. Industrial\n\nCourts</a> (AIR 1967 SC 1450) and <a href=\"/doc/95685/\" id=\"a_4\">Maharashtra State Transport Corporation\n\nv. Balwant Regular Motor Service</a> (AIR 1969 SC 329), Sir Barnes had\n\nstated:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"Now the doctrine of laches in Courts of Equity is not an\n             arbitrary or technical doctrine. Where it would be\n             practically unjust to give a remedy either because the\n             party has, by his conduct done that which might fairly be\n             regarded as equivalent to a waiver of it, or where by his\n             conduct and neglect he has though perhaps not waiving\n             that remedy, yet put the other party in a situation in\n             which it would not be reasonable to place him if the\n             remedy were afterwards to be asserted, in either of these\n             cases, lapse of time and delay are most material. But in\n             every case, if an argument against relief, which\n             otherwise would be just, if founded upon mere delay,\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                     5</span>\n\f             that delay of course not amounting to a bar by any statute\n             of limitation, the validity of that defence must be tried\n             upon     principles      substantially    equitable.  Two\n             circumstances always important in such cases are, the\n             length of the delay and the nature of the acts done during\n             the interval which might affect either party and cause a\n             balance of justice or injustice in taking the one course or\n             the other, so far as relates to the remedy.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_21\">10.   It would be appropriate to note certain decisions of this Court in\n\nwhich this aspect has been dealt with in relation with <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_5\">Article 32</a> of the\n\nConstitution. It is apparent that what has been stated as regards that Article\n\nwould apply, a fortiori, to <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_6\">Article 226.</a> It was observed in <a href=\"/doc/148092167/\" id=\"a_7\">R.N Bose v.\n\nUnion of India</a> (AIR 1970 SC 470) that no relief can be given to the\n\npetitioner who without any reasonable explanation approaches this Court\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_8\">Article 32</a> after inordinate delay. It was stated that though <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_9\">Article 32</a>\n\nis itself a guaranteed right, it does not follow from this that it was the\n\nintention of the Constitution makers that this Court should disregard all\n\nprinciples and grant relief in petitions filed after inordinate delay.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">11.   It was stated in <a href=\"/doc/320843/\" id=\"a_10\">State of M.P. v. Nandlal</a> (AIR 1987 SC 251) that the\n\nHigh Court in exercise of its discretion does not ordinarily assist the tardy\n\nand the indolent or the acquiescent and the lethargic. If there is inordinate\n\ndelay on the part of the petitioner and such delay is not satisfactorily\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                      6</span>\n\fexplained, the High Court may decline to intervene and grant relief in\n\nexercise of its writ jurisdiction. It was stated that this rule is premised on a\n\nnumber of factors. The High Court does not ordinarily permit a belated\n\nresort to the extraordinary remedy because it is likely to cause confusion\n\nand public inconvenience and bring in its trail new injustices, and if writ\n\njurisdiction is exercised after unreasonable delay, it may have the effect of\n\ninflicting not only hardship and inconvenience but also injustice on third\n\nparties. It was pointed out that when writ jurisdiction is invoked,\n\nunexplained delay coupled with the creation of third party rights in the\n\nmeantime is an important factor which also weighs with the High Court in\n\ndeciding whether or not to exercise such jurisdiction.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">12.   In view of the aforesaid position we are not inclined to interfere in\n\nthis appeal which is dismissed accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                         .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                         (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                         .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">                                         (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 28, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                     7</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":2,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"disciplinary committee","formInput":"disciplinary%20committee"},{"value":"bias is biased","formInput":"bias%20is%20biased"},{"value":"\"bias\"","formInput":"%22bias%22"}],"citeList":[{"tid":634160,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=9262","title":"Ashok Kumar Yadav And Ors. Kureshi vs High Court Of Gujarat &amp; Anr on 27 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: K.G. Balakrishnan, P. Sathasivam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                          IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n               CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n                CIVIL APPEAL NO. 472 of 2009\n          (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 676 of 2007)\n\n\nA.U. Kureshi                                             ... Appellant\n                           Versus\n\n\nHigh Court of Gujarat &amp; Another                      ... Respondents\n\n\n                         ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">     Leave granted.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_2\">     The present appeal has been filed against the impugned\norder of the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad, dated July\n25, 2006 which was passed in Special Civil Application No.\n6164 of 2002, whereby the High Court has dismissed the said\napplication.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_3\">FACTS :\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">     The appellant was a Judicial Officer who joined the\nGujarat Judicial Service in 1991 and was posted as Civil\nJudge (Junior Division) at the District Court, Bharuch. The\nHigh Court of Gujarat (respondent) received a complaint\nwherein it was alleged that a case bearing Criminal Case No.\n\f2059/89 under the <a href=\"/doc/1824663/\" id=\"a_1\">Gambling Act</a> was listed for hearing in the\nappellant's Court and that the appellant had acquitted the\naccused and also returned the money seized from the accused\nfrom the scene of occurrence. On the basis of this complaint\nthe respondent issued a charge-sheet to the appellant and the\nappellant submitted his reply. A departmental inquiry was\ninitiated against the appellant and the concerned Inquiry\nofficer submitted his report to the High Court of Gujarat\nstating that the charges levelled against the appellant had\nbeen proved. On the basis of this report, a show-cause notice\nwas issued to the appellant. The appellant filed his reply to\nthis show-cause notice. Dissatisfied with the appellant's reply,\nthe High Court decided that it would be appropriate to dismiss\nthe appellant from service. By letter dated October 25, 2001,\nthe High Court of Gujarat recommended to the State\nGovernment that the appellant be dismissed from service and\naccordingly an order was passed.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_5\">     The   appellant,   being   aggrieved,   filed   Special   Civil\nApplication No. 6164 of 2002 before the High Court of Gujarat\nat Ahmedabad, which has been dismissed by the impugned\norder.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">     Hence, this appeal by grant of special leave.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                2</span>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\f     The learned counsel for the appellant has submitted\nbefore us that one of the members of the Disciplinary\nCommittee of the High Court of Gujarat which dealt with the\nappellant's appeal was one of the judges on the bench which\nheard Special Civil Application No. 6164 of 2002 on the\njudicial side. This fact has not been contested by the learned\ncounsel appearing for the respondents.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">     In view of this, it is our opinion that the learned judge\nwho was part of the Disciplinary Committee which suggested\nthe appellant's dismissal should not have later heard the\nmatter on the judicial side. In the present case, the\nDisciplinary   Committee     had   suggested    the   appellant's\ndismissal on the basis of which the High Court of Gujarat\nmade    the    subsequent    recommendation      to   the   State\ngovernment.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_9\">     The decision made by the Disciplinary Committee was a\nvital component of the process by which the High Court of\nGujarat made the recommendation to the State government\nfor the dismissal of the appellant. It is therefore not proper for\na member of the said Disciplinary Committee to decide on a\nchallenge against the same dismissal order while acting in a\npurely judicial capacity.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                              3</span>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\f     It is an accepted principle of natural justice that a person\nshould not be a judge in his or her own cause. In common\nlaw, this principle has been derived from the Latin maxim -\n`nemo debet esse judex in propria sua causa'. A reasonable\npermutation of this principle is that no judge should\nadjudicate a dispute which he or she has dealt with in any\ncapacity, other than a purely judicial one. The failure to\nadhere to this principle creates an apprehension of bias on\npart of the said judge. It would be useful to refer to the\nobservations of Justice P.N. Bhagwati in <a href=\"/doc/634160/\" id=\"a_2\">Ashok Kumar Yadav\nv. State of Haryana</a>, (1985) 4 SCC 417:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">           \"One of the fundamental principles of our\n      jurisprudence is that no man can be a judge in his\n      own cause. The question is not whether the judge is\n      actually biased or has in fact decided partially but\n      whether the circumstances are such as to create a\n      reasonable apprehension in the mind of others that\n      there is a likelihood of bias affecting the decision. If\n      there is a reasonable likelihood of bias `it is in\n      accordance with natural justice and common sense\n      that the judge likely to be so biased should be\n      incapacitated from sitting'. The basic principle\n      underlying this rule is that justice must not only be\n      done but must also appear to be done.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                 4</span>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\f     Accordingly, we accept this appeal, set aside the\nimpugned order of the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad\nand remit the case to the High Court to decide it afresh in\naccordance with law.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_12\">                                 ..................................CJ I\n                                 [ K.G. BALAKRISHNAN ]\n\n\n\n\n                                  .................................. J.\n                                 [ P. SATHASIVAM ]\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 27, 2009.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                  5</span>\n\f"}, Karam Payaswami Tewar vs State Of Maharashtra on 21 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-21","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":107227500,"url":"http://bombayhighcourt.nic.in/generatenew.php?path=.%2Fdata%2Fjudgements%2F2012%2F&fname=CRAPEAL43006.pdf&smflag=N","title":"Biru
