India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33535","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Shiva Karam Payaswami Tewar vs State Of Maharashtra on 21 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n               CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n               CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.                  OF 2009\n               (Arising out of S.L.P. (Crl.) No.1700 of 2008\n\n\n\nShiva Karam Payaswami Tewari                             ...Appellant\n\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of Maharashtra                                     ...Respondent\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nBombay High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant for the\n\noffence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 302</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1542359/\" id=\"a_2\">321</a> and <a href=\"/doc/386021/\" id=\"a_3\">201</a> of the Indian Penal\n\fCode, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_4\">IPC</a>') and sentence of life, nine months and nine\n\nmonths respectively and fine with default stipulation.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      The accused Shiva Karam Payaswami Tewar was working in Hotel\n\nPremier run by the complainant Anthony Xavier at Dharavi, Mumbai-70.\n\nThe accused was entrusted with the work of preparation of spices.\n\nMuttukumar (hereinafter referred to as the `deceased') was working as a\n\nmanager in the said hotel. Considering the nature of their work the accused\n\nas well as Muttukumar used to stay overnight in the hotel.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      On 31.8.1995 in the evening complainant Anthony Xavier went to the\n\nHotel Premier and after usual supervision and talk with manager at night he\n\nreturned. At that time the accused as well as Muttukumar were in the hotel.\n\nOn the next day morning i.e. on 1.9.1995 one Murugan Shetiya working in\n\nthe hotel went to Anthony (PW-1) and told him that the hotel is open and\n\nMuttukumar and accused are not present in the hotel. He also informed that\n\ncash drawer was open and tape recorder was found missing. Naturally,\n\ncomplainant Anthony immediately went to the hotel. When he was making\n\nquery, Arun Pujari, who was running Pan bidi shop near the hotel and taxi\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\fdriver Suresh Kumar who often used to park his taxi near the hotel told him\n\nthat accused met them at about 5.30 a.m., and made enquiry about the bus\n\ngoing to Bangalore. When complainant took survey of the hotel he found\n\nthat cash box was open and tape recorder kept in the hotel was missing.\n\nThere was no cash in the cash box. According to him on the previous night\n\nthe manager i.e. deceased had informed him that on that day amount of\n\nRs.3500/- was collected and the same was kept in the cash box. Report was\n\nlodged with the police and investigation was undertaken. Appellant was\n\nsuspected to be the murderer.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      After completion of investigation charge-sheet was filed. Since the\n\naccused pleaded innocence, trial was held. Though there was no direct\n\nevidence the Trial Court held that the circumstantial evidences adduced by\n\nthe prosecution were sufficient. Particular reference was made to the extra-\n\njudicial confession made before PW-1. Accordingly, conviction was\n\nrecorded by the Trial Court. Appellant filed appeal before the High Court\n\nwhich upheld the conviction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      Before the High Court the stand was that even if the extra judicial\n\nconfession is accepted to be correct for the sake of argument, case under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 302</a> IPC is not made out. The stand of the prosecution was that the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n\fextra-judicial confession clearly showed both the intention and the\n\nknowledge. Accordingly, the High Court dismissed the appeal. The stand\n\ntaken before the High Court was reiterated by the parties. In addition,\n\nlearned counsel for the appellant submitted that there was no pre-meditation\n\nand in the course of quarrel, a wooden log which was lying was picked up\n\nby the appellant in a heat of passion and assault was made. Only one blow\n\nwas given and, therefore, <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 302</a> IPC, in any event, has no application.\n\nIt was submitted that extra-judicial confession is a very weak piece of\n\nevidence and should not have been made the basis for conviction.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">4.    We shall first deal with the question regarding claim of extra judicial\n\nconfession. Though it is not necessary that the witness should speak the\n\nexact words but there cannot be vital and material difference. While dealing\n\nwith a stand of extra judicial confession, Court has to satisfy itself that the\n\nsame was voluntary and without any coercion and undue influence. Extra\n\njudicial confession can form the basis of conviction if persons before whom\n\nit is stated to be made appear to be unbiased and not even remotely inimical\n\nto the accused. Where there is material to show animosity, Court has to\n\nproceed cautiously and find out whether confession just like any other\n\nevidence depends on veracity of witness to whom it is made. It is not\n\ninvariable that the Court should not accept such evidence if actual words as\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                     4</span>\n\fclaimed to have been spoken are not reproduced and the substance is given.\n\nIt will depend on circumstance of the case. If substance itself is sufficient to\n\nprove culpability and there is no ambiguity about import of the statement\n\nmade by accused, evidence can be acted upon even though substance and\n\nnot actual words have been stated. Human mind is not a tape recorder which\n\nrecords what has been spoken word by word. The witness should be able to\n\nsay as nearly as possible actual words spoken by the accused. That would\n\nrule out possibility of erroneous interpretation of any ambiguous statement.\n\nIf word by word repetition of statement of the case is insisted upon, more\n\noften than not evidentiary value of extra judicial confession has to be\n\nthrown out as unreliable and not useful. That cannot be a requirement in\n\nlaw. There can be some persons who have a good memory and may be able\n\nto repost exact words and there may he many who are possessed of normal\n\nmemory and do so. It is for the Court to judge credibility of the witness's\n\ncapacity and thereafter to decide whether his or her evidence has to be\n\naccepted or not. If Court believes witnesses before whom confession is\n\nmade and is satisfied that confession was voluntary basing on such\n\nevidence, conviction can be founded. Such confession should be clear,\n\nspecific and unambiguous.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                      5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">\f5.    The expression `confession' is not defined in the <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_7\">Evidence Act</a>,\n\n`Confession' is a statement made by an accused which must either admit in\n\nterms the offence, or at any rate substantially all the facts which constitute\n\nthe offence. The dictionary meaning of the word `statement' is \"act of\n\nstating; that which is stated; a formal account, declaration of facts etc.\" The\n\nword `statement' includes both oral and written statement. Communication\n\nto another is not however an essential component to constitute a `statement'.\n\nAn accused might have been over-heard uttering to himself or saying to his\n\nwife or any other person in confidence. He might have also uttered\n\nsomething in soliloquy. He might also keep a note in writing. All the\n\naforesaid nevertheless constitute a statement. It such statement is an\n\nadmission of guilt, it would amount to a confession whether it is\n\ncommunicated to another or not. This very question came up for\n\nconsideration before this Court in <a href=\"/doc/1643745/\" id=\"a_8\">Sahoo v. State of Uttar Pradesh</a>, AIR\n\n1966 SC 40: (1966 Cr1 U 68). After referring to some passages written by\n\nwell known authors on the \"Law of Evidence\" Subba Rao, J. (as he then\n\nwas) held that \"communication is not a necessary ingredient to constitute\n\nconfession\". In paragraph 5 of the judgment, this Court held as follows:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             ...Admissions and confessions are exceptions to the\n             hearsay rule. <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_9\">The Evidence Act</a> places them in the\n             category of relevant evidence presumably on the ground\n             that as they are declarations against the interest of the\n             person making them, they are probably true. The\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n\f            probative value of an admission or a confession goes not\n            to depend upon its communication to another, though,\n            just like any other piece of evidence, it can be admitted\n            in evidence only on proof. This proof in the case of oral\n            admission or confession can be offered only by witnesses\n            who heard the admission pr confession. as the case may\n            be.... If, as we have said, statement is the genus and\n            confession is only a sub-species of that genus, we do not\n            see any reason why the statement implied in the\n            confession should be given a different meaning. We,\n            therefore, hold that a statement, whether communicated\n            or not, admitting guilt is a confession of guilt\n\n                                   (Emphasis supplied)\n\n\n\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_17\">6.    The extra-judicial confession purported to have been made before\n\nPW1 reads as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                   \"He was brought to the hotel in a taxi. In enquired\n            with the accd. what he did to Muttukumar. The accd.\n            disclosed that he and Muttukumar got up at about 4.30\n            a.m. and while he was preparing spices there was quarrel\n            between them; and as a result of the quarrel he had hit\n            Muttukumar with a wooden log used for cutting\n            vegetables and Muttukumar had died of the injuries\n            sustained during the assault.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_19\">7.    In the instant case the extra-judicial confession is believable as rightly\n\ndone by the Trial Court and the High Court. The same not was made to a\n\nstranger but to a friend. Therefore, the Trial Court and the High Court have\n\nrightly acted upon the extra-judicial confession.      At the same time the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                     7</span>\n\fbackground in which the assault has been made clearly shows that <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_10\">Section\n\n302</a> IPC has no application. The assault was made in the course of sudden\n\nquarrel without pre-meditation. The accused was not armed at the relevant\n\npoint of time. Even according to prosecution he picked up the wooden log\n\nwhich was lying there and made the assault.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">8.    That being the position, we alter the conviction to <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 304</a> Part II\n\nIPC. Custodial sentence of 8 years would meet the ends of justice. The\n\nappeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">9.    We record our appreciation for the able manner in which Mr. Nirmal\n\nChopra, Amicus Curiae, assisted the Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                         .........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                         (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                         ...........................................J.\n                                         (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 21, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                     8</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":1,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"scheduled caste","formInput":"scheduled%20caste"},{"value":"port blair","formInput":"port%20blair"}],"citeList":[{"tid":68762,"url":null,"title":"Article 341 in The Constitution Of India   1949"}],"covers":[],"title":"Union Of India & Ors vs Shantiranjan Sarkar on 13 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-13","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":69942083,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=350","title":"Suman Sharma @ Suman Dutt vs State Of Punjab And Others on 24 May, 2013"},{"tid":55468966,"url":null,"title":"Sh. Chaman Lal vs Municipal Corporation Of Delhi on 13 January, 2010"},{"tid":97523308,"url":null,"title":"Smt. Vimla Gupta vs Municipal Corporation Of Delhi ... on 2 September, 2009"},{"tid":134736556,"url":null,"title":"Nitin Chadha vs Union Of India Through Its ... on 8 March, 2010"},{"tid":56152855,"url":null,"title":"T.M. Sampath & Others vs The Secretary on 8 February, 2010"}],"tid":1039413,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"s","lastname":"sinha","numcitedby":30,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33501","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Union Of India &amp; Ors vs Shantiranjan Sarkar on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: S Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                   CIVIL APPEAL NO. _______OF 2009\n\n                 (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 23770 of 2005)\n\n\n\nUnion of India &amp; Ors.                                    .... Appellants\n\n            Versus\n\nShantiranjan Sarkar                                      .... Respondent\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. SINHA, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Appellants are before us aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the\n\njudgment and order dated 11.04.2005 passed by a Division Bench of the\n\nHigh Court of Calcutta, Circuit Bench at Port Blair whereby and\n\nwhereunder the writ petition filed by the respondent herein was allowed.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        2</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.       The basic fact of the matter is not in dispute.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">         An advertisement was issued for filling up the post of Postman/ Mail\n\nGuard under the quota of Extra-departmental candidate at Andaman and\n\nNicobar Island, Port Blair.        Respondent herein pursuant thereto or in\n\nfurtherance thereof applied for the said post. He appeared at an examination\n\nheld for the said purpose. On or about 18.11.1997, the purported results of\n\nthe said examination were published with the remarks \"none qualified\".\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.       Subsequently, some other examinations were also held in which the\n\nrespondent participated. Indisputably, he was a member of the Scheduled\n\nCaste.     He filed several representations before the concerned various\n\nauthorities contending that his candidature had not been considered despite\n\nthe fact that he had obtained more than 30% of marks which was the cut-off\n\nmark for the members of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. As\n\nthe said representations were not responded to, he filed an original\n\napplication before the Central Administrative Tribunal, Calcutta Bench,\n\nKolkata. The said original application was dismissed on 12.9.2003 on the\n\nground of limitation as also on merit, stating:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">               \"Considering the respective contentions of the ld.\n               Counsels for both sides, we find that the applicant\n               having not been qualified in the written test as\n               well as in the interview does not acquire any legal\n               or enforceable right to seek employment for the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                        3</span>\n\n\n                 post. In the result, the application is dismissed\n                 without any order as to cost.\"\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">\n\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_9\">5.         Respondent filed a writ petition before the High Court questioning\n\nthe legality and/or validity of the said judgment and order which was\n\nmarked as WP CT No. 194 of 2003. The said writ petition was initially\n\ndismissed on 9.7.2004 by a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court,\n\nstating:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">                 \"Therefore, although, we do not approve the\n                 reason assigned by the Tribunal, we are not\n                 inclined to entertain this application as the\n                 ultimate conclusion of the Tribunal that the\n                 petitioner was not entitled to get any relief was\n                 correct. As indicated above, the Tribunal ought to\n                 have rejected the application only on the ground of\n                 limitation.\"\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">\n\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_10\">6.         However, a review application filed thereagainst was allowed. By\n\nreason of the impugned judgment dated 11.04.2005, the High Court has\n\nallowed the said writ application.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">7.         Mr. B. Datta, learned Additional Solicitor General appearing on\n\nbehalf of the appellants, would contend:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">     (i)      the High Court committed a serious error insofar as it failed to\n\n              take into consideration that having regard to the fact that the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                        4</span>\n\n\n               respondent failed to pass the tests held in the year 1997 and\n\n               furthermore, having appeared in the subsequent examinations, had\n\n               no right to be appointed and no direction for his appointment in\n\n               the post of Peon or Group `D', thus, could be issued by the High\n\n               Court.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">     (ii)      Respondent having applied against the vacancy in the `OC'\n\n               category and not in the category of `Scheduled Caste', it was\n\n               obligatory on him to obtain the qualifying marks of 45% which he\n\n               having failed to obtain, the impugned judgment is wholly\n\n               unsustainable.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_12\">8.          Mrs. Sarda Devi, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nrespondent, however, would support the impugned judgment.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">9.          Before adverting to the contentions raised before us by the learned\n\ncounsel for the parties, we may notice that the appellants suppressed a\n\nmaterial fact. It appears that the fact that the High Court had recalled its\n\nearlier order dated 9.07.2004 by an order dated 30.11.2004 had not been\n\nmentioned in the list of dates. This Court, therefore, must have proceeded\n\non the basis that the impugned order was passed on a review application and\n\nnot in the original writ proceedings. We do not find appropriate words to\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                    5</span>\n\n\ndeprecate such a practice and that too by the Union of India. We should\n\nhave dismissed the Special Leave Petition on this ground alone.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      Let us, however, also consider the merit of the matter.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">10.   The fact that the respondent is a member of Scheduled Caste is not in\n\ndispute. His name figured at Sl.No. 124 of the seniority list of Dak Sevakas\n\nin A &amp; N Islands Divisions, Port Blair. It has not been denied or disputed\n\nbefore us that in Central Administrative Services, a person belonging to\n\nScheduled Caste in any State would be deemed to be a member of the\n\nScheduled Caste.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">      Respondent, therefore, should have been treated to be a member of\n\n`Schedule Caste' for the purpose of consideration of his candidature.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">11.   The High Court in its impugned order categorically held that the\n\nappellants at no point of time denied or disputed that the respondent had\n\nobtained marks more than 30% but less than 45%.            The High Court\n\nfurthermore noticed that the notification dated 9.06.1989 issued by the\n\nDirector of Postal Services, A &amp; N Islands in categorical terms stated that\n\nhis status of the Scheduled Castes should be accepted and recognized in the\n\ndepartment examination. A member of a Scheduled Caste, thus, notified in\n\nany of the States within the territories of India, having regard to the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                    6</span>\n\n\nprovisions contained in <a href=\"/doc/68762/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 341</a> of the Constitution, was entitled to get\n\nthe benefit of the said status for the purpose of entering into Central Civil\n\nService..\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">12.   The High Court furthermore has rightly held that as a member of the\n\nScheduled Caste, the respondent was entitled to the benefit of the lower\n\npercentage of marks, viz., 30% in the departmental examination for\n\npromotion from the post of Extra-Departmental Mail Guard to the Post of\n\nPeon or Group `D'.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">13.   If, thus, for the reasons known to the respondent that he was entitled\n\nto the benefit of the status of the Scheduled Caste in the Andaman and\n\nNicobar Islands, irrespective of the fact that the advertisement issued\n\nrecognized only two categories of reserve categories, viz., Scheduled Tribes\n\nand `OC', there was no reason to deprive the respondent from the said\n\nbenefit. Respondent, therefore, was not appointed because of a mistake\n\ncommitted on the part of the authorities of the appellants. They, thus,\n\ncannot be permitted to take advantage of the same.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">14.   In that view of the matter, the delay in filing the original application\n\nshould not be held to be a bar in granting him an equitable relief. Union of\n\nIndia as a benevolent litigant cannot be permitted to take advantage of its\n\nown wrong.     Furthermore, the appellants are guilty of suppression of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                      7</span>\n\n\nmaterial facts before this Court. It, in its list of dates, did not state that the\n\noriginal order of the High Court dated 9.07.2004 had been recalled and\n\nreviewed by the Division of the said Court by an order dated 30.10.2004.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">15.   For the reasons aforementioned, the impugned judgment should not\n\nbe interfered with and is directed accordingly. The appeal is dismissed with\n\ncosts. Counsel's fee assessed at Rs.1,00,000/-.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                                          ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                          (S.B. Sinha)\n\n\n\n                                          ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                          (J.M. Panchal)\nNew Delhi\nJANUARY 13, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":15,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"dowry death","formInput":"dowry%20death"},{"value":"304-b","formInput":"304-b"},{"value":"sec code","formInput":"section%20304%20of%20indian%20penal%20code"}],"citeList":[{"tid":653797,"url":null,"title":"Section 304B in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1763444,"url":null,"title":"the Dowry 1961"},{"tid":1023340,"url":null,"title":"Section 4 in the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961"}],"covers":[],"title":"Prem Kumar vs State Of Rajasthan on 7 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-07","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":1239391,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/AK/judgement/16-08-2011/AK11082011CRLA8042001.pdf","title":"Sapan Haldar & Anr. vs The State on 11 August, 2011"},{"tid":108205339,"url":null,"title":"State vs Furkan S/O Mohd. Hisaq on 27 November, 2010"},{"tid":35547217,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/AK/judgement/17-09-2010/AK09092010CRLMP3132010.pdf","title":"State Of Nct Of Delhi vs Javed @ Sonu & Another on 9 September, 2010"},{"tid":89508186,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/MUG/judgement/01-03-2011/MUG04022011CRLA2702001.pdf","title":"Yaswant Kumar vs State on 4 February, 2011"},{"tid":1246251,"url":"http://courtnic.nic.in/jodh/judfile.asp?ID=CW&nID=7274&yID=2010&doj=8%2F10%2F2010","title":"Prem Kumar vs State Of Raj. & Ors on 10 August, 2010"}],"tid":488831,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":10,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33463","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Prem Kumar vs State Of Rajasthan on 7 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELALTE JURISDICTION\n\n                     CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 58 OF 2002\n\n\n\n\nPrem Kanwar                                      ....Appellant\n\n                                 Versus\n\nState of Rajasthan                                      ....Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a learned Single Judge\n\nof the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur allowing the appeal filed by the\n\nState of Rajasthan questioning correctness of the judgment of acquittal\n\npassed by a learned Sessions Judge, Sriganganagar. The appellant and two\n\nothers faced trial for alleged commission of offence punishable under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 306</a> and <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_2\">304</a> Part-B of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the\n\f`<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">IPC</a>') and <a href=\"/doc/1023340/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 4</a> of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 (in short `<a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_5\">Dowry\n\nProhibition Act</a>').\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">2.    Prosecution version unfolded during trial is as follows:-\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">      On 23-04-1988 at about 2.05 p.m., the accused Krishnalal lodged an\n\noral report Ex.P/12 before Jagmalram (PW-11) SHO, Police Station Purani\n\nAbadi, Sri Ganganagar stating inter-alia that he was married with Smt. Raju,\n\n(hereinafter referred to as the deceased) in the year 1984 and his father had\n\nalready died before 15 years back and since then he was living with his\n\nmother Prem Kanwar, the present appellant and uncle Puran Chand and he\n\nwas not in service and thus was unemployed. On that day, he went out from\n\nhis house for some work and when he returned back at about 1.30 p.m. he\n\nfound crowd near his house and also found fire in his house and people\n\nwere extinguishing the fire and he came to know that his wife, the deceased\n\nwas burnt and had died and, therefore, he had come to inform the police.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">      On this report, police registered the FIR No. 7/88 and started\n\ninvestigation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">      During investigation, postmortem of the dead body of the deceased\n\nwas got conducted and the post mortem report is Ex. P/3, where the doctors\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                           2</span>\n\fopined that the cause of the death of the deceased was asphyxia due to ante-\n\nmortem burns.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">      When the investigation in FIR No. 7/88 was going on, PW 1 Bachna\n\nRam, father of the deceased, lodged a written report Ex. P/1 on 26-4-1988\n\nbefore police station Purani Abadi, Sri Ganganagar stating inter-alia that all\n\nthe three accused have murdered his daughter (deceased) by burning her and\n\nhe had also come to know that a report was also lodged on behalf of the\n\naccused stating therein that the deceased had committed suicide, but the fact\n\nwas that all the three accused have killed her. It was further stated in the\n\nreport that all the three accused used to harass and torture her as she was an\n\nilliterate lady and accused no 1 Krishnalal (husband of the deceased) was an\n\neducated person and accused used to say that in dowry nothing was given to\n\nthem and thus, they used to torture, harass and humiliate her. It was further\n\nstated in the report that action be taken against the accused for killing her\n\ndaughter (deceased) by burning.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">      On this report, police chalked out FIR Ex. P/2 for the offence u/Ss.\n\n306, 304 B <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_6\">IPC</a> and started investigation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">      After usual investigation, police submitted challan against the\n\naccused respondents for the offence u/Ss. 306, 304 B <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_7\">IPC</a> in the court of\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                          3</span>\n\fmagistrate holding inter alia that it was a case of dowry death. Thereafter,\n\nthe case was committed to the Court of Session.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">      As the accused persons denied the allegations trial was held. Eleven\n\nwitnesses were examined to establish the accusations. Learned Sessions\n\nJudge directed acquittal inter-alia holding as follows:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">      1.    That it is a case of suicide by the deceased.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      2.     That death of the deceased was caused due to burning\n             and has taken place within seven years of the marriage.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">     3.      That Bachnaram (PW.l) father of the deceased took the\n             deceased to his house at the time of marriage of his son\n             and kept the deceased in his house for 12 months and\n             during that period nobody came from her-in-laws' house\n             to take her back.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">     4.      That at the time of marriage of son of Rairam (PW-4),\n             Bachnaram (PW-1) and PW.4 went to the house of her\n             in-laws to take deceased where accused Prem Kanwar\n             (mother-in-law of the deceased) expressed her\n             displeasure and told that deceased be taken away by\n             them and her clothes were thrown away.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">      5.     That above facts were admitted by the learned Sessions\n             Judge at pages 19 and 20 of his impugned judgment.\n             However, he observed that this statement of accused\n             Prem Kanwar (mother-in-law of the deceased) is to some\n             extent objectionable, but no case of dowry death or\n             abetment of suicide is made from this part of her\n             statement.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">      6.     That prosecution has not been able to prove its case\n             beyond all reasonable doubts against the accused\n             respondents for the offence under <a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_8\">Sections 306</a> and <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_9\">304B</a>\n             IPC and <a href=\"/doc/1023340/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 4</a> of the Dowry Prohibition Act.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                        4</span>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\f      It is to be noted that the three accused persons were related to the\n\ndeceased in the following manner:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      Krishnalal is the husband of he deceased, Puran Chand is the Uncle-\n\nin-law and Prem Kanwar, the present appellant is the mother-in-law.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">      The High Court found that the conclusion of the trial Court that the\n\ncase was one of suicide was not established. The High Court found that the\n\npossibility that before burning the deceased was murdered was clear from\n\nthe evidence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">3.    Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that considering the\n\nlimited nature of the scope of interference in a matter of acquittal, the High\n\nCourt ought not to have interfered, particularly, when it found that the\n\nacquittal was in order so far as the other co-accused persons are concerned.\n\nIt was submitted that the High Court's conclusion that the skull bones were\n\nbroken, which rules out the case of suicide, is contrary to medical evidence.\n\nThe High Court noted that to bring in application of <a href=\"/doc/1439698/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 304</a> Part B, it\n\nis immaterial whether the death is suicidal or homicidal.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                          5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">\f4.    With reference to the evidence of Dhanni Devi (PW-5) it was\n\nsubmitted that her evidence was not sufficient to fasten the guilt on the\n\nappellant.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">5.    In response, learned counsel for the respondent-State supported the\n\njudgment of the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">6.    In order to attract <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 304B</a> IPC, the following ingredients are to\n\nbe satisfied.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">         i)     The death of a woman must have been caused by\n\n         burns or bodily injury or otherwise than under normal\n\n         circumstances.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">         ii)    Such death must have occurred within 7 years of the\n\n         marriage.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">         iii)   Soon before her death, the woman must have been\n\n         subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or any\n\n         relative of her husband; and\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">         iv)    Such cruelty or harassment must be in connection with\n\n         the demand of dowry.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                        6</span>\n\f<a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_13\">Sections 304B</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 498A</a> read as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">      \"304-B. Dowry Death- (1) Where the death of a woman\n      is caused by any burns or bodily injury or occurs\n      otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven\n      years of her marriage and it is shown that soon before\n      her death she was subjected to cruelty or harassment by\n      her husband or any relative of her husband for, or in\n      connection with any demand for dowry, such death shall\n      be called \"dowry death\" and such husband or relative\n      shall be deemed to have caused her death.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">      Explanation - For the purpose of this sub-section\n      `dowry' shall have same meaning as in <a href=\"/doc/1249134/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 2</a> of the\n      Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 (28 of 1961).\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">      (2) Whoever commits dowry death shall be punished\n      with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less\n      than seven years but which may extend to imprisonment\n      for life.\"\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">      \"498-A: Husband or relative of husband of a woman\n      subjecting her to cruelty- Whoever, being the husband\n      or the relative of the husband of a woman, subjects such\n      woman to cruelty shall be punished with imprisonment\n      for a term which may extend to three years and shall also\n      be liable to fine.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">      Explanation - For the purpose of this section `cruelty'\n      means -</blockquote><p id=\"p_30\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">      (a) any wilful conduct which is of such a nature as is\n      likely to drive the woman to commit suicide or to cause\n      grave injury or danger to life, limb or health (whether\n      mental or physical) of the woman; or\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                  7</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">\f             (b) harassment of the woman where such harassment\n             is with a view to coercing her or any person related to\n             her to meet any unlawful demand for any property or\n             valuable security or is on account of failure by her or\n             any person related to her to meet such demand.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">7.    The term \"dowry\" has been defined in <a href=\"/doc/1249134/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 2</a> of the Dowry\n\nProhibition Act, 1961 (in short `<a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_17\">Dowry Act</a>') as under:-\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">             \"<a href=\"/doc/1249134/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 2</a>. Definition of `dowry' - In this Act, `dowry'\n             means any property or valuable security given or agreed\n             to be given either directly or indirectly -\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_13\">                   (a) by one party to a marriage to the other party\n                   to the marriage; or\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_14\">                   (b) by the parents of either party to a marriage\n                   or by any other person, to either party to the\n                   marriage or to any other person,\n\n             at or before or any time after the marriage in connection\n             with the marriage of the said parties, but does not\n             include dower or mehr in the case of persons to whom\n             the Muslim personal law (Shariat) applies.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_15\">             Explanation I- For the removal of doubts, it is hereby\n             declared that any presents made at the time of a marriage\n             to either party to the marriage in the form of cash,\n             ornaments, clothes or other articles, shall not be deemed\n             to be dowry within the meaning of this section, unless\n             they are made as consideration for the marriage of the\n             said parties.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_16\">             Explanation II- The expression `valuable security' has\n             the same meaning in <a href=\"/doc/1320984/\" id=\"a_19\">Section 30</a> of the Indian Penal\n             Code (45 of 1860).\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                                         8</span>\n<p id=\"p_35\">\f8.    Explanation to <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 304-B</a> refers to dowry \"as having the same\n\nmeaning as in <a href=\"/doc/1249134/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 2</a> of the Act\", the question is : what is the periphery\n\nof the dowry as defined therein ? The argument is, there has to be an\n\nagreement at the time of the marriage in view of the words \"agreed to be\n\ngiven\" occurring therein, and in the absence of any such evidence it would\n\nnot constitute to be a dowry. It is noticeable, as this definition by\n\namendment includes not only the period before and at the marriage but also\n\nthe period subsequent to the marriage. This position was highlighted in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/60202/\" id=\"a_22\">Pawan Kumar and Ors. v. State of Haryana</a> (1998 (3) SCC 309).\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">9.    The offence alleged against the accused is under <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_23\">Section 304-B</a> IPC\n\nwhich makes \"demand of dowry\" itself punishable. Demand neither\n\nconceives nor would conceive of any agreement. If for convicting any\n\noffender, agreement for dowry is to be proved, hardly any offenders would\n\ncome under the clutches of law. When <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_24\">Section 304-B</a> refers to \"demand of\n\ndowry\", it refers to the demand of property or valuable security as referred\n\nto in the definition of \"dowry\" under the Act. The argument that there is no\n\ndemand of dowry, in the present case, has no force. In cases of dowry deaths\n\nand suicides, circumstantial evidence plays an important role and inferences\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                                        9</span>\n\fcan be drawn on the basis of such evidence. That could be either direct or\n\nindirect. It is significant that <a href=\"/doc/1023340/\" id=\"a_25\">Section 4</a> of the Act, was also amended by\n\nmeans of Act 63 of 1984, under which it is an offence to demand dowry\n\ndirectly or indirectly from the parents or other relatives or guardian of a\n\nbride. The word \"agreement\" referred to in <a href=\"/doc/1249134/\" id=\"a_26\">Section 2</a> has to be inferred on\n\nthe facts and circumstances of each case. The interpretation that the accused\n\nseek, that conviction can only be if there is agreement for dowry, is\n\nmisconceived. This would be contrary to the mandate and object of the Act.\n\n\"Dowry\" definition is to be interpreted with the other provisions of the Act\n\nincluding <a href=\"/doc/751411/\" id=\"a_27\">Section 3</a>, which refers to giving or taking dowry and <a href=\"/doc/1023340/\" id=\"a_28\">Section 4</a>\n\nwhich deals with a penalty for demanding dowry, under the Act and the\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_29\">IPC</a>. This makes it clear that even demand of dowry on other ingredients\n\nbeing satisfied is punishable. It is not always necessary that there be any\n\nagreement for dowry.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_37\">\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">10.   <a href=\"/doc/1906/\" id=\"a_30\">Section 113-B</a> of the Evidence Act is also relevant for the case at\n\nhand. Both <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_31\">Section 304-B</a> IPC and <a href=\"/doc/1906/\" id=\"a_32\">Section 113-B</a> of the Evidence Act were\n\ninserted as noted earlier by the <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_33\">Dowry Prohibition (Amendment) Act</a> 43 of\n\n1986 with a view to combat the increasing menace of dowry deaths. <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_34\">Section\n\n113-B</a> reads as follows:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                                         10</span>\n\f             \"113-B: Presumption as to dowry death- When the\n             question is whether a person has committed the dowry\n             death of a woman and it is shown that soon before her\n             death such woman has been subjected by such person to\n             cruelty or harassment for, or in connection with, any\n             demand for dowry, the Court shall presume that such\n             person had caused the dowry death.\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">             Explanation - For the purposes of this section `dowry\n             death' shall have the same meaning as in <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_35\">Section 304-B</a>\n             of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860).\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_41\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">11.   The necessity for insertion of the two provisions has been amply\n\nanalysed by the Law Commission of India in its 21st Report dated 10th\n\nAugust, 1988 on `Dowry Deaths and Law Reform'. Keeping in view the\n\nimpediment in the pre-existing law in securing evidence to prove dowry\n\nrelated deaths, legislature thought it wise to insert a provision relating to\n\npresumption of dowry death on proof of certain essentials. It is in this\n\nbackground presumptive <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_36\">Section 113-B</a> in the <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_37\">Evidence Act</a> has been\n\ninserted. As per the definition of `dowry death' in <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_38\">Section 304-B</a> IPC and\n\nthe wording in the presumptive <a href=\"/doc/1906/\" id=\"a_39\">Section 113-B</a> of the Evidence Act, one of\n\nthe essential ingredients, amongst others, in both the provisions is that the\n\nconcerned woman must have been \"soon before her death\" subjected to\n\ncruelty or harassment \"for or in connection with the demand of dowry\".\n\nPresumption under <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_40\">Section 113-B</a> is a presumption of law. On proof of the\n\nessentials mentioned therein, it becomes obligatory on the Court to raise a\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                                                         11</span>\n\fpresumption that the accused caused the dowry death. The presumption\n\nshall be raised only on proof of the following essentials:\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_17\">             (1)      The question before the Court must be whether\n\n             the accused has committed the dowry death of a\n\n             woman. (This means that the presumption can be raised\n\n             only if the accused is being tried for the offence under\n\n             <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_41\">Section 304-B</a> IPC).\n</blockquote>\n<pre id=\"pre_2\">             (2)      The woman was subjected to cruelty or\n\n             harassment by her husband or his relatives.\n\n             (3)      Such cruelty or harassment was for, or in\n\n             connection with any demand for dowry.\n\n             (4)      Such cruelty or harassment was soon before her\n\n             death.\n\n\n\n</pre><blockquote id=\"blockquote_18\">12.   A conjoint reading of <a href=\"/doc/1906/\" id=\"a_42\">Section 113-B</a> of the Evidence Act and <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_43\">Section\n\n304-B</a> IPC shows that there must be material to show that soon before her\n\ndeath the victim was subjected to cruelty or harassment. Prosecution has to\n\nrule out the possibility of a natural or accidental death so as to bring it\n\nwithin the purview of the `death occurring otherwise than in normal\n\ncircumstances'.    The expression `soon before' is very relevant where\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                                                                        12</span>\n\f<a href=\"/doc/1906/\" id=\"a_44\">Section 113-B</a> of the Evidence Act and <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_45\">Section 304-B</a> IPC are pressed into\n\nservice. Prosecution is obliged to show that soon before the occurrence\n\nthere was cruelty or harassment and only in that case presumption operates.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_43\">Evidence in that regard has to be led by prosecution. `Soon before' is a\n\nrelative term and it would depend upon circumstances of each case and no\n\nstrait-jacket formula can be laid down as to what would constitute a period\n\nof soon before the occurrence. It would be hazardous to indicate any fixed\n\nperiod, and that brings in the importance of a proximity test both for the\n\nproof of an offence of dowry death as well as for raising a presumption\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1906/\" id=\"a_46\">Section 113-B</a> of the Evidence Act. The expression `soon before her\n\ndeath' used in the substantive <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_47\">Section 304-B</a> IPC and <a href=\"/doc/1906/\" id=\"a_48\">Section 113-B</a> of the\n\nEvidence Act is present with the idea of proximity test. No definite period\n\nhas been indicated and the expression `soon before' is not defined. A\n\nreference to expression `soon before' used in <a href=\"/doc/731516/\" id=\"a_49\">Section 114</a>. Illustration (a) of\n\nthe <a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_50\">Evidence Act</a> is relevant. It lays down that a Court may presume that a\n\nman who is in the possession of goods `soon after' the theft, is either the\n\nthief or has received the goods knowing them to be stolen, unless he can\n\naccount for his possession. The determination of the period which can come\n\nwithin the term `soon before' is left to be determined by the Courts,\n\ndepending upon facts and circumstances of each case. Suffice, however, to\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                                                          13</span>\n\findicate that the expression `soon before' would normally imply that the\n\ninterval should not be much between the concerned cruelty or harassment\n\nand the death in question. There must be existence of a proximate and live-\n\nlink between the effect of cruelty based on dowry demand and the\n\nconcerned death. If alleged incident of cruelty is remote in time and has\n\nbecome stale enough not to disturb mental equilibrium of the woman\n\nconcerned, it would be of no consequence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_44\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">13.   The Medical evidence is found in the statement of Dr. Rajendra\n\nKuinar Gupta. (PW-6). He stated that for conducting the postmortem of the\n\ndead body of the deceased, a Medical Board was constituted on 25-04-1988\n\nand apart from him, Dr. O.P. Sharma and Dr. Avinash Sardana were\n\nmembers of the Board. He further stated that dead body of the deceased was\n\nreceived on 23-04-1988 at about 8.00 p.m. and same was kept on ice and\n\npost mortem of the dead body of the deceased was conducted on 25-04-\n\n1988 and on examination, following aspects were noticed:\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_19\">            1.    That whole body was burnt.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_20\">            2.    That hairs of head of the deceased were totally burnt.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_21\">            3.    That outer portion of the skull had come out.</blockquote><p id=\"p_46\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_47\">            4.    That there were nine bangles and one kada in the Left\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">                                                                           14</span>\n\f                   forearm of the deceased.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_48\">            5.     That bones of skull of the deceased were broken.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_49\">14.   The doctors opined that cause of death of the deceased was Asphyxia\n\ndue to ante mortem burns. He has proved the post mortem report Ex.P/3.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_50\">15.   Thus, from the post mortem report Ex.P/3 and by the statement of Dr.\n\nRajendra Kumar Gupta (PW-6), the fact that deceased died because of burns\n\nis very well established and at the time of post mortem of the dead body of\n\nthe deceased, her skull bones were found broken.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_51\">16.   In the case of burning the fracture of skull is not a necessary corollary\n\nbut in the present case the skull bones were broken. Therefore, the fact\n\nremains that she was killed before death. Therefore, the High Court was\n\njustified in holding that the Sessions Judge erroneously concluded that it\n\nwas a case of suicide.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_52\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_53\">17.   Jasvinder Singh (PW-7) is an independent witness who is neighbour\n\nof the accused. His evidence is of considerable importance. According to\n\nhim, while he was standing at the place where the deceased was burning the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                                                                          15</span>\n\fwitness told Ramdev for extinguishing the fire upon which the appellant\n\nsaid that the deceased has been burnt and let her burn and it is no use\n\nextinguishing the fire. This statement has been rightly highlighted by the\n\nHigh Court to show that her role as alleged by the prosecution has been\n\nestablished.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_54\">18.   The principles which would govern and regulate the hearing of appeal\n\nby the High Court against an order of acquittal passed by the trial Court\n\nhave been set out in innumerable cases of this Court and in <a href=\"/doc/1989251/\" id=\"a_51\">Ajit Savant\n\nMajagavi v. State of Karnataka</a> (AIR 1997 SC 3255) the following\n\nprinciples have been re-iterated:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_55\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_22\">      1.    In an appeal against an order of acquittal, the High Court\n      possesses all the powers and nothing less than the powers it\n      possesses while hearing an appeal against an order of\n      conviction.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_23\">      2. The High Court has the power to reconsider the whole issue,\n      reappraise the evidence and come to its own conclusion and\n      findings in place of the findings recorded by trial Court, if the\n      said findings are against the weight of the evidence on record,\n      or in other words, perverse.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_24\">      3. Before reversing the finding of acquittal, the High Court has\n      to consider each ground on which the order of acquittal was\n      based and to record its own reasons for not accepting those\n      grounds not subscribing to the view expressed by the trial court\n      that the accused is entitled to acquittal.</blockquote><p id=\"p_56\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_57\">      4. In reversing the finding of acquittal, the High Court has to\n      keep in view the fact that the presumption of innocence is still\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">                                                                          16</span>\n\f      available in favour of the accused and the same stands fortified\n      and strengthened by the order of acquittal passed in his favour\n      by the trial court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_58\">      5.     If the High Court on a fresh scrutiny and re-appraisal of\n      the evidence and other material on record, is of the opinion that\n      there is another view which can be reasonably taken, then the\n      view which favours the accused should be adopted.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_59\">      6.      The High Court has also to keep in mind that the trial\n      court had the advantage of looking at the demeanor of\n      witnesses and observing their conduct in the Court especially\n      in the witness box.\n</p><p id=\"p_60\">      7.     The High Court has also to keep in mind that even at that\n      stage, the accused was entitled to benefit of doubt. The doubt\n      should be such as a reasonable person would honestly and\n      conscientiously entertain as to the guilt of the accused.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_61\">19.   In this respect, the decisions of this Court in Balbir Singh Vs. State of\n\nPunjab (AIR 1957 SC 216) Ram Kumar Vs. State of Haryana (AIR 1995 SC\n\n</p><p id=\"p_62\">280), Bharwad Jakshibhai Nagjibhai Vs. State of Gujarat (AIR 1995 SC\n\n2505), Hari Chand Vs. State of Delhi (AIR 1996 SC 1477), Raghbir Singh\n\nVs. State of Haryana (JT 2000 (5) SC 21), and Hari Ram Vs. State of\n\nRajasthan (JT 2000 (6) SC 254) may be seen.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_63\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_64\">20.   In Ashok Kumar Vs. State of Rajasthan (AIR 1990 SC 2134) this\n\nCourt has held as under :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_65\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">                                                                           17</span>\n\f             \"While caution is the watchword, in appeal against\n             acquittal as the trial Judge has occasion to watch\n             demeanour of witnesses interference should not be made\n             merely because a different conclusion could have been\n             arrived at. Prudence demands restraint on mere\n             probability or possibility but in perversity or misreading\n             interference is imperative otherwise existence of power\n             shall be rendered meaningless. In the present case the\n             order of the trial Court is vitiated as part from deciding\n             the case on irrelevant consideration the most serious\n             error of which he was guilty and which rendered the\n             order infirm which could be set aside by the High Court\n             was that he misread the evidence and indulged in\n             conjectural inferences and surmises.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_66\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_67\">21.   The evidence of PWs 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 clearly shows the greed of the\n\naccused who was persistently taunting and harassing the deceased for not\n\nhaving brought sufficient dowry. Therefore, the High Court was justified in\n\nupsetting the order of acquittal passed by the trial Court and directing her\n\nconviction. We find no merit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_68\">                                      ........................................J.\n                                      (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                      ........................................J.\n                                      (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\n\n\nNew Delhi,\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">                                                                               18</span>\n\fJanuary 7, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\"
