Dattu</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n                IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n              CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.142 OF 2009\n              (Arising out of SLP(Crl) NO. 3589 OF 2006)\n\n\n\nShri Rajendra Ramchandra Kavalekar                  .............. Appellant\n\n                                   Versus\n\nState of Maharashtra &amp; Anr.                      ..............Respondents\n\n                                    With\n\n              Transfer Petition (Criminal) No. 234 of 2006\n\n\n\n                                ORDER\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.L.P(Crl.)No. 3589 of 2006\n\n      Leave is granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">2)    This appeal is directed against the judgment and order passed by the\n\nHigh Court of Judicature at Bombay in Criminal Writ Petition No. 1375 of\n\n2006 dated July 5, 2006. By the impugned order, the High Court has\n\nrejected the writ petition, however, has directed the respondent therein, not\n\nto arrest the appellant for a period of six weeks, in R.C. Case No. 1(A).2004\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                          1</span>\n\fregistered under <a href=\"/doc/1128948/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 120(b)</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1436241/\" id=\"a_2\">420</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1985627/\" id=\"a_3\">467</a>, <a href=\"/doc/556166/\" id=\"a_4\">468</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1466184/\" id=\"a_5\">471</a> of the Indian Penal\n\nCode and <a href=\"/doc/86648814/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 13(2)</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/1101716/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 13(1)(d)</a> of the Prevention of\n\nCorruption Act, 1988, pending on the file of the Special Judge (C.B.I.),\n\nRanchi, Jharkhand, to facilitate the appellant to move the appropriate court\n\nfor appropriate relief. It may be useful to extract the reasoning, conclusion\n\nand the directions issued by the court to appreciate the issues canvassed by\n\nthe appellant. It is as under:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">          \"From the submissions made by the petitioner's advocate, it\n          is clear that the Jharkhand Court seized of the matter. It is\n          the C.B.I. Court, all papers and documents pertaining to the\n          case mentioned above are in the custody and possession of\n          the said court and, therefore, it will not be proper for the\n          court to entertain this petition for quashing the\n          proceedings.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_3\">3)          In the Criminal Writ Petition filed before the High Court of\n\nJudicature at Bombay, the appellant apart from others, had asserted that he\n\nis the accused No. 1 in the case registered by C.B.I., SPE, Ranchi in the\n\nState of Jharkhand for the offences under <a href=\"/doc/1128948/\" id=\"a_8\">Sections 120(b)</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1436241/\" id=\"a_9\">420</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1985627/\" id=\"a_10\">467</a>, <a href=\"/doc/556166/\" id=\"a_11\">468</a>,\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1466184/\" id=\"a_12\">471</a> of IPC and <a href=\"/doc/1259316/\" id=\"a_13\">Sections 13(2)</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/1101716/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 13(1)(d)</a> of the Prevention\n\nof Corruption Act, 1988. The State of Maharashtra which is arrayed as\n\nRespondent No. 1 in the petition, through RCF Police Station, Kurla, has\n\nregistered a case bearing Crime No. 250 of 1999 dated 14th October, 1999\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                          2</span>\n\funder <a href=\"/doc/1436241/\" id=\"a_15\">Sections 420</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1293807/\" id=\"a_16\">461</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1317063/\" id=\"a_17\">465</a>, <a href=\"/doc/556166/\" id=\"a_18\">468</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1466184/\" id=\"a_19\">471</a>, <a href=\"/doc/649216/\" id=\"a_20\">473</a> <a href=\"/doc/1666702/\" id=\"a_21\">476</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1128948/\" id=\"a_22\">120(b)</a> of IPC and\n\ntried as CC No. 855/P/2000 before the Additional Chief Metropolitan\n\nMagistrate, 11th Court, Kurla, Mumbai, wherein the role of Kanhayalal\n\nSharma and his son Prakash Kanhayalal Sharma is being investigated for\n\nhaving issued bogus and false Degree certificates to large number of\n\nstudents purportedly from Ranchi and Pune Universities. It is also stated\n\nthat with the help of the degree certificate and the provisional certificate\n\nissued by the Ranchi University, he had joined India Tourism Development\n\nCorporation (ITDC for short) as Cashier-cum-Sales Assistant by producing\n\nthe aforesaid certificate issued for the academic year 1993-94 and it is also\n\nstated that until he was issued with suspension order by the employer viz.\n\nITDC, he was not aware, that, the certificate issued by the Ranchi\n\nUniversity was bogus/fake/fabricated. The appellamt has further stated that\n\nhe has never been to the State of Jharkhand or to Ranchi for the purpose of\n\nappearing in the examination for the academic year 1993-94. It is further\n\nasserted that Kanhayalal Sharma who is the main accused in the case\n\nregistered   by   RCF Police Station, Kurla, had opened an educational\n\ninstitution known as `Marudhar Mahavidyalaya' operated both from Pune\n\nand Mumbai cities and the said institution has issued forged/bogus/false\n\ncertificates of the Ranchi University. It has also stated that he had applied\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                         3</span>\n\ffor anticipatory bail before the Special Judge, CBI, Ranchi and by an order\n\ndated 22nd November, 2005, the learned Judge had rejected the anticipatory\n\nbail on the ground that appellant was not one of those appellants who had\n\napproached the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in the Writ Petition No.\n\n71 of 2001 and connected matters.         It is further stated, that, he had\n\napproached the High Court of Jharkhand for grant of anticipatory bail and it\n\nwas also rejected. It is further assertion of the appellant that there is no\n\nreason for CBI, SPE, Ranchi to launch a case against the appellant in the\n\nyear 2004, of a case where inquiry had already been initiated by RCF Police\n\nStation for the very same offence and the matter is already pending before\n\nthe Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Kurla, Mumbai. Lastly, it is\n\nstated that the CBI, SPE, Ranchi has no jurisdiction to register a case\n\nagainst the appellant, since the entire cause of action had arisen in the State\n\nof Maharashtra and not in Ranchi and by registering a case at Ranchi by the\n\nCBI, SPE, Ranchi, have abused the process of law and it has no locus standi\n\nto file a complaint against the appellant in respect of the offences mentioned\n\nin the charge sheet in which the appellant is a victim by himself.\n\nAccordingly, he has sought for the following reliefs :\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">      1)        To issue a writ in the nature of writ of certiorari to quash\n\n                registration of the case R.C. Case No. 1(A)/2004 registered\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                           4</span>\n\f                  under <a href=\"/doc/1128948/\" id=\"a_23\">Sections 120(b)</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1436241/\" id=\"a_24\">420</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1985627/\" id=\"a_25\">467</a>, <a href=\"/doc/556166/\" id=\"a_26\">468</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1466184/\" id=\"a_27\">471</a> of IPC and\n\n                  <a href=\"/doc/1259316/\" id=\"a_28\">Section 13(2)</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/1101716/\" id=\"a_29\">Section 13(1)(d)</a> of the Prevention\n\n                  of Corruption Act, 1988 pending before the Special Judge\n\n                  (CBI), Ranchi, Jharkhand State,.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">      2)          Without prejudice to the aforesaid relief, if this Hon'ble\n\n                  Court decline to quash the     registration of the case R.C.\n\n                  Case No. 1(A)/2004 registered under <a href=\"/doc/1128948/\" id=\"a_30\">Sections 120(b)</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1436241/\" id=\"a_31\">420</a>,\n\n                  <a href=\"/doc/1985627/\" id=\"a_32\">467</a>, <a href=\"/doc/556166/\" id=\"a_33\">468</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1466184/\" id=\"a_34\">471</a> of IPC and <a href=\"/doc/1259316/\" id=\"a_35\">Section 13(2)</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/1101716/\" id=\"a_36\">Section\n\n                  13(1)(d)</a> of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988, and the\n\n                  same order to be sent to RCF Police Station for\n\n                  investigation, inquiry and trial before the Additional Chief\n\n                  Metropolitan Magistrate, 11th Court, Kurla, Mumbai in\n\n                  accordance with law.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4)         As we have already stated, the High Court of Judicature at Bombay\n\nhas rejected the writ petition with certain observations and directions.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">5)    Questioning     the correctness or otherwise of the final judgment and\n\norder passed by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Criminal Writ\n\nPetition No. 1375 of 2006, the appellant is before us in this appeal.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                           5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">\f6)    We have heard Shri K.T.S. Tulsi, learned Senior Counsel, for the\n\nappellant and Shri Datta, learned senior counsel for the respondents.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">7)    Shri Tulsi, learned Senior Counsel, submitted that the High Court of\n\nJudicature at Bombay was not right in rejecting the Criminal Writ Petition\n\nfiled by the appellant solely on the ground that the entire matter is pending\n\nbefore the Special Judge (CBI) at Ranchi, and, therefore, it would not be\n\nproper for the court to entertain the petition for quashing the proceedings in\n\nthe case R.C. Case No. 1(A)/2004.      It is further contended that since the\n\npart of the cause of action has arisen in the State of Maharashtra, the High\n\nCourt of Judicature at Bombay has the jurisdiction to entertain the writ\n\npetition and grant relief sought for by the appellant.        In aid of his\n\nsubmission, learned senior counsel would invite our attention to the\n\nobservations made by this Court in the case of Navinchandra N. Majithia\n\nVs. State of Maharashtra &amp; Ors., (2007) 7 SCC 640.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">8)    Shri Datta, learned Senior Counsel      appearing for the respondents\n\nwould contend, that, the appellant in collusion and connivance with the\n\nofficials of the Ranchi University had obtained forged degree certificate and\n\nby producing that certificate had secured a job in ITDC as Cashier-cum-\n\nSales-Assistant and when the Vigilance Department of ITDC tried to verify\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                          6</span>\n\fthose documents from Ranchi University, the appellant with the help of the\n\nDispatching Clerk of the office of the Controller of Examination, Ranchi\n\nUniversity had destroyed the letter dated 26.2.2000 issued by the Controller\n\nof Examinations, Ranchi University, informing the ITDC that the mark\n\nsheet, the Provisional Certificate and the Degree Certificate of the appellant\n\nare false and are not issued by the University and instead a bogus letter\n\nbearing No. EX/1715 dated 17.7.2000 was sent to ITDC under the name of\n\nController of Examination, Ranchi University wherein it had been\n\nmentioned that the appellant had appeared in B.A. Degree Examination of\n\nRanchi University in the year 1993-94 and his marksheet, provisional\n\ncertificate and the degree certificate were declared as genuine and therefore,\n\nthe entire cause of action has arisen in the District of Ranchi, State of\n\nJharkhand. The learned counsel further submitted that the investigation in\n\nR.C. Case No. 1(A)/2004 is completed by the CBI, Ranchi and the\n\nchargesheet against the appellant and against Sri P.C. Ram, Despatch Clerk\n\nof Ranchi University has been filed before the Special Judge (CBI), Ranchi\n\nand the same is pending consideration.       Therefore, the learned counsel\n\nwould submit that the High Court of Judicature at Bombay was right in\n\ndeclining to entertain the Criminal Writ Petition filed by the appellant.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                                            7</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">\f9)    Having heard the learned counsels for the parties, in our view, the\n\nissue that requires our consideration is, whether the High Court of\n\nJudicature at Bombay was right in passing the impugned order rejecting the\n\nCriminal Writ Petition filed by the appellant on the ground, that, the Special\n\nJudge (CBI), Ranchi has heard case R.C. Case No. 1(A)/2004 and all the\n\ndocuments pertaining to the case are in the custody and possession of the\n\nSpecial Judge (CBI), Ranchi.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">10)       Before we advert to the issue raised for our consideration and\n\nconsequent decision, let us first notice the decision on which reliance is\n\nplaced by learned senior counsel Shri Tulsi in support of his submission.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">11)      The facts in Navinchandra N. Majithia Vs. State of Maharashtra's,\n\ncase was that the FIR was filed in Shillong, Meghalaya            against the\n\nappellant to reverse the transaction relating to transfer of company shares\n\nwhich had entirely taken place at Maharashtra. Therefore, the appellant had\n\nfiled a writ petition before the Mumbai High Court for quashing of FIR filed\n\nat Shillong and alternatively a prayer was made for the issue of Writ of\n\nMandamus against the State of Meghalaya for transfer of the investigation\n\nto the Mumbai Police. The High Court had dismissed the petition. In\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                                            8</span>\n\fappeal, this Court observed that the High Court has failed in not considering\n\nthe alternative prayer, since the part of the cause of action had arisen with\n\nthe territorial jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">12)   It is also relevant to state, that, in Navinchandra N. Majithia's case,\n\nthe Court at paragraph 22 of the judgment has observed :\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">            \"So far as the question of territorial jurisdiction with\n      reference to a criminal offence is concerned the main factor to\n      be considered is the place where the alleged offence was\n      committed.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_18\">13)   The territorial jurisdiction of a court with regard to criminal offence\n\nwould be decided on the basis of place of occurrence of the incident and not\n\non the basis of where the complaint was filed and the mere fact that FIR was\n\nregistered in a particular State is not the sole criterion to decide that no\n\ncause of action has arisen even partly within the territorial limits of\n\njurisdiction of another court. The venue of enquiry or trial is primarily to be\n\ndetermined by the averments contained in the complaint or charge sheet.\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1219882/\" id=\"a_37\">Section 177</a> of Criminal Procedure Code provides that every offence shall\n\nordinarily be inquired into and tried by a court within whose local\n\njurisdiction it was committed. Reference can be made to the observations\n\nmade by this court in\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                                           9</span>\n\fAsit Bhattacharjee Vs. Hanuman Prasad Ojha and Ors. (2007) 5 SCC 786.\n\nThis court at paragraph 23 has stated as under :\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">             \"The necessary ingredients for proving a criminal\n      offence must exist in a complaint petition. Such ingredients of\n      offence must be referable to the places where the cause of\n      action in regard to commission of offence has arisen. A cause\n      of action as understood in its ordinary parlance may be relevant\n      for exercise of jurisdiction under clause (2) of <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_38\">Article 226</a> of\n      the Constitution of India but its definition stricto sensu may not\n      be applicable for the purpose of bringing home a charge of\n      criminal offence. The application filed by the petitioner under\n      <a href=\"/doc/99487/\" id=\"a_39\">Section 156(3)</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure disclosed\n      commission of a large number of offences. The fact that major\n      part of the offence took place outside the jurisdiction of the\n      Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Calcutta is not in dispute. But,\n      even if a part of the offence committed by the respondents\n      related to the petitioner Company was committed within the\n      jurisdiction of the said court, the High Court of Allahabad\n      should not have interfered in the matter.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_19\">14)   This court has further observed :\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">      30) \"The High Court has placed strong reliance upon a\n      decision of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/777058/\" id=\"a_40\">Navinchandra N. Majithia v. State of\n      Maharashtra</a>, (2007) 7 SCC 640, wherein this Court held, while\n      considering a contention that the High Court of Bombay was\n      not correct in not entertaining the application for quashing of a\n      complaint petition filed by the complainant in Shillong, went\n      into the merit of the matter and instead of remitting the matter\n      back to the High Court directed: (SCC p. 651, para 29)\n\n                  `29. Considering the peculiar fact situation of\n            the case we are of the view that setting aside the\n            impugned judgment and remitting the case to the\n            High Court for fresh disposal will cause further delay\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                                                           10</span>\n\f            in investigation of the matter and may create other\n            complications. Instead, it will be apt and proper to\n            direct that further investigation relating to complaint\n            filed by J.B. Holdings Ltd. should be made by\n            Mumbai Police.'\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">      31) This Court arrived at the finding that the High Court\n      should have issued a writ of mandamus directing the State of\n      Meghalaya to transfer the investigation to Mumbai Police\n      taking note of the averments made in the writ petition that the\n      complaint petition filed at Shillong was mala fide.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">      32) No such explicit prayer was made by the respondents in\n      their writ petition, although a prayer for issuance of a writ in\n      the nature of mandamus, directing the State of West Bengal to\n      transfer Case No. 381 to the State of U.P. had been made. The\n      question of the State of West Bengal's having a legal duty in\n      that behalf did not arise. Only in the event an investigating\n      officer, having regard to the provisions contained in <a href=\"/doc/1980578/\" id=\"a_41\">Sections\n      154</a>, <a href=\"/doc/523607/\" id=\"a_42\">162</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1219882/\" id=\"a_43\">177</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1220064/\" id=\"a_44\">178</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure had\n      arrived at a finding that the alleged crime was not committed\n      within his territorial jurisdiction, could forward the first\n      information report to the police having jurisdiction in the\n      matter.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">      33) Stricto sensu, therefore, the High Court should not have\n      issued such a direction. Assuming, however, that the High\n      Court could mould the relief, in our opinion, it was not a case\n      where on the face of the allegations made in the complaint\n      petition, the same could be said to be mala fide. A major part\n      of the cause of action might have arisen in the State of U.P., but\n      the same by itself would not mean that the Calcutta Court had\n      no jurisdiction whatsoever.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_20\">15)   In the instant case, the CBI has initiated the suo-moto investigation\n\nagainst the appellant.   In the First Information Report filed before the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                                                                           11</span>\n\fSpecial Judge (CBI), Ranchi, it is stated that during the course of\n\ninvestigation of R.C. Case No. 1(A)/2000, which was registered pursuant to\n\nthe orders of High Court of Jharkhand at Ranchi, a reliable source of\n\ninformation had been received to the effect that Shri Rajendra Ramchandra\n\nKavalekar (appellant) had entered into a criminal conspiracy with the other\n\nunknown persons including the officials of Ranchi University during the\n\nacademic year 1993-94 by obtaining the false and forged mark sheets of\n\nRanchi University,       and, further, on the strength of those false and\n\nfabricated documents pertaining to his graduation degree, fraudulently and\n\ndishonestly   obtained    employment     in   India    Tourism   Development\n\nCorporation as Cashier-cum-Sales Assistant.           In the First Information\n\nReport, it is also stated that the appellant in collusion with the officials of\n\nIndia Tourism Development Corporation Ltd., Mumbai, the University, had\n\nmanaged to suppress letter dated 26.2.2000 written by the Controller of\n\nExamination, Ranchi pursuant to the queries made by the Manager\n\n(Vigilance) of ITDC, for ascertaining whether the provisional certificate\n\nand the degree certificate issued to the appellant for the academic year\n\n1993-94 is forged and fake, and the appellant with a collusion             and\n\nconnivance of the officials of the University had got prepared a letter dated\n\n26.2.2000, wherein it is stated that the marks sheets, provisional certificate\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                                                           12</span>\n\fand the degree certificate produced by the appellant at the time of securing\n\nthe job in ITDC is correct and genuine and thereby has committed a\n\ncriminal offence under the provisions<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_45\"> of Indian Penal Code</a>.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">16)   The case of the appellant before the High Court of Mumbai, was that\n\nhe was nowhere responsible for the issuance of fake/forged degree\n\ncertificates while securing job as Cashier-cum-Sales Assistant in ITDC.\n\nAccording to appellant, it is the handiwork of Shri Kanhayalal Sharma, who\n\nwas managing the institution known as `Marudhar Mahavidyalaya' having\n\nits centres at Pune and Mumbai. Except this bald assertion, he has not\n\nproduced any material in support of that assertion.         However, in the\n\ncomplaint filed by CBI, Ranchi, it is specifically alleged that the appellant\n\nhad entered into criminal conspiracy with the officials of the Ranchi\n\nUniversity and had obtained fake degree certificates. A court trying an\n\naccused for an offence of conspiracy is competent to try him for all offences\n\ncommitted in pursuance of conspiracy irrespective of the fact that any or all\n\nthe other offences were not committed within the territorial jurisdiction (See\n\nBanwarilal Jhunjhunwala vs. Union of India, AIR 1963 SC 1620).\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">                                                                          13</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">\f17)   A bare perusal of the complaint filed would clearly go to show that\n\nthe cause of action arose within the jurisdiction of Special Judge (CBI),\n\nRanchi, the investigation is completed in Ranchi, all the records and the\n\ndocuments pertaining to complaint and the charge sheet are before the\n\nSpecial Judge (CBI), Ranchi, and therefore, in our considered view, the\n\nHigh Court of Judicature at Bombay was perfectly justified in declining to\n\nentertain the Writ Petition filed by the petitioner.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">18)   In view of the above reasons, we reject the appeal. In the facts and\n\ncircumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own costs.\n\nT.P. (Crl.)No. 234 of 2006\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">19)   In view of the orders passed in Criminal Appeal No....... of 2009\n\narising out of S.L.P.(Crl.)No. 3589 of 2006, the Transfer Petition does not\n\nsurvive and no further order is required. The Transfer Petition is disposed\n\nof accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                              .......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">                                              [ TARUN CHATTERJEE ]\n\n\n\n\n                                              .......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">                                              [ H.L. DATTU ]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 23, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\"> 2014"}],"tid":1852103,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":12,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33589","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Kishangiri Mangalgiri Goswami vs State Of Gujarat on 28 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                    IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n             CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.            169      OF 2009\n               (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No.2227 of 2008)\n\n\nKishangiri Mangalgiri Goswami                            .....Appellant\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\n\nState of Gujarat                                         .....Respondent\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nGujarat High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant for offences\n\npunishable under <a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 306</a> and <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_2\">498-A</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860\n\n(in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">IPC</a>') and <a href=\"/doc/751411/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 3</a> of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 (in\n\nshort `DP Act'). Learned Additional Sessions Judge, Court No.9,\n\fAhmedabad City imposed sentences of 3 years, 10 years and 5 years\n\nrespectively for the aforesaid offences and fine of Rs.5,000/-, Rs.20,000/-\n\nand Rs.20,000/- with default stipulations.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Prosecution version in a nutshell is as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      The accused married Kantaben (hereinafter referred to as the\n\n`deceased') in 1989. Soon after two years of his marriage, the accused\n\nstarted inflicting mental and physical torture on her and she was taunted by\n\nthe accused for not bringing sufficient dowry in the marriage. He also\n\ndemanded from the victim an amount of Rs.40,000/- for the purpose of\n\npurchasing a house. He even wrote letters to the in-laws and demanded\n\nRs.40,000/- for purchasing the house. The demand was persistent. Even\n\nthreats were administered to the deceased and her family members. Thus,\n\nthe accused inflicted mental and physical torture on the victim which\n\nprompted her to commit suicide by burning herself on 23-03-1999 after\n\npouring kerosene on her body. Thus, as per the prosecution case, the\n\nappellant has committed the offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 498A</a> and\n\n<a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_6\">306</a> IPC read with Sections 3 and 7 of DP Act.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\f      The complaint was given by Dhulagiri Gumangiri Goswami on\n\n17.5.1999. On the strength of the complaint given by the complainant\n\ninvestigation was carried out. The place where the suicide was committed\n\nby the victim was visited and the panchnama of the place of incident was\n\nprepared in the presence of the panch-witnesses. Statements of the witnesses\n\nfrom the neighbourhood were recorded. The injured was immediately\n\nrushed to the hospital for providing necessary treatment. Muddamal seized\n\nwas sent to Forensic Science Laboratory for the purpose of detailed\n\nanalysis. On the death of the victim, the inquest panchnama was prepared\n\nand the dead body was sent for autopsy. The appellant was arrested during\n\nthe course of investigation. On receipt of the report from FSL, the post-\n\nmortem report along with other material, the appellant was charge-sheeted\n\nfor the offences punishable under <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_7\">Sections 498A</a> and <a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_8\">306</a> of IPC as well as\n\nSections 3 and 7 of the DP Act. He was produced before the Metropolitan\n\nMagistrate, Ahmedabad, who in turn committed the case to the Sessions\n\nCourt under <a href=\"/doc/887219/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 209</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (in short\n\nthe `Code') as the case was exclusively triable by the Sessions Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      As the accused persons pleaded innocence trial was held. Seventeen\n\nwitnesses were examined to further the prosecution version. The trial court\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n\ffound that the letters written by the accused clearly established the demand\n\nof dowry and further the suicide was clearly abetted by the acts and conduct\n\nof the appellant. Accordingly, the conviction was recorded and sentences\n\nwere imposed as afore-stated.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      In appeal, the High court concurred with the views of the trial Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">4.    In support of the appeal, it was submitted that the letters whereby the\n\nalleged demand of dowry was made has not been signed by the appellant\n\nand even has not been addressed to anyone. There was no material to show\n\nthat the appellant had subjected the deceased to such cruelty and harassment\n\nas to instigate her to commit suicide. The evidence on record shows that the\n\nappellant had purchased valuable silver ornaments for the deceased and in\n\nhis insurance policy, the deceased was shown to be his nominee. Their\n\nrelation was otherwise cordial. Since the substratum of the allegations of\n\ndowry and harassment were letters, their authenticity having not been\n\nestablished the trial Court and the High Court should not have relied upon\n\nthe same.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                    4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">\f5.    It is pointed out that the accused himself had taken the deceased to\n\nthe hospital and from his conduct it clearly shows that the accused was not\n\nguilty. In essence, it is submitted that the commission of alleged offences\n\nhas not been established by the prosecution.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">6.    In response, learned counsel for the respondent-State supported the\n\njudgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">7.    We shall first deal with the plea relating to applicability of <a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_10\">Section\n\n306</a> IPC.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">8.    <a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 306</a> IPC deals with abetment of suicide. The said provision\n\nreads as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">            \"306 ABETMENT OF SUICIDE.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">            If any person commits suicide, whoever abets the\n            commission of such suicide, shall be punished with\n            imprisonment of either description for a term which may\n            extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_24\">9.    Abetment involves a mental process of instigating a person or\n\nintentionally aiding that person in doing of a thing. In cases of conspiracy\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                    5</span>\n\falso it would involve that mental process of entering into conspiracy for the\n\ndoing of that thing. More active role which can be described as instigating\n\nor aiding the doing of a thing it required before a person can be said to be\n\nabetting the commission of offence under <a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 306</a> of IPC.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">10.   <a href=\"/doc/337402/\" id=\"a_13\">In State of West Bengal v. Orilal Jaiswal</a> (AIR 1994 SC 1418) this\n\nCourt has observed that the courts should be extremely careful in assessing\n\nthe facts and circumstances of each case and the evidence adduced in the\n\ntrial for the purpose of finding whether the cruelty meted out to the victim\n\nhad in fact induced her to end her life by committing suicide. If it transpires\n\nto the Court that a victim committing suicide was hypersensitive to ordinary\n\npetulance, discord and differences in domestic life quite common to the\n\nsociety to which the victim belonged and such petulance discord and\n\ndifferences were not expected to induce a similarly circumstanced\n\nindividual in a given society to commit suicide, the conscience of the Court\n\nshould not be satisfied for basing a finding that the accused charged of\n\nabetting the offence of suicide should be found guilty.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">11.   <a href=\"/doc/1667403/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 107</a> IPC defines abetment of a thing. The offence of abetment\n\nis a separate and distinct offence provided in the Act as an offence. A\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n\fperson, abets the doing of a thing when (1) he instigates any person to do\n\nthat thing; or (2) engages with one or more other persons in any conspiracy\n\nfor the doing of that thing; or (3) intentionally aids, by act or illegal\n\nomission, the doing of that thing. These things are essential to complete\n\nabetment as a crime. The word \"instigate\" literally means to provoke, incite,\n\nurge on or bring about by persuasion to do any thing. The abetment may be\n\nby instigation, conspiracy or intentional aid, as provided in the three clauses\n\nof <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 107</a>. <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 109</a> provides that if the act abetted is committed in\n\nconsequence of abetment and there is no provision for the punishment of\n\nsuch abetment, then the offender is to be punished with the punishment\n\nprovided for the original offence. 'Abetted' in <a href=\"/doc/1763444/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 109</a> means the\n\nspecific offence abetted. Therefore, the offence for the abetment of which a\n\nperson is charged with the abetment is normally linked with the proved\n\noffence\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">12.   In cases of alleged abetment of suicide there must be proof of direct\n\nor indirect acts of incitement to the commission of suicide. The mere fact\n\nthat the husband treated the deceased-wife with cruelty is not enough. [<a href=\"/doc/1214258/\" id=\"a_18\">See\n\nMahinder Singh v. State of M.P</a>. (1995 AIR SCW 4570)].\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                     7</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">\f13.   The aforesaid aspects were highlighted in <a href=\"/doc/621485/\" id=\"a_19\">Kishori Lal v. State of M.P</a>.\n\n(2007 (10) SCC 797), <a href=\"/doc/1310174/\" id=\"a_20\">Randhir Singh and Anr. v. State of Punjab</a> (2004 (13)\n\nSCC 129) and Criminal Appeal No. 1464 of 2007 (<a href=\"/doc/21622/\" id=\"a_21\">Sohan Raj Sharma v.\n\nState of Haryana</a> disposed of on April 7, 2008).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">14.   The conviction so far as it relates to <a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_22\">Section 306</a> IPC, therefore,\n\ncannot be sustained in view of the background facts and is set aside. But the\n\nmaterials on record particularly the letters on which specific emphasis has\n\nbeen led by the trial Court and the High Court amply demonstrate the\n\ncommission of offences punishable under <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_23\">Section 498-A</a> IPC and Section 3\n\nof DP Act. The convictions are sustained. But the sentence in respect of\n\nSection 3 of DP Act is reduced to three years.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">15.   The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">                                        ...........................................J.\n                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                        ...........................................J.\n                                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 28, 2009\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                    8</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":2,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"sale and ","formInput":"r.%20v.%20raveendran%20"},{"value":"allottee and lessee","formInput":"allottee%20and%20lessee"},{"value":"raveendran ","formInput":"raveendran%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1733066,"url":null,"title":"the Consumer Protection Act, 1986"},{"tid":334666,"url":null,"title":"Section 2 in the Consumer Protection Act, 1986"}],"covers":[],"title":"Secretary, Bhubaneswar ... vs Susanta Kumar Mishra on 30 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-30","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":137967403,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=559","title":"Raksha Rani vs Haryana State Agricultural ... on 14 September, 2012"},{"tid":135136392,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/120101109122018738FA%20No%20210%20of%202010.pdf","title":"Punjab Urban Planning & ... vs Harjinder Pal Singh Son Of Gopal ... on 14 October, 2010"},{"tid":319520,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=25113","title":"M/S. Texfield Engineers vs Texteema Engineering Industries on 18 March, 2010"},{"tid":570073,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=255","title":"The Estate Officer And Another vs Parveen Kumar on 17 September, 2009"},{"tid":37517538,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=257","title":"M/S Panna Lal Kundan And Others vs State Of Haryana And Others on 17 May, 2012"}],"tid":362968,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"_________________j.","numcitedby":13,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33758","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Secretary, Bhubaneswar ... vs Susanta Kumar Mishra on 30 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: _________________J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: R.V. Raveendran, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                                              Reportable\n\n                          IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                           CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                           CIVIL APPEAL NO.605 OF 2009\n                    (Arising out of SLP [C] No.14461 of 2007)\n\n\n\n\nSecretary, Bhubaneswar Development Authority                         ... Appellant\n\nVs.\n\nSusanta Kumar Mishra                                                 ... Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                                         O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">R. V. Raveendran J.,\n\n\n\n        Leave       granted.   The   respondent       who     appears       in    person,   in\n\nresponse to the notice informing the hearing date, has requested that\n\nhis presence may be dispensed with and his written submissions (reply\n\nwith copies of the documents) may be treated as his arguments and\n\nmatter may be disposed of. We have heard the learned counsel for\n\nappellant     and   considered     the   contentions     of    the    respondent       in   his\n\nwritten submissions.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.      The appellant (Bhubaneshwar Development                      Authority) allotted\n\nMIG   house   bearing    No.   M-19,     to   the    respondent,       as   per    letter    of\n\nallotment     dated    1.5.1991.     A    lease-cum-sale       agreement         was   entered\n\nbetween the appellant and the respondent on 6.5.1991. Clause (2) of the\n\fagreement stipulated the price of the house to be Rs.139,215/40. After\n\ndeducting the payment of Rs.37,415/- made by the lessee towards the\n\nprice (on 29.6.1990), it permitted the lessee to pay the balance of\n\nRs.101,800/40 in 52 quarterly instalments of Rs.1957/70 each commencing\n\nfrom 1.9.1989. The said clause gave the option to the Lessee to convert\n\nthe lease into a sale on completion of payment of all the instalments\n\nby paying a commitment charge of Rs.200/-. Clause (3) of the agreement\n\nrequired the lessee to pay an annual rent of Rs.24/90 during the period\n\nof   lease   commencing   from   1.9.1989.   Clause   (6)   of   the   agreement\n\nstipulated that in the event of default in paying any instalment or\n\nother dues on the due date, the lessee shall pay interest at the rate\n\nof 15% per annum on the defaulted instalments/dues from the date when\n\nthe same fell due.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.      On execution of the Lease-cum-Sale Agreement, the respondent\n\ntook possession of the house on 9.5.1991 and commenced paying the\n\ninstalments from June, 1991. He paid the last 12 instalments (No.41 to\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">52) in a lump sum on 5.7.2001. The appellant by letter dated 1.12.2001\n\ninformed the respondent that he was still due in a sum of Rs.57,175/-.\n\nOn 27.12.2001, the respondent applied to the appellant for execution\n\nand registration of a sale deed claiming that he had paid all the\n\ninstalments. The appellant sent a reply dated 30.1.2002 informing the\n\nrespondent that until the sum of Rs.57,175/- which was due was paid,\n\nthe sale deed could not be executed. A calculation sheet showing how\n\nRs.57,175/- was found to be due was also furnished.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.      Feeling   aggrieved,     the   respondent   approached   the    District\n\fConsumer Forum, Khurda alleging deficiency of service. He sought a\n\ndirection to the appellant to execute the sale deed without insisting\n\nupon    the    payment         of   Rs.57,175/-.        He    also   claimed      Rs.60,000/-        as\n\ncompensation from the appellant. The District Forum by the order dated\n\n27.10.2003 dismissed the complaint holding that refusal to execute a\n\nsale deed until the amount due was paid, was not a deficiency in\n\nservice.      The    respondent       filed    an     appeal    before     the    State      Consumer\n\nDisputes Redressal Commission, Cuttack. The State Commission by its\n\norder dated 21.12.2006 allowed the appeal in part and directed the\n\nrespondent to pay a lump sum of Rs.20,000/- to the appellant in full\n\nand final settlement of the dues and directed the appellant to execute\n\nthe sale deed on receipt of such amount. The appellant filed a revision\n\nbefore the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission, New Delhi,\n\nchallenging         the   reduction      in    the    amount    payable,     as    arbitrary        and\n\ncontrary to the terms of contract. The National Commission dismissed\n\nthe    revision      by    a    short    order       dated    8.5.2007     observing         that   the\n\nappellant could not charge compound interest and therefore, the order\n\nof the State Commission was just and equitable and did not call for\n\ninterference. Feeling aggrieved the appellant has filed this appeal by\n\nspecial leave.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5.       The appellant contends that it charged interest strictly in\n\naccordance with the terms of the lease agreement. It contends that\n\ncharging      of     interest       at   the     rate    of    15%   per    annum       on    delayed\n\ninstalments in terms of clause (6) of the agreement was not illegal.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">6.       We find considerable force in the submission of the appellant.\n\nThe    lease-cum-sale           agreement      shows     the    `price'     of    the     house      as\n\fRs.139,215/40. After adjusting Rs.37,415/- paid by the respondent, the\n\nbalance of Rs.101,800/40 was made payable in 52 quarterly instalments\n\ncommencing from 1.9.1989. There is no requirement to pay interest, if\n\nthe    instalments       were    paid    on   the   due        dates.    Only    if     the   lessee\n\ncommitted default in paying any instalment or other dues, interest at\n\n15%    per    annum      was     payable      by    the        lessee,    on      the    defaulted\n\ninstalments/dues from the date of default to date of payment under\n\nclause 6 of the agreement. Even when there was default, neither the\n\ninstalments       that    were    already      paid       on    the     due     dates,    nor    the\n\ninstalments which were yet to fall due, were subjected to interest\n\nunder clause (6) of the agreement. Charging interest under clause (6)\n\nfrom the date of default to date of payment on the defaulted amount is\n\nunexceptionable and does not amount to charging of compound interest as\n\nwrongly assumed by the State Commission and National Commission.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">6.       Even if we assume that the price of Rs.139,215.40 stipulated in\n\nthe lease-cum-sale agreement included, in addition to the cost of the\n\nplot and the construction of the house, interest thereon, the position\n\nwill   be    no   different.      Each     equated    instalment          would    then       have   a\n\nprincipal component and interest component. As the equated instalments\n\nwould include interest on the principal only up to the due date of\n\ninstalment, whenever there is a default, there can be no dispute that\n\nthe `principal' part of the instalment could be subjected to interest\n\nfrom the date of default to date of payment. It is no doubt true that\n\nwhen the defaulted instalment in entirety is subjected to interest, the\n\n`interest' component of the defaulted instalment is also subjected to\n\ninterest. To that limited extent, there may be charging of interest\n\nupon interest. Charging of such interest, on the interest part of the\n\finstalment, on default in payment of the instalment, at a reasonable\n\nrate from the date of default, cannot be termed as charging of compound\n\ninterest in regard to the entire dues. It is only a provision to ensure\n\nthat the dues (instalments) are paid promptly and avoid misuse of the\n\nconcession given by permitting payment in instalments. But for such a\n\nprovision, lessees/allottees who have already been given possession,\n\nwill   be   tempted        to   delay          payments,       thereby      leading     to    continuous\n\ndefaults. A statutory development authority, working on no profit no\n\nloss   basis,       can   ill       afford      to     permit       such   continuous        defaults   by\n\nlessees/allottees, which will paralyse their very functioning, thereby\n\naffecting future developmental activities for the benefit of other\n\nmembers of the general public. Therefore a provision for interest as\n\ncontained      in    clause     6     of       the    lease-cum-sale         agreement       is   neither\n\ninequitable nor in terrorem. Where the basic rate of interest is itself\n\nvery high, or where interest is charged on the entire price instead of\n\ncharging interest on the reducing balance, when working out the equated\n\ninstalments, or where the rate of interest on default is punitively\n\nexcessive, the position may be different. But no such case is made out\n\nby the respondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">7.       If the facts are examined, it becomes evident that the sum of\n\nRs.57,175/-     was       not   due       on    account        of   charging     compound      interest.\n\nThough   the    allotment           was    made       on   1.5.1991        and   the    lease-cum-sale\n\nagreement was signed on 6.5.1991, clause (2) of the lease-cum-sale\n\nagreement    contained          a    rather          unusual    condition        that   the    quarterly\n\ninstalment of Rs.1957/70 would commence from 1.9.1989, which is a date\n\n28 months prior to the date of allotment and lease-cum-sale agreement.\n\nThe reason for such a provision was that the last date for applications\n\fand allotment of houses under the scheme had expired in the year 1989\n\nand the allotment rate of the house had been worked out with reference\n\nto 1989. The respondent had applied belatedly on 29.6.1990 and in the\n\nnormal     course,   would      not   have   obtained   any    allotment.   In     fact,\n\nappellant, by letter dated 19.12.1990, informed the respondent that no\n\nhouse was available for allotment. But subsequently, when some houses\n\nunder the MIG scheme became available on account of default or other\n\nreason, the appellant issued an letter dated 1.5.1991 to the respondent\n\nallotting MIG House No.M-19. Having regarding to the terms of the\n\nscheme, it became necessary to require the lessee to pay the earnest\n\nmoney deposit and the instalments with reference to the original date\n\nstipulated for allotment, namely, 1.9.1989. Therefore, when the lease-\n\ncum-sale     agreement    was     executed    on   6.5.1991,    the   respondent     was\n\nrequired to pay the original allotment price in quarterly instalments\n\nof Rs.1957/70 with effect from 1.9.1989 to avoid revising the allotment\n\nprice. This meant that when the agreement was executed on 6.5.1991, the\n\nrespondent had to pay the initial payment and instalments which had\n\nfallen due between 1.9.1989 and 6.5.1991 and also pay the interest\n\nthereon at 15% per annum from the respective due dates, under clause\n\n(6). But the respondent started paying the quarterly instalments of\n\nRs.1957/70 as if such instalments commenced prospectively only after\n\nthe agreement dated 6.5.1991, and not from 1.9.1989. He paid the first\n\ninstalment only on 25.6.1991. There was thus an accumulated default in\n\nregard to the payments due between 1.9.1989 and 6.5.1991 on which\n\ninterest was payable under clause (6). There were also some delay in\n\npaying the subsequent instalments. If the Development Authority charged\n\ninterest    for   the    defaulted/delayed     instalments,     in    accordance    with\n\nclause (6) of the lease-cum-sale agreement, the respondent could not\n\fobject to the same. We are therefore of the view that the orders of the\n\nState Commission and National Commission are not justified.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">8.       The     case   of    the    respondent       in    its    complaint     was   that   the\n\ninterest could not be charged from September, 1989 as the allotment was\n\nmade    only   on    1.5.1991       followed    by   the    lease-cum-sale        agreement   on\n\n6.5.1991 and delivery of possession on 9.5.1991. He also contended that\n\nthere was no provision for payment of any interest by the lessee as\n\nclause (6) of the agreement was applicable only in the event of default\n\nand he had not committed any default. It should be noted that the\n\nrespondent did not protest against the provisions of clauses (2) and\n\n(6) of the lease-cum-sale agreement requiring payment of instalments\n\nwith effect from 1.9.1989 and took possession of the house in terms of\n\nthe said agreement. Therefore, he could not be heard to say that the\n\ninstalments      should      commence    only    prospectively.          The    District   Forum\n\nrightly held that charging of interest by the appellant from 1.9.1989\n\nin accordance with clause (6) of the agreement and insisting upon\n\npayment of dues before executing the sale deed, did not amount to\n\ndeficiency in service. But the State Commission and National Commission\n\nacted    on    wrong    assumptions.      Further,         any    fora   under   the   <a href=\"/doc/1733066/\" id=\"a_1\">Consumer\n\nProtection Act</a>, 1986 (`Act' for short) before granting any relief to a\n\ncomplainant, should be satisfied                that the complaint relates to any of\n\nthe    matters      specified    in    <a href=\"/doc/334666/\" id=\"a_2\">section       2(c)</a>    of    the   Act,    and   that   the\n\ncomplainant has alleged and made out either unfair or restrictive trade\n\npractice by a trader, or defects in the goods sold, or any deficiency\n\nin a service rendered, or charging of excessive price for the goods\n\nsold, or offering of any goods hazardous to life and safety without\n\ndisplaying information regarding contents etc. If none of these is\n\falleged and made out, the complaint will have to be rejected. When a\n\nlessee signs without protest an agreement agreeing to pay interest at a\n\ngiven rate from a given date in given circumstances, and does not\n\ncontend that the term relating to instalments or interest is invalid or\n\ninequitable, it is not open to the consumer forum to grant any relief.\n\nA demand for any amount due in terms of the unchallenged terms of an\n\nagreement, does not furnish a cause of action to the lessee/allottee to\n\napproach the consumer forum.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">9.     Consequently, we allow this appeal, set aside the orders of the\n\nState Commission and National Commission and restore the order of the\n\nDistrict Forum. We, however, make it clear that on payment of the\n\nbalance amount due, the appellant shall execute the sale deed, if it is\n\nnot already executed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">                                                    _________________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">                                                     [R. V. Raveendran]\n\n\n\n                                                    __________________J\n                                                        [J. M. Panchal]\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">January 30, 2009.\n</p>\f"}, {"numcites":3,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"with out driving licence","formInput":"with%20out%20driving%20licence"},{"value":"national commission","formInput":"national%20commission"},{"value":"swaran singh","formInput":"swaran%20singh"},{"value":"national insurance","formInput":"national%20insurance"},{"value":"swaran","formInput":"swaran"},{"value":"valid licence","formInput":"valid%20licence"},{"value":"national insurance company limited ","formInput":"national%20insurance%20company%20limited%20"},{"value":"national insurance co","formInput":"national%20insurance%20co"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"light motor vehicle ","formInput":"light%20motor%20vehicle%20"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"valid driving licence","formInput":"valid%20driving%20licence"},{"value":"transport vehicle","formInput":"transport%20vehicle"},{"value":"fundamental breach","formInput":"fundamental%20breach"},{"value":"driver have no licence","formInput":"driver%20have%20no%20licence"}],"citeList":[{"tid":208337,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=27536","title":"National Insurance Co. Ltd. vs Sarita Devi & Ors. on 27 January, 2016"},{"tid":140316639,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/130A.1221.08.html","title":"National Ins.Co.Ltd. vs Nand Lal on 23 June, 2009"},{"tid":20672687,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/230140520130713616FA-13-678.pdf","title":"Anil Shrivas vs Branch Manager on 3 May, 2014"},{"tid":188671705,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/120FA%20No_1507%20of%202004.pdf","title":"The National Insurance Co. Ltd vs Kanwal Kumar Kakkar on 9 April, 2010"},{"tid":29150886,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/130A.no.731.2009html.html","title":"Oriental Ins.Co.Ltd. vs Mangal Singh on 4 February, 2010"}],"tid":1615147,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":9,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33546","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">National Insurance Company Ltd vs Meena Aggarwal on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CIVIL APPEAL NO. 396            OF 2009\n               (Arising out of SLP(C ) No. 19513 of 2006)\n\n\n\nNational Insurance Company Ltd.                       ......Appellant\n\n                                  Versus\n\nMeena Aggarwal                                        ......Respondent\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.   Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.   Challenge in this appeal is to the order passed by the National\n\nConsumer Disputes Redressal Commission, New Delhi, (in short the\n\n`National Commission').\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.   Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n\f      Respondent was the owner of a vehicle- a Maruti van which was the\n\nsubject matter of insurance with the present appellant for a period from\n\n27.1.2003 to 26.1.2004. The Vehicle in question met with an accident on\n\n12.6.2003 and was badly damaged. The estimate of the cost of repair was\n\nprepared by Automobiles Satya of Bilaspur. According to him the estimated\n\nexpenditure on total repair of the vehicle was Rs.2,00,000/-. Intimation of\n\nthe same was given by the complainant to the present appellant and claim\n\nwas made. The same was rejected on the ground that the driver of the\n\nvehicle did not possess a valid driving licence and the vehicle which was a\n\nprivate vehicle was insured for personal use, but was being used as a taxi for\n\ncarrying marriage parties. a marriage party was being transported in the\n\nvehicle after charging rent of Rs.2100/- when the accident occurred. The\n\ndriver did not possess a valid licence and, therefore, the vehicle was being\n\nplied against the terms of the insurance policy. The District Consumer\n\nDisputes Redressal Forum Sarguja, Ambikapur Chhattisgarh, rejected the\n\nclaim petition. An appeal was preferred before the State Consumer Dispute\n\nRedressal Commission, Rajpur (in short the `State Commission'). By order\n\ndated 17.10.2005, the appeal was allowed. It was held that it would be\n\nproper to declare the claim of complainant as \"Non-standard\" consequent to\n\nthe violation and breach. Therefore, the present appellant was directed to\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\fpay Rs.90,000/- i.e. 75% of Rs.1,20,000/- i.e. the amount assessed by the\n\nsurveyor of the insurance company along with 9% interest. The only reason\n\ngiven by the State Commission was that even if the vehicle was being used\n\nas a taxi, there was no fundamental breach of the terms of the policy. A\n\nrevision petition was filed before the National Commission which came to\n\nbe dismissed by the impugned order. The National Commission held that\n\neven though the vehicle was being used as a commercial vehicle and the\n\ndriver did not have a valid driving licence, there was no fundamental breach\n\nof the terms of the policy.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      According to the appellant the insured vehicle was being used as a\n\ncommercial vehicle, and the driver of the vehicle is required to hold an\n\nappropriate licence. If the driver who was driving the vehicle at a relevant\n\npoint of time did not possess any licence to drive a commercial vehicle,\n\nthere is a breach of the conditions of the policy and such plea was available\n\nto be raised as a defence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">4.    This Court in <a href=\"/doc/1827019/\" id=\"a_1\">National Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Swaran Singh</a> [2004(3)\n\nSCC 297] clearly laid down that the liability of the Insurance Company vis-\n\n`-vis the owner would depend upon several factors. The owner would be\n\nliable for payment of compensation in a case where the driver was not\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n\fhaving a licence at all. It was the obligation on the part of the owner to take\n\nadequate care to see that the driver had an appropriate licence to drive the\n\nvehicle. The question as regards the liability of the owner vis-`-vis the\n\ndriver being not possessed of a valid licence was considered in Swaran\n\nSingh's case stating:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">               \"89. Section 3 of the Act casts an obligation on a driver\n           to hold an effective driving licence for the type of vehicle\n           which he intends to drive. Section 10 of the Act enables\n           the Central Government to prescribe forms of driving\n           licences for various categories of vehicles mentioned in\n           sub-section (2) of the said section. The various types of\n           vehicles described for which a driver may obtain a licence\n           for one or more of them are: (a) motorcycle without gear,\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">           (b) motorcycle with gear, (c) invalid carriage, (d) light\n           motor vehicle, (e) transport vehicle, (f) road roller, and (g)\n           motor vehicle of other specified description. The\n           definition clause in Section 2 of the Act defines various\n           categories of vehicles which are covered in broad types\n           mentioned in sub-section (2) of Section 10. They are\n           `goods carriage', `heavy goods vehicle', `heavy passenger\n           motor vehicle', `invalid carriage', `light motor vehicle',\n           `maxi-cab', `medium goods vehicle', `medium passenger\n           motor vehicle', `motor-cab', `motorcycle', `omnibus',\n           `private service vehicle', `semi-trailer', `tourist vehicle',\n           `tractor', `trailer' and `transport vehicle'. In claims for\n           compensation for accidents, various kinds of breaches\n           with regard to the conditions of driving licences arise for\n           consideration before the Tribunal as a person possessing a\n           driving licence for `motorcycle without gear', [sic may be\n           driving a vehicle] for which he has no licence. Cases may\n           also arise where a holder of driving licence for `light\n           motor vehicle' is found to be driving a `maxi-cab', `motor-</blockquote><p id=\"p_13\">\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">           cab' or `omnibus' for which he has no licence. In each\n           case, on evidence led before the Tribunal, a decision has to\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                     4</span>\n\f           be taken whether the fact of the driver possessing licence\n           for one type of vehicle but found driving another type of\n           vehicle, was the main or contributory cause of accident. If\n           on facts, it is found that the accident was caused solely\n           because of some other unforeseen or intervening causes\n           like mechanical failures and similar other causes having\n           no nexus with the driver not possessing requisite type of\n           licence, the insurer will not be allowed to avoid its liability\n           merely for technical breach of conditions concerning\n           driving licence.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">5.    The matter came up for consideration again before this Court in\n\n<a href=\"/doc/208337/\" id=\"a_2\">National Insurance Corpn. Ltd. v. Kanti Devi</a> [2005 (5) )SCC 789] wherein\n\nthis Court upon consideration of the observations made in Swaran Singh's\n\ncase opined:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">                  \"12. The decision in Swaran Singh case was not\n               before either MACT or the High Court when the\n               respective orders were passed. Therefore, we think it\n               proper to remit the matter to MACT for fresh\n               consideration. It shall permit the parties to lead such\n               further evidence as they may intend to lead. The matter\n               shall be decided keeping in view the principle enunciated\n               by this Court in Swaran Singh case.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_18\">6.    In a case of this nature, therefore, the owner of a vehicle cannot\n\ncontend that he has no liability to verify the fact as to whether the driver of\n\nthe vehicle possessed a valid licence or not.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                      5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">\f7.    The aforesaid aspect was thereafter highlighted in <a href=\"/doc/1490362/\" id=\"a_3\">National Insurance\n\nCo. Ltd. v. Kusum Rai</a> [2006(4) SCC 250]. The said case related to the\n\nliability in the case of a third party. In the instant case, no such claim is\n\ninvolved and the claim is related to the damage of a vehicle.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">8.    The respondent has not appeared in spite of service of notice.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">9.    We find that the State Commission and the National Commission\n\nhave not practically indicated any reason for coming to the conclusion that\n\nthere was no fundamental breach of the terms of the policy. Both the State\n\nCommission and the National Commission observed that the vehicle was\n\nbeing driven by a person who did not have a valid driving licence. In\n\naddition to that the vehicle which was insured for personal use was used for\n\ncommercial purposes.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">10.   Looked at from any angle the impugned orders of the State\n\nCommission and the National Commission are unsustainable, deserve to be\n\nset aside, which we direct. No costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                            ............................................J.\n                                            (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                        6</span>\n\f                       ..............................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">                       (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 23, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                   7</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":26,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"private defence","formInput":"private%20defence"},{"value":"right of private defence","formInput":"right%20of%20private%20defence"},{"value":"self defence","formInput":"self%20defence"},{"value":"prithvi raj","formInput":"prithvi%20raj"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"section State Of M.P on 21 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-21","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":105149145,"url":"http://www.mphc.in/upload/gwalior/G32101214MCRC-1069714.pdf","title":"Ranveer 2014"},{"tid":120855501,"url":"http://www.mphc.in/upload/gwalior/MPHCJB/2015/MCRC/10643/MCRC_10643_2015_FinalOrder_30-Oct-2015.pdf","title":"Ranveer vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh Thr. on 30 October, 2015"},{"tid":719109,"url":null,"title":"Raees vs State Of U.P. on 16 July,
