Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n             CIVIL APPEAL NOs. 101-102              OF 2009\n          [Arising out of SLP (Civil) Nos. 24293-24294 of 2005]\n\n\nPaul Enterprises &amp; Ors.                                 ...Appellants\n\n                                     Versus\n\nRajib Chatterjee &amp; Co. &amp; Ors.                           ...Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. SINHA, J :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    What would be the meaning of the term `unemployed youth' stated in\n\nan advertisement issued pursuant to an `excise policy' of the State of West\n\nBengal is involved in these appeals which arise out of a judgment and order\n\ndated 8.06.2005 passed by the Calcutta High Court reversing the judgment\n\nand order dated 11.06.2004 passed by a learned Single Judge of the said\n\nCourt in Writ Petition No. 14945 (W) of 2003.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                     2</span><p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    The basic fact of the matter is not in dispute.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      An advertisement was issued on or about 18.01.2001 by the State of\n\nWest Bengal inviting applications from companies/firms/societies formed\n\nby unemployed youth for the purpose of grant of excise licence for country\n\nspirit shops in certain locations. Appellant No. 1, a partnership firm of the\n\nappellant Nos. 2 and 3 herein applied therefor.         In terms of the said\n\nadvertisement, respondent No. 1, which is also a partnership firm of which\n\nrespondent Nos. 2 and 3 are partners as also several others, applied for\n\nallotment of the said country spirit shop.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">4.    In the select list, the appellant No. 1 was placed at Sl. No. 3 whereas\n\nthe respondent No. 1 was placed at Sl. No. 1. The candidature of the\n\nrespondent No. 1 was objected to by the appellants inter alia contending that\n\nthe respondent Nos. 2 and 3 were not `unemployed youth' within the\n\nmeaning of the said advertisement and two locations of the liquor shops\n\nproposed by them were not conducive therefor.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">5.    The District Magistrate, Bankura being a licencing authority directed\n\nan enquiry to be held. The Enquiry Officer, in his report, inter alia opined\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                     3</span>\n\n\nthat whereas the respondent No. 2 carried on seasonal business in paddy,\n\nTil, potatoes, etc.; the respondent No. 1 carried on business with his brother.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      As regards, location, it was stated:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"...The proposed site of the country spirit shop is\n             situated within the market place of Chatramore\n             where ladies also frequently visit the spot for\n             shopping. The drunken people will disturb ladies\n             and other public if license for a country spirit shop\n             is granted with in the market place.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_15\">      It was noticed:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">             \"Rajib Chattopadhyay has stated that he is\n             unemployed and lives with his brother, Sanjib\n             Chattopadhyay in a joint family. His brother,\n             Sanjib Chbattopadhyay is the owner of the \"Light\n             House\" shop at Gelia More. Rajib Chattopadhyay\n             has admitted that he sells electrical goods of the\n             said shop. Rajib Chattopadhyay submitted a\n             Xerox copy of a challan showing deposit of\n             profession Tax by Sanjib Chattopadhyay, as a\n             token of Sanjib's shop. Rajib Chattopadhyay has\n             admitted that there are decorators' shop and\n             tailoring shop by the side of the proposed country\n             spirit shop and the proposed shop is within 30/40\n             feet from the Bishnupur, Kotulpur metalled Road.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">             Another partner, Sri Subhendu Chatterjee has\n             admitted that he was a businessman and dealt in\n             potato till March, 2001.       They signed the\n             application form for grant of license for country\n             spirit shop on 12.2.2001 and mentioned in column\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                    4</span>\n\n\n            4 seasonal business - paddy, Til potatoes etc.\n            against business or sales experience, if any,\n            Subhendu Chatterjee has further admitted that he\n            took loan of Rs. 25,000/- (Rupees Twenty five\n            thousand) for business from Chatramore co-\n            operative Bank but he could not repay the same till\n            4.1.2002. Subhendu Chatterjee has admitted that\n            his partner's name for potato business has been\n            registered with Chatramore Kshudra Babsayee\n            Samiti.    From the above, it transpires that\n            Subhendu Chatterjee, as on the date of application,\n            was self-employed, at least, partially and the site\n            for the proposed country spirit shop is situated\n            within the market place of Chatramore.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_17\">6.    The Additional District Magistrate (Excise), Bankura, however,\n\ndisagreed with the said view of the Enquiry Officer, opining:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">            \"I think, this is not any point for rejecting them\n            because all these points of objection were\n            mentioned in the application form and these are\n            not matters for discarding their candidature for the\n            business in Country Spirit\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_18\">7.    Admittedly, allotment of the country liquor shop in question was\n\nmade in favour of the respondent No. 1 herein.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">8.    Aggrieved by and dissatisfied therewith, appellants filed a writ\n\napplication before the Calcutta High Court. By reason of a judgment and\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                     5</span>\n\n\norder dated 11.06.2004, a learned Single Judge of the said Court allowed\n\nthe said writ application opining that only a person who was sitting idle\n\nwould come within the purview of the term `unemployed youth' and as the\n\nrespondents had been carrying on business, they did not satisfy the\n\nconditions for allotment of country spirit shop. It was directed:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">             \"I accordingly allow this writ application and set\n             aside the order dated December 9, 2002 issued by\n             the District Magistrate and Collector, Bankura\n             granting licence in favour of the Private\n             respondents as well as the order passed by the\n             Appellate Authority dated July 25, 2003 which\n             affirmed the said order. The licence granted in\n             favour of the Private respondents is hereby\n             quashed. The respondents are directed to take\n             consequential steps for setting the licence for\n             setting up the country spirit shop at Chatramore\n             strictly in accordance with law. Such steps must\n             be completed within one month from the date of\n             communication of this order to Collector and\n             District Magistrate, Bankura.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">                    In view of the disposal of the main Writ\n             Petition, the application filed by the respondent\n             Nos. 7 and 8 for vacating the ad-interim order\n             passed in this writ petition, becomes infructuous.\n             The said application is also disposed of as\n             infructuous.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_21\">9.    An intra court appeal was preferred thereagainst. By reason of the\n\nimpugned judgment, the writ appeal was allowed by a Division Bench of the\n\nsaid Court, opining:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                        6</span><p id=\"p_22\">\n\n\n\"11. It cannot be assumed from the nature of the\nadvertisement that by 'unemployed youth' the\nauthorities have meant a person who shall be\ntotally without any income in order to sustain\nhimself. There is no basis for such assumption. In\nfact, in order to get; the licence the candidates will\nhave to furnish an objection free site, normally\nsuch a site has to be obtained either by taking it on\nrent or by offering such a site which is part of\none's property. Apart from that such unemployed\nyouths are supposed to show some financial\nstrength by way of furnishing of bank balance and\nso on. It is not expected that a person who has no\nincome even to sustain himself will be able to\nsatisfy these requirements.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">12. In the instant case it may be noted that the\nappellants are earning some money in order to\nsustain themselves but it is nobody's case that they\nhave got any permanent employment or they are\nserving in any institution as regularly paid\nemployees. In fact the registration of persons'\nname in Employment Exchange will show that the\npersons concerned have registered themselves as\nunemployed youth for an employment but have\nnot got the employment. The same is true of the\nappellants also. It is not disputed by anybody that\nthey are registered with the Employment\nExchange. But even after such registration they are\nnot getting any employment in order to sustain\nthemselves. But they are doing some work may be\nby way of seasonal business or by working in\nfamily business which cannot be called an\nemployment. Therefore on this ground alone the\nlicence which has been granted to the appellants\ncannot be rejected. In this connection this Court is\nalso constrained to observe that since the\nexpression 'unemployed youth' has been explained\nin the advertisement with the help of expression\n'mean', there is no scope for further interpreting\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                     7</span>\n\n\n            the said expression 'unemployed youth' with the\n            help of Black's Law Dictionary or an ordinary\n            dictionary.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n\n      It was held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">            \"17. In view of such authoritative pronouncement\n            of law on the subject it is difficult for this Court to\n            accept the interpretation of 'unemployed youth'\n            given by the learned Judge by relying on Black's\n            Law Dictionary. The learned Judge possibly fell\n            into an error by not holding that, here the\n            expression 'unemployed youth' must receive a\n            contextual interpretation namely it would mean a\n            person who has not been substantially employed\n            or has not been in any service even though lie is\n            registered as an unemployed youth with the\n            Employment Exchange and as has been so\n            declared by the authorities and also must be within\n            a certain age group. Apart from that there is no\n            other requirement. If the person concerned earns\n            some money for subsistence, he does not go out of\n            the category of unemployed youth if he otherwise\n            fulfils the prescribed conditions. Going by this\n            reasoning, as we must, this Court cannot accept\n            the interpretation given to 'unemployed youth' by\n            the ld. Judge of the Writ Court. As such we feel\n            constrained to take a different view and, set aside\n            the judgment under appeal.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_27\">10.   Mr. Joydeep Mazumdar, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nappellants, would contend that the Division Bench of the High Court\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                     8</span>\n\n\ncommitted a serious error insofar as it failed to take into consideration that\n\nthe definition of the term `unemployed youth' as contained in the\n\naforementioned advertisement dated 18.01.2001 was decisive inasmuch as\n\nnot only a person who was to apply for allotment of country liquor shop was\n\nto be registered with the employment exchange, but also a certificate was\n\nrequired to be obtained from the persons specified therein. It was urged that\n\ngrant of such certificate having an impact on the factual aspect in regard to\n\nthe person being employed or not and having an element of subjectivity\n\nwherefor no parameter or guidelines having been laid down, the impugned\n\njudgment cannot be sustained.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">11.   Mr. Tara Chandra Sharma, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nState of West Bengal, on the other hand, would draw our attention to Clause\n\n5(3) of the West Bengal Excise (Selection of Person for grant of License at\n\nNew Sites for Retail Sale of Spirit and Certain other intoxicants other than\n\nForeign Liquor on categories of licensee and licenses for Denatured Spirit)\n\nOrder, 2000 [For short \"the said Order\"] to contend that some income or\n\nsome property at the hands of the applicants was necessary as otherwise\n\nthey would not be in a position to carry out any business in liquor.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                           9</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">12.          Mr. Rana Mukherjee, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nrespondent Nos. 1 to 3, submitted:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">      (i)       Appellants themselves having obtained a certificate granted by the\n\n                persons specified in the advertisement cannot now question the\n\n                correctness or otherwise of the certificate (s) granted in favour of\n\n                the partners of the respondent No. 1.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">      (ii)      In any event, no such contention having been raised before the\n\n                High Court, this Court should not permit the appellant to raise\n\n                such contention for the first time before this Court.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">      (iii)     Validity and/or legality of the advertisement and/ or the said Order\n\n                having not been challenged by the appellants, the contentions of\n\n                the appellants in that behalf are wholly misplaced.\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_31\">13.          The matter relating to grant of licence is governed by the provisions\n\nof the West Bengal Excise (Selection of New Sites and Grant of license for\n\nRetail Sale of Spirit and certain other Intoxicants) Rules, 1993 (for short\n\n\"the Rules\").\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_32\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">             In the said Order, it is stated that \"unless there is anything repugnant\n\nin the subject or context, words and expressions used in this Order and not\n\ndefined, shall have the meaning respectively assigned to them in the West\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                    10</span>\n\n\nBengal Excise (Selection of New Sites and Grant of License for Retail Sale\n\nof Spirit and Certain Other Intoxicants) Rules, 1993\".\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">      Clause 3 of the said Order provides that \"the State Government may\n\nreserve any new site or sites for settlement amongst firms or societies\n\nformed by unemployed youths under the provisions of any law for the time\n\nbeing in force\" Explanation appended thereto reads as under:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">            \"'Unemployed youth' shall mean any person of or\n            above the age of 21 years but not above 37 years,\n            registered as unemployed in any Employment\n            Exchange in the State of West Bengal and certified\n            to be unemployed by any of the authorities\n            mentioned hereunder in whose jurisdiction such\n            person resides:-\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">            a)     Member of Parliament\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_13\">            b) Member of Legislative Assembly\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_14\">            c) Sabhadhipati of a Zilia Parishad\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_15\">            (d) Sabhadhipati, Siliguri Mahakuma Parishad;\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_16\">            (e) Chairman, Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council,\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_17\">            f) Chief Executive Officer of a notified area;\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_18\">            (g) Mayor or Commissioner of a Municipal\n            Corporation;\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_19\">            (h) Chairman of a Municipality\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_20\">      The relevant portion of Clause 5(3) of the said Order reads as under:\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                     11</span>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_21\">             \"(3) To be eligible for a license, an applicant-\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_22\">             i)     must have sufficient education to enable\n             him to make and follow the calculation necessary\n             for conducting the business and writing accounts\n             appertaining thereto correctly. Knowledge of\n             English is essential only in the case of a foreign\n             liquor shop;\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_23\">             ii)   must be in a position to invest the capital\n             necessary for financing the shop properly without\n             borrowing from others;\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_24\">14.   The question posed before us must be answered inter alia keeping in\n\nview the aforementioned rule.\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_35\">15.   There are three criteria attached thereto, viz., (i) the age of the\n\napplicant, (ii) they have to be registered as unemployed in any employment\n\nexchange in the State of West Bengal and (iii) they have to be certified to be\n\nunemployed by any of the authorities specified therein.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">16.   The meaning of the term `unemployed youth' must be culled out from\n\nthe text and context in which the same appeared.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">17.   In Black's Law Dictionary, 5th edition, `Unemployment' is defined as\n\n`state of being not employed; lack of employment'. The word `unemployed'\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                       12</span>\n\n\nhas been explained in the New Shorter Oxford English Dictionary, 1993 as\n\n`not made use of, use for a particular purpose, not engaged in any\n\noccupation, idle, out of paid employment, redundant'.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">18.       The main thrust in this case, however, appears to be on the\n\nregistration of a person as unemployed in the employment exchange.\n\nCertificate is required to be given by the authorities specified therein as\n\ndespite such registration and/ or continuation thereof, a person may be\n\nemployed with a private person or in some other districts or in some other\n\nstates.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">19.       In a case of this nature, a person cannot be said to be employed only\n\nbecause he earns his bare subsistence livelihood by engaging himself in\n\nsome work. In this case, one of the respondents was helping his brother\n\nwho was owner of the shop. He was not the owner of the shop. The other\n\nrespondent used to carry on business which is of seasonal nature. He was,\n\ntherefore, also not a full fledged businessman. Nothing has been brought on\n\nrecord to show that they were income tax payees or were otherwise\n\nestablished in their life. It may be true that the authorities specified in the\n\nExplanation appended to Clause 3 of the said Order were required to issue\n\ncertificate on the basis of their own concept in regard thereto. It is true that\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                     13</span>\n\n\nno guideline had been issued, but, probably no guideline was required to be\n\nissued, as the said authorities concerned, keeping in view the legal position,\n\nwould be presumed to be aware of the financial status as also the fact as to\n\nwhether they remained unemployed. Furthermore, the said Order does not\n\ncontemplate that the applicants would be absolutely poor or they would not\n\nhave any property at all. They were required to establish a business in\n\nliquor. They were required to make substantial investment. Their financial\n\ncapacity was required to be such so as to enable them to carry out the\n\nbusiness and furthermore fulfill their obligations both contractual and\n\nstatutory in terms of the provisions of the <a href=\"/doc/110162683/\" id=\"a_1\">Excise Act</a>, the Rules framed\n\nthereunder as also the conditions of licence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_41\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">20.   In the instant case, the Division Bench satisfied itself that the\n\nrespondents were to be considered as `unemployed youth' in terms of the\n\naforementioned advertisement.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_43\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_44\">21.   In a situation of this nature, the interpretation clause should be given\n\na contextual meaning. It is not exhaustive. It is trite that when a statutory\n\nenactment defines its terms, the same should govern what is proved,\n\nauthorized or done under or by reference to that enactment. It is also trite\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                     14</span>\n\n\nthat all statutory definitions have to be read subject to the qualification\n\nvariously expressed in the interpretation clause, which created them.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">      <a href=\"/doc/1924149/\" id=\"a_2\">In Feroze N. Dotivala v. P.M. Wadhwani and Others</a> [(2003) 1 SCC\n\n433], this Court held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_46\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_25\">             \"11. It appears that the legislature only intended\n             that in cases where the landlord residing in a\n             premises, parts with possession of a part of it, it\n             would always be open to him to regain the\n             possession of the whole as and when the licensor\n             may so deem necessary. The question of acquiring\n             common lease right by a person not a member of\n             the family may not arise. This is a plain and simple\n             meaning flowing from the definition of the words\n             \"paying guest\" under the Act. Introducing any\n             other element or ingredient to give meaning to the\n             words \"paying guest\" as may be prevalent under\n             any other law or under English law will be doing\n             violence to the definition of the words \"paying\n             guest\" as defined under the Act.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_47\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_48\">      <a href=\"/doc/160705552/\" id=\"a_3\">In State of Maharashtra v. B.E. Billimoria</a> [(2003) 7 SCC 336], this\n\nCourt observed:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_49\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_26\">             \"32. It is well settled that the provisions of the\n             statute are to be read in the text and context in\n             which they have been enacted. It is well settled\n             that in construction of a statute an effort should be\n             made to give effect to all the provisions contained\n             therein. It is equally well settled that a statute\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">\f                                    15</span>\n\n\n             should be interpreted equitably so as to avoid\n             hardship...\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_50\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_51\">        <a href=\"/doc/1443197/\" id=\"a_4\">In P. Kasilingam v. P.S.G. College of Technology</a> [1995 Supp (2)\n\nSCC 348], this Court held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_52\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_27\">             \"A particular expression is often defined by the\n             Legislature by using the word `means' or the word\n             `includes'. Sometimes the words `means and\n             includes' are used. The use of the word `means'\n             indicates that \"definition is a hard-and-fast\n             definition, and no other meaning can be assigned\n             to the expression than is put down in definition\".\n             (See : Gough v. Gough; <a href=\"/doc/67608/\" id=\"a_5\">Punjab Land\n             Development and Reclamation Corpn. Ltd. v.\n             Presiding Officer, Labour</a> Court) The word\n             `includes' when used, enlarges the meaning of the\n             expression defined so as to comprehend not only\n             such things as they signify according to their\n             natural import but also those things which the\n             clause declares that they shall include. The words\n             \"means and includes\", on the other hand, indicate\n             `an exhaustive explanation of the meaning which,\n             for the purposes of the Act, must invariably be\n             attached to these words or expressions'.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_53\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_54\">        <a href=\"/doc/1295007/\" id=\"a_6\">In K.V. Muthu v. Angamuthu Ammal</a> [(1997) 2 SCC 53], this Court\n\nheld:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_55\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_28\">             \"10. Apparently, it appears that the definition is\n             conclusive as the word \"means\" has been used to\n             specify the members, namely, spouse, son,\n             daughter, grandchild or dependant parent, who\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">\f                                    16</span>\n\n\n            would constitute the family. <a href=\"/doc/197743596/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 2</a> of the Act\n            in which various terms have been defined, opens\n            with the words \"in this Act, unless the context\n            otherwise requires\" which indicates that the\n            definitions, as for example, that of \"family\", which\n            are indicated to be conclusive may not be treated\n            to be conclusive if it was otherwise required by the\n            context. This implies that a definition, like any\n            other word in a statute, has to be read in the light\n            of the context and scheme of the Act as also the\n            object for which the Act was made by the\n            legislature.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_29\">            11. While interpreting a definition, it has to be\n            borne in mind that the interpretation placed on it\n            should not only be not repugnant to the context, it\n            should also be such as would aid the achievement\n            of the purpose which is sought to be served by the\n            Act. A construction which would defeat or was\n            likely to defeat the purpose of the Act has to be\n            ignored and not accepted.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_30\">            12. Where the definition or expression, as in the\n            instant case, is preceded by the words \"unless the\n            context otherwise requires\", the said definition set\n            out in the section is to be applied and given effect\n            to but this rule, which is the normal rule may be\n            departed from if there be something in the context\n            to show that the definition could not be applied.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_56\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_57\">      In Bharat Coop. Bank (Mumbai) Ltd. v. Coop. Bank Employees\n\nUnion [(2007) 4 SCC 685], this Court held:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">\f                                    17</span><p id=\"p_58\">\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_31\">            \"23. <a href=\"/doc/1481351/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 2(bb)</a> of the ID Act as initially\n            introduced by Act 54 of 1949 used the words\n            \"means ... and includes\" and was confined to a\n            \"banking company\" as defined in <a href=\"/doc/444965/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 5</a> of the\n            Banking Companies Act, 1949, having branches\n            or other establishments in more than one province\n            and includes Imperial Bank of India. Similarly,\n            <a href=\"/doc/197743596/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 2(kk)</a>, which was also introduced by Act\n            54 of 1949, defines insurance company as \"an\n            insurance company as defined in <a href=\"/doc/992854/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 2</a> of the\n            Insurance Act, 1938 (4 of 1938), having branches\n            or other establishments in more than one\n            province\". It is trite to say that when in the\n            definition clause given in any statute the word\n            \"means\" is used, what follows is intended to speak\n            exhaustively. When the word \"means\" is used in\n            the definition, to borrow the words of Lord Esher,\n            M.R. in Gough v. Gough it is a \"hard-and-fast\"\n            definition and no meaning other than that which is\n            put in the definition can be assigned to the same.\n            (Also see <a href=\"/doc/1443197/\" id=\"a_12\">P. Kasilingam v. P.S.G. College of\n            Technology</a>.) On the other hand, when the word\n            \"includes\" is used in the definition, the legislature\n            does not intend to restrict the definition: it makes\n            the definition enumerative but not exhaustive.\n            That is to say, the term defined will retain its\n            ordinary meaning but its scope would be extended\n            to bring within it matters, which in its ordinary\n            meaning may or may not comprise. Therefore, the\n            use of the word \"means\" followed by the word\n            \"includes\" in <a href=\"/doc/1481351/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 2(bb)</a> of the ID Act is clearly\n            indicative of the legislative intent to make the\n            definition exhaustive and would cover only those\n            banking companies which fall within the purview\n            of the definition and no other.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_59\">22.   Even if we apply the standards which are applicable in the industrial\n\nlaw meaning thereby <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 17B</a> of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 as\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">\f                                      18</span>\n\n\nalso a situation where the question arises as to grant of back wages for not\n\nbeing able to gainfully employed, a person living on mere subsistence\n\nearning as of necessity is not considered to be gainfully employed. [<a href=\"/doc/593688/\" id=\"a_15\">See\n\nNovartis India Ltd. v. State of West Bengal and Ors</a>. [2008 (15) SCALE\n\n470]\n\n\n       Keeping in view the interpretative tools required to be used in a case\n\nof this nature, we are of the opinion, despite the fact that the respondents\n\nhad been earning some money, the same would not disentitle them to take\n\npart in the selection process for grant of a license in terms of the order.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_60\">       The advertisement in question keeping in view the text and context in\n\nwhich it was issued clearly go to show that for the purpose of applying for\n\ngrant of a liquor shop, the respondents were qualified having been\n\ncontinuing to be registered in the Employment Exchange and having been\n\ngranted a certificate in that behalf by the person specified in the\n\nadvertisement.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_61\">\n</p><p id=\"p_62\">       It is not a case where the word `unemployed' should be given a literal\n\nor even the dictionary meaning. In our view, it is required to be given a\n\npurposive meaning; a meaning which is capable of being translated in the\n\naction, a meaning which would not lead to an anomaly or absurdity; a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">\f                                      19</span>\n\n\nmeaning which satisfies the text and context in which the word has been\n\nused.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_63\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_64\">23.      Furthermore, the appellant No. 1 applied for and was granted the\n\nsimilar certificate. It is, therefore, too late in the day for him to contend\n\nnow that the provisions relating to grant of certificate being devoid of any\n\nguideline or objective criteria should be declared ultra vires.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_65\">         In any event, even otherwise, the validity and/or legality of the said\n\nOrder has not been challenged.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_66\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_67\">24.      For the reasons aforementioned, the appeals are dismissed. In the\n\nfacts and circumstances of the case, however, there shall be no order as to\n\ncosts.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_68\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_69\">                                               ...............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_70\">                                               [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n                                               ................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_71\">                                               [J.M. Panchal]\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_72\">January 13, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":7,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"appointment of arbitrator","formInput":"appointment%20of%20arbitrator"},{"value":"ahmedabad municipal corporation","formInput":"ahmedabad%20municipal%20corporation"},{"value":"works contract","formInput":"works%20contract"},{"value":"arbitration proceedings","formInput":"arbitration%20proceedings"},{"value":"altamas kabir","formInput":"altamas%20kabir"},{"value":"kabir","formInput":"kabir"}],"citeList":[{"tid":596725,"url":null,"title":"Section 11 in The Arbitration Act,   1940"},{"tid":1841764,"url":null,"title":"Section 11 in THE ARBITRATION AND CONCILIATION ACT, 1996"},{"tid":1306164,"url":null,"title":"THE ARBITRATION AND CONCILIATION ACT, 1996"},{"tid":605764,"url":null,"title":"Section 11(6) in THE ARBITRATION AND CONCILIATION ACT, 1996"},{"tid":738672,"url":null,"title":"Section 2 in The Arbitration Act,   1940"}],"covers":[],"title":"Om Construction Co vs Ahmedabad Municipal Corp.& Anr on 13 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-13","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":45293057,"url":null,"title":"Sugam Construction (P) Ltd vs Ahmedabad Urban Development on 5 April, 2013"},{"tid":6084728,"url":null,"title":"Rajkamal vs Ahmedabad on 5 September, 2011"},{"tid":163771205,"url":null,"title":"Rajkamal vs Ahmedabad on 5 September, 2011"},{"tid":171625667,"url":null,"title":"Rajkamal vs Ahmedabad on 5 September, 2011"},{"tid":64204702,"url":null,"title":"Chitra Construction Company vs District Panchayat & on 22 January, 2016"}],"tid":1976302,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"_______________j.","numcitedby":8,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33485","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Om Construction Co vs Ahmedabad Municipal Corp.&amp; Anr on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: _______________J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Markandey Katju</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                          IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n               CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n            CIVIL APPEAL NO. 107_______OF 2009\n\n     (Arising out of Special Leave Petition (Civil)\n                    NO.1363 of 2008)\n\n\n\nOm Construction Co.                             ...     Appellant\n\n\n                                   Vs.\n\n\nAhmedabad Municipal Corp. &amp; Anr.                ...     Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                        J U D G M E N T\n</pre>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">ALTAMAS KABIR, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.   Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.   The    appellant    herein    is    a    \"C\"   class   approved\n\ncontractor,     whose     tender        was    accepted     by      the\n\nAhmedabad    Municipal     Corporation        for     providing     and\n\nfixing     Nibhada   Stone   for    paving      and    Footpath     in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                                 2</span>\n\n\nKalupur and Dariapur wards in Central Zone within the\n\nCity of Ahmedabad.              The Work Order was issued on 6th\n\nJune, 2006, and as per the appellant's version the\n\nwork    was   completed          by    the     end     of    October,         2006.\n\nAccording to the appellant, after giving credit for\n\npayments which had been made by the Corporation, a\n\nsum of Rs.68,46,872/- was still due towards the work\n\nperformed     in    the     Dariapur           ward,    while       a    sum     of\n\nRs.8,61,760/- was also due for the work carried out\n\nin Kalupur ward.            It is the case of the appellant\n\nthat    despite         notice        having     been       served       on    the\n\nCorporation        on    24th    May,        2007,     the    said       amounts\n\nremained unpaid. Ultimately, on 6th June, 2007, the\n\nappellant issued a notice to the Corporation setting\n\nout the facts relating to the work performed and the\n\nclaim    made       in     detail        and      claimed       a        sum     of\n\nRs.77,08,632/-, together with interest at the rate of\n\n18% per annum, from the due date till the date of\n\nrealization,       which        the    appellant        claimed,         was    the\n\ntotal outstanding amount.                 In the notice it was also\n\nindicated that the claim made by the appellant should\n\nbe   accepted      and     payment       should        be    made       within       a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                          3</span>\n\n\nperiod of 30 days from the date of receipt of the\n\nnotice or that an Arbitrator should be appointed by\n\nthe Corporation within a period of 30 days from the\n\ndate of receipt of the notice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.   As there was no response to the said notice from\n\nthe Municipal Corporation nor was any payment made or\n\nArbitrator appointed, the appellant invoked clause 30\n\nof Form B-I, which provided for the appointment of an\n\nArbitrator and was made applicable in the contract\n\nentered into between the parties when the appellant's\n\ntender was accepted.       It appears that under General\n\nConditions of Contract of the Engineering Department\n\nof   the   Ahmedabad   Municipal   Corporation,   under   its\n\nGeneral Specifications it is provided that certain\n\nconditions are required to be followed which includes\n\nthe condition that Form B-I would be applicable to\n\nthe contract and clause 30 of Form B-I is relevant\n\nfor this case. The relevant portions of clause 30 of\n\nForm B-I reads as follows :-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">     \"Clause 30(1)   Disputes to be referred to\n     Tribunal:   The disputes relating to this\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                    4</span>\n\n\n       contract, so far as they relate to any of\n       the following matters, whether such disputes\n       arise during the progress of the work or\n       after the completion or abandonment thereof,\n       shall   be   referred  to   the  Arbitration\n       Tribunal, Gujarat State;\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">       (2) ...............\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">       (3) The provision of <a href=\"/doc/1052228/\" id=\"a_1\">Arbitration Act</a>, shall\n       in so far as they are inconsistent with the\n       provision of this Act, cease to apply to any\n       dispute arising from a works contract and\n       all arbitration proceedings in relation to\n       such dispute before an Arbitrator, Court or\n       authority shall stand transferred to the\n       Tribunal.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_9\">4.     The appellant filed a petition before the Gujarat\n\nHigh      Court          on   9th   July,   2007,   being   Arbitration\n\nPetition No. 35 of 2007, under <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 11</a> of the\n\nArbitration and <a href=\"/doc/1306164/\" id=\"a_3\">Conciliation Act</a>, 1996, hereinafter\n\nreferred to as \"the 1996 Act\", inter alia, praying\n\nfor the appointment of an Arbitrator to resolve the\n\ndisputes between the parties. The High Court by its\n\norder dated 20th November, 2007, rejected the said\n\npetition. While doing so, the High Court took note of\n\nSection 2(1)(k) of the Gujarat Public Works Contracts\n\nDisputes Arbitration Tribunal Act, 1992, hereinafter\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                                         5</span>\n\n\nreferred    to     as    the    \"Gujarat      Tribunal        Act\",    which\n\ndefines \"works contract\" to mean a contract made by\n\nthe State Government or Public Undertaking which is\n\nnotified     in     the    Official      Gazette         by    the     State\n\nGovernment.        The High Court also noticed <a href=\"/doc/738672/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 2(1)</a>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">(l)   of    the    aforesaid      Act,     which      defines        \"Public\n\nUndertaking\" to, inter alia, mean such class of local\n\nauthorities       as    the    State    Government        specifies       by\n\nNotification in the Official Gazette. It was further\n\nnoticed that in the absence of such Notification, the\n\nAhmedabad    Municipal         Corporation      was      not    a    \"Public\n\nUndertaking\" and the contract entered into by it with\n\nthe appellant could not, therefore, be termed as a\n\n\"Works Contract\" as defined in <a href=\"/doc/738672/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 2(1)(k)</a> of the\n\naforesaid Act.          The High Court, therefore, held that\n\nthe Arbitration Tribunal, Gujarat State, would have\n\nno jurisdiction to entertain the disputes between the\n\nparties emanating from the Work Order in question.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.    The   High    Court      then    went    on   to    consider       the\n\napplicability       of    the    Arbitration        and       <a href=\"/doc/1306164/\" id=\"a_6\">Conciliation\n\nAct</a>, 1996, to the facts of the case.                     The High Court\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                     6</span>\n\n\ntook note of the fact that the Agreement between the\n\nparties,     and    more       particularly        the     Arbitration\n\nAgreement,    did       not    lay        down   any   procedure    for\n\nappointing         an         Arbitrator          or       Arbitrators.\n\nAccordingly, in the absence of such procedure, the\n\nDesignated Court could not invoke its jurisdiction\n\nunder Sub-section (6) of <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 11</a> of the 1996 Act,\n\nwhich contemplates a situation, where the appointment\n\nprocedure    as    agreed      to    by    the   parties    under   Sub-\n\nsection (2) of <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 11</a> is not followed. The High\n\nCourt, therefore, while rejecting the applicability\n\nof the Gujarat Tribunal Act, also closed the doors\n\nfor relief under the provisions of the 1996 Act.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">6.   The said order of the High Court, which has been\n\nchallenged in this appeal, therefore, gives rise to\n\nthe question as to whether in the absence of any\n\nprocedure     in        the    Arbitration        clause      for    the\n\nappointment of an Arbitrator, can the Chief Justice\n\nof the High Court or the Designated Court appoint an\n\nArbitrator under <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 11(6)</a> of the 1996 Act in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                      7</span>\n\n\nterms of the Agreement between the parties to have\n\ntheir disputes settled by arbitration.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">7.    Mr.    S.K.     Gambhir,       learned        Senior     Advocate\n\nappearing for the appellant company, submitted that\n\nhaving regard to the specific condition contained in\n\nthe   General    Conditions         of    Contract     regarding      the\n\napplication      of     Form       B-I,    the      parties     to    the\n\nArbitration Agreement could not be forced to file a\n\nsuit simply because the procedure for arbitration, as\n\nrequired under <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 11(6)</a> of the 1996 Act, had not\n\nbeen agreed upon by the parties or specified therein.\n\nMr.   Gambhir    urged      that    when    there    was   a   specific\n\nArbitration Agreement between the parties, the remedy\n\nin respect thereof under the 1996 Act could not be\n\ndenied on a mere technicality and if no procedure had\n\nbeen mentioned in the Arbitration Agreement, it could\n\nnot   be    contended       that    on    such   ground       alone   the\n\nprovisions of Sub-section (6) of <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 11</a> could not\n\nbe invoked in view of the provisions of Sub-section\n\n(2)   thereof.        Mr.   Gambhir       submitted    that,     in   any\n\nevent, Sub-section (2) of <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 11</a> would have to be\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                              8</span>\n\n\nread with Sub-clauses (3) to (5) as well and the\n\npowers of the Chief Justice or the Designated Court\n\ncould not be fettered by Sub-section (6).                It was\n\nsubmitted that the Chief Justice or the Designated\n\nCourt     could   in   given     circumstances      appoint   an\n\nArbitrator by applying the provisions of Sub-section\n\n(6) of <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 11</a> of the said Act. It was submitted\n\nthat while the High Court had correctly held that the\n\nprovisions of the Gujarat Tribunal Act would have no\n\napplication in the present case, it had gone wrong in\n\nholding    that   no   relief    could   be   provided   to   the\n\nappellant under the provisions of the 1996 Act also.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8.    Mr. Gambhir also contended that the requirements\n\nof Sub-section (6) of <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 11</a> of the 1996 Act have\n\nall     been   fulfilled,       although,     the   appointment\n\nprocedure had not been indicated by the parties.              He\n\nsubmitted that what was most important is that the\n\nparties had failed to reach an agreement regarding\n\nthe appointment of an Arbitrator to resolve their\n\ndisputes, which was the basic requirement to request\n\nthe Chief Justice or the Designated Court to secure\n\nthe appointment of an Arbitrator.             Mr. Gambhir drew\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                              9</span>\n\n\nour attention to the opinion provided by the Legal\n\nDepartment          of   the    Ahmedabad          Municipal       Corporation\n\nitself       indicating        that      in   the    event    of     a   dispute\n\nbetween a contractor and the Corporation in the work\n\nof the Engineering Department, proceedings will have\n\nto     be      initiated            under      the         Arbitration        and\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1306164/\" id=\"a_15\">Conciliation Act</a>, 1996.                     Mr. Gambhir also drew our\n\nattention        to      an     earlier        order        passed       by   the\n\nDesignated          Court      of     the     Gujarat       High     Court     in\n\nArbitration Petition Nos.46-55 of 2003 in respect of\n\na similar contract, where a retired Judge of the said\n\nHigh     Court       was      appointed       as     Sole    Arbitrator        to\n\nresolve the disputes between the parties after the\n\nparties       had     arrived       at    a   consensus       regarding       the\n\npassing of such an order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">9.     Mr.     Gambhir         submitted            that     the     Ahmedabad\n\nMunicipal Corporation had themselves agreed to the\n\nappointment of an Arbitrator under the 1996 Act and\n\ncould not, therefore, resile from such position in\n\nthe instant case.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                                          10</span><p id=\"p_17\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">10. The stand taken by Mr. Gambhir was opposed by Mr.\n\nShyam Divan, learned Senior Advocate, who supported\n\nthe view taken by the High Court and submitted that\n\nthe appellant's remedy lay in the filing of a suit.\n\nIn the alternative, it was also submitted that the\n\ndecision in the matter could be deferred and a notice\n\ncould be issued to the State of Gujarat to indicate\n\nas to whether it had any intention of publishing a\n\nNotification as contemplated in Section 2(k) of the\n\nGujarat Tribunal Act.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">11. Mr. Divan further submitted that in the absence\n\nof such Notification, clause 30 of Form B-I would\n\nremain   inoperative   and   consequently    the   provisions\n\nrelating to the settlement of disputes by arbitration\n\nwould also not be available to the parties.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">12. Mr. Divan urged that other than Clause 30 of Form\n\nB-I, there was no other provision for arbitration in\n\nthe contract between the parties and the question of\n\ninvoking   jurisdiction      under   the    1996   Act   was,\n\ntherefore, misconceived. Mr. Divan urged that as the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                                                  11</span>\n\n\nbasic requirement of Sub-section (6) of <a href=\"/doc/1841764/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 11</a>\n\nregarding an agreed procedure had not been fulfilled,\n\nneither the Chief Justice nor the Designated Court\n\ncould assume jurisdiction thereunder for appointing\n\nan Arbitrator.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">13. We have carefully considered the submissions made\n\non behalf of the respective parties and it appears\n\nthat we are called upon to decide two questions in\n\norder to decide this appeal. The first and possibly\n\nbasic   question     is   whether     in     the   absence   of        a\n\nNotification in the Official Gazette, the Municipal\n\nCorporation   can    at   all   be    considered    as   a   Public\n\nAuthority for the purpose of Section 2(1)(k) of the\n\nGujarat Tribunal Act, 1992. The other question is\n\nwhether the absence of a procedure for appointment of\n\nan Arbitrator in the Arbitration Agreement itself,\n\nwould   constitute    a   bar   for    the   appointment     of   an\n\nArbitrator under <a href=\"/doc/605764/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 11(6)</a> or any other provision\n\nof the 1996 Act, when not only the parties to these\n\nproceedings, but the High Court as well, had arrived\n\nat a conclusion that the provisions of the Gujarat\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                                                         12</span>\n\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1850110/\" id=\"a_18\">Tribunal Act</a>, 1992, would not be applicable in the\n\ninstant case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">14. In this regard, we are inclined to accept the\n\nsubmissions of Mr. Gambhir notwithstanding the fact\n\nthat the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation had not been\n\nnotified to be a \"Public Undertaking\" as defined in\n\nSection 2(1)(iii) of the Gujarat Tribunal Act, 1992.\n\nThere    is   no      dispute      that     the     Ahmedabad    Municipal\n\nCorporation is a local authority and it could assume\n\nthe garb of a \"Public Undertaking\" only pursuant to a\n\nNotification published in that regard in the Official\n\nGazette.      On the other hand, even if Form B-I loses\n\nits   relevance         as   far     as    the    present     contract    is\n\nconcerned,         since       the        parties      have     agreed    to\n\nresolution       of     their      disputes       by   arbitration,      the\n\nprovisions of Sub-section (5) of the 1996 Act can be\n\npressed into service to enable the parties to invoke\n\nthe     powers     of    the    Chief        Justice     to   appoint     an\n\nArbitrator.        The stand taken by Mr. Divan is highly\n\ntechnical and is not in aid of resolution of the\n\ndisputes between the parties by an Arbitral Tribunal.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                                                           13</span>\n\n\nWhile    recognizing         the    right      of    the     appellant     to\n\napproach the Chief Justice or the Designated Court\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/605764/\" id=\"a_19\">Section 11(6)</a> of the 1996 Act, the stand of the\n\nrespondent Corporation has been that the party should\n\nbe relegated to suit, which is quite contrary to the\n\nstand taken by it in the case of other employees.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">15. <a href=\"/doc/1841764/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 11</a> of the 1996 Act deals exclusively with\n\nthe   appointment       of     Arbitrators.            Sub-section         (2)\n\nprovides that the parties are free to agree on a\n\nprocedure        for     appointing            the      Arbitrator          or\n\nArbitrators      but    subject         to    Sub-section       (6)    which\n\nprovides that if an agreed procedure had not been\n\nacted    upon,    the    parties        could       approach    the    Chief\n\nJustice     or   his     Designate           for    appointment       of   an\n\nArbitrator. Sub-sections (3), (4) and (5) contemplate\n\ndifferent situations in which the Chief Justice or\n\nhis     Designate      could       be   requested       to     appoint     an\n\nArbitrator.      In our view, in the facts of this case,\n\nthe answer to the question thrown up in this appeal\n\nlies in Sub-clause (5) of <a href=\"/doc/1841764/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 11</a> of the 1996 Act,\n\nwhich reads as follows :-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                                                   14</span><p id=\"p_27\">\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">       \"(5) Failing any agreement referred to in\n       sub-section (2), in an arbitration with a\n       sole arbitrator, if the parties fail to\n       agree on the arbitrator within thirty days\n       from receipt of a request by one party from\n       the other party to so agree the appointment\n       shall be made, upon request of a party, by\n       the   Chief   Justice   or  any  person  or\n       institution designated by him.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_28\">16. Having arrived at the aforesaid conclusion, the\n\nonly question that remains to be decided is whether\n\nthis matter should be remitted to the High Court for\n\nappointment of an Arbitrator or whether we should\n\nourselves    appoint     an    Arbitrator     in   terms      of   the\n\nArbitration Agreement.          Remitting the matter to the\n\nHigh     Court   would    only        mean   another     round      of\n\nlitigation, whereas if the appointment is made by us,\n\nthe     matter   will    achieve       finality,      which     would\n\nultimately be beneficial for all concerned.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">17. We,    accordingly,       allow    the   appeal    and    appoint\n\nHon'ble Mr. Justice C.K. Thakker, a former Judge of\n\nthe Supreme Court, presently settled at D-64, Akash\n\nTowers, Judges' Bungalow Road, Vastrapur, Ahmedabad\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">\f                                                                       15</span>\n\n\nto be the Arbitrator for settlement of the disputes\n\nwhich have arisen between the parties.                        The learned\n\nArbitrator       shall    fix    his   own    fees      and   shall   also\n\nformulate the procedure to be adopted by him during\n\nthe arbitration proceedings. The Arbitrator shall try\n\nand publish his Award as expeditiously as possible,\n\nbut positively within six months from the date of\n\nentering upon the Reference. The Arbitrator will also\n\ndecide     the     venue    and    sittings        of      the   Arbitral\n\nTribunal    in     consultation        with    the      parties.      The\n\njudgment and order of the High Court impugned in this\n\nappeal is, accordingly, set aside. The costs of this\n\nappeal     shall     be    the     costs      in     the      arbitration\n\nproceedings.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">                                                     _______________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">                                                       (ALTAMAS KABIR)\n\n\n\n                                                     _______________J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">                                                     (MARKANDEY KATJU)\n\nNEW DELHI\nDated: 13.01.2009\n\f</p>"}, & Ors vs Gurmej Singh on 20 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-20","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":188714471,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=1","title":"Smt. Bachan Kaur And Others vs Kabal Singh & Another on 26 April, 2011"},{"tid":16966786,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=286","title":"Manmohan Kaur vs Davinder Pal Singh on 14 July, 2011"},{"tid":61907156,"url":"http://rhccasestatus.raj.nic.in/smsrhcb/rhbcis/jtextfile.asp?ID=CW&nID=961&yID=1995&doj=1%2F3%2F2013","title":"Bhawani Shanker Meena vs B O R & Ors on 3 January, 2013"},{"tid":6749255,"url":"http://courtnic.nic.in/jodh/judfile.asp?ID=CFA&nID=70&yID=1982&doj=3%2F26%2F2014","title":"Dr. A.A. Bhansali vs Mr. D.R. Bhandari on 26 March, 2014"},{"tid":1854822,"url":null,"title":"Watanmal Boolchand vs N.V. Stoomvaart on 19 February, 1960"}],"tid":177893,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"d","lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":9,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33531","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Jai Singh &amp; Ors vs Gurmej Singh on 20 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                     REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                     CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n               CIVIL APPEAL NO.            321      OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 5414 of 2007)\n\n\n\nJai Singh and Ors.                                            ....Appellants\n\n                                 Versus\n\nGurmej Singh                                           ....Respondent\n\n\n\n                               JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">DR. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the order passed by a learned Single\n\nJudge of the Punjab and Haryana High Court dismissing Second appeal\n\nfiled by the appellant in terms of Section 100 of the Code of Civil\n\nProcedure, 1908 (in short the `CPC'). The basic question considered by the\n\nHigh Court was whether sale of a specific portion of a land described by\n\fparticular Khasra numbers by a co-owner out of the joint khewat would be a\n\nsale of shares out of the joint land or whether the vendees become co-\n\nowners with other co-sharers in the joint land, in the event of their\n\nbecoming co-owners, the sale is pre-emptible under Section 15(1)(b) of\n\nPunjab Pre-emption Act, 1913 (in short the `Act').\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    Background facts essentially are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      Vendor (Bhartu) sold the land measuring 20 kanals, being 400/3723\n\nshare out of the total land measuring 186 kanals 3 marlas vide registered\n\nsale deed dated 11.4.1990 to the appellants for a consideration of\n\nRs.1,80,000/-. Gurmej Singh-respondent filed a suit for possession by way\n\nof pre-emption, wherein it was pleaded that the vendor had sold the land\n\nmeasuring 20 kanals out of the joint Khewat. According to him being the\n\nco-sharer he has a right to pre-empt the sale under Section 15(1)(b) of the\n\nAct. The said suit was contested by the vendees stating that the pre-emptor\n\nhad no superior right of pre-emption. Firstly, the Khewat containing the suit\n\nland had been partitioned between various co-sharers much prior to the sale\n\nthrough an oral partition, and secondly the sale was out of the defined share\n\nof the vendor. On the basis of the pleading of the parties various issues were\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\fframed. But only two issues were contested before the trial Court which are\n\nto the following effect:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">          (1)   Whether plaintiff has superior right to pre-empt the land in\n\ndispute being co-sharer?\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">          (2)   Whether plaintiff is estopped from filing present suit by his\n\nown act and conduct?\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">          On both the issues the trial Court returned its findings in favour of the\n\npre-emptor holding that he had a superior right of pre-emption and that he\n\nwas not guilty of any such act which could stop him for pre-empting the\n\nsame. Appeal before learned District Judge, Kurukshetra, did not bring any\n\nrelief.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">          Stand of the appellants before the High Court was that the sale deed\n\nExt.P-4 clearly indicated that specific Khasra numbers had been sold by the\n\nvendor and defined portion of the joint land has been sold and the vendees\n\nhave been put into possession of the specific khasra numbers. The\n\nappellants who are vendees argued that where a co-sharer sells his share as a\n\nspecified part of joint land the vendees do not become co-sharers the sale\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                         3</span>\n\fbeing not a share out of the joint land. It was, therefore, submitted that the\n\nplaintiff respondent does not become a co-sharer in the property in dispute\n\nand as such has no preferential right of pre-emption with regard to sale of\n\nspecific part of the vendor's share. Reliance was placed on a decision of\n\nFull Bench of the High Court in <a href=\"/doc/1819124/\" id=\"a_1\">Lachhman Singh v. Pritam Chand</a> (AIR\n\n1970 P &amp; H 304).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">      On the other hand respondent relied on a later Full Bench judgment\n\nof the High Court in Bhartu v. Ram Sarup (1981 P.L.J. 204) to support the\n\nview of the lower courts.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">      The High Court noted        that the latter decision had taken into\n\nconsideration Lachhman Singh's case (supra) and observed that the question\n\ninvolved in Lachhman Singh's case was as to whether the purchaser of a\n\nspecific portion of some Killa numbers in two rectangles would become a\n\nco-sharer in the Khewat consisting of several other rectangles and would be\n\nentitled to pre-empt the sale out of the rectangles other than in which he\n\nbecame owner by the said purchase and on these facts it was held that such\n\na purchaser does not become a co-sharer in the Khewat and, therefore, has\n\nno right to pre-empt the sale.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                     4</span>\n\f      The High Court observed that the principles laid down in Lachhman\n\nSingh's case (supra) had no direct bearing on the question whether the sale\n\nof a specific khasra number out of a khewat would be a sale of a share out\n\nof the joint land or not. According to the High Court, answer to the above\n\nquestion depends on inter-se rights of the co-sharers in the joint khewat and\n\nthe nature of the sale of a specified portion of the joint holding.\n\nAccordingly, the High Court held that when a co-sharer sells his share in the\n\njoint holding or in part thereof and put the vendees into possession of the\n\nland in his possession what he transfers is his right as co-sharer in the said\n\nland and the right would remain in his exclusive possession till the joint\n\nholding is partitioned amongst all the co-sharers. The transferee gets the\n\nsame right as that of a transferor to joint possession and has further right to\n\nenforce the partition of the same irrespective of the fact whether the\n\nproperty sold is fractional share or specified portion exclusively in\n\npossession of the transferor. After referring to the sale deed the High Court\n\nnoticed that the vendor had sold the land of his share of 400/3723\n\nmeasuring 20 kanals out of the total land. It was mentioned in the sale deed\n\nthat the possession of the land comprised in the specified khasra numbers\n\nwas delivered to the vendees. However, it was nowhere mentioned in the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                     5</span>\n\fsale deed that the land was ever partitioned or was out of the defined part of\n\nthe land. On the contrary, it was clearly mentioned that the vendor was\n\nselling his 400/3723 share out of the total holding. The High Court turned\n\ndown the plea based on repeal of the right of a co-sharer by the <a href=\"/doc/1596533/\" id=\"a_2\">Amending\n\nAct</a> of 1995. It was observed that right of co-sharers has been held to be\n\nprospective in operation and does not affect the right of the parties to the\n\nlitigation on the date of adjudication of the pre-emption suit and the\n\nAppellate Court is not required to take into account or give effect to the\n\nsubstituted <a href=\"/doc/1596533/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 15</a> introduced by the <a href=\"/doc/1596533/\" id=\"a_4\">Amending Act</a>. Accordingly,\n\nSecond Appeal was dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">4.      Learned counsel for the appellants re-iterated the stand taken before\n\nthe High court and submitted that the ratio of the decision of the Full Bench\n\nin Lachhman Singh's case (supra) has full application to the facts of the\n\ncase.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">5.      In response, learned counsel for the respondent supported the\n\njudgment of the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">\f6.    It is to be noted that the subsequent Full Bench judgment in Bhartu's\n\ncase (supra) the earlier decision in Lachhman Singh's case (supra) was\n\ndistinguished on facts.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">7.    The principles relating to the inter-se rights and liabilities of co-\n\nsharers are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">       (l) A co-owner has an interest in the whole property and also in every\n\n      parcel of it.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      (2) Possession of joint property by one co-owner is in the eye of law,\n\n      possession of all even if all but one are actually out of possession.\n\n      (3) A mere occupation of a larger portion or even of an entire joint\n\n      property does not necessarily amount to ouster as the possession of\n\n      one is deemed to be on behalf of all.</blockquote><p id=\"p_30\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">      (4) The above rule admits of an exception when there is ouster of a\n\n      co-owner by another. But in order to negative the presumption of\n\n      joint possession on behalf of all, on the ground of ouster, the\n\n      possession of a co-owner must not only be exclusive but also hostile\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                     7</span>\n\f      to the knowledge of the other as, when a co-owner openly asserts his\n\n      own title and denies, that of the other.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_32\">      (5) Passage of time does not extinguish the right of the co-owner who\n\n      has been out of possession of the joint property except in the event of\n\n      ouster or abandonment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">      (6) Every co-owner has a right to use the joint property in a husband\n\n      like manner not inconsistent with similar rights of other co-owners.\n\n      (7) Where a co-owner is in possession of separate parcels under an\n\n      arrangement consented by the other co-owners, it is not open to any\n\n      body to disturb the arrangement without the consent of others except\n\n      by filing a suit for partition.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">8.    It is thus evident that when a co-sharer is in exclusive possession of\n\nsome portion of the joint holding he is in possession thereof as a co-sharer\n\nand is entitled to continue in its possession if it is not more than his share\n\ntill the joint holding is partitioned. Vendor cannot sell any property with\n\nbetter rights than himself. As a necessary corollary when a co-sharer sells\n\nhis share in the joint holding or any portion thereof and puts the vendee into\n\npossession of the land in his possession what he transfers is his right as a\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                        8</span>\n\fco-sharer in the said land and the right to remain in its exclusive possession\n\ntill the joint holding is partitioned amongst all co-sharers.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">9.    Sale of subsequent portion of the land out of the joint holding by one\n\nof the co-owners is nothing but a sale of a share out of the joint holding and\n\nis pre-emptible under <a href=\"/doc/1596533/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 15(1)(b)</a> of the Act. It is to be noted that the\n\njudgment in Bhartu's case (supra) had the seal of approval of this Court in\n\nPokhar (dead) by Lrs. and <a href=\"/doc/98872883/\" id=\"a_6\">Ors. v. Ram Singh (Civil Appeal No</a>. 4418 of\n\n1986 disposed of on August 14, 2001).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_37\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">10.   Above being the position, we find no merits in this appeal which is\n\ndismissed accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">                                          .................................................J.\n                                          (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                          ...............................................J.\n                                          (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 19, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                      9</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":0,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"court notice","formInput":"court%20notice"}],"citeList":[],"covers":[],"title":"State Of Orissa & Ors vs Balram Sahu on 27 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-27","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":1089140,"url":null,"title":"Maninder Kaur W/O. Leave granted in both the Special Leave Petitions.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.    The controversy in the two appeals lies within a very narrow\n\ncompass.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">Writ Petition No.3445 of 2004 was filed by the respondent before the Orissa\n\nHigh Court, inter-alia, with a prayer that his license as a Super Class\n\nContractor should not be cancelled by the respondent No.2 i.e. Chairman of\n\fthe Committee of Chief Engineers and Engineers in Chief, Orissa. The Writ\n\nPetition was filed under the apprehension that his license was likely to be\n\ncancelled. The High Court disposed of the Writ Petition by order dated\n\n13.5.2004 after hearing learned counsel for the writ petitioner and learned\n\nGovernment Advocate with a direction that without issuing show cause\n\nnotice to the writ petitioner and without giving him a fair opportunity of\n\nhearing, his license as Super Class Contractor shall not be cancelled and his\n\nsecurity deposit shall not be forfeited.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Several miscellaneous cases were thereafter filed by the respondents.\n\nBy order dated 7.10.2005 the Chairman of the aforesaid Committee directed\n\ncancellation of respondent's license under Rule 11(a) of P.W.D. Contractors\n\nRegistration Rules, 1967 (in short the `Rules'). This was questioned by the\n\nrespondent by filing a writ petition taking the stand that the order was\n\npassed by the Chief Engineer, but no notice was issued prior to passing of\n\nthe order. The High Court by order dated 9.2.2007 allowed the Writ\n\nPetition, quashing several orders passed on the ground that before the\n\ncancellation was done, no notice was given. Reference was made by the\n\npresent appellants to notice purportedly issued on 21.2.2004. It was stated\n\nthat before the order was passed by the High Court in Writ Petition\n\nNo.3445/2004, a show cause notice had already been issued. The\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                      2</span>\n\frespondent filed a rejoinder affidavit taking the stand that after the order\n\nwas passed on 13.5.2004 in the earlier writ petition, no notice was issued.\n\nThe High Court noticed that before cancellation of the license no notice had\n\nbeen issued and the previous writ petition was disposed of with a specific\n\ndirection that without notice and grant of fair opportunity of hearing license\n\nshall not be cancelled and the security shall not be forfeited. Undisputedly,\n\nafter the date of the High Court's order, no notice was issued. Thereafter,\n\nseveral miscellaneous cases were filed for extension of time. An application\n\nwas also filed for modification of order passed on 9.2.2007 by the High\n\nCourt. But the High Court by order dated 25.6.2008 rejected the same and\n\nfurther directed the present appellants to implement the order dated\n\n9.2.2007.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4.    Learned counsel for the appellant-state and its functionaries\n\nsubmitted the earlier writ petition was disposed of without issuance of\n\nnotice and the High Court should have taken note of the fact that prior to the\n\ndate of order, notice had been issued.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.    Learned counsel for the respondent, on the other hand, submitted that\n\nthe High Court specifically directed that before cancellation and forfeiture\n\nnotice has to be given. Even though notice was not formerly issued in the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fearlier petition, learned Government Advocate appeared for the State and its\n\nfunctionaries. He did not bring to the notice of the High Court that any show\n\ncause notice was issued on 21.2.2004. The matter was disposed of on\n\n13.5.2004 i.e. after about three months. It was pointed out that the\n\ncancellation order was passed on 7.10.2005. Before that also there was no\n\nprayer made to modify the earlier order. It was never the stand of the State\n\nand its functionaries about the issuance of notice on 21.2.2004. We find that\n\nthe stand taken by the respondent is factually correct. The order dated\n\n13.5.2004 was very specific to the effect that before cancellation and\n\nforfeiture of security deposit, notice has to be given. That admittedly has not\n\nbeen done. In the circumstances we dispose of both the appeals with a\n\ndirection that the impugned order of the High Court shall remain operative.\n\nIt is open to the appellant-State and its functionaries to issue notice in terms\n\nof the order passed by the High Court in Writ Petition No.3445/2004 and\n\nafter grant of opportunity, decide the matter in accordance with law. The\n\nappeals are accordingly disposed of.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                           ...........................................J.\n
