No. 4563 of 2008)\n\n\n\nSurain Singh                                              ...Appellant\n\n                                      Vs.\n\nState of Punjab                                           ...Respondent\n\n\n\n                               JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">DR. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a learned Single Judge\n\nof Punjab and Haryana High Court            upholding the conviction of the\n\nappellant for offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1259316/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 13(2)</a> of the Prevention of\n\nCorruption Act, 1988 (in short the `Act'). According to the prosecution\n\nversion the appellant while working as a Patwari of Circle Gudher Dhandi\n\fhad demanded illegal gratification of Rs.300/- for entering the mutation on\n\nthe basis of a sale deed. Learned Special Judge, Ferozepur, by judgment\n\ndated 28.5.1996 had found him guilty and sentenced him to undergo\n\nrigorous imprisonment for two years and to pay a fine of Rs.1,000/- with\n\ndefault stipulation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Prosecution version in a nutshell is as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      On 17.12.1990, Kehar Singh complainant approached the accused in\n\nhis office situated near Baghi Hospital, Ferozepur, for entering the mutation\n\nin the names of his sons namely Wasakha Singh and Darshan Singh, on the\n\nbasis of the sale deed relating to 4 kanals land purchased by them from one\n\nAhama Ram son of Mohna Ram resident of Village Gudhar Dhandi for a\n\nconsideration of Rs.10,000/-. The accused demanded a sum of Rs.400/- as\n\nillegal gratification for entering the mutation from the complainant, but the\n\nbargain was settled at Rs.300/-. As the complainant was not willing to pay\n\nthe money, he approached Sohan Singh (a shadow witness) and both of\n\nthem approached the Vigilance Bureau, Ferozepur, where Babu Singh,\n\nInspector Vigilance Department recorded his statement Ex.PF and took into\n\npossession three currency notes of the denomination of Rs.100/- each and\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\fafter applying pehnophsthalene powder and after conducting the personal\n\nsearch of the complainant, handed over to him the said currency notes.\n\nThereafter, he completed the formalities. Sohan Singh was deployed as\n\nshadow witness and he was directed to indicate after the accused accepts the\n\nillegal gratification. Babu Singh Inspector Vigilance Department, made his\n\nendorsement Ex.PF/ 1 on his statement Ex.PF and sent the same to the\n\npolice station, on the basis of which FIR Ex.PR was registered at police\n\nStation City, Ferozepur. On their way to the office of the accused, Hari\n\nSingh, a Government employee was also joined as a witness. When the\n\ncomplainant reached the office of the accused, then the accused enquired\n\nfrom the complainant about the bribe money, which was demanded on the\n\nprevious day. The complainant responded in positive and handed over the\n\naforesaid three currency notes to the accused. After the accused put the\n\nsame into his pocket, Sohan Singh, the shadow witness gave signal after\n\ngoing out of the office and the police apprehended the accused red handed.\n\nInspector Babu Singh after giving his identity arranged a glass tumbler and\n\nput clean water in the same and mixed sodium carbonate and made its\n\nsolution. He got washed the hands of Han Singh in the said water but the\n\ncolour of the water did not change. Thereafter, when the accused washed his\n\nhands, then the colour of the water turned pinkish. Thereafter, Inspector\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n\fBabu Singh transferred the said mixture into an empty nip and prepared its\n\nparcel, sealed it and took the same into possession vide memo Ex.PH.\n\nThereafter, Inspector Babu Singh searched the accused and recovered three\n\ncurrency notes Ex.P1 to Ex.P3 from the front pocket of the shirt worn by\n\nhim. After comparing the numbers of the currency notes with the numbers\n\nrecorded in the memo Ex.PG, possession vide memo Ex.PJ of the same was\n\ntaken. Personal search of the accused was conducted. Documents recovered\n\nfrom him were taken into possession vide memo Ex.PK. He completed the\n\nother formalities; after recording the statements of the witnesses; got the\n\nsanction for prosecution of the accused; collected report of the Chemical\n\nExaminer Ex.PT and challaned the accused. The prosecution established its\n\ncase by examining Jait Kumar, Naib Sadar Kanungo (PW1), Kehar Singh\n\ncomplainant (PW2), Sohan Singh (PW3), Inspector Babu Singh (PW4).\n\nAfter tendering into evidence report of the Chemical Examiner Ex. PT, the\n\nprosecution closed its evidence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      The accused took the plea that he had not accepted any money and\n\nhad not recorded any entry in the mutation register and that the complainant\n\nhad a grudge against him.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                    4</span>\n\f      The trial Court found the prosecution version to be cogent and\n\ncredible and as noted above convicted him. In appeal, the stand taken was\n\nrelating to alleged animosity. The High Court did not find any substance in\n\nthe plea. It was noted that DDR 137 dated 23.11.1989 Ex. DA recorded by\n\nthe accused had no relevance. The demarcation had taken place on\n\n23.11.1989 whereas occurrence took place one year after the incident. In\n\nany event, demarcation of the land is not the final verdict regarding\n\nsurrender of land. It was also noted that so far as DDR 158 dated 8.12.1990\n\nEx. DB is concerned, the accused never gave any complaint to his higher\n\nofficers regarding alleged threat given by the complainant. DDR has been\n\nrecorded by the accused himself. There was nothing to show that the entry\n\nwas made on 8.12.1990. During investigation there was reference to it. For\n\nthe first time it was brought to light at the time of recording of evidence.\n\nAccordingly, the High Court dismissed the appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">4.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the appellant re-iterated\n\nthe alleged animosity between the parties. It was also submitted that the\n\noccurrence took place in the year 1990, and more than 19 years have passed,\n\ntherefore, the sentence needs to be appropriately reduced.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                    5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">\f5.    Learned counsel for the respondent-State supported the judgment.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">6.    The High Court has analysed in great detail the evidence to show that\n\nthe alleged animosity has not been established. Two witnesses PWs 2 and 3\n\nin detail had referred to the factual scenario and nothing discrepant has been\n\nbrought on record to cast any doubt on the credibility of their evidence.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">7.    Day in and day out the gigantic problem of corruption in the public\n\nservants is on the increase. Large scale corruption retards the nation-\n\nbuilding activities and everyone has to suffer on that count. Corruption is\n\ncorroding like cancerous lymph nodes, the vital veins of the body politics,\n\nsocial fabric of efficiency in the public service and demoralizing the honest\n\nofficers. The efficiency in public service would improve only when the\n\npublic servant devotes his sincere attention and does the duty diligently,\n\ntruthfully, honestly and devotes himself assiduously to the performance of\n\nthe duties of his post. (See: <a href=\"/doc/398491/\" id=\"a_2\">Swatantar Singh v. State of Haryana</a> (1997 (4)\n\nSCC 14) and <a href=\"/doc/312089/\" id=\"a_3\">State of M.P. v. Shambhu Dayal Nagar</a> (2002 (1) SCC 1).\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">\f8.    Considering the peculiar facts of the case, we are of the view that the\n\ncustodial sentence of one year, which is minimum prescribed, would meet\n\nthe ends of justice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">9.    The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                                        ...........................................J.\n                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                        ...........................................J.\n                                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 27, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                    7</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":2,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"larsen and toubro ltd ","formInput":"larsen%20and%20toubro%20ltd%20"},{"value":"larsen and toubro","formInput":"larsen%20and%20toubro"},{"value":" s h kapadia","formInput":"%20s%20h%20kapadia"},{"value":"aftab alam","formInput":"aftab%20alam"},{"value":"larsen ","formInput":"larsen%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":789969,"url":null,"title":"The Income- Tax Act,   1995"},{"tid":472660,"url":null,"title":"Section 10(5) in The Income- Tax Act,   1995"}],"covers":[],"title":"Commissioner Of Income Tax vs M/S. Thapar)                                                    (Madhu Saxena)\n     PS to Registrar                                                  Court Master\n</pre><p id=\"p_2\">\fThe signed order is placed on the file.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">\f                             IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                              CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                                 CIVIL APPEAL NO.993 OF 2005\n\n\nCOMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX &amp; ANR.                                          ...APPELLANT (S)\n\n\n                                             VERSUS\n\n\nM/S LARSEN &amp; TOUBRO LTD.                                                   ...RESPONDENT(S)\n\n                                              WITH\n\n                                CIVIL APPEAL NO. 992 OF 2005\n\n\n                                            ORDER\n\n            A short question which arises for determination in these Civil Appeal(s) is -\n  whether the assessee(s) was under statutory obligation under <a href=\"/doc/789969/\" id=\"a_1\">Income Tax Act</a>, 1961, and/or\n  the Rules to collect evidence to show that its employee(s) had actually utilized the amount(s)\n  paid towards Leave Travel Concession(s)/Conveyance Allowance?\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">            It may be noted that the beneficiary of exemption under <a href=\"/doc/472660/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 10(5)</a> is an\n  individual employee. There is no circular of Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) requiring\n  the employer under <a href=\"/doc/789969/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 192</a> to collect and examine the supporting evidence to the\n  Declaration to be submitted by an employee(s).\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">            For the above reasons there is no merit in the Civil Appeals and the same are\n  dismissed with no order as to costs.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">                                                               ....................J.</p><pre id=\"pre_3\">\n                                                               [ S.H. KAPADIA ]\n\n\n\n\n         New Delhi,                                        ....................J\n         January 21, 2009                          [ AFTAB ALAM ]\n\f</pre>"}, {"numcites":0,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"restoration of restoration application","formInput":"restoration%20of%20restoration%20application"},{"value":"application for restoration of restoration application ","formInput":"application%20for%20restoration%20of%20restoration%20application%20"},{"value":"restoration application ","formInput":"restoration%20application%20"},{"value":"srivastava","formInput":"srivastava"},{"value":"cause list","formInput":"cause%20list"},{"value":"non prosecution","formInput":"non%20prosecution"}],"citeList":[],"covers":[],"title":"Raj Kishore Pandey vs State Of U.P. & Ors on 27 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-27","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":666962,"url":"http://bombayhighcourt.nic.in/generatenew.php?path=.%2Fdata%2Fjudgements%2F2010%2F&fname=CWP209910.pdf&smflag=N","title":"District Thane vs Dr. Nigam'S Goodhelth Pvt.Ltd on 30 March, 2010"},{"tid":89745479,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=344664","title":"Ii Addl.Sub Ourt vs Venugopalan Nair"},{"tid":88758505,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=207176","title":"Chennai Vanniakula Kshatriya vs Pon.Ramachandran on 26 November, 2014"},{"tid":1278265,"url":null,"title":"Gur Prasad Satsangi vs State Of Uttar Pardesh And Ors. on 7 April, 1964"},{"tid":1380951,"url":null,"title":"Sarju Pandey vs State on 5 January, 1956"}],"tid":1080073,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":null,"numcitedby":7,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33562","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Raj Kishore Pandey vs State Of U.P. &amp; Ors on 27 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Tarun Chatterjee, H.L. Dattu</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                 NON-REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n                IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL Nos.450-452 OF 2009\n              (Arising out of SLP(C) NOs. 5332-34 of 2008)\n\n\n\nRaj Kishore Pandey                                   ........ Appellant\n\n                                   Versus\n\nState of U.P. &amp; Ors.                                ........Respondents\n\n\n\n                                 ORDER\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">      Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2)    Heard learned counsels for the parties to the lis.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">3)    This appeal is directed against the orders passed by the High Court\n\nof Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No. 20552\n\nof 1988 dated 05.08.2003 and the orders passed on Restoration\n\nApplication No. 216574 of 2005 dated 02.11.2006. By the impugned\n\norders, the court has rejected the writ petition for non-prosecution and\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                          1</span>\n\ffurther, has declined to grant the relief sought in the Restoration\n\nApplication only on the ground that the reasons stated in the affidavit\n\naccompanying the application are not satisfactory.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">4)    A Principal working in the \"Paramhans Sanskrit Pathshala\" is\n\nfighting against the mighty Management for payment of his salary and\n\nother allowances right from the year 1988. Since all his efforts to pursue\n\nthe Management to distribute the arrears of salary and the current salary\n\ndue to him, he was constrained to approach the court, inter alia, requesting\n\nthe court to issue a writ in the nature of mandamus, commanding the\n\nrespondents to release the entire arrears of salary to which he is entitled to\n\nand further, to continue to pay his salary and other allowances as and\n\nwhen the same became due to him.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">5)    Respondents have filed their counter affidavits.         Pleadings are\n\ncomplete. In the interregnum, several petitions/applications are filed\n\nbefore the High Court by both the parties. The appellant has succeeded in\n\nall those interlocutory matters.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                           2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">\f6)    When the matter was posted before the Court on 05.08.2003,\n\nunfortunately for the appellant, his lawyers could not be present before the\n\ncourt, and, therefore, the court has rejected the writ petition for non-\n\nprosecution on the ground that though, one of the learned counsel Shri\n\nR.M. Saggi has sent his illness slip, the other counsel, whose name\n\nappears in the cause list, was not present before the court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">7)    The appellant coming to know about the dismissal of the writ\n\npetition for non-prosecution, had filed Restoration Application, bringing\n\nto the notice of the court that he had engaged the services of Shri R.M.\n\nSaggi and Shri S.P. Srivastava, learned advocates, to prosecute the writ\n\npetition. Shri Saggi was unwell on the date when the writ petition was\n\nposted for hearing and, therefore, he had sent his illness slip and had\n\nrequested the court to accommodate him on account of illness and further,\n\nShri S.P. Srivastava, whose name also appeared in the cause list had been\n\nelevated to the bench of the High Court and, therefore, could not appear as\n\nthe counsel for the appellant.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                         3</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">\f8)    The explanation offered according to the learned Judges is not\n\nsatisfactory   and, therefore, have rejected the Restoration Application.\n\nAggrieved by these two orders, the appellant is before us in this appeal.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">9)    In our view, the approach of the learned Judges, to say the least is\n\nhyper technical. Admittedly, the appellant had engaged the services of\n\nShri S.P. Srivastava and Shri R.M. Saggi. Shri Srivastava is elevated to\n\nthe bench and, therefore, he could not appear as a counsel for the appellant\n\nthough his name was shown in the cause list. The other learned counsel\n\nwas suffering from physical ailment. Admittedly, he had sent \"illness\n\nslip\" with the request for adjournment. When these factual assertions\n\nwere not in dispute, in our opinion, court should have allowed the prayer\n\nmade in the Restoration Application and should have heard the case on\n\nmerits which was pending from last two decades.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">10)   It is true that the appellant has to take necessary steps to prosecute\n\nthe petition by following up action after filing the writ petition. The\n\nappellant had engaged the services of two learned counsels. Unfortunately\n\nfor him, one was elevated to the bench and other was suffering with\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                            4</span>\n\fphysical ailment. All this information was forthcoming in the application\n\nfiled for restoration.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">The High Court has not appreciated these facts. In our opinion, whether\n\nthe applicant has made out sufficient cause or not, in the application filed,\n\nthe court is required to look at all the facts pleaded in the application. No\n\ndoubt, the consideration of the existence of sufficient cause is the\n\ndiscretionary power with the court, but such discretion has to be exercised\n\non sound principles and not on mere technicalities. The approach of the\n\ncourt in such matters should be to advance the cause of justice and not the\n\ncause of technicalities. A case as far as possible should be decided on\n\nmerits and the party should not be deprived to get the case examined on\n\nthe merits.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">11)   In view of above, in our opinion, we cannot sustain the impugned\n\norders passed by the High Court, and therefore, the same requires to be\n\nset aside and the writ petition requires to be restored.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">12)   Accordingly, we set aside the impugned orders. We restore the writ\n\npetition on the file of the High Court. We request the High Court to\n\nconsider the writ petition on merits as expeditiously as possible at     any\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                          5</span>\n\frate within an outer limit of six months from the date of receipt of copy of\n\nthis order, after issuing notice to all the parties concerned.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">13)   The appeals are disposed of accordingly. No order as to costs.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">                                                 .......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                                                 [ TARUN CHATTERJEE ]\n\n\n\n\n                                                .......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                                [ H.L. DATTU ]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 27, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                                      6</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":10,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"culpable homicide","formInput":"culpable%20homicide"},{"value":"section 300","formInput":"section%20300"},{"value":"section 299","formInput":"section%20299"},{"value":"s 299","formInput":"s%20299"},{"value":"murder or culpable homicide","formInput":"murder%20or%20culpable%20homicide"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"intentionally causing death","formInput":"intentionally%20causing%20death"},{"value":" injury not sufficiant to cause death ","formInput":"%20injury%20not%20sufficiant%20to%20cause%20death%20"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"natural death","formInput":"natural%20death"},{"value":"virsa singh","formInput":"virsa%20singh"}],"citeList":[{"tid":626019,"url":null,"title":"Section 300 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":305371,"url":null,"title":"Section 299 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":409589,"url":null,"title":"Section 304 in The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Laxminath vs State Of Chhattisgarh on 16 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-16","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":719109,"url":null,"title":"Raees vs State Of U.P. on 16 July, 2010"},{"tid":193812889,"url":null,"title":"State vs Harjeet Singh @ Raju Fir ... on 28 May, 2013"},{"tid":151550373,"url":null,"title":"State vs . Devender Dass on 28 November, 2014"},{"tid":37534885,"url":null,"title":"State vs (1) Anil S/O. Rajinder Prasad on 31 July, 2012"},{"tid":52150504,"url":null,"title":"State vs Amarjeet S/O. Shankar Sahni, R/O. on 30 July, 2012"}],"tid":215530,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"d","lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":7,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33506","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Laxminath vs State Of Chhattisgarh on 16 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                     REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n              CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 75                 OF 2009\n               (Arising out of S.L.P (Crl.) No.6403 of 2006)\n\n\n\nLaxminath                                             ....Appellant\n\n\n                                 Versus\n\nState of Chhattisgarh                                  ....Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                               JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">DR. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of the Division Bench of\n\nthe Chhattisgarh High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant for\n\nthe offences punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 302</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">324of</a> the Indian Penal\n\fCode, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">IPC</a>'). The accused persons were sentenced to\n\nundergo imprisonment for life and for two years respectively for the said\n\noffences.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Prosecution version as unfolded during trial is as follows:\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      Mahgin Bai (PW-1) lodged the F.I.R (Ex. P-1) in the Police Station\n\nBhairamgarh on 4.2.1993 at about 12.30 p.m. to the effect that on 3.2.1993\n\nshe was thrashing paddy in the house. At that time her mother-in-law\n\nGangadei (hereinafter referred to as the `deceased') was preparing page.\n\nAccused Laxminath who is husband of her sister-in-law, came and\n\ndemanded page. Her mother-in-law gave page to the accused. He thereafter\n\ndemanded tobacco, on which her mother-in-law gave him tobacco also and\n\naccused left the house. Thereafter, the accused came with bow &amp; arrow and\n\nshot the arrow on her, which hit on her left upper arm and blood started\n\noozing out of it. Accused also shot an arrow on her mother-in-law, which hit\n\non chest, blood started oozing out of the injury and accused ran away. Her\n\nuncle-in-law Dhaniram (PW2) witnessed the incident, brought the villagers\n\nand by that time, her mother-in-law was alive. Arrow was stuck in the chest\n\nof her mother-in-law. Villagers took her mother-in-law to Police Station\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\fBhairamgarh from where they took her to Jagdalpur Hospital, but on the\n\nway near Mawlibhata Gangadei she succumbed to the injury. Receiving this\n\nreport, the police registered the FIR (Ex. P-1). The Investigating Officer left\n\nfor the scene of occurrence and took into possession the bow under Ex.P-2.\n\nThe Investigating Officer gave a written request Ex. P-3 to the Assistant\n\nSurgeon, Primary Health Centre, Bhairamgarh for examination of the\n\ninjuries of Mahgin Bai, on which doctor examined and prepared the injury\n\nreport and mentioned that there was one incised wound over left upper arm.\n\nArrow, weapon of offence was taken into possession under Ex.P-4 and the\n\npetticoat of deceased Gangadei was taken into possession under Ex.P-5.\n\nBlood stained soil and plain soil was taken into possession under Ex.P-6\n\nfrom the place of occurrence. Arrow in question was examined by the\n\ndoctor on the request of Station House Officer Ex.P-7 and doctor opined\n\nthat the injury on the body of Mahgin Bai could be caused by the said\n\narrow. Panchnama (Ex.P-10) of the body of Gangadei was prepared after\n\ngiving notice Ex.P-9 to the Panchas. Postmortem on the body of deceased\n\nGangadei was conducted by Dr. S.K. Naik and he prepared the post mortem\n\nreport. There was a dying declaration before PW-6.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\f      After completion of investigation, charge sheet was filed against the\n\naccused/appellant in the Court of learned Additional Chief Judicial\n\nMagistrate, Jagdalpur, who in turn committed the case to learned Sessions\n\nJudge, Jagdalpur from where learned 1st Additional Sessions Judge,\n\nJagdalpur received the case on transfer for trial. As accused pleaded\n\ninnocence, trial was held. Learned trial Judge recorded conviction as noted\n\nabove.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      Before the High Court the basic stand was that the evidence was not\n\nsufficient to fasten guilt on the accused. The oral dying declaration was not\n\nbelievable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      It was also submitted that only one arrow was shot from a distance\n\nand, therefore, <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 302</a> IPC has no application. The High Court did not\n\naccept the plea and upheld the conviction and the sentence.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">4.    The stand before the High Court was reiterated before this Court.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                    4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">\f5.    Learned counsel for the respondent, on the other hand, supported the\n\njudgment of the trial Court as affirmed by the High Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">6.    The basic question is whether <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 302</a> IPC has application.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">7.    In the scheme of the <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_6\">IPC</a> culpable homicide is genus and `murder' its\n\nspecie. All `murder' is `culpable homicide' but not vice-versa. Speaking\n\ngenerally, `culpable homicide' sans 'special characteristics of murder is\n\nculpable homicide not amounting to murder'. For the purpose of fixing\n\npunishment, proportionate to the gravity of the generic offence, the <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_7\">IPC</a>\n\npractically recognizes three degrees of culpable homicide. The first is, what\n\nmay be called, `culpable homicide of the first degree'. This is the gravest\n\nform of culpable homicide, which is defined in <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 300</a> as `murder'.\n\nThe second may be termed as `culpable homicide of the second degree'.\n\nThis is punishable under the first part of <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 304</a>. Then, there is\n\n`culpable homicide of the third degree'. This is the lowest type of culpable\n\nhomicide and the punishment provided for it is also the lowest among the\n\npunishments provided for the three grades. Culpable homicide of this degree\n\nis punishable under the second part of <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 304</a>.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                    5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">\f8.     The academic distinction between `murder' and `culpable homicide\n\nnot amounting to murder' has always vexed the Courts. The confusion is\n\ncaused, if Courts losing sight of the true scope and meaning of the terms\n\nused by the legislature in these sections, allow themselves to be drawn into\n\nminute abstractions. The safest way of approach to the interpretation and\n\napplication of these provisions seems to be to keep in focus the keywords\n\nused in the various clauses of <a href=\"/doc/305371/\" id=\"a_11\">Sections 299</a> and <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_12\">300</a>. The following\n\ncomparative table will be helpful in appreciating the points of distinction\n\nbetween the two offences.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">               Section 299                                          Section 300\n\n\n\nA person commits culpable homicide                          Subject to certain exceptions\nif the act by which the death is caused is done-    culpable homicide is murder\n                                                    if the act by which the\n                                                    death is caused is done -\n\n\n                                            INTENTION\n\n\n        (a) with the intention of causing          (1) with the intention of\n           death; or                               causing death; or\n\n\n        (b) with the intention of causing          (2) with the intention of\n          such bodily injury as is likely          causing such bodily injury\n          to cause death; or                            as the offender knows to be\n                                                          likely to cause the death of\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                             6</span>\n\f                                                            the person to whom the harm\n                                                            is caused;\n                                                             or\n\n\n                                                            (3) With the intention of\n                                                            causing bodily injury to any\n                                                            person and the bodily injury\n                                                            intended to be inflicted\n                                                                   is sufficient in the\n                                                                            ordinary course   of\n           nature\n                                                            to cause death; or\n\n\n                                      KNOWLEDGE\n                                                ****\n\n\n      (c) with the knowledge that the act       (4) with the knowledge that\n          is likely to cause death.                       the act is so imminently\n                                                            dangerous that it must in all\n                                                            probability cause death or\n                                                            such bodily injury as is\n                                                            likely to cause death, and\n                                                            without any excuse for\n                                                            incurring the risk of causing\n                                                            death or such injury as is\n                                                            mentioned above.\n\n\n\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_21\">9.   Clause (b) of <a href=\"/doc/305371/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 299</a> corresponds with clauses (2) and (3) of\n\n<a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 300</a>. The distinguishing feature of the mens rea requisite under\n\nclause (2) is the knowledge possessed by the offender regarding the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                            7</span>\n\fparticular victim being in such a peculiar condition or state of health that the\n\ninternal harm caused to him is likely to be fatal, notwithstanding the fact\n\nthat such harm would not in the ordinary way of nature be sufficient to\n\ncause death of a person in normal health or condition. It is noteworthy that\n\nthe `intention to cause death' is not an essential requirement of clause (2).\n\nOnly the intention of causing the bodily injury coupled with the offender's\n\nknowledge of the likelihood of such injury causing the death of the\n\nparticular victim, is sufficient to bring the killing within the ambit of this\n\nclause. This aspect of clause (2) is borne out by illustration (b) appended to\n\n<a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 300</a>.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">10.   Clause (b) of <a href=\"/doc/305371/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 299</a> does not postulate any such knowledge on\n\nthe part of the offender. Instances of cases falling under clause (2) of\n\n<a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 300</a> can be where the assailant causes death by a fist blow\n\nintentionally given knowing that the victim is suffering from an enlarged\n\nliver, or enlarged spleen or diseased heart and such blow is likely to cause\n\ndeath of that particular person as a result of the rupture of the liver, or\n\nspleen or the failure of the heart, as the case may be. If the assailant had no\n\nsuch knowledge about the disease or special frailty of the victim, nor an\n\nintention to cause death or bodily injury sufficient in the ordinary course of\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                     8</span>\n\fnature to cause death, the offence will not be murder, even if the injury\n\nwhich caused the death, was intentionally given. In clause (3) of <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_18\">Section\n\n300</a>, instead of the words `likely to cause death' occurring in the\n\ncorresponding clause (b) of <a href=\"/doc/305371/\" id=\"a_19\">Section 299</a>, the words \"sufficient in the\n\nordinary course of nature\" have been used. Obviously, the distinction lies\n\nbetween a bodily injury likely to cause death and a bodily injury sufficient\n\nin the ordinary course of nature to cause death. The distinction is fine but\n\nreal and if overlooked, may result in miscarriage of justice. The difference\n\nbetween clause (b) of <a href=\"/doc/305371/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 299</a> and clause (3) of <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 300</a> is one of\n\nthe degree of probability of death resulting from the intended bodily injury.\n\nTo put it more broadly, it is the degree of probability of death which\n\ndetermines whether a culpable homicide is of the gravest, medium or the\n\nlowest degree. The word `likely' in clause (b) of <a href=\"/doc/305371/\" id=\"a_22\">Section 299</a> conveys the\n\nsense of probable as distinguished from a mere possibility. The words\n\n\"bodily injury.......sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death\"\n\nmeans that death will be the \"most probable\" result of the injury, having\n\nregard to the ordinary course of nature.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">11.   For cases to fall within clause (3), it is not necessary that the offender\n\nintended to cause death, so long as the death ensues from the intentional\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                      9</span>\n\fbodily injury or injuries sufficient to cause death in the ordinary course of\n\nnature. Rajwant and Anr. v. State of Kerala, (AIR 1966 SC 1874) is an apt\n\nillustration of this point.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">12.    <a href=\"/doc/1296255/\" id=\"a_23\">In Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab</a>, (AIR 1958 SC 465), Vivian Bose,\n\nJ. speaking for the Court, explained the meaning and scope of clause (3). It\n\nwas observed that the prosecution must prove the following facts before it\n\ncan bring a case under <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_24\">Section 300</a>, \"thirdly\". First, it must establish quite\n\nobjectively, that a bodily injury is present; secondly the nature of the injury\n\nmust be proved. These are purely objective investigations. Thirdly, it must\n\nbe proved that there was an intention to inflict that particular injury, that is\n\nto say, that it was not accidental or unintentional or that some other kind of\n\ninjury was intended. Once these three elements are proved to be present, the\n\nenquiry proceeds further, and fourthly it must be proved that the injury of\n\nthe type just described made up of the three elements set out above was\n\nsufficient to cause death in the ordinary course of nature. This part of the\n\nenquiry is purely objective and inferential and has nothing to do with the\n\nintention of the offender.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                     10</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">\f13.   The ingredients of clause \"Thirdly\" of <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_25\">Section 300</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_26\">IPC</a> were brought\n\nout by the illustrious Judge in his terse language as follows:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">      \"To put it shortly, the prosecution must prove the following\n      facts before it can bring a case under <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_27\">Section 300</a>, \"thirdly\".\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      First, it must establish, quite objectively, that a bodily injury is\n      present.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">      Secondly, the nature of the injury must be proved. These are\n      purely objective investigations.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">      Thirdly, it must be proved that there was an intention to inflict\n      that particular bodily injury, that is to say that it was not\n      accidental or unintentional, or that some other kind of injury\n      was intended.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">      Once these three elements are proved to be present, the enquiry\n      proceeds further and,\n\n\n      Fourthly, it must be proved that the injury of the type just\n      described made up of the three elements set out above is\n      sufficient to cause death in the ordinary course of nature. This\n      part of the enquiry is purely objective and inferential and has\n      nothing to do with the intention of the offender.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_30\">14.   The learned Judge explained the third ingredient in the following\n\nwords (at page 468):\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">             \"The question is not whether the prisoner intended to\n             inflict a serious injury or a trivial one but whether he\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                     11</span>\n\f             intended to inflict the injury that is proved to be present.\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">             If he can show that he did not, or if the totality of the\n             circumstances justify such an inference, then of course,\n             the intent that the section requires is not proved. But if\n             there is nothing beyond the injury and the fact that the\n             appellant inflicted it, the only possible inference is that\n             he intended to inflict it. Whether he knew of its\n             seriousness or intended serious consequences, is neither\n             here or there. The question, so far as the intention is\n             concerned, is not whether he intended to kill, or to inflict\n             an injury of a particular degree of seriousness but\n             whether he intended to inflict the injury in question and\n             once the existence of the injury is proved the intention to\n             cause it will be presumed unless the evidence or the\n             circumstances warrant an opposite conclusion.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">15.   These observations of Vivian Bose, J. have become locus classicus.\n\nThe test laid down by Virsa Singh's case (supra) for the applicability of\n\nclause \"Thirdly\" is now ingrained in our legal system and has become part\n\nof the rule of law. Under clause thirdly of <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_28\">Section 300</a> IPC, culpable\n\nhomicide is murder, if both the following conditions are satisfied: i.e. (a)\n\nthat the act which causes death is done with the intention of causing death\n\nor is done with the intention of causing a bodily injury; and (b) that the\n\ninjury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature\n\nto cause death. It must be proved that there was an intention to inflict that\n\nparticular bodily injury which, in the ordinary course of nature, was\n\nsufficient to cause death, viz., that the injury found to be present was the\n\ninjury that was intended to be inflicted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                                      12</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">\f16.   Thus, according to the rule laid down in Virsa Singh's case, even if\n\nthe intention of accused was limited to the infliction of a bodily injury\n\nsufficient to cause death in the ordinary course of nature, and did not extend\n\nto the intention of causing death, the offence would be murder. Illustration\n\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">(c) appended to <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_29\">Section 300</a> clearly brings out this point.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">17.   Clause (c) of <a href=\"/doc/305371/\" id=\"a_30\">Section 299</a> and clause (4) of <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_31\">Section 300</a> both require\n\nknowledge of the probability of the act causing death. It is not necessary for\n\nthe purpose of this case to dilate much on the distinction between these\n\ncorresponding clauses. It will be sufficient to say that clause (4) of <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_32\">Section\n\n300</a> would be applicable where the knowledge of the offender as to the\n\nprobability of death of a person or persons in general as distinguished from\n\na particular person or persons - being caused from his imminently\n\ndangerous act, approximates to a practical certainty. Such knowledge on\n\nthe part of the offender must be of the highest degree of probability, the act\n\nhaving been committed by the offender without any excuse for incurring the\n\nrisk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">18.   The above are only broad guidelines and not cast iron imperatives. In\n\nmost cases, their observance will facilitate the task of the Court. But\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                     13</span>\n\fsometimes the facts are so intertwined and the second and the third stages so\n\ntelescoped into each other that it may not be convenient to give a separate\n\ntreatment to the matters involved in the second and third stages.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">19.   The position was illuminatingly highlighted by this Court in <a href=\"/doc/605891/\" id=\"a_33\">State of\n\nAndhra Pradesh v. Rayavarapu Punnayya and Anr</a>. (1976 (4) SCC 382),\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1506749/\" id=\"a_34\">Abdul Waheed Khan @ Waheed and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh (JT</a>\n\n2002 (6) SC 274), and <a href=\"/doc/252459/\" id=\"a_35\">Augustine Saldanha v. State of Karnataka</a> (2003 (10)\n\nSCC 472) and <a href=\"/doc/11797992/\" id=\"a_36\">Thangaiya v. State of Tamil Nadu</a> (2005 (9) SCC 650).\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">20.   Considering the factual scenario and the facts that one arrow was shot\n\n      the offence is covered by <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_37\">Section 304</a> Part I IPC and not <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_38\">Section 302</a>\n\n      IPC. Though it cannot be laid down that whenever one arrow is shot\n\n      <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_39\">Section 302</a> IPC will not apply, on the facts of the present case it\n\n      appears to be so. Therefore, conviction is altered from <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_40\">Section 302</a>\n\n      IPC to <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_41\">Section 304</a> Part I IPC. Custodial sentence of eight years\n\n      would meet the ends of justice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_42\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">21.   Appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_44\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">                                     14</span>\n\f                                                          .........\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_46\">                                                  (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                                  ...............................................J.\n                                                  (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 13, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                                             15</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":4,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"amendment application","formInput":"amendment%20application"},{"value":"amendment in amendment application","formInput":"amendment%20in%20amendment%20application"},{"value":"town planning scheme","formInput":"town%20planning%20scheme"},{"value":"town planning","formInput":"town%20planning"},{"value":"what is peacful possession","formInput":"what%20is%20peacful%20possession"},{"value":"amendment of plaint","formInput":"amendment%20of%20plaint"},{"value":"surat municipal corporation","formInput":"surat%20municipal%20corporation"},{"value":"pankaja ","formInput":"pankaja%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":320135,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=26280","title":"Pankaja & Anr vs Yellappa (D) By Lrs. & Ors on 5 August, 2004"},{"tid":1033493,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=20630","title":"Sampath Kumar vs Ayyakannu And Anr on 13 September, 2002"},{"tid":1556317,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=20456","title":"Siddalingamma And Anr vs Mamtha Shenoy on 18 October, 2001"},{"tid":908527,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=683","title":"L. Sinha, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                                            REPORTABLE\n\n                                    IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                                     CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                                       CIVIL APPEAL NO.154 OF 2009\n                                    [Arising out of S.L.P.(C)No.9931 of 2008]\n\n        Alkapuri Co-operative Housing Society Ltd.              .....Appellant\n\n                     Versus\n\n        Jayantibhai Naginbhai (deceased) Thr.LRs.               .....Respondents\n\n\n                                                    ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">        1.           Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">        2.           This appeal is directed against the judgment and order dated 03rd March 2008\n\n        passed by a learned Single Judge of the High Court of Gujarat in Special Civil Application\n\n        No.451 of 2008 whereby and whereunder the said Application against an order dated 01st\n\n        December 2007 passed by the learned 3rd Additional Sr. Civil Judge, Surat in Regular Civil\n\n        Suit No.669 of 1985 dismissing an application of the respondent seeking amendment to the\n\n        plaint, was allowed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">        3.           The basic fact of the matter is not in dispute.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">        4.           Plaintiff-appellant filed a suit against Surat Municipal Corporation in its\n\n        capacity both as a town planner and as Local Authority on or about 08th May 1985 before\n\n        the learned Civil Judge, Surat which was earmarked as Regular Civil Suit No.617 of 1985.\n\n        Deceased-respondent herein, claiming to be an allottee in respect of plot no.29-B of the\n\n        Town Planning Scheme No.3 also filed a suit against the appellant herein praying, inter\n\n        alia, for the following reliefs :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">C.A.No.154/09 @ SLP(C)No.9931/08 .... (contd.)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                         -2-</span>\n\f                             \"Therefore the plaintiff humbly prays that,\n\n                            (1) be pleased to restrain the defendants from interfering and\n                 causing obstruction on the land situated in Surat City, Katargam Town\n                 Planning Scheme No.3 having Final Plot No.29-B or cause to interfere, and to\n                 restrain from causing any interference or obstruction in their possession and\n                 occupation, nor put up any compound wall or fencing, such injunction orders\n                 be passed against the defendants.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">                 (2) be pleased to award the entire costs of this suit from the defendants.\n\n                 (3) be pleased to grant any other and further relief as may deem fit in the\n                 facts of this matter.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">        5.           Indisputably, in the said suit, the respondent-plaintiff filed an application for\n\n        grant of temporary injunction which was rejected by an order dated 18th December 1985.\n\n        Respondent thereafter filed an application for his impleadment in the suit filed by the\n\n        appellant herein. We are informed at the Bar that the said matter is pending before the\n\n        Gujarat High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">        6.           Legal representatives of the deceased respondent on or about 09th April 2003\n\n        filed an application for amendment of the plaint in terms whereof they not only sought to\n\n        implead Town Planner, Surat Municipal Corporation but also Surat Municipal\n\n        Corporation as such as party defendants.           In the said application for amendment,\n\n        respondents, inter alia, contended that having regard to an order of injunction passed in\n\n        the suit by the appellant, they did not obtain peaceful possession of the plot in question.\n\n        On the aforementioned premise, the following paragraphs were sought to be added in the\n\n        plaint :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">C.A.No.154/09 @ SLP(C)No.9931/08 .... (contd.)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                       -3-</span>\n\n                 \"... ...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">                 Alternatively,\n\n                 Below the Town Planning Scheme the defendant No.1 in this matter has not\n\f                  handed over the peaceful posession of the Final Plot No.29-B, if the\n                  Honourable Court should arrive on such decision then in these circumstances\n                  the defendants in this matter or the defendant who is held responsible then\n                  from the said defendant the peaceful possession of the Final Plot No.29-B be\n                  allotted from the defendant Nos.2-3 from other lands admeasuring 3689\n                  sq.mts. land be allotted for obtaining such relief the suit is filed.\n\n                  Amendment No.3\n\n                  (1-a) Alternatively if the Honourable Court arrives at the conclusion that in\n                  this matter the peaceful possession of the suit Final Plot No.29-B of the\n                  defendant No.1 is not handed over to the plaintiff then in these circumstances\n                  the final Plot No.29-B 3689 sq.mts. of land peaceful possession be awarded\n                  from the defendant or any defendant held responsible, and the decree to this\n                  effect be passed in favour of the plaintiff and if the Honourable Court does\n                  not find it appropriate to pass such orders then from amongst the defendants\n                  paiki any of the defendants that is held responsible then the land equal to the\n                  Final Plot No.29-B 3689 sq.mts. of other land be allotted to the plaintiff, and\n                  hand over the peaceful possession in favour of the plaintiffs, for this if found\n                  necessary then the Commissioner of appropriate authority be appointed and\n                  accordingly the possession of the land be handed over, be pleased to pass such\n                  orders in the interest of justice.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">        7.           The said application for amendment of plaint was dismissed by the learned 3rd\n\n        Additional Sr. Civil Judge on 01st December 2007, inter alia, opining that having regard to\n\n        the provisions of Section 487 of the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporation Act, no suit\n\n        could have been filed against the Corporation until expiration of one month from the\n\n        date of\n\n        service of notice issued for the said purpose. It was\n\nC.A.No.154/09 @ SLP(C)No.9931/08 .... (contd.)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                       -4-</span>\n\n        furthermore opined that the respondents could not be permitted to amend the plaint after a\n\n        period of 18 years of filing of the suit.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">        8.           The High Court, however, as noticed hereinbefore, by reason of the impugned\n\n        judgment, reversed the said order dated 01st December 2007, inter alia, relying on or on the\n\n        basis of the decisions of this Court in the case of <a href=\"/doc/320135/\" id=\"a_1\">Pankaja &amp; Anr. v. Yellappa (Dead</a>) by\n\n        LRs &amp; Ors. (2004) 6 SCC 415 and <a href=\"/doc/1033493/\" id=\"a_2\">Sampath Kumar v. Ayyakannu &amp; Anr</a>. (2002) 7 SCC\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">\f        559.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">        9.           Mr. Amar Dave, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant would\n\n        submit that the High Court committed a serious error in passing the impugned judgment\n\n        insofar as it failed to take into consideration that the plaintiff-respondents, by reason of the\n\n        said application for amendment of the plaint, sought to change the entire nature and\n\n        character of the suit. According to the learned counsel, the plaintiff-respondents in their\n\n        suit proceeded on the basis that they were in possession of the plot No.29-B, i.e., the plot in\n\n        suit. However, as no order of injunction had been passed in the said suit, as had been\n\n        prayed for by the deceased respondent and furthermore in view of the fact that an order of\n\n        injunction had been passed in favour of the appellant in its suit, they have not only sought\n\n        to implead the Town Planner as a party defendant in the suit but had prayed for an\n\n        alternative relief to grant allotment of an alternative plot in the event they are not found to\n\n        be in possession of the said plot.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">C.A.No.154/09 @ SLP(C)No.9931/08 .... (contd.)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                       -5-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">        10.          Mr. K.K. Trivedi, learned counsel appearing for the respondents would contend\n\n        that whereas the appellant herein had filed a suit questioning the legality and/or validity of\n\n        the Town Planning Scheme, in effect and substance, by reason of the amendment sought\n\n        for in the plaint, the deceased respondent prayed for implementation of the Town Planning\n\n        Scheme. In that view of the matter, the learned counsel would contend that neither only\n\n        the question of limitation arises but also if the amendment of the plaint, as prayed for, is\n\n        allowed, the real issue between the parties would be determined as a result whereof\n\n        multiplicity of proceedings can be avoided.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">        11.          It is unfortunate that two suits filed by the parties hereto as far back as in 1985\n\n        are still pending before the learned Civil Judge for one reason or the other. The fact,\n\n        however, remains that the deceased-respondent who were was not a party to the appellant's\n\f        suit being Suit No.617 of 1985, had filed a suit subsequent thereto only with a prayer of\n\n        grant of permanent injunction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">        12.          In the year 2003, long after the deceased respondent's prayer for injunction had\n\n        been rejected, his legal representatives filed the aforementioned application for amendment\n\n        of the plaint. A bare perusal of the prayers made in the said application clearly goes to\n\n        show that by reason thereof the no prayer has been claimed by the respondents as against\n\n        the appellant herein. The alternative prayer, if it is to be granted, can be granted only\n\n        against the Corporation as Town\n\nC.A.No.154/09 @ SLP(C)No.9931/08 .... (contd.)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                      -6-</span>\n\n        Planner as also as the local authority in their statutory capacities, whether such an\n\n        alternative plot could be allotted to the plaintiff-respondents is a matter of concern by and\n\n        between the Town Planner and the plaintiff-respondents wherewith the defendant-\n\n        appellant had nothing to do.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">        13.          Respondents, we may notice, in their counter affidavit filed before us themselves\n\n        have categorically stated that they, in law, are entitled to take recourse to such remedies as\n\n        are available to them for the purpose of grant of allotment of an alternative plot and/or for\n\n        implementation of the Town Planning Scheme. If they had an independent cause of action\n\n        against the Corporation either in its capacity as a town planner or as a local authority, in\n\n        our opinion, the same by itself cannot be a ground for filing an application for amendment\n\n        in the suit pending between the parties wherein, inter alia, the question of possession, inter\n\n        se, is required to be determined.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">        14.          The High Court as also the learned counsel appearing for the respondents, as\n\n        noticed hereinbefore, have strongly relied upon the decision of this Court in the case of\n\n        Pankaja (supra) wherein relying on or on the basis of a decision of this Court in the case of\n\n        <a href=\"/doc/908527/\" id=\"a_3\">L.J. Leach &amp; Co. Ltd. v. Jardine Skinner &amp; Co</a>. AIR 1957 SC 357, this Court opined that\n\f        in an application for amendment of the plaint it may have to be kept in mind that the\n\n        discretionary jurisdiction in that behalf can be exercised by the court even if the suit is\n\n        barred by limitation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\nC.A.No.154/09 @ SLP(C)No.9931/08 .... (contd.)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                      -7-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">        15.          It is neither in doubt nor in dispute that the court's jurisdiction to consider an\n\n        application for amendment of pleading is wide in nature, but, when, by reason of an\n\n        amendment, a third party is sought to be impleaded not only the provisions of O.VI R.17,\n\n        Code of Civil Procedure (C.P.C.) but also the provisions of O.I R.10, C.P.C. would come\n\n        into play. When a new party is sought to be added, keeping in view the provisions of sub-\n\n        rule (5) of Rule 10 of Order I, C.P.C., the question of invoking the period of limitation\n\n        would come in.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">        16.          The High Court, in our opinion, in a case of this nature, should not have\n\n        interfered with the discretionary jurisdiction exercised by the learned 3rd Additional Sr.\n\n        Civil Judge. The question as to whether an application for amendment should be allowed\n\n        in spite of delay and laches in moving the same, would depend upon the facts and\n\n        circumstances of each case wherefor a judicial evaluation would be necessary.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">        17.          The decision in the case of     Pankaja (supra) itself is an authority for that\n\n        proposition. So far as the decision in the case of Sampat Kumar (supra) is concerned, this\n\n        Court has struck a bit different note therein as it was observed :\n\n\n\n</p>                 \"10. An amendment once incorporated relates back to the date of the suit.<p id=\"p_27\">\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">                 However, the doctrine of relation-back in the context of amendment of\n                 pleadings is not one of universal application and in appropriate cases the court\n                 is competent while permitting an amendment to direct that the amendment\n                 permitted by it shall not relate back to the date of the suit and to the extent\n                 permitted by it shall be deemed to have been brought before the court on the\n                 date on which the application\n\fC.A.No.154/09 @ SLP(C)No.9931/08 .... (contd.)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                     -8-</span>\n\n\n                 seeking the amendment was filed. [See observations in <a href=\"/doc/1556317/\" id=\"a_4\">Siddalingamma v.\n                 Mamtha Shenoy</a> (2001) 8 SCC 561].\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">        18.          There cannot be any doubt or dispute that an application for amendment of the\n\n        plaint seeking to introduce a cause of action which had arisen during the pendency of the\n\n        suit stands on a different footing than the one which had arisen prior to the date of\n\n        institution of the suit. We have noticed hereinbefore that the plaintiff-respondents in their\n\n        application for amendment of the plaint themselves accepted the fact that the appellant\n\n        herein not only had filed a suit prior in point of time to the suit filed by the deceased\n\n        respondent but had also obtained an injunction as a result whereof they did not obtain\n\n        effective possession of the suit land. If that be so, in our opinion, the plaintiff-respondents\n\n        in effect and substance are seeking to alter the basic structure of the suit which in the case\n\n        of Sampath Kumar (supra) itself has been held to be impermissible.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">        19.          For the reasons aforementioned, we are of the opinion that the High Court\n\n        committed a jurisdictional error in interfering with the well considered judgment and order\n\n        of the learned 3rd Additional Sr. Civil Judge rejecting the application filed by the\n\n        respondents for amendment of the plaint. The impugned judgment is, therefore, set aside\n\n        and the appeal is allowed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_32\">\n\nC.A.No.154/09 @ SLP(C)No.9931/08 .... (contd.)\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                     -9-</span>\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">        20.          However, if the respondents have independent cause of action against the\n\n        Municipal Corporation, they may take recourse to such remedies which are available in law.\n\f                                     Sd/-\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                    .........................J.\n                    [S.B. SINHA]\n\n\n\n                                     Sd/-\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                    .........................J.</blockquote><p id=\"p_34\">\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">                    [DR. India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33526","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Daya Shankar vs State Of M.P on 20 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.                 OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 5953 of 2006)\n\n\nDaya Shankar                                             ..Appellant\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of M.P.                                            ..Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nMadhya Pradesh High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant for\n\noffence punishable under Section 302 read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 34</a> of the Indian\n\nPenal Code, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') as was awarded by learned Additional\n\nSessions Judge, Panna, in Sessions Trial No.15/1992.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">\f3.    Prosecution version as unfolded during trial is as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      On 30th November, 1991 at about 5.00 p.m. Ram Kishore (hereinafter\n\nreferred to as the `deceased') was murdered in an agricultural field. First\n\nInformation Report was lodged by Manik Lal at Police Station, Pawal in the\n\nevening at about 7.00 p.m. Offence was registered as Crime No.124/91\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_4\">34</a> IPC. Deceased had eloped with Lalli, sister of\n\nRamcharan (A-2) and both of them had performed court marriage. The court\n\nmarriage was registered and Lalli was living with Ramkishore. The\n\nappellant was having enmity with deceased on account of aforesaid\n\nincident. Deceased after eloping with Lalli was living in some other village\n\nand returned to his village a month before the incident. Ramkishore had\n\ngone to answer the call of nature in the evening on 30.11.1991 at about 4.30\n\np.m. towards the agricultural field of Gadka. Around 5 p.m. Phulla (A-3)\n\narmed with axe, Ramcharan (A-2) armed with sword alongwith\n\nDayashankar (A-1) and Munni Lal (A-4) went to the field of Gadaka. Munni\n\nLal and Dayashankar were barehanded. Phulla gave axe blow on the head of\n\ndeceased. Thereafter, Dayashankar and Munnilal, the co-accused pulled the\n\nlegs of deceased and threw him on the ground. Ram Kishore fell on the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\fcrops in the field. Ramcharan assaulted the deceased by sword on the chest.\n\nThen he placed his sword on the chest of the deceased. On account of\n\nbeating he died. Police after receiving information of the commission of\n\ncrime carried out the investigation, arrested the accused persons and filed\n\nthe challan on 3.1.1992 before the Court of Judicial Magistrate. Case was\n\ncommitted to the Court of Sessions Judge. Trial Court framed charges under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_6\">34</a> IPC against the accused persons. After recording the\n\nevidence the trial Court convicted the accused persons for offence under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_7\">Sections 302</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 34</a> IPC and sentenced them as afore-noted.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      Before the High Court the basic stand was that the prosecution failed\n\nto prove common intention on the part of the appellants and, therefore,\n\n<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 34</a> had no application. The individual act of the appellant should\n\nhave been considered. Merely because the appellant had accompanied other\n\naccused persons, that cannot be sufficient to warrant presumption of\n\ncommon intention.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">4.    Learned counsel for the State submitted that the eye witnesses PWs 2\n\nand 3 had described the act of each of the appellants and the role ascribed to\n\nthe appellant was that he pulled the leg of the deceased as a result of which\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fdeceased fell in the field of Masur crop and thereafter he was assaulted by\n\nother accused persons. The appeal was dismissed accepting the stand of the\n\nState.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">5.       Learned counsel for the appellant re-iterated the stand taken before\n\nthe High Court and submitted that <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 34</a> IPC has no application.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">6.       Learned counsel for the State on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">7.       <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 34</a> has been enacted on the principle of joint liability in the\n\ndoing of a criminal act. The Section is only a rule of evidence and does not\n\ncreate a substantive offence. The distinctive feature of the Section is the\n\nelement of participation in action. The liability of one person for an offence\n\ncommitted by another in the course of criminal act perpetrated by several\n\npersons arises under <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 34</a> if such criminal act is done in furtherance of\n\na common intention of the persons who join in committing the crime. Direct\n\nproof of common intention is seldom available and, therefore, such\n\nintention can only be inferred from the circumstances appearing from the\n\nproved facts of the case and the proved circumstances. In order to bring\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                      4</span>\n\fhome the charge of common intention, the prosecution has to establish by\n\nevidence, whether direct or circumstantial, that there was plan or meeting of\n\nmind of all the accused persons to commit the offence for which they are\n\ncharged with the aid of <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 34</a>, be it pre-arranged or on the spur of\n\nmoment; but it must necessarily be before the commission of the crime. The\n\ntrue contents of the Section are that if two or more persons intentionally do\n\nan act jointly, the position in law is just the same as if each of them has done\n\nit individually by himself. As observed in <a href=\"/doc/673120/\" id=\"a_14\">Ashok Kumar v. State of Punjab</a>\n\n(AIR 1977 SC 109), the existence of a common intention amongst the\n\nparticipants in a crime is the essential element for application of this\n\nSection. It is not necessary that the acts of the several persons charged with\n\ncommission of an offence jointly must be the same or identically similar.\n\nThe acts may be different in character, but must have been actuated by one\n\nand the same common intention in order to attract the provision.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">8.    The Section does not say \"the common intention of all\", nor does it\n\nsay \"and intention common to all\". Under the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 34</a> the\n\nessence of the liability is to be found in the existence of a common intention\n\nanimating the accused leading to the doing of a criminal act in furtherance\n\nof such intention. As a result of the application of principles enunciated in\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                      5</span>\n\f<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 34</a>, when an accused is convicted under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 302</a> read with\n\n<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 34</a>, in law it means that the accused is liable for the act which\n\ncaused death of the deceased in the same manner as if it was done by him\n\nalone. The provision is intended to meet a case in which it may be difficult\n\nto distinguish between acts of individual members of a party who act in\n\nfurtherance of the common intention of all or to prove exactly what part was\n\ntaken by each of them. As was observed in <a href=\"/doc/865810/\" id=\"a_19\">Ch. Pulla Reddy and Ors. v.\n\nState of Andhra Pradesh</a> (AIR 1993 SC 1899), <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 34</a> is applicable even\n\nif no injury has been caused by the particular accused himself. For applying\n\n<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 34</a> it is not necessary to show some overt act on the part of the\n\naccused.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">9.    The evidence of PWs 2 and 3 did not attribute any overt act to the\n\nappellant. The mere fact that he was in the company of the accused who\n\nwere armed would not be sufficient to attract <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_22\">Section 34</a> IPC. It is\n\nundisputed that appellant was not armed and he had no animosity with the\n\ndeceased. This position is also accepted by the prosecution. Additionally,\n\nthe stand that he pulled the leg of the deceased has not been established.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">\f10.   In the peculiar facts of the case therefore it would be appropriate that\n\nthe appellant cannot be held guilty by application of <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_23\">Section 34</a> IPC. His\n\nconviction is accordingly set aside. He be set at liberty forthwith unless\n\nrequired to be in custody in connection with any case.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">11.   The appeal is allowed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                                        ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                        .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 20, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                    7</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"firstname":null,"title":"Om Prakash Srivastava vs Union Of India Thr.
