Sinha, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                    REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 100              OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 10808 of 2006)\n\n\nHARBANS SINGH &amp; ORS.                               ... APPELLANTS\n\n                                  Versus\n\nSANT HARI SINGH &amp; ORS.                              ... RESPONDENTS\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. Sinha, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    The dispute between the parties in this matter is in regard to\n\nmanagement of Gurudwara Sant Bela Sahib Patshahi Naumin (for short,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                   2</span>\n\n\"the said Gurudwara\") situated in Village Kajal Majra and in Village\n\nShergarh Bara. Sant Surjan Singh is the founder of the said Gurudwara. He\n\nhad given the right of management of the said Gurudwara to Jagat Singh,\n\nwho died in an accident during his life time. On or about 6.5.1982, he\n\nexecuted a general power of attorney appointing (1) Balu Singh s/o Talok\n\nSingh (Nabardar), (2) Harbans Singh s/o Ram Singh; and (3) Sant Nand\n\nKaur widow of Jagat Singh as his attorneys in terms whereof they were\n\nconferred the powers to manage the whole of the property of the said\n\nGurudwara.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      Clauses (3) and (4) of the said power of attorney read as under:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"(3) If any member out of these members dies\n             then can elect another member with the acceptance\n             of majority. The elected member will have same\n             rights as these members have. I and the alone\n             general power of attorney holders will act for\n             Gurudwara with the acceptance of majority.\n             (4) After my death the rights given by me to the\n             alone said member will remain with them (sic).\n             The contents of the General Power of Attorney\n             read over and heard are found to be correct. So\n             the General Power of Attorney is written with\n             sound mind.\"\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                    3</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">3.    Sant Surjan Singh died on 2.12.1983. The Managing Committee of\n\nthe Gurudwara, however, passed a resolution on 18.12.1983 in terms\n\nwhereof one Sant Hari Singh was appointed as Mohtmim of the said\n\nGurudwara and In-charge of the affairs thereof. Disputes and differences\n\nhaving arisen between the parties as to who should manage the affairs of the\n\nsaid Gurudwara, two suits were filed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">4.    Sant Hari Singh filed Civil Suit No. 494-T/1995 for permanent\n\ninjunction before the Court of Civil Judge (Jr. Division), Fatehgarh Sahib\n\nclaiming that he was the Mohtmim of the said Gurudwara and he was in\n\npossession, control and management and enjoyment of the said Gurudwara.\n\nThe Managing Committee of the said Gurudwara also filed Civil Suit\n\nNo.367-T/1996 for declaration that the Managing Committee was in\n\nmanagement and control of the said Gurudwara and was entitled to manage\n\nand control the same and the respondent was not a Mohtmim of the said\n\nGurudwara and, thus, not entitled to manage its affairs.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      Both the suits were consolidated and directed to be heard together by\n\nan order dated 28.2.1997 passed by the learned trial judge.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">5.    By reason of a judgment and decree dated 11.5.2000, the suit filed by\n\nSant Hari Singh was decreed with costs in terms whereof a decree of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                    4</span>\n\npermanent injunction was granted restraining the Managing Committee\n\nfrom interfering with the possession, management and control of the\n\nrespondent over the land of the said Gurudwara, and consequently the suit\n\nfiled by the Managing Committee was dismissed with costs.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">6.    Appellant herein and the Managing Committee of the said Gurudwara\n\npreferred appeals thereagainst.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">7.    The learned Additional District Judge by a judgment and order dated\n\n16.7.2003 held that the possession of the suit land as also the management\n\nof affairs of the said Gurudwara had vested in Sant Hari Singh, the\n\nrespondent herein, in his capacity of a Mohtmim, and, thus, affirmed the\n\ndecree for grant of permanent injunction passed by the learned trial court.\n\nThe learned Additional District Judge furthermore opined that the revenue\n\nrecord having not been corrected in regard to the recording of death of Sant\n\nSurjan Singh, the said omission by itself, would not be sufficient to wash off\n\nthe remaining entries which had been entered in favour of the respondent. It\n\nwas furthermore held that the said power of attorney had ceased to have any\n\neffect after the death of Sant Surjan Singh.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">8.    Appellants herein aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the judgment\n\nand order dated 11.5.2000 passed by the learned trial court in Civil Suit No.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                   5</span>\n\n367-T/1995 and judgment and order dated 16.7.2003 passed by the learned\n\nFirst Appellate Court in Civil Appeal No. 62/2000 preferred Regular\n\nSecond Appeal bearing No. 4657/2003 before the High Court of Punjab and\n\nHaryana at Chandigarh.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">9.    By reason of the impugned judgment, the said second appeal has been\n\ndismissed by the High Court, holding:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">            \"      Two appeals being Civil Appeal No. 59 of\n            24.7.2000 and Civil Appeal No. 62 of 24.7.2000\n            were filed. One appeal was filed by Harbans\n            Singh and others claiming that they duly\n            constituted a Managing Committee and were in\n            control and management of Gurudwara and its\n            property. The other appeal was filed by the\n            Managing Committee. This appeal was also filed\n            by the Managing Committee, comprising of the\n            aforesaid persons.\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                  The aforesaid two appeals were dismissed\n            by the learned First Appellate Court.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                  The present appellants, who were\n            defendants in the suit, filed by Sant Hari Singh\n            have chosen to file the present appeal. No appeal\n            has been filed in the connected suit. In these\n            circumstances, it has to be taken that the findings\n            recorded by the learned trial court as well first\n            appellate court in the suit filed by the Managing\n            Committee and others have attained finality and\n            Hari Singh has been held to be in possession,\n            control and management of the Gurudwara and its\n            property. Since the findings recorded in other suit\n            have attained finality, therefore, the appellants in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                    6</span>\n\n             the present appeal cannot be heard (sic) to claim\n             that the judgments and decree of the courts below\n             are erroneous in any manner.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">10.   Mr. B.S. Chahar, learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nappellants would contend that the principles of res judicata is not applicable\n\nin the instant case as in the suit filed by the Managing Committee the\n\nappellant was not a party. It was urged that the said principle could have\n\nbeen held to be applicable only in the event the parties in both the suits were\n\nthe same.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">11.   Mr. P.S. Patwalia, learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nrespondents, however, supported the impugned judgment.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">12.   Appellant herein does not claim any right, title and interest in his\n\nindividual capacity.     He was the Vice-President of the Managing\n\nCommittee. Thus, for all intent and purport, he was also a plaintiff in Civil\n\nSuit No. 367-T/1996. The judgment and decree passed in the suit filed by\n\nSant Hari Singh might not have been binding upon the appellant herein had\n\nhe claimed any right or interest over the said property in his individual\n\ncapacity and not as a member of the Managing Committee. Indisputably,\n\nthe Managing Committee did not file any Second Appeal against the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                    7</span>\n\njudgment and decree passed against it. The said judgment and decree,\n\ntherefore, attained finality.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">13.   Both the suits, as noticed hereinbefore, were consolidated. They were\n\nheard together. The disputes between the parties to both the suits were\n\ncommon. The issues raised therein also were common.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">      The Managing Committee filed a suit for declaration that it was in\n\nmanagement and control of the said Gurudwara Sahib and was entitled\n\nthereto as also a declaration that the respondent was not a Mohtmim of the\n\nsaid Gurudwara and, thus, not entitled to manage its affairs. As the said\n\ndecree had attained finality, it is binding on the appellants also. Appellants,\n\ntherefore, in law, were required to prefer another Second Appeal against the\n\njudgment and decree passed in the said suit. The principle of res judicata in\n\nthe aforementioned fact situation, in our opinion, has rightly been applied\n\nby the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_32\">\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">14.   Section 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure reads thus:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">             \"Section 11 - Res judicata.-- No Court shall try\n             any suit or issue in which the matter directly and\n             substantially in issue has been directly and\n             substantially in issue in a former suit between the\n             same parties, or between parties under whom they\n             or any of them claim, litigating under the same\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                  8</span>\n\n            title, in a Court competent to try such subsequent\n            suit or the suit in which such issue has been\n            subsequently raised, and has been heard and\n            finally decided by such Court.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_34\">15.   <a href=\"/doc/1183361/\" id=\"a_1\">In Premier Tyres Limited vs. Kerala State Road Transport\n\nCorporation</a> [1993 Suppl. (2) SCC 146], this Court held:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">            \"....The question is what happens where no appeal\n            is filed, as in this case from the decree in\n            connected suit. Effect of non-filing of appeal\n            against a judgment or decree is that it becomes\n            final. This finality can be taken away only in\n            accordance with law. Same consequences follow\n            when a judgment or decree in a connected suit is\n            not appealed from.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">            5.     Mention may be made of a Constitution\n            Bench decision in <a href=\"/doc/1215355/\" id=\"a_2\">Badri Narayan Singh v.\n            Kamdeo Prasad Singh</a>. In an election petition filed\n            by the respondent a declaration was sought to\n            declare the election of appellant as invalid and to\n            declare the respondent as the elected candidate.\n            The tribunal granted first relief only. Both\n            appellant and respondent filed appeals in the High\n            Court. The appellant's appeal was dismissed but\n            that of respondent was allowed. The appellant\n            challenged the order passed in favour of\n            respondent in his appeal. It was dismissed and\n            preliminary objection of the respondent was\n            upheld. The Court observed,\n                   \"We are therefore of opinion that so\n                   long as the order in the appellant's\n                   Appeal No. 7 confirming the order\n                   setting aside his election on the\n                   ground that he was a holder of an\n                   office of profit under the Bihar\n                   Government and therefore could not\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                    9</span>\n\n                   have been a properly nominated\n                   candidate stands, he cannot question\n                   the finding about his holding an\n                   office of profit, in the present appeal,\n                   which is founded on the contention\n                   that that finding is incorrect.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_35\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">      <a href=\"/doc/1798260/\" id=\"a_3\">In Union of India vs.V. Pundarikakshudu</a> &amp; sons &amp; anr. [(2003) 8\n\nSCC 168], this Court held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_37\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">             \"31. In this case the District Judge as also the\n             High Court of Madras clearly held that the award\n             cannot be sustained having regard to the inherent\n             inconsistency contained therein. The arbitrator, as\n             has been correctly held by the District Judge and\n             the High Court, committed a legal misconduct in\n             arriving at an inconsistent finding as regards\n             breach of the contract on the part of one party or\n             the other. Once the arbitrator had granted damages\n             to the first respondent which could be granted only\n             on a finding that the appellant had committed\n             breach of the terms of contract and, thus, was\n             responsible therefor, any finding contrary thereto\n             and inconsistent therewith while awarding any\n             sum in favour of the appellant would be wholly\n             unsustainable being self-contradictory.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_38\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">      As no appeal was preferred by the Union of India while accepting the\n\naward made in favour of the first respondent, it had attained finality and,\n\nthus, the principle of res judicata was found to be applicable. It was opined:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">             \"35. As the appellant failed to get that part of the\n             award which was made by the arbitrator in favour\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                    10</span>\n\n            of the first respondent set aside, the basic\n            conclusion of the High Court cannot be faulted.\n            The Court upon setting aside the whole award\n            could have remitted back the matter to the\n            arbitrator in terms of Section 16 of the Act or\n            could have appointed another arbitrator, but at this\n            juncture no such order can be passed as the award\n            in part has become final.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">      The said decision applies to the facts of the present case also.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_40\">16.   For the reasons aforementioned, there is no merit in this appeal. It is\n\ndismissed accordingly. No costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_41\">                                             ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">                                                       [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n\n                                             ......................................J.\n                                                [Dr. Mukundakam Sharma]\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">JANUARY 13, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"anil kumar","formInput":"anil%20kumar"},{"value":"national commission","formInput":"national%20commission"},{"value":"award of interest","formInput":"award%20of%20interest"},{"value":"banking ombudsman","formInput":"banking%20ombudsman"},{"value":"ombudsman","formInput":"ombudsman"},{"value":"federal bank ltd","formInput":"federal%20bank%20ltd"},{"value":"federal bank","formInput":"federal%20bank"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Branch Manager,Federal Bank Ltd vs N.S.Sabastian on 7 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33656","lastname":"......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-07","citedbyList":[{"tid":125690541,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/120121212091853795FA%20No%201010%20of%202008.pdf","title":"Pnb vs Capital Feeds Pvt. Ltd on 4 December, 2012"},{"tid":77081988,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/90131202133050732State%20Consumer%20Disputes%20Redressal%20Commission.htm","title":"Icici Bank Ltd Red Square Market, ... vs Satbir Singh Son Of Shri Bhalle ... on 8 February, 2012"},{"tid":73751520,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/120FA-1358-09.pdf","title":"Punjab National Bank vs Gurinderjit Singh Rai on 18 March, 2010"},{"tid":43961021,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/170120116124555310A-583-2009-2012-01-09.html","title":"The General Manager vs M.Thankappan Pillai, on 9 January, 2012"},{"tid":166175438,"url":"http://164.100.72.12/ncdrcrep/judgement/160130612133101603FA74of2012.htm","title":"1. General Manager (Operations) vs Shaik Omar S/O Shaik Ahmed And ... on 22 May, 2013"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":5,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Branch Manager,Federal Bank Ltd vs N.S.Sabastian on 7 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: B.N. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                           CIVIL APPEAL NO.43 OF 2009\n                      (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.21204 of 2007)\n\n\nBranch Manager, Federal Bank Ltd.                ...Appellant(s)\n\n\n                                        Versus\n\n\nN.S. Sabastian                                       ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n                                     O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">            Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">            This appeal is directed against order dated 10th April, 2007 passed by the\nNational Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (for short \"the National\nCommission\") whereby it dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant against the\norder dated 3.4.2002 of the Kerala State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission\n(for short \"the State Commission\") for award of interest @18% to the complainant-\nrespondent on an amount of Rs.9.85 lakhs.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">            A perusal of the record shows that while he was working as clerk at\nChengannur branch of Federal Bank Limited (for short \"the bank\"), the\ncomplainant-respondent introduced one Mr. M.P. Anil Kumar who opened savings\nbank account in that branch with account no.12291. On 3.4.2000, the respondent\npresented a chqeque drawn in his favour by Anil Kumar for a sum of Rs. 9.85 lakhs\nbefore Kunchithanni branch of the bank for collection and crediting the same in his\naccount. It is worth mentioning that on the date of issue of cheque, Anil Kumar had\nless than Rs.150/- in his account. The cheque was sent for collection to Chengannur\nbranch of\n                                                                                 ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                         -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">the bank through M/s. Professional Couriers but the same was lost in transit. The\nrespondent complained to the Manager of Kunchithanni branch of the bank about\nnon-credit of Rs.9.85 lakhs in his account and then filed a petition before the Banking\nOmbudsman for the State of Kerala. The Manager of the Kunchithanni branch of\nthe bank, vide his letter dated 5th June, 2000, informed the respondent that the cheque\nwas lost in transit and advised him to get a duplicate cheque in lieu of the lost\ninstrument. Thereafter, the Banking Ombudsman issued communication dated 10th\nJuly, 2000 to the respondent that there was no deficiency of service on the part of the\nbank and that he may take necessary steps to obtain duplicate cheque from the\ndrawer by invoking <a href=\"/doc/1337377/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 45A</a> of the Negotiable Instruments Act or approach a\ncourt/appropriate forum for recovery of the money. However, instead of taking steps\nfor obtaining duplicate cheque from the drawer, namely, Anil Kumar, the respondent\nfiled a complaint before the State Commission claiming Rs.9.85 lakhs with interest\n@18% per annum. The bank contested the complaint by asserting that there was no\ndeficiency of service because it had asked the complainant to obtain duplicate cheque\nwhich he failed to do. The bank also questioned the bonafides of the complainant-\nrespondent by alleging that on the date of issue of cheque, the drawer had a negligible\namount of Rs.112/- in his account.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">          The State Commission declined the respondent's prayer for award of\nRs.9.85 lakhs but directed the bank to pay interest @18% per annum on the cheque\namount from the date of its issue, i.e., 03.04.2000 till the date of payment. The\nNational Commission dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant and confirmed\nthe order of the State Commission. Hence this appeal by special leave.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">                                                                                  ...3/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                         -3-</span>\n<p id=\"p_7\">           Learned counsel for the appellant invited our attention to the zerox copy of\nthe statement of account of Anil Kumar to show that between 28th March, 1998 and\n29th September, 2000 he did not deposit any amount in the bank; that outstanding\nbalance as on 28th March 1998 was Rs.148/- and as on 29th September, 1998 total\nbalance amount was Rs.87/- to his credit, and argued that the State Commission\ncommitted grave illegality in awarding interest to the complainant-respondent by\npresuming deficiency of service on the part of the appellant and ignoring the stark\nreality that on the date of presentation of the cheque and five months thereafter, there\nwas no possibility of its encashment. He pointed out that in spite of the\ncommunications of the bank and letter dated 10th July, 2000 of the Banking\nOmbudsman, the respondent did not take steps to obtain duplicate cheque from the\ndrawer apparently because he knew that the drawer did not have the requisite money\nfor encashment of the cheque and argued the award of interest on Rs.9.85 lakhs, by\nthe State Commission which has been confirmed by the National Commission is\nlegally unsustainable. As against this, learned counsel for the respondent supported\nthe impugned orders and argued that the State Commission has not committed any\nerror by awarding interest in lieu of the loss suffered by his client due to the\nappellant's failure to credit the cheque amount in his account.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">           We have considered the respective submissions. In our view the State\nCommission was not at all justified in awarding interest to the respondent.\nUndisputedly the drawer, namely, Anil Kumar did not deposit any amount in the\nbank between 28th March, 1998 and the date on which the cheque is said to have been\nissued in favour of the respondent. Therefore, it was impossible for the respondent to\nget the amount credited in his account. If the cheque had not been lost in transit, the\nsame would have been dishonoured due to\n                                                                                   ...4/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                          -4-</span>\n<p id=\"p_9\">insufficiency of funds. On its part, the bank had advised the respondent to obtain\nduplicate cheque from the drawer. Banking Ombudsman gave similar advise to the\nrespondent by pointing out that he can get duplicate cheque by resorting to <a href=\"/doc/1337377/\" id=\"a_2\">Section\n45A</a> of the Negotiable Instruments Act. However, the respondent did not take any\nsteps whatsoever for obtaining duplicate cheque from Anil Kumar. The reason for\nthis is not far to see. Anil Kumar had sum less than Rs.200/- in his account at the\nrelevant time. The appellant was aware of this and, therefore, he did not resort to\n<a href=\"/doc/1337377/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 45A</a> of the Negotiable Instruments Act. Not only this, he did not take any\naction for recovery of Rs.9.85 lakhs from Anil Kumar either by filing a complaint\nbefore appropriate forum or by filing a suit before the competent civil court.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">           This being the position, the direction given by the State Commission for\npayment of interest to the respondent is liable to be set aside. Consequently, the order\nof the National Commission is also liable to be set aside.\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned orders are set aside and the\ncomplaint filed before the State Commission is dismissed.\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">           No costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                                                [B.N. AGRAWAL]\n\n\n\n                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                                [G.S. SINGHVI]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 07, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1900732,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1337377,"url":null,"title":"Section 45A in The Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881"}]}, {"numcites":16,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"dying declaration","formInput":"dying%20declaration"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"section 498a","formInput":"section%20498a"},{"value":"section-498a","formInput":"section-498a"},{"value":"sec.498a","formInput":"sec.498a"},{"value":"304b","formInput":"304b"},{"value":"498a","formInput":"498a"},{"value":"s.498a","formInput":"s.498a"},{"value":"304b citedby:653797","formInput":"304b%20citedby%3A653797"}],"citeList":[{"tid":538436,"url":null,"title":"Section 498A in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":653797,"url":null,"title":"Section 304B in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":455468,"url":null,"title":"Section 307 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1159790,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=5612","title":"K Ramachandra Reddy & Anr vs The Public Prosecutor on 5 May, 1976"}],"covers":[],"title":"Varikuppal Srinivas vs State Of A.P on 28 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-28","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":131835427,"url":"http://bombayhighcourt.nic.in/generatenew.php?path=.%2Fdata%2Faurjudgements%2F2012%2F&fname=CRAPEAL29206.pdf&smflag=N","title":"Manik vs The State Of Maharashtra on 21 December, 2012"},{"tid":1103877,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=120071","title":"Purushu @ Purushothaman vs State Of Kerala on 25 September, 2009"},{"tid":22153921,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=42","title":"Joginder Singh vs State Of Haryana on 5 December, 2011"},{"tid":140654958,"url":null,"title":"State vs . Suresh Chand Sharma on 14 December, 2010"}],"tid":254868,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":4,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33591","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Varikuppal Srinivas vs State Of A.P on 28 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n                   IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.            168 OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 8054 of 2007)\n\n\nVarikuppal Srinivas                                     ..Appellant\n\n                                   Versus\n\n\nState of A.P.                                                   ..\nRespondent\n\n\n                              JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of the Andhra Pradesh\n\nHigh Court upholding the conviction of the appellant for offences\n\npunishable under <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 498A</a> and <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_2\">304B</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860\n\n(in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">IPC</a>'). Learned 4th Additional Metropolitan Sessions Judge,\n\nHyderabad had convicted both the accused persons for offences punishable\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                      1</span>\n\funder <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_4\">Sections 498A</a> and <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_5\">304B</a>         IPC and sentenced each to undergo\n\nrigorous imprisonment for one year and seven years respectively and to pay\n\na fine of Rs.200/- with default stipulation. In appeal, A2 was acquitted by\n\nthe High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Prosecution version in a nutshell is as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      A1 the present appellant is the son of A2 who married Manjula\n\n(hereinafter referred to as the `deceased') the daughter of PWs.1 &amp; 2 about\n\nsix years prior to the date of incident. Sub Inspector of Police (PW9) of\n\nOsmania University Police Station received a message at 6.45 P.M. on\n\n8.2.1999 from Gandhi Hospital stating that one Manjula was admitted in the\n\nhospital allegedly having consumed unknown acid at her residence on the\n\nsaid date. He entered the same in G.D., went to the hospital and found that\n\nthe deceased was unable to speak due to acid burns in her throat. All his\n\nvisits on subsequent dates proved futile. Therefore, he deputed Constable\n\n(P.W.3) on 13-2-1999 to the hospital. Accordingly, he went to the hospital\n\nat 11 A.M. and recorded her statement-Ex.P2 and handed over the said\n\nstatement to P.W.9. On the basis of the said statement P.W.9 registered a\n\ncase in Cr.No.34 of 1999 under <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_6\">Sections 498-A</a> and <a href=\"/doc/455468/\" id=\"a_7\">307</a> IPC and issued\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                    2</span>\n\fFIR-Ex.P12 to all concerned. He visited the Gandhi Hospital and recorded\n\nstatement under <a href=\"/doc/447673/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 161</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (in\n\nshort the `Code') of the deceased under Ex.P13. He further examined\n\nP.Ws.1, 2 and others, visited the scene of offence, which is the house of the\n\ndeceased at Manikanteswar Nagar, but did not find any incriminating\n\nmaterial at the scene of offence and examined the neighbours. He sent a\n\nrequisition-Ex.P3 to P.W.4-XXII Metropolitan Magistrate, Hyderabad for\n\nrecording the dying declaration of the deceased. On receipt of requisition\n\nthe Magistrate visited the hospital at 7.20 P.M. and after obtaining\n\nendorsement of the doctor that patient was conscious and coherent and also\n\nafter putting some preliminary questions he recorded the dying declaration-\n\n(Ex.P4). Thereafter, P.W.9 arrested the accused on 23-03-1999 and sent\n\nthem to court, subsequently on 13-04-1999 on the instructions of Assistant\n\nCommissioner of Police he along with P.Ws.8 and 7 proceeded to\n\nGolanukonda village and exhumed the dead body of the deceased PW 7, the\n\nM.R.O. conducted inquest over the dead body of the deceased and Professor\n\n(PW 8), Forensic Medicine, Kakatiya Medical College, Waranga conducted\n\npostmortem examination. After completion of investigation police laid the\n\ncharge sheet for the offence as aforementioned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                     3</span>\n\f      On committal, charges were framed against the accused; read over\n\nand explained to them in Telugu and they pleaded not guilty.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">      The prosecution in order- to prove its case examined P.Ws.1 to 13\n\nand marked Exs.P1 to P16. No oral or documentary evidence has been\n\nadduced on defense side.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      The learned Sessions Judge after evaluating the evidence on record\n\nfound the accused guilty and convicted for the offence, as aforementioned.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      The trial court relied primarily on the statement made before the Head\n\nConstable (PW3).       The statement recorded by him is Exh.P2. The\n\nMagistrate (PW 4) recorded the dying declaration. Placing reliance on the\n\nevidence more particularly on the dying declaration, the conviction was\n\nrecorded.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">      In appeal, the primary stand was that the evidence was insufficient to\n\nconvict A2 and that the dying declaration should not have been acted upon.\n\nThe High Court found substance in the plea that the evidence was not\n\nsufficient to convict A2, but found the evidence to be sufficient so far as A1\n\ni.e. present appellant is concerned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                      4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">\f4.    Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that the evidence of the\n\nmagistrate (PW 4) should not have been accepted so far as the dying\n\ndeclaration is concerned. The medical evidence does not show that the\n\nvictim was in a position to give any statement.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">5.    In response, learned counsel for the respondent submitted that the\n\nstatements made by the deceased that is Exhs.P2, P4 and P13 are consistent\n\nwith regard to the A1 pouring acid in the mouth of the deceased which\n\nresulted in her death.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">6.    The deceased breathed her last on 9.4.1999. The dead body was\n\nexhumed on 13.4.1999.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">7.    This is a case where the basis of conviction of the accused by the trial\n\nCourt was the dying declarations. The situation in which a person is on his\n\ndeathbed, being exceedingly solemn, serene and grave, is the reason in law\n\nto accept the veracity of his statement. It is for this reason that the\n\nrequirements of oath and cross-examination are dispensed with. Besides\n\nshould the dying declaration be excluded it will result in miscarriage of\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                      5</span>\n\fjustice because the victim being generally the only eye-witness in a serious\n\ncrime, the exclusion of the statement would leave the Court without a scrap\n\nof evidence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">8.    Though a dying declaration is entitled to great weight, it is\n\nworthwhile to note that the accused has no power of cross-examination.\n\nSuch a power is essential for eliciting the truth as an obligation of oath\n\ncould be. This is the reason the Court also insists that the dying declaration\n\nshould be of such nature as to inspire full confidence of the Court in its\n\ncorrectness. The Court has to be on guard that the statement of the deceased\n\nwas not as a result of either tutoring or prompting or a product of\n\nimagination. The Court must be further satisfied that the deceased was in a\n\nfit state of mind after a clear opportunity to observe and identify the\n\nassailant. Once the Court is satisfied that the declaration was true and\n\nvoluntary, undoubtedly, it can base its conviction without any further\n\ncorroboration. It cannot be laid down as an absolute rule of law that the\n\ndying declaration cannot form the sole basis of conviction unless it is\n\ncorroborated. The rule requiring corroboration is merely a rule of prudence.\n\nThis Court has laid down in several judgments the principles governing\n\ndying declaration, which could be summed up as under as indicated in <a href=\"/doc/1007294/\" id=\"a_9\">Smt.\n\nPaniben v. State of Gujarat</a> (AIR 1992 SC 1817):\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                      6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">\f      (i)     There is neither rule of law nor of prudence that dying\n\ndeclaration cannot be acted upon without corroboration. [<a href=\"/doc/1940450/\" id=\"a_10\">See Munnu Raja\n\n&amp; Anr. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh</a> (1976) 2 SCR 764)]\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">      (ii)    If the Court is satisfied that the dying declaration is true and\n\nvoluntary it can base conviction on it, without corroboration. [<a href=\"/doc/853108/\" id=\"a_11\">See State of\n\nUttar Pradesh v. Ram Sagar Yadav and Ors</a>. (AIR 1985 SC 416) and\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1683212/\" id=\"a_12\">Ramavati Devi v. State of Bihar</a> (AIR 1983 SC 164)]\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">      (iii)   The Court has to scrutinize the dying declaration carefully and\n\nmust ensure that the declaration is not the result of tutoring, prompting or\n\nimagination. The deceased had an opportunity to observe and identify the\n\nassailants and was in a fit state to make the declaration. [<a href=\"/doc/1159790/\" id=\"a_13\">See K.\n\nRamachandra Reddy and Anr. v. The Public Prosecutor</a> (AIR 1976 SC\n\n1994)]\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">      (iv)     Where the dying declaration is suspicious, it should not be\n\nacted upon without corroborative evidence. [<a href=\"/doc/137330/\" id=\"a_14\">See Rasheed Beg v. State of\n\nMadhya Pradesh</a> (1974 (4) SCC 264)]\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">      (v)     Where the deceased was unconscious and could never make\n\nany dying declaration, the evidence with regard to it is to be rejected. [See\n\nKaka Singh v State of M.P. (AIR 1982 SC 1021)]\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                                      7</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">\f      (vi)   A dying declaration which suffers from infirmity cannot form\n\nthe basis of conviction. [<a href=\"/doc/838495/\" id=\"a_15\">See Ram Manorath and Ors. v. State of U.P</a>. (1981\n\n(2) SCC 654)\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">      (vii) Merely because a dying declaration does contain the details as\n\nto the occurrence, it is not to be rejected. [<a href=\"/doc/1072623/\" id=\"a_16\">See State of Maharashtra v.\n\nKrishnamurthi Laxmipati Naidu</a> (AIR 1981 SC 617)]\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">      (viii) Equally, merely because it is a brief statement, it is not to be\n\ndiscarded. On the contrary, the shortness of the statement itself guarantees\n\ntruth. [See Surajdeo Oza and Ors. v. State of Bihar (AIR 1979 SC 1505).\n\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">      (ix)   Normally the Court in order to satisfy whether the deceased\n\nwas in a fit mental condition to make the dying declaration looks up to the\n\nmedical opinion. But where the eye-witness said that the deceased was in a\n\nfit and conscious state to make the dying declaration, the medical opinion\n\ncannot prevail. [<a href=\"/doc/33955999/\" id=\"a_17\">See Nanahau Ram and Anr. v. State of Madhya Pradesh</a>\n\n(AIR 1988 SC 912)].\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">      (x)    Where the prosecution version differs from the version as given\n\nin the dying declaration, the said declaration cannot be acted upon. [<a href=\"/doc/307132/\" id=\"a_18\">See\n\nState of U.P. v. Madan Mohan and Ors</a>. (AIR 1989 SC 1519)].\n\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">      (xi)   Where there is more than one statement in the nature of dying\n\ndeclaration, one first in point of time must be preferred. Of course, if the\n\nplurality of dying declarations could be held to be trustworthy and reliable,\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                                     8</span>\n\fit has to be accepted. [See Mohanlal Gangaram Gehani v.State of\n\nMaharashtra (AIR 1982 SC 839) and <a href=\"/doc/1145585/\" id=\"a_19\">Mohan Lal and Ors. v. State of\n\nHaryana</a> (2007 (9) SCC 151).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_38\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">9.    In the background of the principles set out above, the inevitable\n\nconclusion is that the trial court and the High Court have rightly convicted\n\nthe appellant for offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_20\">Sections 498A</a> and <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_21\">304B</a> IPC.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">10.   The appeal is without merit, deserves dismissal, which we direct.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">                                      ...........................................J.\n                                      (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                      ..........................................J.\n                                      (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 28, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                                           9</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":5,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"notional increment","formInput":"notional%20increment"},{"value":"back wages when can be denied","formInput":"back%20wages%20when%20can%20be%20denied"},{"value":"apsrtc","formInput":"apsrtc"}],"firstname":"s","title":"V.V.G.Reddy vs Apsrtc, Nizamabad Region & Anr on 13 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33497","lastname":"sinha","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-13","citedbyList":[{"tid":168854411,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=200201","title":"The Management vs The Presiding Officer on 15 July, 2014"},{"tid":618582,"url":null,"title":"K.S. Abdulla vs District Collector And Ors. on 8 December, 1971"},{"tid":344488,"url":null,"title":"Maheshwar Rao P. vs Presiding Officer, Labour Court ... on 17 January, 1997"},{"tid":1305448,"url":null,"title":"V. Ramana vs Apsrtc And Others on 14 August, 2001"},{"tid":99570813,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/Judis_Andhra/list_new2.asp?FileName=13738","title":"The Depot Manager, Apsrtc, Medak ... vs Counsel For The on 28 September, 2016"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":4,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">V.V.G.Reddy vs Apsrtc, Nizamabad Region &amp; Anr on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: S Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                    REPORTABLE\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 99             OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 5166 of 2008)\n\n\nV.V.G. REDDY                                           ... APPELLANT\n\n                                  Versus\n\nAPSRTC, NIZAMABAD REGION &amp; ANR.                     ... RESPONDENTS\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. Sinha, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                    2</span><p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Appellant is before us questioning the judgment and order dated\n\n21.9.2007 passed by a Division Bench of the High Court of Judicature of\n\nAndhra Pradesh at Hyderabad in Writ Appeal No.658 of 2007 and others\n\nwhereby and whereunder the said writ appeal preferred from a judgment and\n\norder dated 29.10.2002 passed in W.P. No. 21410 of 2002 filed by appellant\n\nand others was allowed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Respondent - Corporation is constituted and incorporated under the\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1779621/\" id=\"a_1\">Road Transport Corporation Act</a>, 1950 (64 of 1950). Appellant joined its\n\nservices as a conductor in the year 1981. A disciplinary proceeding was\n\ninitiated against him. He was placed under suspension in the year 1982. In\n\nthe said disciplinary proceeding, he, having been found guilty was\n\ndismissed from services.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      An industrial dispute was raised by him, which was eventually\n\nreferred to the Labour Court by the State of Andhra Pradesh in exercise of\n\nits powers conferred upon it under <a href=\"/doc/1218044/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 10(1)(c)</a> of the Industrial\n\nDisputes Act, 1947 (for short, \"the Act\").\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                  3</span><p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">4.    By reason of an Award dated 1.8.1988, the Labour Court directed his\n\nreinstatement in service with continuity therein but without attendant\n\nbenefits and back wages.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">5.    Pursuant to or in furtherance of the said Award, appellant was\n\nreinstated in service. However, he was not paid his salary at par with his\n\ncolleagues whose services had been regularized with effect from 1.10.1983.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">6.    He filed an Execution Petition being E.P. No. 18 of 1989 in I.D. No.\n\n581 of 1987 before Labour Court, Hyderabad praying that his services be\n\ndirected to be regularized at par with his colleagues with effect from\n\n1.10.1983. The said Execution Petition was allowed.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">7.    As despite the same, his pay was not fixed at par with his colleagues\n\nand no notional increments had been granted, a legal notice was issued on\n\nhis behalf by an Advocate on 2.3.1992.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">      He thereafter filed a writ petition before the High Court which was\n\nmarked as Writ Petition No. 21410 of 2002 praying for grant of notional\n\nincrements for the period between 1.10.1983 and 15.2.1989.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                   4</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">      By reason of a judgment and order dated 29.10.2002, the said writ\n\npetition was allowed by a learned single judge of the High Court, directing:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">            \"The controversy in this writ petition is no more\n            res integra, in view of the decision of a Division\n            Bench of this Court in APSRTC, Khammam\n            Region and another Vs. P. Nageswara Rao. The\n            Division Bench while dealing an analogous\n            question has held that when an award was passed\n            by the labour court directing the respondents to\n            reinstate the petitioner into service, the action of\n            the respondent - Corporation in fixing the pay\n            without taking into consideration the notional\n            increments is illegal. It is further held that the\n            Corporation cannot rely on any circular or\n            regulation that takes away the plain meaning of the\n            award in the judgment.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_19\">8.    A writ appeal was preferred thereagainst by the respondent herein.\n\nHowever, the said writ appeal was barred by limitation and an application\n\nfor condonation of delay having not been allowed, the same was dismissed.\n\nA Special Leave Petition filed thereagainst being Special Leave Petition\n\n(Civil) No. 1114 of 2004 was allowed by a judgment and order dated\n\n13.2.2007 in terms whereof the matter was remitted to the High Court for\n\ndisposal of the case on merit. By reason of the impugned judgment, the writ\n\nappeal preferred by the respondent herein has been allowed.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                    5</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">9.    Ms. T. Anamika, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant\n\nwould urge that in view of the fact that the appellant was denied back wages\n\nonly by the Labour Court and having been reinstated in service with\n\ncontinuity, the High Court committed a serious error in declining to grant\n\nnotional increments in his favour from the date of his dismissal till the date\n\nof passing of the Award. Strong reliance in this behalf has been placed on\n\nthe decision of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/1542335/\" id=\"a_3\">Devendra Pratap Narain Rai Sharma vs. State\n\nof Uttar Pradesh &amp; ors</a>. [AIR 1962 SC 1334].\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">10.   Mr. D. Mahesh Babu, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nrespondents, on the other hand, supported the impugned judgment.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">11.   The award appeared to have been passed by the labour court on\n\nconsent of the parties. Appellant himself stated so in his affidavit in support\n\nof the writ petition.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">12.   The terms of the consent order have not been produced before us by\n\nthe appellant. We will, however, proceed on the premise that the parties\n\nthereto agreed that the appellant would be reinstated within a month from\n\nthe said date. Appellant was, therefore, not only denied back wages but also\n\nthe attendant benefits.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                    6</span><p id=\"p_26\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">13.   Interpretation of terms of consent will depend upon the nature of the\n\nlis and the background events.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">14.   Appellant, as noticed hereinbefore, had not only foregone back wages\n\nbut also attendant benefits. The word \"attendant benefits\" should be given\n\nits natural meaning. The \"attendant benefits\" was in regard to a period for\n\nwhich he had been denied back wages. A person may be denied back wages\n\nwhich otherwise can be interpreted to mean that he would be entitled to\n\nclaim the benefit of increments notionally.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">15.   We may, however, notice that in <a href=\"/doc/309814/\" id=\"a_4\">A.P. State Road Transport\n\nCorporation &amp; ors. vs. Abdul Kareem</a> [(2005) 6 SCC 36], this Court held:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">            \".....the Labour Court specifically directed that the\n            reinstatement would be without back wages. There\n            is no specific direction that the employee would be\n            entitled to all the consequential benefits.\n            Therefore, in the absence of specific direction in\n            that regard, merely because an employee has been\n            directed to be reinstated without back wages, he\n            cannot claim a benefit of increments notionally\n            earned during the period when he was not on duty\n            during the period when he was out of service. It\n            would be incongruous to suggest that an\n            employee, having been held guilty and remained\n            absent from duty for a long time, continues to earn\n            increments though there is no payment of wages\n            for the period of absence.\"\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                     7</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_31\">16.   <a href=\"/doc/273787/\" id=\"a_5\">In A.P. SRTC &amp; Anr. vs. S. Narsagoud</a> [(2003) 2 SCC 212], this\n\nCourt held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_32\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">              \"9. We find merit in the submission so made.\n              There is a difference between an order of\n              reinstatement accompanied by a simple direction\n              for continuity of service and a direction where\n              reinstatement is accompanied by a specific\n              direction that the employee shall be entitled to all\n              the consequential benefits, which necessarily flow\n              from reinstatement or accompanied by a specific\n              direction that the employee shall be entitled to the\n              benefit of the increments earned during the period\n              of absence. In our opinion, the employee after\n              having been held guilty of unauthorised absence\n              from duty cannot claim the benefit of increments\n              notionally earned during the period of\n              unauthorised absence in the absence of a specific\n              direction in that regard and merely because he has\n              been directed to be reinstated with the benefit of\n              continuity in service.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_33\">17.   In Devendra Pratap Narain Rai Sharma (supra), this Court upon\n\nreferring to Rule 54 of the Fundamental Rules framed by the State of Uttar\n\nPradesh, held as under:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">              \"11. In our view, this contention is wholly\n              misconceived. Rule 54, as amended in 1953,\n              stands as follows :\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">                     \"54.(1) When a Government servant who\n              has been dismissed, removed or suspended is\n              reinstated, the authority competent to order the\n              reinstatement shall consider and make a specific\n              order--\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">                     (a) regarding the pay and allowances to be\n              paid to the Government servant for the period of\n              his absence from duty and\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">                     (b) whether or not the said period shall be\n              treated as a period spent on duty.</blockquote><p id=\"p_35\">\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                        8</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">       (2) Where such competent authority holds\nthat the Government servant has been fully\nexonerated or, in the case of suspension, that it\nwas wholly unjustified, the Government servant\nshall be given the full pay to which he would have\nbeen entitled, had he not been dismissed, removed\nor suspended, as the case may be together with any\nallowances of which he was in receipt prior to his\ndismissal, removal or suspension.\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">       (3) In other cases, the Government servant\nshall be given such proportion of such pay and\nallowances as such competent authority may\nprescribe.\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">       Provided that the payment of allowances\nunder clauses (2) and (3) shall be subject to all\nother conditions under which such allowances are\nadmissible.\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">       (4) In a case falling under clause (2) the\nperiod of absence from duty shall be treated as the\nperiod spent on duty for all purposes.\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">       (5) In a case falling under clause (3) the\nperiod of absence from duty shall not be treated as\nperiod spent on duty unless such competent\nauthority specifically directs that it shall be so\ntreated for any specified purposes.\"\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">This rule has no application to cases like the\npresent in which the dismissal of a public servant\nis declared invalid by a civil court and he is\nreinstated. This rule, undoubtedly enables the\nState Government to fix the pay of a public\nservant whose dismissal is set aside in a\ndepartmental appeal. But in this case the order of\ndismissal was declared invalid in a civil suit. The\neffect of the decree of the civil suit was that the\nappellant was never to be deemed to have been\nlawfully dismissed from service and the order of\nreinstatement was superfluous, The effect of the\nadjudication of the civil court is to declare that the\nappellant had been wrongfully prevented from\nattending to his duties as a public servant. It would\nnot in such a contingency be open to the authority\nto deprive the public servant of the remuneration\nwhich he would have earned had he been\npermitted to work.\"\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                     9</span><p id=\"p_42\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">      The said decision, in our opinion, has no application to the fact\n\nsituation obtaining in the present case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_44\">\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">18.   Appellant has not been directed to be reinstated in service by reason\n\nof an Award holding that the order of termination was wholly illegal and,\n\nthus, void ab initio. On what premise, parties entered into a compromise is\n\nnot known. It is possible to hold that findings of the Enquiry Officer which\n\nmight have been accepted by the disciplinary authority holding him guilty\n\nof misconduct had not been set aside; the Management might have thought\n\nthat denial of back wages and attendant benefits would be sufficient\n\npunishment. If that be so, appellant being not in service during the period in\n\nquestion, namely, 1.10.1983 to 15.2.1989, in our opinion, would not be\n\nentitled to increment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_46\">\n</p><p id=\"p_47\">19.   For the reasons aforementioned, the appeal is dismissed. No costs.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_48\">                                            ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_49\">                                                      [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n\n\n                                             ......................................J.\n                                                [Dr. Mukundakam Sharma]\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                   10</span>\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_50\">JANUARY 13, 2009\n\f</p>","tid":603694,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":273787,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=20776","title":"A.P.S.R.T.C. Bhimrao Patil vs Maharashtra Industrial Dev. ... on 28 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n              CIVIL APPEAL NO.         477         OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP(C ) No. 3162 of 2006)\n\n\n\n\nKamlakar Bhimrao Patil                                  ......Appellant\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\n\nMaharashtra Industrial Dev. Corpn.                      ......Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the order passed by a Division Bench of\n\nthe Bombay High Court dismissing the writ petition filed. The writ petition\n\nwas filed by the appellant questioning legality of the order passed by the\n\fMaharashtra    Industrial   Development      Corporation   (in   short   the\n\n`Corporation') dated 30.3.2005.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      By Resolution dated 17.8.2004 a decision was taken for allotment of\n\nland at a particular price. The money was deposited on 9.3.2005 but letter\n\ndated 30.3.2005 was written to M/s. Everest Realtors Private Ltd. intimating\n\nthem that the request for allotment of land in the Airoli, Navi,\n\nKnowledge/Apparel Park cannot be considered. The pay orders submitted\n\nalong with letter dated 9.3.2005 were returned. According to the appellant\n\nno reason or basis has been indicated and the High Court misconstrued the\n\nprayer in the writ petition as if it was for enforcement of specific\n\nperformance of contract with the Corporation.            The appellant has\n\ncategorically stated that the subject matter of challenge was the impugned\n\ndecision taken by the Corporation to repudiate the contract. The High Court\n\nerroneously, according to the appellant came to hold that it can be\n\nconsidered by a civil court of competent jurisdiction.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">\f4.    Learned counsel for the appellant further submitted that no reason has\n\nbeen indicated as to why the Corporation decided not to go ahead with the\n\ncontract.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.    Learned counsel for the Corporation on the other hand submitted that\n\nthe Corporation decided not to take any note of the payments made by M/s.\n\nEverest Realtors Private Ltd. In fact the Resolution earlier related to the\n\npresent appellant.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">6.    It is clarified by learned counsel for the appellant that he is a Director\n\nof the Pvt. Ltd. Co. and therefore, the reasons indicated have no relevance.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">7.    We find that this is a case which could have been decided by the High\n\nCourt and therefore we set aside the impugned order of the High Court. The\n\nwrit petition shall be restored for disposal on merit. To avoid unnecessary\n\ndelay, let the parties appear before the High Court on 9.2.2009.           The\n\nHon'ble Chief Justice of the High Court is requested to direct listing of the\n\npetition before an appropriate bench. It is made clear that we have not\n\nexpressed any opinion on the merits of the case. Till 9.2.2009 no third\n\nparties' interest shall be created by the Corporation. It is open to the High\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fCourt to pass such interim orders during the pendency of the writ petition as\n\nthe circumstances warrant.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">8.    The appeal is accordingly disposed of.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">                                            ............................................J.\n                                            (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                            ..............................................J.\n                                            (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 28, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                    4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":965337,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, saran","formInput":"ganga%20saran"},{"value":"ganga","formInput":"ganga"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal
