The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":767287,"url":null,"title":"Section 313 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"}],"covers":[],"title":"Satvir vs State Of U.P on 21 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-21","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":145050916,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/VKJ/judgement/09-08-2010/VKJ09082010CRLA2141997.pdf","title":"Mohd Amil & Another vs State on 9 August, 2010"},{"tid":155534908,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=376991","title":"Friday vs By Advs.Sri.P.Vijaya Bhanu ... on 10 February, 2003"},{"tid":174818339,"url":null,"title":"State vs . Nilanjal Gupta on 19 May, 2012"},{"tid":175370425,"url":"http://elegalix.allahabadhighcourt.in/elegalix/WebShowJudgment.do?judgmentID=4247285","title":"Saurabh Mishra And Another vs State Of U.P. on 26 August, 2015"},{"tid":74622860,"url":"http://elegalix.allahabadhighcourt.in/elegalix/WebShowJudgment.do?judgmentID=5002727","title":"Subrati vs State Of U.P. on 26 September, 2016"}],"tid":1815418,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"l","lastname":"panta","numcitedby":4,"secondname":"s","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33533","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Satvir vs State Of U.P on 21 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: L S Panta</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Lokeshwar Singh Panta, B. Sudershan Reddy</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                             Reportable\n\n\n            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n          CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n          CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 551 OF 2005\n\nSatvir                                    .....   Appellant\n\n                           Versus\n\nState of Uttar Pradesh                     ..... Respondent\n\n\n                         JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">Lokeshwar Singh Panta, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.   Eight accused, namely, (1) Fateh Singh, (2) Ram\n\nChander, (3) Brahma, (4) Satvir, (5) Ram Saran, (6) Harbir,\n\n(7) Pratap and (8) Genda were tried by learned VI Additional\n\nDistrict &amp; Sessions Judge, Meerut, in Sessions Trial No. 70\n\nof 1978 for committing the murder of Hari Dutt Singh.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.   By judgment and order dated 05.12.1979, the learned\n\ntrial judge convicted all the accused under Section 302 read\n\nwith <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 149</a> of the Indian Penal Code (for short \"<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>\")\n\nand sentenced each to imprisonment for life. The accused -\n\nRam Saran, Satvir and Harbir have been further convicted\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 148</a> IPC and each sentenced to two years\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                               2</span>\n\n\nrigorous imprisonment, whereas         Fateh Singh, Genda,\n\nPratap, Brahma and Ram Chander have been convicted\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1258372/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 147</a> IPC and sentenced to one year rigorous\n\nimprisonment. All the sentences were, however, ordered to\n\nrun concurrently.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">3.   The accused persons filed joint appeal in the High\n\nCourt of Judicature at Allahabad. The High Court by final\n\njudgment   and      order   dated   25.02.2003   modified   the\n\njudgment of the trial court. It converted the conviction of\n\naccused Satvir, Ram Saran and Harbir to <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 302</a> IPC\n\nread with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 34</a> IPC and sentenced them to undergo\n\nlife imprisonment.     It, however, acquitted Ram Chander,\n\nBrahma, Pratap and Genda. Fateh Singh accused, during\n\nthe pendency of the appeal before the High Court, had died;\n\ntherefore his appeal stood abated.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">4.   Satvir appellant herein, has now approached this\n\nCourt in this appeal. The learned counsel for the parties\n\nstated before us that no appeal appears to have been filed\n\nby other convicts, namely, Ram Saran and Harbir against\n\nthe judgment and order of the High Court.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                    3</span><p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">5.       The   incident   leading       to the   prosecution      of the\n\nappellant occurred on 31.10.1977 at about 4 P.M. in the\n\njungle of village Ahmadpuri, Police Station Parikshatgarh,\n\nDistrict Meerut (U.P.). The report of the incident was lodged\n\nby Mahendra Singh (PW-1) an eyewitness, son of the\n\ndeceased Hari Dutt Singh at about 5.30 P.M. in the Police\n\nStation in which the names of all the accused persons were\n\nmentioned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">6.       The following pedigree relevant for the purpose of\n\nnoticing the relationships between the parties involved in\n\nthe case is as under:-</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\n\nHari Dutt Singh ---------- Kaley ----------------       Shiv Saran\n(Deceased)               (brother of                   (brother of\n                         deceased)                deceased)\n\n\n     /                        /                         /\nMahendra Singh        Ram Saran              Ram Chander       Brahma\nPW-1 (son of          Accused (son          Accused (son of   Accused\ndeceased)             of Kaley)                   Shiv Saran)      (son of\n                                                                   Shiv Saran)\n                          /                         /\n\n\n                    Harbir                   Satvir - Appellant\n                   Accused (son of           Accused (son of\n                   Ram Saran)                Ram Chander)\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                            4</span>\n\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_10\">Pratap accused is the brother-in-law of Ram Chander\naccused; whereas Genda is `Samdhi' of accused Ram Saran\nand accused Fateh Singh (deceased) was uncle of Mahendra\nSingh (PW-1).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">7.   It was the prosecution case that Mahabir son of Ram\n\nSaran was murdered in the year 1976 and for the said\n\nincident; Hari Dutt Singh [deceased] and his son PW-1 were\n\nfacing trial before the Court. One more criminal case filed\n\nby Smt. Sammo is pending against the deceased and PW-1\n\nin the Court of a Magistrate at Meerut.     On the day of\n\nincident, i.e. 31.10.1977, both PW-1 and Hari Dutt Singh\n\nhad gone to the Court of Magistrate at Meerut to attend the\n\nproceedings in the said case but the same was adjourned at\n\nabout 12 0'Clock in the noon.    PW-1 and his father had\n\nreturned to their village by bus.    After getting down at\n\nParikshatgarh, they started going to their village Ahmadpuri\n\non foot. At about 4 P.M., they reached on the road dividing\n\nthe fields of Balley and Muley where PW-1 was going about\n\n20 paces ahead of his father. The accused persons hiding\n\nthemselves in the sugarcane fields of Balley, suddenly\n\nappeared and laid down Hari Dutt Singh on the ground.\n\nAppellant Satvir, accused Ram Saran and accused Harbir\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                           5</span>\n\n\neach were armed with knives with which they inflicted fatal\n\ninjuries on Hari Dutt Singh at the instigation of accused\n\nRam Saran, who proclaimed that the life of Hari Dutt Singh\n\nshould be cut short as he was responsible for the murder of\n\nhis son Mahabir.    PW-1 shouted and raised alarm which\n\nattracted Bakhtawar Singh (PW-2), Ganga Saran (PW-4),\n\nGajraj and few more persons to the place of occurrence. All\n\nthe accused persons had fled from the place of incident\n\nafter committing the murder of Hari Dutt Singh. One Jasbir\n\nSingh recorded the report (Ex. Ka-1) of the incident at the\n\ninstance of PW-1 on the basis of which First Information\n\nReport came to be lodged at Police Station at about 5.30\n\nP.M.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">8.     Head Constable Satya Pal Singh (PW-6), who at the\n\nrelevant time, was discharging the duties of A.S.I., Police\n\nStation Parikshatgarh visited the scene of incident and\n\nprepared Panchnama (Ex. Ka-6), Khaka-lash (Ex.-Ka-7) and\n\nSite Plan (Ex.-Ka-9) of the dead body and collected blood-\n\nstained sample of earth from the place of occurrence.\n\nConstable Sukhpal (PW-5) alongwith Constable Baburam\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                             6</span>\n\n\ntook the dead body of Hari Dutt Singh to Hospital for post\n\nmortem.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">9.    Dr. O.P. Sharma (PW-3) conducted autopsy on the\n\ndead body of the deceased on 01.11.1977 at about 5 P.M.\n\nThe following ante-mortem injuries were found on the dead\n\nbody:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">        1. Stab wound 13 cm x 5 cm x abdominal\n           cavity deep on the front of abdomen\n           right side upper part just below the\n           coastal margin transversely; inner end\n           of the wound was a little above and\n           outer to the umbilicus.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">        2. Stab wound 11 cm x 5 cm x abdominal\n           cavity deep on the left side of abdomen\n           2 cm below the coastal margin\n           transversely.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">        3. Sub wound 5 cm 1 cm x abdominal\n           cavity deep on the front of abdomen just\n           below the umbilicus transversely.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">        4. Incised wound 1-= cm x 5 cm x muscle\n           on the front of abdomen right side just\n           below the anterior superior iliac spine.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">        5. Incised wound 9 cm x 5 cm trachea cut\n           on the front of neck middle extending on\n           both sides transversely.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">        6. Abrasion 1 cm 1 cm on the back of left\n           elbow.\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_14\">10.     On internal examination, small intestine was found\n\nstabbed at two places and large intestine stabbed at one\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                               7</span>\n\n\nplace. Left lobe of liver was also stabbed. According to the\n\nopinion of the Doctor, the deceased died due to shock and\n\nhaemorrhage as a result of ante-mortem injuries.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">11.   On completion of the investigation, chargesheet was\n\nfiled against the accused persons by Station House Officer\n\nBijendra Singh Chahar (PW-7).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">12.   All the accused pleaded not guilty to the charges and\n\nclaimed to be tried.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">13.   The prosecution, in order to substantiate its case,\n\nexamined as many as 7 witnesses, out of whom Mahendra\n\nSingh (PW-1), Bakhtawar Singh (PW-2) and Ganga Saran\n\n(PW-4) are the eyewitnesses.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">14.   The accused in the statements recorded under <a href=\"/doc/767287/\" id=\"a_7\">Section\n\n313</a>     of   the   Criminal   Procedure   Code   denied    the\n\nincriminating evidence appearing against them.            Their\n\ndefence was denial simpliciter and pleaded false implication\n\ndue to enmity. No defence witness has been examined by\n\nthem.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">15.   The trial court on appraisal of the entire evidence on\n\nrecord held all the accused guilty of the charges and\n\nconvicted them as aforesaid.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                             8</span><p id=\"p_20\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">16.   Being aggrieved, the accused had filed appeal before\n\nthe High Court. The High Court, as stated above, allowed\n\nthe appeal of accused Ram Chander, Brahma, Pratap and\n\nGenda and, accordingly, set aside their conviction and\n\nsentences, whereas the conviction of the appellant-Satvir,\n\nRam Saran and Harbir is converted from <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 302</a> read\n\nwith <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 149</a> and <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 148</a> IPC to <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 302</a> read\n\nwith <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 34</a> IPC. They were sentenced to suffer rigorous\n\nimprisonment for life.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">17.   Feeling aggrieved thereby and dissatisfied with the\n\njudgment of the High Court, this appeal has been filed by\n\nappellant Satvir in this Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">18.   Mr. Shakil Ahmed Syed, learned counsel appearing on\n\nbehalf of the appellant, contended that the evidence\n\nappearing on record against the appellant is verbatim\n\nversion to that which was taken into consideration with\n\nregard to the acquittal of four accused and, therefore, the\n\ncase of the appellant cannot be decided on any other scale\n\nand should have been treated at par with the evidence\n\nappearing against the acquitted persons. The appellant and\n\nother accused persons have been implicated by PW-1 in a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                              9</span>\n\n\nfalse case due to previous enmity as he alongwith deceased\n\nwas an accused in the murder of Mahabir, son of Ram\n\nSaran.   According to the learned counsel, the High Court\n\nhas committed grave error in convicting the appellant on\n\nthe same set of evidence, on the basis of which four\n\naccused, namely, Ram Chander, Brahma, Pratap and\n\nGenda have been acquitted and, therefore, the judgment of\n\nthe High Court suffers from factual and legal infirmity and\n\nperversity. The learned counsel then contended that the\n\nconduct of the alleged eyewitnesses, namely, PW-1, PW-2\n\nand PW-4 is so unnatural and casual that they witnessed\n\nthe entire incident as silent spectators and did not make\n\nany attempt to save the life of Hari Dutt Singh at the hands\n\nof the accused.     Therefore, no implicit reliance can be\n\nplaced on the evidence of these witnesses, who are not\n\ntrustworthy.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">19.   Mr. T.N.Singh, Advocate appearing on behalf of the\n\nState, has canvassed correctness of the views taken by the\n\ntrial judge which were confirmed by the High Court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">20.   In order to appreciate the aforesaid rival contentions of\n\nthe learned counsel for the parties, we have independently\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                            10</span>\n\n\nscrutinized the oral and documentary evidence appearing\n\non record.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">21.   Mahendra Singh (PW-1) has clearly stated that at the\n\ntime and on the day of incident he was with his father when\n\nthe appellant and other accused suddenly attacked the\n\ndeceased. He categorically stated that the appellant and his\n\ntwo companions Ram Chander and Harbir had inflicted\n\nknife injuries on the person of his father. He has given the\n\nnames of all the accused persons in the report on the basis\n\nof which FIR came to be registered in the Police Station.\n\nPW-2 Bakhtawar Singh who is an independent witness\n\ndeposed that on the day of incident when he was going to\n\nhis village Bhadauli from village Kaili, on the way he heard\n\nan alarm raised by PW-1 and saw the appellant, Ram Saran\n\nand Harbir inflicting knife injuries to Hari Dutt Singh.\n\nSuggestion of the accused that he was not present at the\n\nplace of incident or he had not seen the incident or that he\n\nis deposing falsely due to relationship, has been denied by\n\nhim. PW-4 Ganga Saran Singh deposed that on the day of\n\nincident he witnessed the accused giving beatings to Hari\n\nDutt Singh in between the fields of Balley and Muley. The\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                            11</span>\n\n\nappellant alongwith Ram Saran and Harbir had inflicted\n\nknife injuries on the person of Hari Dutt Singh. The\n\neyewitnesses have been cross-examined at length by the\n\nlearned counsel, but nothing tangible has been extracted\n\nfrom their evidence to create any shadow of doubt that they\n\nare not truthfulness witnesses. They have given reliable,\n\nconsistent and creditable version of the crime and their\n\nevidence inspires confidence.    It is well-settled that if the\n\nwitness is related to the deceased, his evidence has to be\n\naccepted if found to be reliable and believable because he\n\nwould inter alia be interested in ensuring that real culprits\n\nare punished.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">22.   On a careful and cautious scrutiny of the evidence of\n\nPW-1, PW-2 and PW-4, we find their evidence concise,\n\nprecise and satisfactory on the point that they had seen the\n\nappellant, Ram Saran and Harbir causing grievous injuries\n\nto Hari Dutt Singh with knife which each was carrying with\n\nhim and due to the fatal injuries, he died on the spot. The\n\nevidence of these three eyewitnesses is neither embellished\n\nnor embroidered. We find no particular reason as to why\n\nPW-1, PW-2 and PW-4 have falsely deposed against the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                              12</span>\n\n\nappellant. The trial court as well as the High Court have\n\nrightly held that there was a motive for the accused to\n\ncommit murder of Hari Dutt Singh because as per the\n\nprosecution evidence, they were nursing a grudge against\n\nthe deceased because of his involvement in the commission\n\nof murder of Mahabir son of Ram Saran. The report of the\n\nincident has been promptly lodged by PW-1 in the Police\n\nStation in which the name of all the accused persons and\n\nPW-2 and PW-4 being eyewitnesses were mentioned. Simply\n\nbecause the eyewitnesses did not make any attempt to save\n\nthe life of the deceased from the clutches of the accused\n\npersons, their abnormal conduct by itself cannot be taken\n\nas a ground to disbelieve and discard their testimony in\n\nregard to the genesis of the occurrence and the part played\n\nby the appellant and the other convicted persons in the\n\ncommission of the offence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">23   The   ocular   version    of   the   eyewitnesses   finds\n\ncorroboration from the evidence of Dr. O.P. Sharma who\n\nhas found abovesaid six injuries on the body of Hari Dutt\n\nSingh. As per the post mortem report placed on record by\n\nDr.O.P. Sharma, the deceased received three stab wounds\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                             13</span>\n\n\nand two incised wounds and in his opinion death of the\n\ndeceased had occurred due to shock and haemorrhage as a\n\nresult of ante-mortem injuries.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">24.   On our independent examination of the judgment\n\ngiven by the trial court and confirmed by the High Court, we\n\nfind that both the courts have properly and rightly re-\n\nassessed and reappraised the entire evidence on record and\n\nwe find no infirmity or perversity in the findings recorded by\n\nthe courts below warranting interference. The High Court\n\nhas not found any reliable and clinching evidence led by the\n\nprosecution to prove the guilt of the acquitted-accused.\n\nTherefore, the contention that the appellant shall be held\n\nentitled to benefit of doubt in the same manner as other\n\nacquitted-accused have been given, cannot be accepted.\n\nThe occurrence, as spoken by the eyewitnesses, is fully\n\nestablished and the appellant alongwith Ram Saran and\n\nHarbir will be constructively liable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 302</a> read\n\nwith <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 34</a> IPC for the commission of the crime as fatal\n\ninjuries were inflicted by them with knives which they were\n\ncarrying in their hands at the time of commission of offence.\n\nThe fatal injuries were caused with dangerous weapons on\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                             14</span>\n\n\nvital parts of the body of deceased which resultantly caused\n\nhis death.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">25.   Learned counsel for the appellant lastly argued that\n\nthe appellant had no intention to murder the deceased,\n\ntherefore, no offence under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 302</a> IPC was made out\n\nagainst him and at the most it could be a case under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 304</a> Part-II IPC, cannot be accepted in view of the\n\nnature of injuries, the manner in which they were inflicted,\n\nthe weapons of offence used and the vital parts of the body\n\nof the deceased selected by the appellant and other two\n\nconvicted accused for causing the fatal injuries.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">26.   We, thus, find no merit and substance in any of the\n\nsubmissions made on behalf of the appellant.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">27.   In the result, for the afore-stated reasons, there is no\n\nmerit in this appeal and it is, accordingly, dismissed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">                                  ........................................J.\n                                  (Lokeshwar Singh Panta)\n\n\n\n                                  ........................................J.\n                                  (B. Sudershan Reddy)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 21, 2009.\n</p>\f"}, {"numcites":12,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"man Penal Code"},{"tid":1011035,"url":null,"title":"Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Hawa Singh & Anr vs State Of Haryana on 16 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-16","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":789023,"url":null,"title":"Gram Panchayat, Kundli And Anr. vs The State Of Haryana And Anr. on 6 May, 1981"},{"tid":532140,"url":null,"title":"Dilbagh Singh vs State Of Punjab on 1 February, 2008"},{"tid":708939,"url":null,"title":"Jai Prakash vs The State on 20 April, 1988"},{"tid":102512407,"url":null,"title":"Also At : vs The State on 1 August, 2012"}],"tid":368861,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":4,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33508","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Hawa Singh &amp; Anr vs State Of Haryana on 16 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                               REPORTABLE\n\n                       IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                    CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.               OF 2009\n                   (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 1515 of 2008)\n\n\nHawa Singh and Anr.                                            ..Appellants\n\n                                      Versus\n\nState of Haryana                                               ..Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                                 JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nPunjab and Haryana High Court upholding the conviction of the appellants\n\nfor offences punishable under Section 302 read with Section 34 and <a href=\"/doc/838469/\" id=\"a_1\">Section\n\n452</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>'). Though they were\n\ncharged of several other offences they were acquitted of those charges. In\n\nthe appeal filed by the appellants before the High Court there were several\n\fco-accused i.e. Jagdish, Devinder, Balwan and Murti Devi. Accused Jagdish\n\nand Devinder who were convicted under <a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 323</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 34</a>\n\nand <a href=\"/doc/838469/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 452</a> IPC. The other two accused persons i.e. Balwan and Murti\n\nwere acquitted of all charges.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Prosecution version in a nutshell is as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      On March 20, 2000 at 4.00 p.m. Man Singh was sitting near the gate\n\nof his house, while members of his family were present inside the house.\n\nHawa Singh, Parkash and Jagdish armed with swords, Balwan and\n\nDevender @ Raju armed with lathis, their sister Murti armed with rapri and\n\ntheir mother Gindori armed with pharsa came there. They entered the house\n\nand upon exhortation that a lesson be taught to Man Singh for getting them\n\nconvicted, Hawa Singh opened the attack with a sword with which he hit\n\nMan Singh on the head. This was followed by Parkash giving a blow with\n\nhis sword which hit Man Singh in the middle of his head. Jagdish also gave\n\na sword blow which hit Man Singh on the back of the head. When alarm\n\nwas raised Balwan hit Sajjan (PW-7) with a lathi on his forehead above left\n\neye. Devender @ Raju hit Sajjan (PW-7) with a lathi on his left leg. Murti\n\nand Gindori also inflicted injuries on Sajjan. They also caused grievous\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                         2</span>\n\finjuries to Anju and Sarti. Sajjan's younger brother Krishan and his uncle\n\nAzad Singh reached the spot to rescue them from the assailants. During the\n\ncourse of rescuing the injured, Azad Singh also sustained injuries. Some\n\ninjuries were also inflicted by complainant party on the accused in self\n\ndefence before the accused retreated from the spot with their respective\n\nweapons. After the occurrence was over, the injured were taken to Civil\n\nHospital, Bhiwani. On reaching the hospital Man Singh succumbed to his\n\ninjuries whereas the injured were medico legally examined. Anju and Sajjan\n\nwere medico legally examined by Dr. Arjun Chander Yadav (PW-1) at 6.35\n\np.m. and 8.15 respectively. Anju was found to have various injuries on her\n\nright hand.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      The case was registered at Police Station Sadar, Bhiwani on the basis\n\nof the statement of Sajjan (PW-7) recorded by ASI Suraj Bhan at 10.50 p.m.\n\non the same evening at General Hospital, Bhiwani. FIR was recorded in\n\nrespect of offences punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_6\">Sections 302</a>, <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_7\">148</a>, <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_8\">149</a>, <a href=\"/doc/838469/\" id=\"a_9\">452</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_10\">323</a>\n\nIPC. Special report was delivered at 3.50 a.m. on March 21, 2000.\n\nThereafter, the Investigating Officer took up the investigation by first\n\npreparing the inquest report on the dead body of deceased Man Singh. After\n\nthe inquest proceedings, post mortem was conducted by Dr. Ramesh Kumar\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                       3</span>\n\f(PW-4). The Medical Officer found several injuries on the body of Man\n\nSingh. In the opinion of the Medical Officer the death was caused due to\n\nhamorrhage and shock and injury to the brain. The accused were arrested on\n\nMarch 30, 2000 by Inspector Darshan Lal (PW-11). On the basis of their\n\nrespective disclosure statements, certain weapons were recovered from\n\npossession of the accused i.e. axes from Parkash and Hawa Singh, rapris\n\nfrom Jagdish and Devender @ Raju and a lathi from Balwan.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      After completion of the investigation all the accused barring Murti\n\nwere sent up for trial. Murti was placed in column 2 of the report under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1412034/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 173</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (in short the `Code').\n\nShe was subsequently summoned to stand trial under <a href=\"/doc/1138947/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 319</a> of the\n\nCode. Charge was first framed against the accused on July 19, 2000 under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 302</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 149</a> IPC and other related offences. Charges\n\nwere reframed on January 25, 2001. By this time Murti Devi had been\n\nsummoned as accused. Finally charge was reframed on April 15, 2004. All\n\nthe accused persons were found guilty and convicted.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      Before the High Court the specific stand was that <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 302</a> had no\n\napplication because there was free fight and the occurrence took place in\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                       4</span>\n\fcourse of sudden quarrel. The High Court accepted that there was a sudden\n\nquarrel and there were injuries on both sides. But it took the view that the\n\nappellants were apparently the aggressors and, therefore, the conviction\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 302</a> IPC was in order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">4.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the appellants submitted\n\nthat after having recording a finding that there was free and open fight, the\n\nquestion as to who was the aggressor was really irrelevant and the fact that\n\nthe persons belonging to the complainant party received more injuries was\n\nalso really of no consequence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">5.    Learned counsel for the respondent-State supported the judgment.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">6.    For bringing in operation of Exception 4 to <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 300</a> IPC it has to\n\nbe established that the act was committed without premeditation, in a\n\nsudden fight in the heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel without the\n\noffender having taken undue advantage and not having acted in a cruel or\n\nunusual manner.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                        5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">\f7.    The Fourth Exception of <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 300</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_19\">IPC</a> covers acts done in a\n\nsudden fight. The said exception deals with a case of prosecution not\n\ncovered by the first exception, after which its place would have been more\n\nappropriate. The exception is founded upon the same principle, for in both\n\nthere is absence of premeditation. But, while in the case of Exception 1\n\nthere is total deprivation of self-control, in case of Exception 4, there is only\n\nthat heat of passion which clouds men's sober reasons and urges them to\n\ndeeds which they would not otherwise do.             There is provocation in\n\nException 4 as in Exception 1; but the injury done is not the direct\n\nconsequence of that provocation. In fact Exception 4 deals with cases in\n\nwhich notwithstanding that a blow may have been struck, or some\n\nprovocation given in the origin of the dispute or in whatever way the quarrel\n\nmay have originated, yet the subsequent conduct of both parties puts them\n\nin respect of guilt upon equal footing. A `sudden fight' implies mutual\n\nprovocation and blows on each side. The homicide committed is then\n\nclearly not traceable to unilateral provocation, nor in such cases could the\n\nwhole blame be placed on one side. For if it were so, the Exception more\n\nappropriately applicable would be Exception 1.          There is no previous\n\ndeliberation or determination to fight. A fight suddenly takes place, for\n\nwhich both parties are more or less to be blamed. It may be that one of them\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                          6</span>\n\fstarts it, but if the other had not aggravated it by his own conduct it would\n\nnot have taken the serious turn it did. There is then mutual provocation and\n\naggravation, and it is difficult to apportion the share of blame which\n\nattaches to each fighter. The help of Exception 4 can be invoked if death is\n\ncaused (a) without premeditation, (b) in a sudden fight; (c) without the\n\noffender's having taken undue advantage or acted in a cruel or unusual\n\nmanner; and (d) the fight must have been with the person killed. To bring a\n\ncase within Exception 4 all the ingredients mentioned in it must be found. It\n\nis to be noted that the `fight' occurring in Exception 4 to <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 300</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_21\">IPC</a> is\n\nnot defined in the <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_22\">IPC</a>. It takes two to make a fight. Heat of passion\n\nrequires that there must be no time for the passions to cool down and in this\n\ncase, the parties have worked themselves into a fury on account of the\n\nverbal altercation in the beginning. A fight is a combat between two and\n\nmore persons whether with or without weapons. It is not possible to\n\nenunciate any general rule as to what shall be deemed to be a sudden\n\nquarrel. It is a question of fact and whether a quarrel is sudden or not must\n\nnecessarily depend upon the proved facts of each case. For the application\n\nof Exception 4, it is not sufficient to show that there was a sudden quarrel\n\nand there was no premeditation. It must further be shown that the offender\n\nhas not taken undue advantage or acted in cruel or unusual manner. The\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                         7</span>\n\fexpression `undue advantage' as used in the provision means `unfair\n\nadvantage'. These aspects have been highlighted in Dhirajbhai Gorakhbhai\n\nNayak v. State of Gujrat (2003 (5) Supreme 223], <a href=\"/doc/573457/\" id=\"a_23\">Parkash Chand v. State\n\nof H.P</a>. (2004 (11) SCC 381) and <a href=\"/doc/1070976/\" id=\"a_24\">Byvarapu Raju v. State of A.P. and Anr</a>.\n\n(2007 (11) SCC 218)\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">8.     From the facts of the case, it appears that the accused persons armed\n\nwith deadly weapons like swords, balwan, lathis, pharsa came to the house\n\nof the Man Singh on 20th March, 2000, at 4 p.m., to teach Man Singh a\n\nlesson for getting the accused persons convicted. After coming to the house\n\nof Man Singh, Hawa Singh opened the attack with the sword, with which he\n\nhit Man Singh on the head and ultimately Man Singh succumbed to his\n\ninjuries.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">9.     Exception 4 to <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_25\">Section 300</a> IPC applies in the absence of any\n\npremeditation. This is very clear from the wording of the exception itself.\n\nThe exception contemplates that the sudden fight shall start upon the heat of\n\npassion on a sudden quarrel but here, the accused party, being deadly\n\narmed, came with the intention of teaching Man Singh a lesson and in\n\nfurtherance of that, one of them, Hawa Singh, hit Man Singh on the head\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                        8</span>\n\fwith a sword, an attack with a deadly weapon on the vital part of the body\n\nand that proved to be a fatal blow.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">10.    Therefore, Exception 4 to <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_26\">Section 300</a> has no application to the facts\n\nof the present case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">11.    The appellants have been rightly convicted in terms of <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_27\">Section 302</a>\n\nIPC.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">12.    The appeal is accordingly dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">                                      ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">                                      (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                      ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">                                      (ASOK KUAMR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 15, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                        9</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"contract  citedby:1625889","formInput":"contract%20%20citedby%3A1625889"},{"value":"estoppel","formInput":"estoppel"},{"value":"transfer of property","formInput":"transfer%20of%20property"},{"value":"sec 43","formInput":"sec%2043"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Jharu Ram Roy vs Kamjit Roy & Ors on 13 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33905","lastname":null,"secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-13","citedbyList":[{"tid":841438,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=27190","title":"Ramakrishna Reddiar vs Sathiamurthy on 12 August, 2010"},{"tid":116269960,"url":"http://bombayhighcourt.nic.in/generatenewauth.php?auth=cGF0aD0uL2RhdGEvbmFnanVkZ2VtZW50cy8yMDE1LyZmbmFtZT1DU0EzMjM2MDEucGRmJnNtZmxhZz1OJnJqdWRkYXRlPSZ1cGxvYWRkdD0xMS8wOS8yMDE1JnNwYXNzcGhyYXNlPTExMDkxNTIzNTc0OA==","title":"Tulsa Mahadeo Nagrale & 4 Ors vs Sita Vilas Zade & 7 Ors on 10 September, 2015"},{"tid":164892602,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/Judis_Chennai/list_new2.asp?FileName=244820","title":"Thangamuthu vs Sridevi Venkidasamy on 30 April, 2015"},{"tid":145391790,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/Judis_Chennai/list_new2.asp?FileName=289310","title":"P. Rajavelu vs Udayapriya on 2 September, 2016"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":3,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Jharu Ram Roy vs Kamjit Roy &amp; Ors on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Mukundakam Sharma, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                         1\n\n\n                            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                            CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n                             CIVIL APPEAL NO. 151         OF 2009\n                            [Arising out of SLP(C) No. 2987/2008]\n\n\nJHARU RAM ROY                                                   ...       APPELLANT(S)\n\n                                         :VERSUS:\n\nKAMJIT ROY AND ORS.                                                 ...   RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n\n                                         ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">              Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">              This appeal is directed against a judgment and order dated 4.6.2007\n\n      passed by the learned Single Judge of the High Court Gauhati in R.S.A No.\n\n      169/2006 preferred by the appellant herein, whereby and whereunder the\n\n      judgment and order dated 18.4.2006 passed by a Civil Judge, Senior Division, was\n\n      affirmed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">              The basic fact of the matter is not in dispute.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n              One Nakho Ram was the owner of the suit property. He had two sons,\n\n      namely, Rajiv Lochan Roy and Kamjit Roy. The property in the suit admeasured\n\n      16 Bighas 4 Kathas.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">              Rajiv Lochan executed two deeds of sale in 1982, in respect of about 4\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        2</span>\n\nBighas of land, inter alia, contending that he had half share in the said property.\n\nIt is not in dispute that the family of Nakho Ram was governed by Dayabhaga\n\nSchool of Hindu Law. It is furthermore not in dispute that in 1982, Nakho Ram\n\nwas alive and he expired only in the year 1990. Appellant, however, claimed that\n\nin terms of the aforementioned deeds of sale executed by Rajiv Lochan in the year\n\n1982, he had remained in possession of the vested property since the date of\n\npurchase.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">         It is, furthermore, not in dispute that in the year 1990, a proceeding\n\nunder Section 107 as also <a href=\"/doc/1405190/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 145</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure was\n\ninitiated and therein, Respondent No.1 herein was put in possession of the\n\nproperty.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">         Respondent No.1 filed a suit in the year 1991 for declaration of his title,\n\nconfirmation of possession as also a decree for setting aside two deeds of sale\n\nexecuted by Rajiv Lochan in the year 1982. The said suit was dismissed by the\n\nlearned Trial Judge, inter alia holding that the legal representatives of the\n\nproforma respondents having not been brought on record, the suit had abated. It\n\nwas furthermore held that the defendant-appellant acquired title to the suit\n\nproperty by adverse possession. The suit so far as it related to setting aside the\n\naforementioned deeds of sale was, however, held to be barred by limitation.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">         The First Appellate Court, however, on an appeal preferred by the\n\ncontesting respondents, reversed the said findings of the Trial Court opining that\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                         3</span>\n\nas the defendant-appellant was a party to the fraud perpetrated by Rajiv Lochan\n\nin so far as he was, at all material times, aware that in the year 1990, Nakho Ram\n\nwas alive and not dead, he cannot take benefit of the said deeds of sale and the\n\nsame were void ab initio. The High Court, as noticed hereinbefore, has affirmed\n\nthe said view.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">         Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant would contend\n\nthat the High Court committed a serious error in passing the impugned judgment\n\nin so far as it failed to take into consideration the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/1907896/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 43</a> of the\n\nTransfer of Property Act, in terms whereof, having regard to the fact that Rajiv\n\nLochan had also died in the year 1992, the doctrine of feeding the estoppel\n\nbecame applicable to the facts of the present case.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">         A finding of fact has been arrived at by the First Appellate Court that\n\nthe appellant was also a party to the fraud inasmuch as he was all along aware\n\nthat on the date of execution of the deeds of sale, Nakho Ram was alive.\n\nIndisputably, therefore, the appellant entered into the aforementioned transaction\n\nknowing fully well that Nakho Ram was alive in the year 1992, Rajiv Lochan\n\ncould not have executed the deeds of sale and only with a view to obviate the legal\n\ndifficulties, Nakho Ram was shown to have expired.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">         Appellant was furthermore aware that although Rajiv Lochan did not\n\ninherit the property of Nakho Ram, he executed the aforementioned deeds of sale.\n\nRajiv Lochan, thus, having no title to the property, by said deeds of sale or\n\notherwise, evidently could not have derived any title thereover.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                         4</span>\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">         <a href=\"/doc/1907896/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 43</a> of the Transfer of Property Act reads as under:\n\n        \"43.Transfer by unauthorised person who subsequently\n        acquires interest in property transferred.- Where a person\n        fraudulently or erroneously represents that he is authorised to\n        transfer certain immovable property and professes to transfer\n        such property for consideration,l such transfer shall, at the option\n        of the transferee, operate on any interest which the transferor may\n        acquire in such property at any time during which the contract of\n        transfer subsists.\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">                   Nothing in this section shall impair the right of\n        transferees in good faith for consideration without notice of the\n        existence of the said option.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n         In this case, as the appellant averred that although in the deeds of sale, a\n\nstipulation was made by Rajiv Lochan that his father had expired, it cannot be\n\nsaid to be a case where he fraudulently or erroneously represented that he was\n\nauthorized to transfer the said immovable property. As noticed hereinbefore, a\n\nfinding of fact had been arrived at by the First Appellate Court that the appellant\n\nwas a party to the fraud and that he was not victim thereof.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">         Our attention, however, has been drawn to a decision of this Court in\n\n[2007 (2) SCC 404]. In the said decision this Court laid down the law in the\n\nfollowing terms:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">        \"12. In order to get the benefit of the said provision, the conditions\n        which must be satisfied are:\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                   (1) the contract of transfer was made by a person who\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                 5</span>\n\n             was competent to contract; and\n           (2) the contract would be subsisting at the time when a\n             claim for recovery of the property is made.\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_20\">13. However, the provisions would have no application if the\ntransfer was invalid as being forbidden by law or contrary to\npublic policy, as envisaged under <a href=\"/doc/1625889/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 23</a> of the Contract Act.\nThus, no estoppel can be pleaded contrary to the provisions of a\nstatute. The 'rule of feeding the estoppel' shall apply in absence\nthereof.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">14. The doctrine of feeding the estoppel envisages that 'where a\ngrantor has purported to grant an interest in land which he did\nnot at the time possess, but subsequently acquires, the benefit of\nhis subsequent acquisition, goes automatically to the earlier\ngrantee, or as it is usually expressed, feeds the estoppel'.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">15. The principle is based on an equitable doctrine that a person\nwho promised to perform more than he can perform must make\ngood his contract when he acquires the power of performance.\nThe difference between the ambit of <a href=\"/doc/584197/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 41</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1907896/\" id=\"a_6\">43</a> of the Act\nis apparent. Whereas <a href=\"/doc/584197/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 41</a> provides that a transfer by an\nostensible owner cannot be avoided on the ground that the\ntransferee should take reasonable care to ascertain that the\ntransferor had power to make the transfer and to act in good\nfaith before a benefit thereof if claimed by him. <a href=\"/doc/1907896/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 43</a>, on the\nother hand, enables the transferee to whom a transferor has made\na fraudulent or erroneous representation to lay hold, at his option,\nof any interest which the transferor may subsequently acquire in\nthe property, unless the right of any subsequent purchaser for\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                            6</span>\n\n           value without notice is in effect.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                     Fraud vitiates all solemn acts.            As the appellant was aware\n\n  of the fact that Nakho Ram had not expired in 1992, in our opinion, the\n\n  provisions of <a href=\"/doc/1907896/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 43</a> of the Transfer of Property Act cannot be said to have\n\n  any application in the instant case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">           For the reasons aforementioned, this appeal is dismissed. However, there\n\n  shall be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">                                                 ..........................J\n                                                 (S.B. SINHA)\n\n\n\n                                                  ..........................J\n                                                 (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\n\n\n\n                                                 ..........................J\n                                                 (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNEW DELHI,\nJANUARY 13, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":868612,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1907896,"url":null,"title":"Section 43 in The Transfer of Property Act, 1882"},{"tid":584197,"url":null,"title":"Section 41 in The Transfer of Property Act, 1882"},{"tid":1625889,"url":null,"title":"Section 23 in The Indian Contract Act, 1872"},{"tid":1405190,"url":null,"title":"Section 145 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"}]}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"apprentices ","formInput":"apprentices%20"},{"value":"national commission","formInput":"national%20commission"},{"value":"legal fiction","formInput":"legal%20fiction"},{"value":" common parlance","formInput":"%20common%20parlance"},{"value":"new india ","formInput":"new%20india%20"},{"value":"meaning of  \"or' ","formInput":"meaning%20of%20%20%22or%27%20"},{"value":"plant ","formInput":"plant%20"}],"firstname":null,"title":"New India Assurance Co. Ltd vs M/S. Abhilash Jewellery on 22 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33553","lastname":"......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-22","citedbyList":[{"tid":1102952,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=18551","title":"Tamil Nadu Spinning Mills ... vs The State Of Tamil Nadu on 30 April, 2009"},{"tid":73894094,"url":null,"title":"Smt. Ragini Sharma vs The Divisional Manager on 22 May, 2015"},{"tid":117739525,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/RSE/judgement/04-06-2010/RSE02062010CW20831989.pdf","title":"M/S Srinivas Malliah Memorial ... vs Regional Provident Fund ... on 2 June, 2010"},{"tid":107902100,"url":"http://phhc.gov.in/pdf/fo/CWP_14575_2014_14_10_2014_FINAL_ORDER.pdf","title":"Trishul Wood Products Pvt Ltd vs Chandigarh Administration And ... on 14 October, 2014"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":4,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">New India Assurance Co. Ltd vs M/S. Abhilash Jewellery on 22 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Markandey Katju, R.M. Lodha</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                               Reportable\n         IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n              CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n       CIVIL APPEAL NO(s). 7972 OF 2002\n\nNEW INDIA ASSURANCE CO. LTD.                 Appellant (s)\n\n            VERSUS\n\nM/S. ABHILASH JEWELLERY                    Respondent(s)\n\n                              O R D E R\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">            Heard learned counsel for the parties. This appeal has been filed\nagainst the order of the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission, New\nDelhi dated 15.03.2002.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">            The respondent had a business establishment at Vellappad in Trissur\nDistrict in the State of Kerala.     It took a Jeweller's Block Policy for Rs.\n1,15,00,000/-. During the currency of the policy, the complainant-respondent\nlodged a claim with the appellant for the loss of gold ornament weighing 587.870\ngrams. The claim was repudiated by the appellant on the ground that the loss of\ngold was occasioned as it was in the custody of an apprentice, who was not an\nemployee.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">            The relevant clause in the Insurance Policy stated;\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">                 \"S. 11(a) property insured whilst in the custody of the\n    insured, his partner or his employees\".\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">            The question, therefore, is whether an apprentice is an employee.\n            The National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission has held\nthat an apprentice is an employee because Section 2 (6) of the Kerala Shops and\nCommercial Establishments Act defines an employee to include an\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                      -2-</span>\n\n\napprentice. The National Commission has also relied on the definition in the\n<a href=\"/doc/88376/\" id=\"a_1\">Employees State Insurance Act</a> and some other enactments.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">            We are of the opinion that the view taken by the Natinal Commssion\nis not correct. The present case is covered solely by the contract of insurance.\nThat contract of insurance no doubt uses the word 'employee', but it does not say\nthat the word 'employee' in the contract of insurance will have the same meaning\nas in the Kerala Shops and Commercial Establishments Act or the <a href=\"/doc/88376/\" id=\"a_2\">Employees\nState Insurance Act</a> or any other enactment.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">            In various enactments, the word 'employee', has no doubt, been\ndefined to include an apprentice, but that is only a deeming provision and a legal\nfiction by which the meaning of the word 'employee' has been extended.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">            Legal fictions are well-knwon in law. For example, <a href=\"/doc/1715862/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 43</a> (3) of\nthe <a href=\"/doc/789969/\" id=\"a_4\">Income Tax Act</a> defines 'plant' to include a book. Ordinarily a plant means a\nfactory, and by no stretch of imagination can we call a factory a book. However,\nthe <a href=\"/doc/789969/\" id=\"a_5\">Income Tax Act</a> deems a book to be a plant for the purpose of depreciation.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">            Many such illustrations of deeming clauses or legal fictions can be\ngiven.   The definition of employee in various enactments which include an\napprentice within the ambit of the definition is such a piece of legal fiction. That,\nhowever, does not mean that in common parlance an apprentice is an employee.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">            In the present case, since the word 'employee' has not been defined in\nthe contract of insurance, we have to give it the meaning which it has in common\nparlance. In common parlance, an apprentice is a trainee and not an employee.\nEven if he is given a stipend, that does not\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                              -3-</span>\n\n\n        mean that there is a relationship of master and servant between the firm and the\n        apprentice.     Hence, we cannot agree with the view taken by the National\n        Commission. In our view , the claim before the National Commission was not\n        maintainable.\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                      Hence we set aside the order of the National Commission.\n                      The appeal is allowed. No orders as to costs.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_12\">                                                            ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                              [MARKANDEY KATJU]\n\n\n\n                                                    .....................J\n                           [R.M. LODHA]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 22, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":938531,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":88376,"url":null,"title":"The Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948"},{"tid":789969,"url":null,"title":"The Income- Tax Act,   1995"},{"tid":1715862,"url":null,"title":"Section 43 in The Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"state of gujarat","formInput":"state%20of%20gujarat"},{"value":"sirpurkar","formInput":"sirpurkar"},{"value":"the director general of police ","formInput":"the%20director%20general%20of%20police%20"},{"value":"communal ","formInput":"communal%20"}],"firstname":"v","title":"Citizens For Justice And Peace vs State Of Gujarat & Ors on 13 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33487","lastname":"sirpurkar","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-13","citedbyList":[{"tid":974464,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/DMA/judgement/16-08-2011/DMA16082011CW34572011.pdf","title":"Ajay Kumar Joshi vs Union Of India & Ors. on 16 August, 2011"},{"tid":117890502,"url":"http://judgmenthck.kar.nic.in/judgments/bitstream/123456789/664095/2/WP8788-12-30-03-2012.pdf","title":"The State Of Karnataka vs Sri A R Infant I.P.S-Karnataka on 30 March, 2012"},{"tid":68208056,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=40310","title":"M.Suresh Kumar vs Union Of India on 10 November, 2012"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":3,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Citizens For Justice And Peace vs State Of Gujarat &amp; Ors on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: V Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Markandey Katju, V.S. Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                              1\n\n                                                        \"REPORTABLE\"\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL ORIGINAL JURISDICTION\n\n                WRIT PETITION (C) NO. 219 OF 2006\n\n\nCitizens for Justice and Peace                           .... Petitioner\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of Gujarat &amp; Others                                .... Respondents\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">V.S. SIRPURKAR, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    This Writ Petition under <a href=\"/doc/981147/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 32</a> of the Constitution of India has\n\nbeen filed basically challenging the appointment and continuation of\n\nrespondent No. 3 Shri P.C. Pandey to the post of Director General of\n\nPolice, State of Gujarat. The other prayer in the Writ Petition is to direct\n\nrespondent No. 1 - State of Gujarat to take disciplinary action including\n\nprosecuting respondent No. 3 for having failed in his duties during the\n\nGujarat carnage of 2002.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">2.    Notice was issued by this Court on 11.5.2006 to the respondents,\n\nwhereupon, the State of Gujarat has come up with a Counter Affidavit,\n\ndenying most of the contentions raised in the Writ Petition.      This Writ\n\nPetition was filed on 1.5.2006 and notice thereof was issued on 11.5.2006\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                      2</span>\n\nand ever since then, number of interim orders in nature of directions came\n\nto be passed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">3.       Shortly stated, the petitioner claiming itself to be an organization,\n\nwhich was started as a response to the alleged carnage which took place\n\nin Gujarat from 27.2.2002 onwards with the main objective to bridge the\n\ngap between the various religious communities, as also to ensure that\n\njustice is done to those who are the victims of communalism. It is claimed\n\nthat it had set up a Citizens Tribunal to go into the causes and extent of\n\ncommunal violence in Gujarat headed by two retired Hon'ble Judges of this\n\nCourt.     The petitioner has filed the Report of the said Tribunal, which\n\npublished in two volumes. The other contentions which are raised are that\n\nthe respondent No. 3 Shri P.C. Pandey was the Commissioner of Police,\n\nAhmedabad during the period when the communal disturbances rocked the\n\nState of Gujarat.     It is claimed that more than 700 persons died and\n\nnumber of irregularities were committed by Shri Pandey such as not\n\nsupplying the reinforcements and serious derelictions of his duties.\n\nNumber of other allegations have been made that Shri Pandey was sent on\n\ndeputation to CBI, which appointment was challenged before this Court by\n\nthe petitioner by filing Writ Petition (C) No. 147 of 2004, wherein, the Union\n\nof India had given an undertaking that he would not handle any cases\n\nrelating to Gujarat riots of 2002. He was accordingly not allowed to handle\n\nthose cases. It has also come in the allegations that on account of the\n\ndirections issued by this Court, about 2000 cases which were hastily closed\n\nby the then Gujarat Government, were directed to be re-opened and a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                    3</span>\n\nfresh scrutiny into those cases was also ordered. It was expresses that if\n\nShri Pandey continued in the highest post of Director General of Police,\n\nthose cases would be adversely affected and the guilty would be shielded\n\nand that would be patent denial of justice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">4.    In its Counter Affidavit, the State of Gujarat opposed most of the\n\nclaims and pointed out that the claim that the appointment of respondent\n\nNo. 3 as a Director General of Police would be detrimental to the cause of\n\njustice, is not correct.   It is pointed out that the Review Committee\n\nconstituted under the directions of this Court earlier vide order dated\n\n17.8.2004 was required to look into all 2020 riot cases, wherein, the\n\ninvestigating agency had filed \"A\" Summary. It is further pointed out that\n\nShri Pandey was not in any manner connected with the Review Committee\n\nnor was he in a position to influence the same. It is further pointed out that\n\nup to the quarter ending 30th April, 2006, as many as 1989 cases out of the\n\naforesaid 2020 cases had already been reviewed in respect of which\n\nperiodic reports were filed by the Committee before this Court. It is claimed\n\nthat in all, hardly 30 \"A\" summary cases had remained and it was,\n\ntherefore, argued before us by the Learned Counsel appearing on behalf of\n\nthe State of Gujarat that there was no point in now taking exception to the\n\nappointment and continuation of the third respondent as the Director\n\nGeneral of Police. Learned Counsel also informed us during the debate\n\nthat even those 30 \"A\" summary cases have already been decided upon\n\nand, therefore, there is no scope for those cases being affected by Shri\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                     4</span>\n\nPandey in his continuation as the Director General of Police. It is further\n\nsubmitted at the Bar that Shri Pandey is going to retire on 31st March, 2009\n\nand under the circumstances, this Writ Petition itself has become\n\nredundant.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">5.    Considering the overall situation, firstly, the fact that almost all the\n\ncases in the \"A\" summary, which were recommenced by the investigating\n\nagency, have already been dealt with by the Scrutiny Committee and\n\nsecondly that Shri Pandey is going to retire on 31st March, 2009, we do not\n\npropose to continue with this Writ Petition. In fact, this Writ Petition has\n\nitself become redundant as the continuation of Shri Pandey as the DGP is\n\nof no consequence insofar as the apprehension expressed by the petitioner\n\nin the Writ Petition is concerned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">6.    Shri P.P. Rao urged that if Shri Pandey continues to that post, he\n\nmay be in a position to pressurize the Courts, where, in pursuance of the\n\nrecommendations of the Scrutiny Committee, the prosecutions are in\n\nprogress. We do not think that such a thing can be said either regarding\n\nShri Pandey or even the Trial Courts in Gujarat. We do not have any\n\nreasons to believe that Shri Pandey, in his remaining tenure of about three\n\nmonths, would take any such steps. We do not think that the Trial Courts\n\nin Gujarat are capable of being pressurized in the manner expressed in the\n\nWrit Petition.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">7.    An appointment of a government servant is the prerogative of the\n\nparticular government, particularly, when it is a sensitive appointment of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                    5</span>\n\nDirector General of Police.     We, under the doctrine of `judicial review',\n\nwould not extend our hands to upset such an appointment, more\n\nparticularly, in the factual panorama which is available today. We hold that\n\nthe present Writ Petition has become redundant and we dispose it of as\n\nsuch.    As for any disciplinary action against Shri Pandey, it is for the\n\nconcerned government. We will not enter the fact finding exercise.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">8.      Shri Rao further expressed that the Government of Gujarat might\n\nextend the appointment by giving extension to Shri Pandey. We do not\n\nthink any such contention can be entertained at this stage, without there\n\nbeing any basis for the same.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">9.      In the result, the Writ Petition is disposed of in the light of\n\nobservations made hereinabove.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                             ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                                             (Markandey Katju)\n\n\n\n                                              ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                             (V.S. Sirpurkar)\n\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">January 13, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1625266,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":981147,"url":null,"title":"Article 32 in The Constitution Of India   1949"}]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"order 41 rule 27","formInput":"order%2041%20rule%2027"},{"value":"order 41","formInput":"order%2041"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Muzaffar Ali vs Dasaram on 12 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33483","lastname":"......j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-12","citedbyList":[{"tid":736126,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=21337","title":"Varadhan vs M.Govindasamy on 5 November, 2009"},{"tid":240995,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=30883","title":"Chinnathayammal vs K.Padmavathy on 21 March, 2011"},{"tid":173132957,"url":"http://bombayhighcourt.nic.in/generatenewauth.php?auth=cGF0aD0uL2RhdGEvanVkZ2VtZW50cy8yMDE1LyZmbmFtZT1DQ1JBMjUzMDExMy5wZGYmc21mbGFnPU4=","title":"Smt. Khatija Ismail Panhalkar And ... vs Shri Baitulla Ismail Shaikh And ... on 4 August, 2015"},{"tid":135316600,"url":"http://bombayhighcourt.nic.in/generatenewauth.php?auth=cGF0aD0uL2RhdGEvanVkZ2VtZW50cy8yMDE1LyZmbmFtZT1DQ1JBMjc3MzUxMy5wZGYmc21mbGFnPU4=","title":"Shri Vasant Mahadeo Gujar vs Shri Baitulla Ismail Shaikh And ... on 4 August, 2015"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":4,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Muzaffar Ali vs Dasaram on 12 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Tarun Chatterjee, H.L. Dattu</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                               NON-REPORTABLE\n\n      IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n       CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n          CIVIL APPEAL NO.85 OF 2009\n       (Arising out of SLP)No.6241 of 2008)\n\n\nMuzaffar Ali                          ...Appellant\n\n     VERSUS\n\nDasaram                                ...Respondent</pre>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">     1.   Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">     2.   In our view, the impugned order is liable to be\n\n          set aside on a simple ground that while\n\n          deciding the Second Appeal, the High Court of\n\n          Madhya Pradesh had not considered a part of\n\n          the order of the Appellate Court, by which the\n\n          application filed by the appellant before the\n\n          Appellate Court under Order 41 Rule 27 of\n\n          the Code of Civil Procedure was rejected. It is\n\n          true that the First Appellate Court, while\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                        1</span>\n\f     deciding the First Appeal, had given reasons\n\n     for rejection of the said application but the\n\n     ground for such rejection was, as noted\n\n     hereinabove, not considered by the High\n\n     Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.   That being the position, we set aside the\n\n     Judgment of the High Court and direct it to\n\n     decide the appeal afresh on merits and in\n\n     accordance     with   law    along   with     the\n\n     application under Order 41 Rule 27 of the\n\n     CPC and the reasons given by the First\n\n     Appellate Court for its rejection.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">4.   The High Court is now requested to decide\n\n     the second appeal along with the application\n\n     under Order 41 Rule 27 of the CPC on merits\n\n     within a period of three months from the date\n\n     of supply of a copy of this order.          While\n\n     deciding the same, the High Court shall also\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                     2</span>\n\f             consider the reasons for rejection of the\n\n             application under Order 41 Rule 27 of the\n\n             CPC given by the Appellate Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">        5.   The impugned order is, therefore, set aside.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">             The appeal is allowed to the extent indicated\n\n             above. There will be no order as to costs.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                    ...............................J.\n                                   [TARUN CHATTERJEE]\n\n\n\nNEW DELHI:                                      .....................\n......J.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">JANUARY 12, 2009.
