APPELLANT(S)\n\n                                          :VERSUS:\n\nARCHANA PRAKASH NARKHEDE AND ORS.                                ...   RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n\n                                          ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">             Delay condoned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">             Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">             Respondents filed a writ petition before the High Court, inter alia, praying\n\n    for the following reliefs:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"(d) Issue writ of mandamus or any other appropriate writ, order\n             or direction to direct the Respondent No.2 to appoint the petitioner\n             on the post of Anganwadi Madatnis, who is more meritorious\n             candidate for the post of Anganwadi Madatnis.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_5\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">             The High Court passed an interim order in terms of prayer (d) and (c) in the\n\n    writ petition, without assigning any reason therefor and without giving an\n\n    opportunity of being heard to the appellant herein.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                         -2-</span>\n\f         An application for review of the said order was filed by the appellant, which\n\nagain, without assigning any reason, has been dismissed.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">         We, therefore, are of the opinion that the impugned judgment cannot be\n\nsustained and it is set aside accordingly.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">         However, the respondents may file appropriate application for grant of an\n\ninterim relief(s) if any occasion arises therefor.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">         We would request the High Court to consider the desirability of disposing of\n\nthe writ petition as expeditiously as possible, preferably within a period of three\n\nmonths form the date of communication of this order.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">         The appeal is allowed with the aforementioned direction.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                                 ..........................J\n                                                 (S.B. SINHA)\n\n\n\n\n                                                 ..........................J\n                                                (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\n\nNEW DELHI,\nJANUARY 12, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":756380,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":5,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"bhandari","formInput":"bhandari"},{"value":"dalveer bhandari","formInput":"dalveer%20bhandari"},{"value":"best evidence","formInput":"best%20evidence"},{"value":"market value of land","formInput":"market%20value%20of%20land"},{"value":"land sale ","formInput":"land%20sale%20"}],"firstname":"d","title":"T.S. Ramachandra Shetty vs Chairman, Karnataka Housing ... on 22 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33660","lastname":"bhandari","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-22","citedbyList":[{"tid":1650996,"url":null,"title":"Moidi Beary vs The President, Taluk Board on 31 March, 1932"},{"tid":84296716,"url":null,"title":"Mr.M.L.Wadhera vs Union Of India on 27 January, 2012"},{"tid":137329170,"url":null,"title":"Reference Under Section 18 Of Land ... vs Union Of India on 6 July, 2011"},{"tid":174836125,"url":"http://phhc.gov.in/pdf/fo/RFA_1496_1991_27_08_2015_FINAL_ORDER.pdf","title":"(O&M;) Karam Devi And Others vs State Of Haryana And Another on 27 August, 2015"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":4,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">T.S. Ramachandra Shetty vs Chairman, Karnataka Housing ... on 22 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D Bhandari</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Dalveer Bhandari, Harjit Singh Bedi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                          IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO.3332 OF 2001\n\nT.S. Ramachandra Shetty                            ... Appellant\n\n             Versus\n\nChairman, Karnataka Housing Board\n&amp; Another                                               ...\nRespondents\n\n\n                                WITH\n\n         CIVIL APPEAL NOS.3333 AND 3334 OF 2001\n\n\n\n                        JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dalveer Bhandari, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">     We are disposing of Civil Appeal Nos.3332 to 3334\n\nof 2001 by this judgment. The facts of these appeals are\n\nidentical.    For the sake of convenience, the facts are\n\nbeing   taken    from   Civil   Appeal   No.3332   of   2001.\n\nAppellant's land measuring 1 acre 32 guntas in Survey\n\nNo.32/1 at Henjagondanahalli village was acquired\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                2</span>\n\n\npursuant to the preliminary notification published on\n\n20.5.1997.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">     The     Land     Acquisition     Officer   had     granted\n\ncompensation at the rate of Rs.17,500/- per acre. The\n\nReference Court on appeal enhanced the amount from\n\nRs.17,500/- to Rs.2,17,800/- per acre. This amount was\n\ncalculated at the rate of Rs.5/- per square feet.            The\n\nKarnataka    Housing     Board      aggrieved   by    the    said\n\njudgment preferred appeal before the High Court of\n\nKarnataka.    The Division Bench of the Karnataka High\n\nCourt while taking into consideration all the facts\n\nreduced the amount of compensation from Rs.2,17,800/-\n\nto Rs.1,30,680/- per acre. This amount of compensation\n\nhas been calculated at the rate of Rs.3/- per square feet.\n\nIn   the   impugned    judgment,      the   High     Court   has\n\nmentioned that the claimant-appellant herein himself\n\nhad purchased the land in question on 24.3.1986 for\n\nRs.45,000/- which is based on calculation at the rate of\n\nRs.1.75 per square ft.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                              3</span><p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">       The preliminary notification under section 4(1) of\n\nthe Act was issued a year later i.e. 20.5.1987.            The\n\nappellant relied on the sale deeds executed subsequently\n\nand that too for smaller pieces of lands meant for\n\nhousing sites being Ex.P.2 and that of 1990. The High\n\nCourt in the impugned judgment has rightly observed\n\nthat    Ex.P.2    cannot     be   taken    into   consideration\n\nparticularly keeping in view that the sale deed in respect\n\nof this very acquired land which was effected only a year\n\nago in 1986 itself was available as a ready basis for\n\ndetermining the market value of the land.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">       The High Court in the impugned judgment observed\n\nthat    after    giving    reasonable     deductions   towards\n\ndevelopment charges, the market rate can be safely taken\n\nas Rs.3/- per square feet since this price was even\n\nsuggested for the lands in question even by the\n\nrespondent - Housing Board to the claimant-witness.\n\nThe High Court granted compensation at the rate of\n\nRs.3/- per square feet.       The compensation in this case\n\nworked out to be Rs.1,30,680/- per acre. The High Court\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                   4</span>\n\n\nalso observed that the appellant - land owner will also be\n\nentitled to other statutory benefits and interest as per the\n\nprovisions contained under sections 23 and 28 of the Act.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">        The fact is that this very land was purchased by the\n\nappellant a year ago i.e. on 24.3.1986 for Rs.45,000/-\n\nand for the same land the High Court gave compensation\n\nof Rs.1,30,680/- per acre only after a year.                 In our\n\nconsidered opinion, the view which has been taken in the\n\nimpugned judgment is in consonance with the settled\n\nlegal    position.         The    High   Court   has    taken   into\n\nconsideration        all    the    relevant   facts    in   granting\n\ncompensation.         The High Court was fully justified in\n\ngiving due weightage to the fact that the sale deed of\n\n1986 in respect of this very acquired land was available\n\nand the same ought to be the basis for determining the\n\nmarket value of the land.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">        Learned counsel for the respondent placed reliance\n\non the case of <a href=\"/doc/1534594/\" id=\"a_1\">Bangaru Narasingha Rao Naidu &amp; Ors.\n\nv. Revenue Divisional Officer, Vizianagaram</a> (1980) 1\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                          5</span>\n\n\nSCC 575. In this case, this Court observed that the best\n\nevidence of the market value of the acquired land is\n\nafforded by transactions of sale in respect of the very\n\nacquired land.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">     In   the    case   of   <a href=\"/doc/1893035/\" id=\"a_2\">Special   Tehsildar     Land\n\nAcquisition, Vishakapatnam v. A. Mangala Gowri\n\n(Smt</a>.) (1991) 4 SCC 218, this Court observed as under:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">     \"The market value postulated in Section 23(1) of the\n     Act designed to award just and fair compensation\n     for the lands acquired. The word \"market value\"\n     would postulate price of the land prevailing on the\n     date of the publication of the notification under\n     Section 4(1).\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">          The acid test that for determining the market\n     value of the land, the price which a willing vendor\n     might reasonably expect to obtain from a willing\n     purchaser would form the basis to fix the market\n     value. For ascertaining the market rate, the Court\n     can rely upon such transactions which would offer\n     a reasonable basis to fix the price. The price paid in\n     sale or purchase of the land acquired within a\n     reasonable time from the date of the acquisition of\n     the land in question would be the best piece of\n     evidence. In its absence the price paid for a land\n     possessing similar advantages to the land in the\n     neighbourhood of the land acquired in or about the\n     time of the notification would supply the data to\n     assess the market value. But exclusion of bona fide\n     and genuine sale transactions in respect of the\n     same land under acquisition and to place reliance\n     on the award of some other land is obviously illegal.</blockquote><p id=\"p_14\">\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                           6</span>\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">     In the case of <a href=\"/doc/1559215/\" id=\"a_3\">Periyar and Pareekanni Rubbers\n\nLtd. v. State of Kerala</a> (1991) 4 SCC 195, in para 10,\n\nthis Court observed as under:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">     \"10. ..When the Courts are called upon to fix the\n     market value of the land in compulsory acquisition,\n     the best evidence of the value of property is the sale\n     of the acquired land to which the claimant himself\n     is a party, in its absence the sales of the\n     neighbouring lands. In proof of the sale transaction,\n     the relationship of the parties to the transaction,\n     the market conditions, the terms of the sale and the\n     date of the sale are to be looked into. These features\n     would be established by examining either the\n     vendor or vendee and if they are not available, the\n     attesting witnesses who have personal knowledge of\n     the transaction etc. The original sale deed or\n     certified copy thereof should be tendered as\n     evidence. The underlying principle to fix a fair\n     market value with reference to comparable sales is\n     to reduce the element of speculation. In a\n     comparable sale the features are: (1) it must be\n     within a reasonable time of the date of the\n     notification; (2) it should be a bona fide transaction;\n     (3) it should be a sale of the land acquired or land\n     adjacent to the land acquired and (4) it should\n     possess similar advantages. These should be\n     established by adduction of material evidence by\n     examining as stated above the parties to the sale or\n     persons having personal knowledge of the sale\n     transactions. The proof also would focus on the fact\n     whether the transactions are genuine and bona fide\n     transactions.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_16\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">     Learned counsel for the respondent also placed\n\nreliance on Printers House Pvt. Ltd. v. Cold Storage\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                          7</span>\n\n\nand Food Products and Ors. (1994) 2 SCC 133.            He\n\ndrew our attention to paragraph 7 of this judgment\n\nwhich deals with the similar proposition that the sale\n\nprice of the acquired land is an important factor for\n\ndetermining the compensation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">     Reliance has also been placed on the case of\n\n<a href=\"/doc/330503/\" id=\"a_4\">Ranvir Singh and Another v. Union of India</a> (2005) 12\n\nSCC 59.    In this case, the Court reiterated the well\n\nsettled principle that the sale deeds pertaining to the\n\nportion of lands which are subject to acquisition would\n\nbe the most relevant piece of evidence for assessing the\n\nmarket value of the acquired lands.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">     The facts of the case of <a href=\"/doc/232986/\" id=\"a_5\">The Dollar Company,\n\nMadras v. Collector of Madras</a> (1975) 2 SCC 730 are\n\nidentical to the facts of the instant case.       Relevant\n\nportion of paragraphs 5 and 6 read as under:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">     \"In determining the market value the main criterion\n     is what a willing purchaser would pay a willing\n     vendor. Ordinarily a party will be entitled to get the\n     amount that he actually and willingly paid for a\n     particular property, provided the transaction be\n     bona fide and entered into with due regard to the\n     prevalent market conditions and is proximate in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                          8</span>\n\n\n     time to the relevant date under Section 23. The\n     best evidence of the value of property is the sale of\n     the very property to which the claimant is a party.\n     If the sale is of a recent date, then all that need\n     normally be proved is that the sale was between a\n     willing purchaser and a willing seller, that there has\n     not been any appreciable rise or fall since and that\n     nothing has been done on the land during the short\n     interval to raise its value. But if the sale was long\n     ago, may be the Court would examine more recent\n     sales of comparable lands as throwing better light\n     on current land value. Such lands should be close\n     by and not a mile-and-half away as one of the\n     examples pressed here was.            So, an actual\n     transaction with respect to the specific land of\n     recent date is a guide-book that courts may not\n     neglect when called upon to pin the precise\n     compensation.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_22\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">     Similarly, in the instant case, only an year ago, the\n\nappellant himself purchased this very piece of land for\n\nRs.45,000/- and after an year, the State has given\n\ncompensation of Rs.1,30,680/-, which cannot be said to\n\nbe inadequate by any stretch of imagination. The\n\nReference Court was not justified in enhancing the\n\namount of compensation to Rs.2,17,800/-. There is no\n\nbasis whatsoever.    In our considered opinion, the view\n\nwhich has been taken by the High Court in the\n\nimpugned judgment is based on settled legal position of\n\nlaw, as indicated in some of the cases noted above. No\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                    9</span>\n\n\ninterference is called for. These appeals being devoid of\n\nmerits are accordingly dismissed, leaving the parties to\n\nbear their own costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                   ...............................J.\n                                   (Dalveer Bhandari)\n\n\n\n                                    ...........................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                     (H.S. Bedi)\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">January 22, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":471209,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1534594,"url":null,"title":"Bangaru Narasingha Rao Naidu And ... vs Revenue Divisional Officer, ... on 8 October, 1979"},{"tid":1893035,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=12673","title":"Spl. Tehsildar Land Acqn. ... vs Smt. A. Mangala Gowri on 9 August, 1991"},{"tid":1559215,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=7425","title":"Periyar And Pareekanni Rubbers ... vs State Of Kerala on 6 September, 1990"},{"tid":232986,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=5971","title":"Dollar Company, Madras vs Collector Of Madras on 1 May, 1975"},{"tid":330503,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=27165","title":"Ranvir Singh & Anr vs Union Of India on 7 September, 2005"}]}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"alpesh","formInput":"alpesh"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"police patil","formInput":"police%20patil"},{"value":"\"alarm\"","formInput":"%22alarm%22"}],"firstname":null,"title":"State Of Maharashtra vs Prakash Sakha Vasave & Ors on 21 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33534","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-21","citedbyList":[{"tid":1312651,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=34632","title":"Santosh Kumar Satishbhushan ... vs State Of Maharashtra on 13 May, 2009"},{"tid":786404,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=37477","title":"Sheo Shankar Singh vs State Of Jharkhand & Anr on 15 February, 2011"},{"tid":75642681,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/SRB/judgement/23-02-2013/SRB21022013DSRF12011.pdf","title":"State vs Jitender on 21 February, 2013"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":3,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">State Of Maharashtra vs Prakash Sakha Vasave &amp; Ors on 21 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n               CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 654 OF 2004\n\n\n\nState of Maharashtra                                     ..Appellant\n\n                                  Versus\n\nPrakash Sakha Vasave and Ors.                            ..Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nBombay High Court directing acquittal of the respondents who were\n\nconvicted for offence punishable under Section 302 read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 34</a> of\n\nthe Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') and sentenced to suffer\n\ncapital punishment so far as respondents 1 and 2, namely, Prakash and\n\nRamu are concerned. Accused No.3-Shiva was convicted for the aforesaid\n\noffence but was sentenced to suffer imprisonment for life. All the three\n\faccused persons were also convicted for offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/180217/\" id=\"a_3\">Section\n\n506</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 34</a> IPC. No separate sentence was imposed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.    Prosecution version as unfolded during trial is as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">      Jaitubai is the sister of respondent Nos.1 and 2 and niece of\n\nrespondent No.3. Jaitubai was married to Madhukar (hereinafter referred to\n\nas the deceased) long back. Jaitubai had a son Alpesh (PW6) and daughter\n\nHema (PW5). Alpesh and Hema are major. All of them are residents of\n\nRayagaon (Patilfali), Taluka Nawapur, District Nandurbar.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">      Deceased Madhukar brought Ramabai, a married woman and kept her\n\nin his house. On 15.7.2001, first husband of Ramabai, alongwith 15 to 20\n\npersons came to Madhukar. There is a custom prevailing in their\n\ncommunity, which is commonly known as ZAGDA system. As per this\n\ncustom compensation is required to be paid to former husband. Pursuant to\n\nZAGDA system, Madhukar paid Rs.5,051/- to the former husband of\n\nRamabai. Thereafter Madhukar was allowed to marry Ramabai. Jaitubai and\n\nRamabai stayed with Madhukar for a period of 15 days.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\f      On account of marriage with Ramabai, the married life of Jaitubai\n\nwas disturbed. Accused nos. 1 to 3 were not happy over this affair. They\n\nwere shocked to know that their brother-in-law Madhukar married Ramabai\n\nand kept her in the house which adversely affected the married life of\n\nJaitubai. Accused became furious and decided to teach a lesson to\n\nMadhukar.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      The incident occurred on 16.7.2001 at about 6.30 p.m. at a close\n\nproximity of the house of deceased Madhukar. Madhukar gave alarm to the\n\neffect \"MARLE, MARLE\". On hearing the alarm of Madhukar, Reenabai\n\n(PW 3), sister of Madhukar, Gemji (PW 4), brother of Madhukar, daughter\n\nHemabai (PW 5) and son Alpesh (PW 6) immediately arrived on the spot in\n\norder to see what had happened to Madhukar. Surtan (PW 7), Gulabsingh\n\n(PW 8) and other persons from neighbourhood also arrived on the spot after\n\nhaving heard the alarm of Madhukar. Accused Prakash went inside the\n\nhouse and brought two axes. He retained one axe with him and handed over\n\nanother axe to his brother Ramu. Accused no.3 Shiva caught the legs of\n\nMadhukar by means of rope. Accused no.l cut the left hand of Madhukar.\n\nHe also cut right foot of Madhukar. Accused no.2 inflicted axe blows on the\n\nright eye-brow and near the left ear of Madhukar. The blow was given with\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                   3</span>\n\fso much force that the blade of the axe stuck into the head of Madhukar and\n\nhandle of the axe was broken. Accused no.2 brought knife from the house\n\nand inflicted blows on the back of Madhukar by means of knife. Reenabai\n\n(PW 3) tried to rescue her brother Madhukar, however, because of threats\n\nadministered by the accused, she did not dare to rescue her brother\n\nMadhukar. In the presence of dear ones, Madhukar was brutally assaulted.\n\nHis organs were severed by means of axes. But the dear ones and close ones\n\ncould not offer any kind of help to Madhukar. After the brutal assault on\n\nMadhukar, accused nos. 1 to 3 disappeared from the scene of offence.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      Reenabai (PW3) asked Alpesh (PW6) to go to the Police Patil. Alpesh\n\n(PW6) went to Pangram and contacted Police Patil Shamji Gavit (PW11).\n\nAlpesh (PW-6) narrated the entire incident to him. Police Patil Shamji (PW\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">11) went to Navapur Police Station on the bike belonging to Sarpanch and\n\ndisclosed the occurrence to the Police. Reenabai (PW3) lodged FIR\n\n(Exh.14) at 10.30 p.m. On the basis of FIR (Exh. 14) Crime No. 55/2001\n\ncame to be registered. P.1. Pradip Sonawane (PW18) carried out further\n\ninvestigation of the crime and, after completion of the investigation, sent up\n\nthe charge sheet against the accused nos.1 to 3. Learned Judicial Magistrate,\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                     4</span>\n\fFirst Class, Navapur, District Nandurbar, committed the accused nos.1 to 3\n\nto the Court of Sessions to stand their trial.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">      Since the accused persons pleaded innocence trial was held. As noted\n\nabove, the trial Court found the accused persons guilty and death sentence\n\nin respect of A-1 and A-2 and life imprisonment to A-3 was awarded. Three\n\nwitnesses were stated to have witnessed the occurrence. They are PWs 3, 4\n\nand 6. The trial Court found their evidence to be adequate and accordingly\n\nrecorded the conviction and imposed sentences. The High Court directed\n\nacquittal primarily on the ground that PW-3 did not speak about the\n\npresence of Gemji (PW-4) and there is doubt about the place of recording\n\nthe first information report and delay in lodging it. PW-3 did not speak\n\nabout the assault by A-2 with knife. Only PW-6 spoke about it. No overt act\n\nwas attributed by PW-6 to A-3. PW-4 did not say that the axe was fixed on\n\nthe head. The evidence of PW-2 was full of contradictions as there was\n\ndiscrepancy about the recovery.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">3.    Learned counsel for the appellant-State submitted that the High Court\n\nhas lost sight of several important factors and attached undue importance to\n\nminor discrepancies which are normal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                       5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">\f4.    Learned counsel for the respondents on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment of the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">5.    It is to be noted that PW-3 is the sister of the deceased. There was\n\npractically no cross examination on the assault part. So far as fixing of the\n\naxe on the head is concerned, unnecessary importance appear to have been\n\nattached to the same. As a matter of fact the conclusion of the High Court is\n\nerroneous because PW-4 in his evidence has categorically stated that the\n\ndeceased was having injury on his body due to assault by means of axes.\n\nOne axe was found inserted in the bone of head near the left ear. The handle\n\nof that axe was in a broken condition. According to the evidence the axe\n\nwas inserted near about 4 to 5 inches in the head. Thereafter, all the three\n\naccused persons ran way from the spot. The motive indicated was that the\n\ndeceased was having a illicit relationship with another lady and, therefore,\n\nthe family members of the wife were upset. The High Court has come to an\n\nabsurd conclusion that the eye witnesses PWs 3 and 6 gave account of 4 to 5\n\nexternal injuries but the witnesses did not utter a single word about\n\nremaining 15 injuries. The High Court came to the conclusion that if at all\n\nthese two witnesses witnessed the incident from a short distance then it was\n\nnot explained as to why they were not able to account for the remaining\n\ninjuries which were found on the body of the deceased. A witness who\n\nwitnesses an attack on another by three persons armed is not supposed to go\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                    6</span>\n\fon counting number of assaults on the parts of the body where the injuries\n\nwere inflicted. They had categorically stated about the external injuries 1, 4,\n\n8, 14 and 18. It is noticed that PWs 3 and 4 came running after hearing\n\nshout of the deceased. So it was possible that they had not noticed the\n\ninjuries which were earlier sustained due to assaults. They appeared at the\n\nspot when the assault was continuing. As a matter of fact, in his cross\n\nexamination PW-4 had stated that on hearing shout of the deceased he\n\nrushed towards him and reached there within a short time. When he reached\n\nat the spot of incident, at that time the deceased was lying on the ground\n\nhaving injuries on his person. As noted above, there is practically no cross\n\nexamination of any of the eye witnesses i.e. PWs 3, 4 and 6 on the assault\n\npart.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">6.      So far as the delay in lodging the First Information Report is\n\nconcerned, it has been accepted that the informant went to the wrong police\n\nstation and when he was directed to go to Navapur Police Station, he went\n\nthere and lodged the FIR. That clearly explains the delay. In the ultimate\n\nanalysis, High Court was not justified in directing acquittal of A1 and A2.\n\nHowever, so far as A-3 is concerned, the High Court has indicated sufficient\n\nreasons for holding him not guilty. Same needs no interference. But the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                     7</span>\n\freasons indicated for directing acquittal of A-1 and A-2 are not justified.\n\nWe, therefore, set aside the judgment of High Court so far as their acquittal\n\nis concerned. But considering the facts of the case, it is apparent that the\n\naccused persons were annoyed with the deceased because of his having\n\nillicit relationship with another lady while his wife was alive. The case does\n\nnot fall to the rarest of rare category. The appropriate sentence would be\n\nlife imprisonment. The State's appeal is allowed to the extent indicated\n\nabove. Respondents 1 and 2 are directed to surrender to custody forthwith to\n\nserve the remainder of sentence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">                                ..........................................J.\n                                (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                ..........................................J.\n                                (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 21, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                     8</span>\n\f</p>","tid":882689,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":37788,"url":null,"title":"Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":180217,"url":null,"title":"Section 506 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"}]}, {"numcites":5,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"narcotics","formInput":"narcotics"},{"value":"opium","formInput":"opium"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Abbas Khan vs Central Bureau Of Narcotics on 14 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33518","lastname":"...............","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-14","citedbyList":[{"tid":19424181,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/SMD/judgement/02-06-2009/SMD29052009BA6732009.pdf","title":"Amarjeet Singh vs D.R.I. on 29 May, 2009"},{"tid":75074028,"url":null,"title":"Ncb vs . Balakrishnan, P. Sathasivam, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                1\n\n                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                    CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                    CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.101 OF 2005\n\nABBAS KHAN                            Appellant (s)\n\n              VERSUS\n\nCENTRAL BUREAU OF NARCOTICS                    Respondent(s)\n\nWITH CRL.A.NO.651/2006\n\n\n                                  ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">            These appellants were tried along with two other accused by the\n\nSpecial Judge, N.D.P.S., Mandsore(M.P.) for the offences punishable under\n\nSection 18 read with <a href=\"/doc/704277/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 8</a> of the Narcotic Drugs and <a href=\"/doc/1727139/\" id=\"a_2\">Psychotropic\n\nSubstances Act</a>, 1985 (for short 'the Act'). The prosecution case was that the\n\nSuperintendent-M.C.Vijay of the Central Bureau of Narcotics, along with\n\nother officers, were on patrol duty on 1.5.1997 and at about 9.45 p.m. they\n\nintercepted the truck-DIG 4753. Two persons were in the truck and when\n\nthey stopped the truck and thereafter started running away and the\n\nInspector A.K.Tulsidasan apprehended them. The truck was searched in the\n\npresence of the witnesses and it was found that 2.10 KGs of Opium and 8\n\nKGs of Dodachura were also found in the truck.        The officers prepared a\n\nmazhar and seized the articles and a case was registered against two accused\n\nviz. Shri Hardeo Singh and Daljeet Singh. On questioning these two accused,\n\nofficers came to   know   that   Opium was sold by the present appellants\n\nAbbas\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                     2</span>\n\nKhan and Azam Khan. P.W.6 issued a notice under <a href=\"/doc/1752792/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 67</a> of the Act to\n\nthe appellants and their statements were taken.     In their statements they\n\nadmitted having sold Opium to other accused who were also travelling in the\n\ntruck.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">            After the trial the Special Judge found all the four guilty under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/325366/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 18</a> of the Act and they were sentenced to undergo 10 years rigorous\n\nimprisonment with a fine of Rs.1 lac each.      In the appeal filed by the\n\naccused, the High Court confirmed the conviction.      The first and second\n\naccused Hardeo Singh and Daljeet Singh did not prefer any appeal while\n\naccused nos.3 and 4 have filed the present appeals before this Court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">            Heard both sides.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">            The prosecution relied on the admission made under <a href=\"/doc/1752792/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 67</a>\n\nof the Act by these two accused before P.W.6 but we notice that the\n\ncontraband articles allegedly seized from the first and second accused were\n\nnot shown to the present two appellants and there is no evidence to show\n\nthat the very same articles were seized by the officers in the course of\n\ninvestigation. There is practically no evidence to show as to how much\n\nquantity of articles were allegedly sold by these appellants. However, we do\n\nnot think that the statements made by these accused are inadmissible in\n\nevidence as they were made under <a href=\"/doc/1752792/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 67</a> of the Act. At the same time\n\nthe evidence adduced would only prove that they had dealt with narcotic\n\ndrugs and to that extent the admission is valid. As the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                      3</span>\n\nquantity itself is not proved, one could only say that it is not possible to\n\nassume that they were dealing with any commercial quantity of contraband\n\narticles, which offence by itself is of a very serious nature. The prosecution\n\nshould have produced better evidence to sustain such conviction.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">            Under the above circumstances, we hold that the accused could\n\nonly be convicted under <a href=\"/doc/30948923/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 18(b)</a> of the Act.       We are told that the\n\nappellants have already undergone a fairly long period of sentence. There is\n\nno evidence that they were dealing with any commercial quantity of these\n\ncontraband articles. Therefore, we confirm the conviction. In our opinion,\n\nthe sentence already undergone by the appellants is sufficient to meet the\n\nends of justice.   We direct the appellants to be released forthwith, if not\n\nrequired in any other case. Learned counsel for the appellants submits that\n\nthe fine imposed is also not paid so far.    The fine so imposed upon the\n\nappellants is also waived off.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">            The appeals are disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                                ...............CJI.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                        (K.G. 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33555","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-27","citedbyList":[{"tid":1468090,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=129620","title":"Santhosh 2009"},{"tid":1739097,"url":null,"title":"Ramji Duda Makwana vs The State Of Maharashtra on 12 August, 1993"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":3,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Ramchandra Dhondiba Kaware vs State Of Maharashtra on 27 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n               CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n               CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.                 OF 2009\n               (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 5369 of 2008)\n\n\nRamchandra Dhondiba Kaware                                           ..\nAppellant\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of Maharashtra                                           ..Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nBombay High Court dismissing the appeal filed by the appellant. Learned\n\n2nd Additional Sessions Judge, Sangli, had convicted the appellant for\n\noffence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 302</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                          1</span>\n\fshort the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') and sentenced to undergo life imprisonment and to pay a\n\nfine of Rs.1,000/- with default stipulation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">3.    Prosecution version in a nutshell is as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      The accused-appellant and one Shivaji Baba Lohar who was working\n\nwith Keru (hereinafter referred to as the `deceased') were on inimical terms.\n\nShivaji's sister was married to the accused. The accused had borrowed\n\nmoney from Shivaji which he had not returned. The accused used to visit\n\nShivaji in the field owned by the deceased. Keru and his family knew the\n\naccused and would often give him agricultural produce from their lands\n\nsince the accused was jobless. Shivaji demanded repayment of the loan he\n\nhad advanced to the accused. The accused was annoyed by this and on\n\n3.6.2000 he went to Keru's farm. Keru was asleep at a little distance from\n\nthe rest of the members of his family. Shivaji was sleeping at another spot\n\non the farm, a little further away from the family. The accused entered the\n\nfarm before daybreak, at about 3 am. The dogs started barking and Maruti,\n\nthe son of the deceased saw the accused beating the victim with a yoke.\n\nMaruti alerted Shivaji and they chased the accused, but he managed to\n\nescape their clutches. Maruti and Shivaji returned to the spot where the\n\nvictim was lying. They found that his skull had been fractured and a part of\n\nhis brain was protruding. Three fingers of his right hand were fractured and\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                         2</span>\n\fbroken. His head and ears were bleeding. Maruti lodged a complaint with\n\nthe police. The dead body of Keru was taken for the autopsy. The required\n\npanchanamas were drawn up and statements of witnesses were recorded.\n\nThe accused was apprehended and charged for having committed an offence\n\npunishable under section, 302 <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">IPC</a>. His trial was committed to Sessions. The\n\nSessions Court after consideration of the evidence on record as noted above\n\nconvicted the accused.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">         Before the High Court the only stand was that the evidence of the so\n\ncalled eye witnesses PWs 1 and 4 cannot be relied upon. It was also\n\nsubmitted that a case under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 302</a> IPC was not made out. The High\n\nCourt found no substance in the plea and dismissed the appeal as afore-\n\nnoted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">4.       The stand taken before the High Court was re-iterated in the present\n\nappeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">5.       The evidence of PWs 1 and 4 does not suffer from any infirmity. PW-\n\n1 has categorically stated that he was awakened by the barking of dogs. He\n\nheard the sound of somebody being beaten. He saw the incident in the light\n\nfrom a lantern when the accused was hitting his father on the head with a\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                         3</span>\n\fyoke. The witness claimed to have chased the accused but could not catch\n\nhim. The evidence of PW-4, the widow was to the similar effect. Both the\n\ntrial Court and the High Court have referred to the evidence in great detail\n\nand found that their evidence is credible and cogent and unerringly points at\n\nthe accused to be author of the crime. The other question is regarding\n\napplicability of <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 302</a> IPC. It appears that the accused and the\n\ndeceased were in inimical terms. Only one blow was given with the yoke in\n\nthe night. PW-4 has categorically admitted that it was dark, but he identified\n\nthe accused because he was known to him. Number of injuries is always not\n\na determinative factor regarding applicability of <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 302</a> IPC. The\n\nnature of the weapon, place where it was struck and several other relevant\n\nfactors throw light on this aspect. Considering the background facts of the\n\npresent case according to us the appropriate conviction would be under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 304</a> Part I IPC. Custodial sentence of 10 years would meet the ends\n\nof justice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">6.     The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">                                       ...........................................J.\n                                       (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                                4</span>\n\f                   ..........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">                   (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 27, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                            5</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1537053,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":409589,"url":null,"title":"Section 304 in The Indian Penal Code"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"undisclosed income","formInput":"undisclosed%20income"},{"value":"settlement commission","formInput":"settlement%20commission"},{"value":"sec 32","formInput":"sec%2032"}],"firstname":null,"title":"E.K. Lingamurthy And Anr vs Settlement Commnr. (It&amp;Wt)&amp; Anr on 22 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.H. Kapadia, Aftab Alam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                          CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                         CIVIL APPEAL NOS.382-383 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P.(C) Nos.19393-19394/2007)\n\n\nE.K. Lingamurthy &amp; Anr.                                         ...Appellant(s)\n\n                   Versus\n\nSettlement Commissioner (IT&amp;WT) &amp; Anr.                          ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                         ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">         Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">         In these appeals, we are required to consider the scope of Section 158BB(4)\n\nof Chapter XIV-B of the Income Tax Act, 1961 (for short, 1961 Act).\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">         We quote hereinbelow Section 158BB, which refers to 'Computation of\n\nundisclosed income of a block period':\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                   \"158BB. (1) The undisclosed income of the block period shall be\n         the aggregate of the total income of the previous years falling within the\n         block period computed, in accordance with the provisions of Chapter IV, on\n         the basis of evidence found as a result of search or requisition of books of\n         account or documents and such other materials or information as are\n         available with Assessing Officer, as reduced by the aggregate of the total\n         income, or as the case may be, as increased by the aggregate of the losses of\n         such previous years, determined,--\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">               (a) Where assessments under section 143 or section 144 or section 147\n               have been concluded, on the basis of such assessments;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">               (b) where returns of income have been filed under section 139 or\n               section 147 but assessments have not been made till the date of search\n               or requisition, on the basis of the income disclosed in such returns;</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">               (c) where the due date for filing a return of income has expired but\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                          1</span>\n\f               no return of income has been filed, as nil;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">               (d) where the previous year has not ended or the date of filing the\n               return of income under sub-section (1) of section 139 has not expired,\n               on the basis of entries relating to such income or transactions as\n               recorded in the books of account and other documents maintained in\n               the normal course on or before the date of the search or requisition\n               relating to such previous years;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">               (e) where any order of settlement has been made under sub-section\n               (4) of section 245D, on the basis of such order;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">               (f) where an assessment of undisclosed income had been made earlier\n               under clause (c) of section 158BC, on the basis of such assessment.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">         Explanation: For the purposes of determination of undisclosed income,--\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">               (a) the total income or loss of each previous year shall, for the\n               purpose of aggregation, be taken as the total income or loss computed\n               in accordance with the provisions of Chapter IV without giving effect\n               to set off of brought forward losses under Chapter VI or unabsorbed\n               depreciation under sub-section (2) of section 32;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">               (b) xxx xxx xxx\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">               (c) xxx xxx xxx\n         (2) &amp; (3) xxx xxx\n         (4) For the purpose of assessment under this Chapter, losses brought\n         forward from the previous year under Chapter VI or unabsorbed\n         depreciation under sub-section (2) of section 32 shall not be set off against\n         the undisclosed income determined in the block assessment under this\n         Chapter, but may be carried forward for being set off in the regular\n         assessments.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">         In these Civil Appeals, we are concerned with the block period commencing\n\nfrom 1.4.1986 to 11.10.1996, when the search took place.</blockquote><p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">         It is the case of the appellants-assessee that there is a conceptual difference\n\nbetween current losses and carried forward losses. Similarly, assessee contends that\n\nthere a conceptual difference between current depreciation and carried forward\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                           2</span>\n\funabsorbed depreciation. It is the case of the assessee that Explanation (a) to Section\n\n158BB does not rule out current year's losses or current year's depreciation; it only\n\nrules out the brought forward losses or unabsorbed depreciation under Section 32(2).\n\nAccording to the appellant, this difference is lost sight of by the Settlement\n\nCommission in its impugned judgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">         In order to answer the contention raised on behalf of the assessee, one has\n\nto examine the scheme of Section 158BB of the 1961 Act. It is not in controversy that\n\nChapter XIV-B constitutes a Code by itself.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">         In this case, we are concerned with the computation of \"undisclosed\n\nincome\" under Section 158BB of the Act. Section 158BB, inter alia, states that\n\nundisclosed income of the block period shall be \"the aggregate of the total income of\n\nthe previous years falling within the block period\" computed in accordance with the\n\nprovisions of Chapter IV. \"Total income\" is defined in Section 2(45) to mean the\n\ntotal amount of income referred to in section 5, computed in the manner laid down in\n\nthe Act. In other words, Chapter XIV does not rule out Chapter IV of the Act in the\n\nmatter of computation of undisclosed income under Chapter XIV-B. It may be\n\nmentioned that ordinarily, in the case of regular assessment, the unit of assessment is\n\none year consisting of twelve months whereas in the case of block assessment, the unit\n\nof assessment consists of ten previous years and the period upto the date of the\n\nsearch. Section 158BB provides for aggregation of income/loss of each previous year\n\ncomprised in the block period. The block period assessment under Chapter XIV-B is\n\nin addition to regular assessment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">         Analysing Section 158BB(4) read with Explanation (a) thereto, one finds\n\nthat only brought forward losses of the past years under Chapter VI and unabsorbed\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                           3</span>\n\fdepreciation under Section 32(2) are to be excluded while aggregating the total\n\nincome or loss of each previous year in the block period but set off of the loss suffered\n\nin any of the previous year in the block period against the income assessed in other\n\nprevious years in the block period is not prohibited. In our view, the Settlement\n\nCommission had erred in disallowing the application of the assessee for set off of\n\ninter se losses and depreciation accruing in any of the previous year in the block\n\nperiod against the income returned/assessed in any other previous year in the block\n\nperiod.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">          For the aforestated reasons, we set aside the impugned judgment of the\n\nHigh Court as well as the decision of the Settlement Commission and we remit the\n\nmatter to the Settlement Commission for fresh computation of the undisclosed income\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1971671/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 158BB</a> of the Income Tax Act, 1961 for the block period in question.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">          Civil Appeals are allowed accordingly, with no order as to costs.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                                    ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                                       (S.H. It was their case\n\n  that one M.Amarender Reddy (hereinafter referred to as `deceased') was traveling\n\n  in a bus owned by the Corporation. The driver of the bus, who was driving the\n\n  vehicle in a rash and negligent manner, suddenly applied the brakes as a result of\n\n  which the deceased was thrown out of the bus and was injured and ultimately\n\n  succumbed. He was aged about 24 years of age.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        -2-</span><p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">         The learned Additional District Judge, Motor Accidents Claims\n\nTribunal, (in short `MACT') Hyderabad, held that the deceased was also partly\n\nresponsible for the accident as he was traveling on the footboard of the vehicle.\n\nTherefore, the contributory negligence was fixed at 25% and consequential\n\ndeduction was made by fixing the monthly income of the deceased at Rs.3,000/-.\n\nAccordingly an amount of Rs.2,58,000/- was awarded as compensation with\n\ninterest at 12% p.a. from the date of the claim.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">         An appeal was preferred by the claimants before the High Court. The\n\nCorporation also filed appeal before the High Court. By the impugned judgment,\n\nthe High Court held that there was no negligence on the part of the deceased. It\n\nenhanced the compensation by Rs.204,000/- with interest at 6% p.a. from the date\n\nof claim till dfate of realization. It is to be noted that the MACT had worked out\n\nthe loss of dependency at Rs.1,500/- by deducting 50% of the monthly income. The\n\nHigh court reduced the deduction to Rs.1,000/- p.m.     It is to be noted that the\n\nappeal filed by the Corporation was dismissed.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                        -3-</span>\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">         Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that the High court\n\f  accepted    that there was scope for negligence as claimed;         but came to the\n\n  conclusion that there was no negligence on the part of the deceased.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">             Taking into account the relevant materials on record, we reduce the\n\n  compensation to Rs.3,25,000/- to be paid along with interest at the rate fo 6% p.a.\n\n  from the date of the claim. The balance amount, after adjustment of amounts\n\n  already deposited shall be paid within a period of six weeks.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">             The appeals are allowed to the above extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                   ................ .J.\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                                                      (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                         ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 27, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1290101,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"firstname":"d","title":"The State Of West Bengal & Ors vs Somdeb Bandyopadhayay & Ors on 23 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33545","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-23","citedbyList":[{"tid":187966049,"url":null,"title":"Sri Pravash Chandra Kshetry And ... vs Smt. Nilima Mullick And Others on 25 August, 2010"},{"tid":179796400,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=32","title":"Puran And Another vs Gram Panchayat Etc on 22 September, 2009"},{"tid":99523267,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/phhc/showfile.php?sn=333","title":"Parmod Kumar vs Unknown on 1 April, 2013"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":3,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">The State Of West Bengal &amp; Ors vs Somdeb Bandyopadhayay &amp; Ors on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n              CIVIL APPEAL NO.         397         OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 5454 of 2005)\n\n\nThe State of West Bengal &amp; Ors.                         ....Appellants\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\nSomdeb Bandyopadhayay &amp; Ors.                            ....Respondents\n\n\n\n                                JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">DR. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Heard learned counsel for both the parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    This appeal arises from the order passed by the Division Bench of the\n\nCalcutta High Court allowing the writ appeal filed by the respondent No.1.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f4.    The facts, as presented by the appellants, are as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      Respondent No.1 was appointed to the post of Superintendent of\n\nChhoto Jagulia Junior Technical School, presently named as Industrial\n\nTraining Centre Chhoto Jagulia, by the Governing Body of the said Institute\n\non 7.7.1993. He was also given the responsibility of the Ex-officio Secretary\n\nof the Governing Body.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      Due to some allegations against Respondent No.1, namely, non-\n\nfunctioning of the administrative work as well the non-attending the\n\nInstitution an Enquiry Committee was set up. On the basis of the decision\n\nof the Committee, administrative function as a Member Secretary was\n\nwithdrawn and another person was appointed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      A writ petition was filed by respondent No.1 taking the stand that he\n\nshould be allowed to continue as Superintendent. His stand was that he was\n\nprevented from discharging duties after 10.3.1997. Originally, the petition\n\nwas filed before the West Bengal Administrative Tribunal (in short `the\n\nTribunal') and interim order was passed by the Tribunal directing that there\n\nshould be so interference with the functioning of the present respondent\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                     2</span>\n\fNo.1. Alleging that the interim order was not being carried out contempt\n\npetition was filed. Tribunal disposed of the petition with certain directions.\n\nSubsequently, on 30.3.1998 the Original Application was dismissed on the\n\nground that Tribunal had no jurisdiction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">      On 11.5.1998, a writ petition was filed in the Calcutta High Court\n\nseeking restoration of status as Member Secretary of the Governing Body.\n\nCertain interim directions were given. The present appellant took the stand\n\nthat the respondent was not attending the office and was not signing the\n\nattendance register. A special leave petition was filed by respondent No.1\n\nbefore this Court which was withdrawn. The same was directed against the\n\norder dated 22.9.2000 in CPAN 768/2000. The writ petition was dismissed\n\nby learned Single Judge on several counts. The basic conclusion was that\n\nsince factual dispute was involved the writ petition was not to be\n\nentertained.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">      A writ appeal was filed before the High Court and contempt\n\nproceedings were also initiated. The Division Bench directed that lawful\n\narrears have to be paid. Certain directions were given making stringent\n\nobservations against the officials. An amount of Rs.7,33,567/- was paid.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                      3</span>\n\fThe High Court was primarily of the view that since the proceedings for\n\nabsence were not initiated, the appellant should be bound to pay and there\n\nwas no question of any prejudice involved. The writ appeal was allowed in\n\nthe aforesaid terms.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">5.    Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that the writ petition was\n\ndismissed on the ground that factual controversy is involved, i.e. whether\n\nthe writ petitioner's stand that he was prevented from attending duties or\n\nwhether the appellant's stand that he was not attending office is correct. It\n\nrequires factual adjudication and such question cannot be decided in the\n\nwrit petition. It is also pointed out that without condoning the delay several\n\ninterim orders were passed which is not permissible in law.            Learned\n\ncounsel for the respondent No.1, on the other hand, submitted that\n\nvoluminous documents are available to show that the writ petitioner was\n\nprevented from attending their duties and carrying on his functions.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">6.    It is to be noticed that even without condoning the delay and\n\nentertaining the writ appeal the High Court has passed series of interim\n\norders. Such a course is impermissible as the appeal was non-est in the eye\n\nof law without it being entertained. Admittedly, the delay in preferring the\n\nwrit appeal was not condoned at the time when the interim orders were\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                       4</span>\n\fpassed. The High Court has committed another error in holding that the\n\nwrit petition was dismissed principally on the ground that it was the\n\ndecision of the Governing Body as to who should be its Secretary, although\n\nGovernment approval is necessary for appointment of the Secretary of the\n\nGoverning Body of the Institute. On the contrary the learned Single Judge\n\ndismissed the writ petition principally on the ground that factual\n\ncontroversy is involved. The Division Bench has not discussed this aspect\n\nat all. Therefore, the order is clearly indefensible.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">7.    In the aforesaid background, we set aside the impugned judgment of\n\nthe High Court and remit the matter for its consideration as to whether the\n\nwrit appeal was to be entertained in view of the conclusions of the learned\n\nSingle Judge that factual controversies are involved and, therefore, the writ\n\npetition was not maintainable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">8.    The appeal is allowed without any order as to costs.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                        .................................................J.\n                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                                      5</span>\n\f                                           ...................\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">      ............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                       (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 23, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                 6</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1782579,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":" s h kapadia","formInput":"%20s%20h%20kapadia"},{"value":"aftab alam","formInput":"aftab%20alam"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Union Of India & Ors vs P.N.Singh & Ors on 23 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33572","lastname":"....................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-23","citedbyList":[{"tid":1082042,"url":null,"title":"State Of Kerala And Anr. vs V.M. Sudershan Reddy</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CIVIL APPEAL NO. 389               OF 2008\n     [Arising out of Special Leave Petition (Civil) No. 15612 of 2008]\n\nACADEMY OF GENERAL EDU., MANIPAL\n&amp; ANR.                                               ... APPELLANTS\n\n                                  Versus\n\nB. MALINI MALLYA                                     ... RESPONDENT\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. SINHA, J.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_2\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_3\">2.    `Yakshagana' is a form of ballet dance. It has its own heritage.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_4\">      Indisputably, Dr. Kota Shivarama Karanth (for short, \"Dr. Karanth\"),\n\na Jnanapeeth awardee, who was a Novelist, Play Writer, Essayist,\n\nEncyclopediationist, Cultural Anthropologist, Artist, Writer of Science,\n\nEnvironmentalist. He developed a new form of `Yakshagana'. He was a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                   2</span>\n\nDirector of the appellant - institute. On or about 18.6.1994, he executed a\n\nWill in favour of the respondent.      Dr. Karanth expired on 9.12.1997.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">Yakshagana Ballet dance as developed by Dr. Karanth was performed in\n\nNew Delhi on or about 18.9.2001. Respondent filed a suit for declaration,\n\ninjunction and damages alleging violation of the copyright in respect of the\n\nsaid dance vested in her in terms of the said Will stating that Dr. Karanth\n\ndeveloped a new distinctive dance, drama troop or theatrical system which\n\nwas named by him as `Yaksha Ranga' which in his own words mean\n\n\"creative extension of traditional Yakshagana\" and, thus, the appellants\n\ninfringed the copyright thereof by performing the same at New Delhi\n\nwithout obtaining her prior permission. It was stated that Dr. Karanth had\n\ncomposed seven verses or prasangas for staging Yaksharanga Ballet apart\n\nfrom bringing in changes in the traditional form thereof on its relevant\n\naspects, namely, Raga, Tala, Scenic arrangement, Costumes etc. These\n\nprasangas are: (i) Bhishma Vijaya; (ii) Nala Damayanthi; (iii) Kanakangi or\n\nKanakangi Kalyana; (iv) Abhimanyu or Abhimanyu Vada; (v) Chitrangadha\n\nor Babruvahana Kalaga; (vi) Panchavati; and (vii) Ganga Charitha.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">3.    Plaintiff - respondent admittedly claimed copyright in respect of\n\n`literary and artistic works' in her favour in terms of clauses 11 and 12 of\n\nthe said Will dated 18.6.1994, which read as under:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                       3</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">\"11. Since I left the house `suhasa' I have been\nliving in a specially built house \"Manasa\" of Smt.\nMalini Mallya, who has built it with borrowed\nmoney at her cost. She had joined my service as\nCopyist and later, she secured an employment in\nLife Insurance Corporation of India. Ever since\n1974 till now in my old age she has been serving\nme with exemplary devotion and sincerity. And in\nthis occasion I must also acknowledge with\ngratitude that she diligently cared and nursed my\nwife Leela Karanth during her prolonged illness\ntill her last day. And she has cared and looked\nafter me also during my illness which at times had\nbeen quite serious, enfeebling me for long period.\nIn recognition of her devotion and sincere\naffection towards me in 1986 I have dedicated one\nof my novels namely, \"Antida Aparanji\" to her. I\nhave also placed on record her invaluable services\nto me in my Memoirs, \"Hunchu Mansina Hathu\nMukhagalu\" 1991 Edition. In my opinion, very\nlong enduring and a signal service she has done to\nme and to my literary works is, in writing a\nbibliography of all my books- a highly meritorious\nand scholarly work involving so much of pains\ntaking research, that it has been acclaimed and\nrated as the first of its kind in Kannada and highly\nappreciated by Critics and Scholars. Apart from\nthis, she has collected and edited all my stray\nwritings from 1924 onwards upto date in eight\nSumptuous volumes which are being published by\nMangalore University.          This work also has\nbrought her deserving fame and appreciation of\nScholars.      Such painstaking service in this\ndirection has brought to light several of my\nhitherto untraced, forgotten and unknown writings\nand thereby giving them extended or renewed\nlease of life. For all these services, I hereby\ndeclare that after my death copyrights in respect of\nall my literary works shall vest with Smt. Malini\nMallya and she alone shall be entitled to receive\nroyalties of all my books and she shall be entitled\nto print, publish and republish and market the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                    4</span>\n\n             same. Whatever she may earn thereby shall be her\n             exclusive income and property. No one else shall\n             have any right or claims for the same.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">             12. From time to time I have distributed among\n             my children all gold and silver jewels and\n             ornaments and other valuables, which were gifted\n             to me by my friends and admirers. And I have\n             distributed all copper and bronze vessels and\n             utensils among my children while leaving my\n             former home \"Suhasa\" keeping only bare essential\n             and necessary things and articles. Whatever\n             movable properties, books, fittings, furniture,\n             utensils etc. belonging to me into this house\n             `Manasa' and my Car and cash money in hand\n             after my death shall go to Smt. Malini Malya only.\n             No one else shall have any claim or right over the\n             same. Any outstanding due to me and Bank\n             Deposits and whatever assets or properties not\n             mentioned above, that is, residuary after my death\n             shall belong to Smt. Malini Mallya alone.\"\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_9\">4.    Plaintiff- Respondent, inter alia, prayed for passing a judgment and\n\ndecree against the defendants - appellants granting the following reliefs:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"1.   A declaration that the plaintiff is the\n                   exclusive copyright holder in respect of\n                   Yaksharanga ballets, namely, Bhishma\n                   Vijaya, Kanakangi, Nala Damayanthi,\n                   Panchavati, Gaya Charitha, Chitrangadha,\n                   Abhimanyu Vadha, and for consequential\n                   permanent injunction restraining the\n                   Defendants, their agents, employees etc.\n                   from staging or performing any of the above\n                   said 7 ballets or Prasangas or any parts\n                   thereof.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                                                       1,000-00\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                       5</span>\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">            2.     Directing the Defendants to pay to the\n                   plaintiff damages of Rs.15,000/- towards\n                   infringement of her copyright on account of\n                   stating or performing Abhimanyu Vadha on\n                   18-9-2001 at New Delhi.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">                                                            15,000-00\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">            3.     Directing the Defendants to pay to the\n                   plaintiff interest on Rs.15,000/- at 15% p.a.\n                   from 18-9-2001 till now which is\n                                                               95-00\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">            4.     Directing the Defendants to pay future\n                   interest on Rs.15,000/- at 15% p.a. till\n                   payment of the entire amount.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">            5.     ...................................\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">            6.     .....................................\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_10\">5.    Appellants in their written statement, however, denied and disputed\n\nany copyright of the said dance in Dr. Karanth alleging that whatever work\n\nhe had done was in the capacity of a Director of the Kendra with the\n\nassistance, finance and staff provided by the Organization of Mahatma\n\nGandhi Memorial College Trust in respect whereof a Committee was\n\nformed under him by the Board of Trustees. It was furthermore contended\n\nthat Dr. Karanth was appointed as the President of the Executive Committee\n\nof Yakshagana Kendra for a period of three years by the appellant and while\n\nholding the said post only he expired.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                    6</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_11\">6.    By reason of a judgment and decree dated 14.11.2003, the District\n\nJudge, Udupi decreed the said suit declaring the plaintiff - respondent as a\n\nperson having the exclusive copyright in respect of seven Prasangas and\n\nthat she had acquired the same by reason of a Will as a residuary legatee and\n\nthe defendants - appellants or their employees or agents were restrained\n\nfrom performing the said seven ballets or Prasangas or any parts thereof in\n\nany manner as evolved distinctively by Dr. Karanth.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_12\">7.    Appellants aggrieved thereby and dissatisfied therewith preferred an\n\nappeal before the Karnataka High Court which was marked as R.F.A. No.\n\n271 of 2004.     By reason of the impugned judgment and order dated\n\n5.12.2007, the said appeal has been dismissed.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_13\">8.    Appellants are, thus, before us.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_14\">9.    Dr. Rajiv Dhavan, learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of\n\nappellants in his usual fairness conceded:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">      i.    The copyright in the literary work has been assigned by reason\n\n            of the said Will in favour of the respondent in terms of clause\n\n            12 of the Will.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">      ii.   Dr. Karanth has made substantial changes in the original\n\n            traditional form of the Yakshagana dance. Additions made in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                    7</span>\n\n             the form of the said dance including the Prasangas fell within\n\n             the purview of `originality' in respect whereof copyright could\n\n             be claimed.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">      It was, however, urged:\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">      i.     Keeping in view of the findings of the learned trial judge, it\n\n             ought to have been held that no cause of action arose against\n\n             the appellants in this case as the Institution had performed the\n\n             said dance at New Delhi in the memory of Dr. Karanth without\n\n             charging any fees.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_13\">      ii.    The form of copyright as regards dramatic work as has been\n\n             held by the High Court stating the same to be a part of the\n\n             literary work is not correct as they connote two different things.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_14\">      iii.   The form of injunction granted in favour of the plaintiff -\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_15\">             respondent is not in terms of the provisions of the <a href=\"/doc/1136195/\" id=\"a_1\">Copyright\n\n             Act</a>, 1957 as the appellant as an institution or otherwise is\n\n             entitled to use the same in terms of clauses (a), (i) and (l) of\n\n             sub-Section (1) of <a href=\"/doc/1013176/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 52</a> thereof.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_16\">10.   Mr. G.V. Chandrashekhar, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nrespondent, on the other hand, would support the impugned judgment.\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                     8</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_15\">11.   <a href=\"/doc/1136195/\" id=\"a_3\">The Copyright Act</a>, 1957 (for short, \"the Act\") was enacted to amend\n\nand consolidate the law relating to copyright.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_16\">      <a href=\"/doc/797096/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 2</a> is the interpretation section.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_17\">      <a href=\"/doc/121334999/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 2(c)</a> defines `artistic work' to mean (i) a painting, a sculpture,\n\na drawing (including a diagram, map, chart or plan), an engraving or a\n\nphotograph, whether or not any such work possesses artistic quality; (ii) a\n\nwork of architecture; and (iii) any other work of artistic craftsmanship.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_18\">      The word `author' is defined in <a href=\"/doc/1655540/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 2(d)</a> to mean, (i) in relation to\n\na literary or dramatic work, the author of the work; (ii) in relation to a\n\nmusical work, the composer; (iii) in relation to an artistic work other than a\n\nphotograph, the artist; (iv) in relation to a photograph, the person taking the\n\nphotograph; (v) in relation to a cinematograph film or sound recording, the\n\nproducer; and (vi) in relation to any literary, dramatic, musical or artistic\n\nwork which is computer-generated, the person who causes the work to be\n\ncreated.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_19\">      The term \"communication to the public\" as defined in <a href=\"/doc/797096/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 2(ff)</a>\n\nreads as under:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_17\">             \"(ff) \"communication to the public\" means\n             making any work available for being seen or heard\n             or otherwise enjoyed by the public directly or by\n             any means of display or diffusion other than by\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                    9</span>\n\n              issuing copies of such work regardless of whether\n              any member of the pubic actually sees, hears or\n              otherwise enjoys the work so made available.\n              Explanation.- For the purposes of this clause,\n              communication through satellite or cable or any\n              other means of simultaneous communication to\n              more than one household or place of residence\n              including residential rooms of any hotel or hostel\n              shall be deemed to be communication to the\n              public\"</blockquote>\n\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_20\">        <a href=\"/doc/797096/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 2</a> (ffa) defines the word \"composer\", in relation to a musical\n\nwork, to mean the person who composes the music regardless of whether he\n\nrecords it in any form of graphical notation. <a
