href=\"/doc/31552/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 2(h)</a> defines \"dramatic\n\nwork\" to include any piece of recitation, choreographic work or\n\nentertainment in dumb show, the scenic arrangement or acting, form of\n\nwhich is fixed in writing or otherwise but does not include a cinematograph\n\nfilm.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_21\">        <a href=\"/doc/797096/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 2(o)</a> defines \"literary work\" to include computer programmes,\n\ntables and compilations including computer databases.         <a href=\"/doc/797096/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 2(qq)</a>\n\ndefines \"performer\" to include an actor, singer, musician, dancer, acrobat,\n\njuggler, conjurer, snake charmer, a person delivering a lecture or any other\n\nperson who makes a performance.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                     10</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_22\">       <a href=\"/doc/1635970/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 2(y)</a> defines \"work\" to mean any of the following works,\n\nnamely:- (i) a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work; (ii) a\n\ncinematograph film; (iii) a sound recording.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_23\">       <a href=\"/doc/4010217/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 13</a> which occurs in Chapter III of the Act provides that\n\nsubject to the provisions thereof and the other provisions of the said Act,\n\ncopyright shall subsists throughout India in the following classes of works,\n\nthat is to say,-\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_18\">              (a)   original literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works;\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_19\">              (b)   cinematograph films; and\n\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_20\">              (c)   sound recording.</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_24\">       <a href=\"/doc/1404402/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 17</a> of the Act deals with \"First owner of copyright\", in terms\n\nwhereof, subject to the provisions of the Act, the author of a work shall be\n\nthe owner of the copyright therein. Proviso (d) appended thereto states that\n\nin the case of a Government work, Government shall, in the absence of any\n\nagreement to the contrary, be the first owner of the copyright therein.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_25\">       <a href=\"/doc/535461/\" id=\"a_15\">Sections 22</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1008980/\" id=\"a_16\">23</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1247029/\" id=\"a_17\">52(1)(a)</a>, (i) and (l) of the Act, which are relevant\n\nfor our purpose read as under:\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_26\">              \"22. Term of copyright in published literary,\n              dramatic, musical and artistic works.- Except as\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                        11</span>\n\notherwise hereinafter provided, copyright shall\nsubsist in any literary, dramatic, musical or artistic\nwork (other than a photograph) published within\nthe life time of the author until fifty years from the\nbeginning of the calendar year following the year\nin which the author dies.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_27\">Explanation- In this section, the reference to the\nauthor shall in the case of a work of joint\nauthorship, be construed as a reference to the\nauthor who dies last.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_28\">23 - Term of copyright in anonymous and\npseudonymous works.- (1) In the case of a\nliterary, dramatic, musical or artistic work (other\nthan a photograph), which is published\nanonymously or pseudonymously, copyright shall\nsubsist until sixty years from the beginning of the\ncalendar year next following the year in which the\nwork is first published:\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">      Provided that where the identity of the\nauthor is disclosed before the expiry of the said\nperiod, copyright shall subsist until sixty years\nfrom the beginning of the calendar year following\nthe year in which the author dies.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">(2) In sub-section (1), references to the author\nshall, in the case of an anonymous work of joint\nauthorship, be construed,--\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_21\">      (a)    where the identity of the authors is\n             disclosed, as references to that author;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_22\">      (b)    where the identity of more authors\n             than one is disclosed, as references to\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                       12</span>\n\n             the author who dies last from amongst\n             such authors.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_31\">(3) In sub-section (1), references to the author\nshall, in the case of a pseudonymous work of joint\nauthorship, be construed,--\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_32\">      (a)    where the names of one or more (but\n             not all) of the authors arc\n             pseudonymous and his or their\n             identity is not disclosed, as references\n             to the author whose name is not a\n             pseudonym, or, if the names of two or\n             more of the authors are not\n             pseudonyms, as references to such of\n             those authors who dies last;\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_33\">      (b)    where the names of one or more (but\n             not all) of the authors arc pseudonyms\n             and the identity of one or more of\n             them is disclosed, as references to the\n             author who dies last from amongst the\n             authors whose names arc not\n             pseudonyms and the authors whose\n             names are pseudonyms and are\n             disclosed; and\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">      (c)    where the names of all the authors arc\n             pseudonyms and the identity of one of\n             them is disclosed, as references to the\n             author whose identity is disclosed or\n             if the identity of two or more of such\n             authors is disclosed, as references to\n             such of those authors who dies last.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">      Explanation.--For the purposes of this\nsection, the identity of an author shall be deemed\nto have been disclosed, if either the identity of the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                       13</span>\n\nauthor is disclosed publicly by both the author and\nthe publisher or is otherwise established to the\nsatisfaction of the Copyright Board by that author.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_36\">52. Certain acts not to be infringement of\ncopyright.- (1) The following acts shall not\nconstitute an infringement of copyright, namely:-\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_23\">       (a) a fair dealing with a literary,\n       dramatic, musical or artistic work not being\n       a computer programme for the purpose of--\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_24\">       (i)   Private use including research;\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_25\">       (ii) criticism or review, whether of that\n       work or of any other work;\n</blockquote>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_2\">            xxx          xxx          xxx\n\n\n      (i)    the performance, in the course of the\n</pre><blockquote id=\"blockquote_26\">      activities of an educational institution, of a\n      literary, dramatic or musical work by the\n      staff and student of the institution, or of a\n      cinematograph film or a sound recording, if\n      the audience is limited to such staff and\n      students, the parents and guardians of the\n      students and persons directly connected\n      with the activities of the institution or the\n      communication to such an audience of a\n      cinematograph film or sound recording.\n</blockquote><pre id=\"pre_3\">            xxx          xxx          xxx\n\n\n      (l)    the performance of a literary,\n      dramatic or musical work by an amateur\n</pre><blockquote id=\"blockquote_27\">      club or society, if the performance is given\n      to a non-paying audience, or for the benefit\n      of a religious institution.\"\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                    14</span>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_37\">12.   Before adverting to the submissions made by the learned counsel for\n\nthe parties, we may notice the issues framed in the suit, which are:\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_38\">                   \"i.    Does plaintiff prove that late Dr.\n                          Shivaramaji Karanth had acquired\n                          copyright in respect of seven\n                          Yakshagana Prasangas and also in\n                          respect of Yakshagana dramatic or\n                          theatrical form i.e., Bhishma Vijaya,\n                          Nala Damayanthi, Kanakaangti or\n                          Kanakangi Kalyana, Abhimanyu or\n                          Abhimanyu Vadha, Chitrangadha or\n                          Babruvahana Kalaga, Panchavati\n                          Chritha followed in the plaint?\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">                   ii.    Has the plaintiff became entitled to\n                          the said right under the Registered\n                          Will dated 18.06.1994?\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">                   iii.   Does the plaintiff prove that her right\n                          under the said Will was infringed by\n                          the defendants?\"\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_41\">13.   Indisputably, in view of the submissions made at the bar, respondent\n\nhad acquired copyright in respect of seven Yakshagana Prasangas as also in\n\nrespect of Yakshagana dramatic or theatrical form as a residuary legatee in\n\nterms of clause 12 of the Will dated 18.6.1994.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">\f                                     15</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_42\">      However, we may notice that whereas the trial court has proceeded on\n\nthe basis that clause 12 of the Will shall apply in the instant case, the High\n\nCourt opined that clause 11 thereof is attracted, stating:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_28\">              \".....No doubt, by reading para-12 of the `Will'\n             in isolation, one can certainly arrive at the\n             conclusion that the bequest made in favour of the\n             plaintiff is in the nature of residuary bequest.\n             But, that is not all, in the `Will'-Ex. P-1. I have\n             already referred to para No. 11 of the `Will'\n             while dealing with the topic dramatic works vis-\n             `-vis literary work and therefore if the `Will' is\n             read in its entirety and if we take into account,\n             the benefits that flow from the bequest made by\n             Dr. Karanth in favour of the plaintiff, it is not as\n             if the plaintiff received the bequest only in\n             respect of the things which form the residuary as\n             mentioned in para-12 of the `Will' but the\n             plaintiff also was given the copyrights in respect\n             of literary works and all books as well as the\n             right to print, republished and mark the literary\n             works as well as the books.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_43\">      Referring to the new Encyclopaedia Britannica and Halsbury's Laws\n\nof England, that a literary work with dramatic elements in it would also be\n\nliterary work, the High Court observed:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_29\">             \"Dramatic works also could contain in its,\n             passages of great literary taste, as in the case of\n             great plays of William Shakespear. Therefore, the\n             main classification as literary work and dramatic\n             work cannot be construed to mean that dramatic\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">\f                                    16</span>\n\n            work has nothing to do with literary work. The\n            only difference I see in them is that the dramatic\n            work (Plays) forms the text upon which the\n            performance of the plays rests whereas a `literary\n            work' enables one to read the printed words.\n            Neither of the two can be produced without the\n            imaginative skill of the author.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_30\">      It was furthermore held:\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_31\">            \"I am of the considered opinion that all the above\n            changes brought about by Dr. Karanth in respect\n            of Yakshagana Ballet leads to the inference that\n            the imaginative faculties of Dr. Karanth permeated\n            the entire Yakshagana Prasangas and thus a new\n            look was given to the Yakshagana Ballets. I,\n            therefore, hold that the bequest of copyright in\n            literary works and books in favour of the plaintiff\n            by Dr. Karanth, will have to be treated as the\n            bequest covering the dramatic works also since I\n            have also drawn the conclusion that the dramatic\n            works is also a form of literature. Therefore,\n            necessity of mentioning copyright separately in\n            respect of dramatic works does not arise. The\n            plaintiff, therefore, is entitled to copyright even in\n            respect of the dramatic works namely the seven\n            prasangas, by virtue of bequest made in her favour\n            in respect of copyrights and books.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_32\">14.   Broadly speaking, a dramatic work may also come within the purview\n\nof literary work being a part of dramatic literature. The new Encyclopaedia\n\nBritannica (Vol-IV) 15th Edition, provides the following information about\n\n\"Dramatic Literature.\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">\f                                      17</span>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_33\">         \"Dramatic Literature: the texts of plays that can be read, as distinct\n         from being seen and heard in performance.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_34\">         We must, however, notice that the provisions the Act make a\n\ndistinction between the `literary work' and `dramatic work'. Keeping in\n\nview the statutory provisions, there cannot be any doubt whatsoever that\n\ncopyright in respect of performance of `dance' would not come within the\n\npurview of the literary work but would come within the purview of the\n\ndefinition of `dramatic work'. We, however, do not mean to suggest that any\n\nact of literary work will be outside the purview of the Will dated 18.6.1994.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_44\">Our exercise in this behalf was only for the purpose of clarifying the\n\nprovisions of the Act with reference to the findings arrived at by the High\n\nCourt.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_45\">15.      For the aforementioned reasons, we agree with Dr. Dhavan that\n\nparagraph 12 of the Will, namely, residuary clause shall apply in the instant\n\ncase apart from the areas which are otherwise covered by paragraph 11 of\n\nthe Will. The residuary clause will apply because it is well settled that no\n\npart of the stay lies in limbo. It was also not a case where respondent in any\n\nmanner whatsoever waived her right.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">\f                                    18</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_46\">16.   The learned trial judge on issue No. 4 opined that plaintiff had not\n\nbeen able to prove actual loss or damage particularly having regard to the\n\nfact that Dr. Karanth had associated himself with the appellants for a long\n\ntime. The learned trial judge recognized the equitable interest vested in the\n\nplaintiff - respondent. A declaratory decree, therefore, was passed.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_47\">17.   We may notice at this stage that the form of injunction granted both\n\nby the learned trial judge as also by the High Court in favour of the\n\nplaintiff-respondent. The operative part of the judgment of the trial court\n\nreads as under:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_35\">            \"Defendants or their employees or agents are\n            restrained from performing the above said 7\n            ballets or Prasangas or in parts thereof in any\n            manner as evolved distinctively by Dr. Karanth by\n            way of permanent injunction.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_36\">      The High Court, however, directed:\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_37\">             \"(iii) As far as the restraint order passed by the\n            Trial Court by granting permanent injunction to\n            the plaintiff is concerned, the same is modified by\n            ordering that if the appellants desire to stage any\n            of the seven Yakshagana prasangas in the manner\n            and form as conceived in all respects viz.,\n            costumes, choreography and direction by Dr.\n            Karanth, the appellants can do so only in\n            accordance with the provisions of the Copyrights\n            Act, 1957 in view of copyright in seven prasangas\n            vesting with the plaintiff.\"\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">\f                                     19</span>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_38\">18.   Decree for injunction is an equitable relief. The courts while passing\n\na decree for permanent injunction would avoid multiplicity of proceedings.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_48\">The court while passing such a decree, is obligated to consider the statutory\n\nprovisions governing the same. For the said purpose, it must be noticed as\n\nto what is a copyright and in respect of the matters the same cannot be\n\nclaimed or otherwise the same is lodged by conditions and subject to\n\nstatutory limitation.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_49\">19.   <a href=\"/doc/1734007/\" id=\"a_18\">In R.G. Anand vs. M/s Delux Films &amp; ors</a>. [(1978) 4 SCC 118], this\n\nCourt held:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_39\">              \"46. Thus, on a careful consideration and\n              elucidation of the various authorities and the case\n              law on the subject discussed above, the following\n              propositions emerge:\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_40\">                 1. There can be no copyright in an idea,\n                    subject-matter, themes, plots or historical or\n                    legendary facts and violation of the\n                    copyright in such cases is confined to the\n                    form, manner and arrangement and\n                    expression of the idea by the author of the\n                    copyrighted work.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_41\">                 2. Where the same idea is being developed in a\n                    different manner, it is manifest that the\n                    source being common, similarities are\n                    bound to occur. In such a case the courts\n                    should determine whether or not the\n                    similarities are on fundamental or\n                    substantial aspects of the mode of\n                    expression adopted in the copyrighted work.\n                    If the defendant's work is nothing but a\n                    literal imitation of the copyrighted work\n                    with some variations here and there it would\n                    amount to violation of the copyright. In\n                    other words, in order to be actionable the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">\f                      20</span>\n\n     copy must be a substantial and material one\n     which at once leads to the conclusion that\n     the defendant is guilty of an act of piracy.\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_50\">3.   One of the surest and the safest test to\n     determine whether or not there has been a\n     violation of copyright is to see if the reader,\n     spectator or the viewer after having read or\n     seen both the works is clearly of the opinion\n     and gets an unmistakable impression that\n     the subsequent work appears to be a copy of\n     the original.\n</p><p id=\"p_51\">4.   Where the theme is the same but is\n     presented and treated differently so that the\n     subsequent work becomes a completely new\n     work, no question of violation of copyright\n     arises.\n</p><p id=\"p_52\">5.   Where however apart from the similarities\n     appearing in the two works there are also\n     material and broad dissimilarities which\n     negative the intention to copy the original\n     and the coincidences appearing in the two\n     works are clearly incidental no infringement\n     of the copyright comes into existence.\n</p><p id=\"p_53\">6.   As a violation of copyright amounts to an\n     act of piracy it must be proved by clear and\n     cogent evidence after applying the various\n     tests laid down by the case-law discussed\n     above.\n</p><p id=\"p_54\">7.   Where however the question is of the\n     violation of the copyright of stage play by a\n     film producer or a director the task of the\n     plaintiff becomes more difficult to prove\n     piracy. It is manifest that unlike a stage play\n     a film has a much broader prospective,\n     wider field and a bigger background where\n     the defendants can by introducing a variety\n     of incidents give a colour and complexion\n     different from the manner in which the\n     copyrighted work has expressed the idea.\n     Even so, if the viewer after seeing the film\n     gets a totality of impression that the film is\n     by and large a copy of the original play,\n     violation of the copyright may be said to be\n     proved.\"\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">\f                                     21</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_55\">      Yet again in <a href=\"/doc/1062099/\" id=\"a_19\">Eastern Book Company &amp; ors. vs. D.B. Modak &amp; Anr</a>.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_56\">[(2008) 1 SCC 1], this Court held:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_42\">             \"57. <a href=\"/doc/1136195/\" id=\"a_20\">The Copyright Act</a> is not concerned with the\n             original idea but with the expression of thought.\n             Copyright has nothing to do with originality or\n             literary merit. Copyrighted material is that what is\n             created by the author by his own skill, labour and\n             investment of capital, maybe it is a derivative\n             work which gives a flavour of creativity. The\n             copyright work which comes into being should be\n             original in the sense that by virtue of selection,\n             coordination or arrangement of pre-existing data\n             contained in the work, a work somewhat different\n             in character is produced by the author. On the face\n             of the provisions of the <a href=\"/doc/1136195/\" id=\"a_21\">Copyright Act</a>, 1957, we\n             think that the principle laid down by the Canadian\n             Court would be applicable in copyright of the\n             judgments of the Apex Court. We make it clear\n             that the decision of ours would be confined to the\n             judgments of the courts which are in the public\n             domain as by virtue of <a href=\"/doc/1013176/\" id=\"a_22\">Section 52</a> of the Act there\n             is no copyright in the original text of the\n             judgments. To claim copyright in a compilation,\n             the author must produce the material with exercise\n             of his skill and judgment which may not be\n             creativity in the sense that it is novel or non-\n             obvious, but at the same time it is not a product of\n             merely labour and capital. The derivative work\n             produced by the author must have some\n             distinguishable features and flavour to raw text of\n             the judgments delivered by the court. The trivial\n             variation or inputs put in the judgment would not\n             satisfy the test of copyright of an author.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_57\">20.   The High Court, in our opinion, should have clarified that the\n\nappellants can also take the statutory benefit of the provisions contained in\n\nclauses (a), (i) and (l) of sub-section (1) of <a href=\"/doc/1013176/\" id=\"a_23\">Section 52</a> of the Act.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_21\">\f                                       22</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_58\">      <a href=\"/doc/1013176/\" id=\"a_24\">Section 52</a> of the Act provides for certain acts which would not\n\nconstitute an infringement of copyright. When a fair dealing is made, inter\n\nalia, of a literary or dramatic work for the purpose of private use including\n\nresearch and criticism or review, whether of that work or of any other work,\n\nthe right in terms of the provisions of the said Act cannot be claimed. Thus,\n\nif some performance or dance is carried out within the purview of the said\n\nclause, the order of injunction shall not be applicable. Similarly, appellant\n\nbeing an educational institution, if the dance is performed within the\n\nmeaning of provisions of clause (i) of sub-section (1) of <a href=\"/doc/1013176/\" id=\"a_25\">Section 52</a> of the\n\nAct strictly, the order of injunction shall not apply thereto also. Yet again,\n\nif such performance is conducted before a non-paying audience by the\n\nappellant, which is an institution if it comes within the purview of amateur\n\nclub or society, the same would not constitute any violation of the said order\n\nof injunction.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_59\">21.   With the aforementioned modification in the order of injunction, this\n\nappeal is dismissed. However, in the facts and circumstances of the case,\n\nthere shall be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_60\">                                             ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_61\">                                                    [S.B. Sinha]\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_22\">\f                   23</span>\n\n\n\n                        .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_62\">                        [Lokeshwar          Singh      Panta]\n\n\n\n\n                        .....................................J.\n                           [B. Sudershan Reddy]\n\n\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_63\">January 23, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":11,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"multiplier","formInput":"multiplier"},{"value":"loss of dependency","formInput":"loss%20of%20dependency"},{"value":"claim cases","formInput":"claim%20cases"},{"value":"section 166","formInput":"section%20166"},{"value":"future prospects","formInput":"future%20prospects"},{"value":"s. mohan singh","formInput":"s.%20mohan%20singh"},{"value":"shankar lal","formInput":"shankar%20lal"},{"value":"shankarlal","formInput":"shankarlal"},{"value":"deviation","formInput":"deviation"}],"citeList":[{"tid":136948773,"url":null,"title":"Section 166 in The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":22871263,"url":null,"title":"Section 163A in The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":785258,"url":null,"title":"The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"},{"tid":1683465,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=12278","title":"General Manager, Kerala S.R.T.C vs Susamma Thomas on 6 January, 1993"},{"tid":1259215,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=20541","title":"United India Insurance Co. Ltd. ... vs Patrica Jean Mahajan And Ors. Etc. ... on 8 July, 2002"}],"covers":[],"title":"Mohan Singh vs Kashi Bai & Ors on 13 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-13","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":131799,"url":null,"title":"United India Insurance Company ... vs Raj Rani And Ors. on 24 February, 1996"}],"tid":438956,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"s","lastname":"sinha","numcitedby":1,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33503","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Mohan Singh vs Kashi Bai &amp; Ors on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: S.B. Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Cyriac Joseph</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                   IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 105            OF 2009\n               [Arising out of SLP (Civil) No. 6227 of 2006]\n\n\nMohan Singh                                              ...Appellant\n\n                                      Versus\n\nKashi Bai &amp; Ors.                                         ...Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. SINHA, J :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_3\">2.    Appellant before us is the driver and owner of the jeep bearing\n\nregistration No. MP-04J 1824 which met with an accident on 21.11.1999\n\nhaving collided with a truck.     The deceased Balma @ Balram Gond,\n\nRamgopal and Shankarlal admittedly were travelling in the said vehicle.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_4\">3.    A First Information Report was lodged.         The heirs and legal\n\nrepresentatives of the deceased filed applications for grant of compensation\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        2</span>\n\n\nin terms of <a href=\"/doc/136948773/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 166</a> of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 (for short \"the\n\nAct\") which was marked as Claim Case Nos. 76, 78 and 79 of 2002.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_5\">4.    The learned Tribunal, having regard to the rival contentions of the\n\nparties, framed the following issues:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"1. Whether on 21.11.99 in the night at about 8\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">             a.m. near village Semri, non applicant No. 1</span>\n             driving Jeep No. MP04 1824 and truck No.\n             MP04K2028 driven negligently and rashly the\n             collision between the two vehicle occurred and in\n             the result Shankarlal died.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">             2.     Whether there was contributory negligence\n             on the part of both the drivers? If so, effect.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">             3.     At 8 p.m. Jeep No. MP04J1824 was dashed\n             by truck No. MP04 K 2028 and the accident was\n             caused, if so, effect..\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">             4.     Whether applicants are entitled for\n             compensation.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">             5.     Relief &amp; Cost.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">5.    The learned Tribunal upon consideration of the depositions of the\n\nwitnesses held that neither the truck No. MP04K 2028 was involved in the\n\naccident, nor was it caused on account of rash and negligent driving on the\n\npart of its driver. The learned Tribunal passed awards in all the three cases\n\nas under:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                    3</span>\n\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">      Claim Case No. 76 of 2002             Rs. 1,32,000/-\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">      Claim Case No. 78 of 2002             Rs. 1,92,000/-\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">      Claim Case No. 79 of 2002             Rs. 4,22,400/-\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">6.    Appeals were preferred thereagainst by the appellant. By reason of\n\nthe impugned judgment, the High Court, however, reversed the said\n\nfindings, holding:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">            \"16. Coming to question of negligence, though\n            Mohan Singh and two other witnesses examined\n            by the claimant has stated that it was the truck\n            driver who drove it in rash and negligent manner.\n            However, in the claim petition, it was rightly\n            mentioned that jeep driver also drove it in rash and\n            negligent manner and the accident took place\n            when two vehicles dashed against each other.\n            Both were coming from opposite direction, thus, it\n            was the duty of both the drivers to avoid the\n            collision in which they have failed. Thus, we\n            come to the conclusion that it is a case of\n            contributory negligence in equal proportion of\n            both drivers.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">      Although we are of the opinion that the High Court in doing so\n\nshould have considered the matter at some details and it was further\n\nrequired to assign some reasons in support thereof, but, it is not necessary\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                     4</span>\n\n\nfor us to consider that aspect of the matter as the owner or the insurer of the\n\ntruck having not preferred any appeal, the same has attained finality.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_9\">      In this appeal we are concerned with only one question, viz., as to\n\nwhether any case has been made out for enhancement of the amount of\n\ncompensation in favour of the appellant.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_10\">7.    So far as the quantum of compensation is concerned, the Tribunal\n\nproceeded on the basis that the age of the deceased Shankarlal was 35 years.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">His monthly income was assessed at Rs. 1500/- per month. One-third of the\n\nsaid amount was deducted as his personal expenditure.           Applying the\n\nmultiplier of 10, it was held that the applicants were entitled to\n\ncompensation of Rs. 1,20,000/-.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_12\">      As regards the quantum of compensation payable to the heirs and\n\nlegal representatives of the deceased Balma is concerned, the loss of\n\ndependency was determined at Rs. 12,000/- per annum by the Tribunal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">Having regard to the fact that he was aged 25 years, the multiplier of 15 was\n\nused to hold that a compensation for a sum of Rs. 1,92,000/- should be\n\ngranted.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                      5</span>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_14\">      The deceased Ram Gopal was aged 31 years at the time of the\n\naccident.   A multiplier of 12 was used in his case and the amount of\n\ncompensation of Rs. 4,22,400/- was held to be payable to him on the\n\npremise that the loss of dependency was Rs. 34,200/- per annum.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_15\">8.    The High Court, however, although did not interfere with these\n\nfinding of facts, applied the multiplier of 17 in all the cases.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_16\">9.    Mr. Shiv Sagar Tiwari, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nappellant would contend that the High Court committed a serious error in\n\nholding that the multiplier of 17 should be applied in modification of the\n\norder of the Tribunal.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_17\">10.   The liability to pay compensation in a case where a vehicle meets\n\nwith an accident is principally that of the owner thereof. The age of the\n\ndeceased as also the loss of dependency suffered by his heirs respectively\n\nand legal representatives is seriously not in dispute.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_18\">11.   The core question, therefore, which arises for consideration is as to\n\nwhether the multiplier specified in the table contained in the Second\n\nSchedule appended to the Act should have been applied. Although the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                     6</span>\n\n\nSecond Schedule is applicable only in respect of the claim petitions filed\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/22871263/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 163A</a> of the Act, indisputably, the same provides for some\n\nguidelines.   In a case where the deceased was above 25 years but not\n\nexceeding 30 years, in terms of the said Second Schedule, the multiplier of\n\n18 is to be applied. In the case of the deceased whose age was above 30\n\nyears but not exceeding 35 years, the multiplier of 17 in terms of the Second\n\nSchedule is required to be applied.      The High Court, therefore, in our\n\nopinion, has applied the correct multiplier. The quantum of multiplicand, as\n\nnoticed hereinbefore, is not in question. In a case of this nature, it is not\n\nnecessary to go into the larger question, viz., as to whether the courts should\n\napply the multiplier specified in the Second Schedule in a proceeding under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/136948773/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 166</a> of the Act.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_19\">12.   <a href=\"/doc/1683465/\" id=\"a_4\">In General Manager, Kerala State Road Transport Corporation,\n\nTrivandrum v. Susamma Thomas and others</a>, [(1994) 2 SCC 176] apart\n\nfrom applying the structured formula for determination of the amount of\n\ncompensation with regard to the future prospect of the deceased, it was\n\nopined :-\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_20\">              \"19. In the present case the deceased was 39 years\n              of age. His income was Rs 1032 per month. Of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                        7</span>\n\n\ncourse, the future prospects of advancement in life\nand career should also be sounded in terms of\nmoney to augment the multiplicand. While the\nchance of the multiplier is determined by two\nfactors, namely, the rate of interest appropriate to a\nstable economy and the age of the deceased or of\nthe claimant whichever is higher, the\nascertainment of the multiplicand is a more\ndifficult exercise. Indeed, many factors have to be\nput into the scales to evaluate the contingencies of\nthe future. All contingencies of the future need not\nnecessarily be baneful. The deceased person in\nthis case had a more or less stable job. It will not\nbe inappropriate to take a reasonably liberal view\nof the prospects of the future and in estimating the\ngross income it will be unreasonable to estimate\nthe loss of dependency on the present actual\nincome of Rs 1032 per month. We think, having\nregard to the prospects of advancement in the\nfuture career, respecting which there is evidence\non record, we will not be in error in making a\nhigher estimate of monthly income at Rs 2000 as\nthe gross income. From this has to be deducted his\npersonal living expenses, the quantum of which\nagain depends on various factors such as whether\nthe style of living was spartan or bohemian. In the\nabsence of evidence it is not unusual to deduct\none-third of the gross income towards the personal\nliving expenses and treat the balance as the\namount likely to have been spent on the members\nof the family and the dependents. This loss of\ndependency should capitalize with the appropriate\nmultiplier. In the present case we can take about\nRs 1400 per month or Rs 17,000 per year as the\nloss of dependency and if capitalized on a\nmultiplier of 12, which is appropriate to the age of\nthe deceased, the compensation would work out to\n(Rs 17,000 x 12 = Rs       2,03,000) to which is\nadded the usual award for loss of consortium and\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                    8</span>\n\n\n            loss of the estate each in the conventional sum of\n            Rs 15,000.\"\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_21\">      <a href=\"/doc/484625/\" id=\"a_5\">In Kaushnuma Begum v. New India Assurance Co. Ltd</a>., [ (2001) 2\n\nSCC 9 ] this Court observed:-\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">            22. The appellants claimed a sum of Rs 2,36,000.\n            But PW 1 widow of the deceased said that her\n            husband's income was Rs 1500 per month. PW 4\n            brother of the deceased also supported the same\n            version. No contra-evidence has been adduced in\n            regard to that aspect. It is, therefore, reasonable to\n            believe that the monthly income of the deceased\n            was Rs. 1500. In calculating the amount of\n            compensation in this case we lean ourselves to\n            adopt the structured formula provided in the\n            Second Schedule to the <a href=\"/doc/785258/\" id=\"a_6\">MV Act</a>. Though it was\n            formulated for the purpose of <a href=\"/doc/22871263/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 163-A</a> of the\n            MV Act, we find it a safer guidance for arriving at\n            the amount of compensation than any other\n            method so far as the present case is concerned.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_22\">      <a href=\"/doc/1259215/\" id=\"a_8\">In United India Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Patricia Jean Mahajan</a>,\n[ (2002) 6 SCC 281 ], however, this Court held :-\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">            \"21. The purpose to compensate the dependants of\n            the victims is that they may not be suddenly\n            deprived of the source of their maintenance and as\n            far as possible they may be provided with the\n            means as were available to them before the\n            accident took place. It will be a just and fair\n            compensation. But in cases where the amount of\n            compensation may go much higher than the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                    9</span>\n\n\n             amount providing the same amenities, comforts\n             and facilities and also the way of life, in such\n             circumstances also it may be a case where, while\n             applying the multiplier system, the lesser\n             multiplier may be applied. In such cases, the\n             amount of multiplicand becomes relevant. The\n             intention is not to overcompensate.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">             22. We therefore, hold that ordinarily while\n             awarding compensation, the provisions contained\n             in the Second Schedule may be taken as a guide\n             including the multiplier, but there may arise some\n             cases, as the one in hand, which may fall in the\n             category having special features or facts calling\n             for deviation from the multiplier usually\n             applicable.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_23\">      It is evident from the above that this Court in the said decisions had\n\ntaken a departure from the Second Schedule.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_24\">      <a href=\"/doc/722960/\" id=\"a_9\">In Jyoti Kaul v. State of M.P</a>., [ (2002) 6 SCC 306 ] multiplier of 15\n\nwas adopted, stating :-\n</p>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_13\">             \"The aforesaid decision makes it clear that the\n             principle of multiplier would depend on the facts\n             and circumstances of each case. Looking to the\n             facts of this case we find that the Tribunal has\n             given good reasons for applying the multiplier of\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_14\">             15. This was in addition of taking into\n             consideration that the predecessors of the deceased\n             all lived for more than 80 years. The High Court\n             reduced the multiplier from 15 to 10 without\n             taking     into     consideration    circumstances\n             considered by the Tribunal and thus committed the\n             error. We, accordingly, set aside the findings of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                    10</span>\n\n\n            the High Court only to the extent of the\n            application of multiplier and uphold other findings\n            including reduction of interest. The present appeal,\n            accordingly, succeeds in part. The computation of\n            compensation now shall be made on the basis of\n            multiplier of 15. The difference of enhanced\n            amount which has yet not been paid by the\n            respondent State shall be paid to the claimants\n            within a period of three months from today.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_15\">      <a href=\"/doc/909799/\" id=\"a_10\">In Smt. Supe Dei &amp; Ors. v. M/s. National Insurance Co. Ltd. &amp; Anr</a>.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_25\">[JT 2002 (Suppl.1) SC 451], this Court held:\n</p>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_16\">               \"...While considering the question of just\n            compensation payable in a case all relevant factors\n            including the appropriate multiplier are to be kept\n            in mind. The position is well settled that the\n            second schedule under <a href=\"/doc/22871263/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 163A</a> to the Act\n            which gives the amount of compensation to be\n            determined for the purpose of claim under the\n            section can be taken as a guideline while\n            determining the compensation under <a href=\"/doc/136948773/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 166</a>\n            of the Act. In that view of the matter, there is no\n            reason why multiplier of 17 should not be taken as\n            the appropriate multiplier in the case.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_26\">      <a href=\"/doc/1407348/\" id=\"a_13\">In Abati Bezbaruah v. Dy. Director General, Geological Survey of\n\nIndia and Another</a> [(2003) 3 SCC 148], this Court held:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                   11</span>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_17\">                \"11. It is now a well-settled principle of law\n            that the payment of compensation on the basis of\n            structured formula as provided for under the\n            Second Schedule should not ordinarily be deviated\n            from. <a href=\"/doc/41160316/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 168</a> of the Motor Vehicles Act lays\n            down the guidelines for determination of the\n            amount of compensation in terms of <a href=\"/doc/136948773/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 166</a>\n            thereof. Deviation from the structured formula,\n            however, as has been held by this Court, may be\n            resorted to in exceptional cases. Furthermore, the\n            amount of compensation should be just and fair in\n            the facts and circumstances of each case.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_18\">                12. The victim at the relevant time was 40\n            years of age. The Tribunal and the High Court,\n            therefore, cannot be said to have committed an\n            error in applying the multiplier of 15. The only\n            question which is required to be considered now is\n            as to how the multiplicand should be arrived at.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_19\">               13. The deceased at the time of accident was a\n            young man. He had a stable job. A reasonably\n            liberal view of his future prospects should have,\n            therefore, been taken into consideration by the\n            High Court as well as by the Tribunal.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_20\">                14. Having regard to the prospects and\n            advancement of the future career, a higher\n            estimate of the yearly income at Rs.45,000 would\n            not be out of place. From the said amount, one-\n            third of the gross income towards personal living\n            expenses should be deducted. The amount of\n            Rs 30,000 should thus be determined as the loss of\n            dependency. The said sum should be capitalized\n            by applying the multiplier of 15, which comes to\n            Rs 4,50,000.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_27\">      In Kanhaiyalal Kataria and Others v. Mukul Chaturvedi and Others\n\n[(2005) 12 SCC 190], this Court held:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                    12</span>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_21\">               \"3. Learned counsel for the claimants made\n            submissions         seeking      enhancement      of\n            compensation on the ground that the income of the\n            deceased has not been properly estimated. We are\n            not going into any other aspect except the question\n            of proper multiplier for computation of\n            compensation. In our opinion, by taking the\n            multiplier of 17, the amount of compensation\n            deserves to be increased. The compensation\n            amount may be suitably recomputed by the\n            Tribunal by applying the multiplier of 17 and\n            interest at the rate of 12 per cent per annum on the\n            increased amount be also granted.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_28\">      <a href=\"/doc/1786856/\" id=\"a_16\">In Bilkish v. United India Insurance Company Limited and Another</a>\n\n[(2008) 4 SCC 259], this Court held:\n</p>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_22\">               \"4. After hearing learned counsel for the\n            parties, we are of the opinion that the view taken\n            by the High Court and the Tribunal is not correct.\n            The incumbent was a bachelor and he could not\n            have spent more than 1/3rd of his total income for\n            personal use and rest of the amount earned by him\n            would certainly go to the family kitty. Therefore,\n            determining the loss of dependency by 50% was\n            not correct. Therefore, we assess that he must be\n            spending 1/3rd towards personal use and\n            contributing 2/3rd of his income to his family.\n            Therefore, we work out that Rs        30,000 was\n            earned by him per annum. The loss of dependency\n            was 2/3rd i.e. Rs 20,000. The multiplier of `11'\n            applied for loss of dependency was also not\n            correct and as per Schedule appended to the <a href=\"/doc/785258/\" id=\"a_17\">Motor\n            Vehicles Act</a>, 1988 it should be `12'. Applying the\n            multiplier of 12 the total loss of dependency will\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                      13</span>\n\n\n             be Rs 20,000 x 12 = Rs 2,40,000 and Rs\n             10,000 towards loss of estate and funeral\n             expenses, the total compensation comes to\n             Rs 2,50,000 and incumbent is entitled for interest\n             @ 9% p.a. from the date of the petition. The\n             appeal is allowed with the aforesaid modification.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_29\">13.   We, therefore, keeping in view the aforementioned peculiar facts and\n\ncircumstances of the case, are of the opinion that the judgment of the High\n\nCourt in applying the multiplier of 17 need not be interfered with.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_30\">14.   For the reasons aforementioned, there is no merit in this appeal which\n\nis dismissed accordingly. However, in the facts and circumstances of the\n\ncase, there shall be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_31\">                                             ...............................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">                                             [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n\n                                             ................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">                                             [Cyriac Joseph]\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">January 13, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"17b","formInput":"17b"},{"value":"section 17b","formInput":"section%2017b"},{"value":"33c(2)","formInput":"33c%282%29"},{"value":"gainfully employed","formInput":"gainfully%20employed"},{"value":"maintenance allowance","formInput":"maintenance%20allowance"},{"value":"the industrial disputes act 1947","formInput":"the%20industrial%20disputes%20act%201947"},{"value":"remuneration","formInput":"remuneration"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Kaivalyadham Employees ... vs Kaivalyadham S.M.Y.M. Samity on 28 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33684","lastname":"...................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-28","citedbyList":[{"tid":47416825,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/PKB/judgement/22-11-2011/PKB08112011CMA72062006.pdf","title":"Superhouse Leathers Limited vs Rana Pratap Singh & Anr. on 8 November, 2011"},{"tid":1842345,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/RSE/judgement/12-05-2011/RSE09052011CW226272005.pdf","title":"Anil Engineering Works vs Secretary Labour & Labour ... on 9 May, 2011"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":2,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Kaivalyadham Employees ... vs Kaivalyadham S.M.Y.M. Samity on 28 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Cyriac Joseph</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                          CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                            CIVIL APPEAL NO.480 OF 2009\n                          (Arising out of S.L.P.(C) No.2588/2007)\n\n\nKaivalyadham Employees Association                              ...Appellant(s)\n\n                   Versus\n\nKaivalyadham S.M.Y.M. Samity                                     ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                      ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">         Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">         This appeal is directed against the judgment and order dated 3rd October,\n\n2006, passed by the Bombay High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No.200/2006\n\narising out of Civil Application No.2481/2005 in Writ Petition No.4000/2005.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">         At the very outset, it may be indicated that since then, the Writ Petition has\n\nbeen finally disposed of by an order dated 7th May, 2007 and another Letters Patent\n\nAppeal No.138/2007, filed by the respondent Samity, is pending before the High\n\nCourt.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">         The appellant Association raised an industrial dispute relating to the\n\nretrenchment orders passed against some of its members and, while passing an\n\nAward on 2nd March, 2005, the Industrial Court directed reinstatement of the\n\nconcerned employees within one month from the date of the publication of the\n\nAward. Feeling aggrieved by the said Award, the respondent Samity filed Writ\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                          1</span>\n\fPetition No.4000/2005 before the Bombay High Court. The same was admitted and\n\nthe implementation of the Award was stayed by the High Court by its order dated 21st\n\nJuly, 2005.   Since the Award regarding reinstatement was stayed, the appellant\n\nAssociation moved Civil Application No.2481/2005 in the Writ Petition praying for\n\nthe benefit under <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 17B</a> of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, to be extended to\n\nthe successful workmen who had been directed to be reinstated.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">         After considering the affidavits filed on behalf of the workmen and those of\n\nthe respondent Samity, the learned Single Judge, in paragraphs 10, 11 and 12 of his\n\njudgment, observed as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">         \"10. On the fact of the evidence that was sought to be placed before\n         this Court by the employer along with the affidavits filed by Mr.\n         Agarwal opposing this application, it cannot be said that any of the 10\n         workmen are or were gainfully employed during the pendency of this\n         Petition in any establishment and were/are in receipt of adequate\n         remuneration. Working as a petty labour is not employment in any\n         establishment and at the same time it was not a regular job. Such\n         employment is obviously as and when and wherever available. The\n         submissions of Mrs. Doshi that the trial court be directed to record\n         evidence as is done in the proceedings instituted under <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 33C(2)</a>\n         of the I.D. Act cannot be considered as the scheme of <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 17B</a> does\n         not envisage such an exercise. Mrs. Doshi also pointed out by referring\n         to some correspondence between the management and the Government\n         of India to the effect that if these 10 to 12 workmen are reinstated, the\n         financial burden will have to be borne by the management alone and\n         the Central Government would not contribute anything towards the\n         same. The management is running a Hospital, a College and Yoga\n         Research Centre etc. These 10 workmen were employed by the\n         management Trust and they were not the employees of the college,\n         Hospital or Yoga Centre as a separate establishment.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">         11. In the premises it is clear that the employer failed to defeat this\n         application in spite of series of affidavits and the CD having been\n         placed before this Court.\n</blockquote>\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                          2</span>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\f          12. The application, therefore, succeeds and the same is hereby\n          allowed in respect of the above 10 workmen.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\nFrom the above, it will be evident that the learned Single Judge decided the question\n\nof gainful employment by the workmen on its merits and decided that it could not be\n\nsaid that any of the ten workmen were gainfully employed during the pendency of the\n\npetition, in any establishment and were in receipt of adequate remuneration.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">         Challenging the said order of the learned Single Judge, the respondent\n\nSamity filed Letters Patent Appeal No.200/2006 wherein, considering the the financial\n\nsituation of the Samity, the Division Bench observed that the interest of justice would\n\nbe served if a direction was given to the Samity to pay 70% of the last drawn wages to\n\nthe said ten workmen. An order was passed disposing of the Letters Patent Appeal in\n\nthe said terms. The said order passed in the Letters Patent Appeal is the subject\n\nmatter of the present appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">         On behalf of the appellant Association, it has been submitted by Mr. Nitin\n\nS. Tambwekar, learned Advocate, that the Division Bench of the Bombay High Court\n\nhad misconstrued the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 17B</a> of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947,\n\nwhich makes it very clear that in the event an award for reinstatement is stayed by a\n\nHigh Court or the Supreme Court, the employer would be liable to pay such\n\nworkman, during the period of pendency of such proceedings, full wages last drawn\n\nby him, inclusive of any maintenance allowance admissible to him under any rule,\n\nprovided that the workman had not been employed in any establishment during such\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                           3</span>\n\fperiod and an affidavit by such workman has been filed to that effect in such court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">          Learned counsel reiterated the findings of the learned Single Judge that the\n\nworkmen concerned had not been gainfully employed during the period in question.\n\nMr.Tambwekar, accordingly, submitted that the order of the Division Bench of the\n\nHigh Court was liable to be set aside and that of the learned Single Judge restored.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">          Appearing for the respondent Samity, Ms.Ranjeeta Rohatagi, learned\n\nAdvocate, submitted that no interference is called for with the impugned order since\n\nthe Division Bench had considered the financial condition of the respondent Samity\n\nwhile passing the said order. She also urged that before the learned Single Judge, it\n\nhad been submitted on behalf of the Samity that in order to quantify the workmen's\n\ndues, the matter should be remitted to the Labour Court for the purpose of taking\n\nevidence as is done under <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 33C(2)</a> of the Act. However, such submission was\n\nalso rejected by the learned Single Judge and was not considered by the Division\n\nBench, while passing the impugned order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">          We have considered the submissions made on behalf of the respective\n\nparties. Since interpretation of <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 17B</a> of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, is\n\ncentral to the disposal of this appeal, the provisions thereof are extracted below:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">                 \"17B. Payment of full wages to workman pending proceedings\n       in higher courts:-\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">       Where in any case, a Labour Court, Tribunal or National Tribunal by its\n       award directs reinstatement of any workman and the employer prefers\n       any proceedings against such award in a High Court or the Supreme\n       Court, the employer shall be liable to pay such workman, during the\n       pendency of such proceedings in the High Court or the Supreme Court,\n       full wages last drawn by him, inclusive of any maintenance allowance\n       admissible to him under any rule if the workman had not been employed\n       in any establishment during such period and an affidavit by such\n       workman had been filed to that effect in such Court :\n</blockquote>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                            4</span>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\f                  Provided that where it is proved to the satisfaction of the High\n       Court or the Supreme Court that such workman had been employed and\n       had been receiving adequate remuneration during any such period or\n       part thereof, the Court shall order that no wages shall be payable under\n       this section for such period or part, as the case may be.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n         The provisions of <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 17B</a> stipulates that when an Award of\n\nreinstatement of a workman is challenged by the employer before the High Court or\n\nthe Supreme Court and the operation of the same is stayed, the employer shall be\n\nliable to pay the workman, during the period of pendency of such proceedings, full\n\nwages last drawn by him. It also indicates that the same would be subject to the\n\nworkman filing an affidavit to satisfy the Court that he had not been gainfully\n\nemployed during the said period.      The said question has been set at rest by the\n\nlearned Single Judge in favour of the workmen.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">         The invocation of <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 33C(2)</a> of the aforesaid Act is also, in our view,\n\nmisconceived, having regard to the fact that <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 33C(2)</a> stands on a different\n\nfooting from <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 17B</a>. While under <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 17B</a> it is under the orders of the High\n\nCourt or the Supreme Court in a pending proceeding that the full wages last drawn\n\nby the workman, inclusive of any maintenance allowance admissible to him under\n\nany rule, is to be paid, <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 33C(2)</a>, on the other hand, provides for recovery of\n\nmoney due from the employer or any benefit which is capable of being computed in\n\nterms of money. The question of invocation of <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 33C(2)</a> arises only when there\n\nis a dispute as to the quantum of the dues. The two aforesaid provisions contemplate\n\ntwo different situations and in certain cases the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 33C(2)</a> may\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                          5</span>\n\fhave to be resorted to in respect of an order under <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 17B</a>, but not as a matter of\n\ncourse. The necessary details required for giving effect to an order under <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_16\">Section\n\n17B</a> of the 1947 Act are available both with the employer as also the employee and\n\nonly involves a matter of calculation for which no evidence is required to be taken.\n\nFor better appreciation of the matter, the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 33C(2)</a> are\n\nreproduced hereinbelow:\n</p>\n<pre id=\"pre_2\">         \"33C      Recovery of money due from an employer-\n\n                   (1) xxx xxx xxx\n\n                   (2) Where any workman is entitled to receive from the\n</pre><p id=\"p_17\">         employer any money or any benefit which is capable of being computed\n         in terms of money and if any question arises as to the amount of money\n         due or as to the amount at which such benefit should be computed, then\n         the question may, subject to any rules that may be made under this Act,\n         be decided by such Labour Court as may be specified in this behalf by\n         the appropriate Government within a period not exceeding three\n         months.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">                  Provided that where the presiding Officer of a Labour Court\n         considers it necessary or expedient so to do, he may, for reasons to be\n         recorded in writing, extend such period by such further period as he\n         may think fit.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n         Sub-sections (3), (4) and (5) of <a href=\"/doc/592257/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 32</a> of the Act define the procedure to\n\nbe followed for recovery of the dues as computed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">         In contrast, <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_19\">Section 17B</a> provides in unambiguous terms that if an award\n\nfor reinstatement of a workman is stayed at the instance of the employer, either by\n\nthe High Court or the Supreme Court, the employer will be liable to pay to the\n\nworkman during the pendency of the proceedings before the High Court or the\n\nSupreme Court full wages as last drawn by him, including any maintenance\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                           6</span>\n\fallowance admissible to him under any Rule, if the workman had not been gainfully\n\nemployed elsewhere during the said period.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">         On the other hand, <a href=\"/doc/483633/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 33C(2)</a> of the aforesaid Act contemplates a\n\nproceeding requiring evidence to be taken to determine the quantum of the dues\n\npayable to the workman. Taking recourse to such a course of action as a matter of\n\ncourse would destroy and frustrate the very purpose of <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 17B</a> which, as has\n\nbeen consistently held by this Court, is to provide the workman with the means of\n\nsustenance of his family members and himself during the pendency of the\n\nproceedings taken by the employer before the High Court or the Supreme Court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">         Apart from the above, while disposing of the letters patent appeal, the\n\nDivision Bench of the High Court has not also come to a finding which is different\n\nfrom the finding arrived at by the learned Single Judge in this regard.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">         During the course of the hearing of this appeal, Ms.Rohatagi brought to our\n\nnotice an order dated 6th August, 2007 and subsequent amendments made therein by\n\norders dated 31st October, 2007 and 5th March, 2008 passed in Letters Patent Appeal\n\nNo.138/2007, which had been filed against the final disposal of the writ petition. It\n\nhas been submitted by her that since the learned counsel of the appellant Association,\n\nrepresenting the workmen, had agreed that they would be entitled to get the benefits\n\nof the interim order passed by the Division Bench, the present appeal had been\n\nrendered infructuous.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">         We are unable to find any merit in the said submission, having regard to\n\nthe observations made herein-above regarding the effect of <a href=\"/doc/770112/\" id=\"a_22\">Section 17B</a> of the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                           7</span>\n\f<a href=\"/doc/500379/\" id=\"a_23\">Industrial Disputes Act</a> regarding payment of full wages to a workman as last drawn\n\nby him during the pendency of the proceedings either before the High Court or\n\nbefore this Court in which the award of reinstatement is stayed.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">         We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the order          passed by the\n\nDivision Bench of the Bombay High Court and restore that of the learned Single\n\nJudge dated 31st August, 2006. However, we also request the Bombay High Court to\n\ntry and dispose of the pending appeal as early as possible.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                    ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">                                                       (ALTAMAS KABIR)\n\n\n\n                                     ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">                        (CYRIAC JOSEPH)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 28, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                            8</span>\n\f</p>","tid":558739,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":770112,"url":null,"title":"Section 17B in The Industrial Disputes Act,   1947"},{"tid":483633,"url":null,"title":"Section 33C(2) in The Industrial Disputes Act,   1947"},{"tid":500379,"url":null,"title":"The Industrial Disputes Act,   1947"},{"tid":592257,"url":null,"title":"Section 32 in The Industrial Disputes Act,   1947"}]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"co-sharer","formInput":"co-sharer"},{"value":"co- sharers","formInput":"co-%20sharers"},{"value":"who is a proforma defendant","formInput":"who%20is%20a%20proforma%20defendant"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Kartick Chandra Mandal vs Netai Mondal(Dead)By Lrs. & Ors on 6 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33447","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-06","citedbyList":[{"tid":461269,"url":null,"title":"Bhoora And Ors. vs Tara Singh And Anr. on 2 November, 1926"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Kartick Chandra Mandal vs Netai Mondal(Dead)By Lrs. &amp; Ors on 6 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                              REPORTABLE\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CIVIL APPEAL NO. 8            OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP (C) No. 296 of 2006)\n\n\n\nKartick Chandra Mandal                                  ......Appellant\n\n\n                                 Versus\n\n\nNetai Mondal (dead) by Lrs. and Ors.                    ......Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a learned Single Judge\n\nof the Calcutta High Court allowing the Second Appeal filed by the\n\frespondents under Section 100 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (in\n\nshort the `CPC').\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    The appellant as plaintiff filed a suit for declaration of title and\n\nrecovery of khas possession and also of permanent injunction contending\n\ninter-alia that the suit land in R.S. Khatian No.31 of Mouza Chandibera\n\nunder P.S. Rajarhat originally belonged to Ananda Chandra Mondal, Mubir\n\nMondal, Bhutnath Mondal, Gadadhar Mondal, Mathar Mondal, Kartick\n\nMondal, Haradhan Chandra Ghosh and Bishwanath Ghosh. While they were\n\nin joint possession in same for convenience of possession they made an\n\namicable partition amongst themselves and in that partition plaintiff and\n\nproforma defendant No.3 got 12 decimals of land in plot No.223/455 which\n\nwas described in schedule A of the plaint. Subsequently, by an amicable\n\npartition between the plaintiff and proforma defendant No.3, plaintiff got B\n\nschedule property, that is to say, 6 decimals of land at the southern portion\n\nof the aforesaid suit property and proforma defendant No.3 got 6 decimals\n\nof land at the northern portion of the suit plot. In this way, plaintiff got B\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                      2</span>\n\fschedule of land and C schedule of land fell in the share of pro-defendant\n\nno.3. Thereafter, as per the case of the plaintiff by way of an oral exchange,\n\ndefendants 1 and 2 got C schedule property from proforma defendant No.3\n\nand they started residing thereon by constructing house. B schedule of land\n\nwas lying vacant. Plaintiff was in possession of that land by cultivation.\n\nDefendant Nos.1 and 2 threatened the possession of the plaintiff. In that\n\nbackground, the plaintiff filed the suit originally for permanent injunction\n\nagainst defendants 1 and 2. Subsequently, it was contended by the plaintiff\n\nthat defendant Nos.1 and 2 dispossessed the plaintiff from the suit property\n\nand, therefore, the plaintiff prayed for recovery of possession of such\n\nproperty. Defendant Nos.1 and 2 contested the suit by a written statement\n\nalleging inter-alia that the plaintiff was all along since the date of partition\n\nremained separately in his own allotted land and the defendants also were\n\npossessing the land and structure according to their own share on the\n\nportion allotted to them. In this background, they denied the allegation of\n\ndispossession from the suit property made by the plaintiff. It was the further\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                        3</span>\n\fallegation of the contesting defendants that the total land were amicably\n\npartitioned amongst themselves by the intervention of the members of the\n\ngram Panchayat as per the family arrangements. The parties were separated\n\nin respect of the possession of the land in dispute and the contesting\n\ndefendants after getting the plan sanctioned, constructed the building over\n\nthe allotted land. The plaintiff was not entitled to get a decree as prayed for.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.    Learned Munsiff formulated several issues and relied on certified\n\ncopy of the decreed suit. The first Appellate Court has also upheld the view\n\nof the trial Court. The Second Appeal was admitted with the following\n\nquestions of law:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">      (i)    Whether the learned Judge in the courts below\n\n      substantially   erred    in   law   in   completely    misleading,\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_10\">      misconstruing and misappreciating the scope of the suit for\n\n      declaration, injunction and recovery of possession between the\n\n      co-sharers in the absence of any legal and valid partition and\n\n      erroneously decreed the suit on a misconception of law?\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                         4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">\f(ii)    Whether the learned Judge in the courts below\n\nsubstantially erred in law in decreeing the suit by declaring that\n\nthe plaintiff/respondent No.1 has right, title and interest in\n\nrespect of `B' schedule suit property and for recovery of\n\npossession of the said property by evicting the appellants\n\ntherefrom inasmuch as the learned Judge in the courts below\n\nhave failed to appreciate that all the parties to the proceeding\n\nare co-sharers having joint share in the suit property and as\n\nsuch before valid partition neither of the co-sharers could be\n\ndirected to vacate some portion of the joint property?\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">(iii)   Whether the learned Judge in the courts            below\n\nsubstantially erred in law in dismissing the appeal on a\n\nmisconception of law inasmuch as per the provision of Section\n\n14 of the West Bengal Land Reforms Act, 1955 any partition\n\namong the co-sharers other than by a registered instrument or\n\nby a decree or order of a Court is not partition at all and in\n\nabsence of any valid partition among the parties, the\n\nplaintiff/respondent No.1 cannot claim for injunction to prevent\n\nother co-sharers from enjoying joint share in the property.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                 5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">\f5.    The High Court answered question No.3 in favour of the present\n\nrespondents and it held that the partition, if any, did not take place prior to\n\nthe introduction of Section 14 of the West Bengal Land Reforms Act, 1955\n\n(in short the `Act').\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">6.    Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that there was no dispute\n\nregarding the date of partition. In fact, no issue was framed. In the plaint\n\nthere was a specific assertion with reference to the R.S.R.O.R. which\n\nundisputedly is of the year 1955. Though the defendants filed written\n\nstatement there was no challenge to the authenticity of the R.S.R.O.R.\n\nThough the High Court noted that there was an admission strangely it came\n\nto hold that the admission was as regards the point of law and, therefore,\n\ndecided the appeal in favour of the respondents.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">7.    Learned counsel for the respondents, on the other hand, supported the\n\njudgment of the High Court and submitted that though it appeared that there\n\nwas no specific issue relating to the date of partition there was denial as\n\nregards the factum of partition as claimed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                       6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">\f8.    The High Court noted that the section came into force in West Bengal\n\nw.e.f. 7.6.1965 except in the areas transferred from Bihar to West Bengal.\n\nTherefore, after the introduction of the aforesaid provision the partition of a\n\nholding can be effective only by registered instrument or by decree or order\n\nof a Court. There is no dispute so far as this aspect is concerned. As rightly\n\ncontended by learned counsel for the appellant there was specific averments\n\nin the plaint as regards the partition which refers to R.S.R.O.R. Though,\n\nthere was no date of partition indicated, a reference was made to the\n\naforesaid document. The High Court after having noted that none of the\n\nparties made any endeavour to ascertain when the actual alleged partition\n\ntook place came to an abrupt conclusion that from the facts and\n\ncircumstances it was clear that the partition, if any, did not take place prior\n\nto the introduction of Section 14 of the Act.
