The basis for coming to such a\n\nconclusion is not clear. Further, the conclusion of the High Court that\n\nthough there may have been admission that related to the question of law is\n\nequally unsustainable. What is the date of partition is not a question of law.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">9.    In the circumstances, we set aside the impugned judgment of the High\n\nCourt and remit the matter to the trial Court to formulate the following\n\nissues:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                       7</span>\n\f             What is the date of alleged partition between the plaintiff\n\n      and original defendant No.3;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">             The parties shall be permitted to place evidence in\n\n      support of their respective stand.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">10.   The trial Court shall hear the suit afresh on the aforesaid issue alone\n\nand decide the same in accordance with law. Since the matter is pending\n\nsince long, we request the trial Court to dispose of the matter by the end of\n\nMay, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">11.   The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">                                       ................................................J.\n                                       (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                       ................................................J.\n                                       (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 6, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\"> Raveendran, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                1\n\n\n                                                              REPORTABLE\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 174 OF 2009\n              (Arising out of SLP [Criminal] No.3173 of 2006)\n\n\n\nSurendra Kumar Bhatia                                      ... Appellant\n\nVs.\n\nKanhaiya Lal &amp; Ors.                                        ... Respondents\n\n[With Crl.A. No. 175/2009 [@ SLP [Crl.] No.6213/2006]\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">R.V.RAVEENDRAN, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">      Leave granted. Heard counsel.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    These appeals by special leave are preferred against the order dated\n\n24.2.2006 passed by the Rajasthan High Court, allowing a petition filed by\n\nrespondents 1 and 2 herein, under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_1\">section 482</a> of the Code of Criminal\n\nProcedure (`the Code' for short) and quashing FIR No.241 of 2005\n\nregistered at Jyoti Nagar Police Station, Jaipur, in so far as respondents 1 to\n\n3 herein.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                      2</span><p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    One Chauthmal is said to have entered into an agreement of sale\n\ndated 11.8.1980 followed by an agreement dated 24.11.1988 agreeing to sell\n\n20 bighas of land in Khasra No.9 in Sukhalpura village to Shiva Co-\n\noperative Housing Society Ltd. (for short `Society'). The said agreement is\n\nsaid to have confirmed (i) that payment of the entire price of 20 bighas of\n\nland was made by the society to Chauthmal; (ii) that possession of the land\n\nagreed to be sold was delivered to the society; and (iii) that out of 20 bighas\n\nagreed to be sold, 5 bighas of land stood in the name of other persons and\n\nChauthmal would ensure that an agreement was executed by them also in\n\nfavour of the society in regard to that extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4.    Some lands in Sukhalpura village, including 31 bighas in Khasra\n\nNo.9, were acquired for a housing scheme floated by Rajasthan Housing\n\nBoard (for short, `the Board') under preliminary notification dated 5.4.1985\n\nand final notification dated 16.10.1985 issued under the <a href=\"/doc/7832/\" id=\"a_2\">Land Acquisition\n\nAct</a>, 1894 (`Act' for short). Khasra No.9 was shown as `Sivaya Chak'\n\n(government land) in the said notification and possession thereof was\n\ndelivered to the Housing Board on 13.6.1988.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                     3</span><p id=\"p_10\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.    Chauthmal is said to have filed a revenue suit for a declaration that\n\nKhasra No.9 was not government land and that he was one of the owners of\n\nthe said land and for consequential reliefs. The said suit was decreed on\n\n10.9.1986, and was affirmed by the Revenue Board, Ajmer. In pursuance of\n\nit, the following five persons were shown as owners of Khasra No.9 in the\n\nrevenue records, their share being shown in brackets : Chauthmal (15/33),\n\nMohanlal (2/33), Geeta Devi (2/33), Kaushaliya Devi (1/33) and\n\nKanhaiyalal (13/33).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">6.    The State Government formulated a scheme enabling the land owners\n\nto opt for allotment of developed land equal to 15% of acquired land in lieu\n\nof the compensation for the acquired land. The cases where the land\n\nowners opt for such allotment, were to be considered by an Allotment\n\nCommittee, to decide upon the requests after due inquiry into title and after\n\nascertaining that there were no claims or court-cases.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">7.    The land owners/power of Attorney holders of Khasra No.9\n\napproached the Board for such allotment. One Kailash Chand who claimed\n\nto be the successor (legatee) of Chauthmal was one of them and he claimed\n\nallotment of developed land in lieu of 15 bighas of acquired land. The\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                    4</span>\n\n\nsociety also appears to have filed an application before the Board on\n\n21.12.2001 claiming compensation in respect of 20 bighas in Khasra No.9\n\non the basis of the agreement of sale. The claim of the society was rejected\n\non 8.7.2002.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">8.    On 17.7.2002 the power of attorney holders of four owners of Khasra\n\nNo.9 (Kailash Chand, Mohanlal, Geeta Devi and Kanhaiyalal) entered into\n\nseparate agreements with the Housing Board, consenting for allotment of\n\ndeveloped land (15% of the extent of the acquired land) in lieu of\n\ncompensation.     In the said agreements, the land owners asserted and\n\ndeclared that their respective shares in the land were not subject to any\n\nencumbrance and no dispute or litigation was pending in regard to the same.\n\nAfter an inquiry, the Allotment Committee accepted the request and a\n\nsettlement award dated 22.7.2002 was passed by the Special Officer of\n\nRajasthan Housing Board recording the agreement to allot 15% developed\n\nland in lieu of compensation in respect of 28 bighas 17 Biswas in Khasra\n\nNo.9 (as the remaining 2 bighas 3 Biswas out of 31 bighas notified, was\n\nfound to be under encroachment). Pattas were issued subsequently in regard\n\nto such allotted land.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                     5</span><p id=\"p_17\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">9.    Thereafter, the members of the society filed a complaint before the\n\nBoard claiming that the society ought to have received the said 15%\n\ndeveloped land in lieu of compensation relating to the 20 bighas of acquired\n\nland. Some members of the society, through a forum known as Mithila\n\nNagar Suraksha &amp; Vikas Samiti also made a representation to the Chief\n\nMinister on 17.10.2005 alleging that the Khatedars/power of attorney\n\nholders of Khasra No.9 in collusion with the Special Officer had practiced\n\nfraud and grabbed the valuable land from the Rajasthan Housing Board. The\n\nChief Minister's office appears to have suggested action on such\n\nrepresentation. In pursuance of it, the appellant on behalf of the Board\n\nlodged an FIR on 7.11.2005 (at about 9.20 p.m.), alleging that the\n\nKhatedars/Power of Attorney holders of Khasra No. 9 had made false\n\nrepresentations to the Board, and in collusion with the Special Officer of the\n\nBoard and office bearers of the society, had fraudulently obtained allotment\n\npattas in the year 2002.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">10.   First respondent herein who claimed to be the owner of 13 bighas in\n\nKhasra No.9 and respondent No. 2 herein who was his attorney holder, filed\n\na petition under <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_3\">section 482</a> of the Code for quashing the FIR on the ground\n\nthat the averments made in the FIR did not make out a prima facie case\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                     6</span>\n\n\nagainst them, even if the allegations in the FIR was taken to be true. The\n\nHigh Court by the impugned order dated 24.2.2006 allowed the said petition\n\nand quashed the FIR insofar as respondents 1 and 2 as also the Special\n\nOfficer of the Board on the following two grounds :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">(i)    The Land Acquisition Officer, when passing an award under <a href=\"/doc/26767651/\" id=\"a_4\">Section\n11(2)</a> of the Act functions as a \"Judge\" as defined in <a href=\"/doc/1807029/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 19</a> of the\nIndian Penal Code (`<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_6\">IPC</a>' for short) and therefore, is entitled to the\nprotection of <a href=\"/doc/306489/\" id=\"a_7\">section 77</a> IPC. Therefore making a settlement award by the\nSpecial Officer of the Board granting developed land in lieu of\ncompensation to the land owners could not, under any circumstances, give\nrise to an offence under the penal Code.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">(ii)   The allegations in the FIR did not constitute an offence of cheating or\nforgery punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1436241/\" id=\"a_8\">Sections 420</a>,<a href=\"/doc/1985627/\" id=\"a_9\">467</a>,<a href=\"/doc/556166/\" id=\"a_10\">468</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1466184/\" id=\"a_11\">471</a> of IPC.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">11.    The said order of the High Court is challenged in these two appeals\n\nby special leave. The first is filed by the complainant namely the Deputy\n\nHousing Commissioner of Rajasthan Housing Board. The second is filed by\n\n`Mithila Nagar Nyay Manch' claiming to represent the members of the\n\nsociety. On the contentions urged, two questions arise for consideration:-\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                     7</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">(i)    Whether the immunity under <a href=\"/doc/306489/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 77</a> IPC is available to a\nCollector/Land Acquisition Officer/Special Officer who makes an award, by\nway of settlement or otherwise, under the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/7832/\" id=\"a_13\">Land Acquisition\nAct</a>, 1894.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">(ii)   Whether the allegations in the FIR did not constitute an offence under\n<a href=\"/doc/1436241/\" id=\"a_14\">sections 420</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1985627/\" id=\"a_15\">467</a>,<a href=\"/doc/556166/\" id=\"a_16\">468</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1466184/\" id=\"a_17\">471</a> of IPC.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\nRe : Question No.(i)\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">12.    <a href=\"/doc/306489/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 77</a> IPC provides that nothing is an offence which is done by a\n\nJudge when acting judicially in the exercise of any power which is, or which\n\nin good faith he believes to be, given to him by law. <a href=\"/doc/1807029/\" id=\"a_19\">Section 19</a> IPC defines\n\na `Judge' as denoting not only every person who is officially designated as a\n\nJudge, but also every person who is empowered by law to give in any legal\n\nproceedings, civil or criminal, a definitive judgment, or a judgment which, if\n\nnot appealed against, would be definitive, or a judgment which, if confirmed\n\nby some other authority, would be definitive, or who is one of a body of\n\npersons empowered by law to give such a judgment.            The question is\n\nwhether the Collector (or any officer appointed by the appropriate\n\ngovernment or other acquiring authority) performing functions assigned\n\nunder the <a href=\"/doc/7832/\" id=\"a_20\">Land Acquisition Act</a>, can be said to be a `Judge' as defined in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                    8</span>\n\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1807029/\" id=\"a_21\">section 19</a> IPC, that is, a person empowered by law to give a definitive\n\njudgment in a legal proceeding and acting judicially in the exercise of such\n\npower.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">13.   The findings of the High Court that a Collector/Land Acquisition\n\nOfficer making an award under <a href=\"/doc/26767651/\" id=\"a_22\">Section 11(2)</a> of the Act is entitled to the\n\nimmunity of a Judge under <a href=\"/doc/306489/\" id=\"a_23\">section 77</a> IPC, is based on the following\n\nreasoning :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\"Once an agreed award is passed by the competent authority and that award\nacquires the status of an executable decree under the law, the evidence\nwhich came before the competent authority on the basis of which such\naward is passed, cannot be subjected to investigation by the police\nauthorities.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n\nThe respondents also supported the said finding by referring to the various\n\nprovisions of the Act relating to the powers exercised by the Collector\n\n(which term includes not only the Collector of a District or Deputy\n\nCommissioner, but any officer specially appointed by the appropriate\n\nGovernment to perform the functions of a Collector under the Act). <a href=\"/doc/1990166/\" id=\"a_24\">Section\n\n9</a> requires the Collector to cause public notice to be given stating that the\n\nGovernment intends to take possession of land in pursuance of the\n\nacquisition and that claims to compensation for all interests in such land\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                     9</span>\n\n\nmay be made to him. <a href=\"/doc/742973/\" id=\"a_25\">Section 10</a> empowers the Collector to require any\n\nsuch person to make a statement containing the names of persons possessing\n\nany interest in the land and of the nature of such interest etc. <a href=\"/doc/291273/\" id=\"a_26\">Section 11</a>\n\nauthorizes and requires the Collector to hold an enquiry and make an award\n\nin regard to the true area of land, the compensation which, in his opinion\n\nshould be allowed for the land, and the apportionment of the compensation\n\namong all the persons interested in the land. It also provides that no award\n\nshall be made by the Collector without the previous approval of the\n\nappropriate Government or officer authorized by it. <a href=\"/doc/948147/\" id=\"a_27\">Section 12</a> provides\n\nthat the award so made shall be final and conclusive evidence as between\n\nthe Collector and the person interested, of the true area and value of the land\n\nand the apportionment of the compensation among the persons interested.\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1857501/\" id=\"a_28\">Section 13</a> empowers the Collector to adjourn the inquiry from time to time\n\nfor any cause he deems fit. <a href=\"/doc/196014452/\" id=\"a_29\">Section 13A</a> empowers the Collector to correct\n\nany clerical or arithmetical mistakes in the award within six months.\n\n<a href=\"/doc/475622/\" id=\"a_30\">Section 14</a> empowers the Collector for the purpose of enquiries under the\n\nAct, to summon and enforce the attendance of witnesses, including the\n\nparties interested or any of them and to compel the production of documents\n\nby the same means and so far as may be in the same manner, as is provided\n\nin the case of a Civil Court only or of Civil procedure Code. <a href=\"/doc/1235658/\" id=\"a_31\">Section 15</a>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                    <a href=\"/doc/742973/\" id=\"a_32\">10</a></span>\n\n\nrequires the Collector to be guided by the provisions contained in <a href=\"/doc/31609/\" id=\"a_33\">Section\n\n23</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1485112/\" id=\"a_34\">24</a> of the Act in determining the amount of compensation. Having\n\nregard to the said provisions, it was contended that the powers and functions\n\nexercised by the Collector under the Act were judicial powers of a Civil\n\nCourt in rendering definitive judgments and therefore a Collector making an\n\naward, determining the compensation is a Judge as defined in <a href=\"/doc/1807029/\" id=\"a_35\">section 19</a>\n\nIPC.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">14.    On the other hand, the appellant contended that the Land Acquisition\n\nOfficer merely makes an offer on behalf of the Government/Acquiring\n\nAuthority and does not discharge any judicial functions. It was also\n\nsubmitted that the award made by the Collector does not bind the claimants,\n\nas they have the choice of not accepting the award and requiring the\n\nCollector to refer the matter to the Civil Court for determination of the\n\ncompensation. The appellants pointed out that while <a href=\"/doc/634137/\" id=\"a_36\">Section 26</a> the Act\n\nspecifically provided that the award by the `Judge' (Reference Court) shall\n\nbe deemed to be a decree and the statement of the grounds of such award, a\n\njudgment, <a href=\"/doc/291273/\" id=\"a_37\">section 11</a> contains no such provision in regard to the awards by\n\nCollector.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                     11</span><p id=\"p_37\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">15.   The question whether the Collector/Land Acquisition Officer while\n\nmaking an enquiry and award under the Act, acts in a judicial capacity or\n\nnot, has been considered in a series of judgments. The well settled\n\nprinciples are :\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_39\">\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">(a)   Any inquiry as to the market value of property and determination of\nthe amount of compensation by the Collector, is administrative and not\njudicial in nature, even though the Collector may have power to summon\nand enforce the attendance of witnesses and production of documents. In\nmaking an award or making a reference or serving a notice, the Collector\nneither acts in judicial nor quasi judicial capacity but purely in an\nadministrative capacity, exercising statutory powers as an agent and\nrepresentative of the Government/Acquiring Authority.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">(b)   The award by a Collector is merely an offer of the amount mentioned\nas compensation, on behalf of the Government/Acquiring Authority to the\nperson/s interested. It is neither an executable decree, nor binds the owners\nor persons interested in the acquired property.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_42\">\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">(c)   The Collector does not function as a Judicial Officer who is required\nto base his decision only on the material placed in the enquiry in the\npresence of parties, but functions as a valuer who ascertains the market\nvalue on material collected from all sources, personal inspection and his\nown knowledge and experience.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                     12</span><p id=\"p_44\">\n\n\n(See the decision of the Privy Council in Ezra vs. Secretary State -1905 (32)\n\nIndian Appeals 93, the decision of the Patna High Court in Gokul Krishna\n\nBanerji vs. Secretary of State - AIR 1932 Pat. 134 and the decisions of this\n\nCourt in <a href=\"/doc/214713/\" id=\"a_38\">Raja Harish Chandra Raj Singh vs. The Dy. Land Acquisition\n\nOfficer</a> - 1962 (1) SCR 676; <a href=\"/doc/1637345/\" id=\"a_39\">M/s. Boman Behram v. State of Mysore</a> - 1974\n\n(2) SCC 316; <a href=\"/doc/746895/\" id=\"a_40\">Mrs. Khorshed Shapoor Chenai vs. Controller of Estate Duty</a>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">- 1980 (2) SCC 1; <a href=\"/doc/190283669/\" id=\"a_41\">Sharda Devi v. State Government of Bihar</a> - 2003 (3)\n\nSCC 128, and <a href=\"/doc/1866334/\" id=\"a_42\">Kiran Tandon v. Allahabad Development Authority</a> - 2004\n\n(10) SCC 745).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_46\">\n</p><p id=\"p_47\">16.   Only Judges (as defined in <a href=\"/doc/1807029/\" id=\"a_43\">section 19</a> IPC) acting judicially are\n\nentitled to the protection under <a href=\"/doc/306489/\" id=\"a_44\">Section 77</a> IPC. The Collector is neither a\n\nJudge as defined under <a href=\"/doc/1166255/\" id=\"a_45\">Section 19</a> nor does he act judicially, when\n\ndischarging any of the functions under the Act. Therefore he is not entitled\n\nto the protection under <a href=\"/doc/306489/\" id=\"a_46\">Section 77</a> IPC. The decision of the High Court that\n\nthe FIR is to be quashed as the subject matter of the complaint related to the\n\naction taken by the Collector/Special Officer in his capacity as a `Judge' is\n\nopposed to law and therefore, liable to be set aside.\n\n\nRe : Question No. (ii)\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                     13</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_48\">17.   The complaint by the members of the society was in regard to the 20\n\nbighas of land out of Khasra No. 9 in regard to which late Chauthmal is\n\nalleged to have agreed to sell to the society under agreements dated\n\n11.8.1980 and 24.11.1988. The members of the society gave a complaint to\n\nthe Board claiming that the compensation payable (or 15% developed land\n\nin lieu of compensation) in respect of the said 20 bighas of land, had to be\n\ngiven to the society and not persons claiming to be legal heirs of\n\nChauthmal. It was also their contention that on account of collusion among\n\nthe successor of Chauthmal and his attorney holder, the Special Officer of\n\nthe Board, and the office bearers of the society, the 15% developed land was\n\nallotted to persons who were not entitled to allotment, thereby defrauding\n\nthe society and the Board. The respondents 1 and 2 approached the High\n\nCourt pointing out that neither the society nor the members of the society, at\n\nany point of time had made any claim in regard to the 13 bighas in Khasra\n\nNo.9, which belonged to first respondent, that the entire complaint related\n\nto 20 bighas agreed to be sold by Chauthmal to the society, and that as there\n\nwas no complaint of irregularity or commission of any offence in regard to\n\nthe 13 bighas of land belonging to the first respondent, there was no\n\nquestion of involvement of first respondent or his attorney holder (second\n\nrespondent) in any offence of cheating or forgery. It is not in dispute that\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                     14</span>\n\n\neven the suit filed by the society, that was said to be pending at the relevant\n\ntime was against Chauthmal in regard to the 20 bighas in Khasra No.9 and\n\nthat no suit or proceeding was pending in regard to the remaining 13 bighas\n\nclaimed by the first respondent. Only in January, 2003, second respondent\n\nand some others were impleaded in the said suit relating to 20 bighas, in\n\npursuance of an application filed on 14.11.2002, long after respondents 1\n\nand 2 had executed the agreement and consent award had been made. The\n\nHigh Court, therefore, rightly held that the allegations in the FIR, even if\n\naccepted as true, did not relate to the respondents 1 and 2 but to others who\n\nhad claimed to be the owners/attorney holders in regard to remaining 20\n\nbighas of land.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_49\">\n</p><p id=\"p_50\">18.   Having regard to the well settled principles laid down in <a href=\"/doc/1033637/\" id=\"a_47\">State of\n\nHaryana v. Bhajan Lal</a> - 1992 Suppl. (1) SCC 335; <a href=\"/doc/39679/\" id=\"a_48\">Indian Oil Corporation\n\nv. NEPC India Ltd</a>. - 2006 (6) SCC 736; <a href=\"/doc/855018/\" id=\"a_49\">Inder Mohan Goswami v. State of\n\nUttaranchal</a> - 2007 (12) SCC 1, we are of the view that the High Court was\n\njustified in holding that the allegations even if taken at their face value did\n\nnot prima facie constitute an offence under <a href=\"/doc/1436241/\" id=\"a_50\">sections 420</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1985627/\" id=\"a_51\">467</a>, <a href=\"/doc/556166/\" id=\"a_52\">468</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1466184/\" id=\"a_53\">471</a>\n\nIPC, by respondents 1 and 2.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_51\">\n</p><p id=\"p_52\">19.   The leaned counsel for the appellants next submitted that even if the\n\nquashing of the FIR qua respondents 1 and 2 was upheld, the quashing of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">\f                                    15</span>\n\n\nthe FIR against the Special Officer of the Board was unwarranted. While\n\nrespondents 1 and 2 were concerned only with 13 bighas which was not the\n\nsubject matter of the agreement with the society, the FIR specifically\n\nalleged collusion between Kailash Chand and the Special Officer of the\n\nBoard, in regard to 20 bighas of land which was agreed to be sold to the\n\nsociety by Chauthmal. In fact the writ petition filed by Kailash Chand for\n\nquashing the FIR was rejected by the High Court. (Civil W.P.\n\nNo.9293/2005 decided on 23.11.2005). As the finding of the High Court\n\nthat the Collector/Special Officer was a Judge has been set aside, the\n\nquashing of the FIR with reference to the Special Officer, cannot be upheld.\n\nTo this extent, the contention of the appellants merits acceptance and the\n\nquashing of the FIR with reference to the then Special Officer is set aside.\n\nThe quashing of FIR as against respondents 1 and 2 will have no bearing on\n\nthe FIR in so far as the other accused with reference to the 20 bighas of\n\nland. Nor anything stated above shall be construed as a finding on the\n\nmerits.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_53\">\n</p><p id=\"p_54\">20.   The appeals are accordingly allowed in part to the extent mentioned\n\nabove.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_55\">.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_56\">                                                  ............................J.</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\n                                                  (R V Raveendran)\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">\f                    16</span>\n\n\n\n\nNew Delhi;               ............................J.\nJanuary 30, 2009.        (J M Panchal)\n\f</pre>"}, {"numcites":16,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"juvenile","formInput":"juvenile"},{"value":"juvenile act","formInput":"juvenile%20act"},{"value":"arnit das","formInput":"arnit%20das"},{"value":"juvenile delinquents ","formInput":"juvenile%20delinquents%20"},{"value":"juvenile justice","formInput":"juvenile%20justice"},{"value":"domicile","formInput":"domicile"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1648433,"url":null,"title":"Section 20 in The Children Act,   1960"},{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":153138729,"url":null,"title":"Section 3 in The Indian Majority Act,   1875"},{"tid":147254410,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=30900","title":"Pratap Singh vs State Of Jharkhand & Anr on 2 February, 2005"}],"covers":[],"title":"Eerati Laxman vs State Of A.P on 23 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-23","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":64569769,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=36030","title":"D. Vivekanandan vs 2 The Madras High Court on 21 March, 2012"},{"tid":180678110,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_kerala/qrydisp.aspx?filename=372195","title":"Ramalingam.M. vs Life Insurance Corporation Of ..."}],"tid":1538378,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"s","lastname":"sinha","numcitedby":2,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33583","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Eerati Laxman vs State Of A.P on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: S Sinha</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n\n                   IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 139 OF 2009\n                 (Arising out of SLP (CRL.) No. 2135 of 2007)\n\n\nEERATI LAXMAN                                        ... APPELLANT\n\n                                   Versus\n\nSTATE OF A.P.                                        ... RESPONDENT\n\n\n\n\n                              JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">S.B. Sinha, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Appellant was convicted for commission of an offence punishable\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 302</a> of the Indian Penal Code. He was sentenced to undergo\n\nimprisonment for life. Allegations against him were that on or about\n\n9.5.1994 at about 1.00 p.m. he committed murder of one Pittala\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                    2</span>\n\nChandrakala by pouring kerosene over her and setting her on fire with a\n\nmatchstick.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    One of the grounds taken by him during trial was that he was a\n\njuvenile within the meaning of the provisions of Juvenile Justice Act, 1986\n\n(for short, \"the said Act\") on the date of commission of offence.\n\nIndisputably, the date of birth of the appellant is 10.5.1978. The question,\n\nhowever, which arises for consideration is as to whether he had completed\n\nthe age of 16 years on 9.5.1994.        During the trial, it appears, such a\n\ncontention was rejected by the learned trial judge opining that he was not a\n\njuvenile as no reliance could be placed on the date of his birth recorded in\n\nthe registers of the primary school.      A revision application was filed\n\nthereagainst before the High Court. By reason of a judgment and order\n\ndated 26.7.2000, the matter was remanded back to the trial court. Relying\n\non or on the basis of a decision of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/161448/\" id=\"a_2\">Arnit Das vs. State of Bihar</a>\n\n[(2000) 5 SCC 488], it was held that the date of production of the appellant\n\nbefore the learned Magistrate being 25.5.1994 and assuming that the date of\n\nbirth of the accused was 10.5.1978, he was not a juvenile within the\n\nmeaning of the provisions of the said Act.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                             3</span><p id=\"p_8\">\n\nThe learned Sessions Judge, held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">      \"The learned Advocate feebly contended that the\n      accused should be treated as a juvenile on the date\n      of offence as per the decision reported in 2000\n      Supreme Court (Crl) 1270, ALT 2002 AP 511\n      page, ALT 2002 AP 485, SCC 2000 Vol. II page\n      1270 and AIR 1972, SC 1557. With due respect to\n      all the above decisions, I express my inability to\n      accept the contention of the learned advocates for\n      the accused. As already stated by me earlier the\n      accused in this case has preferred Criminal\n      Revision Case No. 418 of 2000 before the Hon'ble\n      High Court of Andhra Pradesh aggrieved by the\n      earlier order of this Court refusing to accept him\n      as a juvenile. In the order dated 26.7.2000, the\n      Hon'ble High Court of Andhra Pradesh has\n      specifically directed this Court to follow the\n      decision reported in Arnit Das Vs. State of Bihar\n      2000 (4) Supreme 186. Therefore, I am bound by\n      the order of the Hon'ble High Court and I cannot\n      take a divergent view. I therefore, find that there\n      is no force in the argument advanced by the\n      learned counsel for the accused in this behalf. I\n      accept the contention of the learned Public\n      Prosecutor that the accused was not a juvenile on\n      the date when he was brought before the Court. On\n      an analysis of the entire evidence on record, I hold\n      that the prosecution has successfully driven home\n      the guilt of the accused under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a> IPC\n      beyond the reasonable doubt.\"\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                    4</span>\n\n<p id=\"p_10\">4.    An appeal preferred by appellant thereagainst has been dismissed by\n\nreason of the impugned judgment, holding:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">            \"We do not agree with such a statement in view of\n            the fact that a year is completed on 9.5.1994, if the\n            date of birth of a person is 10th May of any of the\n            preceding year, because in the case of reckoning\n            of a calendar year which starts with 1st January of\n            a particular year, a year is not completed on first\n            January of the next year but is completed on 31st\n            December, of the same year. So, by 10th May,\n            1994, the accused would start 17th year of his life\n            and on 9th May, 1995, it shall be presumed that he\n            completed 16 years of his life, if his date of birth is\n            10.5.1978.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">            Under <a href=\"/doc/174566148/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 3(35)</a> of the General Clauses Act,\n            1897 (for short \"the Act\"), \"Month\" shall mean a\n            month reckoned according to the British Calendar.\n            \"Year\" as defined under <a href=\"/doc/174566148/\" id=\"a_5\">section 3(66)</a> of the Act\n            shall mean a \"Year\" reckoned according to the\n            British Calendar.     The Halsbury's Laws of\n            England in Paragraph 143, Volume No. 37 (Third\n            Edition), described \"Month\" as under:-\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">                  `When the period prescribed is a\n                  calendar month running from any\n                  arbitrary date the period expires with\n                  the day in the succeeding month\n                  immediately preceding the day\n                  corresponding to the date upon which\n                  the period starts; save that, if the\n                  period starts as the end of a calendar\n                  month which contains more days than\n                  the next succeeding month the period\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                     5</span>\n\n                   expires at the end of the latter\n                   month.'\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">5.    Indisputably, Arnit Das (supra) has been overruled by a Constitution\n\nBench of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/147254410/\" id=\"a_6\">Pratap Singh vs. State of Jharkhand</a> [(2005) 3 SCC\n\n551] wherein it was clearly laid down that the date on which the offence had\n\nbeen committed and not the date when the accused was first produced\n\nbefore the court/competent authority would be the relevant date for the\n\npurpose of ascertaining as to whether the accused before it was a juvenile\n\nwithin the meaning of the provisions of the said Act or not. In Pratap Singh\n\n(supra) this Court in regard to Arnit Das (supra) stated:\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">             \"84. With great respect, we cannot agree to the\n             said statement of law. It is incorrect to say that the\n             preamble speaks of the things of post-delinquency\n             only. <a href=\"/doc/905940/\" id=\"a_7\">The Act</a> not only refers to the obligations of\n             the country to re-enact the existing law relating to\n             juveniles bearing in mind, the standards prescribed\n             in various conventions but also all other\n             international instruments. It states that the said Act\n             was enacted inter alia to consolidate and amend\n             the law relating to juveniles. Once the law relates\n             to delinquent juveniles or juveniles in conflict\n             with law, the same would mean both pre-and post-\n             delinquency.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">             85. The definition of \"juvenile\" under the 1986\n             Act, of course refers to a person who has been\n             found to have committed offence but the same has\n             been clarified in the 2000 Act. The provisions of\n             the 1986 Act, as noticed hereinbefore, sought to\n             protect not only those juveniles who have been\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                    6</span>\n             found to have committed an offence but also those\n             who had been charged therefor. In terms of\n             <a href=\"/doc/174566148/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 3</a> of the 1986 Act as well as the 2000 Act,\n             when an enquiry has been initiated even if the\n             juvenile has ceased to be so as he has crossed the\n             age of 16 and 18 as the case may be, the same\n             must be continued in respect of such person as if\n             he had continued to be a juvenile. <a href=\"/doc/174566148/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 3</a> of the\n             1986 Act therefore cannot be given effect to if it is\n             held that the same only applied to post-\n             delinquency of the juvenile.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">             86. The field covered by the Act includes a\n             situation leading to juvenile delinquency vis-`-vis\n             commission of an offence. In such an event he is\n             to be provided the post-delinquency care and for\n             the said purpose the date when delinquency took\n             place would be the relevant date. It must,\n             therefore, be held that the relevant date for\n             determining the age of the juvenile would be one\n             on which the offence has been committed and not\n             when he is produced in court.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">{See also <a href=\"/doc/589959/\" id=\"a_10\">Balu @ Bakthvatchalu vs. State of Tamil Nadu</a> [2008 (2) SCALE\n\n419], <a href=\"/doc/1863244/\" id=\"a_11\">Jyoti Prakash Rai @ Jyoti Prakash vs. State of Bihar</a> [2008 (3)\n\nSCALE 348, <a href=\"/doc/1045688/\" id=\"a_12\">Ravinder Singh Gorkhi vs. State of U.P</a>. [(2006) 5 SCC 584],\n\n<a href=\"/doc/226549/\" id=\"a_13\">Vimal Chadha vs. Vikas Choudhary &amp; Anr</a>. [2008 (8) SCALE 608]}\n\n\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_12\">6.    The offence, as noticed hereinbefore, was committed on 9.5.1994. A\n\n\"delinquent juvenile\" in terms of the provisions of the said Act would be a\n\njuvenile who has been found to have committed an offence. In terms of the\n\nprovisions of the said Act, \"juvenile\" means a boy who has not attained the\n\nage of sixteen years or a girl who has not attained the age of eighteen years.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                     7</span>\n\nThe said Act was repealed and replaced by the Juvenile Justice (Care and\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1973522/\" id=\"a_14\">Protection of Children) Act</a>, 2000 (for short, \"the 2000 Act\") in terms\n\nwhereof \"juvenile\" or \"child\" means a person who has not completed\n\neighteenth year of age.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">         <a href=\"/doc/1648433/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 20</a> of the 2000 Act as amended by Act 33 of 2006 reads as\n\nunder:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">              \"20. Special provision in respect of pending\n              cases.- Notwithstanding anything contained in this\n              Act, all proceedings in respect of a juvenile\n              pending in any court in any area on the date on\n              which this Act comes into force in that area, shall\n              be continued in that court as if this Act had not\n              been passed and if the court finds that the juvenile\n              has committed an offence, it shall record such\n              finding and instead of passing any sentence in\n              respect of the juvenile, forward the juvenile to the\n              Board which shall pass orders in respect of that\n              juvenile in accordance with the provisions of this\n              Act as if it had been satisfied on inquiry under this\n              Act that a juvenile has committed the offence.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">                     Provided that the Board may, for any\n              adequate and special reason to be mentioned in the\n              order, review the case and pass appropriate order\n              in the interest of such juvenile.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">                    Explanation.--In     all    pending    cases\n              including trial, revision, appeal or any other\n              criminal proceedings in respect of a juvenile in\n              conflict with law, in any court, the determination\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                      8</span>\n\n             of juvenility of such a juvenile shall be in terms of\n             clause (1) of <a href=\"/doc/625357/\" id=\"a_16\">section 2</a>, even if the juvenile ceases\n             to be so on or before the date of commencement of\n             this Act and the provisions of this Act shall apply\n             as if the said provisions had been in force, for all\n             purposes and at all material times when the alleged\n             offence was committed.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_16\">7.    In our opinion, the High Court is not entirely correct in arriving at the\n\nsaid conclusion. The said Act is a beneficent legislation. It, however,\n\nwould not mean that the principle of literal interpretation thereof should not\n\nbe resorted to.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">8.    <a href=\"/doc/153138729/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 3</a> of the Indian Majority Act, 1875 provides for age of\n\nmajority of persons domiciled in India and the criteria for computation of\n\nage of majority. It reads as under:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_13\">             \"3. Age of majority of persons domiciled in\n             India.-(1) Every person domiciled in India shall\n             attain the age of majority on his completing the\n             age of eighteen years and not before.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_14\">             (2) In computing the age of any person, the day\n             on which he was born is to be included as a whole\n             day and he shall be deemed to have attained\n             majority at the beginning of the eighteenth\n             anniversary of that day.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_20\">\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                    9</span>\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">      <a href=\"/doc/1143213/\" id=\"a_18\">In Prabhu Dayal Sesma vs. State of Rajasthan &amp; Anr</a>. [ (1986) 4 SCC\n\n59], this Court categorically held that in absence of any express provision,\n\nwhile calculating a person's age, the day of his birth must be counted as a\n\nwhole day and any specified age in law is to be computed as having been\n\nattained on the day preceding the anniversary of the birthday. A legal day\n\ncommences at 12 o'clock midnight and continues until the same hour the\n\nfollowing night. [<a href=\"/doc/440118/\" id=\"a_19\">See Salag Ram Sharma v. State of Rajasthan</a>, (2005) 10\n\nSCC 77]\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">9.    Appellant, therefore, having been born on 10.5.1978, the said day was\n\nto be counted as a whole day and, thus, he had not attained the age of 16\n\nyears before 12 o'clock in the midnight of the previous day, i.e. 9.5.1978.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">      This aspect of the matter has recently been considered in <a href=\"/doc/182706/\" id=\"a_20\">Achhaibar\n\nMaurya vs. State of Uttar Pradesh &amp; ors</a>. [(2008) 2 SCC 639], wherein it\n\nwas held:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_15\">             \"14. It is interesting to note, however, that the\n             common law rule stated in Shurey, Re, Savory, LR\n             (1918) 1 Ch 263, in respect of anniversaries has\n             been abrogated by virtue of the Family Law\n             Reform Act, 1969. The effect of the change is that,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                    10</span>\n             in respect of anniversaries falling after 1-1-1970,\n             the time at which a person attains a particular age\n             expressed in years is the commencement of\n             relevant anniversary of the date of his birth. (See\n             Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th Edn., Reissue,\n             p. 209.) We do not have such statute. We have,\n             therefore, to determine the cases on the touchstone\n             of statute operating in the field and in absence\n             thereof by common law principle.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_25\">10.    We, for the reasons stated hereinbefore, are of the opinion that the\n\nimpugned judgment cannot be sustained. It is set aside accordingly and the\n\nmatter is remitted to the Juvenile Justice Board in terms of <a href=\"/doc/1648433/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 20</a> of the\n\nAct.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">11.    The appeal is allowed with the aforementioned direction.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">                                            ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">                                                      [S.B. Sinha]\n\n\n\n                                             ......................................J.\n                                                [Dr. Mukundakam Sharma]\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">January 23, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":12,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"thika","formInput":"thika"},{"value":"tenancy act","formInput":"tenancy%20act"},{"value":"thika tenant","formInput":"thika%20tenant"},{"value":"thika tenancy","formInput":"thika%20tenancy"},{"value":"provisional acceptance","formInput":"provisional%20acceptance"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"thika tenancy act","formInput":"thika%20tenancy%20act"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"condonation","formInput":"condonation"},{"value":"bala ","formInput":"bala%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1272508,"url":null,"title":"Section 5 in The Transfer of Property Act, 1882"},{"tid":1489134,"url":null,"title":"The Registration Act, 1908"},{"tid":106689,"url":null,"title":"Section 13 in The Transfer of Property Act, 1882"},{"tid":1331149,"url":null,"title":"Article 227 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":782097,"url":null,"title":"Section 5 in The Registration Act, 1908"}],"covers":[],"title":"Dwarika Nath Acooli vs Dulal Chandra Bayen & Ors on 6 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-06","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":544079,"url":null,"title":"Sukhadakanta Bhattacharjya vs Jogineekanta Bhattacharjya on 3 May, 1933"}],"tid":478028,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":1,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33446","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Dwarika Nath Acooli vs Dulal Chandra Bayen &amp; Ors on 6 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                               REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 7 OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP (C) No.15559 of 2004)\n\n\n\nDwarika Nath Acooli                                      ...Appellant\n\n                                    Vs.\n\nDulal Chandra Bayen and Ors.                             ...Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nCalcutta High Court allowing the writ petition filed by the respondents.\n\fChallenge in the writ petition was to the judgment and order passed by the\n\nWest Bengal Reforms and Tenancy Tribunal (in short the `Tribunal')\n\nwhereby the earlier writ petition filed by the respondents was dismissed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    Background facts, as projected by appellant, in a nutshell, are as\n\nfollows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      Originally, one Durga Bala Acooli, the predecessor-in-interest of the\n\nappellant was the owner of the premises being 18/1, Ramesh Mitra Road,\n\nKolkatta. In terms of the final decree passed in Suit No.467 of 1970 the\n\nCalcutta High Court, the appellant claimed to have become the absolute\n\nowner of the suit property. The aforesaid Durga Bala Acooli had inducted\n\none Ratan Chandra Byen as monthly tenant in respect of premises i.e. land\n\nwith structures and/or sheds. On 2.11.1981 the Calcutta Thika Tenancy\n\n(Acquisition &amp; <a href=\"/doc/1489134/\" id=\"a_1\">Regulation) Act</a>, 1981 (in short the `Act') came into force.\n\nOn 5.5.1982 in exercise of power conferred by Section 20 of the Act the\n\nState Government framed Calcutta Thika Tenancy (Acquisition &amp;\n\nRegulation) Rules, 1981 (in short the `Rules') which became operative from\n\nthat date and under Rule 3(a) of the Rules, the Thika tenants were directed\n\nto file Return under Form-A before the Thika Controller within 240 days\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                      2</span>\n\ffrom the date of commencement of the Act. However, the Thika Controller\n\nwas given power to extend the time not exceeding six months subject to\n\nfiling of an application for condonation of delay.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">      According to the appellant the tenant was paying rent to the owner of\n\nthe said premises after the death of Durga Bala Acooli in 1969. The\n\nappellant collected rent upto the months of August and September, 1986.\n\nThe last payment was made on 14.3.1987 relating to September 1986.\n\nSeveral writ petitions were filed before the High Court challenging the\n\nvalidity of the Act. By judgment dated 8.7.1987 it was held as follow:\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">            \"Within the scope and ambit of <a href=\"/doc/782097/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 5</a> of the\n      impugned Act only lands comprised in Thika Tenancy within\n      the meaning of Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act, 1949 namely\n      Kutcha structure and/or Pucca structure constructed for\n      residential purpose, with the permission of the Thika Controller\n      under the Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act, 1949 and Khatal land\n      held under a lease shall vest and save as aforesaid no other\n      lands and structure vests under the impugned Act. Sub-sections\n      (2) and (3) of <a href=\"/doc/601175/\" id=\"a_3\">section 8</a> of the impugned Act and rule 5 of the\n      Calcutta Thika Tenancy (Acquisition &amp; Regulation) Rules,\n      1982 are ultra vires to the Constitution.\"\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                     3</span>\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_11\">\f      The appellant through his advocate sent a notice to respondent No.1\n\nunder Section 13(6) of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act, 1956 (in\n\nshort the `Tenancy Act') and <a href=\"/doc/80042/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 106</a> of the Transfer of Property Act,\n\n1882 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/515323/\" id=\"a_5\">TP Act</a>') for terminating the tenancy. Against the\n\njudgment of the High Court an appeal was preferred before this Court. In\n\nCivil Appeal Nos. 3713-3900 of 1987 an order of status quo as on the date\n\nwas directed to be maintained. On 18.2.1988 the respondents replied to the\n\nnotice sent by the appellant's advocate denying that the appellant was not\n\ntheir landlord. Since the tenant failed to hand over the vacant and peaceful\n\npossession a title suit was instituted for recovery of possession, damages\n\nand/or mesne profits and other reliefs which was numbered as Title Suit 68\n\nof 1988. Shri Birendra Chandra Bayen, defendant No.4 in the civil suit\n\nfiled an application under <a href=\"/doc/614006/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 17(2)</a> and Section 2A and 2B of the\n\nTenancy Act before learned Civil Judge, Junior Division 4th Court, Alipore.\n\nThe appellant also filed a petition on 23.7.1988 in connection with the\n\napplication under Section 17(2) of the Tenancy Act denying the allegations.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      According to the appellant Shri Birendra Chandra Bayen by filing a\n\npetition not only admitted on oath that appellant was the landlord of the\n\npremises but also sought for a direction upon the appellant to repair the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                     4</span>\n\fsheds and structures of the premises. Since the deceased after 7 years from\n\nthe date of coming into force of the Act filed Return under Section Form-A\n\nof Rule 3(a) of the Rules before the Thika Controller claiming to be the\n\nThika tenant of the property without notice to the appellant, the controversy\n\nin real sense starts from this point. On 4.10.1989 the Inspector of Regional\n\nOffice of Thika Controller provisionally accepted the Return subject to the\n\nverification of tenancy and without any legal right. Such acceptance was\n\nmade without notice to the appellant and also without disclosing the fact\n\nthat the civil suit was pending between the parties. Such acceptance of rent\n\nwas without prejudice to the right of the Government and without creating\n\nany right of the tenant. After the provisional acceptance of rent, Shri\n\nBirendra Chandra Bayen filed an application in the pending suit that in view\n\nof <a href=\"/doc/1272508/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 5</a> of the Act, the suit is not maintainable. The High Court on\n\nrevision application being C.O.2670/1990 directed that the preliminary\n\npoint raised by the defendant would be decided at the final hearing of the\n\nsuit. When the appellant came to know about the filing of the Return in\n\nForm-A under Rule 3(a) without application for condonation of delay\n\nduring the pendency of the civil suit, he raised an objection by filing an\n\napplication before the Thika Controller against the preliminary acceptance\n\nof rent and prayed for determination under <a href=\"/doc/1272508/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 5</a> of the Act inasmuch as\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                     5</span>\n\fthere was no provision in the Act to prefer an appeal under <a href=\"/doc/106689/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 13</a> of the\n\nAct against the provisional acceptance of the Return. Since the objection\n\nwas not considered for a long time, appellant filed a writ petition before the\n\nCalcutta High Court for a direction to the Thika Controller to decide\n\nwhether the said property has been vested to the State. The High Court\n\ndisposed of the writ petition directing the Thika Controller to dispose of the\n\nrepresentation after giving hearing to the parties. In terms of the aforesaid\n\norder of the Thika Controller he concluded that the property had not been\n\nvested to the State under <a href=\"/doc/1272508/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 5</a> and Shri Birendra Chandra Bayen was\n\nnot the Thikha tenant. The learned Munsif disposed of the application of\n\nlate Birendra Chandra Bayen under Section 17(2) and 2A and 2B of the\n\nTenancy Act determining the relationship between the parties of the suit as\n\nlandlord and tenant under the Tenancy Act. Thus, this application had\n\nbecome final. Against the order dated 8.12.1993 of the Thika Controller,\n\nlegal heirs of Shri Birendra Chandra Bayen preferred a statutory appeal\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/106689/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 13</a> of the Act before learned District Judge who dismissed the\n\nsame holding that the defendants could not produce any document that they\n\nwere Thika tenants and the Controller had jurisdiction to pass an order\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1272508/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 5</a> of the Act. Respondent No.1 filed an application under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1331149/\" id=\"a_13\">Article 227</a> of the Constitution of India, 1950 (in short the `Constitution')\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                      6</span>\n\fchallenging the aforesaid order of the District Judge which was transferred\n\nto the Tribunal. The Tribunal dismissed the appeal holding as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">            (i)     After the statutory period of limitation as provided\n\n            under Rule 3(a) no Return could be filed.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">            (ii)    Further the tenants paid rent to the landlord upto\n\n            1986 accepting the appellant as landlord when the Act of\n\n            1981 came into force on 18.1.1982 and the liability of\n\n            `Thika Tenant to pay rent ceased from that date.\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">            (iii)   Therefore, acceptance of Return under Form-A\n\n            was without jurisdiction and dismissed the application\n\n            holding that the Thika Controller has got jurisdiction to\n\n            decide whether the person is a Thika Tenant or not.\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">            (iv)    The applicant is a tenant in respect of structures,\n\n            he does not own structures therefore he is a premises\n\n            tenant.</blockquote><p id=\"p_13\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      On 1.3.2003 a Notification under Section 1(3) of the West Bengal\n\nThika Tenancy (Acquisition and <a href=\"/doc/1489134/\" id=\"a_14\">Regulation) Act</a>, 2001 (in short the `2001\n\nAct') was published and under <a href=\"/doc/1629541/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 27</a>, the earlier Act of 1981 was\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                       7</span>\n\freplaced but pending proceedings were saved. By the 2001 Act, sub-section\n\n(3) of <a href=\"/doc/1272508/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 5</a> was amended to provide that if any question arises as to\n\nwhether the person is a Thika tenant or not the matter shall be decided by\n\nthe Controller. Respondent No.1 challenged the said order passed by the\n\nTribunal dated 19.9.2002 by filing a writ petition under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_17\">Article 226</a> of the\n\nConstitution on the ground inter-alia that the Thika Controller has no\n\njurisdiction to decide the question whether the respondent was a Thika\n\ntenant or not and only the Civil Court had jurisdiction. On 19.8.2003 the\n\nState of West Bengal withdrew the appeal before this Court. On 23.2.2004\n\na Division Bench of the High Court by an impugned order allowed the writ\n\napplication and set aside the order of Thika Controller, Appellate Tribunal\n\nand the Tribunal holding that the predecessor-in-interest of respondent No.1\n\nwas accepted as Thika tenant. Against the adjudication under <a href=\"/doc/1272508/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 5(3)</a>\n\nof the Act, no appeal was preferred and as such the application of the\n\nappellant for cancelling the recording of Thika tenancy is not maintainable\n\nand there is no provision in the Act empowering the Thika Controller to\n\nentertain such application after declaration of the Thika tenant.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">4.    Stand of learned counsel for the appellant essentially is that there was\n\nno question of condonation of delay of an application which was filed after\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                                      8</span>\n\fabout 7 years. The eviction suit was filed on 14.3.1988 and rent was paid till\n\n1986 under the Tenancy Act and thereafter it was stopped. It is pointed out\n\nthat under Section 17 of the Tenancy Act if the application is on the\n\nground of default, an application can be made to make the deposit. The\n\napplication dated 25.4.1988 is still pending. On 4.10.1989 the only\n\nendorsement was of provisional acceptance subject to verification. It was\n\nclearly noted as follows:\n</p>\n<pre id=\"pre_2\">\"By whom paid      Payment made              Amount              Head of Account\n                   On behalf of the                              Account Officer\n                   Person\n\n\nBiren Ch.          Biren Ch.Bayen            Adhoc Rent          .029 Land Revenue\nBayen              40/1 Ramen Mitra          165/- 3869.5/-      Land Revenue/Tgax\n                   Road, Cal-25              Ist Instalment      Collection of Tax\n                                                                 Under the Calcutta\n                                                                 Thika Tenancy\n                                                                 Acquisition and\n                                                                 RegulationAct,1951\n\n\n      Calcutta Collectorate            Acceptance provisionally subject to\n      Treasury Department              1) Verification of tenancy and\n      Counter No.                      2) recovery adjustment with the\n                                      revenue to the Cash received\n                                       finally determined under the <a href=\"/doc/688958/\" id=\"a_19\">W.B.\n                                       Act</a> XXXVII\n                                       Of 1981. Such acceptance of rent shall not treat\n                                       or established and right or interest without\n                                       Which otherwise not legally in existence.\"\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                                      9</span>\n</pre><p id=\"p_16\">\f5.       The representation made by the appellant was on 16.11.1992. It was\n\nhowever unnecessary as there was no order. The High Court inter-alia had\n\ndisposed of earlier writ petition by directing the Controller to consider and\n\ndispose of the representation. The High Court by the impugned judgment\n\nseems to have over-looked the fact that there was in fact no cancellation.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">6.       Learned counsel for the respondent on the other hand supported the\n\norder.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">7.       In the impugned order the High Court seems to have proceeded on the\n\nbasis that there was cancellation. It noted as if the Thika Controller was\n\nmoved for cancelling the order recording the tenancy. As a matter of fact\n\nthere was no cancellation and there was a provisional order. There was no\n\nquestion of preferring an appeal unless the final order is passed. So far as\n\nthe onus is concerned, it is on the appellant to establish the tenancy. It needs\n\nto be noted that on the Return no order was passed. The Thika Controller,\n\nAppellate Authority and the Tribunal came to positive finding that\n\nrespondent No.1 was not a Thika tenant. They took decision on the basis of\n\nthe High Court's order to deal with a representation of the appellant.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                                         10</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">\f8.    In view of the aforesaid we are satisfied that the order of the High\n\nCourt is indefensible. We set aside the impugned order and direct that the\n\nrevenue authority shall decide the relevance of the Return and pendency of\n\nthe eviction suit. As the Return is in terms of Rule 3, the revenue authority\n\nhas to decide the matter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">9.    The appeal is accordingly disposed of with no order as to costs.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                      .........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                      (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                      .........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                      (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 6, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                                                            11</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"transfer petition","formInput":"transfer%20petition"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"firstname":"d","title":"Rajesh vs State Of Rajasthan & Anr on 23 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33547","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-23","citedbyList":[{"tid":376175,"url":null,"title":"State Of Rajasthan vs Fakir Mohd. Alias Fakira on 2 August, 2000"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Rajesh vs State Of Rajasthan &amp; Anr on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: D A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                          REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                 CRIMINAL ORIGINAL JURISDICTION\n\n              TRANSFER PETITION (Crl.) NO. 71 OF 2007\n\n\n\nRajesh                                                     ...Petitioner\n\n                                     Vs.\n\nState of Rajasthan and Anr.                                ...Respondents\n\n\n\n                              JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">DR. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    The petitioner has sought for transfer of Criminal Case FIR No.352\n\ndated 7.12.2005 under Sections 406, 498A read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 34</a> IPC titled\n\nSangeeta v. Rajesh pending in the Court of Judicial Magistrate, First Class,\n\nChittorgarh, to a court of competent jurisdiction in Hissar.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.    This transfer petition was posted before Supreme Court Lok Adalat\n\non 6.12.2008. The parties and their lawyers appeared and filed a joint\n\fpetition stating that their disputes have been settled under the guidelines of\n\nthe mediators who acted as Amicus Curiae.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">3.    The following were the terms of settlement:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">      A.     It is agreed between the parties that Shri Rajesh will pay\n      a sum of Rs.8 lakhs by way of a demand draft to Smt. Sangeeta\n      on or before 30th June, 2009.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      B.     It is further agreed that the articles, as agreed upon by\n      the parties in a separate list, shall be sent by Shri Rajesh to the\n      house of Smt. Sangeeta at Chitorgarh.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">      C.     It is further agreed that the custody of the minor child\n      named Lucky who is now been with Smt. Sangeeta shall\n      remain with her and Shri Rajesh will not claim anything with\n      regard to child's custody from Smt. Sangeeta or her family\n      hereinafter.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">      D.     It has been agreed that the cases filed by both the\n      parties:-\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">             (i)    Criminal Case filed by Smt. Sangeeta under\n             <a href=\"/doc/445276/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 498(A)</a> of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (in\n             short the `Code') against Rajesh at Chittorgarh;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">             (ii) Criminal case filed against Shri Rajesh under\n             <a href=\"/doc/1056396/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 125</a> of the Code at Chittorgarh;\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                      2</span>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">\f             (iii) Petition under <a href=\"/doc/1284729/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 13</a> of Hindu Marriage Act\n             for grant of divorce filed by Shri Rajesh against Smt.\n             Sangeeta pending before the Family Court at\n             Chittorgarh;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">             (iv) Present Transfer Petition No. 71/2007 filed by\n             Shri Rajesh pending before this Court\n\n\n                    shall be withdrawn/settled.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">             It is further agreed that in terms of this settlement arrived\n      at hereinabove a decree for divorce may be passed. No further\n      claim of any kind shall be raised against each other or with\n      regard to the minor child Lucky hereinafter.\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">4.    It is heartening to note that the parties have settled their disputes\n\namicably and have agreed to the aforesaid terms. The transfer petition is\n\ndisposed of in terms of the settlement. The petition incorporating the terms\n\nof settlement shall form a part of the record.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                          ..........................................J.\n                                          (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                          ..........................................J.\n                                          (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 23, 2009\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                      3</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":581879,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1056396,"url":null,"title":"Section 125 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"},{"tid":37788,"url":null,"title":"Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":445276,"url":null,"title":"The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"},{"tid":1284729,"url":null,"title":"Section 13 in The Hindu Marriage Act, 1955"}]}, {"numcites":2,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Jagdish Bagri vs Rajendra Kumar Luhariwala & Anr on 21 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33536","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-21","citedbyList":[{"tid":1994593,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=27292","title":"Radhakrishnan vs Lakshmipathi @ A.L.Pathy on 10 August, 2010"},{"tid":434934,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydisp.aspx?filename=27684","title":"C.Venkatesh vs M/S.Vel Beds on 18 August, 2010"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":2,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Jagdish Bagri vs Rajendra Kumar Luhariwala &amp; Anr on 21 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                            REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n             IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n            CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n          CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.              OF 2009\n          (Arising out of SLP (CRL) No. 154 of 2009)\n\n\n\nJagdish Bagri                                 ....Appellant\n\n                           Versus\n\n\n\nRajendra Kumar Luhariwala and Anr.            ....Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                      JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.   Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">\f2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the order passed by a learned Single\n\nJudge of the Calcutta High Court dismissing the application filed under\n\nSection 401 read with <a href=\"/doc/1679850/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 482</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973\n\n(in short the `Code'). Challenge in the Criminal Revision Petition was to the\n\norder passed in Criminal Appeal No.2 of 2004 by learned Additional\n\nSessions Judge, Asansol confirming the judgment and order of conviction\n\nand sentence dated 22.4.2004 passed by learned Additional Chief Judicial\n\nMagistrate, Asansol.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">3.    Since the appellant did not appear when the matter was called, the\n\nmatter was taken ex-parte. The High Court noted that a sum of\n\nRs.2,30,000/- was payable to the complainant-respondent No.1 herein by\n\nthe present appellant -accused and since the payment was not made there\n\nwas an agreement between the parties to stipulate the mode of payment. A\n\nsum of Rs.2,30,000/- was to be paid in 8 instalments and the first instalment\n\nwas of a sum of Rs.50,000/- payable by 22.6.2002 and the 8th instalment of\n\nRs.10,000/- was payable by 28.2.2003. As a security for the payment, the\n\nappellant issued three cheques. One of the cheques was of Rs.1 lakh and\n\nthat is the subject matter of present controversy. Stand was taken that since\n\nthe cheque was issued as a security, the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/1823824/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 138</a> of the\n\nNegotiable Instruments Act, 1881 (in short the `Act') had no application.\n\nThe High Court noticed that the appellant failed to pay Rs.2,30,000/- in\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\finstalments as agreed to and therefore because of default of payment cheque\n\nof Rupees one lakh was presented. In that sense there is no question of any\n\nsecurity.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that because of\n\nunavoidable difficulties there was no appearance when the matter was\n\ncalled. It was submitted that the matter was suddenly appeared in the list\n\nand due to some unavoidable difficulties, the appellant's advocate could\n\nnot appear at the time of hearing before learned Single Judge.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">5.    Learned counsel for the respondents on the other hand submitted that\n\non two dates the appellant did not appear and, therefore, the Court had no\n\noption but to dismiss the revision petition on merits. It appears from the\n\nrecords that case was filed in 2005 and was listed on 17.3.2008 for the first\n\ntime and on the next day it was dismissed for non prosecution.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">6.    Learned counsel for the appellant highlighted several difficulties\n\nwhich stood on the way of learned counsel for the appellant to appear before\n\nthe Court when the matter was taken up. It is true that the lawyers are\n\nexpected to be vigilant once they accept a brief. But on the peculiar facts of\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fthe case we set aside the impugned order and remit the matter to the High\n\nCourt for a fresh consideration on merits. To avoid unnecessary delay the\n\nparties are directed to appear before the concerned Court on 28.1.2009. The\n\nlearned Chief Justice of the High Court is requested to assign the case to an\n\nappropriate Bench.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">7.    The appeal is disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                        ...........................................J.\n                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                        ..........................................J.\n                                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 21, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                    4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":115417,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1823824,"url":null,"title":"Section 138 in The Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881"},{"tid":1679850,"url":null,"title":"Section 482 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"}]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"demarcation","formInput":"demarcation"},{"value":"commissioners report ","formInput":"commissioners%20report%20"},{"value":"land demarcation dispute: supremecourt","formInput":"land%20demarcation%20dispute%3A%20supremecourt"},{"value":"sirpurkar","formInput":"sirpurkar"},{"value":"land not identified","formInput":"land%20not%20identified"},{"value":"decree in executable","formInput":"decree%20in%20executable"}],"firstname":"v","title":"Abdul Rehman Shora(D) By Lrs. & Ors vs State Of J & K & Anr on 7 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33493","lastname":"sirpurkar","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-07","citedbyList":[{"tid":254999,"url":null,"title":"Dharma Reddy vs State And Anr. on 12 November, 1990"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Abdul Rehman Shora(D) By Lrs. &amp; Ors vs State Of J &amp; K &amp; Anr on 7 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: V Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Markandey Katju, V.S. Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">           0                                  1\n\n                                                          \"REPORTABLE\"\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                    CIVIL APPEAL NO. 25 OF 2009\n              (Arising out of SLP(C) No. 22945 of 2007)\n\n\n\nAbdul Rehman Shora (D)\nby LRs. &amp; Ors.                                           .... Appellants\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\n\nState of J &amp; K &amp; Anr.                                   .... Respondents\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">V.S. SIRPURKAR, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">      Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.    Being aggrieved by the Order passed by the High Court in its\n\nRevisional Jurisdiction and issuing certain directions, appellants have come\n\nup before this Court. The appellants herein are the original plaintiffs and\n\nthe legal representatives of one of the original plaintiffs.    First three\n\nappellants are the original plaintiffs, while the other three are the legal\n\nrepresentatives of one Abdul Salam Shora, who was the original plaintiff\n\nNo. 2.
