During the pendency of this appeal, appellant No. 1 died on\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f0                                   2</span>\n\n28.11.2007. Vide order dated 25.3.2008, his legal representatives were\n\nbrought on record. They filed a suit for perpetual injunction against the\n\nrespondents/defendants, whose defence was that the appellants/plaintiffs\n\nwere encroaching upon the portion of land, which they alleged to have\n\npurchased and which is adjacent to the land in question. The location,\n\nidentification and plaintiffs' title and possession over the suit land was not\n\ncontroverted by the respondents/defendants in their written statement.\n\nTwo issues came to be framed and subsequently two additional issues also\n\ncame to be framed and ultimately, the suit was decreed, after about 14\n\nyears of its filing by the Court of Sub-Judge, Srinagar. Admittedly, this\n\njudgment had become final, since no appeal was filed against this\n\njudgment. However, since the respondents/defendants did not obey the\n\nterms of the decree and did not allow the appellants/plaintiffs to fence the\n\nland, which was in their possession and which was identifiable and\n\nsufficiently delineated in the suit, Execution Application was filed in March,\n\n1987 for issuing directions to the respondents/defendants to comply with\n\nthe terms of decree dated 18.10.1984. An objection came to be raised by\n\nthe Judgment-Debtors before the Executing Court that the decree was un-\n\nexecutable, since the identity of the land in respect of which the decree\n\nwas passed, was itself not established. This objection was upheld by the\n\nExecuting Court by its order dated 21.6.1988.         Against this order, a\n\nRevision Petition was filed by the appellants herein before the High Court\n\nvide Revision No. 153 of 1988. The Revision stood allowed by the High\n\nCourt by its judgment dated 25.8.1998, whereby, the order of the Executing\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f0                                   3</span>\n\nCourt was set aside and the Executing Court was directed to proceed with\n\nthe execution of the decree. The High Court had observed in the judgment\n\nthat the Executing Court had not taken any steps to identify the suit land,\n\nthough the factors like extent and limits of the suit land were available. The\n\nextent of the suit land was 1 canal 12 marlas, which was clearly given in\n\nKhewat and Khasra Numbers, while its location was given as Brari Nambal.\n\nIt was found that no attempt was made by the Executing Court to look out\n\nfor situational and other identifiable features and locale of the land even\n\nfrom the suit file, Revenue records including `Aksilatha'. Therefore, it was\n\nrecommended that a Commissioner should be appointed for local\n\ninvestigation and if required, the oral evidence also could be taken. The\n\nHigh Court further observed that even the site plan coupled with the\n\npermission of Srinagar Municipality to raise the wall accorded to the decree\n\nholders for fencing or walling of the suit land, was not taken into\n\nconsideration and it appeared that the Executing Court had gone by\n\nwhatever had been raised and stated by the Judgment-Debtors alone,\n\nwithout arriving at an independent decision regarding executability of the\n\ndecree, in totality of facts and circumstances of the case.      It was also\n\nobserved by the High Court that a decree cannot be defeated by reason of\n\ntechnical or hyper-technical objection and those unconnected with the\n\nrealities on the ground level.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    After this decision, the respondents/defendants filed an Application-\n\ncum-Reply/Statement, in which it was stated that the appellants/plaintiffs\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f0                                          4</span>\n\nhad grabbed the land of the respondents/defendants and under the garb of\n\nthe   decree,       they    were        trying   to     grab    the   land   of   the\n\nrespondents/defendants, adjacent to the suit land, which land was required\n\nto be protected by the Court. It was, therefore, prayed that the Revenue\n\nAuthorities should be directed to demarcate the land, so that the decree-\n\nholders    are      not    able    to     grab   the     land    belonging   to   the\n\nrespondents/defendants.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.    Much prior to this, Srinagar Municipality had granted permission to\n\nthe appellants/plaintiffs for fencing of the suit land, which was demarcable\n\nand identifiable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5.    However, on this application, three persons were appointed as\n\nCommissioners, two of them were from the Revenue Department and one\n\nwas from the Srinagar Municipality. They visited the spot on 7.12.2004 in\n\npresence of the parties, when the Deputy Director of Estates Department\n\nwas also present on the spot, and after detailed inspection, the decreetal\n\nland measuring 1 canal 12 marlas was found to be in possession of the\n\ndecree holders, i.e., the appellants.                 The decreetal land was also\n\ndemarcated. A site plan was prepared and the report was submitted to the\n\nCourt on 30.12.2004.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">6.    On receipt of this report, the Executing Court gave an opportunity to\n\nthe parties to file their objections to the abovesaid Report. The counsel for\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f0                                      5</span>\n\nthe respondents/defendants appeared before the Court on 16.5.2005 and\n\nhe also had made a Statement that he was satisfied with the Report of the\n\nCommissioners and he accepted the same as correct. Thereafter, various\n\norders were passed by the Executing Court, and the Court went to the\n\nextent   of    issuing     the     coercive     measures,   compelling       the\n\nrespondents/defendants to obey the decree. The first such order dated\n\n14.12.2005 was not even challenged by the respondents in time, while by\n\nthe second passed order dated 27.6.2006, the Director of Estates was\n\ndirected to file an undertaking regarding the acknowledgement of the\n\ndecree and demarcation of land.             It is against these orders dated\n\n14.12.2005 and 27.6.2006 that a Revision Petition came to be filed before\n\nthe High Court, wherein, a totally new case was set up, which had no\n\nconnection    with   the   execution       matter.   Very   significantly,   the\n\nrespondents/defendants had accepted the facts regarding the previous\n\nRevision Petition No. 153 of 1988 decided on 25.8.1998. After filing of the\n\nsaid Revision Petition, the respondents herein requested for placing certain\n\ndocuments on record.             According to the appellants/plaintiffs, the\n\nrespondents/defendants tried to manipulate the record, which could not\n\nhave been considered in the Revision Petition by the High Court. The\n\nappellants/plaintiffs filed objections to the respondents' request of\n\nproduction of documents, in which it was contended that the documents\n\ncan not be produced at the stage of Revision because by doing so, the\n\nwhole case was tried to be reopened, and there was an attempt on the part\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f0                                    6</span>\n\nof the respondents/defendants to adduce fresh evidence, which too was\n\nmanipulated and manufactured.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">7.    However, it seems that the High Court allowed that Application by its\n\norder dated 23.11.2006, even without hearing the appellants. During that\n\ntime, no lawyer used to appear in the Court due to the strike call given by\n\nthe militants in the Valley of Kashmir. The Court went on to allow this\n\napplication, and the appellants filed a detailed Application on 4.12.2006 for\n\nrecalling the order dated 23.11.2006. Ultimately, it seems that the High\n\nCourt passed the final judgment on 7.9.2007, whereby, the High Court\n\ngave a finding in the following words:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"Accordingly, and in view of what has been stated above, I feel\n             that the decreetal land whatever and wherever it is, is yet to be\n             duly identified and demarcated without which the execution\n             proceedings run the risk of being misdirected. So before\n             passing final orders hereupon, I feel it would be proper to seek\n             suggestions of appearing sides regarding mode and method of\n             identifying the decreetal land, so that the decree under\n             reference is properly executed and without any further loss of\n             time.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      The appellants, feeling aggrieved by this, have come up before us.\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_15\">8.    The Learned Counsel appearing on behalf of the appellants pointed\n\nout that there was no question of passing these fresh directions,\n\nparticularly, in the wake of finalized order in the earlier Civil Revision dated\n\n25.8.1998.    Our attention was invited to the said order and more\n\nparticularly, the observations made therein, to which we have already\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f0                                      7</span>\n\nmade reference in the earlier part of the judgment. Even at the cost of\n\nrepetition, we must note that the High Court has clearly observed therein\n\nas follows:-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">               \"What the Executing Court has exactly failed to do is that it has\n               not taken any steps to identify the suit land. The extent and\n               limits of the suit land despite available evidence on record has\n               not been determined. This aspect has not been considered.\n               The extent of suit land (1 canal 12 marlas) is clearly given with\n               Khewat No. and Khasra No. The location of the land is given\n               as Brari Nambal. No attempt has been made by the Executing\n               Court to look out for situational and other identifiable features\n               and locale of the land even from the suit file, revenue records\n               including `Aksilatha' and may be through appointment of\n               Commissioner for local investigation and if required, on an\n               enquiry where oral evidence could have been taken. Even the\n               site plan coupled with permission of Srinagar Municipality to\n               raise the wall accorded to the decree holders for\n               fencing/walling of the suit land has not been taken into\n               consideration. It appears that the Executing Court has gone\n               by whatever has been raised and stated by the respondent-\n               judgment Debtors, without arriving at an independent decision\n               regarding the executability of the decree in the totality of facts\n               and circumstances of the case. The Executing Court appears\n               to have been in a hurry to rush to the conclusion that the\n               decree is un-executable for the ambiguity and vagueness as\n               sighted by the Executing Court.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_16\">The learned counsel pointed out that by these observations, the High Court\n\nhad finally held that the land had been finally identified and that the\n\nExecuting Court was duty bound to execute the decree in respect of such\n\nidentified land, which was clear from the Khewat and Khasra Numbers, as\n\nalso the permission granted by Srinagar Municipality to the appellants to\n\nbuild a wall. Our attention then was invited to the Commissioners' Report,\n\nwherein, as many as two officers of the respondents'/defendants'\n\ndepartment were present, as also the Deputy Director of Estates\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f0                                  8</span>\n\nDepartment. It was pointed out that the Commissioners' Report had finally\n\nclinched the issue by locating the said land. Our attention was invited even\n\nto the sketch map drawn by the Commissioners. It was then pointed out by\n\nthe learned counsel that the order dated 27.6.2006 read with order dated\n\n14.12.2005, passed by the Executing Court, which was impugned before\n\nthe High Court in the Revision, was clear enough, inasmuch as, in the\n\norder dated 14.12.2005, it was clearly mentioned that:-\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">            \"To cope up with the problem, this Court has also vide its order\n            dated 10.7.2004 read with the order dated 16.8.2004 &amp;\n            15.9.2004 got the decreetal land demarcated on 7.12.2004\n            through a commission for local inspection.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">                  The Commission has already submitted its report on\n            31.12.20004, which is on the file. The commission in its report\n            has submitted that the demarcation of the decreetal land was\n            conducted on spot in presence of both the parties on\n            7.12.2004. It has been reported that Deputy Director, Estates\n            (Mr. Farooq Ahmad Lone) was present on behalf of the\n            judgment debtors. It has been unambiguously reported that\n            the decree holder were found the recorded owners, as well as\n            in the physical possession of the decreetal land which was\n            demarcated.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">                  It is most pertinent to mention that the Ld. Standing\n            Counsel for judgment debtors on 16.5.2005 had admitted in\n            the open court that he admits the report of the commission\n            and has no objection vis-`-vis the same.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">                   But, despite the demarcation of the decreetal land, the\n            judgment debtors are persisting in their attempt of interference\n            with the decreetal land by objections on spot the construction\n            of the fencing wall by the decree holder around the decreetal\n            land.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_17\">It was also found in that order that in spite of the demarcation of the\n\ndecreetal land, the Judgment-Debtors were persisting in their attempt of\n\ninterference with the decreetal land by objecting to the construction of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f0                                   9</span>\n\nfencing wall.   In that order, the Executing Court has very specifically\n\nobserved that the objections of the Judgment-Debtors were already stood\n\nrejected by the High Court in its order dated 25.8.1998. Ultimately, the\n\nCourt went up to the extent of observing:-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">            \"As such, the judgment debtor Director Estates, Srinagar\n            against whom the decree is sought to be executed is liable to\n            be committed to civil prison for compelling him to implement\n            the decree. The office is directed to issue bailable warrant of\n            arrest in the amount of rupees thirty thousand for his\n            appearance in person before this Court on 18.1.2006, which\n            shall be entrusted to the S.S.P., Jammu for execution. The\n            warrant shall be accompanied with a copy of this order put up\n            on 18.1.2006.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_18\">On the heels of this order came the order dated 27.6.2006, wherein, the\n\nExecuting Court noted that the Judgment-Debtor was not satisfied with the\n\ndemarcation, which was already conducted in the case during execution\n\nprocess.   It seems that on that day, the Judgment-Debtor was present\n\nbefore the Executing Court, which had issued a non-bailable warrant\n\nagainst him. The Court, then went on to observe that the conduct of the\n\nJudgment-Debtors was contemptuous.           The Court also noted that the\n\nexecution was pending disposal right from 4.3.1987 and that made it a\n\nrarest of the rare case. It seems that these two orders were composedly\n\nchallenged before the High Court in the Revision. The learned counsel,\n\nappearing on behalf of the respondents tried to feebly support the order of\n\nthe High Court. However, one look at the High Court suggests that the\n\nHigh Court has gone on to reopen the whole process. It has undoubtedly,\n\nmade a reference to some documents and on the basis of those\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f0                                    10</span>\n\ndocuments, the Court seems to have observed in para 5 that the land\n\nunder reference was sold by one Mehraj-ud-din S/o Assad              Shah and\n\nGhulam Nabi S/o Ghulam Shah to one Khazir Mohammad S/o Subhan\n\nParey, who sold the same to Government in January, 1969. The Court\n\nfurther observed that the sale of land by aforesaid persons is shown to\n\nhave been effected sometime prior to December, 1968, when the\n\nconcerned Patwari had entered the mutation regarding it, while the other\n\npart of the land comprising of Survey No. 1659/1667 measuring 6 marlas is\n\nshown to have been mutated in favour of Government on 2.1.1960. A very\n\ncurious observation is made thereafter, by the High Court as under:-\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">             \"At the same time, however, as per copy of the judgment, the\n             decree holders had before the trial Court in their plaint claimed\n             ownership of the land under reference under a sale deed\n             purported to have been executed in their favour by Ghulam\n             Nabi Shah S/o Ghulam Ali Shah reportedly executed on 12th\n             and registered on 28th March, 1968. Accordingly, the root of\n             the controversy appears to be lying somewhere here. If\n             Ghulam Nabi Shah aforesaid who is shown as son of Ghulam\n             Ali Shah and Ghulam Shah in photocopy of mutation No. 1004\n             above mentioned had sold the land to Khazir Mohammad S/o\n             Subhan Parrey aforesaid before it is sold to decree holders in\n             March, 1968 then obviously their claim would be defective.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_19\">We do not know, as to how, such observations could be made regarding\n\nthe appellants'/plaintiffs' title, particularly, in view of the decree which had\n\nfinally been passed. This seems to be the main reason why the High Court\n\nhas interfered in the matter. Even the observations made by the High\n\nCourt in para 6 of the impugned judgment regarding the Commissioners'\n\nReport, could not have been made, particularly, because the counsel for\n\nthe    respondents/defendants       unequivocally      had     accepted     the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f0                                   11</span>\n\nCommissioners' Report, which is clear from the earlier orders passed by\n\nExecuting Court on 27.6.2006 and referred to earlier. In short, the High\n\nCourt in its Revisionary jurisdiction has tried to go behind the decree, which\n\nis not permissible. The High Court has also returned a finding of fact in\n\npara 8 that the decreetal land was yet to be duly identified and demarcated\n\nand, thereafter, the High Court has chosen to open a Pandora's box by\n\ninviting the suggestions from both the sides for identifying the decreetal\n\nland, which had already been identified by the Commissioners' report.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">9.    In short, the High Court has exceeded its jurisdiction in the matter\n\nand has chosen to allow itself to be swept away by some documents,\n\nwhich though available to the respondents/defendants, were never\n\nbothered to be filed either while the Civil Suit was in progress or even\n\nduring the execution. We do not know how and under what provision, the\n\nsaid documents came to be produced at the Revisional stage, even without\n\nhearing the appellants/plaintiffs, who were parties to that Revision.               In\n\nshort, the impugned order is clearly erroneous and suffers from the\n\njurisdictional error and the same is, therefore, set aside. The appellants\n\nshall be entitled to proceed on the basis of the Commissioners' Report,\n\nwhile the respondents/defendants would be bound by the subsequent\n\norders dated 14.12.20005 and 27.6.2006 passed by the Executing Court.\n\nUnder the circumstances, the appeal is allowed with costs.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">                                             ......................................J.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f0                 12</span><p id=\"p_22\">\n\n                       (Markandey Katju)\n\n\n\n                        ......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                       (V.S. There shall be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<pre id=\"pre_2\">       (S. Thapar)                                                  (Madhu Saxena)\n      PS to Registrar                                                Court Master\n</pre><p id=\"p_3\">\fThe signed order is placed on the file.\n\f                             IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                              CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                                CIVIL APPEAL NO.347 OF 2009\n                             (Arising out of SLP(C) No.29807 of 2008)\n\nKAMAL RAJ BANSAL                                              ...APPELLANT (S)\n\n                                            VERSUS\n\n       RAJPAUL SINGH                                                     ...RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n                                            ORDER\n\n           Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">           In this case the Rent Controller has refused to grant leave to defend, hence this\n Civil Appeal is filed by the tenant.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           We have gone through the records. We are satisfied that the leave has been rightly\n rejected. However, from such rejection it does not follow that the landlord has not to prove\n the ingredients of Section 13B of East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949. We may\n also add that the appellant herein would have right to cross-examine the landlord in pending\n proceedings.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           Subject to above, we dismiss the appeal and direct the Rent Controller to decide\n the case as expeditiously as possible, preferably within nine months from today.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">           There shall be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">                                                              ....................J.</p><pre id=\"pre_3\">\n                                                              [ S.H. KAPADIA ]\n\n\n\n\n        New Delhi,                                        ....................J\n        January 19, 2009                          [ AFTAB ALAM ]\n\f</pre>","tid":1749714,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":5,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"constitution of bench ","formInput":"constitution%20of%20bench%20"},{"value":"regularisation","formInput":"regularisation"},{"value":"public employment ","formInput":"public%20employment%20"},{"value":"umadevi","formInput":"umadevi"}],"firstname":null,"title":"B.S.N.L., Jammu vs Teja Singh on 16 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33906","lastname":null,"secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-16","citedbyList":[{"tid":454499,"url":null,"title":"Smt. Gobindi Devi vs Haryana Vidyut Prasaran Nigam ... on 17 April, 2006"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">B.S.N.L., Jammu vs Teja Singh on 16 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                          1\n\n\n\n                           IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                           CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n                              CIVIL APPEAL NO. 292 OF 2009\n                            [Arising out of SLP(C) No. 7803/2006]\n\n\nBHARAT SANCHAR NIGAM LIMITED, JAMMU                                ...    APPELLANT(S)\n                               :VERSUS:\n\nTEJA SINGH                                                         ...    RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n\n\n                                      ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">             Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">             The respondent was employed with the appellant company as a daily-rated\n\n    Mazdoor. He was recruited in the year 1973. He was appointed on regular basis with\n\n    effect from 11.8.1986. He attained the age of superannuation on 30th August, 1989.\n\n    Thereafter, again while working on daily-wages, his services were terminated in 1993.\n\n    He filed a representation for payment of gratuity as also other retiral benefits. He\n\n    having been denied the retiral benefits on the premise that he had not completed 10\n\n    years' qualifying service as required in terms of the Service Rules, he filed an original\n\n    application before the Central Administrative Tribunal.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">             The said application was allowed inter alia on the premise that the appellant\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                            2</span>\n\nhad formulated a regularisation scheme in the year 1989 in terms whereof the\n\nrespondent should have been given a permanent status. The High Court has upheld\n\nthe said view.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           A Constitution Bench of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/179794777/\" id=\"a_1\">Secretary, State of Karnataka and\n\nOrs. vs. Umadevi</a> (3) and Ors. [2006 (4) SCC 1], has categorically held that keeping in\n\nview the constitutional scheme of equality, as contained in Articles 14 and 16 of the\n\nConstitution of India, regularisation or permanent continuance of temporary,\n\ncontractual, casual, daily-wage or ad hoc employees in public employment dehors the\n\nconstitutional scheme is impermissible in law.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">           By way of one time concession the Constitution Bench, however, held as\n\nunder:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">         \"53. One aspect needs to be clarified. There may be cases where\n         regular appointments (not illegal appoints) as explained in S.V.\n         Narayanappa (1967 1 SCR 128), R.N. Nanjundappa (1972 1 SCC 409)\n         and B.N. Nagarajan (1979 4 SCC 507) and referred to in para 15\n         above, of duly qualified persons in duly sanctioned vacant posts might\n         have been made and the employees have continued to work for ten\n         years or more but without the intervention of orders of the courts or\n         of tribunals. The question of regularisation of the services of such\n         employees may have to be considered on merits in the light of the\n         principles settled by this Court in the cases abovereferred to and in\n         the light of this judgment. In that context, the Union of India, the\n         State Governments and their instrumentalities should take steps to\n         regularise as a one-time measure, the services of such irregularly\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                             3</span>\n\n       appointed, who have worked for ten years or more in duly sanctioned\n       posts but not under cover of orders of the courts or of tribunals and\n       should further ensure that regular recruitments are undertaken to fill\n       those vacant sanctioned posts that require to be filled up, in cases\n       where temporary employees or daily wagers are being now employed.\n       The process must be set in motion within six months from this date.\n       We also clarify that regularisation, if any already made, but not sub\n       judice, need not be reopened based on this judgment, but there should\n       be no further bypassing of the constitutional requirement and\n       regularising or making permanent, those not duly appointed as per\n       the constitutional scheme.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">         We may notice that the law in this behalf has been laid down by the\n\nConstitution Bench of this Court, stating:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">       \"43. Thus, it is clear that adherence to the rule of equality in public\n       employment is a basic feature of our Constitution and since the rule of\n       law is the core of our Constitution, a court would certainly be disabled\n       from passing an order upholding a violation of <a href=\"/doc/367586/\" id=\"a_2\">Article 14</a> or in\n       ordering the overlooking of the need to comply with the requirements\n       of <a href=\"/doc/367586/\" id=\"a_3\">Article 14</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/211089/\" id=\"a_4\">Article 16</a> of the Constitution. Therefore,\n       consistent with the scheme for public employment, this Court while\n       laying down the law, has necessarily to hold that unless the\n       appointment is in terms of the relevant rules and after a proper\n       competition among qualified persons, the same would not confer any\n       right on the appointee. If it is a contractual appointment, the\n       appointment comes to an end and the end of the contract, if it were an\n       engagement or appointment on daily wags or casual basis, the same\n       would come to an end when it is discontinued. Similarly, a temporary\n       employee could not claim to be made permanent on the expiry of his\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                        4</span>\n\nterm of appointment. It has also to be clarified that merely because a\ntemporary employee or a casual wage worker is continued for a time\nbeyond the term of his appointment, he would not be entitled to be\nabsorbed in regular service or made permanent, merely on the\nstrength of such continuance, if the original appointment was not\nmade by following a due process of selection as envisaged by the\nrelevant rules. It is not open to the court to prevent regular\nrecruitment at the instance of temporary employees whose period of\nemployment has come to an end or of ad hoc employees who by the\nvery nature of their appointment, do not acquire any right. The High\nCourts acting under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_5\">Article 226</a> of the Constitution, should not\nordinarily   issue   directions   for       absorption,   regularisation,   or\npermanent continuance unless the recruitment itself was made\nregularly and in terms of the constitutional scheme. Merely because\nan employee had continued under cover of an order of the court,\nwhich we have described as 'litigious employment' in the earlier part\nof the judgment, he would not be entitle to any right to be absorbed or\nmade permanent in the service. In fact, in such cases, the High Court\nmay not be justified in issuing interim directions, since, after all, if\nultimately the employee approaching it is found entitled to relief, it\nmay be possible for it to mould the relief in such a manner that\nultimately no prejudice will be caused to him, whereas an interim\ndirection to continue his employment would hold up the regular\nprocedure for selection or impose on the State the burden of paying an\nemployee who is really not required. The courts must be careful in\nensuring that they do not interfere unduly with the economic\narrangement of its affairs by the State or its instrumentalities or lend\nthemselves the instruments to facilitate the bypassing of the\nconstitutional and statutory mandates.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_12\">  In view of the said decision of the Constitution Bench, there cannot be any\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                           5</span>\n\ndoubt whatsoever that the 1989 regularisation scheme having not been enforced in the\n\ncase of the respondent, it did not come within the purview of the exception carved out\n\nby the Court in paragraph 53, of Umadevi as quoted above. The view of the\n\nConstitution Bench in Umadevi (supra) has been reiterated by a three-Judge Bench of\n\nthis Court in Official Liquidator vs. Dayanand and Ors. [2008 (10) SCC 1], stating\n\nthat the High Courts shall give effect thereto, opining:\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">       \"90. We are distressed to note that despite several pronouncements on\n       the subject, there is substantial increase in the number of cases\n       involving violation of the basics of judicial discipline. The learned\n       Single Judges and Benches of the High Courts refuse to follow and\n       accept the verdict and law laid down by coordinate and even larger\n       Benches by citing minor difference in the facts as the ground for doing\n       so. Therefore, it has become necessary to reiterate that disrespect to\n       the constitutional ethos and breach of discipline have grave impact on\n       the credibility of judicial institution and encourages chance litigation.\n       It must be remembered that predictability and certainty is an\n       important hallmark of judicial jurisprudence developed in this\n       country in the last six decades and increase in the frequency of\n       conflicting judgments of the superior judiciary will do incalculable\n       harm to the system inasmuch as the courts at the grass roots will not\n       be able to decide as to which of the judgments lay down the correct\n       law and which one should be followed.\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">       91. We may add that in our constitutional set-up every citizen is under\n       a duty to abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and\n       institutions. Those who have been entrusted with the task of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                            6</span>\n\n       administering the system and operating various constituents of the\n       State an who take oath to act in accordance with the Constitution and\n       uphold the same, have to set an example by exhibiting total\n       commitment to the constitutional ideals. This principle is required to\n       be observed with greater rigour by the members of judicial fraternity\n       who have been bestowed with the power to adjudicate upon important\n       constitutional and legal issues and protect and preserve rights of the\n       individuals and society as a whole. Discipline is sine qua non for\n       effective and efficient functioning of the judicial system. If the courts\n       command others to act in accordance with the provisions of the\n       Constitution and rule of law, it is not possible to countenance violation\n       of the constitutional principle by those who are required to lay down\n       the law.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">       92. In the light of what has been stated above, we deem it proper to\n       clarify that the comments and observations made by the two-Judge\n       Bench in <a href=\"/doc/1569551/\" id=\"a_6\">U.P. SEB v. Pooran Chandra Pandey</a> (2007 11 SCC 92)\n       should be read as obiter and the same should neither be treated as\n       binding by the High Courts, tribunals and other judicial foras nor\n       they should be relied upon or made basis for bypassing the principles\n       laid down by the Constitution Bench.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_13\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">         For the reasons aforementioned, we are of the opinion that the view of the\n\nlearned Tribunal as also the High Court cannot be sustained. The impugned judgment\n\nis, therefore, set aside and the appeal is allowed accordingly. No costs.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                                ..........................J\n                                                (S.B. SINHA)\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                    7</span>\n\n\n\n                         ..........................J\n                        (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\n\nNEW DELHI,\nJANUARY 16, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":653775,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":367586,"url":null,"title":"Article 14 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":211089,"url":null,"title":"Article 16 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":179794777,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=30227","title":"Secretary, State Of Karnataka And ... vs Umadevi And Others on 10 April, 2006"},{"tid":1712542,"url":null,"title":"Article 226 in The Constitution Of India   1949"},{"tid":1569551,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=29658","title":"U.P. State Electricity Board vs Pooran Chandra Pandey & Others on 9 October, 2007"}]}, {"numcites":5,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"common intention","formInput":"common%20intention"},{"value":"302/34","formInput":"302/34"},{"value":"criminal act","formInput":"criminal%20act"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"ramcharan  ","formInput":"ramcharan%20%20"},{"value":"munnilal","formInput":"munnilal"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Munnilal vs State Of M.P on 20 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33527","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-20","citedbyList":[{"tid":89001527,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/Judis_Chennai/list_new2.asp?FileName=252322","title":"Ishad Ahamed @ Asalam vs State on 30 November, 2015"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Munnilal vs State Of M.P on 20 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                        REPORTABLE\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.               OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 6604 of 2006)\n\n\n\nMunnilal S/o Gokul Teli                                              ..\nAppellant\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of M.P.                                                  ..Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nMadhya Pradesh High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant for\n\noffence punishable under Section 302 read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 34</a> of the Indian\n\nPenal Code, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') as was awarded by learned Additional\n\nSessions Judge, Panna, in Sessions Trial No.15/1992.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">\f3.    Prosecution version as unfolded during trial is as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      On 30th November, 1991 at about 5.00 p.m. Ram Kishore (hereinafter\n\nreferred to as the `deceased') was murdered in an agricultural field. First\n\nInformation Report was lodged by Manik Lal at Police Station, Pawal in the\n\nevening at about 7.00 p.m. Offence was registered as Crime No.124/91\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_4\">34</a> IPC. Deceased had eloped with Lalli, sister of the\n\nRamcharan (A-2) and both of them had performed court marriage. The court\n\nmarriage was registered and Lalli was livng with Ramkishore. The appellant\n\nwas having enmity on account of aforesaid incident. Deceased after eloping\n\nwith Lalli was living in some other village and returned to his village a\n\nmonth before the incident. Ramkishore had gone to answer the call of nature\n\nin the evening on 30.11.1991 at about 4.30 p.m. towards the agricultural\n\nfield of Gadka. Around 5 p.m. Phulla (A-3) armed with axe, Ramcharan (A-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">2) armed with sword alongwith Dayashankar (A-1) and Munni Lal (A-4)\n\nwent to the field of Gadaka. Munni Lal and Dayashankar were barehanded.\n\nPhulla gave axe blow on the head of deceased. Thereafter, Dayashankar and\n\nMunnilal the co accused pulled the legs of deceased and threw him on the\n\nground. Ramkishore fell on the crops in the field. Ramcharan assaulted the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\fdeceased by sword on the chest. Then he placed his sword on the chest of\n\nthe deceased. On account of beating he died. Police after receiving\n\ninformation of the commission of crime carried out the investigation,\n\narrested the accused persons and filed the challan on 3.1.1992 before the\n\nCourt of Judicial Magistrate. Case was committed to the Court of Sessions\n\nJudge. Trial Court framed charges under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_6\">34</a> IPC against the\n\naccused persons. After recording the evidence the trial Court convicted the\n\naccused persons for offence under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_7\">Sections 302</a> read with <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 34</a> IPC\n\nand sentenced them as afore-noted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">      Before the High Court the basic stand was that the prosecution failed\n\nto prove common intention on the part of the appellants and, therefore,\n\n<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 34</a> had no application. The individual act of the appellant should\n\nhave been considered. Merely because the appellant had accompanied other\n\naccused persons, that cannot be sufficient to warrant presumption of\n\ncommon intention.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">4.    Learned counsel for the State submitted that the eye witnesses PWs 2\n\nand 3 had described the act of each of the appellants and the role ascribed to\n\nthe appellant was that he pulled the leg of the deceased as a result of which\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fdeceased fell in the field of Masur crop and thereafter he was assaulted by\n\nother accused persons. The appeal was dismissed accepting the stand of the\n\nState.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">5.       Learned counsel for the appellant re-iterated the stand taken before\n\nthe High Court and submitted that <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 34</a> IPC has no application.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">6.       Learned counsel for the State on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">7.       <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 34</a> has been enacted on the principle of joint liability in the\n\ndoing of a criminal act. The Section is only a rule of evidence and does not\n\ncreate a substantive offence. The distinctive feature of the Section is the\n\nelement of participation in action. The liability of one person for an offence\n\ncommitted by another in the course of criminal act perpetrated by several\n\npersons arises under <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 34</a> if such criminal act is done in furtherance of\n\na common intention of the persons who join in committing the crime. Direct\n\nproof of common intention is seldom available and, therefore, such\n\nintention can only be inferred from the circumstances appearing from the\n\nproved facts of the case and the proved circumstances. In order to bring\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                      4</span>\n\fhome the charge of common intention, the prosecution has to establish by\n\nevidence, whether direct or circumstantial, that there was plan or meeting of\n\nmind of all the accused persons to commit the offence for which they are\n\ncharged with the aid of <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 34</a>, be it pre-arranged or on the spur of\n\nmoment; but it must necessarily be before the commission of the crime. The\n\ntrue contents of the Section are that if two or more persons intentionally do\n\nan act jointly, the position in law is just the same as if each of them has done\n\nit individually by himself. As observed in <a href=\"/doc/673120/\" id=\"a_14\">Ashok Kumar v. State of Punjab</a>\n\n(AIR 1977 SC 109), the existence of a common intention amongst the\n\nparticipants in a crime is the essential element for application of this\n\nSection. It is not necessary that the acts of the several persons charged with\n\ncommission of an offence jointly must be the same or identically similar.\n\nThe acts may be different in character, but must have been actuated by one\n\nand the same common intention in order to attract the provision.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">8.    The Section does not say \"the common intention of all\", nor does it\n\nsay \"and intention common to all\". Under the provisions of <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 34</a> the\n\nessence of the liability is to be found in the existence of a common intention\n\nanimating the accused leading to the doing of a criminal act in furtherance\n\nof such intention. As a result of the application of principles enunciated in\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                      5</span>\n\f<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 34</a>, when an accused is convicted under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 302</a> read with\n\n<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 34</a>, in law it means that the accused is liable for the act which\n\ncaused death of the deceased in the same manner as if it was done by him\n\nalone. The provision is intended to meet a case in which it may be difficult\n\nto distinguish between acts of individual members of a party who act in\n\nfurtherance of the common intention of all or to prove exactly what part was\n\ntaken by each of them. As was observed in <a href=\"/doc/865810/\" id=\"a_19\">Ch. Pulla Reddy and Ors. v.\n\nState of Andhra Pradesh</a> (AIR 1993 SC 1899), <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 34</a> is applicable even\n\nif no injury has been caused by the particular accused himself. For applying\n\n<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 34</a> it is not necessary to show some overt act on the part of the\n\naccused.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">9.    The evidence of PWs 2 and 3 did not attribute any overt act to the\n\nappellant. The mere fact that he was in the company of the accused who\n\nwere armed would not be sufficient to attract <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_22\">Section 34</a> IPC. It is\n\nundisputed that appellant was not armed and he had no animosity with the\n\ndeceased. This position is also accepted by the prosecution. Additionally,\n\nthe stand that he pulled the leg of the deceased has not been established.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">\f10.   In the peculiar facts of the case therefore it would be appropriate that\n\nthe appellant cannot be held guilty by application of <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_23\">Section 34</a> IPC. His\n\nconviction is accordingly set aside. He be set at liberty forthwith unless\n\nrequired to be in custody in connection with any case.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">11.   The appeal is allowed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                        ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                        .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 20, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                    7</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f8</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1229991,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":37788,"url":null,"title":"Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":673120,"url":null,"title":"Ashok Kumar vs State Of Punjab on 21 September, 1976"},{"tid":865810,"url":null,"title":"Chinta Pulla Reddy And Ors. vs State Of Andhra Pradesh on 30 March, 1993"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"}]}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Aparna Goyal vs Rakesh Goyal on 27 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33575","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-27","citedbyList":[{"tid":47422,"url":null,"title":"Pinkiben vs Heard on 15 March, 2010"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Aparna Goyal vs Rakesh Goyal on 27 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . In support of assertion, the petitioner\n\nhas produced certificates issued by the competent authorities of the\n\nhospitals who have treated him for his heart ailments and also the\n\ncertificate of the doctor who is performing dialysis once in two weeks, who\n\nhas opined that the petitioner should not take long journeys outside the\n\ncity.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">3)      The assertion made by the petitioner is not disputed by the other side\n\nand, in our opinion, cannot also be disputed in the light of the voluminous\n\nmedical certificates produced by the petitioner alongwith the petition\n\ndocket.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">4)      After   perusing the certificates issued by the different hospitals,\n\nwhere the petitioner had undergone treatment for his heart ailments and\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                             2</span>\n\falso taking into consideration the certificate issued by the doctor who is\n\nperforming the dialysis once in two weeks and has also advised him not to\n\ntravel a long distance, we are of the opinion that the petitioner has made\n\nout a case for relief claimed in the petition.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">5)    Interest of justice demands that the case requires to be transferred.\n\nTherefore, we direct the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, at Ludhiana,\n\nPunjab, to transfer the case to the District Judge, Tis Hazari Courts, Delhi,\n\nwithin a month from the date of receipt of a copy of this court's order. The transferor court shall remit the\n\nrecords of the case to the transferee court soon on communication of copy\n\nof our order. We further direct that the transferee court shall decide the\n\ncomplaint filed by the complainant as expeditiously as possible at any rate\n\nwithin an outer limit of six months month from the date of transfer.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">6)    The transfer petition is disposed of accordingly.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                                 .......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                                 [ TARUN CHATTERJEE ]\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                                        3</span>\n\f                    .......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                    [ H.L. 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-16","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[{"tid":63355818,"url":"http://bombayhighcourt.nic.in/generatenew.php?path=.%2Fdata%2Fjudgements%2F2012%2F&fname=CRAPEAL81106.pdf&smflag=N","title":"Laxman
