India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33507","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Raj Nath vs State Of U.P on 16 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                    IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.             OF 2008\n                (Arising out of S.L.P.(Crl.) No.5031 of 2007)\n\n\n\nRaj Nath                                                 ...Appellant\n\n                         Versus\n\n\nState of U.P.                                            ..Respondent\n\n\n(With Crl. A. No.         /2008 @ SLP (Crl.) No. 2054 of 2008)\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">2.    Challenge in these appeals is to the judgment of a Division Bench of\n\nthe Allahabad High Court dismissing the appeal filed by the five appellants\n\nbefore the High Court. The present appellants, his two sons Yatindra and\n\nSurendra alongwith Ram Kripal, Gajendra and Govind were tried by\n\flearned IInd Additional Sessions Judge, Mainpuri for alleged commission\n\nof offences punishable under Sections 147, 148, 302 read with Section 149\n\nand Section 307 read with <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 149</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in\n\nshort the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>'). The trial Court acquitted accused Govind but rest of the\n\nfive accused were convicted for offences punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a> read\n\nwith <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 149</a> IPC, 307 read with <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 149</a> and <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 148</a> IPC. Life\n\nsentence, five years rigorous imprisonment and two years rigorous\n\nimprisonment respectively were imposed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      The informant Vijay Bahadur is a resident of village Sakaragarhi, P.S.\n\nKishni, district Mainpuri. There was a litigation between Smt. Rama Devi\n\nand appellant Raj Nath resident of Nagla Tara in which Raj Nath lost in the\n\nlitigation before court. In the said litigation, informant Vijay Bahadur had\n\nhelped Smt. Rama Devi. Four months prior to the incident Rama Devi had\n\nsold 16 bighas of her land to Lokeshwar Nath (PW-2) nephew of informant\n\nwhich sale was not relished by the appellant Raj Nath and his sons and they\n\nstarted nurturing animosity for the informant. On 18.5.1978 appellant Raj\n\nNath and others plucked Jackfruits from trees standing over the land\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                        2</span>\n\fpurchased by Lokeshwar Nath regarding which a first information report\n\nwas lodged by him.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">      On the date of the incident i.e. 5.6.1978 at 6.00 P.M. Vijay Bahadur\n\nalong with his sons Narendra Nath and Mahendra             accompanied by\n\nLokeshwar Nath and Shrawan Kumar had gone to the house of his cousin\n\nRam Prakash in village Nagla Tara, also the village of the accused, for\n\nhearing Bhagwat and to participate in the feast thereafter. After taking meal\n\nthey were returning to their village along with Murari Lal and Mitthu Lal\n\nGadaria. When they reached near the house of Kalka Prasad at 6 p.m. the\n\naccused appellants Raj Nath, his sons Satyendra and Surendra, Gajendra,\n\nRam Kripal and Govind came there from the south western corner of the\n\nbrick wall and threatened that they will teach a lesson to Lokeshwar Nath\n\nfor purchasing the land and immediately thereafter appellant Raj Nath with\n\nhis licensed gun and rest of the appellants with their country made pistols\n\nopened fire at the prosecution party. Lalit Kumar (hereinafter referred to as\n\nthe `deceased no.1') sustained gunshot injury and died instantaneously.\n\nNarendra Nath and Shrawan Kumar sustained firearm injuries and fell down\n\nat a short distance. Lokeshwar Nath and Mahendra Nath also sustained\n\nfirearm injuries. Gun fire attracted Prem Narayan and many others to the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                         3</span>\n\fplace of the incident. When the injured were being transported to the\n\nhospital in the bullock cart by the informant, injured Narendra Nath\n\n(hereinafter referred to as deceased no.2) lost his life in the way. Shrawan\n\nKumar, Mahendra and Lokeshwar Nath were dispatched to the District\n\nHospital, Mainpuri. Informant got the FIR (Ex.Ka-7) of the said incident\n\nscribed through one Arun Kumar and lodged it at police station Kishni on\n\nthe same day at 10.30 p.m. covering a distance of 8 miles south. Lajja Ram\n\nPW-4 Constable clerk prepared the chik Fir Ex. Ka-6 and G.D. entry Ex.Ka-\n\n7 and the investigation was immediately engineered by Mahendra Prasad\n\nSingh S.O. PW-10.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      Investigating Officer proceeded to the village Kusmara where the\n\ncorpse of Narendra was lying and there he conducted the inquest on his\n\ndead body as Ex.Ka-38. Thereafter, he came to the place of the incident in\n\nvillage Nagla Tara near the dead body of Lalit Kumar and conducted the\n\ninquest. Thereafter he conducted spot inspection and prepared site plan Ex.\n\nKa-47 collected blood stained and plain earth Ex. Ka-48. He also recovered\n\nempty cartridges (material Ex.1 to 3) from the roof of Kalka Prasad and\n\nprepared its recovery memo Ex.Ka-49. He thereafter arrested appellant Ram\n\nKripal and recovered country made pistol and three cartridges from him. On\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                        4</span>\n\f5.6.1978 he recorded the statement of the informant and thereafter in the\n\nmorning he prepared the inquest report of Narendra Nath deceased who had\n\nexpired in the hospital at 5.20 a.m. next day. Thereafter he was transferred.\n\nShrawan Kumar also lost his life after four days in the hospital because of\n\nthe sustained injuries in the incident. The post mortem examination on the\n\ndead bodies of Shrawan Kumar, Lalit Kumar, Narendra Nath and Mahendra\n\nNath was held and various gunshot injuries and ante mortem injuries were\n\nfound on their bodies.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      The report of Forensic Science Laboratory, Lucknow, U.P. dated\n\n31.7.1978 brought out the fact the cartridges E.C.-3 was fired from\n\ncountrymade pistol marked as 1/79.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">      After investigation charge sheet was filed and charges were framed\n\nagainst all the six accused persons. Since the accused persons pleaded\n\ninnocence trial was held. PWs 1 and 2 were stated to be the eye witnesses.\n\nPlacing reliance on the evidence of the eye witnesses the trial Court found\n\nthe prosecution case to have been established and recorded conviction as\n\nnoted above.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                         5</span>\n\f      Before the High Court the stand was that there was no recovery of\n\ngun and no injury is relatable to any act purported to have been done by the\n\nappellants. The High Court did not accept this plea and held that because of\n\napplication of <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_7\">Section 149</a> IPC the prosecution case has been fully\n\nestablished.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">4.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the appellants submitted\n\nthat the Forensic Science Laboratory report clearly shows that no injury\n\ncould be inflicted with the weapon held by the appellants.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">5.    Learned counsel for the respondent-State on the other hand submitted\n\nthat four persons lost their lives because of acts of the accused persons. The\n\nrole of the present appellants has been clearly established. Therefore, the\n\nHigh Court's judgment does not suffer from any infirmity.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">6.    So far as the reliability of evidence of the eye witnesses PWs 1 and 2\n\nis concerned their evidence has been analysed in great detail by the trial\n\nCourt and the High Court. PW-2 was one of the injured persons. Therefore,\n\nthere is nothing infirm in the conclusions of the trial Court and the High\n\nCourt placing reliance on their evidence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                          6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">\f7.    It is to be noted that one of the deceased persons received nearly 30\n\ninjuries which is consistent with the prosecution case that the accused\n\npersons were holding country made pistols.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_24\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">8.    A plea which was emphasized by the appellant relates to the question\n\nwhether <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 149</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_9\">IPC</a> has any application for fastening the constructive\n\nliability which is the sine qua non for its operation. The emphasis is on the\n\ncommon object and not on common intention.            Mere presence in an\n\nunlawful assembly cannot render a person liable unless there was a common\n\nobject and he was actuated by that common object and that object is one of\n\nthose set out in <a href=\"/doc/1542085/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 141</a>.      Where common object of an unlawful\n\nassembly is not proved, the accused persons cannot be convicted with the\n\nhelp of <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 149</a>. The crucial question to determine is whether the\n\nassembly consisted of five or more persons and whether the said persons\n\nentertained one or more of the common objects, as specified in <a href=\"/doc/1542085/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 141</a>.\n\nIt cannot be laid down as a general proposition of law that unless an overt\n\nact is proved against a person, who is alleged to be a member of unlawful\n\nassembly, it cannot be said that he is a member of an assembly. The only\n\nthing required is that he should have understood that the assembly was\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                         7</span>\n\funlawful and was likely to commit any of the acts which fall within the\n\npurview of <a href=\"/doc/1542085/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 141</a>. The word `object' means the purpose or design\n\nand, in order to make it `common', it must be shared by all. In other words,\n\nthe object should be common to the persons, who compose the assembly,\n\nthat is to say, they should all be aware of it and concur in it. A common\n\nobject may be formed by express agreement after mutual consultation, but\n\nthat is by no means necessary. It may be formed at any stage by all or a few\n\nmembers of the assembly and the other members may just join and adopt it.\n\nOnce formed, it need not continue to be the same. It may be modified or\n\naltered or abandoned at any stage.     The expression `in prosecution of\n\ncommon object' as appearing in <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 149</a> have to be strictly construed as\n\nequivalent to `in order to attain the common object'. It must be immediately\n\nconnected with the common object by virtue of the nature of the object.\n\nThere must be community of object and the object may exist only up to a\n\nparticular stage, and not thereafter. Members of an unlawful assembly may\n\nhave community of object up to certain point beyond which they may differ\n\nin their objects and the knowledge, possessed by each member of what is\n\nlikely to be committed in prosecution of their common object may vary not\n\nonly according to the information at his command, but also according to the\n\nextent to which he shares the community of object, and as a consequence of\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                                        8</span>\n\fthis the effect of <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 149</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_16\">IPC</a> may be different on different members of\n\nthe same assembly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">9.    `Common object' is different from a `common intention' as it does\n\nnot require a prior concert and a common meeting of minds before the\n\nattack. It is enough if each has the same object in view and their number is\n\nfive or more and that they act as an assembly to achieve that object. The\n\n`common object' of an assembly is to be ascertained from the acts and\n\nlanguage of the members composing it, and from a consideration of all the\n\nsurrounding circumstances. It may be gathered from the course of conduct\n\nadopted by the members of the assembly. For determination of the common\n\nobject of the unlawful assembly, the conduct of each of the members of the\n\nunlawful assembly, before and at the time of attack and thereafter, the\n\nmotive for the crime, are some of the relevant considerations. What the\n\ncommon object of the unlawful assembly is at a particular stage of the\n\nincident is essentially a question of fact to be determined, keeping in view\n\nthe nature of the assembly, the arms carried by the members, and the\n\nbehaviour of the members at or near the scene of the incident. It is not\n\nnecessary under law that in all cases of unlawful assembly, with an\n\nunlawful common object, the same must be translated into action or be\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                                        9</span>\n\fsuccessful. Under the Explanation to <a href=\"/doc/1542085/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 141</a>, an assembly which was\n\nnot unlawful when it was assembled, may subsequently become unlawful.\n\nIt is not necessary that the intention or the purpose, which is necessary to\n\nrender an assembly an unlawful one comes into existence at the outset. The\n\ntime of forming an unlawful intent is not material. An assembly which, at\n\nits commencement or even for some time thereafter, is lawful, may\n\nsubsequently become unlawful. In other words it can develop during the\n\ncourse of incident at the spot co instanti.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">10.   <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 149</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_19\">IPC</a> consists of two parts. The first part of the section\n\nmeans that the offence to be committed in prosecution of the common\n\nobject must be one which is committed with a view to accomplish the\n\ncommon object. In order that the offence may fall within the first part, the\n\noffence must be connected immediately with the common object of the\n\nunlawful assembly of which the accused was member. Even if the offence\n\ncommitted is not in direct prosecution of the common object of the\n\nassembly, it may yet fall under <a href=\"/doc/1542085/\" id=\"a_20\">Section 141</a>, if it can be held that the offence\n\nwas such as the members knew was likely to be committed and this is what\n\nis required in the second part of the section. The purpose for which the\n\nmembers of the assembly set out or desired to achieve is the object. If the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                                           10</span>\n\fobject desired by all the members is the same, the knowledge that is the\n\nobject which is being pursued is shared by all the members and they are in\n\ngeneral agreement as to how it is to be achieved and that is now the\n\ncommon object of the assembly. An object is entertained in the human\n\nmind, and it being merely a mental attitude, no direct evidence can be\n\navailable and, like intention, has generally to be gathered from the act\n\nwhich the person commits and the result therefrom. Though no hard and\n\nfast rule can be laid down under the circumstances from which the common\n\nobject can be called out, it may reasonably be collected from the nature of\n\nthe assembly, arms it carries and behaviour at or before or after the scene of\n\nincident. The word `knew' used in the second branch of the section implies\n\nsomething more than a possibility and it cannot be made to bear the sense of\n\n`might have been known'. Positive knowledge is necessary. When an\n\noffence is committed in prosecution of the common object, it would\n\ngenerally be an offence which the members of the unlawful assembly knew\n\nwas likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object. That,\n\nhowever, does not make the converse proposition true; there may be cases\n\nwhich would come within the second part but not within the first part. The\n\ndistinction between the two parts of <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_21\">Section 149</a> cannot be ignored or\n\nobliterated. In every case it would be an issue to be determined, whether\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                                                          11</span>\n\fthe offence committed falls within the first part or it was an offence such as\n\nthe members of the assembly knew to be likely to be committed in\n\nprosecution of the common object and falls within the second part.\n\nHowever, there may be cases which would be within first part, but offences\n\ncommitted in prosecution of the common object would be generally, if not\n\nalways, be within the second part, namely, offences which the parties knew\n\nto be likely committed in the prosecution of the common object. (<a href=\"/doc/952560/\" id=\"a_22\">See\n\nChikkarange Gowda and others v. State of Mysore</a> : AIR 1956 SC 731.)\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">11.     <a href=\"/doc/1142123/\" id=\"a_23\">In State of U.P. v. Dan Singh and Ors</a>. (1997 (3) SCC 747) it was\n\nobserved that it is not necessary for the prosecution to prove which of the\n\nmembers of the unlawful assembly did which or what act. Reference was\n\nmade to <a href=\"/doc/1093191/\" id=\"a_24\">Lalji v. State of U.P</a>. (1989 (1) SCC 437) where it was observed\n\nthat:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">              \"while overt act and active participation may indicate\n              common intention of the person perpetrating the crime,\n              the mere presence in the unlawful assembly may fasten\n              vicariously criminal liability under <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_25\">Section 149</a>\".\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                                                                          12</span>\n<p id=\"p_32\">\f12.   This position has been elaborately stated by this Court in <a href=\"/doc/137587/\" id=\"a_26\">Gangadhar\n\nBehera and Ors. v. State of Orissa</a> (2002 (8) SCC 381 and Shivjee Singh\n\nand Ors. v. State of Bihar (SLP (Crl.) No.1494/2004 disposed of on\n\n30.7.2008).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">13.   <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_27\">Section 149</a> IPC has clear application to the facts of the case.\n\nTherefore, the trial Court and the High Court were justified in convicting\n\nthe appellants. The appeals are dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_36\">                                     ....................................................J.\n                                     (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                     ...........................................J.\n                                     (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\n\nJanuary 13, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                                                                              13</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"absorption","formInput":"absorption"},{"value":"against  statutory rules","formInput":"against%20%20statutory%20rules"},{"value":"deputationist","formInput":"deputationist"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Union Of India & Ors vs S.A. Khaliq Pasha & Anr on 13 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33904","lastname":null,"secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-13","citedbyList":[{"tid":143463626,"url":"http://lobis.nic.in/dhc/VKR/judgement/05-09-2013/VKR05092013CW9362005.pdf","title":"Anil Kumar Jain vs Uoi on 5 September, 2013"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Union Of India &amp; Ors vs S.A. Khaliq Pasha &amp; Anr on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Mukundakam Sharma, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                           1\n\n\n                           IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                            CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NOS. 368-369           OF 2009\n                        [Arising out of SLP(C) Nos. 20212-20213/2005]\n\n\nUNION OF INDIA AND ORS.                                             ...      APPELLANT(S)\n\n                                           :VERSUS:\n\nS.A. KHAILIQ PASHA AND ANR.                                         ...      RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n\n\n                                           ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">             Nobody appears for Respondent No. 1.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">             Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">             Respondent No.1, who was a Head Constable in the State of Andhra\n\n    Pradesh, was sent on deputation to the Subsidiary Intelligence Bureau (\"SIB\"),\n\n    Ministry of Home Affairs, Hyderabad, on or about 9.3.1992 for a period of 5 years.\n\n    While working with the transferee organization, he was promoted to the post of\n\n    Assistant Central Intelligence Officer-II, with effect from 10.8.1994.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">             He filed a representation in the year 2001 praying for his absorption. His\n\n    representation for permanent absorption was rejected. Aggrieved by and dissatisfied\n\n    therewith, he filed original application before the Central Administrative Tribunal.\n\n    By a judgment and order dated 31.8.2004, the said application was allowed.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           2</span>\n\nAppellant herein was directed to give effect to the order of absorption, aggrieved\n\nwhereby it filed a writ petition which by reason of the impugned judgment has been\n\ndismissed by the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">         Before the High Court, reliance was placed on a purported Memo dated\n\n17.4.2003 issued by the SIB, in terms whereof those who had only one year's service\n\nleft for retirement, were not to be considered for absorption, inter alia on the\n\npremise that the said Memo will have prospective effect. The contention of the\n\nappellant was rejected by the High Court, stating:\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">       \"But this communication, as already observed by us, is not based on\n       legal position as available in the Rules. The very contention of the\n       Department is that the personnel shown in the letter dated 19.7.2001\n       are entitled for absorption in the Central Services and consequent on\n       their absorption, their lien in the parent department will be\n       terminated. It is also on record that number of police personnel were\n       absorbed in the IB and also continuing in the IB Service. In view of\n       this, it is not understood as to how the Government could refuse the\n       same benefit in respect of the 1st respondent.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">         Mr. Radhakrishnan, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the\n\nappellant would submit that the first respondent having no right to be absorbed in\n\nthe appellant services, the impugned judgment is wholly unsustainable.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">         Mr. Chowdhary, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the State of\n\nAndhra Pradesh, supported the contention of the appellants.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                           3</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">         Nothing has been shown either before the Tribunal or before the High\n\nCourt by or on behalf of the first respondent herein that he had a statutory right to\n\nbe absorbed in the appellants' services.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">         In this case, the State of Andhra Pradesh, which was the lending authority,\n\ndid not accede to the prayer of the first respondent for permanent absorption in the\n\nservices of the SIB. The first respondent while on deputation, was holding lien in the\n\nState of Andhra Pradesh. The employer, therefore, had a right to give or withhold\n\nits consent for permanent absorption of its employee.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">         Furthermore, in absence of any statutory rules, an employee does not have\n\nany legal right to be absorbed in the services. It is so held in <a href=\"/doc/527418/\" id=\"a_1\">Kunal Nanda vs. Union\n\nof India and Anr</a>. [2000 (5) SCC 362], in the following terms:\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">       \"On the legal submissions also made there are no merits whatsoever.\n       It is well settled that unless the claim of the deputationist for a\n       permanent absorption in the department where he works on\n       deputation is based upon any statutory rule, regulation or order\n       having the force of law, a deputationist cannot assert and succeed in\n       any such claim for absorption.          The basic principle underlying\n       deputation itself is that the person concerned can always and at any\n       time be repatriated to his parent department to serve in his\n       substantive position therein at the instance of either of the\n       departments and there is no vested right in such a person to continue\n       for long on deputation or get absorbed in the department to which he\n       had gone on deputation. The reference to the decision reported in\n       <a href=\"/doc/656676/\" id=\"a_2\">Rameshwar Prasad v. M.D., U.P. Rajkiya Nirman Nigam Ltd</a> is\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                           4</span>\n\n       inappropriate since the consideration therein was in the light of the\n       statutory Rules for absorption and the scope of those Rules. The\n       claim that he need not be a graduate for absorption and being a\n       service candidate, on completing service of 10 years he is exempt from\n       the requirement of possessing a degree needs mention, only to be\n       rejected.    The stand of the respondent Department that the\n       absorption of a deputationist being one against the direct quota, the\n       possession of basic educational qualification prescribed for direct\n       recruitment i.e. a degree is a must and essential and that there could\n       be no comparison of the claim of such a person with one to be dealt\n       with on promotion of a candidate who is already in service in that\n       Department is well merited and deserves to be sustained and we see\n       no infirmity whatsoever in the said claim.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_14\">See also Mahesh Kumar K. Parmar and Ors. Vs. SI.G. of Police and Ors., [2002 (9)\n\nSCC 485].\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">         In that view of the matter, the High Court must be held to have proceeded\n\non a wrong legal premise.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">         It is, however, accepted at the Bar that the 1st respondent has since retired\n\nfrom service.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">         We, therefore, keeping in view the peculiar facts and circumstances of this\n\ncase, particularly in view of the fact that, rightly or wrongly, he has been allowed to\n\ncontinue in the services of the SIB till he attained the age of superannuation, i.e. 60\n\nyears, it is not a fit case where any order should be passed against him at this stage\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                            5</span>\n\nin exercise of our jurisdiction under <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_3\">Article 136</a> of the Constitution of India.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">         We make it clear that we have refused to exercise our discretionary\n\njurisdiction in the matter only having regard to the facts and circumstances of this\n\ncase.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">         Subject to the declaration of law as mentioned hereinabove, the appeals are\n\ndismissed with the aforementioned observation.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                                ..........................J\n                                                (S.B. SINHA)\n\n\n\n                                                 ..........................J\n                                                (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\n\n\n\n                                                ..........................J\n                                                (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\n\nNEW DELHI,\nJANUARY 13, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":746902,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":527418,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=16390","title":"Kunal Nanda vs Union Of India & Anr on 24 April, 2000"},{"tid":656676,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=21123","title":"Rameshwar Prasad vs Managing Director U.P. Rajkiya ... on 16 September, 1999"},{"tid":427855,"url":null,"title":"Article 136 in The Constitution Of India   1949"}]}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"trilok singh","formInput":"trilok%20singh"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"committed rape on","formInput":"committed%20rape%20on"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"uttarakhand","formInput":"uttarakhand"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Mohan Chand vs State Of Uttarakhand on 23 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33550","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-23","citedbyList":[{"tid":169274811,"url":"http://ldemo.mp.nic.in/causelist/ciskiosk/asafr/RCM150513CRA--0180510.pdf","title":"Surendra Singh Baghel vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 15 May, 2013"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Mohan Chand vs State Of Uttarakhand on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                 REPORTABLE\n\n               IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n             CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n         CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.           140        OF 2009\n           (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 5536 of 2008)\n\n\n\nMohan Chand                                             ...Appellant\n\n                               Versus\n\nState of Uttarakhand                                    ...Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                          JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a learned Single Judge\n\nof Uttarakhand at Nainital High Court     finding the appellant guilty of\n\noffence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1279834/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 376</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in\n\nshort the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') and sentencing him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for\n\fseven years. Two persons i.e. Khemanand and the present appellant filed the\n\nappeal before the High Court which was dismissed by the impugned\n\njudgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      On 6.2.1985 the prosecutrix was sent by her mother to purchase rice\n\nfrom cheap grain shop. The prosecutrix waited there for sometimes in front\n\nof the shop. Ultimately, the prosecutrix returned to her home without\n\npurchasing rice. When her mother saw her without rice and coming late at\n\nhome, she scolded and admonished her. The prosecutrix was again sent to\n\nthe cheap grain shop and she again found it closed. When the prosecutrix\n\nwas in a sad and remorseful mood, the accused Basant Ballabh (who died\n\nduring the pendency of appeal) who was known to the prosecutrix came\n\nover there and inquired from her the reason for her remorse. The accused\n\nBasant Ballabh started to console her by saying that her mother was\n\nadmonishing her everyday and suggested that they should run away and\n\nmarry at Purnagiri temple. The accused, Basant Ballabh also told her that\n\nhis maternal uncle has a factory where he would get an employment and\n\nearn money and live comfortably. The accused Basant Ballabh took the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\fprosecutrix to his room where they stayed throughout the night. The accused\n\nBasant Ballabh promised her to marry on the next day in Purnagiri Temple.\n\nDuring the intervening night of 6th/7th February, 1985, accused Basant\n\nBallabh committed rape on the prosecutrix thrice in the night. On the next\n\nday, the prosecutrix along with accused Basant Ballabh proceeded to the\n\nbus station Champawat The accused Basant Ballabh asked the prosecutrix\n\nto go on foot 1 k.m. ahead from Champawat towards Tanakpur side and\n\nwait for him near the Deodar tree from where he would pick her up in the\n\nbus. Following the said instructions, the prosecutrix proceeded towards the\n\nDeodar tree on foot which is ahead of Champawat, from where she was\n\ntaken in the bus by the accused Basant Ballahh and Trilok Singh (who\n\nturned Approver) who had also joined hands with accused Basant Ballabh.\n\nThey all proceeded towards Tanakpur and got down little before Tanakpur\n\nfrom where they proceeded on foot and reached on Tanakpur-Bareilly road.\n\nThey again boarded a bus going towards the side of Bareilly. The\n\nprosecutrix became anxious and inquired as to where they were going. In\n\nreply, the accused told her that they would first purchase the articles\n\nrequired to perform marriage from Pilibhit and then would go to the temple.\n\nWhen they reached at Pilibhit, the prosecutrix was taken to a liquor shop\n\nwhere the accused Khemanand used to work as a Salesman. The accused\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                   3</span>\n\fKhemanand was also having an accommodation there. The accused Basant\n\nBallabh, Trilok Singh and Khemanand took the prosecutrix inside the room\n\nof accused Khemanand where the accused persons consumed liquor. After\n\nfinishing the drinks, Trilok Singh and Basant Ballabh slept on one cot,\n\nwhile Khemanand and the prosecutrix took separate cots. After sometimes,\n\naccused Khemanand went upto the cot of the prosecutrix and tried to molest\n\nher. The prosecutrix resisted his attempts and complained against accused\n\nKhemanand to Basant Ballabh. Accused Basant Ballabh instead of helping\n\nher, asked her to fulfill the desire of the accused Khemanand. Accused\n\nKhemanand subjected the prosecutrix to sexual intercourse forcibly. On\n\n9.2.1985 the prosecutrix was taken to village Tikri where distantly related\n\nsister of Trilok Singh was residing so that they may not be apprehended by\n\nthe police. Accused Triok Singh and Basant Ballabh went outside the\n\nvillage to ascertain whether any report against them has been made or not.\n\nThey came to know that a report has been lodged in the police station. The\n\naccused brought the prosecutrix from village Tikri to Tanakpur. At Pilibhit,\n\naccused Basant Ballabh got down and asked Trilok Singh to send the\n\nprosecutrix to Champawat. Trilok Singh brought the prosecutrix to\n\nTanakpur. Thereafter, accused Trilok Singh found truck No.USZ-4480 with\n\nits driver accused Mohan Chand near a pump at Tanakpur. Accused Trilok\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                    4</span>\n\fSingh told accused Mohan Chand that the prosecutrix was a student of class\n\nIX and her school is to open the next day, therefore, she may be taken in the\n\ntruck. Accused Trilok Singh also paid fare and instructed accused Mohan\n\nChand that the prosecutrix be made to get down 1 k.m. before Champawat.\n\nThereafter accused Mohan Chand also committed rape upon her. When the\n\ntruck moved a little forward, it stopped and an unknown person who was\n\nsitting by the side of the driver also went to the prosecutrix and committed\n\nrape upon the prosecutrix. Accused Mohan Chand made the prosecutrix to\n\nget down 1 k.m. before Champawat. She covered the distance on foot and\n\nwent straight to the house of accused Basant Ballabh. A written report\n\nEx.Ka.7 was lodged by Girish Chandra Paneru on 07.02.1985 before the\n\nPatti Patwari Talla Charao alleging therein that his niece, i.e. the prosecutrix\n\nis not traceable since 06.02.1985 and that he has gathered the information\n\nthat the accused Basant Ballabh has taken her away from Champawat\n\ntowards Tanakpur. On the basis of FIR, the Chick FIR Ex.Ka.8 was\n\nprepared. Patti Patwari Devi Datt (PW7) investigated the case. He recorded\n\nthe statement of the prosecutrix under <a href=\"/doc/447673/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 161</a> of the Code of Criminal\n\nProcedure, 1973 (in short the `Code') on 10.02.1985. During the course of\n\ninvestigation, the prosecutrix gave a written report Ex.Ka.3 and disclosed\n\nthat she has been raped by the accused persons. The Investigating Officer\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                     5</span>\n\fsent the prosecutrix for medical examination in order to ascertain her age\n\nand whether she was subjected to sexual intercourse or not. The\n\ninvestigating officer after completing the necessary formalities of the\n\ninvestigation submitted the charge sheet Ex.Ka.13 before the Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">      After completion of investigation charge sheet was filed and since the\n\naccused persons pleaded innocence trial was held. Prem Lata Tiwari (PW-2)\n\nwas the principal of the school where the prosecutrix was studying. PW-4\n\nwas the prosecutrix. Trilok Singh (PW-5) was the accused but later on was\n\nmade an approver. The trial Court found the evidence to be sufficient and\n\nconvicted the accused persons.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      In appeal, the basic stand taken was that at the first instance the name\n\nof the appellant was not stated and, therefore, there was false implication\n\nand the conviction should not have been recorded as the evidence is not\n\nsufficient to establish the accusations. The High Court did not find any\n\nsubstance in the plea and dismissed the appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">4.    The stand taken before the High Court was reiterated by the appellant.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                    6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">\f5.    Learned counsel for the State on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment of the trial Court and the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">6.    It is to be noted that the prosecutrix did not know the name of the\n\naccused and, therefore, there was necessity for Test Identification Parade.\n\nThe evidence of the prosecutrix is clear and cogent. In the instant case the\n\naccused is not personally known to the victim and therefore stating his name\n\nin the FIR did not arise. However, she has categorically stated that the rape\n\nwas committed on her by the truck driver. After the arrest of the accused he\n\nwas put in TI Parade and the victim had correctly identified him. That being\n\nso, the judgments of the trial Court and the High Court do not suffer from\n\nany infirmity to warrant interference.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">7.    The appeal is dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">                                         ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                                         (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                         .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                         (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 23, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                     7</span>\n\f</p>","tid":356282,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":447673,"url":null,"title":"Section 161 in The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"},{"tid":1279834,"url":null,"title":"Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"}]}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"firstname":null,"title":"Aparna Mehta Kapur & Anr vs State Of U.P. & Anr on 16 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33585","lastname":".................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-16","citedbyList":[{"tid":102729215,"url":null,"title":"Aparna & Anothers vs . Lodha</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                       IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n            CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n            CIVIL APPEAL NO. 7398 OF 2002\n\n\n      Oriental Insurance Co. Ltd.                            .. Appellant(s)\n\n                                  Versus\n\n      M/s. Prem Printing Press                               .. Respondent(s)\n\n                  ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">1.        We do not find any reason to interfere in the judgment passed by the National\n\nConsumer Disputes Redressal Commission, New Delhi (for short, `the National\n\nCommission'). It seems that the National Commission has rejected the matter on the\n\nbasis of their earlier view holding the concerned clause 7 in the policy to be void after\n\nthe interpretation of <a href=\"/doc/1224074/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 28</a> of the Contract Act, 1872 ( for short `the Act').\n\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">2.        Learned counsel appearing for the appellant,              Shri Mehra, tried to\n\npersuade us on the basis of few cases that the view taken on the interpretation of\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1224074/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 28</a> is not correct. Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the respondent,\n\nhowever, points out that there is no necessity to consider <a href=\"/doc/1224074/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 28</a> as the complaint\n\nbefore the consumer forum was filed well within the limitation indicated by the\n\nrepudiation clause in the policy. The clause is as under :\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">                                                                                     ..2/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\nC.A. 7398/2002..contd...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                             :2:</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">                           \"It is also hereby further expressly agreed and\n\f              declared that if the company shall disclaim liability to the\n              insured for any claim hereunder and such claim shall not, within\n              3 calendar months from the date of such disclaimer have been\n              made the subject matter of a suit in a court of law, then the\n              claim shall for all purposes be deemed to have been abandoned\n              and shall not thereafter be recoverable hereunder.\"\n\nAccording to the learned counsel there is enough material to suggest that even after the\n\nfirst repudiation by the appellant when the matters were taken up again by the\n\nrespondent through the representations dated 12.4.1993, 12.5.1993 and 4.8.1993, the\n\nappellant- Insurance Company suggested by its reply dated August 06, 1993 that the\n\nmatter of repudiation was being taken under fresh consideration. It is tried to be\n\nsuggested before us by Shri Mehra that the first repudiation was confirmed by reply\n\ndated 28.2.1994. However, we find on record that there is a legal notice served on the\n\nappellant company, in answer to which again the appellant- insurance company\n\npromised to take up the matter for further consideration. As if that is not sufficient,\n\nour attention is invited to the affidavit of one Mr. U.S. Asthana dated 16.3.1996, which\n\nis a reply affidavit to the complaint before the District Consumer Forum. In that\n\naffidavit, in\n\n                                                                                    ..3/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\nC.A. 7398/2002....contd...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                            :3:</span>\n\nparagraph 9, it is reiterated as under :\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                      \" ...accordingly after thorough study the final decision as\n             per advice of the Head Office of the oppo. party and the same was\n             conveyed to the complainant vide letter dated 28.7.94.\"\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_9\">3.         This leaves us in no doubt that the final decision about the repudiation was\n\fconveyed on 28.7.1994 and till then, the appellant kept on dangling a carrot of hope\n\nbefore the respondent herein that the matter regarding repudiation of claim was being\n\nconsidered afresh.      If that is so, then the complaint made on 6.8.1994 would be\n\nwithin three months of 28.7.94 which was a final answer and there would be no\n\nquestion of the general condition No. 7 coming into play. Therefore, viewing from this\n\nangle, the order of the National Commission need not be interfered with.          We,\n\ntherefore, find it not necessary to go into the question of <a href=\"/doc/1224074/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 28</a> of the Contract\n\nAct. Be that as it may, we find that the matter has no bearing, no merit and the\n\nappeal is, accordingly, dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">                          ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                                  [ V.S. Sukumaran vs N.S.D. Raju & Ors on 9 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33652","lastname":"......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-09","citedbyList":[{"tid":1947598,"url":null,"title":"Amir Singh vs Om Prakash And Ors. on 7 October, 1977"},{"tid":25641904,"url":"http://cms.nic.in/ncdrcusersWeb/GetPdf.do?method=getPdf&cid=23%2F0%2FCC%2F13%2F5&dtOfHearing=2015-04-07","title":"Smt. Mahindra Devi Ostwal vs Dr. Sandeep Kothari & Anr. on 7 April, 2015"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">A.U. Sukumaran vs N.S.D. Raju &amp; Ors on 9 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: B.N. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                            CIVIL APPEAL NO.64 OF 2009\n                       (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.3146 of 2007)\n\n\nA.U. Sukumaran                                            ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                         Versus\n\nN.S.D. Raju and Ors.                                      ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                                     O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">          The appellant-complainant filed a petition before the Kerala State\nConsumer Disputes Redressal Commission (for short, `the State Commission') for\naward of compensation to the tune of Rs.13,96,500/- by alleging that due to negligence\nof the respondent-Cochin Hospital and doctors, he had lost vision in one eye and was\nforced to seek voluntary retirement from service. He claimed Rs.13,000/- as cost of\ntreatment, Rs.7,500/- towards transportation charges, Rs.4,32,000/- as loss of income\ndue to voluntary retirement, Rs.1,44,000/- which he would have earned by continuing\nin service, Rs.2,00,000/- by way of damages for pain and suffering, Rs.5,00,000/- by\nway of damages for mental agony to himself, wife and children and Rs.1,00,000/- as\ndamages for disfigurement.      Respondent Nos.1 to 3 contested the complaint by\nasserting that it was not a case of medical negligence and that the claim made by the\nappellant was exorbitant.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">                                                                                 ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">           The State Commission, after considering the pleadings of the parties and\nrecord produced by them, held that the doctors who performed the surgery are not\nguilty of negligence and the loss of vision may have been caused due to infection. In\nthe opinion of the State Commission, the hospital authorities may have been negligent\nin maintaining hygiene and this may have led to infection. The State Commission\nthen observed that the complainant has not been able to prove that he suffered any\npecuniary loss and awarded Rs.40,000/- as compensation, Rs.5,000/- towards\nexpenditure and Rs.1,000/- by way of cost. On appeal, the National Consumer\nDisputes Redressal Commission (for short, the National Commission') criticized the\nobservation of the State Commission that the complainant could not prove that he\nhad suffered pecuniary loss and observed that loss of one eye for the entire life was an\nextremely serious matter which deserved a more sensitive approach by the State\nCommission. The National Commission held that the appellant has suffered due to\ngross negligence of the hospital authorities and enhanced the compensation from\nRs.40,000/- to Rs.1,00,000/- and cost of treatment from Rs.5,000/- to Rs.13,000/-. The\nNational Commission directed that the amount be paid to the appellant-complainant\nwithin six weeks, failing which he shall be entitled to interest at the rate of nine per\ncent per annum. Feeling dissatisfied, the complainant has filed this appeal by special\nleave.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           We have heard learned counsel for the parties. Undisputedly, the appellant\nsuffered loss of vision in one eye due to negligence of the hospital authorities to\nmaintain\n                                                                                   ....3/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                          -3-</span>\n<p id=\"p_6\">hygiene, which led to infection. This finding of the State Commission was not\nchallenged by the respondents before the National Commission and, therefore, the\nsame will be deemed to have become final. The disability suffered by the appellant is\nof permanent nature. The appellant, who was in government service, was forced to\ntake pre-mature retirement nine years before the date of superannuation apparently\nbecause he could not effectively discharge his duties. At the relevant time his salary\nwas Rs.6400/-. On retirement, the appellant was given pension at the rate of Rs.2500/-\nper month. Thus, the difference in salary and retirement benefit was Rs.3,900/- per\nmonth. After taking into consideration the expected increase in salary, the appellant\nclaimed compensation of Rs.4,32,000/- in lieu of the loss of salary. The respondents\nhave not disputed the fact that the appellant had sought voluntary retirement and\nconsequently, he suffered pecuniary loss. The State Commission awarded paltry\namount of Rs.40,000/- without even considering the appellant's plea that he was\nforced to seek voluntary retirement nine years before the age of superannuation. The\nNational Commission did enhance the compensation to Rs.1,00,000/- but without\nadverting to the pecuniary loss suffered by the appellant due to pre-mature\nretirement from service. In our considered view, the monetary loss suffered by the\nappellant furnishes valid basis for award of enhanced compensation to him.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed in part with costs, impugned order is\nmodified and the management of Cochin Hospital is directed to pay enhanced\ncompensation of Rs.4,32,000/- to the appellant in addition to enhanced cost of\ntreatment i.e. Rs.13,000/-. The appellant shall get cost of litigation which is assessed\nat Rs.50,000/-. The entire\n                                                                                   ....4/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                           -4-</span>\n<p id=\"p_8\">amount shall be paid to the appellant within three months from the date of receipt of\ncopy of this order, failing which the hospital authority shall be liable to pay interest at\nthe rate of twelve per cent per annum with effect from the date of this order till the\ndate of actual payment. The Management shall be entitled to deduct the amount, if\nany, already paid to the appellant pursuant to the orders of the State and/or National\nCommission.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_9\">                                                                           ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                                 [B.N. Islamuddin @ Pappu on 12 May, 2010"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">U.P.State Road Transport Corp vs Islamuddin on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                        REPORTABLE\n                                        IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                                CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n                              CIVIL APPEAL No.        OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of SLP(C) No. 18196 of 2007)\n\n\nU.P.STATE ROAD TRANSPORT CORP.                                       ...     Appellant(s)\n\n            Versus\n\nISLAMUDDIN                                                             ...   Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                         JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">               Heard.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">               Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">               This is an appeal against the order passed by a learned Single Judge of the\n\n     Delhi High Court allowing the appeal filed by the respondent who had filed a claim\n\n     petition claiming compensation on the ground that he had sustained injuries on\n\n     account of vehicular accident which took place on 03.12.2002 near G.T.Road,\n\n     Flyover,Shahdara,Delhi. Learned MACT, Karkardooma Court, Delhi              fixed the\n\n     amount payable as compensation to be Rs. 3,00,598/-. But deducting 40% for the\n\n     alleged contributory negligence of the claimant, ultimately the amount payable by the\n\n     present appellant to the claimant was fixed at Rs. 1,80,358/- (approximately). In\n\n     appeal filed by the claimant, the High Court by the impugned judgment held that the\n\n     reasons indicated by the MACT for making deduction on\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                   -2-</span>\n\faccount of alleged contributory negligence were not sufficient for the purpose of\n\nmaking a deduction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">             In the present appeal, it is stated by learned counsel for the appellant-\n\nCorporation that MACT categorically indicated reasons as to why it held that there\n\nwas contributory negligence on the part of the respondent leading to the accident in\n\nquestion.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">            There is no appearance on behalf of the respondent in spite of service of\n\nnotice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">            We find that the High court has discarded the view indicated by MACT on\n\nthe ground that the evidence of the driver who was examined shows about the\n\ncontributory negligence cannot be given any preference over the evidence of the\n\nclaimant. That was not the only ground on which MACT had directed deduction for\n\ncontributory negligence.     It was observed that though the place of accident was\n\nindicated, the site plan did not plan other relevant details.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">            In the peculiar facts of the case, we are of the view that there was\n\ncontributory negligence on the part of the claimant. Considering the nature of the\n\naccident we held that the liability of the Corporation shall be Rs. 2,35,000/- with\n\ninterest @ 6% from the date of accident. It is stated that nearly Rs. 2,22,000/- had\n\nalready been deposited. The balance amount payable on the basis of present order\n\nshall be deposited with MACT within six weeks.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                 -3-</span>\n\n\n\nThe respondent shall be permitted to withdraw the amount on such terms as the\n\nMACT shall stipulate.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">            The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent. A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                           REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n\n                   IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 40            OF 2009\n\n\n                  (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No.5671 of 2008)\n\n\n\nRamjit and Ors.                                    .........Appellants\n\n\n\n                                   Versus\n\n\n\nState of U.P.                                             ........\nRespondent\n\n\n\n\n                                 JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     1</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">\f1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    A Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court dismissed the appeal\n\nfiled by the appellants who were convicted for offences punishable under\n\nSection 302 read with Section 149 and Section 307 read with Section 149\n\nand <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 148</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>').\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    In all five persons had filed the appeal. During pendency of the\n\nappeal before the High Court appellant accused Mangaru died and the\n\nappeal stood abated so far as he is concerned. The learned 3rd Additional\n\nSessions Judge, Azamgarh, had found the five accused persons guilty in\n\nS.T. No.78 of 1982. The present appeal has been filed by four of the\n\naccused persons who were A2, A3, A4 and A5 before the trial Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    Prosecution version in a nutshell is as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      The incident resulting in the death of Sukhai and causing injuries to\n\nSabhajit and Laljit occurred on 26.12.1981 in Village Larpur Saheb Ali\n\nsituated within the limits of P.S. Didarganj, District Azamgarh. First\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    2</span>\n\fInformation Report was lodged on 26.12.1981 by Ramjit S/o Sukhai Yadav\n\nR/o Village Larpur Saheb Ali. The case of prosecution as appearing from\n\nthe F.I.R. in brief is that the chak of the complainant Ramjit was situated in\n\nnorthern side near to the house of Mangaru S/o Munne Lal Yadav. On\n\n26.12.1981 Sabhajit, brother of the complainant, along with one Dhodhai\n\n(PW-2) was harrowing his wheat field. At about 4.30 p.m. the bull of the\n\naccused Mangaru entered into another field of the complainant and started\n\ngrazing and damaging the wheat crop. Sabhajit seeing the bull grazing and\n\ndamaging his wheat crop, called Ramjit son of Mangaru and asked him to\n\ntake out his bull. Sabhajit complained also to Ramjit that their cattle always\n\ntrespass in his field and damage the grown standing crop. Thereupon,\n\nRamjit hurling abuses to Sabhajit went inside his house and immediately\n\nthereafter the accused Mangaru and Rajdev having lathies in their hands and\n\nRam Bachan, Ram Achal and Ramjit armed with knife, bhala and gandasi\n\nrespectively came there and they all began to assault Sabhajit. When on\n\nhearing hue and cry, the complainant Ramjit, his father Sukhai and brother\n\nLaljit rushed to save Sabhajit, the accused persons assaulted Sukhai and\n\nLaljit also. Behind the complainant, his cousin Indrajit, witnesses Sabhajit\n\nS/o Bahadur Yadav and Sita S/o Madhar Yadav of his village and Ram\n\nNarayan Singh S/o Hub Raj Singh of village Larpur Jhokhu as well as his\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                     3</span>\n\fmaternal uncle Sudarshan of village Gilwara also reached there. On being\n\nchallenged by these persons, the accused went away after causing injuries to\n\nSabhajit, Laljit and Sukhai. The complainant Ramjit witnessed the incident\n\nstanding at some distance. Sukhai having sustained serious injuries fell\n\ndown in the field and died instantaneously. Sabhajit and Laljit also\n\nsustained serious injuries due to which they were carried to Government\n\nHospital, Phulpur for treatment. The complainant with the help of Banarsi,\n\nJeetu, Adhin and Keesa carried the dead body of his father to P.S.\n\nDeedarganj and handed over written report there which was scribed by\n\nAbhai Raj (P.W.4).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      On the basis of written report the then Head Moharir, Bal Govind\n\nTiwari prepared chik F.I.R. and registered a case on 26.12.1981 at 6.30 p.m.\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1258372/\" id=\"a_3\">Sections 147</a>, <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_4\">148</a>, <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_5\">149</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_6\">323</a>, <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_7\">324</a>, <a href=\"/doc/455468/\" id=\"a_8\">307</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_9\">302</a> I.P.C. at Crime\n\nNo.106/1981 against Mangaru, Ramjit, Ram Achal, Ram Bachan and\n\nRajdev and made entry in G.D. vide Ext.Ka-3.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      The inquest proceeding on the dead body of Sukhai was conducted on\n\n27.12.1981 by S.I. Lat Buksh Singh (PW-5) who prepared inquest report\n\nand connected papers. Thereafter, the dead body in sealed condition was\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                    4</span>\n\fsent through the constable Ram Ugrah Pandit for post mortem examination\n\nwhich was conducted on 28.12.1981 at 2.00 p.m. by Dr. S.N. Sinha (PW-7)\n\nwho prepared post mortem report. Various injuries were found on the\n\nperson of the deceased. Investigation of the case was entrusted to S.I. Lat\n\nBuksh Singh (PW-5) who recorded the statement of the witnesses and after\n\nmaking spot inspection at the instance of the complainant Ramjit prepared\n\nsite plan. Blood stained and sample earth were collected from two places in\n\nthe field of occurrence and one knife was also recovered from the place\n\nwhere the dead body of the Sukhai was stated to be lying in the field and\n\nfard Ext.Ka.8 and KA-9 were prepared in this regard. Thereafter, blood\n\nstained lathi, gandasi and bhala were recovered from the well of accused\n\nMangaru at the instance of witnesses and fard was prepared.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      After completion of investigation charge sheet was filed. Since the\n\naccused persons pleaded innocence trial was held. Nine witnesses were\n\nexamined to further the prosecution version. Sabhajit Yadav (PW-1) and\n\nLaljit (PW-3) were injured witnesses. Similarly, Dhodhai (PW-2) was also\n\nan eye witness. Placing reliance on the evidence of the eye witnesses the\n\ntrial Court recorded the conviction as noted above.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                    5</span>\n\f      In appeal, the primary stand was that occurrence took place in a\n\nsudden quarrel and, therefore, <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 302</a> has no application. It was\n\npointed out that there was exchange of hot words and there was sudden\n\nquarrel because the bullocks damaged the crops.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">      The High Court did not find any substance in the plea of the\n\nappellants and upheld the conviction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">5.    Learned counsel for the appellants reiterated the stand taken before\n\nthe High Court. Learned counsel for the respondent-State on the other hand\n\nsupported the judgment of the Trial Court as affirmed by the High court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">6.    It is submitted by learned counsel for the State that this cannot be\n\nstated to be a case of sudden quarrel because the accused persons after the\n\nquarrel went inside and came back with arms. In the instant case though the\n\nwitnesses stated that after initial exchange of hot words and quarrel the\n\naccused persons went inside and came back, it is to be noted that they have\n\nfairly accepted that while the exchange of hot words, quarrel was continuing\n\nand immediately i.e. in less than two and three minutes they came back.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                    6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">\f7.    That being so, in the peculiar facts of the case we are of the\n\nconsidered view that appropriate conviction would be under Section 304\n\nPart I read with <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 149</a> IPC. The conviction is accordingly altered.\n\nThe other convictions remain unaltered. Custodial sentence of 10 years in\n\nrespect of offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 304</a> Part I IPC would suffice.\n\nThe sentences in respect of other offences remain unaltered. All the\n\nsentences shall run concurrently.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">8.    The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                        ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                        ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 12, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                    7</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"actionable claims","formInput":"actionable%20claims"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"lottery tickets","formInput":"lottery%20tickets"},{"value":"lottery","formInput":"lottery"}],"firstname":null,"title":"State Of Kerala & Ors vs Prabhavathy Thankamma & Ors on 23 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33592","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-23","citedbyList":[{"tid":906555,"url":null,"title":"Vysali Pharmaceuticals Ltd. vs S.G.S. Mediom (P) Ltd. on 13 December, 2000"},{"tid":1432649,"url":null,"title":"Babu Premarajan vs Superintendent Of Police, ... on 30 August, 2000"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":2,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">State Of Kerala &amp; Ors vs Prabhavathy Thankamma &amp; Ors on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                         IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                            CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                           CIVIL APPEAL NO. 460 OF 2009\n                         (Arising out of SLP(C) No. 2215 of 2009)\n                                       (CC No. 476)\n\n\nState of Kerala &amp; Ors.                                          ...Appellant(s)\n\n                    Versus\n\nPrabhavathy Thankamma &amp; Ors.                                    ...Respondent(s)\n\n                                        ORDER\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT,J.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_2\">           Heard learned counsel for the petitioner.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">           Delay condoned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">           Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">            In view of the decision of the Constitution Bench of this Court in <a href=\"/doc/1118022/\" id=\"a_1\">Sunrise\n\n  Associates vs. Govt. of NCT of Delhi &amp; Ors</a> reported in 2006 (5) SCC 603, we find\n\n  no merit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed. It need to be stated that\n\n  this Court in the said case inter alia held as follows:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                      \"We have noted earlier that all the statutory definitions of the\n           word `goods' in the State Sales Tax Laws have uniformly excluded, inter\n           alia,\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                     -2-</span>\n\n\nactionable claims from the definition for the purpose of the Act. Were\nactionable claims etc., not otherwise includible in the definition of `goods'\nthere was no need for excluding them. In other words, actionable claims\nare `goods' but not for the purpose of the <a href=\"/doc/1645178/\" id=\"a_2\">Sales Tax Act</a>s and but for this\nstatutory exclusion, an actionable claim would be `goods' or the subject\nmatter of ownership.     Consequently, an actionable claim is movable\nproperty and `goods' in the wider sense of the term but a sale of an\nactionable claim would not be subject to the sales tax law.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">          xxxxxx              xxxxxx              xxxxx\n\n\n          A lottery ticket has no value in itself. It is a mere piece of\npaper. Its value lies in the fact that it represents a chance or a right to a\nconditional benefit of winning a prize of a greater value than the\nconsideration paid for the transfer of that chance. It is nothing more\nthan a token or evidence of this right. The Court in H.Anraj, as we have\nseen, held that a lottery ticket is a slip of paper of memoranda evidencing\nthe transfer of certain rights. We agree.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">          xxxxxxx xxxxxxx xxxxxx\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     -3-</span>\n\n\n          The question is, what is this right which the ticket represents?\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_6\">There can be no doubt that on purchasing a lottery ticket, the purchaser\n\f          would have a claim to a conditional interest in the prize money which is\n          not in the purchaser's possession. The right would fall squarely within\n          the definition of an actionable claim and would therefore be excluded\n          from the definition of `goods' under the <a href=\"/doc/651105/\" id=\"a_3\">Sale of Goods Act</a> and the Sales\n          tax statutes.\"\n</p>\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">                                ................ .J.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">                                                   (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                       ...................J.</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_7\">                      (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 23, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1160487,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":651105,"url":null,"title":"The Sale of Goods Act, 1930"},{"tid":1645178,"url":null,"title":"the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956"},{"tid":1118022,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=30231","title":"Sunrise Associates vs Govt. Of Nct Of Delhi & Ors on 28 April, 2006"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"undisclosed income","formInput":"undisclosed%20income"},{"value":"settlement commission","formInput":"settlement%20commission"},{"value":"sec 32","formInput":"sec%2032"}],"firstname":null,"title":"E.K.
