Lingamurthy And Anr vs Settlement Commnr. (It&amp;Wt;)&amp; Anr on 22 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.H. Kapadia, Aftab Alam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                          CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                         CIVIL APPEAL NOS.382-383 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P.(C) Nos.19393-19394/2007)\n\n\nE.K. Lingamurthy &amp; Anr.                                         ...Appellant(s)\n\n                   Versus\n\nSettlement Commissioner (IT&amp;WT) &amp; Anr.                          ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                         ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">         Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">         In these appeals, we are required to consider the scope of Section 158BB(4)\n\nof Chapter XIV-B of the Income Tax Act, 1961 (for short, 1961 Act).\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">         We quote hereinbelow Section 158BB, which refers to 'Computation of\n\nundisclosed income of a block period':\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                   \"158BB. (1) The undisclosed income of the block period shall be\n         the aggregate of the total income of the previous years falling within the\n         block period computed, in accordance with the provisions of Chapter IV, on\n         the basis of evidence found as a result of search or requisition of books of\n         account or documents and such other materials or information as are\n         available with Assessing Officer, as reduced by the aggregate of the total\n         income, or as the case may be, as increased by the aggregate of the losses of\n         such previous years, determined,--\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">               (a) Where assessments under section 143 or section 144 or section 147\n               have been concluded, on the basis of such assessments;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">               (b) where returns of income have been filed under section 139 or\n               section 147 but assessments have not been made till the date of search\n               or requisition, on the basis of the income disclosed in such returns;</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">               (c) where the due date for filing a return of income has expired but\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                          1</span>\n\f               no return of income has been filed, as nil;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">               (d) where the previous year has not ended or the date of filing the\n               return of income under sub-section (1) of section 139 has not expired,\n               on the basis of entries relating to such income or transactions as\n               recorded in the books of account and other documents maintained in\n               the normal course on or before the date of the search or requisition\n               relating to such previous years;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">               (e) where any order of settlement has been made under sub-section\n               (4) of section 245D, on the basis of such order;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">               (f) where an assessment of undisclosed income had been made earlier\n               under clause (c) of section 158BC, on the basis of such assessment.\n</blockquote>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">         Explanation: For the purposes of determination of undisclosed income,--\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">               (a) the total income or loss of each previous year shall, for the\n               purpose of aggregation, be taken as the total income or loss computed\n               in accordance with the provisions of Chapter IV without giving effect\n               to set off of brought forward losses under Chapter VI or unabsorbed\n               depreciation under sub-section (2) of section 32;\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">               (b) xxx xxx xxx\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">               (c) xxx xxx xxx\n         (2) &amp; (3) xxx xxx\n         (4) For the purpose of assessment under this Chapter, losses brought\n         forward from the previous year under Chapter VI or unabsorbed\n         depreciation under sub-section (2) of section 32 shall not be set off against\n         the undisclosed income determined in the block assessment under this\n         Chapter, but may be carried forward for being set off in the regular\n         assessments.\"</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_12\">         In these Civil Appeals, we are concerned with the block period commencing\n\nfrom 1.4.1986 to 11.10.1996, when the search took place.</blockquote><p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">         It is the case of the appellants-assessee that there is a conceptual difference\n\nbetween current losses and carried forward losses. Similarly, assessee contends that\n\nthere a conceptual difference between current depreciation and carried forward\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                           2</span>\n\funabsorbed depreciation. It is the case of the assessee that Explanation (a) to Section\n\n158BB does not rule out current year's losses or current year's depreciation; it only\n\nrules out the brought forward losses or unabsorbed depreciation under Section 32(2).\n\nAccording to the appellant, this difference is lost sight of by the Settlement\n\nCommission in its impugned judgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">         In order to answer the contention raised on behalf of the assessee, one has\n\nto examine the scheme of Section 158BB of the 1961 Act. It is not in controversy that\n\nChapter XIV-B constitutes a Code by itself.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">         In this case, we are concerned with the computation of \"undisclosed\n\nincome\" under Section 158BB of the Act. Section 158BB, inter alia, states that\n\nundisclosed income of the block period shall be \"the aggregate of the total income of\n\nthe previous years falling within the block period\" computed in accordance with the\n\nprovisions of Chapter IV. \"Total income\" is defined in Section 2(45) to mean the\n\ntotal amount of income referred to in section 5, computed in the manner laid down in\n\nthe Act. In other words, Chapter XIV does not rule out Chapter IV of the Act in the\n\nmatter of computation of undisclosed income under Chapter XIV-B. It may be\n\nmentioned that ordinarily, in the case of regular assessment, the unit of assessment is\n\none year consisting of twelve months whereas in the case of block assessment, the unit\n\nof assessment consists of ten previous years and the period upto the date of the\n\nsearch. Section 158BB provides for aggregation of income/loss of each previous year\n\ncomprised in the block period. The block period assessment under Chapter XIV-B is\n\nin addition to regular assessment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">         Analysing Section 158BB(4) read with Explanation (a) thereto, one finds\n\nthat only brought forward losses of the past years under Chapter VI and unabsorbed\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                           3</span>\n\fdepreciation under Section 32(2) are to be excluded while aggregating the total\n\nincome or loss of each previous year in the block period but set off of the loss suffered\n\nin any of the previous year in the block period against the income assessed in other\n\nprevious years in the block period is not prohibited. In our view, the Settlement\n\nCommission had erred in disallowing the application of the assessee for set off of\n\ninter se losses and depreciation accruing in any of the previous year in the block\n\nperiod against the income returned/assessed in any other previous year in the block\n\nperiod.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">          For the aforestated reasons, we set aside the impugned judgment of the\n\nHigh Court as well as the decision of the Settlement Commission and we remit the\n\nmatter to the Settlement Commission for fresh computation of the undisclosed income\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1971671/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 158BB</a> of the Income Tax Act, 1961 for the block period in question.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">          Civil Appeals are allowed accordingly, with no order as to costs.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                                    ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                                       (S.H. KAPADIA)\n\n\n\n                                            ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                        (AFTAB ALAM)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 22, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                            4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":592988,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1971671,"url":null,"title":"Section 158BB in The Income- Tax Act,   1995"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":" wedlock","formInput":"%20wedlock"},{"value":"self-acquired property","formInput":"self-acquired%20property"},{"value":"self acquired property","formInput":"self%20acquired%20property"}],"firstname":"b","title":"Subba & Anr vs Debiya And Anr on 22 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33541","lastname":"reddy","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-22","citedbyList":[{"tid":73946021,"url":null,"title":"Trilok Singh vs Gursharan Kaur on 16 February, 2013"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Subba &amp; Anr vs Debiya And Anr on 22 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: B Reddy</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, Lokeshwar Singh Panta, B. Sudershan Reddy</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                             IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                       CIVIL APPEAL NO.361 OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP(c) No. 17695 of 2006)\n\n\nSubba &amp; Anr.                                            ...Appellant\n\n                                 Versus\n\nDebiya &amp; Anr.                                     ...Respondent\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">B.SUDERSHAN REDDY,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    This appeal is directed against the judgment and order of\n\nAllahabad High Court dated 3.7.2006 in CMWP No. 5813/85 setting\n\naside the judgment and order of Revisional Court .\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    The facts leading to filing of this appeal are: one Smt. Sonia\n\nresident of village Chhibab was married in   Zari with Mengi. Only two\n\ndaughters namely Bhagwania and Maiki were born out of the wedlock.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                  2</span>\n\n\nThe appellants herein Subba and Sudish are the sons of Maiki. After\n\nthe demise of Mengi, Sonia inherited the property in question from the\n\ndeceased Mengi. It is alleged that after the death of Mengi one Teni\n\nwho was working for Sonia as labourer developed illicit relations with\n\nSonia as a result one son Debiya respondent herein was born. Be it\n\nnoted, as per the version of the appellants Debiya is not the legal son\n\nof Sonia and Mengi, therefore, he could not be the legal heir to\n\nsucceed the inherited property of Sonia. Teni died in the year 1956.\n\nSonia died in April, 1977. In the year 1978, the appellants herein filed\n\nobjections under the provisions of U.P. Consolidation Holdings Act,\n\n1953 before the Assistant Consolidation Officer, Zari, District Banda\n\nfor declaration as legal heirs of Sonia and their names to be recorded\n\nin the revenue records in place of Sonia.        Deviya also filed his\n\nobjections whereunder he claimed that the disputed property was\n\nself-acquired property of his father Teni. The Consolidation Officer\n\nvide order dated 7.7.1980 declared Debiya to be the sole legal heir of\n\nSonia and Teni. The appellants herein being aggrieved by the said\n\norder filed Appeal No. 1838 before the Assistant Settlement Officer\n\nConsolidation, Jhansi Camp-Banda which was dismissed vide order\n\ndated 25.9.1980. Thereafter the appellants filed revision no. 1656\n\nwhich was allowed by the Assistant Director Consolidation vide order\n\ndated 19.4.1985 setting aside the judgment and order of Settlement\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                 3</span>\n\n\nOfficer Consolidation and directed the names of the appellants to be\n\nrecorded in respect of the said property left behind by Sonia. Being\n\naggrieved by the revisional order Debiya-the respondent herein filed\n\nwrit petition before the High Court. The High Court while allowing the\n\nwrit petition quashed the judgment and order of Assistant Director\n\nConsolidation and restored the order of Consolidation Officer and\n\nSettlement Officer Consolidation. Hence this appeal.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    We have elaborately heard the learned counsel for the parties\n\nand perused the impugned judgment and the material made available\n\non record.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">5.    The High Court mainly relied upon the admission stated to have\n\nbeen made by the appellants herein in their objections to the effect\n\nthat the respondent was born out of \"illegal relationship of Teni and\n\nSonia.\" The whole conclusion of the High Court and its decision to\n\nreverse the order of the Revisional Court is based upon the said\n\nadmission.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">6.    The question that arises for consideration in this appeal is as to\n\nwhether the High Court committed any error apparent on the face of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                  4</span>\n\n\nthe record in coming to such conclusion that the respondent herein\n\nwas born out of the relationship between Teni and Sonia? Secondly,\n\nwhether the evidence available on record supports the conclusion\n\nreached by the High Court in a proceeding under <a href=\"/doc/1331149/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 227</a> of the\n\nConstitution of India? Thirdly, whether is there any such admission at\n\nall made by the appellants herein in their objections?\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">7.    The evidence adduced on behalf of the respondent herein is not\n\nclear as regards the birth of Debiya out of the relationship between\n\nTeni and Sonia. No doubt the entries in the voter list of the year 1959\n\nas well as 1975 the name of the respondent was shown as son of Teni\n\nbut that evidence of respondent itself is not of any assistance to arrive\n\nat any conclusion that he was born out of the relationship between\n\nTeni and Sonia. He expressed his ignorance as to when and where\n\nTeni died.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8.    So far as the evidence of the appellants is concerned, the\n\nwitnesses examined on their behalf in clear and categorical terms\n\nstated that Teni did not belong to their village Zari but he came to that\n\nvillage in search of work along with the respondent and he was\n\nengaged to work as labourer by Sonia.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                 5</span><p id=\"p_15\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">9.    There is no dispute whatsoever that entries in the revenue\n\nrecords before the commencement of lis between the parties were in\n\nthe name of Sonia and Mengi in respect of the property in question. It\n\nis also not in dispute that Sonia was the legally wedded wife of Mengi.\n\nIt is out of the wedlock of Sonia and Mengi, two daughters namely\n\nBhagwania and Maiki were born. The appellants are the sons of Maiki\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">- the deceased daughter of Sonia.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">10.   In the circumstances it becomes difficult to accept the case set\n\nup by the respondent herein that he inherited the property after the\n\ndeath of Sonia. There is no acceptable evidence that he was born out\n\nof the relationship between Sonia and Teni. In order to overcome this\n\ndifficulty Debiya appears to have set up altogether a different case\n\nthat the possessory right of land was acquired from one Bhagwat\n\nPrasad Zamindar. But there is no acceptable evidence except the\n\nassertion of the respondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">11.   We have perused the objections filed by the appellants herein\n\nbefore the authority in which there is no such admission to the effect\n\nthat the respondent was born out of the \"illegal relationship between\n\nTeni and Sonia\" or any such admission in the evidence of the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                   6</span>\n\n\nappellants. It is in the evidence of the appellant that Mengi died about\n\n55 years ago as told to them by none other than Sonia. It is also in\n\ntheir evidence that the respondent herein is the son of Teni and not of\n\nSonia. Teni was merely cultivating the land on behalf of the appellants.\n\nIt is also in their evidence that Sonia and respondent both lived\n\nseparately and never lived together. The other witnesses on behalf of\n\nthe appellants reiterated and supported the version given by the\n\nappellants that Teni does not belong to their village but came to the\n\nvillage in search of the work along with Debiya. It is in their evidence\n\nthat after the death of Mengi, Sonia did not give birth to any\n\nchild/children.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">12.   That so far as the evidence produced on behalf of the\n\nrespondent to the effect that Sonia and Mengi did not have any issues\n\nat all out of their wedlock does not inspire any confidence. It is a self-\n\nserving statement which cannot be accepted. No evidence has been\n\nproduced by the respondent that the property was acquired by Teni\n\nfrom one Bhagwat Prasad Zamindar as claimed by him. There is no\n\nrecord to that effect maintained by the revenue administration. On the\n\ncontrary, the entries made in Khasra 1333 and 1334F in respect of the\n\nland in question support the case of the appellants inasmuch as the\n\nname of Sonia has been recorded in the said documents.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                 7</span>\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">13.   That the Revisional Court after elaborate consideration of the\n\nmatter and upon appreciation of the evidence available on record in\n\ncategorical terms found that even during the lifetime of Teni and for a\n\nvery long time the name of Sonia has been continuously recorded in\n\nall the revenue records.   It is for that reason the Revisional Court\n\nfound that the plea set up by the respondent herein that the property\n\nin question was that of self-acquired property of his father Teni was\n\nnot acceptable. The Revisional Court also found that the name of the\n\nrespondent herein had never been entered in any of the records after\n\nthe death of his father Teni. The Revisional Court found that had it\n\nbeen self-acquired property of Teni the name of the respondent would\n\nhave been found place in the revenue records after the death of Teni.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">14.   For all the aforesaid reasons it is clear from the evidence and\n\nmaterial available on record that the appellants herein never made any\n\nadmission that the respondent was born out of the illegal relationship\n\nof Teni and Sonia nor there is any such admission made by them in\n\ntheir evidence. The finding recorded by the Revisional Court that the\n\nproperty was always held and possessed by Sonia as her absolute\n\nproperty does not suffer from any error.        The finding that the\n\nappellants herein are the sons of Maiki - the deceased daughter of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                   8</span>\n\n\nSonia also does not suffer from any error as the same is based upon\n\nproper appreciation of evidence available on record. There is no\n\nevidence   whatsoever    to   arrive   at   any    proper       conclusion         that\n\nrespondent herein was born out of the wedlock/relationship between\n\nSonia and Teni.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">15.   In our considered opinion, the High Court ought not to have\n\ninterfered in exercise of its jurisdiction under <a href=\"/doc/1331149/\" id=\"a_2\">Article 227</a> of the\n\nConstitution of India with the\n\n\n\ndecision of the Revisional Court which does not suffer from any factual\n\nand legal infirmities.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">16.   For all the aforesaid reasons, the impugned order is set aside.\n\nThe appeal is accordingly allowed with no order as to costs.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">                                            ..........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">                                                        (S.B. Sinha)\n\n\n\n                                            ..........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">                                                     (Lokeshwar Singh Panta)\n\n\n\n                                            ..........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">                                                           (B. Sudershan Reddy)\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                   9</span>\n\n\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">January 22, 2009\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f10</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1932372,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1331149,"url":null,"title":"Article 227 in The Constitution Of India   1949"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"slp","formInput":"slp"},{"value":"hotels","formInput":"hotels"}],"firstname":null,"title":"M/S. Cross Country Hotels Ltd vs Tourism Finance Corpn.Of India ... on 5 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33895","lastname":null,"secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-05","citedbyList":[{"tid":1925716,"url":null,"title":"Central Bank Of India vs Sharad Rice Industries on 19 December, 2005"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":1,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">M/S. Cross Country Hotels Ltd vs Tourism Finance Corpn.Of India ... on 5 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.B. Sinha, V.S. Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                       IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                            CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n                               CIVIL APPEAL NO. 49 OF 2009\n                            [Arising out of SLP(C) No. 5541/2006]\n\n\nM/S. CROSS COUNTRY HOTELS LTD.                                    ...   APPELLANT(S)\n\n                                         :VERSUS:\n\nTOUSISM FINANCE COROPRATION OF INDIA LTD. AND                     ...   RESPONDENT(S)\nORS.\n\n                                           WITH\n\n                             CIVIL APPEAL NO. 51 OF 2009\n                            [Arising out of SLP(C) No. 26738/2008]\n\n\n\n\n                                         ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">  CIVIL APPEAL NO. 49 /2009 [@ SLP(C) No. 5541/2006]\n\n              Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">              Having heard Mr. Altaf Ahmed, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf\n\n    of the appellant and Mr. Dushyant Dave, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of\n\n    the respondents, with the consent of the parties, this appeal is disposed of with the\n\n    following directions:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">    1. Respondents herein need not supply the appraisal reports for various projects of the\n\n       appellant company.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           -2-</span><p id=\"p_5\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">2.          The respondents herein shall produce for inspection of the learned counsel\n\nfor the appellant, within four weeks, all other documents wherefor an application for\n\nproduction and discovery had been filed before the learned Debt Recovery Tribunal,\n\nNew Delhi, being I.A. No. 186/2003.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">3.          It is directed that all such documents which are available with the\n\nrespondents-Corporation shall be supplied to the appellant within two weeks\n\nthereafter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">            Keeping in view the fact that the matter is pending for a long time, the Debt\n\nRecovery Tribunal is requested to dispose of the matter as expeditiously as possible.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">            With the aforementioned direction, the impugned judgment is set aside and\n\nthe appeal is disposed of.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n\nCIVIL APPEAL NO. 51/2009 [@ SLP(C) No.26738/2008]\n\n            Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">            This appeal is directed against the judgment and order dated 24th October,\n\n2008 passed by a learned Single Judge of the High Court of Judicature of Rajasthan at\n\nJaipur, in S.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 9609/2008, whereby and whereunder it was\n\ndirected:\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                           -3-</span><p id=\"p_13\">\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">       \"Meanwhile, operation of the office order dated 14.8.2008 (Anx.4) and\n       19.8.2008 (Anx.5) shall remain stayed. Further, in case the petitioner\n       submits the notorised undertaking within a period of fifteen days from\n       today, for payment of Rs. 10 lacs (Rupees ten lacs) per month for a\n       period of one year, then the possession of the seized property shall be\n       restored to the petitioner on depositing first installment of Rs. 10 lacs.\n       The remaining installments shall be paid by the 15th of each month,\n       failing which the interim order shall stand vacated automatically\n       without reference to this Court.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                    List in the month of December, 2008 for further orders.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_14\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">             In view of the order proposed to be passed by us we need not enter into the\n\nmerit of the matter as the order as quoted above was passed ex-parte.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">             Mr. Dave, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant\n\nsubmits that the possession of the Hotel in question had already been taken over on\n\n22.8.2008.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">             Mr. Altaf Ahmed, learned senior counsel on the other hand, submits that the\n\norders impugned before the High Court, being office orders dated 14.8.2008 and dated\n\n19.8.2008, the said orders are ex-facie illegal and without jurisdiction and, furthermore,\n\nas the possession had been obtained by the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                           -4-</span>\n\n\n\nwrit petitioner purportedly to be in terms of Securitisation and Reconstruction of\n\nFinancial Assets and <a href=\"/doc/198257891/\" id=\"a_1\">Enforcement of Security Interest Act</a>, 2002 and in that view of the\n\fmatter the High Court cannot be said to have committed any error in passing the\n\nimpugned order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">          Be that as it may, by reason of the impugned judgment, the High Court has\n\npassed the ex-parte order in mandatory form.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">          By an order dated 25.11.2008, a Division Bench of this Court while issuing\n\nnotice, directed status quo as on that date, to be maintained by all concerned. In that\n\nview of the matter, we are of the opinion that interest of justice would be subserved if\n\nthe impugned judgment is set aside and the High Court be requested to hear out the\n\nmatter afresh, after giving an opportunity of hearing to both the parties. It is directed\n\naccordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">          While making the interim order dated 25.11.2008 passed by this Court\n\nabsolute, we would request the High Court to hear out the parties and pass appropriate\n\norder as expeditiously as possible, preferably within a period of three weeks from the\n\ndate of communication of this order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                          -5-</span>\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">          With the aforementioned observation and direction, this appeal is disposed\n\nof.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                          ..........................J\n                                          (S.B. SINHA)\n\f                    ..........................J\n                   (V.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                       CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NO.29 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.13325 of 2007)\n\n\nUrmila Devi                                               ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                       Versus\n\n\nCommissioner, Varanasi &amp; Ors.                             ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n                                    O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">          The District Magistrate, Varanasi, after issuing show cause notice to the\npetitioner proposing recovery of deficit stamp and levy of penalty with interest and\nconsidering appellant's objections, passed order dated 30th December, 2004 under\n<a href=\"/doc/74910796/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 47A</a> of the Indian Stamp Act, whereby he directed the appellant to pay deficit\nstamp fee of Rs.1,17,000/- on the basis of deemed valuation of the land and structure\nat the rate of Rs.140/- per sq. ft. He also levied penalty of Rs.1,17,000/- on the\nappellant apart from interest at the rate of 1.5 per cent on the amount of deficit\nstamp. That order was confirmed by the Divisional Commissioner, Varanasi who\ndismissed the appeal preferred by the petitioner. Her writ petition was also dismissed\nby the High Court. Hence, this appeal by special leave.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">          We have heard learned counsel for the parties and perused the record.\nNeither from the orders of the District Magistrate and Commissioner, Varanasi nor\nfrom the report of the Sub Registrar which constituted foundation of the action\n                                                                                  ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">initiated by the District Magistrate, it is possible to discern the basis for fixing the\nvalue of the land and structure at the rate of Rs.140 per sq. ft. Learned counsel for\nthe respondents could not draw our attention to any other material from which the\ncourt can find out the criteria for fixing the value of the property at Rs.140 per sq. ft.\nTherefore, it must be held that the order of the District Magistrate suffers from\narbitrariness and is liable to be set aside on that ground. Consequently, the orders\npassed in appeal and by the High Court are also liable to be set aside.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned orders are set aside and the\nmatter is remitted to the District Magistrate with the direction to pass appropriate\norder after giving opportunity to the parties to adduce evidence on the issue of\nvaluation of the property.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">                                                                          ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                                 [B.N. Balakrishnan, P. Sathasivam, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">           ITEM NO.2     COURT NO. 1      SECTION XIV\n     SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n          RECORD OF PROCEEDINGS\n\nPetition(s) for Special Leave to Appeal (Civil) No(s).10630/2006\n(From the judgement and order dated 24/02/2006 in WP No. 21211/2005 of The HIGH\nCOURT OF DELHI AT N. DELHI)\n\nGOVT.OF N.C.T.OF DELHI &amp; ORS                           Petitioner(s)\n\n              VERSUS\n\nALL INDIA YOUNG LAWYERS ASSN.(REGD)                         Respondent(s)\n(With appln(s) for impleadment and prayer for interim relief ))\n(for final disposal)\n\nDate: 29/01/2009 This Petition was called on for hearing today.\n\nCORAM :\n   HON'BLE THE CHIEF JUSTICE\n   HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE P. SATHASIVAM\n   HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE J.M. PANCHAL\n\n\nFor Petitioner(s)      Mr. Brijender Chahar, Sr. Adv.\n                                 Ms. Sadhna Sandhu, Adv.\n                                 Mr. Om Prakash, Adv.for\n                                 Mrs Anil Katiyar,Adv.\n\nFor Respondent(s) Mr. Surya Kant,Adv.\nNo.1                       Ms. Shailja Sinha, Adv.\n\nFor RR No.2                 Mr. Maninder Singh ,Adv.\n                            Mr. Gaurav Sharma, Adv.\n                            Mr. Sumeet Bhatia, Adv.\n      UPON hearing counsel the Court made the following\n                ORDER\n</pre><p id=\"p_1\">              Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">                    The Appeal is partly allowed in terms of the signed order. No costs.\n\n                    The Application for impleadment is rejected.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">              (Parveen Kr. Chawla)                                     (Veera Varma)\n                  Court Master                                          Court Master\n\f             [Signed Order is placed on the File]\n\n\n                                                              REPORTABLE\n\n                    IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                    CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                   CIVIL APPEAL NO. 498 OF 2009\n           (Arising out of SLP(C) No.10630 of 2006)\n\n\n\nGovt. of NCT of Delhi &amp; Others                      ..Appellants\n\n\n                    versus\n\n\nAll India Young Lawyers Association(Regd.)\n&amp; Another                                                     ..Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                              ORDER\n\n\n          Leave granted.\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_4\">          This appeal has been filed by the Government of NCT of Delhi against the\n\njudgment of the High Court of Delhi dated 24th February, 2006 passed in Writ Petition\n\nNo. 21211 of 2005, whereby the High Court has allowed the writ petition filed by\n\nrespondent No.1 herein.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">          Facts:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n          Respondent No.1 preferred a Writ Petition being W.P.(C) No.21211 of 2005\n\fbefore the High Court of Delhi, inter alia, seeking a mandamus to the appellants herein\n\nthat the actual\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                           -2-</span>\n\nperiod of practice at the Bar subject to a maximum of 15 years, should be added to the\n\ntotal pensionable service while computing the pension and other retiral benefits in the\n\ncase of a direct recruitee to the Delhi Higher Judicial Service. The High Court, after\n\nhearing both sides, by its impugned judgment held that the prayers made by the writ\n\npetitioner (respondent No.1 herein) were reasonable and directed that the Rule 26(B)\n\nbe inserted in the Delhi Higher Judicial Service Rules, 1970 (for short 'the Rules') and\n\nweightage of fifteen years of practice or such other number of years of practice at the\n\nBar whichever is less be given to the direct recruits while computing their pension and\n\nother retiral benefits, thereby allowed the writ petition.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">          Aggrieved by the said order, this appeal has been filed by the Government of\n\nNCT of Delhi challenging the aforesaid decision of the Delhi High Court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">          We have heard learned counsel for the State and learned counsel for the\n\nLawyers Association and High Court of Delhi.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">          In the Delhi Higher Judicial Service, direct recruitment to 25% of posts are\n\nmade from amongst the members of the Bar who have completed seven years practice\n\nat the Bar. The minimum age for entry is 35 years and the maximum age is 45 years.\n\nThe main contention of the writ petitioner\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                           -3-</span>\n\n(respondent No.1 herein) before the High Court was to include the fifteen years'\n\fpractice at the Bar. If a candidate joinsat the age of 35 years and retires at the age of\n\n60 years, if not elevated to the Bench of the High Court, he would not be able to get full\n\npension as for getting full pension one should have 33 years of service whereas the total\n\nservice rendered by a member who joins at the age of 35 years will be 25 years of\n\nservice. The High Court, on the administrative side, brought this fact to the notice of\n\nthe government by writing a letter in the year 1987. Though repeated reminders were\n\nsent to the government,       no decision was taken by the Government till the end of\n\n2005 and only on 02nd February, 2006 by a letter, Government has indicated that it was\n\nagreeable to give weightage of 7 years of practice at the Bar while computing the\n\npension and other retiral benefits for direct recruits.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">          Learned counsel appearing for the State contended that the reason why\n\ngovernment has agreed to give weightage of 7 years practice at the Bar is that because\n\nin the case of direct recruitments to the Delhi Higher Judicial Service, a member\n\nshould have seven years' practice at the Bar and that is why Government thought it fit\n\nto give weightage of seven years. Learned counsel appearing for the first respondent-\n\nassociation submitted that High Court was right in directing\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                           -4-</span>\n\nthe government to give weightage of fifteen years' practice at the Bar while computing\n\npension and other retiral benefits because otherwise most of the members of the Delhi\n\nHigher Judicial Service would not be able to get full or adequate/reasonable pension at\n\nthe time of retirement. It is also submitted that better conditions of service should be\n\nmade available to the persons who are direct recruitees from the Bar otherwise the best\n\ntalent would not be attracted for selection. Learned counsel appearing for respondent\n\fNo.1-High Court of Delhi has also brought to our notice the fact that the request was\n\nmade by the High Court in the year 1987 and despite repeated reminders, Government\n\nhas acceded to the request only in the year 2006 by its letter dated 02nd February, 2006.\n\nIt is also brought to our notice by the learned counsel appearing for respondent No.2\n\nthat in the States of Punjab, Haryana and Gujarat, weightage of 10 years' practice at\n\nthe Bar is given in the case of direct recruits while computing pension and other retiral\n\nbenefits.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">            We have considered the various contentions raised before us. Learned\n\ncounsel appearing for the State vehemently contended that only the period of seven\n\nyears' practice at the Bar is to be added because the minimum qualification to enter\n\ninto the Delhi Higher Judicial Service as a direct recruit is seven years' practice at the\n\nBar. That reason, by itself,\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                          -5-</span>\n\ndoes not appear to be justifiable as the total period of service for getting maximum or\n\nfull pension is 33 years as per the general rules of the Government of Delhi. Learned\n\ncounsel for the State submitted that if 15 years' practice at the Bar is added, then there\n\nis an apprehension that after joining the Delhi Higher Judicial Service and working for\n\na shorter period, members may quit the job because even after working for a shorter\n\nperiod, they will get the proportionate pension if their past practice of 15 years at the\n\nBar is added.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">            Having regard to the facts of the case and having heard learned counsel for\n\nthe parties, we deem it appropriate that 10 years practice at the Bar or such other\n\nnumber of years whichever is less, could be added while computing pension and other\n\fretiral benefits in the case of a direct recruit to the Delhi Higher Judicial Service. We\n\norder accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">          Insofar as apprehension of learned counsel for the State is concerned, we\n\nmake it clear that weightage of 10 years' practice at the Bar will be given only if the\n\ndirect recruit, who joins the Delhi Higher Judicial Service, actually works for minimum\n\nten years in the Delhi Higher Judicial Service and then retire so as to enable them to\n\nget reasonable/adequate pension at the time of retirement because as per general rules\n\nto be eligible for minimum pension a\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                         -6-</span>\n\nperson should have completed at least ten years of service. Government of NCT of\n\nDelhi is directed to suitably insert Rule 26(B) in the Delhi Higher Judicial Service\n\nRules, 1970.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">          The Appeal is partly allowed in the aforesaid terms. No costs.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">                                                    ...................CJI\n                                                    [K.G. The\n\nsaid notice refers to 18 specific documents and item 19 refers to any other relevant\n\ndocuments.    It appears that subsequently the said number of documents were\n\nreduced to 13 as will appear from clause 10 of paragraph 12 of the counter affidavit\n\nfiled on behalf of   BCCL. The notice will, therefore, be confined to the said 12/13\n\ndocuments and also any other relevant documents.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">5      The stoppage of supply, pursuant to the aforesaid notice, was questioned by\n\nthe appellants herein before the learned Single Judge of the Patna High Court, who\n\nby his judgment and order dated 10th January, 2008 held that the decision to stop\n\nsupply of coal on the failure of the appellants to produce all the documents in\n\nquestion could not be supported, particularly, in view of the fact that no hearing had\n\nbeen given to them before such stoppage.        On the ground of violation of the\n\nprinciples of natural justice the learned Single Judge declared the decision to stop\n\nsupply of coal to the appellants to be void ab initio and unenforceable.\n\nConsequently, the writ petition was allowed and the decision of the appellants herein\n\nto stop supply of coal to the appellants was set aside and BCCL was directed to\n\nforthwith resume supply of coal to the appellants. As against the decision of the\n\nlearned Single Judge, BCCL filed a Letters Patent Appeal, being LPA No.174 of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                            3</span>\n\n2008, which was disposed of on 24th April, 2008 relying on an earlier decision of the\n\nPatna High Court in M/s. Having regard to the said decision, the Division Bench allowed the\n\nLetters Patent Appeal to the extent that it was left open to BCCL to resume or not\n\nto resume supply of coal to the appellants till the proceedings were finally\n\ndetermined and after considering the explanation of the respondents in respect of the\n\nalleged deficiency. The Division Bench also observed that it would be open to the\n\nappellants to make up the alleged deficiency and to supply the required particulars,\n\nif they had necessary materials for the same along with the submission of their\n\nexplanation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">6      The appellants are before us on a very narrow ground, namely, that in\n\naddition to a hearing been given to them, a another\n\nsimilar matter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">7      Having heard learned counsel for the respective parties, and also having\n\nregard to the fact that stoppage of supply of coal to the Units in by\n\nthe Division Bench need not be interfered with, but we modify the same to the extent\n\nthat while considering the representations made by the appellants, in the event the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                   4</span>\n\n      appellants are unable to produce a particular document, the authorities of BCCL\n\n      would permit the appellants to produce supporting documents in corroboration of\n\n      the documents which they are unable to produce, in order to effectively decide as to\n\n      whether the unit of the appellant in question, was a running unit or not.\n\n      8      This will not preclude BCCL from holding any inspection, if it so deems fit.\n\n      9      We also request BCCL to dispose of the representations at an early date and\n\n      preferably within two months from date.\n</p>\n<pre id=\"pre_3\">      10     The appeal is disposed of.\n\n      11     There will, however, be no January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                        REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CIVIL APPEAL NO.                 OF 2009\n               (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.12815 of 2007\n\n\n\nRaj Kumar Singh                                        ...Appellant\n\n\n\n                                 Versus\n\nUnion of India &amp; Ors.                                  ...Respondents\n\n\n\n                           JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment passed by a Division\n\nBench of the Guwahati High Court dismissing the writ appeal filed by the\n\nappellant. Appeal was directed against the judgment and order dated\n\f19.5.2003 passed by the learned Single Judge in Civil Rule No.3053 of\n\n1996. Appellant's case in the writ petition and the writ appeal was that\n\nwhile serving as Rifleman in the Assam Rifles he was removed from service\n\non the ground of desertion and that too without serving any notice to him as\n\nrequired under law and without holding any disciplinary proceedings. The\n\nrespondent-Union of India took the stand that the writ petitioner and others\n\ngot themselves involved in some controversies whereupon the writ\n\npetitioner was given punishment of quarters guard. Thereafter he submitted\n\na letter of resignation which was accepted by order dated 18.12.1995 to be\n\neffective from 29.2.1996. But before that date the writ petitioner deserted\n\nwhereupon he was declared as deserter and notices were served on him\n\nalong with others. Learned Single Judge held that the appellant was not\n\nremoved from service on the ground of desertion but on the ground that he\n\nhad sought for voluntary discharge from service which was accepted.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.    Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that there was, in fact, no\n\nvoluntary resignation and his signatures were taken on blank papers while\n\nhe was in illegal detention.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f4.    Learned additional standing counsel referred to the letter dated\n\n21.11.1995 wherein the appellants clearly stated that he wanted the\n\nresignation from service due to domestic problem as there was nobody in\n\nthe family to look after it.    Three persons including the appellant had\n\nsubmitted for discharge from service at own request and the same request\n\nwas accepted on 23.11.1995 and the same was to be effective from\n\n29.2.1996.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5.    We find that the authorities placed on record original letter dated\n\n23.11.1995. By order dated 18.12.1995, the DG, Assam Rifles passed the\n\norder and accepted the resignation on compassionate ground to be effective\n\nfrom 29.2.1996. The appellant has taken the stand that he has not given\n\nvoluntary resignation and the blank signatures were taken from him. The\n\nplea is clearly unsustainable. There is no material on record and, in fact, it\n\nis not the stand of the appellant that he made any grievance about the\n\naforesaid act before any authority. Whether he had signed the letter\n\nvoluntarily or signatures were taken on blank papers involves disputed\n\nquestions of fact which cannot be decided in a writ petition. Learned Single\n\nJudge and the Division Bench noted that the authorities have acted on the\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     3</span>\n\fbasis of the letter of resignation. That being so, there is no scope for\n\ninterference in this appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">6.    Learned counsel for the appellant stated that the appellant may seek\n\nappropriate remedy for declaration that the letter was not voluntarily given.\n\nWe have expressed no opinion in that regard. If and when such remedy is\n\navailed, the question has to be decided in its proper perspective.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">7.    The appeal fails and is dismissed. No costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                         .........................................J.\n                                         (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                         ...........................................J.\n                                         (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 27, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                     4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1550100,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"inquiry officer","formInput":"inquiry%20officer"},{"value":"disciplinary authority","formInput":"disciplinary%20authority"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Union Of India Trh. Sharan, learned Additional Solicitor General for the\nappellant, and the respondent, who has appeared in-person.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">          The disciplinary authority initiated departmental inquiry against the\nrespondent on the ground of violation of Rule 3(1)(ii) and (iii) of Central Civil\nServices (Conduct) Rules, 1964 as extended to ICAR employees. The respondent\nchallenged the same in OA No.1333 of 2004, which was dismissed by Allahabad Bench\nof Central Administrative Tribunal (for short `the Tribunal') vide its order dated 13th\nDecember, 2004. Civil Misc. Writ Petition No.19054 of 2005 filed against the order of\nthe Tribunal was disposed of by the Division Bench of the High Court with a\ndirection that representation made by the respondent for change of the inquiry officer\nbe decided and till then the inquiry proceedings shall remain stayed. Thereafter, by\nan order dated 28.11.2005, the competent authority rejected the\n                                                                                  ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">representation of the respondent. O.A. No.144 of 2006 filed by the respondent for\nquashing the orders passed by the competent authority for initiation of disciplinary\nproceedings and appointment of inquiry officer was dismissed by the Tribunal on 2nd\nJune, 2006. Against the said order, the High Court was moved in writ petition, which\nwas registered as Writ Petition No.35336 of 2006. The Division Bench of the High\nCourt passed several interim orders whereby repeated directions were issued to the\nappellants herein to file affidavits on one or the other issues. Hence, these appeals by\nspecial leave.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           A perusal of different orders passed by the High Court including orders\ndated 20th July, 2007 and 5th October, 2007 which are subject matter of challenge in\nthese appeals shows that the High Court has been making a roving inquiry in relation\nto matters which have direct bearing on the merits of the charge levelled against the\nrespondent ignoring the fact that the Tribunal dismissed the application of the\nrespondent on the ground that it was pre-mature and there was no valid ground to\nquash the proceedings of the inquiry at that stage. In our view, the High Court\nshould not have entertained the writ petition at the threshold of the disciplinary\nproceedings and passed orders touching the merits of the charge. Instead, the High\nCourt should have directed the disciplinary authority to conclude the inquiry after\ngiving opportunity of hearing to the respondent.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           Accordingly, the appeals are allowed, impugned orders rendered by the\nHigh Court are set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent is dismissed.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                                                                   ....3/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                          -3-</span>\n<p id=\"p_8\">           Shri A. Heard.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.    The   lands    in   question   originally      belonged   to   one\n\nIrfanul Haq Beg.       He is stated to have died leaving a will\n\ndated 13.12.1967 bequeathing the suit lands to one Naseer\n\nBaig (father of appellants) subject to a life interest in\n\nfavour of Mariyam Bibi (wife of the testator).              The first\n\nrespondent is a transferee from Mariyam Bibi under sale\n\ndeed dated 11.10.1990.        On the death of Mariyam Bibi, the\n\nfirst respondent sought mutation to his name in the revenue\n\nrecords. The appellants objected. The Tehsildar by order\n\ndated 26.4.2001 overruled the objections of the appellants\n\nand directed mutation from the name Mariyam Bibi to that of\n\nfirst respondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                     1</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">\f3.   Feeling    aggrieved        the    appellants      appealed   to    the\n\nAdditional     District    Magistrate       (Sadar),      Sultanpur,      who\n\nallowed the appeal by order dated 9.10.2002 and directed\n\nthat the names of appellants be entered as the Bhumidars in\n\nplace of Mariyam Bibi and remanded the matter for rehearing\n\non merits after granting opportunity to the parties. The\n\nfirst respondent filed a revision against the said order.\n\nThe Additional Commissioner (Judicial), Faizabad rejected\n\nthe revision by order dated 25.10.2005 thereby affirming\n\nthe order of the appellate authority. The said order was\n\nchallenged by the first respondent in a writ petition.                       A\n\nlearned   Single   Judge    of    the    High   Court    by   order     dated\n\n29.3.2006 dismissed the writ petition filed by the first\n\nrespondent. Having dismissed it, he however observed that\n\nuntil the matter was decided by the Tahsildar on remand as\n\ndirected by the appellate authority, the entry of first\n\nrespondent's name in the revenue records will continue and\n\nthe possession of the first respondent will also continue\n\nundisturbed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.   Being aggrieved by the said observation of the High\n\nCourt while dismissing the first respondent's writ petition\n\nthe appellants have filed this appeal by special leave.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                         2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f5.     The Additional District Magistrate set aside the order\n\nof the Tahsildar directing mutation in the name of first\n\nrespondent, and directed that the name of the appellants\n\nshould be entered pending rehearing.                  The said order was\n\naffirmed by the revisional authority. The said order was\n\nalso   affirmed   by    the    High   Court   by   dismissing      the   writ\n\npetition filed of the first respondent. Having dismissed\n\nthe writ petition, the High Court ought not to have added\n\nany observation which would tend to virtually nullify the\n\ndismissal    of   the    writ   petition      as   also   orders    of   the\n\nappellate authority and the revisional authority which were\n\naffirmed by its order.          Further, the observation in regard\n\nto possession was not warranted, as it was not the subject\n\nmatter of the writ petition.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">6.     In the circumstances, we allow this appeal in part and\n\nset aside the observations in the impugned order to the\n\neffect that the entry of first respondent's name in the\n\nrevenue     records     will    continue      until    the   decision        of\n\nTahsildar and the first respondent's possession will not be\n\ndisturbed. Having regard to the nature of the dispute, the\n\nTahsidar will decide the matter as per the order of remand,\n\nin accordance with law, expeditiously.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                                      _________________J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                         3</span>\n\f                    [R.
