Dattu</div>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                1</span>\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">2.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f2</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f3</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1322423,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"mamlatdar","formInput":"mamlatdar"},{"value":"tenancy act","formInput":"tenancy%20act"},{"value":"goa","formInput":"goa"},{"value":"goa tenancy act","formInput":"goa%20tenancy%20act"},{"value":"protected tenant","formInput":"protected%20tenant"},{"value":"negative declaration","formInput":"negative%20declaration"},{"value":"bombay tenancy act","formInput":"bombay%20tenancy%20act"},{"value":"bombay tenancy","formInput":"bombay%20tenancy"},{"value":"section 70","formInput":"section%2070"},{"value":"property dispute","formInput":"property%20dispute"},{"value":"mamlatdar act","formInput":"mamlatdar%20act"},{"value":"jurisdiction of mamlatdar","formInput":"jurisdiction%20of%20mamlatdar"},{"value":"section 85","formInput":"section%2085"},{"value":"jurisdiction of civil court","formInput":"jurisdiction%20of%20civil%20court"},{"value":"tarun chatterjee","formInput":"tarun%20chatterjee"},{"value":"goa daman ","formInput":"goa%20daman%20"},{"value":"Acting in person ","formInput":"Acting%20in%20person%20"},{"value":"pari materia","formInput":"pari%20materia"},{"value":"daman","formInput":"daman"}],"firstname":"t","title":"Madhumati Atchut Parab vs Rajaram V. Parab & Ors on 29 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33617","lastname":"chatterjee","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-29","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Madhumati Atchut Parab vs Rajaram V. Parab &amp; Ors on 29 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: T Chatterjee</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Tarun Chatterjee, Aftab Alam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                               REPORTABLE\n\n      IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n       CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n        CIVIL APPEAL NO.2971 OF 2001\n\nSmt. Madhumati Atchut Parab                ...\n\nAppellant\n\nVERSUS\n\nShri Rajaram v. Parab &amp; Ors.          ..Respondents\n\n\n                JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">TARUN CHATTERJEE, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1. This appeal is directed against the judgment and\n\n  order dated 26th of June, 2000 of the Division\n\n  Bench of the High Court of Bombay at Panaji in\n\n  Letters Patent Appeal No.9 of 1999 whereby the\n\n  appeal was dismissed by the High Court based on\n\n  the decision passed in Letters Patent Appeal No.44\n\n  of 1998 decided on 13th of June, 2000.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                 1</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">\f2.   The relevant facts leading to the present appeal\n\nare as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">     The appellant is the owner of a property called\n\nVAGAD, survey No. 131, sub-division No. 33 and 37\n\nsituated at Paliem, Taluka Pernem, Goa, (hereinafter\n\nreferred to as \"the disputed property\"). Three persons\n\nnamely Vassu, Shankar and Bhiva were recorded as\n\ntenants in respect of the disputed property in 1972\n\nand the present respondents are their heirs and legal\n\nrepresentatives. The appellant applied before the\n\nCourt of Mamlatdar at Pernem, for a declaration that\n\nthe respondents were not tenants of the disputed\n\nproperty within the meaning of the Goa, Daman and\n\nDiu Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1964 (in short \"Goa\n\nTenancy Act). The Mamlatdar, after a detailed enquiry\n\ninto the facts, passed an order on 28th of October 1986\n\ngranting the aforesaid declaration in respect of the\n\ndisputed property. In appeal, the Deputy Collector\n\ndismissed the same and affirmed the order of the\n\nMamlatdar, by an order dated 5th of January 1992.\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                               2</span>\n\fFurther, an appeal to the Administrative Tribunal was\n\ntaken, which reversed the orders of the Deputy\n\nCollector and the Mamlatdar, by an order dated 30th of\n\nJune, 1997 by re-appreciating the evidence on record.\n\nThe appellant filed a writ petition being WP No. 113 of\n\n1998, before the High Court of Bombay at Panaji,\n\nchallenging the order of the Administrative Tribunal.\n\nThe Writ Petition was dismissed on the ground that\n\nunder Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act, there was no\n\npower vested with the Mamlatdar to grant negative\n\ndeclaration. Aggrieved by this judgment, the appellant\n\nfiled a Letters Patent Appeal being LPA No. 9 of 1999\n\nbefore the Division Bench of the High Court. As noted\n\nherein earlier, the same was dismissed vide its\n\njudgment dated 26th of June, 2000. Thereafter, the\n\nappellant had filed this special leave petition in this\n\nCourt, which on grant of leave was heard by us in the\n\npresence of the learned counsel appearing on behalf of\n\nthe parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                               3</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f3.   We have heard the learned counsel appearing on\n\nbehalf of the parties and examined the materials on\n\nrecord. The issue which we have to deal with while\n\ndisposing of this appeal is whether under Section 7 of\n\nthe Goa Tenancy Act, the Mamlatdar was vested with\n\nthe authority to grant a negative declaration to the\n\neffect that a particular person is/was not a tenant\n\nwhen any such dispute is/was referred to him for his\n\ndecision.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">4.   Before going into the rival contentions of the\n\nparties, it is necessary for us to refer to objects and\n\nreasons for enacting the Goa Tenancy Act. This Act\n\nhas been enacted to provide for the regulation of the\n\nterms of tenancy with respect to agricultural lands in\n\nthe Union Territory of Goa, Daman and Diu and for\n\nmatters connected therewith.    Section 7 of the Goa\n\nTenancy Act reads as under :-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">     \"Section 7: Question of tenancy:- If any\n     question arises whether any person is or\n     was a tenant or should be deemed to be a\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                4</span>\n\f     tenant under this Act the Mamlatdar shall,\n     after holding an inquiry, decide such\n     question.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">     In any such enquiry, the Mamlatdar shall\n     presume that any statement as to the\n     existence of a right of tenancy in a record\n     of rights prepared in the prescribed\n     manner under and in accordance with the\n     provisions of this Act, is true.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_11\">5.   As noted hereinearlier, the learned Single Judge\n\nas well as the Division Bench of the High Court\n\ndecided   that   the   Mamlatdar    did     not    have   any\n\njurisdiction to grant a negative declaration following\n\nthe ratio of its decision in LPA No. 44 of 1998. On a\n\nconsideration of the objects and reasons of the Goa\n\nTenancy Act and the relevant provisions of the same,\n\nwe are of the view that although Section 7 of the Goa\n\nTenancy Act provides that where any question arises\n\nwhether any person is or should be deemed to be a\n\ntenant, the Mamlatdar shall, after holding an enquiry,\n\ndecide    such   question,   even   then,    the    negative\n\ndeclaration namely \"such a person is/was not a\n\ntenant\" should also be dealt with by the Mamlatdar for\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                     5</span>\n\fthe reasons stated hereinafter.      The expression in\n\nSection 7 of the Act as to the determination of the fact\n\nthat whether a person \"is or was a tenant\", would also\n\ninclude the question whether the person is not a\n\ntenant,   and   after   conducting   an   enquiry   the\n\nMamlatdar shall decide the same.          Therefore the\n\nquestion, which was raised, is that, if the Mamlatdar\n\nafter conducting an enquiry comes to the conclusion\n\nthat the concerned person is/was not a tenant, he is\n\nbound to mention the same. Therefore, it does also\n\namount to a declaration to the effect that the person is\n\nnot a tenant.    Accordingly, it results in a negative\n\ndeclaration. It bemuses us that when the wordings in\n\nthe section are clear to the effect that the Mamlatdar\n\nhas to decide about the tenancy of a concerned\n\nperson, the expression \"If any question arises\n\nwhether any person is or was a tenant.....\" can\n\npurport to have a meaning that the mamlatdar is not\n\nauthorized to issue a negative declaration that the\n\nperson is not a tenant.    This   expression, as noted\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                6</span>\n\fherein earlier also, is clear that when there is a\n\ndispute or doubt over the tenancy of a person, then\n\nthe Mamlatdar shall decide such question after\n\nconducting a due enquiry to establish the same.\n\nTherefore, if the conclusion of the Mamlatdar, on\n\nenquiry, is that a particular person is not a tenant, he\n\nis bound to declare such a person that he is not a\n\ntenant. We do not also have any doubt regarding the\n\nexpression \"is or was tenant\" in Section 7 of the Goa\n\nTenancy Act       which would include the positive\n\ndeclaration as well as the negative declaration. If the\n\nobservations made by the Division Bench of the High\n\nCourt are accepted, it would then mean that if a\n\nperson approaches the Mamlatdar to declare him as a\n\ntenant or on the application of a landlord for a\n\ndecision   on   the   tenancy   of   his   occupant,   the\n\nMamlatdar ultimately reaches to a conclusion that the\n\nconcerned person whose tenancy has to be decided is\n\nnot a tenant, he has to refrain from taking any\n\ndecision and decline to exercise his jurisdiction. Such\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                  7</span>\n\fa situation would be unacceptable, untenable and a\n\nsheer waste of time of the Mamlatdar to conduct a\n\ndetailed enquiry under Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy\n\nAct on the application filed before it. This, in our view,\n\ncannot be the intention of the Legislature to create\n\nsuch an ambiguous position, which would result in a\n\nlengthy procedure, that might ultimately yield no\n\nresult.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">6.   At the risk of repetition, it is pertinent to mention\n\nthat the expression \"if any question arises\" embraces\n\nwithin    its   sweep   both   the   facets,   i.e.,   positive\n\ndeclaration as well as negative declaration, and the\n\nconclusion can be reached only at the end of the\n\nenquiry. The learned counsel appearing on behalf of\n\nthe appellant contended that if we examine the\n\nprovision of section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act and also\n\nSection 70 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, it would be\n\nevident that both the provisions are similar in nature\n\nand are pari-materia to each other. We have already\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                                       8</span>\n\fquoted Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act. It is,\n\ntherefore, necessary now to reproduce Section 70 of\n\nthe Bombay Tenancy Act which is as follows :-\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">     \"Section 70-Duties of the Mamlatdar:-\n     \"For the purposes of this Act, the following\n     shall be the duties and the functions to be\n     performed by the Mamlatdar :-\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">     (a) To decide whether a person is an\n         agriculturist;\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_5\">     (b) To decide whether a person is, or was at\n         any time in the past, a tenant or a\n         protected tenant or a permanent tenant...\n         ........\".\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_14\">7.   In this connection, Section 85 of the Bombay\n\nTenancy Act is also necessary to be produced. Section\n\n85 of the said Act is as follows:-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_6\">     \"Section 85 - Bar of Jurisdiction\n     (1)      No Civil Court shall have jurisdiction to\n              settle, decide or deal with any question\n              (including a question whether a person\n              is or was at the time in the past a\n              tenant and whether any such tenant is\n              or should be deemed to have\n              purchased from his landlord the land\n              held by him) which is by or under this\n              Act required to be settled, decided or\n              dealt with by the Mamlatdar or\n              Tribunal, a Manager, the collector or\n              the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal in\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">                                                  9</span>\n\f                  appeal or on revision, the State\n                  Government in exercise of their powers\n                  of control.\n</blockquote>\n<pre id=\"pre_2\">       (2)        No order of the Mamlatdar, the\n                  Tribunal,    the Collector or    the\n</pre><blockquote id=\"blockquote_7\">                  Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal or the\n                  State Government made under this Act\n                  shall be questioned in any civil or\n                  criminal court.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_8\">       Explanation:- For the purposes of this section a\n       Civil Court shall include a Mamlatdar's Court\n       constituted under the Mamlatdar Courts Act,\n       1906.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_15\">8.     From a bare perusal of Section 85 of the Bombay\n\nTenancy Act, it would be evident that this provision\n\nbars the jurisdiction of Civil Court to deal with any\n\nquestion including a question whether a person is or\n\nwas at the time in the past a tenant and whether any\n\nsuch     tenant    is   or   should   be   deemed   to    have\n\npurchased from his landlord the land held by him\n\nwhich would be decided or dealt with only by the\n\nMamlatdar or Tribunal or a Manager, the Collector or\n\nthe Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal in appeal or\n\nrevision by the State Government in exercise of their\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                                     10</span>\n\fpowers of control. When a question arises whether a\n\nparticular person is an agriculturist or a tenant or not,\n\nit is only the Mamlatdar who has the jurisdiction to\n\ndecide the same. The question, therefore, is whether\n\nunder Section 70 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, the\n\nMamlatdar has the power or jurisdiction to grant a\n\nnegative declaration that is whether the concerned\n\nperson is or was not a tenant. <a href=\"/doc/1885259/\" id=\"a_1\">In Nivrutti Laxman\n\nKondobahiri vs. Shiv Dayal Laxminarayan Sarda &amp;\n\nOrs</a>.     [AIR    1960     Bombay      56]    (Full   Bench),\n\nHon.Chainani,      C.J.   (as   His   Lordship   then     was)\n\nobserved :-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_9\">       \"It has, however, been urged that while an\n       application may be made to a Mamlatdar for\n       obtaining a declaration that a person is a\n       tenant, an application for a negative\n       declaration that a person is not a tenant,\n       is not competent. It has been contended that\n       the object of the Act is to protect tenant and\n       that it confers special rights upon them and\n       that consequently, where the owner of a\n       land alleges that person is not a tenant or\n       that he is not entitled to be protection of the\n       Act, the application cannot be said to be one\n       for the purposes of the Act. There does not\n       seem to us to be much force in this\n       argument. The purposes of the Act are, as\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">                                                     11</span>\n\fwill be seen from the preamble, to regulate\nthe relations of landlords and tenants of\nagricultural lands. While the Act confers\nextensive rights on tenants, the landlords\nare not deprived of all their rights - For\ninstances, they can terminate the tenancies\nand resume possession of their lands in\ncertain circumstances. Under Section 29,\nboth the landlords and the tenants can\napply to the Mamlatdar for obtaining\npossession of lands. Under clause (b) of\nSection 70 of the act, the Mamlatdar has\njurisdiction to determine whether a person\nis a tenant. He can, therefore, also decide\nthat a person is not a tenant. If he can\ndecide this question, on an application\nmade to him by a tenant, it is difficult to\nunderstand why he should not be able to\ndecide this question, when the application is\nmade by the landlord. In either case, the\nquestion which the Mamlatdar will have to\ndetermine is whether the relationship of\nlandlord and tenant exists between the\nparties. The jurisdiction to decide this\nquestion vests exclusively in the Mamlatdar\nand the Civil Court is not competent to\ndecide it. This question will also have to be\ndetermined by reference to and in the light\nof the provisions of the Act as to who are\nand who are deemed to be tenants and as\nto how and in what circumstances a\ntenancy can be terminated. Such a\ndetermination will, therefore, be for the\npurpose of the Act. The words for the\npurpose of this Act, in our opinion, mean for\nthe purposes of deciding any question\nrelation to a matter, which is regulated or\ngoverned by the provisions of this Act. If,\ntherefore, the question raised before the\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                            12</span>\n\f     Mamlatdar relates to a matter, which is to\n     be decided by reference to the provisions of\n     the Act, its determination by the Mamlatdar\n     will be for the purposes of the Act and it is\n     immaterial whether the application raising\n     the question is made by the landlord or by\n     the tenant.\" (Emphasis supplied)\n\n\n\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_16\">9.   Similar was the view expressed by the Bombay\n\nHigh Court relating to Section 70 of the Bombay\n\nTenancy Act in the decision in <a href=\"/doc/1590569/\" id=\"a_2\">Trimbak Sopan vs.\n\nGanga Ram Mhatarba</a> [AIR 1953 Bombay 241] in\n\nwhich the Bombay High Court observed as follows :-\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_10\">     \".............A very interesting argument has\n     been advanced by Mr.Tarkunde, and his\n     contention is that a suit against a trespasser\n     is only cognizable by the civil court, and\n     therefore, if an issue arises in such a suit as\n     to whether it is for the civil court to decide\n     that issue: if the defendant is a trespasser,\n     the Civil Court has jurisdiction to pass a\n     decree for possession; if, on the other hand,\n     the civil court comes to the conclusion that the\n     defendant is a protected tenant, then the\n     Court would have no jurisdiction and the suit\n     would have to be dismissed or sent to the\n     Mamlatdar to dispose of it according of law.</blockquote><p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">            Mr.Tarkunde's further contention is that\n     it is only to those issues which the Mamlatdar\n     is required to determine in a proceeding\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">                                                   13</span>\n\fwhich should be filed before the Mamlatdar\nthat Section 70(b) has any application........\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">       .............Now, if this argument was\nsound, really no occasion would ever arise\nfor the Mamlatdar to decide the issue as to\nwhether a person is a tenant or a protected\ntenant, because, if a person could only go to\nthe Mamlatdar in those case where he\nadmitted that the defendant was a tenant or\na protected tenant, then the issue as to\nwhether the person was a tenant or a\nprotected tenant would not arise. Such an\nissue can only arise when there is a dispute\nas to the status of the particular person, and\nit is only when an allegation is made that the\nperson is not a tenant or a protected tenant\nthat the Mamlatdar would be called upon to\ntry such an issue. Now, it is clear that the\nquestion whether a person is a tenant or a\nprotected tenant is not a jurisdictional fact as\nfar as the Mamlatdar is concerned but is a\nfact in issue.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">The jurisdiction of the Mamlatdar does not\ndepend upon the person being a tenant or a\nprotected tenant. On the contrary, the\nMamlatdar himself has been given the\njurisdiction to try the question as to whether a\nperson is a tenant or a protected tenant.\n\nMr.Tarkunde says that the issue before the\ncivil court is not whether the defendant is a\nprotected tenant or not, but the issue is\nwhether the defendant is a trespasser or a\nprotected tenant. In my opinion, when the\nLegislature has left it to the Mamlatdar to\ndecide the issue whether the defendant is a\nprotected tenant or not, it implies that he must\ndecide that the defendant is not a trespasser\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                                              14</span>\n\f      in order to hold that he is a tenant or a\n      protected tenant and he must also hold that\n      he is a trespasser in order to determine that\n      he is not a tenant or a protected tenant. I\n      agree with Mr.Tarkunde that the provisions\n      in law which oust the jurisdiction of the civil\n      court must be strictly construed. But\n      considering it as strictly as I can, looking to\n      the language used by the Legislature in\n      Section 70(b) of the Tenancy Act, and looking\n      to the scheme of the Act, it seems to me clear\n      that all questions with regard to the status of\n      a party, when the party claims the status of a\n      protected tenant, are left to be determined by\n      the Revenue Court, and the jurisdiction of the\n      civil court is ousted............\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">10.   In view of the discussions made hereinabove, we\n\nare, therefore, of the view that under Section 7 of the\n\nGoa Tenancy Act, which is pari-materia with Section\n\n70 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, the Mamlatdar is\n\nconferred with power to decide the question after\n\nholding an enquiry whether a particular person is or is\n\nnot a tenant of the disputed property.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">11.   It is true that the High Court by the impugned\n\njudgment has distinguished the two provisions of the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">                                                   15</span>\n\ftwo different Acts, namely, Section 7 of the Goa\n\nTenancy Act and Section 70 of the Bombay Tenancy\n\nAct relying on the provisions of Section 4 of the Goa\n\nTenancy Act. According to the High Court, if Section 7\n\nof the Goa Tenancy Act and Section 70 of the Bombay\n\nTenancy Act could be considered as pari materia in\n\nthat case the Mamlatdar could decide the question,\n\ni.e. the concerned person is or is not a tenant, there\n\nwould be no need to provide for negative declaration\n\nunder Section 4 of the Goa Tenancy Act. According to\n\nthe High Court, the cardinal principle of interpretation\n\nwas that the duty of the court is to give effect to the\n\nintendment of the legislature. Once the legislature has\n\nexpressly provided for grant of negative declaration in\n\nlimited   cases,   it   would   contemplate   ouster   of\n\njurisdiction in matters other than Section 4. This\n\nwould also be a harmonious construction as the\n\njurisdiction of the civil court would not be ousted and\n\nthere would be no conflicting judgments. Making these\n\nobservations, the High Court held that the language of\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">                                                 16</span>\n\f            the Goa Tenancy Act contemplates that no negative\n\n            declaration can be granted by the Mamlatdar under\n\n            Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act. At the same time,\n\n            the High Court also observed that, of course, when the\n\n            issue arises whether the person is a tenant or not\n\n            before the Mamlatdar, he could always decide whether\n\n            the person who claims the right has so proved or not.\n\n            It was also the finding of the High Court that the\n\n            jurisdiction of the Mamlatdar to decide whether the\n\n            concerned person is or was not a tenant, was inherent\n\n            in deciding the said issue. Before we proceed further,\n\n            let us produce Section 4 of the Goa Tenancy Act which\n\n            runs as under:-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_11\">                 \"Section 4 - Persons deemed to be tenants -\n                 A person lawfully cultivating any land\n                 belonging to another person (hereinafter in\n                 this section referred to as the owner) on or\n                 after the 1st of July, 1962 but before the\n                 commencement of this Act, shall be deemed\n                 to be a tenant if such land is not cultivated\n                 personally by the owner and if such person\n                 is not -\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_24\">(i)    a member of the owner's family, or\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">(ii)   a servant on wages payable in cash or kind but not in\n       crop share or a hired labourer cultivating the land under\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_17\">                                                              17</span>\n\f        the personal supervision of the owner or of any member\n        of the owner's family, or\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">(iii)   a mortgagee in possession.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">                  Provided that if upon an application made by\n                  the landlord within one year from the\n                  commencement of this Act to the Mamlatdar\n                  within whose jurisdiction the land is\n                  situated:-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">                  (a) the Mamlatdar declares that such person\n                      is not a tenant and his decision is not\n                      reversed on appeal or revision, or\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">                  (b) the Mamlatdar refuses to make such\n                      declaration but his decision is reversed on\n                      appeal or revision,\n\n                  such person shall not be deemed to be a\n                  tenant under this Section.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_30\">                  Provided further that a sub-tenant cultivating\n                  any land belonging to another person [on or\n                  after the 1st of July, 1962, but before the\n                  commencement        of   this     Act]   shall,\n                  notwithstanding the fact that the creation of\n                  the sub-tenancy might have been prohibited\n                  by any law for the time being in force, be\n                  deemed to be lawfully cultivating the land as\n                  a tenant for the purposes of this section; and\n                  in such cases, the intermediary tenant or\n                  tenants prior to the creation of the sub-\n                  tenancy shall not be deemed to be tenant or\n                  tenants for the purposes of this Act;\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">                  Provided further that in the case of a person\n                  claiming to be a tenant on the ground that he\n                  was a sub-tenant cultivating any land after\n                  the    1st   July,1962,    but   before   the\n                  commencement of this Act, the application by\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_18\">                                                               18</span>\n\f      the landlord for a declaration that such\n      person is not a tenant may be made within\n      three months of the commencement of the\n      Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy\n      (Amendment) Act, 1966.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_32\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_33\">12.   A plain reading of this provision which in addition\n\nwould show that legislature has provided by introducing\n\nSection 4 that the landlord can seek a negative\n\ndeclaration in respect of the category of persons\n\nmentioned in Section 4(1). It is true that under Section\n\n4(1) of the Goa Tenancy Act, the Mamlatdar is conferred\n\nwith jurisdiction to declare the category of person\n\nmentioned therein is or was not a tenant in respect of\n\nthe disputed property. But if we read Section 7 and the\n\nobjects and reasons of the Act and considering the fact\n\nthat for a limited purpose the Mamlatdar is conferred\n\nwith such power to declare the negative declaration in\n\nrespect of the certain category of persons under Section\n\n4(1) of the Goa Tenancy Act, it cannot be said that while\n\ndeciding the question under <a href=\"/doc/816397/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 7</a> of the Goa\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_19\">                                                19</span>\n\fTenancy Act, the jurisdiction of the Mamlatdar to\n\ndeclare that the concerned person is or was not a\n\ntenant is ousted. Accordingly, we are of the view that\n\nthe High Court was not justified in holding that a\n\nMamlatdar is not conferred under Section 7 of the Goa\n\nTenancy Act to deal with and decide whether the\n\nconcerned person is a tenant or not a tenant in respect\n\nof the disputed property.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_34\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_35\">13.   Again it is needed to be mentioned that the\n\njurisdiction under Section 7 of the Goa Tenancy Act is\n\nnot confined to cases where the relationship of the\n\nlandlord and tenant is admitted. In fact, it is only where\n\nthe said relationship is alleged by one party and denied\n\nby the other that the question falls to be considered and\n\nthe decision of the question is left exclusively to be\n\ndetermined by the Mamlatdar under the provision of the\n\nAct. It is likely that a trespasser would thereby be able\n\nto prolong litigation between him and the owner of the\n\nproperty by frivolously raising a plea that he is a tenant\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_20\">                                                 20</span>\n\for a protected tenant; but, on the other hand, a\n\nlandlord may also frivolously allege that a tenant is a\n\ntrespasser. We must, therefore, hold that the only\n\nforum that can deal with this plea is the Mamlatdar. If\n\nhe rejects the plea, then only the dispute between the\n\nowner and the trespasser would be triable by the\n\nordinary Civil Court; but otherwise, the Mamlatdar\n\nalone would decide the dispute in so far as it falls\n\nwithin the purview of the Act. In our view, the\n\njurisdiction of the Mamlatdar under Section 7 of the\n\nGoa Tenancy Act is not confined to cases where the\n\nquestion is whether a person is or was a tenant in\n\nrespect of the disputed property. The High Court in the\n\nimpugned judgment, as noted herein earlier, held that\n\nthe provisions of the Bombay Tenancy Act and Goa\n\nTenancy Act are similar, but in view of Section 4 of the\n\nGoa Tenancy Act, the decisions of the Bombay Tenancy\n\nAct, as referred to herein earlier, could not be applied in\n\nthe present case. We are unable to subscribe this view.\n\nWhen the legislature has provided that the landlord can\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_21\">                                                  21</span>\n\fseek a negative declaration in respect of the category of\n\nperson mentioned in Section 4(1) of the Goa Tenancy\n\nAct, it cannot conclusively lead to the conclusion that in\n\nother cases, namely, where the question arises as to\n\nwhether a person is or is not a tenant, the Mamlatdar is\n\nnot   conferred   with   any power    to   grant   negative\n\ndeclaration that the concerned person is not a tenant in\n\nrespect of the disputed property. Accordingly, we are of\n\nthe view that the Mamlatdar had the jurisdiction to\n\ndeclare a negative declaration, that is to say, a\n\nparticular person is not a tenant under Section 7 of the\n\nGoa Tenancy Act and, therefore, the judgment of the\n\nHigh Court cannot be sustainable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">14.   That apart, in our view, the scope of Section 7 of\n\nthe Goa Tenancy Act is quite different from that of\n\nSection 4 of the Goa Tenancy Act. <a href=\"/doc/875938/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 4</a> is to\n\noperate from within a limited period of one year from\n\nthe date of enforcement of the Act, i.e., 8th of February,\n\n1965, while <a href=\"/doc/816397/\" id=\"a_5\">section 7</a> is operative for all time.\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_22\">                                                   22</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_38\">\f15.   For the reasons aforesaid, we set aside the\n\njudgment of the High Court and restore the order of the\n\nMamlatdar and the application filed by the appellant\n\nbefore the Mamlatdar stands allowed.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">16.   The appeal is accordingly allowed. There will be no\n\norder as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_40\">                                     ...........................\n</p><p id=\"p_41\">                                                          ...J.\n</p><p id=\"p_42\">                                 [TARUN CHATTERJEE]\n\n\n\nNEW DELHI;                         .............................J.\n</p><pre id=\"pre_3\">January 29, 2009
