2007"},{"tid":561833,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=18617","title":"Ruli Ram And Anr vs State Of Haryana on 17 September, 2002"},{"tid":1597655,"url":null,"title":"Section 7 in The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Jarnail Singh vs State Of Punjab on 15 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-15","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":184398,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"sharma","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"m","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33496","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Jarnail Singh vs State Of Punjab on 15 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . M Sharma</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                              IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                  CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 62               OF 2009\n                (Arising out of S.L.P. (Crl.) No. 2872 of 2008)\n\n\nJarnail Singh                                              .... Appellant\n                                   Versus\n\nState of Punjab                                            .... Respondent\n\n\n                                JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1. Leave Granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2. The present appeal is filed by the appellant being aggrieved by the\n\n   judgment and order of the learned Single Judge of the Punjab &amp;\n\n   Haryana High Court affirming the judgment and order of the learned\n\n   Additional Sessions Judge, Patiala finding the appellant- accused guilty\n\n   of the offence alleged against him. The learned Additional Sessions\n\n   Judge, found the appellant-accused guilty and convicted him under\n\n   <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 304</a> Part II of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (for short `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') and\n\n   sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for eight years.\n\n   However, in the appeal filed by the appellant as against the order of\n\n   conviction and sentence the learned Single Judge while maintaining the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                         2</span>\n\n   finding of guilt of the appellant converted the conviction of the appellant\n\n   from <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 304</a> Part II IPC to offence under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 304</a> Part I IPC\n\n   and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for five years.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3. In order to appreciate the contention raised by the appellant-accused\n\n   that the courts below have failed to properly analyse and scrutinise the\n\n   evidence of the solitary witness and that the presence of the said\n\n   solitary witness at the place of occurrence was not natural and also that\n\n   his testimony was not free from embellishment, we are required to\n\n   mention brief facts as alleged by the prosecution.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4. Ramtar (hereinafter referred to as `deceased') was the younger brother\n\n   of the Harjinder Kumar, the complainant, both sons of Jiwa Nath. The\n\n   deceased was employed as a driver of a Maruti Van bearing\n\n   Registration No. PB-01-0353 belonging to Gurdev Singh, resident of\n\n   village Sular.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">      On 15.11.1993, Harjinder Kumar was proceeding from village Phagan\n\nMajra to meet Mohinder Singh son of Kartar Singh and at about 6.30 p.m.,\n\nhe reached the bus stop of village Phagan Majra, where he met Manjit\n\nSingh, Sarpanch and Chanan Singh, Member Panchayat of village Kasiana.\n\nThey all then started to village Phagan Majra. When they reached the point\n\nfrom where a kacha path takes off to village Kasiana, they found the\n\nabovementioned Maruti Van with its headlight on, lying parked with its\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                                        3</span>\n\nwindows open at a distance of about 1 = Killa from the metalled road. On\n\nsuspicion, they went towards the van and on reaching there, they found\n\ndeceased seated on the right rear seat and accused Jarnail Singh seated on\n\nthe left rear seat of the van.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">      Accused was putting pressure on deceased to take the van by kacha\n\npath way to village Kasiana but the decease was disinclined. An exchange\n\nof hot words ensued. Accused dealt two stab blows with knife, one on the\n\nchest and other on right flank of deceased.         The deceased became\n\nunconscious and rolled down on the ground through the right window of the\n\nvan. On sensing that deceased has succumbed to the injuries, accused\n\nplunged the knife into his chest, in order to commit suicide.   The knife fell\n\ndown from his grip in the van.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">      After having arranged a tractor the deceased and accused were\n\nbrought to Rajindra Hospital, Patiala. On reaching the hospital, Harjinder\n\nKumar and others were told by doctor that deceased had already expired.\n\nHarjinder Kumar and Manjit Singh left for the Police Station, Sadar Patiala.\n\nWhen they reached near the general bus stand, Patiala they came across\n\nASI Karnail Singh alongwith other police officials at about 10.30 p.m.\n\nHarjinder Kumar made statement Ex. PD before the ASI who made his\n\nendorsement Ex.PD/1 and sent the same to the Police Station where on its\n\nbasis formal FIR Ex. PD/2 was recorded.        ASI Karnail Singh alongwith\n\nHarjinder Kumar, Manjit Singh and other police officials went to Rajindra\n\nHospital, Patiala. At that time the dead house was lying locked. Early in the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                      4</span>\n\nmorning at about 6.30 a.m. Raj Kumar the attendant came to the dead\n\nhouse and opened the same. The dead body of deceased was identified by\n\nHarjinder Kumar and Manjit Singh. The ASI prepared the Inquest Report\n\nEx. PA/1 and handed over the dead body alongwith request Ex. PA/2 to\n\nConstable Gurdeep Singh for postmortem examination.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      ASI in the company of Harjinder Singh, Manjit Singh and other police\n\nofficials went to the scene of crime, and prepared site plan Ex. PW 11/A\n\nshowing the place of occurrence. He seized the knife Ex. P1, which was\n\nallegedly stained with blood. The same was converted into a parcel after\n\npreparing its rough sketch Ex. PW 11/B.           The knife was taken into\n\npossession vide memo Ex. PW 10/A. Some portion of the rear seat of the\n\nvan which was blood stained alongwith its foam was also removed and\n\nturned into a parcel with seal `GS' and taken into possession vide memo Ex\n\nPW.10/E. The van alongwith its Registration Certificate Ex. PW 10/D was\n\nalso seized vide memo Ex. PW 10/C. Thereafter ASI came to Rajindra\n\nHospital, Patiala and took into possession the parcel containing clothes of\n\nthe deceased. He deputed some constables including Amar Singh to guard\n\nthe accused in the hospital.       He went back to the police station on\n\n16.11.1993 and deposited the case property with seals intact with MHC\n\nBhupinder Singh. He arrested the accused on 9.12.1993. After completion\n\nof investigation, the charge-sheet was filed in the court of learned Chief\n\nJudicial Magistrate, Patiala, who vide his order dated 15.03.1994 committed\n\nthe case to the court of learned Sessions Judge, Patiala for trial.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                                      5</span>\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">5. The accused was charged u/s 302 <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_5\">IPC</a> as well as u/s 309 <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_6\">IPC</a>.\n\n  However, the charge u/s 309 <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_7\">IPC</a> was deleted subsequently. In order to\n\n  substantiate its case, the prosecution examined 12 witnesses in all.\n\n  Harjinder Singh who was the eye witness and complainant was\n\n  examined as PW7. Manjit Singh, Sarpanch, the alleged eye witness\n\n  was also examined as PW6 but he did not support the prosecution\n\n  version, not even the presence of PW7 at the time of occurrence.\n\n  Consequently he was declared hostile. Chanan Singh another alleged\n\n  eye witness was given up on the ground that he has been won over by\n\n  the accused.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">6. In the FIR it was stated by PW-7, the alleged eye witness, that the\n\n  deceased brother first gave a knife blow in the chest of the accused and\n\n  thereafter the accused gave two stab blows with his knife on the person\n\n  of deceased. The same set of allegation was made by said PW-7 even\n\n  before the police during the course of investigation. However, during\n\n  the trial he stated that there was an exchange of hot words between the\n\n  accused and the deceased consequent to which the accused gave two\n\n  stab blows with the knife to the deceased, one of which fell on the chest\n\n  whereas the other on the right flank of the deceased. It was also stated\n\n  in the evidence by the said PW-7 that on seeing that the deceased had\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                        6</span>\n\n   died the accused attempted to commit suicide by plunging the knife on\n\n   the left side of his chest.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">7. On the other hand, the accused put forth that he was learning driving\n\n   from the deceased, who was his friend. He stated that on the day of the\n\n   occurrence three unidentified person hired the van of the deceased and\n\n   on reaching the spot, deceased refused to take his van on kacha path\n\n   and those person picked up a row with him and they assaulted both the\n\n   deceased and the accused with the Gatra Kirpan due to which both of\n\n   them suffered injuries. He further stated that he became unconscious\n\n   on receipt of injury in his stomach and subsequently he was involved in\n\n   this case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">8. The learned Additional Sessions Judge, on appreciation of the evidence\n\n   on record held that though the injury on the accused could have been\n\n   self inflicted as stated by the doctor, but even considering that the same\n\n   was inflicted in self-defence, the right of self-defence to the extent of\n\n   causing the death of the deceased was not available to the accused.\n\n   On noticing and appreciating the fact that there was allegation of an\n\n   exchange of hot words and that the incident occurred at the spur of the\n\n   moment without any premeditation, the learned Additional Sessions\n\n   Judge found the accused guilty and convicted him under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 304</a>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                          <a href=\"/doc/1597655/\" id=\"a_9\">7</a></span>\n\n   Part II IPC and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for\n\n   eight years.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">9. On an appeal being filed by the appellant as against the aforesaid order\n\n   of conviction and sentence the learned Single Judge heard the parties\n\n   on merits. While maintaining the finding of guilt against the appellant the\n\n   learned Single Judge, however, convicted the appellant under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_10\">Section\n\n   304</a> Part I IPC by altering the same from one under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 304</a> Part II\n\n   IPC. However, taking into consideration the fact that the accused has\n\n   become permanently physically handicapped and his disability is 80%\n\n   the learned Single Judge reduced the sentence to five years instead of\n\n   eight years.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">10.The accused filed the present appeal as against the aforesaid orders.\n\n   We have heard the learned counsel appearing for the appellant-\n\n   accused as also learned counsel appearing for the State and also\n\n   scrutinised the evidence on record.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">11.The learned counsel appearing for the appellant submitted before us\n\n   that the presence of PW-7, the only eye witness supporting the alleged\n\n   story of the prosecution, at the spot is too providential to be true. It was\n\n   also submitted that although it is alleged that the First Information\n\n   Report was recorded at 10.30 or 11.00 p.m., but in the inquest report\n\n   which was drawn at 7.00 a.m. on the next day, in the place of the F.I.R\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                                        8</span>\n\n   number no particulars were given and only a dash was shown and the\n\n   F.I.R number was inserted at the later point of time. Relying on the said\n\n   fact it was submitted that the first information report was submitted late\n\n   and belatedly on the next date i.e. on 16.11.1993 at about 9.00 a.m. He\n\n   further submitted that the statement of PW-7 is full of embellishment\n\n   and contradictions from his previous statement. He drew our attention\n\n   to the allegation made in the first information report and to the\n\n   statement of said PW-7.      He submitted that said PW-7 is neither\n\n   trustworthy nor reliable, and therefore, the appellant should have been\n\n   acquitted instead of being convicted in the aforesaid manner.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">12.The learned counsel appearing for the respondent, on the other hand,\n\n   submitted that both the courts below namely the High Court and the\n\n   learned Additional Sessions Judge found the appellant guilty of the\n\n   offence and the said findings and conclusion reached should not be\n\n   interfered with.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">13.The learned Additional Sessions Judge found the appellant guilty of the\n\n   offence and convicted the appellant-accused under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 304</a> Part II\n\n   IPC. The prosecution did not file any appeal as against the aforesaid\n\n   order of conviction and sentence whereas the appellant-accused filed\n\n   an appeal against his order of conviction.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                        9</span><p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">14.It is established fact that the offence of <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 304</a> Part I IPC is of a\n\n   higher degree than that of the offence under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 304</a> Part II IPC, as\n\n   also held in <a href=\"/doc/561833/\" id=\"a_15\">Ruli Ram v. State of Haryana</a> [(2002) 7 SCC 691, Para 8].\n\n   The learned Single Judge, therefore, was not justified in converting the\n\n   order of conviction and altering the same from <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 304</a> Part II IPC to\n\n   <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 304</a> Part I IPC, particularly when the prosecution did not file any\n\n   appeal. By virtue of the order passed by the learned Single Judge the\n\n   appellant stood convicted of a higher degree of offence than that of\n\n   <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 304</a> Part II IPC, although the learned Single Judge altered the\n\n   sentence from eight years to five years. In the case of <a href=\"/doc/1534338/\" id=\"a_19\">Abdul Aziz v.\n\n   State of Rajasthan</a> [(2007) 10 SCC 283] it was held by this Court that if\n\n   a person is charged under a grave Section, but however, if acquitted\n\n   under the said grave section by the Trial Court, then it would amount to\n\n   travesty of Justice if in his own appeal he is convicted under that grave\n\n   section, without there being any appeal from the State and without there\n\n   being prior notice of enhancement issued by the appellate Court.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">15.Be that as it may, it is necessary now to consider whether the\n\n   prosecution case as alleged could be said to be trustworthy and reliable,\n\n   for which we are required to refer and analyse the evidence as adduced\n\n   by the parties.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                                                       10</span><p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">16.According to the prosecution the incident took place on 15.11.1993 at\n\n  about 6.30 p.m. which was an incident happening on an evening of the\n\n  winter season.    The deceased who was the brother of PW-7 was\n\n  allegedly driving the van which was parked at the place of incident with\n\n  windows open and headlights on, which meant that it was dark at that\n\n  point of time. Although it was a winter night still the windows of the car\n\n  were kept open, for which according to the prosecution, PW-7 could see\n\n  the entire incident.   In the first information report PW-7 stated that\n\n  initially a knife blow was given by the deceased to the accused and\n\n  thereafter the accused gave two knife blows to the deceased, which\n\n  resulted in his death and consequently his body came out of the\n\n  window. The aforesaid version as stated in the first information report,\n\n  was however, later on changed and altered when PW-7 deposed in the\n\n  court that the accused after giving two knife blows to the deceased\n\n  attempted to commit suicide by plunging the knife in his chest.         In\n\n  support of the said contention reliance was placed on the evidence of\n\n  the doctor who has stated during his examination that the aforesaid\n\n  injury on the accused could have been self inflicted also. PW-7 is said\n\n  to be the eye witness who has allegedly seen the entire occurrence\n\n  including the exchange of hot words between the appellant and the\n\n  deceased in a winter night and that also when it was totally dark.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                                                         11</span>\n\n   According to him, he could see the entire incident in the light of the\n\n   headlight of the car.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_33\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_34\">17.The aforesaid statement of PW-7 does not appear to be trustworthy and\n\n   reliable for the simple reason that even though the headlight of the car\n\n   was on, it would be lighting only the front portion and not the side of the\n\n   car and may not even have lighted sufficiently to enable PW 7 to see as\n\n   to what had happened inside the car. Although it was a winter night it is\n\n   not stated nor understood as to why the windows of the car were kept\n\n   open. It is also not stated by PW-7 that he had made any effort to help\n\n   or render assistance to stop the verbal dual between the accused and\n\n   the deceased or took any effective steps to stop the stabbing on both\n\n   the persons. PW-7 had further stated that his brother was a driver of\n\n   the van and that the incident had happened because he was unwilling to\n\n   take the vehicle by the village path. However, in his deposition he has\n\n   stated that his brother was seated at the back seat alongwith the\n\n   deceased.    It is not understood as to why the driver of the vehicle\n\n   driving the car would seat in the back seat of the car instead of driving\n\n   the car from the front seat. Presence of PW-7 at the spot at that point\n\n   of time was also providential and he has been examined only as a\n\n   chance witness. The other alleged eye witness namely Chanan Singh,\n\n   Member Panchayat of village Kasiana was not examined at all on the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                                                        12</span>\n\n   ground that he was won over by the accused. Manjit Singh, Sarpanch\n\n   who is stated to be the last and third eye witness turned hostile.\n\n   Therefore, out of the three eye witnesses' one has become hostile\n\n   whereas the other was not examined at all by the prosecution and we\n\n   have only one eye witness PW-7, who happens to be the brother of the\n\n   deceased. If his evidence is discarded there is no other evidence on\n\n   the basis of which the accused could be convicted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_35\">It is no doubt true that conviction could be based on the sole testimony of a\n\nsolitary eye witness but in order to be the basis of conviction his presence\n\nat the place of occurrence has to be natural and his testimony should be\n\nstrong and reliable and free from any blemish. <a href=\"/doc/391420/\" id=\"a_20\">In Chuhar Singh v. State\n\nof Haryana</a>, [(1976) 1 SCC 879] this Court held that what is important is\n\nnot how many witnesses have been examined by the prosecution but what\n\nis the nature and quality of evidence on which it relies. The evidence of a\n\nsingle witness may sustain a sentence of death whereas a host of\n\nvulnerable witnesses may fail to support a simple charge of hurt. Since the\n\ncase must stand or fall by the evidence of single witness, it is necessary to\n\nexamine that evidence critically.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_36\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_37\">18.However, when we scrutinize the evidence of PW-7, in the present\n\n   case, we do not find him to be trustworthy and reliable witness for he is\n\n   changing his version frequently. He had given one version in the F.I.R\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">\f                                                                    13</span>\n\nwhich is reiterated during the course of investigation before the police\n\nwhereas he had given a totally different version at the time of his\n\nstatement before the court. He had stated in the F.I.R that following the\n\naltercation between the deceased and the accused the deceased first\n\ngave a knife blow. When inquest proceedings took place on the next\n\nday at 7.00 a.m. he stuck to the same version and during investigation\n\nalso he confirmed the aforesaid allegation made by him whereas in the\n\ntrial he stated that the accused first gave two knife blows to the\n\ndeceased and then he tried to commit suicide by giving a knife blow to\n\nhimself.   He had also stated that on receiving those two blows the\n\ndeceased came through the window and fell down on the ground. The\n\nsaid version also cannot be believed for the deceased after receiving\n\nthe injuries could not have gone out of the window unless the door was\n\nopen. The car was allegedly parked with the headlights on and if that\n\nwas so, the key of the car was available in the starting/ignition switch\n\nand, therefore, there was no reason why the said car could not have\n\nbeen driven with the dead body of the deceased and the injured to the\n\nhospital as also to the police station by the said PW-7 and the other\n\nwitnesses allegedly with him at that point of time for it has come in\n\nevidence that the other witness knew driving as he was driving the\n\ntractor.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                                                        14</span><p id=\"p_38\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_39\">19.The prosecution also examined Balbir Singh, PW-8, who stated that he\n\n   is the owner and driver of a taxi and on 15.11.1993 Jarnail Singh hired\n\n   the taxi of Ramtar in his presence and after that Ramtar never returned.\n\n   The deposition of the said witness is also found to be not worthy of\n\n   reliance for he did not produce any registration certificate.     On his\n\n   statement that he was owning a taxi, he later said that he had sold the\n\n   taxi. He also stated in his evidence that he is unable to recollect as to\n\n   where from he had purchased the taxi or to whom he had sold his taxi.\n\n   He also stated in his deposition that he was holding a forged driving\n\n   license. These circumstances make him totally unreliable.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_40\">20.The entire story sought to be put forth by the prosecution and by PW-7\n\n   particularly appears to be doubtful and full of contradictions. It will be\n\n   unsafe to convict a person on the basis of such unreliable and\n\n   untrustworthy evidence particularly when such statements are full of\n\n   embellishment and contradictions, without corroboration in material\n\n   particulars by reliable testimony, direct or circumstantial. Consequently,\n\n   we set aside the order of conviction and sentence passed against the\n\n   appellant and give him benefit of doubt. He stands acquitted of the\n\n   charges. He shall be set free immediately, unless required in any other\n\n   matter.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_41\">21.The appeal is accordingly allowed.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">\f                                                         15</span><p id=\"p_42\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_43\">                   .................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_44\">                   (Altamas Kabir)\n\n\n                   .................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_45\">                   (Dr. Mukundakam Sharma)\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_46\">January 15, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"interpretation","formInput":"interpretation"},{"value":"dumping","formInput":"dumping"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"anti dumping","formInput":"anti%20dumping"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Designated Auth.Min.Of Com.& ... vs Indian Metals & Ferro Alloys Ltd on 27 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33556","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-27","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Designated Auth.Min.Of Com.&amp; ... vs Indian Metals &amp; Ferro Alloys Ltd on 27 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n           SPECIAL LEAVE PETITION (C) NO 1795 OF 2009\n\n\nDesignated Authority, Ministry of Commerce\n&amp; Industry &amp; Anr.                                        ...Petitioners\n\n\n                          Versus\n\nIndian Metals &amp; Ferro Alloys Ltd.                        ...Respondent\n\n\n                              JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in this petition is to the order passed by the Division Bench\n\nof the Delhi High Court allowing the writ petition filed by the respondent.\n\nThe issue before the High Court was with regard to interpretation of Anti\n\nDumping provisions of the <a href=\"/doc/442204/\" id=\"a_1\">Customs Tariff Act</a>, 1975 (in short the `Act')\n\nand the Custom Tariff (Identification, Assessment and Collection of Anti-\n\nDumping Duty on Dumped Articles and For Determination of Injury) Rules,\n\n1995 (hereinafter referred to as the `Rules').\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">\f2.    The writ petition was allowed primarily relying on <a href=\"/doc/806084/\" id=\"a_2\">Reliance\n\nIndustries Ltd. v. Designated Authority and Ors</a>. (2006 (10) SCC 368) and\n\nthe interpretation placed on <a href=\"/doc/946858/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 9A(5)</a> of the Act in the matter and scope\n\nof <a href=\"/doc/946858/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 9A(5)</a> of the Act as considered by this Court in <a href=\"/doc/953834/\" id=\"a_5\">Rishiroop\n\nPolymers (P) Ltd. v. Designated Authority &amp; Ors</a>. (2006 (4) SCC 303).\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.    It is submitted by learned counsel for the appellant that the issues are\n\nof complex nature and will have wide ramifications on domestic and\n\ninternational business and commerce.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.    We are of the view that the view expressed in Reliance Industries\n\ncase (supra) needs a fresh look and following questions need to be dealt\n\nwith by a Larger Bench:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">      (1)   Whether the interpretation that Anti Dumping Duty is country\n\n            specific rather than exporter specific in consonance with the\n\n            provision of Rules 12, 15, 17(3), 18, 19(3) and Annexure 1 to\n\n            the Rules.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n</blockquote><p id=\"p_9\">\f      (2)   Whether the interpretation placed upon Rule 7 of the Rules is\n\n            correct in so far as it diminishes the Rule of confidentiality\n\n            statutorily provided for under Rule 7.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.    The records be placed before the Hon'ble the Chief Justice of India\n\nfor necessary orders.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">                                       ...........................................J.\n                                       (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                       ..........................................J.\n                                       (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 27, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                   3</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1503498,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":946858,"url":null,"title":"Section 9A in The Customs Tariff Act,   1975"},{"tid":442204,"url":null,"title":"The Customs Tariff Act,   1975"},{"tid":806084,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=29773","title":"Reliance Industries Ltd vs Designated Authority And Ors on 11 September, 2006"},{"tid":953834,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=27740","title":"Rishiroop Polymers Pvt. Ltd vs Designated Authority & ... on 23 March, 2006"}]}, {"numcites":2,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"construction workers","formInput":"construction%20workers"},{"value":"what is cess","formInput":"what%20is%20cess"},{"value":"union and its territory","formInput":"union%20and%20its%20territory"},{"value":"beneficiary","formInput":"beneficiary"}],"firstname":null,"title":"National Campaign Commtt., C.L., ... vs Union Of India & Ors on 13 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33879","lastname":"...................","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-13","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">National Campaign Commtt., C.L., ... vs Union Of India &amp; Ors on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...................</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: K.G. Balakrishnan, P. Sathasivam, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                 1\n\n                                                            REPORTABLE\n                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                         CIVIL ORIGINAL JURISDICTION\n\n                     WRIT PETITION(C) NO.318 OF 2006\n\n\n     NATIONAL CAMPAIGN COMMTT.,C.L.LABOUR                ...PETITIONER.\n\n            VERSUS\n\n     UNION OF INDIA &amp; ORS.                          ...RESPONDENTS.\n\n\n                                  ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">      The Building and Other Construction Workers (Regulation of\n\nEmployment and Conditions of Service) Act, 1996 (for short 'The Act'),\n\nwas passed by the Parliament and in this writ petition it is alleged that\n\nmany of the provisions of the enactment are not put in practice and the\n\nrespective authorities have not complied with the statutory provisions.\n\nAll the State Governments and Union territories are impleaded as parties\n\nin this writ petition.   The Act is intended to benefit the unorganized\n\nworkers in the construction sector.         Under Section 6 of the Act, the\n\nappropriate Government has to appoint registering officers and under\n\nSection 7 of the Act every employer shall register their establishment.\n\nThe building workers are given various benefits and in order to enable\n\nthe workers to avail the benefits, each State has to constitute a State\n\nWelfare Board. The Board shall consist of a Chairman nominated by the\n\nCentral Government, and such other Members, not exceeding 15, as may\n\nbe appointed by the State Government.            The Board shall appoint a\n\nSecretary as its Chief Executive Officer.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                         2</span><p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">         Under Section 22 of the Act, the Board may provide immediate\n\nassistance to the beneficiaries in case of accident, and also pay\n\ncompensation to those workers who had completed the age of sixty\n\nyears.     The Board may also sanction loans and advances to the\n\nbeneficiaries and also to give financial assistance for the education of\n\nchildren of the beneficiaries and also to give the benefit of group\n\ninsurance schemes. The Board can also grant maternity benefit to the\n\nfemale beneficiaries. A construction welfare fund has to be constituted\n\nand there are other provisions also to regulate the conditions of service\n\nof construction workers. There are also provisions to take care of the\n\nsafety and health conditions of the workers. In order to implement the\n\nprovisions there shall be inspecting staff and certain penal provisions are\n\nalso in the Act to punish those who act in violation of the provisions of\n\nenactment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">         The   Parliament   has   also   passed   the   Building   and   <a href=\"/doc/611977/\" id=\"a_1\">Other\n\nConstruction Workers Welfare Cess Act</a>, 1996 for the purpose of levy and\n\ncollection of cess and <a href=\"/doc/1902664/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 3</a> of the Act envisages that- there shall be\n\nlevied and collected a cess for the purposes of the Building and Other\n\nConstruction Workers (Regulation of Employment and Conditions of\n\nService) Act, 1996, at such rate not exceeding two percent; but not less\n\nthan one per cent of the cost of construction incurred by an employer, as\n\nthe Central Government may specify for him to time. <a href=\"/doc/611977/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 62</a> of the\n\nBuilding and\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                      3</span>\n\n<a href=\"/doc/611977/\" id=\"a_4\">Other Construction Workers Welfare Cess Act</a> says that proper Rules are\n\nto be framed by the Government after consultation with the expert\n\ncommittee.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">             The learned counsel appearing for the writ petitioners filed a\n\nchart before us indicating the steps that had been taken by the various\n\nstate governments. It says that many of the governments had not taken\n\nsteps as per the provisions of the Act.       Though some of the state\n\ngovernments have collected cess but the benefits have not been fully\n\npassed on to the construction workers. Some of the State governments\n\nhave not constituted either the State Advisory Committee or the expert\n\ncommittee or the Welfare Board as envisaged under the Act.       The Delhi\n\nGovernment has framed detailed Rules, namely, the Delhi Building and\n\nOther Construction Workers (Regulation of Employment and Conditions\n\nof Service) Rules, 2002.   These Rules exclusively deal with the matter\n\nand gives various model forms also for compliance of the provisions of\n\nthe Act. The State Governments and Union Territories which have not\n\nframed the rules as per <a href=\"/doc/611977/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 62</a> of the Act can very well take the Delhi\n\nBuilding and Other Construction Workers (Regulation of Employment and\n\nConditions of Service) Rules 2002, as a model and the same can be\n\nadopted for the purpose of this Act.      Copy of the same is available on\n\ninternet and the same can be had from the Government of Delhi.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">             We direct the Chief Secretary of the respective States and\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                      4</span>\n\n Secretary (Labour) of each States and the Union Territories to take timely\n\n steps as per the provisions of the Act, if not already done.     We would\n\n like to have the appraisal report in the first week of May as to what steps\n\n have been taken in this regard. If any of the State Government has not\n\n done anything pursuant to the Act, urgent steps are to be taken so that\n\n the benefits of this legislation shall not go waste.        Otherwise the\n\n unorganized workers of the construction sector will be denied the\n\n benefit of the Act.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">       Post in the 1st week of May, 2009.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">       A copy of the order be sent to the Chief Secretary of all the States\n\n and Secretary (Labour) of each State and the Union Territories for taking\n\n further action in this regard.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                     ...................CJI\n                                                  (K.G. BALAKRISHNAN)\n\n\n\n                                       .....................J\n                                                (P. SATHASIVAM)\n\n\n\n                                       .....................J\n                                                (J.M. PANCHAL)\n  NEW DELHI;\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">JANUARY 13, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":177171,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":611977,"url":null,"title":"THE BUILDING AND OTHER CONSTRUCTION WORKERS' WELFARE CESS ACT, 1996"},{"tid":1902664,"url":null,"title":"Section 3 in THE BUILDING AND OTHER CONSTRUCTION WORKERS' WELFARE CESS ACT, 1996"}]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"ghaziabad","formInput":"ghaziabad"},{"value":"national consumer disputes redressal commission ","formInput":"national%20consumer%20disputes%20redressal%20commission%20"},{"value":"ghaziabad development authority","formInput":"ghaziabad%20development%20authority"},{"value":"award of interest","formInput":"award%20of%20interest"},{"value":"urmila","formInput":"urmila"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Ghaziabad Development Authority vs Urmila on 22 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=34001","lastname":"......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-22","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Ghaziabad Development Authority vs Urmila on 22 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: B.N. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                         CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NO.3727 OF 2001\n\n\nGhaziabad Development Authority                  ...Appellant(s)\n\n\n                                        Versus\n\n\nUrmila                                                     ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                          With Civil Appeal No.6955 of 2004\n\n\n                                    O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Civil Appeal No.3727 of 2004:\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">          Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">          The District Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum, Ghaziabad (for short,\n\"the District Forum\") by its order dated 20th January, 1999, partly allowed the\ncomplaint filed by respondent-Urmila and directed Ghaziabad Development\nAuthority (hereinafter referred to as \"the Authority\") to remove the defects in the\nhouse allotted to the respondent with the stipulation that if the needful is not done,\nthen decision will be taken in the execution proceedings for award of the amount\nspent by the complainant on removal of the defects. The District Forum further\ndirected the Authority to pay interest to the respondent at the rate of 15 per cent per\nannum for the period from 1st April, 1995 to 6th September, 1996 on the amount\ndeposited by her up to 31st March, 1995 and Rupees four thousand towards mental\nagony and cost of litigation as, in its opinion, there was delay on the part of the\nAuthority in delivering possession of the house to the respondent. The said order was\nconfirmed in appeal by\n                                                                                  ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                         -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">the State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission, U.P.(for short, \"the State\nCommission\") and when the matter         was taken in revision before the National\nConsumer Disputes Redressal Commission (for short, \"the National Commission\"),\nthe same has been dismissed. Hence, this appeal by special leave.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant-Authority submitted\nthat the District Forum was not justified in directing it to remove the defects in the\nhouse allotted to the respondent on the basis of report dated 15th September, 1996\nprepared by the Engineer appointed by her because she had taken possession of the\nhouse without making any grievance regarding the so-called defects. In our view,\nthere is no merit in the submission of the learned counsel and the direction given by\nthe District Forum does not call for interference because the Authority did not adduce\nany evidence before the District Forum to controvert the report produced by the\nrespondent. If the house was free from defects on the date of delivery of possession\nand the Authority thought that report dated 15th September, 1996 does not reflect the\ntrue status of the house, then it could have, on receipt of the notice of the complaint,\ndeputed its own engineer for inspection and submitted report before the District\nForum to convince it that the grievance made by the respondent was untenable.\nHowever, the fact of the matter is that no such report was produced by the Authority.\nTherefore, we do not find any justification to interfere with the direction given by the\nDistrict Forum, which was confirmed by the State Commission as well as the National\nCommission.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           Learned counsel for the appellant next submitted that the District Forum\nwas not justified in awarding interest on the amount deposited by the respondent up\nto 31st March, 1995 because there was no delay in the delivery of possession of the\nhouse. Learned counsel pointed out that in terms of letter dated 3rd February, 1993\nthe respondent was required to\n                                                                                   ...3/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                          -3-</span>\n<p id=\"p_7\">pay balance of the estimated cost by 30th July, 1995 but she did not pay the\ninstalments on due dates and the last one was paid after more than one year and four\nmonths of the delivery of possession. Learned counsel for the respondent fairly\nadmitted that his client did not pay instalments of the balance estimated cost on due\ndates. In this view of the matter, the Authority cannot be blamed for delay in\nhanding over possession of the house to the respondent. Even otherwise, we are\nsatisfied that the finding recorded by the District Forum on the issue of delay in the\ndelivery of possession is based on total misreading of letter dated 3rd February, 1993\nand the pleadings of the parties. The District Forum completely ignored the fact that\nthe respondent had not paid even a single instalment on due date and even as on the\ndate of handing over possession, substantial amount was due from her. A reading of\nletter dated 3rd February, 1993 shows that the respondent was required to pay\ninstalments of the balance estimated costs between 30th January, 1993 and 30th July,\n1995. It was mentioned in that letter that the expected date of delivery of possession of\nthe house would be during the year 1995, which would necessarily mean after\npayment of the instalments by 30th July, 1995. It was further mentioned in the letter\nthat if the house is made ready before one or more instalments are due, then\npossession of the same would be made over to the complainant only upon payment of\nentire balance instalments in one lump sum. In paragraph (4) of the complaint the\nrespondent has given a table of the instalments paid by her. A reading thereof makes\nit clear that not a single instalment was paid within time. Till the year 1994, the\nrespondent paid only a sum of Rupees one lakh. No payment was made in the year\n1995 and substantial amount was paid between the years 1996 and 1998. The last\ninstalment was paid on 16th January, 1998. From these facts it is evident that there\nwere laches on the part of the respondent\n                                                                                    ...4/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                           -4-</span>\n<p id=\"p_8\">in payment of the instalments. In this view of the matter, it must be held that District\nForum was not justified in awarding interest upon the amount deposited till 31st\nMarch, 1995 and the sum of Rupees four thousand by way of compensation for\nmental agony as also cost of litigation.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed in part and the impugned order passed\nby the District Forum awarding interest from 1st April, 1995 till 6th September, 1996\nand sum of Rupees four thousand by way of compensation and the orders of the State\nCommission and the National Commission confirming the same are set aside.\nCIVIL APPEAL NO. 6955 OF 2004:\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">           Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">           By the impugned order, the National Consumer Disputes Redressal\nCommission (for short \"the National Commission\"), has remanded the matter to the\nDistrict Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum, Ghaziabad (for short, \"the District\nForum\") for calculation of the amount payable to the respondent as also the amount\ndue to the appellant-Authority. The District Forum, on remand, is directed to pass a\nfresh order, as directed by the National Commission, after taking into consideration\nthe order passed by us today in Civil Appeal No. 3727 of 2001.\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">           With this direction, the civil appeal is disposed of.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_13\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                                                 [B.N. AGRAWAL]\n\n\n\n                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                                 [G.S. Rocklines Constructions and Anr.     ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                                    O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Delay condoned.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">          Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">          By the impugned order, the National Consumer Disputes             Redressal\nCommission (hereinafter referred to as `the National Commission') dismissed the\noriginal complaints as, in its opinion, the complainants were not \"consumer\" within\nthe meaning of <a href=\"/doc/992267/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 2(1)(d)</a> of the Consumer Protection Act, 1986 (for short, `the\nAct') and Respondent No.1 was not a \"service provider\" within the meaning of\n<a href=\"/doc/1809742/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 2(1)(o)</a> of the Act. The point raised in this case is concluded by the judgment\nof this case in <a href=\"/doc/1048731/\" id=\"a_3\">Faqir Chand Gulati vs. Uppal Agencies Private Limited and Another</a>\n[2008 (10) SCC 345] in which this Court dealt with a case similar to that of the\nappellants and held that complaint is maintainable.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">                                                                                 ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                         -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">            In view of this, the appeals are allowed, impugned order is set aside and\nthe matter is remitted to the National Commission for disposal of the complaints in\naccordance with law after giving opportunity of hearing to the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">            As the complaint petitions were filed in the years 1998 and 1999, the\nNational Commission is requested to dispose of the matter as expeditiously as\npossible.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">                                                                          ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                               [B.N. SINGHVI]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 05, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1101970,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":992267,"url":null,"title":"Section 2(1)(d) in the Consumer Protection Act, 1986"},{"tid":1048731,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=31822","title":"Faqir Chand Gulati vs Uppal Agencies Pvt. Ltd. & Anr on 10 July, 2008"},{"tid":1809742,"url":null,"title":"Section 2(1)(o) in the Consumer Protection Act, 1986"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"section 351","formInput":"section%20351"},{"value":"351","formInput":"351"},{"value":"interim injunction","formInput":"interim%20injunction"},{"value":"ganguli","formInput":"ganguli"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Prakash Harichandra Muranjan vs Mumbai Metropolitan ... on 23 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33552","lastname":".......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-23","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Prakash Harichandra Muranjan vs Mumbai Metropolitan ... on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: .......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                           NON-REPORTABLE\n\n                IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                 CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n          CIVIL APPEAL NO._392_____/2009\n(@ SPECIAL LEAVE PETITION (CIVIL) NO.21543 OF 2006)\n\n\nPrakash Harishchandra Muranjan                   ...Appellant\n\n\n            - Versus -\n\n\nMumbai Metropolitan Region\nDevelopment Authority and Another             ..Respondent(s)\n\n\n                        J U D G M E N T\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">GANGULY, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">  1.        Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">       2.   The   Appellant   impugns     the    judgment     and\n\n       order    dated   23.11.2006   passed     by   a    learned\n\n       Single Judge of the High Court of Bombay in an\n\n       appeal from Order No. 688 of 2006 of City Civil\n\n       Court,     Mumbai   whereby    the       learned    Judge\n\n       rejected the application for injunction after a\n\n       detailed judgment dated 23.8.2006.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                              1</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">\f3.    The City Civil Court, Mumbai in a detailed\n\njudgment, came to a finding that the Plaintiff-\n\nAppellant herein failed to show that the suit\n\nstructures    existed    prior     to    datum    line       i.e.\n\nprior to 1962 and no Sanctioned Plan of the\n\nsuit structure was produced before the Court.\n\nThe    documentary     evidence,        produced       by     the\n\nPlaintiff-Appellant was discrepant in that the\n\nAssessment Numbers and the addresses did not\n\ntally.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">4.    Further finding of the City Civil Court,\n\nMumbai was that the Appellant could not produce\n\nany documentary evidence to link the assessment\n\ndocuments with the suit structure and thus the\n\nCourt held that the Appellant failed to make\n\nout    any    prima-facie       case      for     grant        of\n\ninjunction.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">5.    Virtually   on    those    findings,       the    prayer\n\nfor injunction was concurrently refused by the\n\nHigh Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">6.    Apart   from   those   two    proceedings,            other\n\nproceedings were also initiated in respect of\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                         2</span>\n\fthe structures in question as would appear from\n\nthe facts discussed below.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">7.     The    Appellant       claims       to     be    one     of    the\n\nowners       of   land      measuring       485     square       yards,\n\nbearing       Survey        No.35,        Hissa        No.1     (Part),\n\nC.T.S.No.688,          situated       at     Saki       Vihar     Road,\n\nKilick Nikason Marol, Andheri (East), Mumbai-\n\n40007       and   a   Chawl       standing      thereon       and    the\n\nAppellant claims that his father constructed\n\nthe same Chawl in the year 1956 and the shops\n\ntherein       were    let     out    to    various       tenants      on\n\nrent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">8.    One    of   the    tenants          Chetan       Prakash       Jain\n\nreceived      a    notice      under      Section       351     of   the\n\nMumbai Municipal Corporation Act (hereinafter\n\n`the said Act'), from the second respondent who\n\nhad issued the same in purported exercise of\n\nthe powers delegated to him under Section 4A of\n\nthe     Mumbai        Metropolitan         Region        Development\n\nAuthority Act, 1974 (hereinafter `the Act of\n\n1974'). The noticee was asked to show cause why\n\nthe shop in his possession be not demolished\n\nsince it has been constructed in contravention\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                              3</span>\n\fof the provisions of Section 347 of the said\n\nAct.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">9.     That    notice        was        replied     to      by     Chetan\n\nPrakash Jain to the effect that the structure\n\nin question was in existence much prior to the\n\ndate of the notice and hence the same is a\n\ntolerable structure under the said Act and is\n\nnot required to be removed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">10.     The grievance             of    the     Appellant        is    that\n\nthe     second        Respondent             without     giving         the\n\nnoticee an opportunity of being heard, passed\n\nan order directing him to remove the portion of\n\nthe     structure       to        be    affected       by    the      road\n\nwidening scheme and to hand over the possession\n\nof     the    same     to     the       first     Respondent.          The\n\nfurther grievance is that no such notice was\n\ngiven    to     the    other          tenants    and/or      adjoining\n\nshop owners in the said Chawl.</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\n\n11.     Thereafter, in the second week of                          March,\n\n2006         some     of          the        officers       and         the\n\nrepresentatives              of        the      Respondent            No.1-\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_13\">Corporation allegedly fixed boundary marks in\n\nand around the said Chawl on the basis that the\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                  4</span>\n\farea covered under the said boundary wall would\n\nbe required for the widening of the road.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">12.     The Appellant and the other owners of the\n\nChawl    through       the   notice       of       their    Advocate\n\ndated     22.3.2006       claimed       to     have       placed     on\n\nrecord        correct     facts         and        documents       and\n\ncomplained       against         such    activities         of     the\n\nRespondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">13.     The    second     Respondent          while       exercising\n\nthe powers under Section 351 of the said Act\n\ndirected       Chetan     Prakash       by     a    notice       dated\n\n3.4.2006 to remove the suit structure, inter-\n\nalia,     on     the     ground         that       the     same     is\n\nunauthorized and not tolerable.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">14.     Against the said notice, a Writ Petition\n\nbeing    W.P.(L)       No.868      of    2006       was    filed    on\n\n12.4.2006 by the Appellant which was disposed\n\nof on the same very day by the Division Bench\n\nof the Bombay High Court, inter-alia, holding\n\nthat the first Respondent is to give notice to\n\nthe Petitioner No.1 who will accept the notice\n\non behalf of the Petitioners and all co-owners\n\nand     directed    the      first      Respondent          to     pass\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                             5</span>\n\fappropriate order according to law. The Court\n\nmade it clear that the construction shall not\n\nbe demolished without notice and hearing the\n\nPetitioner No.1.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">15.   Thereafter,       the      second     Respondent      on\n\n13.4.2006 sent several notices to the Appellant\n\nand other tenants under Section 351 of the said\n\nAct asking the occupants to vacate the suit\n\npremises and to remove the suit structure.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">16.     The case of the Appellant is that even\n\nthough the said notices were replied to, but no\n\nhearing was given to them nor were they given\n\ninspection of those orders by which the powers\n\nwere delegated upon the second Respondent by\n\nthe first Respondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">17.     The    second     Respondent,      it   is   alleged,\n\nwithout hearing the Appellant passed orders on\n\n13.5.06       declaring    the    suit    structure    to   be\n\nillegal       and   directing    the     Appellant    and   the\n\ntenants to remove the construction within seven\n\ndays.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">18.     Challenging the same, the Appellant filed\n\nL.C. Suit No. 2238 of 2006, out of which the\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                           6</span>\n\f  present proceedings arise, before the Bombay\n\n  City Civil Court praying for interim order. The\n\n  learned Trial Judge rejected on 19.5.2006 the\n\n  prayer for ad-interim injunction holding that\n\n  the    plaintiff    failed       to   make    out    any    prima\n\n  facie case on any of the grounds urged before\n\n  the Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">  19.    Against     the    said    order,      an    appeal    was\n\n  filed before the High Court and the High Court\n\n  took up the matter for hearing on 18.7.2006 and\n\n  by granting an interim injunction remanded the\n\n  matter to the Trial Court for consideration of\n\n  injunction prayer afresh.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">  20.    Thereafter,       the     Trial    Court     heard     the\n\n  matter and dismissed on 23.8.2006 the prayer\n\n  for interim injunction and the said order has\n\n  been    upheld     by    the     High     Court     under    the\n\n  impugned judgment dated 23.11.2006.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">21.   In the background of these facts, the only\n\nlegal issue which arises is:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             Whether       the     second      Respondent,      the\n\n         Executive Engineer of Mumbai Metropolitan\n\n         Region Development Authority (hereinafter,\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                             7</span>\n\f          the said Authority) is entitled in law to\n\n          issue       notice          dated       13.04.2006       under\n\n          Section     351    of       the     said    Act.        It   was\n\n          further argued since the second Respondent\n\n          has no authority to issue the notice, all\n\n          steps taken pursuant to such notice are\n\n          illegal and should be set aside by this\n\n          Court.\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_24\">22. These        questions      have        been     very    adequately\n\ndealt with in the judgment of the High Court. The\n\nHigh Court after considering the provisions of\n\nthe Act of 1974 and specially the amendment made\n\nto   it    in     1989,     came       to     a   finding     that     the\n\nExecutive Engineer can exercise or perform the\n\nfunctions       and    duties         delegated      to     him   by   the\n\nMetropolitan Commissioner.                    The High Court noted\n\nthat provisions for delegation were statutorily\n\nmade. Therefore, notice issued by him cannot be\n\nheld to be illegal.            Those findings have not been\n\nchallenged        before       us      during        the     course     of\n\nargument        and   in    view       of     the    provisions        for\n\nstatutory delegation, which have been noted in\n\nthe judgment of the High Court, we do not think\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                  8</span>\n\f  there       is     any    merit          in     the    aforesaid         legal\n\n  contention.         No other argument is made before us.\n\n  It is well settled when prayer for injunction is\n\n  concurrently refused by two courts, this court,\n\n  in     a    proceeding          under         <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_1\">Article       136</a>     of     the\n\n  Constitution,            will    be       very    slow      and    cautious\n\n  before it can take a different view.                          This court\n\n  can only do so, if it finds that the judgment of\n\n  the court below is perverse.                           In the facts of\n\n  this       case,    discussed            above,       the   court    cannot\n\n  arrive at such a finding.                       Therefore, we do not\n\n  find       any     merit        in       this     appeal,         which     is\n\n  accordingly dismissed.                   No costs.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                                           .......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                           (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n\n vs National Aluminium Company Ltd on 20 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33522","lastname":"chatterjee","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-20","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Balli Petrochemicals Ltd vs National Aluminium Company Ltd on 20 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: T Chatterjee</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Tarun Chatterjee</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                        1\n\n\n\n                                           REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                   CIVIL ORIGINAL JURISDICTION\n\n          ARBITRATION PETITION NO.7 OF 2006\n\nBalli Petrochemicals Limited.                     ...Petitioner\n\n     Versus\n\nNational Aluminium Company Ltd.                  ...Respondent\n\n\n                      JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">TARUN CHATTERJEE, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">     1.    The petitioner is a company incorporated in\n\n           London. The respondent is a Government of\n\n           India undertaking having its corporate office at\n\n           NALCO Bhawan, P-1 Nayapalli, Bhubaneswar,\n\n           Orissa. The petitioner filed an application under\n\n           <a href=\"/doc/596725/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 11(6)</a> of the Arbitration and <a href=\"/doc/1306164/\" id=\"a_2\">Conciliation\n\n           Act</a>, 1996 (hereinafter referred to as the `Act')\n\n           for    appointment   of   a   Sole   Arbitrator   to\n\n           adjudicate the disputes, which arose between\n\n           the parties in respect of the global tender and\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                    2</span>\n\n\nthe purchase order dated 29th of September,\n\n2000 issued by the respondent pursuant to the\n\ntender. Clause 16.0 of the tender contained the\n\nArbitration Clause which reads thus :-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">   \"All disputes or differences arising under\n   the contract whether during or after\n   completion of the contract or whether before\n   or after determination, for closure or breach\n   of the contract (other than those in respect\n   of which the decision of any person is by\n   the contract expressed to be final and\n   binding) shall after written notice by either\n   party to the contract to the other of them\n   and to the appointing authority herein after\n   mentioned be referred to adjudication to a\n   sole arbitrator to be appointed as\n   hereinafter provided.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">   For the purpose of appointing the sole\n   Arbitrator referred to above, the CMD\n   NALCO who shall be Appointing Authority\n   will send within thirty days of receipt of the\n   notice to the seller a panel of three names\n   of persons.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">   The contractor shall on receipt of the names\n   as referred select any one of the person\n   name to be appointed as a sole arbitrator\n   and communicate his name to the\n   Appointing Authority shall thereupon\n   appoint the said person as the sole\n   Arbitrator.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">   If the seller fails to communicate such\n   selection as provided above within the\n   period specified, the Appointing Authority\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                  3</span>\n\n\nshall make the selection and appoint the\nselected person as the sole Arbitrator.\n\nIf the Arbitrator so appointed is unable to/\nunwilling to act or resign his appointment or\nvacates his office due to any reason\nwhatsoever sole arbitrator shall be\nappointed as aforesaid. The work under\nthe contract shall not be stopped during the\narbitration proceedings.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">The Arbitrator shall be deemed to have\nentered on the reference on the date he\nissues notices to both the parties fixing the\ndate of the first hearing.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">The Arbitrator may, from time to time, with\nthe consent of the parties, enlarge the time\nfor making and publishing the award.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">The Arbitrator shall give a separate award\nin respect of each dispute of difference and\nshall give a reasoned and speaking\naward/awards.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">The venue of arbitration shall be at\nBhubaneswar. However, if the situation so\nwarrants, it may as and when required, be\nheld at the place where the site of work is\nsituated.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">The fees, if any, of the Arbitrator shall, if\nrequired to be paid before the award is\nmade and published, be paid half and half\nby each of the parties. The cost of the\nreference and of the award including the\nfees, if any, of the Arbitrator shall be in the\ndiscretion of the Arbitrator who may direct\nto and by whom and in what manner, such\ncosts or any part thereof shall be paid and\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                  4</span>\n\n\n                   may fix or settle the amount of costs to be\n                   paid. The award of the Arbitrator shall be\n                   final and binding on both the parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">                   Subject to aforesaid provisions of the\n                   Arbitration and <a href=\"/doc/1306164/\" id=\"a_3\">Conciliation Act</a>, 1996 or\n                   any statutory modification or re-enactment\n                   thereof and the rules made thereunder,\n                   and for the time being in force, shall apply\n                   to the arbitration proceedings under this\n                   clause.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">2.   On account of breach between the parties, disputes and\n\ndifferences had arisen which were referred to the arbitration of\n\nHon.Mr.Justice R.S.Pathak, (since deceased)       Former Chief\n\nJustice of India and Former Judge of the International Court of\n\nJustice (as His Lordship then was). The learned Arbitrator, so\n\nappointed, entered appearance and the arbitration proceedings\n\nwent on till 25th of November, 2005 when the learned Arbitrator\n\nby an order dated 25th of November, 2005 resigned and had\n\nwithdrawn as Arbitrator from the arbitration stating that as the\n\nissues involved in the arbitration were similar to the issues\n\ninvolved in an earlier award passed by him and, therefore, it\n\nwas thought fit that he should withdraw from the arbitration.\n\nAt this juncture, we may examine the arbitration clause which\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                                  5</span>\n\n\nis enumerated in clause 16 of the tender, as noted herein\n\nbefore. From a plain reading of the arbitration clause, it is\n\nevident that for the purpose of appointing the sole Arbitrator,\n\nthe Chief Managing Director of the respondent, i.e. NALCO who\n\nshall be the appointing authority will send within 30 days of\n\nreceipt of the notice of the seller a panel of three names of\n\npersons. It will also be evident from the said arbitration clause\n\nthat the contractor shall on receipt of the names, as referred,\n\nselect any one of the persons' named to be appointed as a sole\n\nArbitrator and communicate his name to the appointing\n\nauthority who shall thereupon appoint the said person as sole\n\nArbitrator. This clause further provides that if the seller fails to\n\ncommunicate such selection, as noted above, within the period\n\nspecified, the appointing authority shall make the selection and\n\nappoint the selected person as the sole Arbitrator. An over all\n\nlook of the aforesaid provision of the arbitration clause makes it\n\nclear that the appointing authority for appointment of an\n\nArbitrator under the arbitration clause is the Chief Managing\n\nDirector of the respondent who shall send a notice to the\n\npetitioner within 30 days of receipt of a panel of three names. It\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                 6</span>\n\n\nwould be obligatory on the part of the petitioner to select any\n\none of the persons' named by the appointing authority to be\n\nappointed as the sole Arbitrator and communicate his name to\n\nthe   appointing   authority   and   thereupon    the   appointing\n\nauthority shall appoint the said person as the sole Arbitrator. If\n\nthe seller fails to communicate such selection as provided\n\nabove within the period specified, the appointing authority shall\n\nmake the selection and appoint the selected person as the sole\n\nArbitrator. On the resignation of the sole Arbitrator, namely,\n\nHon.Mr.Justice R.S.Pathak, (since deceased) in terms of the\n\naforesaid clause, a list of three names were admittedly served\n\nupon the petitioner out of which one was to be selected for\n\nappointment in replacement of Hon.Mr.Justice R.S. Pathak,\n\n(since deceased). It is not in dispute that the said notice was\n\nduly served on the petitioner, but in spite of such service of\n\nnotice, the petitioner had failed to appoint or select any one of\n\nthe persons named in the panel of three persons from the list\n\nsent by the respondent within the time specified therein. Since\n\nthe arbitration clause clearly provides for selection of one of the\n\npersons named in the panel to be appointed as the sole\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                  7</span>\n\n\nArbitrator by the respondents, it was open for the respondent\n\nto select one persons' named from the panel and appoint as the\n\nsole Arbitrator. In this case admittedly the respondent has\n\nalready appointed and selected a retired Judge of the Delhi\n\nHigh Court as the sole Arbitrator to replace Justice R.S.Pathak\n\n(since deceased). After such appointment having been made,\n\nthe petitioner has filed this application saying that since the\n\nformer Chief Justice of India was appointed as the sole\n\nArbitrator, it would not be possible for the petitioner to accept a\n\nretired Judge of the Delhi High Court for being appointed as\n\nthe sole Arbitrator. As noted herein above, it is not in dispute\n\nthat a panel of three persons in compliance with the arbitration\n\nclause was sent by the respondent which was duly received by\n\nthe petitioner. In spite of receipt of the said notice to select any\n\none of the persons named in the panel and the petitioner\n\nhaving failed to select or choose any one of them and had\n\nstarted saying that as a former Chief Justice of India was\n\nappointed to arbitrate the disputes between the parties, the\n\nquestion of accepting a retired Judge of the High Court as the\n\nsole Arbitrator in replacement of a former Chief Justice of India\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                               8</span>\n\n\nwas not acceptable to the petitioner. We are unable to accept\n\nthe submissions made by Mr.Ganguly, learned senior counsel\n\nappearing on behalf of the petitioner and after going through\n\nthe arbitration clause in depth and in detail, in my view, it was\n\nopen to the respondent to select any one from the panel sent by\n\nthe respondent after the expiry of the period for selecting a\n\nperson by the petitioner. In this case, since the respondent has\n\nalready exercised the arbitration clause and already replaced\n\nand selected a sole arbitrator in place of Justice R.S.Pathak\n\n(since deceased) who has already entered appearance, I do not\n\nfind any reason to replace the appointed arbitrator at this stage\n\nwhen admittedly no allegations have been put forward by the\n\npetitioner against such appointment excepting that since a\n\nformer Chief Justice of India was appointed to arbitrate the\n\ndisputes between the parties, this time also a former Chief\n\nJustice of India ought to have been appointed.         As noted\n\nherein earlier, a plain reading of the arbitration clause would\n\nclearly show that it was solely on the respondent to select the\n\nperson from the panel of three persons in the event the\n\npetitioner had failed to select any one of the persons named by\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                9</span>\n\n\nthe respondent. In view of the aforesaid admitted fact and in\n\nview of the fact that the arbitration clause was very clear, it\n\nwould not be necessary for me to go into the details in this\n\nmatter as I find that the appointment was already made and it\n\nis only a case of replacement of earlier sole arbitrator on the\n\nground of his resignation. Therefore, the objections raised by\n\nMr.Ganguly, learned senior counsel appearing for the petitioner\n\ncannot be sustained at this stage particularly when the\n\npetitioner has not raised any objection on the creditability of\n\nthe sole arbitrator now appointed by the respondent.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">3.   It is to be kept on record that although comprehensive\n\nsubmissions were filed by both the parties before me, but in\n\nview of the admitted fact, as stated hereinabove and on a plain\n\nreading of the arbitration clause itself I do not find any\n\njustification to deal with the submissions put forward by the\n\nparties. I, however, request the sole arbitrator to start with the\n\narbitration at an early date and it is expected that he will pass\n\nthe award in accordance with law within six months from the\n\ndate of supply of a copy of this order to him.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                                                   10</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">4.        For the reasons aforesaid, I do not find any ground to\n\nallow this application and accordingly the application is\n\nrejected. There will be no order as to costs.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">                                                    ..................\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">.....J.\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">                                                [Tarun\nChatterjee]\n\n          New Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">          January 20, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":921698,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1306164,"url":null,"title":"THE ARBITRATION AND CONCILIATION ACT, 1996"},{"tid":596725,"url":null,"title":"Section 11 in The Arbitration Act,   1940"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"national commission","formInput":"national%20commission"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Krishna Singh & Anr vs L.I.C. This appeal is directed against the Judgment and order\n\n     dated 31st of August, 2006 passed by the High Court of\n\n     Judicature at Bombay in Family Court Appeal No. 15 of\n\n     2006, by which the decree passed by the Family Court at\n\n     Pune, granting divorce under Section 13(1) (1-a) of the\n\n     <a href=\"/doc/590166/\" id=\"a_1\">Hindu Marriage Act</a>, 1955 was affirmed but had\n\n     remanded the matter back to the Family Court for proper\n\n     determination of issues of permanent alimony and\n\n     ownership of flat in Triveni Nagar. Against the aforesaid\n\n     order of remand, the husband/appellant had filed a\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                            1</span>\n\f     Special Leave Petition, which on grant of leave, was\n\n     heard in presence of the learned counsel for the parties.\n\n     It is to be noted that while issuing notice on this Special\n\n     Leave Petition on 12th of March, 2007, this Court passed\n\n     the following order :-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">           \"Delay condoned.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">           Issue notice.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">           Learned counsel for the petitioner states\n           that he does not challenge the finding on\n           divorce and monthly maintenance.\"\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_3\">3.
