Appellant(s)\n\n\n           Versus\n\nSANJAY KERALKAR                                                      ...   Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                      ORDER\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">           Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">           Having heard learned counsel for the respective parties, we are unable to\n\n    sustain the order passed by the Division Bench of the Madhya Pradesh High Court\n\n    dismissing the appeal as preferred by the appellant herein on the ground that the\n\n    appeal had been preferred against an order passed under <a href=\"/doc/1331149/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 227</a> of the\n\n    Constitution. We have had occasion to look into the petition which had been filed\n\n    before the Single Bench of the High Court, which has been styled as writ petition\n\n    under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_2\">Article 226</a><a href=\"/doc/1331149/\" id=\"a_3\">/227</a> of the Constitution of India. The Division Bench of the High\n\n    Court appears to have not taken into consideration the fact that the petition had\n\n    been styled as a writ petition under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_4\">Article 226</a> as well and that the frame of the\n\n    petition was that of a writ petition as would also be evident from the prayers made\n\n    therein.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">\f             We are unable to agree with the High Court that the learned Single Judge\n\n      had passed order under <a href=\"/doc/1331149/\" id=\"a_5\">Article 227</a> of the Constitution of India and that the appeal\n\n      was not maintainable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">             We, accordingly, allow the appeal and remit the matter to the High Court to\n\n      treat the petition as one under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_6\">Article 226</a> of the Constitution and to dispose of W.A.\n\n      182   of 2006 in accordance with law, within two months from the date of\n\n      communication of this order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">             There will be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                             ...................J.\n</p><p {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Bhagwan Sarup Nagar(D) By Lrs vs Ram Kishan on 16 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33505","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-16","citedbyList":[{"tid":129750231,"url":"http://services.ecourts.gov.in/ecourtindia/cases/display_pdf.php?filename=%2Forders%2F201704762322015_7.pdf&caseno=CS%2F476232%2F2015&cCode=1&appFlag=web","title":"Judgment:Â­ vs . on 3 December, 2016"}],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Bhagwan Sarup Nagar(D) By Lrs vs Ram Kishan on 16 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                        REPORTABLE\n\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                   CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 258           OF 2009\n                  (Arising out of SLP(C) 14865 OF 2006)\n\n\nBhagwan Sarup Nagar (D)                                  ...Appellants\nBy Lrs.\n\n                                   Versus\n\nRam Kishan                                                      ...\nRespondent\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a learned Single Judge\n\nof the Punjab and Haryana High Court allowing the appeal filed by the\n\nrespondent. The appeal was filed under Section 100 of the Code of Civil\n\nProcedure, 1908 (in short the `CPC'). Appellant as plaintiff has filed a suit\n\nfor mandatory injunction with a prayer that the defendant-respondent be\n\fdirected to ensure possession to him of the demised premises description of\n\nwhich was given in the plaint. He also claimed Rs.3,900/- towards mesne\n\nprofit for use and occupation of the property by the respondent. It was the\n\ncase of the plaintiff that he was the owner of the house and the defendant\n\nwas his cousin and he had inducted him as a licensee in two rooms.\n\nThereafter, when the defendants started misbehaving, he issued a notice to\n\nhim on 27.9.1991 revoking his licence. Since he failed to vacate the portion\n\nof the house in dispute, mesne profit was claimed and the occupation of the\n\ndemised property was also claimed. The defendant took the plea that the\n\nproperty was exclusively in continuous peaceful possession of the defendant\n\nfor last more than 50 years as its owners without paying rent to anybody\n\nincluding the plaintiff. It was also denied that he was ever inducted as a\n\nlicencee. Five issues were framed by the trial court. It is to be noted that\n\nreplication was filed by the plaintiff.    After considering the evidence\n\nbrought on record it was held that the plaintiff was the owner of the\n\nproperty in dispute but all the issues were decided against him. The issues\n\nwere as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">            1.     Whether the plaintiff is entitled for the relief of\n\n            injunction as alleged in the plaint? OPP.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                        2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">\f             2.    Whether the plaintiffs entitled to recover Rs.3,900/- as\n\n             mesne profits as alleged in the plaintiff? OPP.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">             3.    Whether the plaintiff has no locus standi to file the\n\n             present suit? OPD.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">             4.    Whether the suit of the plaintiffs not maintainable? OPD.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">             5.    Whether the plaintiff has no cause of action to file the\n\n             present suit? OPD.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">3.    The finding of the trial court was reversed by the First appellate court\n\nand the suit filed by the plaintiff was decreed. When the second appeal was\n\nadmitted, the following question was formulated:\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"Whether the learned lower Appellate Court could\n             reverse the findings without considering the documents\n             Ex.D1, D2 and D3.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_15\">4.    The High Court came to hold that the appeal was bound to succeed as\n\nthe plaintiff has failed to prove his ownership. Mere fact that adverse\n\npossession has been claimed by the defendant paled into insignificance and\n\nno benefit of the same can be given to the plaintiff.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                          3</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">\f5.    In support of the appeal learned counsel for the appellant submitted\n\nthat the approach of the High Court was clearly erroneous. It is not a fact\n\nthat Exh. D1 to D7 were not considered. In fact the trial court observed as\n\nfollows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">            \"Now coming to with regard of creation of relationship\n            of Plaintiff and Defendant as licensor and licensee\n            between the parties, nothing is stated by the Plaintiff in\n            his pleadings when Defendant was inducted as a licensee\n            in the portion of the House No. 5912-13 whereas in his\n            statement as PW-1 he has stated in the cross examination\n            that Defendant was inducted into the Property as licensee\n            about six years earlier. Whereas from the perusal of the\n            oral as well as documentary evidence produced by the\n            Defendant on the file it goes to show that portion of the\n            house has been coming in possession initially of Ghasi\n            Ram father of the Defendant and after his death in\n            possession of the Defendant since 1931. These facts\n            stand proved from the copy of the resolution of the\n            committee dated 19-8-31 Ex. D-1 vide which application\n            of the Defendant for opening the slaughter house in\n            House N0.5912-13 was rejected. Thus it shows that on\n            19.8.31 father of he Defendant was in possession of the\n            house on 19.8.31. Similarly Defendant has filed a loan\n            application Ex. D-2 before the secretary Punjab Khadi &amp;\n            Village Industries Board, Chandigarh for carrying on a\n            business under the Tanners production Co. Op. Society\n            Ltd. In this house. Central Sales tax receipt Ex. D-3,\n            electricity bills since 1984 on wards in the name of Ghasi\n            Ram Show the continuous possession of the Defendant\n            in portion of the house. It is pertinent to mention here\n            that apart form the bar statement of Plaintiff there is not\n            an iota of supporting evidence of any person from the\n            locality in order to prove that Defendant was inducted as\n            a licenses about 5/6 years earlier. Neither any suggestion\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                          4</span>\n\f               was put to the Defendant in cross-examination regarding\n               the creation of the license about 5/6 years earlier. It is\n               well settled that suggestion not put up on any point to the\n               Defendant regarding the matter in dispute. The claim of\n               the Defendant regarding the denial of the relationship as\n               licensor and licensee is deemed to be admitted.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_18\">6.    Further it appears that the High Court proceeded on an erroneous\n\nimpression as if the First appellate court has reversed the finding regarding\n\nownership. As a matter of fact the First Appellate Court had concurred with\n\nthe finding.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">7.    It is to be noted that the High Court's observations regarding non-\n\nconsideration of Exh.D1 to D7 by the trial court, are as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">                      \"Similarly while deciding question of title, trial\n               court has not said a word about the documents Ex.D1 to\n               D7, though D1 and D2 were earlier to the filing of the\n               suit by the respondent in favour of the appellant was not\n               proved on record.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_21\">8.    The quoted portion of the trial court's judgment shows that the\n\nconclusions of the High Court are erroneous.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                             5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">\f9.    As noted above the First Appellate Court also held that it was\n\nestablished that the plaintiff is the owner of the property in dispute. The\n\nFirst Appellate Court observed as follows:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">               \"The defendant in the written statement claimed his\n               continuous long possession over the house for the last 56\n               years without paying any rent. Meaning thereby, the\n               defendant has taken a plea of adverse possession. In\n               other words the ownership of the plaintiff stands\n               admitted by the defendant. So from every angle it stands\n               proved that the plaintiff is the owner of the property in\n               dispute.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_24\">10.   Above being the position the High Court has fallen into grave error\n\nby overlooking the aforesaid conclusions and in allowing the second appeal.\n\nIn the aforesaid background we are of the view that the second appeal needs\n\nto be heard afresh by the High Court. The matter is, therefore, remanded to\n\nthe High Court for a fresh consideration in accordance with law.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">11.   Appeal is allowed. No costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">                                                                ..................................................J.\n                                                                (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n      .....................................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">                                                                (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                                                              6</span>\n\fJanuary 13, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                   7</span>\n\f</p>","tid":869901,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"slp","formInput":"slp"},{"value":"orissa","formInput":"orissa"},{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"steel authority is other authority","formInput":"steel%20authority%20is%20other%20authority"},{"value":"steel authority","formInput":"steel%20authority"},{"value":" s h kapadia","formInput":"%20s%20h%20kapadia"},{"value":"aftab alam","formInput":"aftab%20alam"},{"value":"steel","formInput":"steel"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Steel Authority Of India Ltd vs State Of Orissa & Ors on 19 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33567","lastname":"....................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-19","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Steel Authority Of India Ltd vs State Of Orissa &amp; Ors on 19 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ....................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: S.H. Bala, mother of Dinesh who died on\n\n25.7.2003 while he was studying in 8th Class in Sarvodaya Vidyalaya, Bakner, New\n\nDelhi (respondent No. 2 herein). Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NO.317 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.13260 of 2008)\n\n\nDeo Kumar Singh                                           ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                        Versus\n\nC.B.P. Sinha                                              ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                                     O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">           Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">           By the impugned order, Bihar State Consumer Disputes Redressal\nCommission [for short, `the State Commission'] dismissed the complaint filed by the\nappellant in which he claimed compensation of Rupees ten lakhs by alleging that on\naccount of negligence of the respondent wrong blood group came to be mentioned in\nthe report of the laboratory and, as a result of that, his wife had to suffer two\nabortions. When the matter was taken in appeal, the National Consumer Disputes\nRedressal Commission [for short, `the National Commission'], held that there was\ntotal failure on the part of the respondent in exercising adequate care in analyzing the\nblood which made his wife to go for abortions. Accordingly the National Commission\nawarded compensation of Rupees twenty five thousand together with interest @ 9%\nper annum. Feeling dissatisfied, the appellant has filed this appeal.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">                                                                                   ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">            Having heard learned counsel for the parties and perused the record, we\nare convinced that in the facts and circumstances of the case, the National\nCommission was not justified in awarding meagre compensation of Rupees twenty\nfive thousand. When the National Commission found that the respondent was guilty\nof negligence in analyzing the blood and the wrong report given by him made the\nappellant's wife to suffer two abortions, higher compensation should have been\nawarded to him. In our view, in the facts and circumstances of the case, the ends of\njustice will be met if the appellant is awarded compensation of Rupees one lakh with\ninterest.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">            Accordingly, the appeal is allowed in-part, the impugned order is modified\nand the respondent is directed to pay a sum of Rupees one lakh by way of\ncompensation together with interest at the rate of nine per cent per annum form the\ndate of passing of the order by the National Commission, i.e., 11th December, 2007, till\npayment is made.      The respondent is directed to pay the entire amount to the\nappellant within a period of four months from today.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                                [B.N. AGRAWAL]\n\n\n\n                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                [G.S. SINGHVI]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 19, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1341824,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"bar council","formInput":"bar%20council"},{"value":"state bar council","formInput":"state%20bar%20council"},{"value":"disciplinary committee","formInput":"disciplinary%20committee"},{"value":"disciplinary","formInput":"disciplinary"},{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"mohanti","formInput":"mohanti"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Goverdhan Pujari vs Jugal Kishore Sahu on 12 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33596","lastname":"......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-12","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Goverdhan Pujari vs Jugal Kishore Sahu on 12 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: B.N. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                          CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                           CIVIL APPEAL NO.4206 OF 2008\n\n\nGoverdhan Pujari                              ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                        Versus\n\nJugal Kishore Sahu                            ...Respondent(s)\n\n                  With Civil Appeal Nos.4207 of 2008 and 4387 of 2008\n\n                                     O R D E R\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">            Heard learned counsel for the appellant, learned counsel for the\nrespondents and the respondent, who has appeared in-person in Civil Appeal No.\n4207 of 2008.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">            Disciplinary Committee No.(II) of the Orissa State Bar Council consisting\nof three persons, one of whom was one Shri R.K. Mohanty, advocate, dismissed the\ncomplaints filed by the appellant. The said order has been confirmed in appeal by the\nBar Council of India. Hence, these appeals.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">            The appellant has challenged the impugned orders mainly on the ground\nthat Shri R.K. Mohanty, Advocate ceased to be a Member of the Disciplinary\nCommittee (II) of the State Bar Council on 23.12.1999 and, therefore, he could not\nhave, as a Member of the Committee, decided the complaints.      It   has   not   been\ndisputed before us that the day on which the complaints filed by the appellant were\ndismissed, Shri R.K. Mohanty was not a Member of Disciplinary Committee (II) of\nthe State Bar Council. Therefore, on this ground alone, the impugned orders are\nliable to be set aside.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">                                                                                  ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">           Accordingly, the appeals are allowed, impugned orders are set aside with\nthe direction to the State Bar Council to decide the complaints afresh. The Chairman\nof the Orissa State Bar Council shall see that the complaints filed by the appellant are\nplaced before properly constituted Disciplinary Committee and disposed of in\naccordance with law.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_6\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                                [B.N. AGRAWAL]\n\n\n\n                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                [G.S. SINGHVI]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 12, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1500683,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":9,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"deen dayal","formInput":"deen%20dayal"},{"value":"cruelty citedby:538436","formInput":"cruelty%20citedby%3A538436"},{"value":"dowry demand","formInput":"dowry%20demand"},{"value":"304-b","formInput":"304-b"},{"value":"sec 304-b","formInput":"sec%20304-b"},{"value":"as soon as","formInput":"as%20soon%20as"},{"value":"amar singh","formInput":"amar%20singh"},{"value":"aftab alam","formInput":"aftab%20alam"},{"value":"dowry death","formInput":"dowry%20death"},{"value":"proximate cause","formInput":"proximate%20cause"}],"citeList":[{"tid":653797,"url":null,"title":"Section 304B in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":295920,"url":null,"title":"The Supreme Court (Enlargement of Criminal Appellate Jurisdiction) Act, 1970"},{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":294349,"url":null,"title":"Section 113A in The Indian Evidence Act, 1872"},{"tid":409589,"url":null,"title":"Section 304 in The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Deen Dayal & Ors vs State Of U.P on 7 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-07","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":1496603,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"a","lastname":"alam","numcitedby":0,"secondname":null,"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33460","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Deen Dayal &amp; Ors vs State Of U.P on 7 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: A Alam</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Lokeshwar Singh Panta, Aftab Alam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                               1\n\n\n\n\n                                            REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.67 OF 2006\n\nDeen Dayal &amp; Ors.                                      ... Appellants\n\n\n                                   Vs.\n\n\nState of U.P.                                          ... Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">AFTAB ALAM,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    This appeal under <a href=\"/doc/1524736/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 379</a> of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973\n\nread with <a href=\"/doc/927005/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 2(A)</a> of the Supreme Court (Enlargement of Criminal\n\nAppellate Jurisdiction) Act, 1970 is at the instance of three appellants.\n\nAmar Singh, appellant no.3, is the son of Deen Dayal, appellant no.1 and\n\nSmt. Sukhrani, appellant no.2. They were tried for killing Asha Devi, wife\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                       2</span>\n\n\nof appellant no.3 for non fulfilment of their demand for dowry and were\n\ncharged under <a href=\"/doc/295920/\" id=\"a_3\">sections 498-A</a> and <a href=\"/doc/295920/\" id=\"a_4\">304-B</a>, alternatively <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_5\">section 302</a> of the\n\nPenal Code.    At the conclusion of the trial they were acquitted of the\n\ncharges by the 4th Additional Session Judge, vide judgment and order dated\n\nApril 30, 2001 in Sessions Trial no.740 of 1998. Against the judgment of\n\nacquittal passed by the trial court the State of U.P. preferred an appeal\n\nbefore the High Court that was registered as Govt. Appeal no.2998 of 2001.\n\nA Division Bench of the High Court found and held that in the face of\n\nprosecution evidence the conclusion arrived at by the trial court was wholly\n\nuntenable. Accordingly, the High Court allowed the appeal, set aside the\n\nJudgment of acquittal passed by the trial court and by judgment and order\n\ndated September 21, 2005 convicted all the three appellants under <a href=\"/doc/538436/\" id=\"a_6\">sections\n\n498-A</a> and <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_7\">304-B</a> of the Penal Code and sentenced them to undergo\n\nrigorous imprisonment for three years and ten years respectively for the two\n\noffences subject to the direction that the two sentences would run\n\nconcurrently. The judgment and order passed by the High Court is brought\n\nunder appeal to this court by the three appellants.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">2.    Dr. J. N. Dubey learned senior counsel made long and elaborate\n\nsubmissions in support of the appeal. Learned counsel first contended that\n\nin a criminal case the scope of an appeal against acquittal is quite different\n\nfrom an appeal against conviction and sentence. In the former case, if the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                       3</span>\n\n\ntrial court has taken one of the two possible views the judgment of acquittal\n\nwould not warrant any interference in appeal. Counsel further submitted that\n\nthe present case fell under that category and the High Court was in error in\n\ninterfering with the judgment of the trial court and substituting its own view\n\nin place of the view taken by trial court. Next, passing over to the merits of\n\nthe case, Dr. Dubey submitted that on the evidence on record several\n\ningredients of the offence of dowry death remained unproved and since the\n\nprosecution failed to establish all the necessary conditions no presumption\n\nwould arise against the appellants under <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 304-B</a> of the Penal Code\n\nand Sec. 113-<a href=\"/doc/1953529/\" id=\"a_9\">A of the Indian Evidence Act</a>.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">3.    Before examining the submissions made on behalf of the appellants in\n\nany detail it would be useful and proper to state certain facts of the case that\n\nare admitted or are in any event undeniable. Asha Devi, the deceased was\n\nmarried with appellant no.3 in June 1997. Fifteen months later she died on\n\nSeptember 6, 1998. At the time of her death she was living with the\n\nappellants. Her dead body was taken out of a well situate at a distance of\n\nabout four hundred paces from the house of the appellants. Here it must be\n\nstated that her death was not caused by drowning. According to the\n\nprosecution, Asha Devi was killed by the appellants and her dead body was\n\nthrown into the well. The appellants, however, have a different story. Their\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                       4</span>\n\n\ncase is that she had gone to fetch water and while pulling up the pail of\n\nwater she accidently slipped and fell down into the well and died.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">4.    At this stage we may take a look at the medical evidence. P. W.3, the\n\ndoctor holding post-mortem on the dead body of Asha Devi found the\n\nfollowing two injuries\n\n 1: Swelling 3 x 3 cm in front upper part of nose.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\"> 2: Swelling mark 5 x 5 cm on top and middle of head.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">On internal examination he found the following injuries :\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">      \"Left parietal bone of head was fractured. Membrane was\n      soiled in blood. There was blood in brain. Bone of nose was\n      fractured. There was 2 ounce clotted blood in nose. There was\n      2 ounce watery fluid in stomach\".\n</blockquote>\n\n<p id=\"p_9\">He opined that death was caused due to coma resulting from head injury. He\n\nstated before the court that the injuries were possibly caused by some blunt\n\nweapon. He found no water in the lungs or the wind pipe. He further said\n\nthat that if there was water in the well then those injuries couldn't possibly\n\nhave been caused (by falling down into it). In cross-examination he said that\n\nboth the injuries could be caused by dashing against two different\n\nprojections; those could not caused by a single projection. Under persistent\n\ncross-examination he further said that as a result of falling from a high place\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                      5</span>\n\n\nwith mouth (Sic. face) facing downward injury no.1 could possibly be\n\ncaused and injury no.2 could be caused by dashing against some stone.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5.    The medical evidence thus fully corroborates the prosecution case\n\nthat Asha Devi was thrown into the well when she was already dead or was\n\ndying. At any rate she had stopped breathing as indicated by the absence of\n\nany water in her lungs or windpipe.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">6.    In order to reconcile the defence case with the medical evidence Dr.\n\nDubey came up with an explanation. Learned Counsel suggested that in\n\ncourse of her fall in the deep well (water surface in the well was at a depth\n\nof 60-70 ft.) Asha Devi might have smashed her head against the wall of the\n\nwell and as a result she went into coma even before hitting the water\n\nsurface. We are totally unable to accept the submission. According to the\n\ninvestigating officer the mouth of the well was half covered by wooden\n\nplanks and a pulley was fixed over the other open half for pulling up the\n\nfilled up bucket. With that kind of arrangement it is highly unlikely for a\n\nperson to slip and fall down in the well. But even assuming that such an\n\naccident took place no injuries as found on the person of Asha Devi can be\n\ncaused in course of the fall into the water. The investigating officer\n\ndescribed the well in question as a kuccha well, that is to say its inner walls\n\nwere not brick lined. Asha Devi had suffered two injuries, one over her nose\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                       6</span>\n\n\nand the other in the parietal area of the head. The doctor was quite definite\n\nthat the two injuries were the result of two separate blows by some hard and\n\nblunt substance. In cross examination he said that the two injuries could be\n\ncaused by dashing against two different projections; those could not caused\n\nby a single projection. We are completely unable to see Asha Devi falling\n\ndown inside the well and getting her face and head smashed twice against\n\ntwo projections jutting out from the soft clay inner walls without any lining\n\nof bricks. We have no manner of doubt that Asha Devi was first beaten and\n\nthen her body was dumped into the well when she was dying or was already\n\ndead.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">7.      Here, it may be stated that the defence also examined a witness. He of\n\ncourse said that the appellants kept Asha Devi with great love and affection\n\nand further that she died due to an accidental fall into the well. He himself\n\nsaw her slipping while bending down to pull up the bucket full of water and\n\nfalling into the well head downwards. The witness has no value in our eyes\n\nand Dr. Dubey too rightly did not even refer to his evidence. As a matter of\n\nfact the defence witness did not make any statement before the investigating\n\nofficer and was examined for the first time before the trial court. It also\n\nappears from the materials on record that the appellants' village where the\n\noccurrence took place belonged to the people of one and the same caste.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                      7</span>\n\n\nDuring investigation the co-villagers tried to conceal the facts and no one\n\nwas prepared to give any statement against the appellants.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">8.      Thus on the evidence on record we find it fully established that only\n\nafter fifteen months of her marriage and while she was living with the\n\nappellants Asha Devi died under circumstances that were not only far from\n\nnormal but also plainly indicated homicide.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">9.      At this stage Dr. Dubey submitted that though Asha Devi might have\n\ndied under abnormal circumstances within seven years of her marriage,\n\nthere was no evidence of any demand for dowry by the appellants or her\n\nbeing    subjected to cruelty or harassment by the appellants for or in\n\nconnection with the demand for dowry. In any event, there was absolutely\n\nno evidence that any demand for dowry was made soon before her death on\n\nSeptember 6, 1998 and the demand for dowry and the cruelty or harassment\n\nmeted out to her in connection with the demand were the proximate cause of\n\nher death. In support of the submission that the appellants did not make any\n\ndemand for dowry Dr. Dubey heavily relied on certain sentences picked out\n\nfrom the evidence of PW 1, the father of the deceased. Learned counsel\n\nreferred to two sentences from the statement of PW 1 in reply to the court's\n\nquestions where he said that no dowry was decided at the time of the\n\nmarriage and appellant no.1 had said that he would be happy with whatever\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                      8</span>\n\n\nthey gave. Learned counsel then pointed out two or three sentences from his\n\ncross examination where he said that there was no talk of dowry at the time\n\nof engagement and marriage of his daughter; there was no talk of dowry at\n\nthe time of solemnization of marriage (taking steps around the sacred fire).\n\nAnd that the appellants took his daughter happily and at the time of\n\ndeparture also there was no talk (of dowry).\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">10.   We find absolutely no substance in the submission. The evidence of\n\nthe witness has to be taken as a whole and not by plucking out one or two\n\nsentences from here and there. In his examination-in-chief PW 1 clearly\n\nstated that in the marriage of his daughter he gave dowry according to his\n\ncapacity but the members of the bridegroom side were not satisfied. Asha\n\nDevi's husband Amar Singh (appellant No.3), father-in-law Deen Dayal\n\n(appellant No.1) and mother-in-law Sukhrani (appellant No.2) used to\n\ndemand Rs.10, 000/- and a chain of gold in addition to what was already\n\ngiven by him. They had made the demand from him. They had also made\n\nthe demand of dowry from his son when he went to their place for bringing\n\nback Asha Devi. The appellant used to beat and abuse her for the sake of\n\ndowry. When Asha Devi used to come to their house she would tell them\n\nthat her in-laws demanded Rs.10, 000/- and a chain of gold and if the money\n\nand the chain were not given then they would arrange a second marriage of\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                     9</span>\n\n\nAmar Singh. In July 1998, Deen Dayal (appellant no. 3) had come to his\n\nhouse for taking his daughter. Then too he had demanded Rs.10, 000/- and\n\nthe gold chain. He (the witness) had nothing to give; therefore, he could not\n\ngive anything. Deen Dayal became annoyed and took away his daughter\n\nAsha Devi with him in angry mood.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">11.   Dr. Dubey has referred to two sentences in the statement of PW 1 in\n\nreply to the court questions. In reply to the court questions PW 1 indeed\n\nsaid that at the time of marriage no dowry was decided and the father-in-law\n\nof his daughter had said that he would be happy with whatever they gave.\n\nBut in the very next sentence he said that after six days of marriage they\n\nbrought back Asha Devi from her matrimonial home and then his daughter\n\ntold them that his mother-in-law had been beating her and demanding\n\nRs.10, 000/-. He further said that after three to four months of marriage he\n\nwent to the matrimonial home of her daughter. He had told them (the\n\nappellants) not to make (any further) demand of dowry as he was not in a\n\nposition to give them anything. But the father-in-law of his daughter told\n\nhim that they would not keep his daughter in their house. Similarly, in his\n\ncross-examination he said that there was no talk of dowry either at the time\n\nof engagement or at the time of solemnization of marriage and the\n\nappellants took his daughter happily but again the next sentence is that at\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                     1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">                                     0</span>\nthe time of departure Deen Dayal had refused to take food and he had\n\ndemanded dowry. The deposition of PW 1 is full of the assertion about the\n\nappellants demanding rupees ten thousand and a gold chain in dowry and\n\nsubjecting her daughter Asha Devi to cruelty and harassment due to non\n\nfulfilment of their demand.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">12.   Further, the evidences of PW 2 and PW 5, the brother and the mother\n\nrespectively of the deceased, leave no room for doubt in regard to the\n\ndemand of dowry by the appellants and their subjecting Asha Devi to\n\ncruelty and harassment in connection with the demand. From the\n\nprosecution evidence the picture comes out vivid and clear that in addition\n\nto what was given to them the appellants demanded Rs.10, 000/- and a gold\n\nchain. PW 5 stated before the court as follows:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">      \"At the time of marriage, Amar Singh had demanded\n      chain of gold for himself and rupees ten thousand for his\n      father. After that the demand was repeated many times.\"\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_18\">She further stated:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">      \"Two months before death of Asha Devi, Deen Dayal\n      father-in-law of Asha Devi had come to our house for\n      taking her. Deen Dayal had demanded chain of gold for\n      his son and rupees ten thousand and he had asked to send\n      Asha Devi. My daughter was not prepared to go. But\n      we made her to comprehend and then she was sent.\n      Deen Dayal took Asha Devi with him in anger.\"\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f                                     1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_12\">                                     1</span>\n<p id=\"p_19\">The evidence on record fully establishes that there was a persistent demand\n\nof dowry by the appellants and they subjected Asha Devi to cruelty and\n\nharassment in connection with the demand and eventually beat her to death\n\ndue to its non-fulfilment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">13.   Dr. Dubey lastly contended that before any presumption may be\n\ndrawn against the appellants it must be shown that they had made the\n\ndemand for dowry and in that connection subjected Asha Devi to cruelty\n\nand harassment `soon before her death'. He submitted that according to the\n\nprosecution evidence the demand for dowry was last made in July 1998\n\nwhen appellant no.1 had gone to bring Asha Devi from her parents' house\n\nand she died on September 6, 1998. Thus, according to Dr Dubey, there was\n\nno evidence that she was subjected to any cruelty or harassment soon before\n\nher death and hence, there would be no application of <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 304-B</a> of the\n\nPenal Code and no presumption could be raised against the appellants as\n\nprovided under <a href=\"/doc/294349/\" id=\"a_11\">Section 113-A</a> of the Evidence Act. In support of the\n\nsubmission he relied upon a very large number of decisions but we see no\n\nneed to refer to those decisions as in the facts of the case the submission\n\nappears to us to be completely unacceptable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">14.     The words `soon before her death' occurring in <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_12\">section 304</a> B of the\n\nPenal Code are to be understood in a relative and flexible sense. Those\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_13\">\f                                       1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_14\">                                       2</span>\nwords cannot be construed as laying down a rigid period of time to be\n\nmechanically applied in each case. Whether or not the cruelty or harassment\n\nmeted out to the victim for or in connection with the demand of dowry was\n\nsoon before her death and the proximate cause of her death, under abnormal\n\ncircumstances, would depend upon the facts of each case. There can be no\n\nfixed period of time in this regard. From the evidence on record, it is clear\n\nthat there was an unrelenting demand for dowry and Asha Devi was\n\npersistently subjected to cruelty and harassment for and in connection with\n\nthe demand. Both her parents and her brother (PW 1, PW 5 and PW 2)\n\ndeposed before the court that appellant no.1 had once again raised his\n\ndemand when he had gone to their house in July 1998 to bring Asha Devi to\n\nhis place. Their inability to meet his demand had caused him annoyance and\n\nanger. Asha Devi was naturally apprehensive and was very reluctant to go\n\nwith him. But they somehow prevailed upon her and made her depart with\n\nhim. There is thus direct and positive evidence of her being subjected to\n\nharassment. There is nothing to show that after she was brought to the\n\nappellants' place and till her death on September 6, 1998 merely about two\n\nmonths later the situation had radically changed, the demand of dowry had\n\nceased and relations had become cordial between the deceased and the three\n\nappellants. In the facts and circumstances of the case, we are satisfied that in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_15\">\f                                        1</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_16\">                                        3</span>\nconnection with the appellants' demand for dowry Asha Devi was subjected\n\nto cruelty and that was the proximate cause of her homicidal death.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">15.      We are satisfied that all the ingredients of <a href=\"/doc/653797/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 304-B</a> of the Penal\n\nCode are fully satisfied and on the evidence on record no other view is\n\npossible but to hold that the three appellants are guilty of committing dowry\n\ndeath.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">16.      In view of the discussions made above, it follows that the view taken\n\nby the trial court was completely untenable and the High Court was fully\n\njustified in reversing its verdict in appeal preferred by the State. We thus\n\nfind no merit and substance in any of the submissions made on behalf of the\n\nappellants. The appeal fails and is accordingly dismissed.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                             .....................................J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\"> 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-20","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":1871920,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33524","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Baskar @ Kannan vs State Of T.Nadu on 20 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n               CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 1249 OF 2006\n\n\nBaskar @ Kannan                                          ....Appellant\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of Tamil Nadu                                      ....Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nMadras High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant for offence\n\npunishable under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 304</a> Part II of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in\n\nshort the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>'). The accused persons are described as A-1, A-2 etc. as\n\ndescribed by the Trial Court. A-1 by the impugned judgment of the High\n\nCourt was held guilty of offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a> IPC, while\n\fA-2 to A-7 including the present appellant were found guilty under Section\n\n304 Part II, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_4\">IPC</a> and each was sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment\n\nfor five years. A-3 to A-7 were found guilty of offence under <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 324</a>\n\nIPC and each was sentenced to under RI for two years. A-1 to A-7 were\n\nacquitted of the other charges leveled against them. A-9 and A-10 were\n\nacquitted of the charges levelled against them. Fifteen persons faced trial,\n\nout of whom the trial Court acquitted A-8, A-11 to A-15. By the impugned\n\njudgment, as noted above, the High Court directed acquittal of A-9 and A-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">10.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    The prosecution version as unfolded during trial is as follows:\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">      PW-1 is the native of Thugli Periyar Nagar. PWs 2, 3, 4 5 and 6 all\n\nbelonged to the same place. PWs 2, 3 and 4 were originally employed in\n\nAmbika Sugar Mills, Kottur. P.Ws. 6 and 7 are also the residents of the said\n\nplace and all were carrying on agricultural operations. P.W.8 belonged to\n\nkealathur village, where he was serving as village menial. P.W.9 belonged\n\nto Keezhasuriya Moolai village, where he was serving as village assistant\n\ncommunity. A-1 to A-11 and A-13 to A-15 belong to Hindu Padayachi out\n\nof whom, A-1 and A-2, though belonged to Hinduism originally, switched\n\nover to Muslim faith. A-12 belonged to another community. P.Ws. 1 to 4\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                        2</span>\n\fbelonged to scheduled caste and they were all employed at the time of\n\noccurrence under one Bhaskar.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">     On 26.3.2001 at about 5.00 p.m., after finishing work, P.Ws. 1 to 4\n\ncame out of the sugar factory and went to a nearby tea stall for taking tea. At\n\nthat time, A-1 was plying auto on the road. On seeing sugarcane on the\n\nroad, P.Ws. 1 to 4 were able to proceed on the middle of the road. When A-\n\n1 came nearby he uttered \"you add four more persons and lie on the road\".\n\nIn reply, P.W.1 told him \"on hearing the horn of the Auto, we gave way and\n\neven then, why are you scolding\". There arose a quarrel. In that, A-1 took\n\ncasurine stick and tried to attack P.W.1. The other witnesses, namely P.Ws.\n\n2 to 4 held the accused and stopped him from attacking. This was also\n\nwitnessed by Thangeraj (hereinafter referred to as deceased), who was\n\ntaking tea in a nearby tea stall. He suddenly intervened and pacified them.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">     A-1 turned the Auto and took the same to Keezhasuriyamoolai village.\n\nP.Ws. 1 to 4 went to Muniyendi Vilas for taking tea. Forty five minutes\n\nlater, at about 6.00 p.m., when the witnesses along with Thangaraju were at\n\nthe place of occurrence, A-l, A-2, A-4 to A-6 armed with aruvals, A-3\n\narmed with an iron road and A-7 armed with a knife and the other accused\n\narmed with casurina sticks, came there. The deceased Thangaraju tried to\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                           3</span>\n\fpacify them. A-1 cut the deceased on the left side of the neck. Again A-1 cut\n\nthe deceased below the left ear. A-4 cut him on the left side of the hip. A2\n\ncut him with aruval on the left shoulder. A-5 cut the deceased on the waist.\n\nA-7 stabbed him with the knife on the left armpit and the deceased fell\n\ndown. A-3 beat PW-1 on the head with the iron rod. A-4 cut P.W.1 on the\n\nleft waist. The rest of the accused surrounded P.W.1 and cut P.W.1 on the\n\nright arm, left shoulder, right thigh and on the back respectively and they\n\nfled away from the place of occurrence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">      One Mohan took P.W.1 to the Government Hospital, Kumbakonam,\n\nwhere he was admitted by P.W.10, the Doctor, at about 7.00 p.m. He issued\n\nEx.P.11, the wound certificate. A communication was received by P.W.\n\n13, the Head Constable, attached to Kumbakonam East Police Station at\n\n19.30 hours, who in turn informed the same to Penthenellur Police Station,\n\nwithin whose jurisdiction the occurrence has taken place. On receipt of the\n\nintimation on 26.3.2001 at 1930 hours, P.W.16, the Sub Inspector of Police\n\nproceeded to the Government Hospital, Kumbakonam at 2030 hours. He\n\nrecorded the statement of P.W.1, which was marked as Ex.P.1, on the\n\nstrength of which a case came to be registered in Crime No. 72 of 2001\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1258372/\" id=\"a_6\">Sections 147</a>, <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_7\">148</a>, <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_8\">324</a>, <a href=\"/doc/455468/\" id=\"a_9\">307</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_10\">302</a> IPC and Section 3(2)(v) of\n\nSC/<a href=\"/doc/53524/\" id=\"a_11\">ST Act</a>. Ext. P17 the FIR was dispatched to the Court.\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                         4</span>\n\f      P.W.19, the Deputy Superintendent of Police, on receipt of the copy\n\nof the FIR on 26.03.2001 at about 11.00 p.m., proceeded to the place of\n\noccurrence and made an inspection in the presence of two witnesses. He\n\nprepared Ex.P.2, the observation mahazar and Ex.P.35, the rough sketch. He\n\nconducted inquest on the dead body of the deceased in the presence of the\n\nwitnesses and panchayatdars and prepared Ex.P.35, the inquest report.\n\nFollowing the same, the dead body was sent to the Government Hospital,\n\nThiruvidaimarudur for the purpose of post-mortem.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      The autopsy of the dead body was conducted. During investigation\n\nA-5 gave confessional statement voluntarily and the same was recorded in\n\nthe presence of witnesses. Following the same A-5 produced five aruvals,\n\none iron rod and one knife in the presence of witnesses. After completion\n\nof investigation, charge sheet was filed. Since the accused persons pleaded\n\ninnocence trial was held. Prosecution examined 20 witnesses. As noted\n\nabove, the trial Court found the appellants to be guilty and awarded\n\npunishments.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                       5</span>\n\f      Before the High Court the primary stand related to acceptability of so\n\ncalled eye witnesses PWs 1 to 4, particular emphasis was made on the\n\nevidence of PW-1 to show that there could not have been a common object\n\nto murder the deceased or attempt to murder PW-1. It was also submitted\n\nthat it is highly unbelievable that twenty persons were involved in such an\n\nattempt. It was, therefore, highlighted that in a group clash PWs 1 to 4 could\n\nnot identify the assailants properly.     The High Court did not find any\n\nsubstance in the stand taken by the appellant. The High Court did not accept\n\nthe stand of the prosecution regarding applicability of <a href=\"/doc/53524/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 302</a> read with\n\n<a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 149</a> IPC. It was held that in respect of the respective acts committed\n\nby each one of them the matter is required to be considered. From the post\n\nmortem certificate it was noticed that the first injury was caused by A-1\n\nwith aruval on the neck and the corresponding injuries caused the death. At\n\nthe same time, A-2, A-4, A-5 and A-6 were armed with aruval, A-7 with\n\nknife and A-3 with iron rod and they have attacked the deceased and\n\ncontributed corresponding injuries. Therefore, it was held that A-1 had to\n\nbe convicted in terms of <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 302</a> IPC. So far as others are concerned the\n\nacts attracted <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_15\">Section 304</a> Part II IPC.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                          6</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">\f3.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the appellant submitted\n\nthat the High Court has erred in discarding the stand of the appellants before\n\nit. So far as the present appellant is concerned there was no specific role\n\nattributed to him. Therefore, his conviction as maintained by the High\n\nCourt cannot be sustained.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">4.    Learned counsel for the respondent-State on the other hand submitted\n\nthat this is a case where clearly <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 302</a> IPC read with <a href=\"/doc/53524/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 149</a> was\n\napplicable. He however conceded that no appeal has been filed by the State\n\nquestioning the judgment of the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">5.    It is to be noted that PW-1 was not only an eye witness but also an\n\ninjured witness. Merely because PWs 1 to 4 were related to the deceased\n\nthat cannot be a ground to cast a doubt on the authenticity of their evidence.\n\nWhat was required was the closer scrutiny of the evidence. PW-1 has\n\nnarrated the entire incident in Ext.P-1 which was lodged immediately while\n\nhe was admitted in the Government Hospital for treatment. In the Ext.P-1\n\nPW-1 has categorically stated about the presence of A-1 to A-7. He had also\n\nstated that A-1, A-2, A-3 A-4, A-5, and A-6, the present appellant were\n\narmed with aruvals. He had also given a detailed description of the overt\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                          7</span>\n\facts attributable to each one of them, and as to how they attacked the\n\ndeceased. His evidence in Court is to similar effect . The evidence of PWs 2\n\nto 4 is also in similar lines.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">6.     The High Court noted that after there was a quarrel A-1 went to his\n\nvillage and brought all the accused persons with him. On the facts of the\n\ncase the High Court noted that there was absence of common object. What\n\nwas to be expected was an assault. Accordingly, it was held that A-2 to A-7\n\nwere guilty of offence punishable under Section 304 Part II, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_18\">IPC</a>. We find\n\nthat the trial Court and the High Court have rightly found the appellant\n\nguilty. The reasoning given by the High Court to find the appellant guilty\n\ndoes not suffer from any infirmity. The appeal is without merit and is\n\ndismissed accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                                                  ...............................................J.\n                                                                 (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n       .....................................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                                                 (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 206, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                                                                              8</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":2,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"sec 2(1)(d)","formInput":"sec%202%281%29%28d%29"},{"value":"meaning of  \"or' ","formInput":"meaning%20of%20%20%22or%27%20"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Vyavasthapak C. The appeal preferred against that order\nwas dismissed by the Maharashtra Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission [for\nshort, `the State Commission'], and appellate order has been confirmed by the\nNational Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission [for short, `the National\nCommission]. Hence, this appeal by special leave.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">          Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellants submitted that the\ncomplainant was not a \"consumer\" within the meaning of <a href=\"/doc/992267/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 2(1)(d)</a> of the\nConsumer Protection Act, 1986 (for short, `the Act') and the complaint was barred by\nlimitation, but without properly appreciating the arguments put forward on behalf of\nthe appellants, the District Forum and State and National Commissions ruled in\n                                                                                 ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">favour of the respondent. On the other hand, learned counsel appearing on behalf of\nthe respondent submitted that he was a \"consumer\" within the meaning of <a href=\"/doc/334666/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 2</a>\n(1)(d) of the Act, especially in view of the explanation thereto as the machine was\npurchased by the complainant exclusively for earning livelihood by means of self-\nemployment. He further submitted that the complaint was not barred by limitation\nand the District Forum did not commit any error by granting relief to the respondent.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           A perusal of the record shows that both the parties had filed affidavits\nbefore the District Forum in support of their respective pleadings, but no evidence\nwas produced on the issues whether the respondent is a \"consumer\" within the\nmeaning of <a href=\"/doc/992267/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 2(1)(d)</a> of the Act and whether the complaint was within\nlimitation. In our view, having regard to the nature of controversy raised before it,\nthe District Forum should have afforded opportunities to the parties to lead evidence\nand as the matter has been decided without taking recourse to that procedure, the\nimpugned orders are liable to be set aside.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned order are set aside and the\nmatter is remitted to the District Forum, Jalgaon, to decide the complaint afresh after\ngiving opportunity to the parties to adduce evidence. It is needless to say that the\nquestion of limitation shall also be decided afresh by the District Forum.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                [B.N. He has agreed to pay\nthe first instalment of Rupees seven lakhs fifty thousand on 30th April, 2009 and the\nsecond instalment on or before 31st July, 2009. Both the parties have agreed in Court\nthat the aforesaid payment shall be made by an Account Payee Draft drawn in favour\nof the wife upon a Bank at Lahar, District Bhind, within the State of Madhya\nPradesh. Learned\n                                                                                ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">counsel appearing on behalf of the wife stated that the petition filed by her under\n<a href=\"/doc/1056396/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 125</a> of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which is pending in the Court of\nJudicial Magistrate, First Class, Lahar, may be treated as withdrawn. As regards\nCriminal Case No.4929 of 2006 pending in the Court of Judicial Magistrate, First\nClass, Gwalior, within the State of Madhya Pradesh, against the husband and other\naccused persons, the parties agree that the same may be quashed in view of the\ncompromise.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           In our view, the compromise is lawful. Madhava Reddy & Anr vs Land Acqu.Officer-Cum-Mandal ... on 22 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33988","lastname":"......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-22","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">T. Madhava Reddy &amp; Anr vs Land Acqu.Officer-Cum-Mandal ... on 22 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: B.N. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NO.4070 OF 2001\n\n\nT. Madhava Reddy and Anr.                      ...Appellant(s)\n\n\n                                        Versus\n\n\nLand Acquisition Officer-Cum-Mandal\nRevenue Officer                                           ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                                     O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">            Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">            The Land Acquisition Officer awarded compensation in relation to the\nland belonging to Appellant No.1 at the rate of rupees ten thousand per acre, whereas\nin relation to Appellant No.2 compensation was awarded at the rate of Rupees six\nthousand per acre. On an application filed under <a href=\"/doc/1517117/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 18</a> of the Land Acquisition\nAct, 1894, the Reference Court after making a detailed analysis of the evidence\nproduced by the parties, enhanced the compensation in relation to the land of\nAppellant No.1 from Rupees ten thousand per acre to rupees twenty thousand per\nacre, whereas, in relation to the land of Appellant no.2 from rupees six thousand per\nacre to rupees ten thousand per acre. On appeal, the High Court reversed that order.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">            Having heard learned counsel for the parties and perused the records, we\nare of the view that the impugned order is liable to be set aside because the High\nCourt has\n                                                                                ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">not recorded any reason whatsoever for upsetting the well reasoned award passed by\nthe Reference Court after due consideration of the material produced by the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned order rendered by the High\nCourt is set aside and award dated 20th August, 1990, passed by the Reference Court\nis restored.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           No costs.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">                                                                       ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                              [B.N.
