SINGHVI]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 22, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1488812,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1517117,"url":null,"title":"Section 18 in The Land Acquisition Act, 1894"}]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"weaker section","formInput":"weaker%20section"},{"value":"slp","formInput":"slp"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Suraj Singh vs State Of M.P. & Ors on 9 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33659","lastname":"......................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-09","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Suraj Singh vs State Of M.P. &amp; Ors on 9 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ......................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: B.N. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                      CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NO.58 OF 2009\n                     (Arising out of S.L.P. (C) No.3193 of 2004)\n\n\n\nSuraj Singh                                              ...Appellant(s)\n\n\n                                       Versus\n\n\nState of Madhya Pradesh &amp; Ors.                           ...Respondent(s)\n\nWith Civil Appeal No.63/2009 @ S.L.P. (C) No.12082/2004\n\n\n\n\n                                   O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">          The appellants filed petitions under Section 5 of the Madhya Pradesh\nSamaj Ke Kamjor Vargon Ke Krishi Bhumi-Dharakon Ka Udhar Dene Walon Ke\nBhumi Hadapane Sambhandhi Kuchakron Se Paritran Tatha Mukti Adhiniyam,\n1976, (for short `the Adhiniyam') and claimed relief under Section 7 of the\nAdhiniyam by asserting that they belong to the category of weaker section of the\nbackward caste; that they borrowed amount from Jai Kumar Jain (husband of\nrespondent No.4 herein) and executed sale deed of land measuring 1.32 and 2.57\nhectares respectively as security for return of the borrowed money; that they have\nrepaid the loan within one year but instead of canceling the sale deeds, Jai Kumar\nJain, in connivance with the revenue authorities, got the name of his wife, Smt.\nSampat Bai, mutated in the revenue records.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">                                                                             ....2/-\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">\f                                         -   2-\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           The Sub-Divisional Officer, before whom petitions were filed issued notice\nto respondent No.4, heard the parties and passed order dated 22.6.1999 whereby he\ndeclared the sale transactions as null and void under Section 7 of the Adhiniyam and\ndirected the concerned Patwari to delete the land which was subject matter of sale\ndeeds from the land record of respondent No.4 and include the same in the land\nrecord of the petitioners (appellants herein). Respondent No.4 challenged the order\nof the Sub Divisional Officer by filing appeals under Section 8 of the Adhiniyam,\nwhich were allowed by the Collector on the premise that the appellants do not belong\nto weaker section. The Collector observed that the Sub Divisional Officer did not\nconduct enquiry in accordance with Section 6 of the Adhiniyam and held that he\ncould not have nullified the sale deeds on the basis of preliminary enquiry. The writ\npetitions filed by the appellants against the order of the Collector were dismissed by\nthe learned Single Judge who confirmed the finding of the Collector that the\nprovisions of the Adhiniyam are not applicable to the cases of the appellants herein.\nWrit appeals preferred by the appellants were dismissed by the Division Bench.\nHence, these appeals by special leave.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           We have heard learned counsel for the parties and perused the record. The\nonly question which requires consideration in these appeals is whether the appellants\nfall within the ambit of the expression `holder of agricultural land' as defined in\nSection 2(c) of the Adhiniyam, which reads as under:\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">       \"'holder of agricultural land' in the weaker sections of the people\n       means a holder of land used for purposes of Agriculture not exceeding\n       eight hectares of unirrigated land or four hectares of irrigated within\n       the State whether as a Bhumiswami or an occupancy tenant or a\n       Government lessee either in any one or all of the capacities together\n       within the meaning of the Code.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                                                                         ....3/-\n</blockquote><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                        -3-</span>\n\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">       Explanation.- One hectare of irrigated land shall be equal to two\n       hectares of unirrigated land and vice-versa.\"</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_7\">          From a bare perusal of the above reproduced definition, it becomes clear\nthat a person holding land not exceeding eight hectares (unirrigated) or four hectares\n(irrigated) which is used for agricultural purposes, whether as a Bhumiswami or as a\noccupancy tenant or a Government lessee, is covered by the definition of the `holder\nof agricultural land' in the weaker sections of the people. In terms of Section 5, such\nperson is entitled to protection and relief under the Adhiniyam, which has been\nenacted for protecting weaker sections of the people who are often compelled to seek\nloan from private money lending agency to meet their obligations and are coerced to\ntransfer their agricultural holdings for securing repayment of loan. The revenue\nrecords produced before the Court shows that the appellants in civil appeals arising\nout of S.L.P. (C) No.3193 of 2004 and S.L.P.(C) No.12082 of 2004 were holding 1.32\nand 2.57 hectares of land respectively. The Sub Divisional Officer examined the\nrecords and concluded that they are entitled to protection under Section 5 of the\nAdhiniyam because the sale deeds executed by them in favour of Jai Kumar Jain fall\nin the category of prohibited transactions within the meaning of Section 4 of the\nAdhiniyam. While allowing the appeals filed by respondent No.4, the Collector held\nthat the provisions of the Adhiniyam are not applicable to the appellants herein but\nhe did not assign any reason for recording that finding. The Collector also observed\nthat the sale deeds are not vitiated by fraud but while doing so he\n                                                                                  ....4/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                          -4-</span>\n<p id=\"p_8\">completely ignored Sections 3 and 4 of the Adhiniyam which give overriding effect to\nthe provisions of the Adhiniyam and declare that all prohibited transactions of loan\nas defined in Section 2(f) are subject to the protection and relief under the\nAdhiniyam. The learned Single Judge of the High Court confirmed the order of the\nCollector by relying upon the statement made by the appellants herein in which they\nare said to have admitted that apart from doing agricultural operations, they were\nhaving a shop, floor mill, a motorcycle, buffalos and other animals. In the opinion of\nthe learned Single Judge, the appellants do not belong to the weaker section because\nthey were not wholly dependent on agriculture. The Division Bench simply reiterated\nthe reasoning of the learned Single Judge and dismissed the letters patent appeals.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">            In our view, the order of the Collector is vitiated by error of law apparent\non the face of the record because while allowing the appeals of respondent No.4, he\ndid not consider the relevant provisions of the Adhiniyam and did not assign any\nreason why provisions thereof are not applicable to the appellants. The observations\nof the Collector that the appellants herein were holding more land is ex facie contrary\nto the revenue records. The learned Single Judge repeated the error committed by the\nCollector and went a step further by observing that the appellants cannot be said to\nbelong to weaker section because they were having a shop, floor mill, motorcycle,\nbuffalos and other animals. Since, the definition of `holder of agricultural land'\ncontained in Section 2(c) does not exclude a person having a floor mill or a shop,\ndismissal of the writ petitions by the learned Single Judge and letters patent appeals\nby the Division Bench only on the ground that the appellants possessed shop, floor\nmill, etc. cannot be sustained.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                                                                        ....5/-\n</p>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                          -5-</span>\n<p id=\"p_11\">            Accordingly, the appeals are allowed, impugned orders passed by the\nCollector and confirmed by the High Court in writ petitions as well as in letters\npatent appeals are set aside and the orders passed by the Sub Divisional Officer are\nrestored.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_12\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">\f                    [B.N. AGRAWAL]\n\n\n\n                                     ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                    [G.S. SINGHVI]\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 09, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1369564,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"taking over the possession","formInput":"taking%20over%20the%20possession"},{"value":"allotment of plots ","formInput":"allotment%20of%20plots%20"},{"value":"allotment letter","formInput":"allotment%20letter"},{"value":"darsh kumar","formInput":"darsh%20kumar"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Ghaziabad Development Authority vs Ramesh Chandra Pandiya on 29 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33644","lastname":"...........................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-29","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Ghaziabad Development Authority vs Ramesh Chandra Pandiya on 29 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...........................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: R.V. Raveendran, Aftab Alam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                         CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NO. 6049 OF 2002\n\nGHAZIABAD                     DEVELOPMENT                        .......APPELLANT(S)\nAUTHORITY\n\n                                                   Versus\n\nRAMESH CHANDRA PANDIYA                                           .....RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n\n                                      ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          The appellant allotted plot No. E-170 at Nehru Nagar measuring 167.44 sq.\n\nmt. vide allotment letter dated 5.6.1985, the price being Rs.37,842/-. The appellant send\n\nletters demanding payment of instalments which had become due and called upon the\n\nrespondent to enter into a lease deed and take possession of the allotted site. The said\n\nallotment was cancelled on 16.3.1990 on the ground that the respondent had failed to\n\ntake possession.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.        The respondent requested withdrawal of the cancellation and restoration of\n\nthe allotment, vide letter dated 17.3.1990.   By letter dated 19.4.1990, the appellant\n\nrestored the allotment subject to payment of restoration fee and subject to the condition\n\nthat it would be the responsibility of the respondent to take possession and he will not\n\nseek change of plot. The respondent, however, applied for allotment of alternative plot\n\non 15.9.1994, alleging that the municipal authorities had laid a sewer line on the plot\n\nand that some\n\n                                                                                   ......2.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           -2-</span><p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\n\npart of the plot was also encroached. The appellant thereafter allotted an alternative\n\nplot (Plot No. 6/167, Vaishali) measuring 250.77 sq.mt. on 31.1.1996 and demanded\n\npayment of Rs.3,39,179/- after adjusting Rs.56,820/- which had been paid by the\n\nrespondent towards the earlier allotment. The price charged for the Vaishali site is\n\nstated to be about Rs.1400/- per sq. mt.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.        Feeling aggrieved by the said demand, the respondent approached the State\n\nConsumer Disputes Redressal Commission, U.P. seeking a direction to the appellant to\n\ndeliver the Vaishali plot at the original price of allotment which was about Rs.226/- per\n\nsq.mt. He also prayed for damages as also interest on the amount that was deposited by\n\nhim for the Nehru Nagar plot. The State Commission by its order dated 29.3.2001\n\nallowed the complaint. It directed the appellant to deliver the Vaishali plot measuring\n\n250.77 sq.mt. at the original allotment price of Rs.226/- per sq.mt. It further directed\n\nthe appellant to pay interest at 18% per annum on the amount deposited by the\n\nrespondent towards the cost of Nehru Nagar plot.         It also awarded Rs.38,000/- as\n\ncompensation to respondent and also directed the appellant to pay the escalation\n\ntowards the cost of construction of the house, worked out on the basis of cost of\n\nconstruction index in U.P. in the year 1985 and the year of delivery of possession.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                                                                      .......3.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                           -3-</span><p id=\"p_8\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4.        The said order was challenged by the appellant before the National\n\nCommission.      The National Commission deleted the direction for payment of\n\ncompensation of Rs.38,000/- and the direction that appellant should pay escalation in\n\nthe cost of construction. It, however, affirmed the direction for delivery of Vaishali plot\n\nat the price of Rs.226/- and the direction for payment of interest at 18% per annum on\n\nthe amount earlier deposited by the respondent in regard to Nehru Nagar plot. The\n\nNational Commission relied on its earlier decision in HUDA Vs. Darsh Kumar (Revision\n\nPetition No.1197/1998 decided on 31.8.2001) for awarding interest at such rate. The\n\nsaid order is under challenge.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.        Appellant submitted that the decision of the National Commission in Darsh\n\nKumar has been reversed by this Court in Haryana Urban Development Authority Vs.\n\nDarsh Kumar &amp; Ors., (2005) 9 SCC 449.            The appellant also contended that the\n\ncancellation of allotment in the year 1990 was as a consequence of breaches and was in\n\naccordance with the terms of allotment and the Rules. It was pointed out that as per the\n\nterms of letter of allotment, instalments of Rs.3784.20 had to be paid by the respondent\n\non 4.12.85, 4.6.86, 4.12.86, 4.6.87, 4.12.87, 4.6.88, 4.12.88 and 4.6.89, apart from\n\nexecuting the lease deed and taking possession. It was stated that the respondent did\n\nnot enter into any lease agreement and\n\n                                                                                     .....4.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                          -4-</span><p id=\"p_12\">\n\n\n\ntake possession nor pay the instalments as and when they fell due in terms of the said\n\nallotment letter. It was contended that on account of the delay and breaches on the part\n\nof the respondent in executing the lease deed and taking possession, the plot was\n\nencroached subsequent to the date of allotment leading to unnecessary complications. It\n\nwas submitted that the appellant was entitled to charge the prevailing price for the\n\nalternative plot.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">6.         The respondent denies the allegation of breach by him. According to the\n\nrespondent, the allotted plot was under encroachment even when he went to inspect it\n\nand, therefore, he could not take possession.       He also stated that possession of\n\nalternative site at Vaishali has been delivered to him in the year 2008, when he executed\n\nthe order of the State Commission.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">7.         However, after the matter was argued for some time, the learned counsel for\n\nrespondents on instructions, submitted that to put an end to the controversy,         the\n\nrespondent was willing to pay the prevailing allotment price of Rs.1400/- per sq. mt. in\n\nregard to the Vaishali plot and will not press the claim for interest on the amount paid\n\nfor the earlier allotted site.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">                                                                                   ......5.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                           -5-</span><p id=\"p_19\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">8.        Learned counsel for the appellant is not in a position to give any acceptable\n\nreason to deny the respondent the benefit of the alternative plot that has been delivered\n\nto him, when he is even willing to pay the price demanded. We are of the view that\n\nhaving regard to the factual background, neither party shall be entitled to interest.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">9.        We, therefore, allow this appeal in part and modify the order of the State\n\nCommission and National Commission as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">(a)       The respondent will be entitled to retain plot No.6/167 at Vaishali measuring\n\n250.77 sq.mt. allotted to him. Consequently, the appellant shall issue necessary letter of\n\nallotment/communication regularising and confirming the allotment.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">(b)       The cost of the said Vaishali plot shall be paid at the rate of Rs.1400/- per sq.\n\nmt. The price calculated at the said rate less the amount already deposited by the\n\nrespondent shall be paid by the respondent to the appellant within three months.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">(c)       A sum of Rs.1,09,160/- is said to have been paid by the appellant to the\n\nrespondent towards interest etc. in terms of\n\n                                                                                        ....6.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                              -6-</span><p id=\"p_26\">\n\n\n\nthe order of the Commission. The said amount shall also be refunded by the respondent\n\nto the appellant within three months in addition to the difference in price as a condition\n\nprecedent for confirming the allotment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_27\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">(d)       Failing such payments, the appellant shall be entitled to cancel the allotment\n\nand take back possession.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_29\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">(e)       The appellant will not be entitled to charge any interest on the balance amount\n\ndue for the Vaishali plot. Nor will the respondent be entitled to any interest on the\n\namount already paid.        Neither party will be entitled to any amount by way of\n\ncompensation or costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_31\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_32\">(f)       On payment of amounts as aforesaid, the appellant will execute/issue the\n\nnecessary documents of title in regard to the Vaishali plot at the cost of the respondent.\n\n\n\n</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">(g)       Parties to bear their respective costs.\n\n\n\n                                                ...........................J.\n                                                ( R.V. VIDEOCON LEASING&amp;INDL.FIN.LTD.&amp;ANR.                                ...   Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n                                  ORDER\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">             Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">             This appeal is directed against the judgment and order dated 12th June,\n\n    2006 passed by the Bombay High Court in Appeal No.922 of 2005 in Summons for\n\n    Judgment No.717 of 1999 in Summary Suit No. 475 of 1999 affirming the judgment\n\n    of the learned Single Judge, granting conditional leave to the appellant to contest the\n\n    suit filed by the respondent upon depositing Rs. 3.1 crores as pre-condition for\n\n    defending the suit.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">             We have heard Mr. R.F. Nariman, learned senior\n\n    counsel, appearing in support of the appeal and from the materials, it appears that\n\n    there are several triable issues\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                     -2-</span>\n\nto be considered in the suit, which has been filed under Order 37 CPC. He has relied\n\non the decision of this Court in the case of Mechelec Engineers &amp; Manufacturers Vs.\n\nM/s. Basic Equipment Corporation, reported in 1977 (1) SCR 1060, wherein a Bench\n\nof three Judges had laid down certain propositions with regard to the grant of leave\n\nin respect of     summary trials.     The present case appears to be covered by\n\nproposition (b) of the said propositions.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">         On behalf of the respondent(s) it has been submitted that since leave had\n\nbeen obtained by the respondent herein for filing the suit under Clause 12 of the\n\nLetters Patent, that itself should be sufficient to indicate that part of the cause of\n\naction has arisen within the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">         Be that as it may, since the suit filed by the respondent does raise questions\n\nwhich, prima facie, appear to be triable, following the decision in the Mechelec\n\nEngineers &amp; Manufacturers case (supra), we are of the view that the High Court\n\nerred in directing the appellant to deposit the amount, as mentioned in the cheque.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">         We, accordingly, allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court\n\nand grant unconditional leave to\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     -3-</span>\n\nthe appellant to defend the suit in question. The High Court, however, is requested\n\nto take all such steps as may be possible to dispose of the suit as expeditiously as\n\npossible, but at least within a year from the date of communication of this order.\n\f              There will be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                      (ALTAMAS KABIR)\n\n\n\n                                                  ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                            (CYRIAC JOSEPH)\n\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 05, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":1077173,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"transfer petition","formInput":"transfer%20petition"},{"value":"family judge","formInput":"family%20judge"},{"value":"special judge","formInput":"special%20judge"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Ajaya vs Sanjaya Golecha on 7 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33657","lastname":"...................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-07","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Ajaya vs Sanjaya Golecha on 7 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: B.N. Raveendran, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                        CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                             CIVIL APPEAL NO. 35 OF 2009\n                           [Arising out of SLP(C) No.12856/2008]\n\nADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER, MUNICIPAL SCHOOL\nBOARD, KAGAL                                                       .......APPELLANT(S)\n\n                                                   Versus\n\nKAGAL TALUKA KALA KRIDA SHAIKSHANIK AND\nSANSKRUTIK MANDAL &amp; ORS.                                           .....RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n                                       ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.        The appellant is the Municipal School Board, Kagal, ('the Board', for short).\n\nSant Rohidas Vidyamandir, the fourth respondent, is one of the schools run by the\n\nBoard. The said school, which was running classes from first to fourth standards,\n\nstarted fifth standard classes (Standard V Division) from the session 2007-2008. The\n\nfirst respondent, which runs a secondary school (V Standard to X Standard) in the Zila\n\nParishad area adjoining the municipal area, filed W.P. No.8261/2007 seeking a direction\n\nto the State of Maharashtra, the appellant and the Deputy Director of Education,\n\nKolhapur Region to close down the V Standard started in the fourth respondent school\n\nand a further direction not to grant any recognition or permission to the fourth\n\nrespondent school to start Standard V Division.      They   also     sought   an   interim\n\ndirection restraining the fourth\n\n                                                                                   .......2.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span><p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\n\nrespondent school from running or continuing the V Standard classes.            The first\n\nrespondent contended that starting of the V Standard classes by the fourth respondent\n\nschool was unauthorised and illegal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">3.        In the said writ petition, the High Court, while issuing rule on 8.4.2008 issued\n\nan interim direction to the fourth respondent to close down the V Standard and transfer\n\nthe students of V Standard to other schools as per the desire of the students and their\n\nguardians, and issue school leaving certificates to the students to enable them to get\n\nadmissions in other authorised schools. The Deputy Director of Education and the\n\npetitioner were also directed by way of interim order to ensure that the V Standard\n\nclasses opened by the fourth respondent was closed down and the students were\n\ntransferred to other schools. The said interim order is challenged by the appellant\n\nBoard which runs the fourth respondent school.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.        We find that the High Court has virtually allowed the writ petition by the\n\ninterim order, that too by an irreversible peremptory direction that the students be\n\nshifted to other schools. The students were not parties before the High Court and they\n\nhave been asked to take school leaving certificates from the fourth respondent school and\n\nshift to other schools. Such a peremptory irreversible step should not normally have\n\nbeen granted by way of interim relief, unless\n\n                                                                                    ......3.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                          -3-</span><p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n\nextraordinary or special circumstances exist. We find that there are no such special\n\ncircumstances.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.        Learned counsel for the first respondent submitted that            the fourth\n\nrespondent was one of the feeder schools for the first respondent school, and if the\n\nfourth respondent runs classes from V Standard onwards, their admission will be\n\naffected. This contention, we are afraid, is not sound. The question is not whether first\n\nrespondent is affected, but whether fourth respondent was doing something which was\n\nillegal and whether the first respondent had any right to complain.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">6.        Primary education is defined in Section 2(15) of the Bombay Primary\n\nEducation Act, 1947 as meaning education in such subjects and upto such standards, as\n\nmay be determined by the State Government from time to time. Primary education,\n\ntherefore, does not mean education from first to fourth standards only, as contended by\n\nthe first respondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">7.        The State Government has, in its counter filed before the High Court, clearly\n\nstated that as per the provisions of the Mumbai Primary Education Rule 1949 the\n\nPrimary Education Boards of Municipal Council are empowered to open standards as\n\nnatural growth in the primary schools being run by them, that\n\n                                                                                  ........4.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                            -4-</span><p id=\"p_15\">\n\n\n\nthe Primary Education Board had opened the V Standard classes in the fourth\n\nrespondent school in pursuance of such natural growth and that no permission was\n\nrequired to open V Standard classes as natural growth in schools run by Municipal\n\nBoard. It was further categorically stated that the Board was authorised to open V\n\nStandard as natural growth in the fourth respondent school and that was not\n\nunauthorised or illegal.    We may also refer to the Government Resolution dated\n\n14.11.1979 of the State Government relied on by the first respondent itself which says\n\nthat classes V to VII may either be annexed to secondary schools or to primary schools\n\nrun by local bodies. If that is so, primary schools run by Boards, prima facie, can run\n\nclasses V to VII. Be that as it may. All that we are pointing out is there was absolutely\n\nno basis for the High Court at the stage of admission of the writ petition filed by the first\n\nrespondent to assume that the starting of V Standard by the fourth respondent school\n\nwas unauthorised or illegal and direct closure by way of interim relief.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">8.        We, therefore, allow this appeal, set aside the interim order. The fourth\n\nrespondent school run by the appellant can, therefore, have V, VI and VII Standards,\n\nsubject to the final decision in the writ petition.     We are told that the issue as to\n\nwhether Standards V to VII can be part of primary\n\n                                                                                       ......5.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                             -5-</span><p id=\"p_17\">\n\n\n\nschools, is causing considerable confusion in the State. In view of it, we request the High\n\nCourt to dispose of the Writ Petition expeditiously.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">                                              ...........................J.</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\n                                              ( R.V. RAVEENDRAN )\n\n\n\nNew Delhi;                              ...........................J.\nJanuary 05, 2009.          ( J.M. 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-13","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":827169,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":"l","lastname":"panta","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"s","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33484","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Ram Das vs State Of M.P on 13 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: L S Panta</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Lokeshwar Singh Panta, B. Sudershan Reddy</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                              Non-Reportable\n\n\n            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n           CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n         CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.            47 OF 2009\n       [Arising 0ut of S.L.P. (Crl.) No.7738 OF 2008]\n\n\nRamdas                                    .....         Appellant\n\n                              Versus\n\nState of Madhya Pradesh                    .....      Respondent\n\n\n\n                          ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Lokeshwar Singh Panta, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">1.   Delay condoned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">2.   Special leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.   This appeal arises out of judgment dated 26.10.2007\n\npassed by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh, Bench at\n\nGwalior, whereby and whereunder the appeal preferred by the\n\nappellant has been partly allowed.        By the impugned\n\njudgment, the learned Single Judge of the High Court altered\n\nthe conviction of the appellant from <a href=\"/doc/261195/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 307</a> of the Indian\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                             2</span><a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">\n\n\nPenal Code</a> (for short `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">IPC</a>') to <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 324</a> IPC recorded by the\n\nlearned Sessions Judge, Morena, in Sessions Trial No.\n\n190/1999 and sentenced him to suffer rigorous imprisonment\n\nfor 3 years instead of 7 years as imposed by the trial judge.\n\nFine of Rs.2,000/-, out of which a sum of Rs.1,500/- was\n\nordered to be paid to Smt. Shakuntla Bai (PW-4) widow of\n\ndeceased Krishna Sharma, has not been interfered with.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">4.   The incident leading to the prosecution of the appellant\n\noccurred on 20.08.1994 at Village Purawas Khurd, Police\n\nStation Sihoniy, District Morena, Madhya Pradesh. According\n\nto the prosecution, one month prior to the day of the incident,\n\nShri Krishna Sharma purchased a she-buffalo from appellant\n\nRamdas for a consideration of Rs.5,000/-.       It was agreed\n\nbetween the parties that the amount of consideration would\n\nbe paid after birth of calf of she-buffalo. On 19.08.1994, calf\n\nof she-buffalo was born.         On the day of incident, i.e.\n\n20.08.1994, at about 10 a.m. Shri Krishna Sharma went to\n\nthe house of the appellant for the payment of Rs.5,000/-\n\nwhere Sheetal Prasad co-accused was also present. The\n\nappellant made a demand of Rs. 150/- towards interest\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                             3</span>\n\n\namount for which Shri Krishna Sharma did not agree because\n\nthere was no such agreement between the parties to pay the\n\ninterest of Rs.150/-. On this trivial issue, some altercation\n\ntook place between the parties, as a result whereof the\n\nappellant dealt sickle blow on the back of the person of Shri\n\nKrishna Sharma. As a result of the said injury, blood started\n\ncoming from the wound. The incident had been witnessed by\n\nRajaram (PW-2), Ram Kishan (PW-3), Smt. Shakuntla Bai (PW-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4) and Ram Swaroop (PW-5).       After causing injury to the\n\nvictim, the appellant and Sheetal Prasad both had fled from\n\nthe scene of occurrence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">5.   Shri Krishna Sharma, injured, lodged First Information\n\nReport under <a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_5\">Sections 323</a>/<a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_6\">324</a>/<a href=\"/doc/555306/\" id=\"a_7\">504</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_8\">34</a> of IPC in the Police\n\nStation against the accused persons, on the basis of which the\n\ninvestigation was conducted by Lal Singh Yadav (PW-8) who\n\nrecorded the statements of the witnesses, inspected the place\n\nof the occurrence and arrested the accused. Shri Krishna\n\nSharma was medically examined by Dr. Jagdish Karkot (PW-7)\n\non the same day who found following injuries on his person:\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                               4</span>\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">             \"One incised wound on the left side back\n             of patient in the size of 1.4 cm x 2 mm x\n             1.3 cm.\"\n</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_9\">6.   Injured Shri Krishna Sharma died on 01.07.1996 (near\n\nabout 2 years after the incident). Therefore, <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 302</a> IPC\n\nwas added in the chargesheet.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">7.   The learned Sessions Judge, on the basis of the evidence,\n\ncharge-sheeted the appellant and the co-accused Sheetal\n\nPrasad under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_10\">Sections 302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_11\">34</a> IPC.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">8.   Both the accused pleaded not guilty to the charges and\n\nclaimed to be tried. In order to bring home the charges,\n\nprosecution examined as many as 10 witnesses and placed on\n\nrecord relevant documentary evidence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">9.   The learned Sessions Judge, on scrutiny of the entire\n\nevidence on record, held the appellant guilty of the offence\n\npunishable   under   <a href=\"/doc/455468/\" id=\"a_12\">Section       307</a>   IPC   and,   accordingly,\n\nsentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for 7 years\n\nand to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000/-. Out of the said amount, a\n\nsum of Rs. 1,500/- has been ordered to be paid to Smt.\n\nShakuntla Bai (PW-4), widow of deceased Shri Krishna\n\nSharma. However, no tangible and convincing evidence has\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                5</span>\n\n\nbeen found against co-accused Sheetal Prasad, therefore, he\n\nwas acquitted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">10. Being aggrieved, the appellant filed appeal under <a href=\"/doc/261195/\" id=\"a_13\">Section\n\n374</a> (2)<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_14\"> of Code</a> of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (for short `<a href=\"/doc/445276/\" id=\"a_15\">Cr.P.C</a>')\n\nbefore the High Court. The learned Single Judge of the High\n\nCourt allowed the appeal in part and altered the conviction of\n\nthe appellant from <a href=\"/doc/455468/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 307</a> IPC to <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_17\">Section 324</a> IPC and\n\nimposed the aforesaid sentence upon him.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">11.   Feeling aggrieved thereby and dissatisfied with the\n\njudgment of the High Court, this appeal by special leave has\n\nbeen preferred in this Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">12.   Having heard Mr. T.S. Doabia, learned Senior Advocate\n\nfor the appellant, this Court issued notice to the State of\n\nMadhya Pradesh confined to the question of quantum of\n\nsentence. Mr. Govind Goel, learned counsel has appeared on\n\nbehalf of the State. Mr. T.S. Doabia, learned Senior Advocate,\n\nstates at the Bar that the appellant has already undergone\n\nabout 15 months of imprisonment in terms of the order of the\n\nHigh Court.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                               6</span><p id=\"p_16\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">13.   On our close scrutiny of the testimony of eye-witnesses -\n\nPWs 2 and 3 and having gone through the First Information\n\nReport (Ex.P/1), it is clear that on the date of the incident, all\n\nof a sudden altercation ensued between the appellant and\n\ndeceased Shri Krishna Sharma on the issue of payment of Rs.\n\n150/- as interest amount. There is no evidence on record to\n\nindicate that there was any previous enmity between the\n\nappellant and the deceased. The appellant is an agriculturist.\n\nUndisputedly, a single blow of sickle had been inflicted by the\n\nappellant on the back of the deceased. Dr. P.R. Pendharkar\n\n(PW-1) conducted an autopsy on the dead body of Shri\n\nKrishna Sharma who as stated above died on 01.07.1996.\n\nAccording to Dr. P.R. Pendharkar, 11 injuries were found on\n\nthe dead body of the deceased, out of which injury no. 10 was\n\nincised wound allegedly inflicted by the appellant on the back\n\nside of the deceased. In the opinion of the doctor, injury nos.\n\n1 to 9 were in the nature of `Ulcers' and indirect outcome of\n\ninjury no. 10.    The opinion of the doctor proves that the\n\ndeceased had not died due to direct result of injury no. 10\n\nsustained by him. It is also pertinent to mention that the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                              7</span>\n\n\noccurrence had taken place on 20.08.1994 and since then the\n\nappellant has been prosecuting the present case for the last\n\nmore than 14 years in various courts and in that process he\n\nundoubtedly has undergone mental agony and financial\n\nsufferings.   In this view of the matter, in our considered\n\nopinion we feel that justice would be sub-served if the\n\nsentence imposed by the High Court, is reduced to the\n\nsentence already undergone by the appellant.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">14.   For the aforementioned reasons while maintaining the\n\nconviction of the appellant under <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_18\">Section 324</a> IPC, the\n\nsentence of 3 years imposed by the learned Single Judge of\n\nthe High Court is reduced to imprisonment already suffered\n\nby the appellant.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">15.   Ramdas-appellant, who is in custody, is directed to be\n\nset at liberty and released forthwith unless wanted in\n\nconnection with any other case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">16.   With the above modification, the appeal is partly allowed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">                                   ........................................J.\n                                  (Lokeshwar Singh Panta)\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                   8</span>\n\n\n\n\n                        ........................................J.\n                       (B. Sudershan Reddy)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 13, 2009\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":10,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"tea","formInput":"tea"},{"value":"section 304(a) and 304 part ii","formInput":"section%20304%28a%29%20and%20304%20part%20ii"},{"value":"section 304 part ii","formInput":"section%20304%20part%20ii"},{"value":"section 304 part ii ipc","formInput":"section%20304%20part%20ii%20ipc"},{"value":"304 part ii","formInput":"304%20part%20ii"},{"value":"304 part i","formInput":"304%20part%20i"},{"value":"304 ipc part ii","formInput":"304%20ipc%20part%20ii"},{"value":"304 ipc part ii of ipc","formInput":"304%20ipc%20part%20ii%20of%20ipc"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"citeList":[{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":724142,"url":null,"title":"Section 324 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":409589,"url":null,"title":"Section 304 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":763672,"url":null,"title":"Section 148 in The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Jagebar Ali @ Settu vs State Of Tamil Nadu on 20 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-20","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":962945,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33528","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Jagebar Ali @ Settu vs State Of Tamil Nadu on 20 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n               CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                  CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 38 OF 2007\n\n\nJagebar Ali @ Settu                                      ....Appellant\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of Tamil Nadu                                      ....Respondent\n\n\n\n\n                             JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nMadras High Court convicting A-1, the present appellant for offence\n\npunishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 302</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the\n\n`<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>'). A-2 to A-7 were found guilty under Section 304 Part II, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">IPC</a> and\n\neach was sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for five years. A-3 to\n\fA-7 were found guilty of offence under <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 324</a> IPC and each was\n\nsentenced to undergo RI for two years. A-1 to A-7 were acquitted of the\n\nother charges levelled against them. A-9 and A-10 were acquitted of the\n\ncharges levelled against them. Fifteen persons faced trial, out of them the\n\ntrial Court acquitted A-8, A-11 to A-15. By the impugned judgment, as\n\nnoted above, the High Court directed acquittal of A-9 and A-10.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">2.    The prosecution version as unfolded during trial is as follows:\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">     PW-1 is the native of Thugli Periyar Nagar. PWs 2, 3, 4 5 and 6\n\nbelonged to the same place. PWs 2, 3 and 4 were originally employed in\n\nAmbika Sugar Mills, Kottur. P.Ws. 6 and 7 are also the residents of the said\n\nplace and were carrying on agricultural operations. P.W.8 belonged to\n\nKealathur village, where he was serving as village menial. P.W.9 belonged\n\nto Keezhasuriya Moolai village, where he was serving as village assistant\n\ncommunity. A-1 to A-11 and A-13 to A-15 belong to Hindu Padayachi out\n\nof whom, A-1 and A-2, though belonged to Hinduism originally, switched\n\nover to Muslim faith. A-12 belonged to another community. P.Ws. 1 to 4\n\nbelonged to scheduled caste and they were all employed at the time of\n\noccurrence under one Bhaskar.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                        2</span>\n\f     On 26.3.2001 at about 5.00 p.m., after finishing work, P.Ws. 1 to 4\n\ncame out of the sugar factory and went to a nearby tea stall for taking tea. At\n\nthat time, A-1 was plying auto on the road. On seeing sugarcane on the\n\nroad, P.Ws. 1 to 4 went near the middle of the road. When A-1 came nearby\n\nhe uttered \"you add four more persons and lie on the road\". In reply, P.W.1\n\ntold him \"on hearing the horn of the Auto, we gave way and even then, why\n\nare you scolding\". There arose a quarrel. In that, A-1 took casurine stick and\n\ntried to attack P.W.1. The other witnesses, namely P.Ws. 2 to 4 restrained\n\nP.W.1. The other witnesses, namely P.Ws. 2 to 4 held the accused and\n\nstopped him from attacking. This was also witnessed by the Thangaraju\n\n(hereinafter referred to as deceased), who was taking tea in a nearby tea\n\nstall. He suddenly intervened and pacified them.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">     A-1 turned the Auto and took the same to Keezhasuriyamoolai village.\n\nP.Ws. 1 to 4 went to Muniyendi Vilas for taking tea. Forty five minutes\n\nlater, at about 6.00 p.m., when the witnesses along with Thangaraj were at\n\nthe place of occurrence, A-l, A-2, A-4 to A-6 armed with aruvals, A-3\n\narmed with an iron road and A-7 armed with a knife and the other accused\n\narmed with casurina sticks, came there. The deceased Thangaraju tried to\n\npacify them. A-1 cut the deceased on the left side of the neck. Again A-1 cut\n\nthe deceased below the left ear. A-4 cut him on the left side of the hip. A2\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                           3</span>\n\fcut him with aruval on the left shoulder. A-5 cut the deceased on the waist.\n\nA-7 stabbed him with the knife on the left armpit and the deceased fell\n\ndown. A-3 beat PW-1 on the head with the iron rod. A-4 cut P.W.1 on the\n\nleft waist. The rest of the accused surrounded P.W.1 and cut P.W.1 on the\n\nright arm, left shoulder, right thigh and on the back respectively and they\n\nfled away from the place of occurrence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">     One Mohan took P.W.1 to the Government Hospital, Kumbakonam,\n\nwhere he was admitted by P.W.10, the Doctor, at about 7.00 p.m. He issued\n\nEx.P.11, the wound certificate. A communication was received by P.W.\n\n13, the Head Constable, attached to Kumbakonam East Police Station at\n\n19.30 hours, who in turn informed the same to Penthenellur Police Station,\n\nwithin whose jurisdiction the occurrence has taken place. On receipt of the\n\nintimation on 26.3.2001 at 1930 hours, P.W.16, the Sub Inspector of Police\n\nproceeded to the Government Hospital, Kumbakonam at 2030 hours. He\n\nrecorded the statement of P.W.1, which was marked as Ex.P.1, on the\n\nstrength of which a case came to be registered in Crime No. 72 of 2001\n\nunder <a href=\"/doc/1258372/\" id=\"a_5\">Sections 147</a>, <a href=\"/doc/763672/\" id=\"a_6\">148</a>, <a href=\"/doc/724142/\" id=\"a_7\">324</a>, <a href=\"/doc/455468/\" id=\"a_8\">307</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_9\">302</a> IPC and <a href=\"/doc/42436223/\" id=\"a_10\">Section 3(2)(v)</a> of the\n\nScheduled Castes and the <a href=\"/doc/25085007/\" id=\"a_11\">Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act</a>,\n\n1989. Ext. P17 the FIR was dispatched to the Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                        4</span>\n\f      P.W.19, the Deputy Superintendent of Police, on receipt of the copy\n\nof the FIR on 26.03.2001 at about 11.00 p.m., proceeded to the place of\n\noccurrence and made an inspection in the presence of two witnesses. He\n\nprepared Ex.P.2, the observation mahazar and Ex.P.35, the rough sketch. He\n\nconducted inquest on the dead body of the deceased in the presence of the\n\nwitnesses and panchayatdars and prepared Ex.P.35, the inquest report.\n\nFollowing the same, the dead body was sent to the Government Hospital,\n\nThiruvidaimarudur for the purpose of post-mortem.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      The autopsy of the dead body was conducted. During investigation\n\nA-5 gave confession statement voluntarily and the same was recorded in the\n\npresence of witnesses. Following the same A-5 produced five aruvals, one\n\niron rod and one knife in the presence of witnesses. After completion of\n\ninvestigation charge sheet was filed. Since the accused persons pleaded\n\ninnocence trial was held. Prosecution examined 20 witnesses. As noted\n\nabove, the trial Court found the appellants to be guilty and awarded\n\npunishments.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">      Before the High Court the primary stand related to acceptability of so\n\ncalled eye witnesses PWs 1 to 4. Particularly the emphasis was made on the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                        5</span>\n\fevidence of PW-1 to show that there could not have a common object to\n\nmurder the deceased or attempt to murder PW-1. It was also submitted that\n\nit is highly unbelievable that twenty persons were involved in such an\n\nattempt. It was, therefore, highlighted that in a group clash PWs 1 to 4 could\n\nnot identify the assailants properly.    The High Court did not find any\n\nsubstance in the stand taken by the appellant. The High Court did not accept\n\nthe stand of the prosecution regarding applicability of Section 304 Part II\n\nread with <a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_12\">Section 149</a> IPC. It was held that in respect of the respective acts\n\ncommitted by each one of them       the matter is required to be considered.\n\nFrom the post mortem certificate it was noticed that the first injury was\n\ncaused by A-1 with aruval on the neck and the corresponding injury caused\n\nthe death. At the same time, A-2, A-4, A-5 and A-6 were armed with aruval,\n\nA-7 with knife and A-3 with iron rod and they have attacked the deceased\n\nand contributed corresponding injuries. Therefore, it was held that A-1\n\nhad to be convicted in terms of <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 302</a> IPC. So far as others are\n\nconcerned the acts attracted <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 304</a> Part II IPC.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">3.    Learned counsel for the appellant has submitted that while others\n\nwere convicted for offence punishable under Section 304 Part II, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_15\">IPC</a> he\n\nalone has been convicted under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_16\">Section 302</a> IPC. According to him, there is\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                          6</span>\n\fa parity between the co-accused persons. The High Court has indicated the\n\nreasons for which the appellant's case was treated differently. The trial\n\nCourt and the High Court have noted that the appellant had given a fatal\n\nblow on the neck with aruval and the injury caused by such act proved fatal.\n\nTherefore, there is no substance in the plea of the appellant that he stood on\n\nsimilar footing as that of co-accused persons.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">4.    In view of the findings recorded by the trial Court and the High Court\n\nwe find no merit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\"> {"numcites":8,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"grant of bail","formInput":"grant%20of%20bail"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"bail granted","formInput":"bail%20granted"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"record his reasons ","formInput":"record%20his%20reasons%20"}],"citeList":[{"tid":970675,"url":null,"title":"Section 389 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":836557,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=18362","title":"Ram Govind Upadhyay vs Sudarshan Singh & Ors on 18 March,
