2009","publishdate":"2009-01-23","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":1227808,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33549","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Khilari vs State Of U.P.&amp; Ors on 23 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n            CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.              141     OF 2009\n              (Arising out of S.L.P. (Crl.) No.2589 of 2008\n\n\n\nKhilari                                                  ....Appellant\n\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of U.P. &amp; Ors.                                    ....Respondents\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the order passed by a Division Bench of\n\nthe Allahabad High Court allowing the prayer for bail made by respondent\n\nnos.2 and 3 during the pendency of Criminal Appeal No.6724 of 2006.\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                     1</span>\n\fChallenge before the High Court was to the conviction recorded by learned\n\nSessions Judge, Bagpat, in Sessions Trial No.299 of 2000. Respondent nos.\n\n2 and 3 were convicted for offences punishable under Section 302 and\n\n<a href=\"/doc/180217/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 506</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>') and each was\n\nsentenced to undergo imprisonment for life and one year for the offences\n\nrespectively. The accused persons were convicted allegedly for committing\n\nmurder of Shiv Kumar. Challenging the conviction appeal has been filed\n\nand simultaneously prayer for being released on bail during the pendency of\n\nthe appeal was filed. By the impugned order the Division Bench accepted\n\nthe prayer and granted bail to the respondent nos. 2 &amp; 3. The High Court\n\nnoted that the allegation was that the incident took place on 8.6.2000 at\n\nabout 8.30 p.m. and accused persons assaulted Shiv Kumar (hereinafter\n\nreferred to as the `deceased') mercilessly with iron rods and he succumbed\n\nto the injuries.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.     The only stand taken before the High Court was that the ante mortem\n\ninjuries on the body of the deceased included three contusions, one abraded\n\ncontusion and four lacerated wounds of different dimensions on various\n\nparts of the body which could not have been caused by iron rods. It was\n\ntheir stand that some unknown assailants caused the injuries to the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                    2</span>\n\fdeceased. It was also submitted that by order dated 15.11.2006 the co-\n\naccused has been released on bail.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4.    The prosecution and the present appellant opposed the prayer for\n\ngrant of bail. It was their stand that PWs 1 and 2 and the informant had seen\n\nthe attacks and were eye-witnesses to the occurrence and PW3 is an\n\nindependent witness. Their evidence has been analysed in great detail by\n\nthe trial Court who found it to be credible and cogent. So far as the\n\npossibility of injuries is concerned, that aspect was also examined by the\n\ntrial Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.    After noticing the rival stands, the High Court by the impugned order\n\ngranted the bail with the following conclusions:\n\n\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">                     \"Considering fact and circumstances of the case\n               but without making any opinion on the merit of the\n               appeal at this stage, we are of the view that the accused-\n               appellants Dharmendra and Manoj shall also be released\n               on bail.\"\n</blockquote>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_12\">6.    Learned counsel for the informant appellant submitted that the\n\napproach of the High Court is clearly erroneous. After the conviction has\n\nbeen recorded by believing three eye witnesses and also discarding the stand\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                        3</span>\n\fthat some of the injuries were not possible by iron rods, the High Court\n\nshould not have by a cryptic order directed grant of bail. It was, therefore,\n\nsubmitted that the impugned order is unsustainable.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">7.    Learned counsel for the State supported the stand of the informant.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8.    Learned counsel for the respondent nos.2 and 3 accused submitted\n\nthat it is common knowledge that appeals in the High Court take a long time\n\nfor disposal. A balance has to be struck between the right to speedy trial\n\nand the need for the accused being in custody. The High Court has taken\n\nnote of relevant factors and has granted bail.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">9.    The parameters to be adopted while dealing with the application for\n\nbail by suspension of sentence during the pendency of the appeal has been\n\nexamined by this Court in several cases. <a href=\"/doc/486717/\" id=\"a_3\">In Kishori Lal v. Rupa and Ors</a>.\n\n(2004 (7) SCC 638) it was noted as follow:\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">             \"4. <a href=\"/doc/970675/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 389</a> of the Code deals with suspension of\n             execution of sentence pending the appeal and release of\n             the appellant on bail. There is a distinction between bail\n             and suspension of sentence. One of the essential\n             ingredients of <a href=\"/doc/970675/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 389</a> is the requirement for the\n             appellate court to record reasons in writing for ordering\n             suspension of execution of the sentence or order\n             appealed against. If he is in confinement, the said court\n             can direct that he be released on bail or on his own bond.</blockquote><p id=\"p_16\">\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">             The requirement of recording reasons in writing clearly\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                      4</span>\n\f             indicates that there has to be careful consideration of the\n             relevant aspects and the order directing suspension of\n             sentence and grant of bail should not be passed as a\n             matter of routine.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">             5.     The appellate court is duty-bound to objectively\n             assess the matter and to record reasons for the conclusion\n             that the case warrants suspension of execution of\n             sentence and grant of bail. In the instant case, the only\n             factor which seems to have weighed with the High Court\n             for directing suspension of sentence and grant of bail is\n             the absence of allegation of misuse of liberty during the\n             earlier period when the accused-respondents were on\n             bail.\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">10.   <a href=\"/doc/500640/\" id=\"a_6\">In Anwari Begum v. Sher Mohammad and Anr</a>. (2005 (7) SCC 326) it\n\nwas, inter alia, observed as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">             \"7. Even on a cursory perusal the High Court's order\n             shows complete non-application of mind. Though a\n             detailed examination of the evidence and elaborate\n             documentation of the merits of the case is to be avoided\n             by the court while passing orders on bail applications,\n             yet a court dealing with the bail application should be\n             satisfied as to whether there is a prima facie case, but\n             exhaustive exploration of the merits of the case is not\n             necessary. The court dealing with the application for bail\n             is required to exercise its discretion in a judicious\n             manner and not as a matter of course.\n</blockquote>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_4\">             8. There is a need to indicate in the order reasons for\n             prima facie concluding why bail was being granted,\n             particularly where an accused was charged of having\n             committed a serious offence. It is necessary for the\n             courts dealing with application for bail to consider\n             among other circumstances, the following factors also\n             before granting bail, they are:\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                       5</span>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\f                   1. The nature of accusation and the severity of\n                   punishment in case of conviction and the nature of\n                   supporting evidence;\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                   2. Reasonable apprehension of tampering with the\n                   witness or apprehension of threat to the\n                   complainant;\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                   3. Prima facie satisfaction of the court in support\n                   of the charge.\n</p><p id=\"p_25\">                   Any order dehors of such reasons suffers from\n                   non-application of mind as was noted by this\n                   Court in <a href=\"/doc/836557/\" id=\"a_7\">Ram Govind Upadhyay v. Sudarshan\n                   Singh &amp; Ors</a>. (2002 (3) SCC 598), Puran etc. v.\n                   Rambilas and Anr. etc. (2001) (6) SCC 338) and in\n                   <a href=\"/doc/1342616/\" id=\"a_8\">Kalyan Chandra Sarkar v. Rajesh Ranjan Alias\n                   Pappu Yadav &amp; Anr. (JT</a> 2004 (3) SC 442).\"\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_26\">\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">11.   As the extracted portion of the High Court's order goes to show there\n\nwas complete non-application of mind and non-consideration of the relevant\n\naspects. The order relating to grant of bail in respect of co-accused by order\n\ndated 15.11.2006 was the subject matter of challenge in <a href=\"/doc/996014/\" id=\"a_9\">Pancham Chand &amp;\n\nOrs. v. State of Himahal Pradesh &amp; Ors</a>. (2008 (3) SCALE 379) and the\n\norder was set aside.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">12.   The impugned order, therefore, is not sustainable and is set aside.\n\nThe bail granted to the respondent nos. 2 and 3 is cancelled. The matter is\n\nremitted to the High Court for fresh consideration in accordance with law.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">13.   The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                                      6</span>\n\f                                     .........................................\n.............J.\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">                   (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                   .................................................J.\n                   (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY\nNew Delhi\nJanuary 23, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                                                  7</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":8,"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"abduction","formInput":"abduction"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"},{"value":"Rajasthan  filter:  Rape sec. 376","formInput":"Rajasthan%20%20filter%3A%20%20Rape%20sec.%20376"}],"citeList":[{"tid":999134,"url":null,"title":"Section 149 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1258372,"url":null,"title":"Section 147 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1011035,"url":null,"title":"Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":796352,"url":null,"title":"Section 366 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":959623,"url":null,"title":"Section 458 in The Indian Penal Code"}],"covers":[],"title":"Neku Khan & Ors vs State Of Rajasthan on 7 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-07","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":101428,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33464","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Neku Khan &amp; Ors vs State Of Rajasthan on 7 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                      REPORTABLE\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.100 OF 2002\n\n\n\n\nNeku Khan &amp; Ors.                                              .....\nAppellants\n\n\n                                 Versus\n\nState of Rajasthan                                      ....Respondent\n\n\n\n                               JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a learned single Judge\n\nof the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur upholding the conviction of\n\nappellant No.1 Neku Khan for offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1279834/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 376</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1258372/\" id=\"a_2\">147</a>,\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_3\">323</a>/<a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_4\">149</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1243353/\" id=\"a_5\">342</a>, <a href=\"/doc/959623/\" id=\"a_6\">458</a> and <a href=\"/doc/796352/\" id=\"a_7\">366</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in short the\n\f`<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_8\">IPC</a>') The other appellants were convicted for offence punishable under\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1258372/\" id=\"a_9\">Section 147</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_10\">323</a>/<a href=\"/doc/999134/\" id=\"a_11\">149</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1243353/\" id=\"a_12\">342</a>, <a href=\"/doc/959623/\" id=\"a_13\">458</a> and <a href=\"/doc/796352/\" id=\"a_14\">366</a> IPC.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Prosecution version as unfolded during trial is as follows:\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">      Between the intervening night 13.9.1984 and 14.9.1984 Muse Khan\n\n(PW-2), Janu Khan (PW-4), Prosecutrix (PW-5), wife Reshma, Indro (PW-\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">6) wife of Bakhsu Khan, Makhni (PW-7) wife of Sachchu Khan were\n\nsleeping at the house of Bakhsu Khan in village Raivada, accused persons\n\nNeku Khan, Bakhsu Khan, Barkat Khan, Ali Sher and Same Khan arrived\n\non a Nisan vehicle, the accused Barkat was having the iron rod and the other\n\npersons were having lathis, they beat Muse Khan (PW-2) and placed\n\nProsecutrix daughter of Bakhsu in Nisan vehicle forcefully and went away,\n\nthe accused Same Khan shut her mouth with hand and then got down at\n\nGida village with Prosecutrix, for some time walked on foot, after a while\n\nthe accused Same Khan came with a camel and made Prosecutrix ride the\n\ncamel. Another man also rode and Neku Khan, Same Khan and Bakhsu\n\nKhan walked on feet and then took her to the Dadi of the accused, stripped\n\nher clothes and dressed her with new clothes and ornaments and then Neku\n\nKhan did bed work like husband-wife, she stayed there for two nights and\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\ffor two nights Neku Khan did bed work with her, thereafter the police\n\narrived there with her father, the accused persons ran away, the police\n\nbrought her to Mandli Police Station.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      After completion of investigation charge sheet was filed and since\n\naccused persons pleaded innocence they were put on trial.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">      Dr. Mangi Lal Bohra (PW 1) has proved the injuries caused to Muse\n\nKhan on the date of incident by the accused persons while abducting the\n\nprosecutrix. PW-2 is Muse Khan who is brother of prosecutrix and he has\n\ndeposed that he was asleep when he was assaulted. He saw the accused\n\nassaulting his brother and then saw them taking away his sister. The fact\n\nthat Muse Khan was assaulted by the accused, stands corroborated by the\n\nevidence of Doctor who is completely independent witness. Ishaqu (PW 3)\n\nat whose place, the accused is alleged to have kept the prosecutrix. The\n\nprosecution has proved the state of prosecutrix at the place of Ishaqu (PW\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">3). (PW 4) Janu Khan , was also present when the abduction took place. He\n\nsaw the accused assaulting Muse Khan and abducting the prosecutrix. He is\n\nthe person who has lodged the report of the incident to the police. The\n\ntestimony of Muse Khan that he was assaulted and abduction of prosecutrix\n\nis thus corroborated by testimony of Janu Khan. The prosecution version\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n\frelied primarily on the evidence of Prosecutrix (PW 5). Two witnesses were\n\nexamined by the appellant to show that the victim was married to appellant\n\nno. 1 and therefore there was no rape as contended and no abduction. The\n\ntrial court and the High court did not find any substance in the plea. They\n\nreferred to the evidence of PWs 2,4 &amp; 5 and held the appellant guilty and\n\ndirected conviction and imposed sentence as aforenoted.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">3.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the appellant submitted\n\nthat the trial court and the High Court lost sight of the fact that the DWs 1 &amp;\n\n2 categorically stated about the marriage of the victim with appellant No. 1.\n\nThat being so the question of any rape or abduction as claimed does not\n\narise. It is further pointed out that there is no evidence to link the appellants\n\n3 to 5 with the offence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">4.    Learned counsel for the State on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment of the trial court and the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">5.    We find that there was no evidence of the marriage as claimed. The\n\nevidence of Bhouware Khan (DW 2) on which strong reliance was placed to\n\ncontend that there was a marriage, it did not in fact substantiate the claim.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                      4</span>\n\fBhouware Khan (DW 2) in his cross examination admitted that the Kazi\n\nwrites their nikah. No signature or thumb impression was obtained and the\n\nKazi Yusuf Khan who is claimed to have solemenised the nikah was not\n\nexamined. It is submitted that there is no need for such writing. But in any\n\nevent DW 1 who is claimed to have settled the marriage accepted that same\n\nis the procedure. Thus there was no other material adduced to say that the\n\naccused no.1 and the prosecutrix were married.           That being so the\n\nconviction of appellant No.1 as recorded by the trial court and maintained\n\nby the High Court cannot be faulted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">6.    So far as the role played by appellant No. 2 is concerned the same\n\nwas clearly established by the evidence of injured witnesses PW 2 and PW\n\n4, apart from the evidence of the PW 5. That being so the appeal fails so far\n\nas they are concerned.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">7.    It is rightly contended by learned counsel for the appellants, that there\n\nis practically no evidence to link with the other appellants i.e. Ali Sher,\n\nBakhsu Khan and Barkat Khan with the crime. Their conviction is set aside.\n\nThe bail bonds executed by them shall stand discharged. The appellants 1\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                     5</span>\n\f&amp; 2 Neku Khan and Same Khan shall surrender to custody to serve the\n\nremainder of sentence. The appeal is disposed of in the aforesaid terms.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">                                            ................................................J.\n                                            (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                           .....................................................J.\n                                           (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 7, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                    6</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"surjit kaur","formInput":"surjit%20kaur"},{"value":"makhan singh","formInput":"makhan%20singh"},{"value":"makhan","formInput":"makhan"},{"value":"kirpan","formInput":"kirpan"},{"value":"bathinda","formInput":"bathinda"},{"value":"kuldip","formInput":"kuldip"},{"value":"substantive evidence","formInput":"substantive%20evidence"},{"value":"recovery memo","formInput":"recovery%20memo"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Mukhtiar Singh & Anr vs State Of Punjab on 20 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33521","lastname":"sharma","secondname":"m","publishdate":"2009-01-20","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Mukhtiar Singh &amp; Anr vs State Of Punjab on 20 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . M Sharma</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                    CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                     CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 448 OF 2007\n\n\nMUKHTIAR SINGH &amp; ANR.                                  ..\n\n                                   Versus\n\nSTATE OF PUNJAB                                       ..Respondent\n\n\n                                   JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. Mukundakam Sharma, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.     Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment and order of the Division\n\nBench of Punjab and Haryana High Court, allowing the appeal filed by the\n\nrespondent State. By the impugned judgment the Division Bench set aside the\n\norder of acquittal passed by the learned Sessions Judge, Bhatinda and\n\nconvicted both the appellants for offence punishable under Section 302 read\n\nwith <a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 34</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (for short `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>').            The\n\nappellants-accused were sentenced to suffer imprisonment for life and to pay a\n\nfine of Rs. 10,000/- each with default stipulation.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.     The prosecution version as unfolded during the trial is as follows:\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">       A land dispute had been going on between Mukhtiar Singh and his\n\nbrother Babu Singh (hereinafter referred to as `deceased') which had ended in\n\nfavour of the deceased. Mukhtiar Singh was aggrieved thereby. His two sons\n\nGurmail Singh and Harbans Singh had caused injuries to the deceased which\n\nresulted into fracture of his leg and thereafter Harbans Singh son of Mukhtiar\n\nSingh was murdered by deceased and his son Buta Singh.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                         1</span>\n\f      On 15.04.1994, the deceased and his family members which included\n\nhis wife Surjit kaur, son Makhan Singh, daughter-in-law Jasvir Kaur and father-\n\nin-law of daughter of deceased Balwant Singh decided to visit Bathinda jail\n\nwhere the son of the deceased was lodged.          In order to catch a train to\n\nBathinda they reached Kahangarh Railway Station which was next to their\n\nvillage at about 5:00 AM and waited there for the arrival of the Train. Since the\n\ntrain was late from its scheduled time the ticket counter at the Station was\n\nclosed. Except the deceased all had seated themselves on a bench while the\n\ndeceased was standing nearby. In the meantime Mukhtiar Singh armed with a\n\nkirpan and his son Gurmail Singh armed with a takua came there. Mukhtiar\n\nSingh gave two kirpan blows one on the neck of the deceased and another on\n\nhis head. Consequently, he fell down. Immediately thereafter Gurmail Singh\n\ngave blows on the chin, right shoulder, left shoulder and chest of the deceased.\n\nThe family members of the deceased raised an alarm. Mukhtiar Singh accused\n\nexclaimed that they had avenged murder of his son.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      One SPO Gurdas Singh who was posted on the Assault Post,\n\nKahangarh Railway Station came running and challenged the accused but both\n\nthe accused managed to escape. A wireless message was received in the\n\nrailway station Bathinda at 11:50 AM upon which ASI Gurdip Singh\n\naccompanied by other police officials reached the Kahangarh Railway Station\n\nwhere he found Surjit Kaur, Makhan Singh, Jasvir kaur, Balwant Singh and\n\nSPO Gurdas Singh present. He prepared the inquest report Ex. PC which was\n\nattested by Surjit Kaur and Makhan Singh. Thereafter statement Ex. PM, of\n\nSurjit Kaur was recorded at 5.15 PM, on which he made an endorsement Ex.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                       2</span>\n\fPM/1, upon which formal FIR EX. PM/2 was registered in the concerned Police\n\nStation. The ASI Gurdip Singh went to the spot, lifted the blood stained earth\n\nand put it into a container. After sealing the same, the container was taken into\n\npossession vide recovery memo Ex. PK which was attested by the witnesses.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">      SPO Gurdas Singh also produced a pair of shoes which was taken into\n\npossession vide memos Ex.P.U. and a sum of Rs. 165/- which was recovered\n\nfrom the person of the deceased. A rough site plan Ex.PR of the place of\n\noccurrence was prepared by the Investigating Officer. The autopsy on the\n\ndead body of the deceased was conducted on the next day (16.4.1994) by Dr.\n\nKuldip Rai.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">      Thereafter, Sub-Inspector Hukam Chand arrested both the accused on\n\n20.4.1994. The investigation was taken up by ASI Gurdip Singh and during\n\ninterrogation accused Mukhtiar Singh suffered a disclosure statement Ex.PU\n\nabout concealing of kirpan and blood stained clothes. Thereafter, the accused\n\nMukhtiar Singh got recovered his kirpan and blood stained clothes. Kirpan was\n\ntaken into possessin vide memo Ex.P.U./1 and its sketch Ex.P.U./2 was also\n\nprepared.     The blood stained clothes were also taken into possession vide\n\nseparate recovery memos. Similarly Gurmail Singh accused also suffered a\n\ndisclosure statement Ex.P.V. about concealment of takua and blood stained\n\nclothes.    Thereafter, he also got recovered takua which was taken into\n\npossession vide recovery memo Ex.P.V. and its sketch Ex.P.V./2 was also\n\nprepared. His blood stained clothes were also taken into possession.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">      After the completion of the investigation, challan was filed against both\n\nthe accused and they were charged under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_4\">34</a> IPC. During the trial\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                       3</span>\n\fDr. Kuldip Rai was examined as PW 1, Makhan Singh, son of the deceased\n\nwas examined as PW 2; Surjit Kaur, wife of the deceased was examined as\n\nPW 3; ASI Gurdip Singh was examined as PW 4 and SPO Gurdas Singh was\n\nexamined as PW 5.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">      The trial Court acquitted both the accused of the charges on the ground\n\nthat the testimony of two eye witnesses cannot be believed as the\n\ncircumstances confirm absence of the eyewitness at the place of occurrence. It\n\nwas further stated by the trial Court that the prosecution case was nothing but a\n\ngot up story, knitted after due deliberation between the police and the named\n\neye witnesses. On appeal by the State the High Court set aside the order of\n\nthe trial Court. It held that the trial Court had discarded the testimony of two\n\neye witnesses on feeble grounds and had entertained un-necessary doubts\n\ndespite there being clear and sufficient evidence pointing towards the guilt of\n\nthe accused.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">3.    Mr. Aman Lekhi, learned senior counsel appearing for the appellant very\n\neloquently argued that it was a blind murder and the appellants have been\n\nfalsely implicated due to the previous animosity.         While elaborating his\n\nargument he submitted that there was significant delay in giving the information\n\nto the police and that the alleged eyewitness were not present at the time of the\n\nincident and came to the railway station at 3:00 PM only. He submitted that\n\nstory knitted by the prosecution is belied which is established from the very fact\n\nthat before recording the statement of the eye witness who were well present\n\nthere the ASI proceeded to prepare the inquest report.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                        4</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">\f4.    On the other hand Mr. Kuldip Singh, learned counsel appearing for the\n\nState while supporting the judgment of the High Court submitted that the Trial\n\nCourt committed grave error while acquitting the accused appellants, in as\n\nmuch as, the presence of the eye witnesses was natural and the delay in\n\ncommunicating the offence and lodging the First Information was well explained\n\nby the prosecution.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">5.    We heard the learned counsel appearing for the parties and have also\n\nperused the testimonies on record in addition to other documents.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">6.    Before proceeding with the discussion on the merit of the appeal, we\n\nwould like to mention that the trial court acquitted both the accused persons.\n\nThe aforesaid order of acquittal was, however, set aside by the Division Bench\n\nof the High Court. While doing so, reasons have been given by the High Court\n\nand that too after discussing the law laid down by this Court with respect to the\n\nformalities and pre-conditions required to be followed by the court before\n\nsetting aside the order of acquittal.       We have very carefully perused the\n\naforesaid reasons and on careful perusal we found that the reasons given for\n\nsetting aside the acquittal of the accused persons are cogent and strong.\n\nThere are two eye witnesses to the occurrence, namely, Makhan Singh, PW-2,\n\nwho happened to be the son of the deceased, and Surjit Kaur, PW-3, widow of\n\nthe deceased.    Although the counsel appearing for the appellant strongly\n\nsubmitted that none of the aforesaid eye-witnesses were present at the time of\n\noccurrence but we are unable to accept the said statement for the simple\n\nreason that on the day of the alleged occurrence the deceased was going to\n\nmeet his son Buta Singh and was at the Kahangarh Railway Station to catch a\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                        5</span>\n\ftrain at 5.00 a.m. Since Buta Singh was in jail, therefore, it was natural that not\n\nonly the father, the deceased but also his wife Surjit Kaur, son Makhan Singh\n\nand other family members were accompanying the deceased so as to meet\n\nButa Singh, one of the family members in the jail. Much was said about the\n\nabsence of any train ticket with the alleged eye witnesses but absence of the\n\nsame in our considered opinion was well explained. The train was late from its\n\nscheduled time due to which the ticket counter was also not opened, and\n\ntherefore, there was no question of purchasing the tickets for traveling in the\n\ntrain and production of the same in the trial.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">7.     Argument was also advanced by the senior counsel appearing for the\n\nappellant regarding the conduct of the eye-witnesses in not intervening while\n\nthe accused persons were allegedly attacking the decease. PW-3, the widow\n\nof the deceased was a lady whereas Makhan Singh, PW-2, was aged only 15-\n\n16 years at the time of the alleged occurrence.          Therefore, it cannot be\n\nexpected that a lady and a small boy of 15-16 years would dare to intervene in\n\nthe attack made by the two accused persons being armed with sharp edged\n\nweapons in their hands. PW-5, Gurdas Singh, SPO reached at the scene of\n\nthe occurrence immediately after the occurrence and in fact he ran after and\n\npursued the accused persons but was unable to catch them. While scrutinizing\n\nthe evidence of PW-5, we find no reason to disbelieve the statement of the said\n\nofficer. He was not an investigating officer nor has he any connection with the\n\ncase apart from being a witness. He also flashed the initial information which\n\nwas received by PW-4, Gurdeep Singh, the investigating officer, at Railway\n\nPolice Station, Bathinda.    Much was said about the aforesaid information,\n\nwhich was sent to the investigating officer stating only that a dead body is lying\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                         6</span>\n\fat the Railway Station, Kahangarh. There is no dispute that the aforesaid\n\ninformation was very sketchy since the details of the incident were not given in\n\nthe aforesaid information. But as it was a telegraphic information, therefore, it\n\ncannot be said that the absence of material information in any manner destroy\n\nthe case of the prosecution.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">8.    PW-5 has clearly stated in his statement that no telephone was installed\n\nat the Railway Station, Kahangarh but there was a telephone installed at the\n\nRailway Control Room at the Railway Station which, however, was found to be\n\nout of order. He also stated that he had gone to GRP Police Post at Budhlada\n\nfrom where he sent a message to the Control Room at Bathinda on telephone\n\nabout the occurrence. The aforesaid statement clearly explains the delay in\n\nsending the information and also explained as to why detailed information\n\nregarding all materials leading to the occurrence was not mentioned by him.\n\nHe cannot be called in any manner an interested witness; in fact he was a most\n\ndis-interested witness. Nothing has been brought on record to show that he is\n\ninimical to the accused persons.   He has specifically stated in his depositions\n\nthat he saw the aforesaid accused running towards the village side carrying\n\nweapons. His presence at the spot cannot be doubted as it is established that\n\nhe was at duty at the Railway Police Post, Kahangarh, which is the place of\n\noccurrence. He has also stated in his depositions that he had in fact chased\n\nthe two accused persons up to a certain distance but could not manage to nab\n\nthem and that when he returned to the scene of occurrence, Surjit Kaur, PW-3,\n\ndisclosed to him about the occurrence. This shows that he did not see the\n\naccused persons attacking the deceased but learnt about the same from an\n\neye witness and the said information about the dead body lying at the platform\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">                                       7</span>\n\fwas flashed by him, for he knew that on receipt of the aforesaid information the\n\npolice should start investigation and during that course police would definitely\n\nask eye witnesses and get all the information from them. In any case, his\n\ninformation would be hearsay evidence, but as the same corroborates the\n\nsubstantive evidence of PW 2 and PW 3 the same would be admissible, as was\n\nheld in the case of <a href=\"/doc/60202/\" id=\"a_5\">Pawan Kumar v. State of Haryana</a>, [(2003) 11 SCC 241],\n\nwherein it was observed that evidence of such nature could be used to\n\ncorroborate the substantive evidence. However, in that case, as there was no\n\nsubstantive evidence the benefit of said evidence was not granted.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">9.    During the course of examination a kirpan and takua were recovered\n\npursuant to the discloser statement made by the accused.         The aforesaid\n\nweapons were shown to Dr. Kuldip Rai, PW-1, who gave his opinion that the\n\ninjuries on the person of the deceased could be inflicted by the said weapons.\n\nIn the opinion of the doctor, the death was caused due to shock and\n\nhemorrhage as a result of the injuries received, which were ante-mortem and\n\nwere sufficient to cause death in the ordinary course of nature. The aforesaid\n\nfact of recovery of the weapons and also blood stained clothes sufficiently\n\nprove and establish involvement of the accused in the occurrence as alleged by\n\nthe prosecution. We find no reason to disbelieve the eye-witnesses, namely,\n\nPW-2 - Makhan Singh and PW-3 - Surjit Kaur nor do we find any reason to\n\ndiscard the evidence of PW-5, who had reached the place of occurrence\n\nimmediately after the attack on the deceased and in fact he chased the two\n\naccused persons for some distance.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">                                       8</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">\f10.    Upon taking all the facts into consideration including that of the fact of\n\nrecovery of the alleged weapons at the instance of the accused would explicitly\n\nprove and establish that the accused persons are guilty of the offence alleged\n\nagainst them.    We are of the considered opinion that the High Court was\n\njustified in setting aside the order of acquittal and also convicting the accused\n\npersons for the offence under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 302</a> IPC and sentencing them to undergo\n\nrigorous imprisonment for life. With the aforesaid findings we find no infirmity in\n\nthe impugned order, which we uphold and consequently dismiss the appeal.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">                                                     ............................................J\n                                                                      [Dr. Arijit Pasayat]\n\n\n                                                     ............................................J\n                                                       [Dr. Mukundakam Sharma]\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">January 20, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span ipc","formInput":"section%20300%20ipc"},{"value":"uttarakhand","formInput":"uttarakhand"}],"citeList":[{"tid":626019,"url":null,"title":"Section 300 in The Indian Penal 2007"},{"tid":573457,"url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=26297","title":"Parkash Chand vs State Of H.P on 9 August, 2004"}],"covers":[],"title":"Buddu Khan vs State Of Uttarkhand on 12 January, 2009","publishdate":"2009-01-12","divtype":"judgments","citedbyList":[],"tid":808133,"showurl":true,"covertids":[],"firstname":null,"lastname":"pasayat","numcitedby":0,"secondname":"a","docsource":"Supreme Court of India","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33477","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Buddu Khan vs State Of Uttarkhand on 12 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n\n                    IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n               CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 39              OF 2009\n               (Arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 6109 of 2008)\n\n\nBuddu Khan                                               ....Appellant\n\n                                  Versus\n\nState of Uttarakhand                                     ....Respondent\n\n\n\n                                JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nUttarakhand High Court     upholding the conviction of the appellant for\n\noffence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 302</a> of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (in\n\nshort the `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">IPC</a>').\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">\f3.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">      On 18.9.1993 at about 8.00 p.m. in Village Fauji Math Kota within\n\nthe limits of P.S. Rudrapur (now part of District Udham Singh Nagar)\n\naccused appellant Buddu Khan and deceased Dinesh Oli were sitting\n\ntogether on a cot. Girish Chandra Chaturvedi (PW-1) was also present there.\n\nIn his presence Buddu Khan protested to the deceased as to why did he bite\n\non his cheek in the presence of his wife. Thereafter, Girish Chandra\n\nChaturvedi had left the place. When PW-1 along with Tejpal (PW-5) and Jai\n\nPrakash again came towards near the office of Co-operative Society where\n\nearlier aforesaid incident had taken place, they saw Buddu Khan hitting\n\nwith a brick on the head of Dinesh Oli and was saying that he will give the\n\ndeceased taste of biting the cheek. The three eye witnesses rushed and\n\ncaught hold of appellant. However, he escaped after freeing himself. The\n\nreport of the incident was lodged by Tejpal Singh (PW-5) with P.S.\n\nRudrapur on the very day i.e. on 18.9.1993 at about 9.30 p.m. after getting it\n\nscribed from one Dharampal. Constable Ved Pal (PW-3) who received the\n\nFirst Information Report prepared check report and made necessary entry in\n\nthe general diary, a copy of which is Ext.A-7. The crime was initially\n\ninvestigated by Sub-Inspector Surendra Singh Dagri (PW-7). He went to the\n\nspot and got prepared inquest report on 19.9.1993 at 2.00 a.m. after taking\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\fthe dead body of the deceased in his possession. He also prepared site plan.\n\nThe police also got prepared other necessary papers, sketch of the dead\n\nbody, police form No.13 and letter to the Chief Medical Officer, requesting\n\nhim for getting the autopsy done. Constable Pramod Kumar (PW-4) took the\n\ndead body in a sealed condition for post mortem examination to Soban\n\nSingh Jina Hospital, Haldwani and handed it over for the purpose. Dr. A.S.\n\nSingh (PW-2) conducted the post mortem examination on 19.9.1993 at\n\nabout 1.00 p.m. on the dead body of deceased and prepared report. He\n\nopined that cause of death was ante mortem injuries on the skull bone and\n\neffusion of blood into the brain matter. Subsequently, investigation was\n\ntaken over by Prem Singh Ahlawat (PW-6), Inspector who after\n\ninterrogation of the witnesses and completing the investigation submitted\n\ncharge sheet to the Magistrate concerned. Case was committed to the Court\n\nof Sessions.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">      The trial Court placed reliance on the evidence of the eye witnesses\n\nPWs 1 and 5. In appeal, the stand was that there was no pre-meditation. On\n\nthe contrary, because the deceased had bitten on the cheek of appellant in\n\nthe presence of his wife, there was a quarrel and in course of which the\n\nappellant picked up a brick and hit it on the head and one blow was given.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n\fThe High Court did not find substance in the plea that <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a> has no\n\napplication.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">4.    In support of the appeal, learned counsel for the appellant submitted\n\nthat the background facts clearly established that <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 302</a> has no\n\napplication.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">5.    Learned counsel for the respondent-State on the other hand supported\n\nthe judgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">6.    For bringing in operation of Exception 4 to <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_5\">Section 300</a> IPC it has to\n\nbe established that the act was committed without premeditation, in a\n\nsudden fight in the heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel without the\n\noffender having taken undue advantage and not having acted in a cruel or\n\nunusual manner.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">7.    The Fourth Exception of <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_6\">Section 300</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_7\">IPC</a> covers acts done in a\n\nsudden fight. The said exception deals with a case of prosecution not\n\ncovered by the first exception, after which its place would have been more\n\nappropriate. The exception is founded upon the same principle, for in both\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                   4</span>\n\fthere is absence of premeditation. But, while in the case of Exception 1\n\nthere is total deprivation of self-control, in case of Exception 4, there is only\n\nthat heat of passion which clouds men's sober reasons and urges them to\n\ndeeds which they would not otherwise do.             There is provocation in\n\nException 4 as in Exception 1; but the injury done is not the direct\n\nconsequence of that provocation. In fact Exception 4 deals with cases in\n\nwhich notwithstanding that a blow may have been struck, or some\n\nprovocation given in the origin of the dispute or in whatever way the quarrel\n\nmay have originated, yet the subsequent conduct of both parties puts them\n\nin respect of guilt upon equal footing. A `sudden fight' implies mutual\n\nprovocation and blows on each side. The homicide committed is then\n\nclearly not traceable to unilateral provocation, nor in such cases could the\n\nwhole blame be placed on one side. For if it were so, the Exception more\n\nappropriately applicable would be Exception 1.          There is no previous\n\ndeliberation or determination to fight. A fight suddenly takes place, for\n\nwhich both parties are more or less to be blamed. It may be that one of them\n\nstarts it, but if the other had not aggravated it by his own conduct it would\n\nnot have taken the serious turn it did. There is then mutual provocation and\n\naggravation, and it is difficult to apportion the share of blame which\n\nattaches to each fighter. The help of Exception 4 can be invoked if death is\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                      5</span>\n\fcaused (a) without premeditation, (b) in a sudden fight; (c) without the\n\noffender's having taken undue advantage or acting in a cruel or unusual\n\nmanner; and (d) the fight must have been with the person killed. To bring a\n\ncase within Exception 4 all the ingredients mentioned in it must be found. It\n\nis to be noted that the `fight' occurring in Exception 4 to <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_8\">Section 300</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_9\">IPC</a> is\n\nnot defined in the <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_10\">IPC</a>. It takes two to make a fight. Heat of passion\n\nrequires that there must be no time for the passions to cool down and in this\n\ncase, the parties have worked themselves into a fury on account of the\n\nverbal altercation in the beginning. A fight is a combat between two and\n\nmore persons whether with or without weapons. It is not possible to\n\nenunciate any general rule as to what shall be deemed to be a sudden\n\nquarrel. It is a question of fact and whether a quarrel is sudden or not must\n\nnecessarily depend upon the proved facts of each case. For the application\n\nof Exception 4, it is not sufficient to show that there was a sudden quarrel\n\nand there was no premeditation. It must further be shown that the offender\n\nhas not taken undue advantage or acted in cruel or unusual manner. The\n\nexpression `undue advantage' as used in the provision means `unfair\n\nadvantage'. These aspects have been highlighted in Dhirajbhai Gorakhbhai\n\nNayak v. State of Gujrat (2003 (5) Supreme 223], <a href=\"/doc/573457/\" id=\"a_11\">Parkash Chand v. State\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n\fof H.P</a>. (2004 (11) SCC 381) and <a href=\"/doc/1070976/\" id=\"a_12\">Byvarapu Raju v. State of A.P. and Anr</a>.\n\n(2007 (11) SCC 218)\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">8.    Considering the background facts of the case we are of the view that\n\nException 4 to <a href=\"/doc/626019/\" id=\"a_13\">Section 300</a> applies to the facts of the case. The appropriate\n\nconviction would be under <a href=\"/doc/409589/\" id=\"a_14\">Section 304</a> Part I IPC. Custodial sentence of 10\n\nyears would meet the ends of justice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">9.    The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">                                        ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">                                        (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n                                        .....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">                                        (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 12, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                    7</span>\n\f</p>"}, {"numcites":5,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"ram krishan ","formInput":"ram%20krishan%20"},{"value":"manohar lal","formInput":"manohar%20lal"},{"value":"pasayat","formInput":"pasayat"},{"value":"arijit pasayat","formInput":"arijit%20pasayat"}],"firstname":null,"title":"State Of H.P vs Ram Krishan on 12 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33476","lastname":"pasayat","secondname":"a","publishdate":"2009-01-12","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">State Of H.P vs Ram Krishan on 12 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: . A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Mukundakam Sharma</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                           REPORTABLE\n\n\n                 IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 553 OF 2002\n\n\n\nState of H.P.                                                  ...Appellant\n\n\n                                  Versus\n\n\nRam Krishan                                              ...Respondent\n\n\n\n                               JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Challenge in this appeal is to the judgment of a Division Bench of the\n\nHimachal Pradesh High Court directing acquittal of the respondent. The\n\nDivision Bench had disposed of two appeals, one by the accused and the\n\nother by the State, both questioning correctness of the judgment passed by\n\nlearned Additional Sessions Judge, Mandi. As noted above, while the\n\naccused questioned his conviction for offence punishable under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 302</a>\n\fIPC, the State's appeal was against the acquittal in respect of offences\n\npunishable under <a href=\"/doc/838469/\" id=\"a_2\">Sections 452</a>, <a href=\"/doc/222396/\" id=\"a_3\">427</a> and <a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_4\">323</a> IPC so far as Respondent Ram\n\nKrishan is concerned and also questioning acquittal of co-accused\n\nHarminder. The High Court by the impugned judgment affirmed the order\n\nof acquittal as done by the trial court while also directing acquittal of the\n\nrespondent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">      Laxmi Dutt (PW-1), resident of village Mandap in Tehsil Karsog was\n\nrunning a tailoring shop at the material time in village Maghundi at a\n\ndistance of about one kilometer from his residential house. Manohar Lal\n\n(hereinafter referred to as the `deceased') was his younger brother and was\n\nrunning a shop of general merchandise at Maghandi in the business\n\npremises of PW-1 in the morning and evening, while during the day time he\n\nused to teach students of a nearby school. On 26.11.1998 at about 7.30 p.m.\n\nwhen the deceased was present in his aforesaid business premises, Ram\n\nKrishan (hereinafter referred to as the `accused') and Harmender Singh\n\n(hereafter referred to as 'the co-accused') came there while under the\n\ninfluence of liquor. They wanted to take more liquor at the said business\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                    2</span>\n\fpremises of the deceased. They asked the deceased to give them some\n\neatables. The deceased, however, asked the accused persons not to take\n\nliquor in his business premises which infuriated them and as a result they\n\nquarrelled with the deceased and slapped him. The accused persons also\n\nthrew the goods at the business premises of the deceased helter-skelter.\n\nWhen the deceased asked them not to indulge in such mischief, they asked\n\nhim to get lost. Thereupon the deceased went to the houses of Pawan\n\nKumar (PW-5) and Dogar Ram residents of village Thaltu. The deceased\n\ninformed them about the acts and conduct of the accused persons and then\n\nreturned to his business premises along with PW5 and Dogar Ram, who is\n\nelder brother of accused Harmender Singh. PW-5 and Dogar Ram requested\n\nthe accused persons not to commit the mischief in the business premises of\n\nthe deceased. However, the accused persons asked them to get lost. The\n\ndeceased then went to his house and informed Laxmi Dutt (PW-l) and\n\nKaram Dass (PW 6) and other persons present in the house about the acts\n\nand conduct of the accused persons. Laxmi Dutt (PW-1), Amba Dutt\n\n(PW2), Nanak Chand (PW3) and Preen Lal came along with the deceased\n\nand reached the business premises at about 8.15 p.m. They inquired from\n\nthe accused persons as to why they had picked up a quarrel with the\n\ndeceased? On such enquiry, the accused persons stepped out of the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                  3</span>\n\fbusiness premises of Manohar Lal (deceased), and with a stone, hit on the\n\nleft side of his head and as a consequence, the deceased dropped dead at the\n\nsite where he had sustained injury with stone Ext. P-1 and rolled down the\n\nhill-side upto a distance of about 50 feet. The accused persons thereafter\n\npelted stones on the other persons present there thereby causing simple hurt\n\nto PW6 and Dogar Ram. On hearing the noise from the spot, Man Singh\n\n(PW7) also came to the place of occurrence. He asked the accused persons\n\nnot to pelt stones and took them to their houses. PW-l, PW-7 and Khuba\n\nRaid went to the house of Krishna Devi (PW-4), Pardhan of' the Gram\n\nPanchayat and informed her of the murder of Manohar Lal (deceased). She\n\naccompanied them to the place of occurrence and inspected the dead body\n\nof the deceased. Thereafter, PW-1, PW-4 and PW-7 went to Police Station,\n\nKarsog and lodged FIR. Ext. PW-1/A under <a href=\"/doc/838469/\" id=\"a_5\">Sections 452</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_6\">323</a>, <a href=\"/doc/222396/\" id=\"a_7\">427</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_8\">302</a>/<a href=\"/doc/37788/\" id=\"a_9\">34</a>\n\nof the Indian Penal Code against the accused persons and the investigation\n\nin the matter followed. SHO, Harbhajan Singh, S.I. (PW-13) visited the\n\nplace of occurrence and took the dead body of Manohar Lal in possession.\n\nPhotographs of the dead body and the place of occurrence were taken and\n\nthe developed photographs are Exts. PW-10/A-1 to PW-10/A-8. The report\n\nMarg Exts. PW-13/B and PW-13/C were prepared and the dead body was\n\nsent for post mortem examination. Stone Ext. PW 1 was also taken in\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                   4</span>\n\fpossession vide recovery memo. Ext.PW-4/1 and was sealed. Stone Ext. P2\n\nwas also taken in possession from the business premises of the deceased\n\nvide recovery memo Ext. PW-4/B. The post mortem of the dead body of the\n\ndeceased was conducted by Dr. Girish (PW-14) and the post mortem report\n\nissued by him is Ext. PW-14/A. As per opinion of PW- 14, the deceased\n\ndied due to the injuries to brain caused by the head injury.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">      Fourteen witnesses were examined to substantiate the prosecution\n\nversion. PWs. 1, 2, 3, 5 &amp; 6 were stated to be eye witnesses. The High court\n\nnoticed that the injury could have been caused because of the fall and not\n\nbecause of the assault made by the respondent. The basis for such\n\nconclusion was that the injuries noticed on post mortem clearly revealed\n\nthat there was a scope for the injuries having been sustained during the fall.\n\nIt was, therefore, held that the vital injury could not have been caused by the\n\naccused Ram Krishan.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">3.    In support of the appeal learned counsel for the appellant submitted\n\nthat the conclusions of the High Court are purely based on conjectures.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                     5</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">\f4.    Learned counsel for the respondent on the other hand supported the\n\njudgment.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">5.    It is to be noted that there is no dispute that the deceased died out of a\n\nhead injury. PWs 1, 2, 3, 5 &amp; 6 are eye witnesses and all of them stated that\n\nthe accused Ram Krishan hit the deceased on the left side of the head with\n\nthe stone and he rolled down. Thus there was no material before the High\n\nCourt to come to a conclusion that the death occurred due to fall. The High\n\nCourt came to a peculiar finding that it might be possible that before the\n\nstone had hit the head of the deceased, he had slipped and had rolled down.\n\nThere was no material on record in this regard.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">6.    The High Court's conclusion is that no one examined the body of the\n\ndeceased before it rolled down to ascertain whether he was alive or dead. It\n\nis relevant that all the eye witnesses had stated about the assault of the head\n\nof the deceased by the accused with the stone. Injury No. 9 was described\n\nas the fatal injury. At least five of the injuries were on the head, which can\n\nbe related to the assault by the stone and more particularly injury No. 9 viz.\n\nthe fracture in the left temporal region. Since the High Court's order is\n\nbased on surmises and conjectures, it cannot be sustained and is set aside\n\nand the order of conviction recorded by the trial court stands restored. The\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                     6</span>\n\frespondent shall surrender to custody forthwith to serve remainder of\n\nsentence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">7.    Appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">                                                                ................................................J.\n                                                                (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n\n      .....................................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">                                                                (Dr. MUKUNDAKAM SHARMA)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 12, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">                                                     7</span>\n\f</p>","tid":609895,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":222396,"url":null,"title":"Section 427 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1011035,"url":null,"title":"Section 323 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":838469,"url":null,"title":"Section 452 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1560742,"url":null,"title":"Section 302 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":37788,"url":null,"title":"Section 34 in The Indian Penal Code"}]}, {"numcites":4,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"respondent is not accused","formInput":"respondent%20is%20not%20accused"},{"value":"suspend","formInput":"suspend"},{"value":"Rajasthan  filter:  Rape sec. 376","formInput":"Rajasthan%20%20filter%3A%20%20Rape%20sec.%20376"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Suzanne Lousie Martin vs State Of Rajasthan & Anr on 16 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33517","lastname":".........................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-16","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Suzanne Lousie Martin vs State Of Rajasthan &amp; Anr on 16 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: .........................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Markandey Katju, V.S. Sirpurkar</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                           REPORTABLE\n                               IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                               CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                              CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.78 OF 2009\n            (Arising out of SLP(Crl.) No.6783 of 2008)\n\n\nSuzanne Louise Martin                                          ..Appellant\n\n                               versus\n\nState of Rajasthan &amp; Another                          ..Respondents\n\n\n                                        ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">          Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n          This Appeal has been filed against the order dated 29.07.2008 passed by\n\nthe Division Bench of the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan at Jodhpur in\n\nD.B.Criminal Miscellaneous Bail Application/Suspension of Sentence Petition No.\n\n712 of 2008 in D.B.Criminal Appeal No.344 of 2008 whereby the High Court has\n\nsuspended the sentence awarded to the accused-respondent No.2 under Section 389,\n\n<a href=\"/doc/445276/\" id=\"a_1\">Cr.P.C</a>. and granted him bail on certain conditions.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">          We have carefully perused the record in this case, especially the first\n\ninformation report bearing No.18 dated 9.1.2008 registered under <a href=\"/doc/1279834/\" id=\"a_2\">Sections 376</a> &amp;\n\n<a href=\"/doc/1982060/\" id=\"a_3\">450</a> of the Indian Penal Code at Police Station Ambamata District, Udaipur in\n\nwhich serious allegations have been made against the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                      -2-</span>\n\frespondent-accused. The appellant is a British journalist and business woman. She\n\nhad come to India and was staying in Pardeshi Guest House, Udaipur.                 On\n\n23/24.12.2007, the respondent No.2, who was running the guest house, barged into\n\nthe room where the appellant was staying and forcibly raped her. She has alleged\n\nthat because of this incident she was emotionally, mentally and physically wrecked\n\nand became totally uncapicitated to even think and act like a normal human being.\n\nWe have also perused the judgment of the trial Court convicting the accused on\n\nboth counts and awarded life imprisonment under <a href=\"/doc/1279834/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 376</a>, <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_5\">IPC</a>.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">          Under the circumstances, without expressing any opinion on the merits of\n\nthe dispute and culpability of the accused, we are certainly of the opinion that this\n\nwas not a fit case where the sentence awarded should have been suspended and the\n\naccused released on bail. The High Court was, thus, totally unjustified in granting\n\nbail to the accused, or in suspending the sentence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">          Accordingly, we accept this appeal, set aside the impugned judgment of\n\nthe High Court and cancel the bail granted to the accused-respondent No.2. He\n\nshall be taken\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                      -3-</span>\n\n\n\ninto custody forthwith. However, we would request the High Court to dispose of the\n\nappeal expeditiously.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                      .........................J.</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\n\f                                   [MARKANDEY KATJU]\n\n\nNEW DELHI;          ...........................J.\nJANUARY 16, 2009.   [V.S.SIRPURKAR]\n\f</pre>","tid":72187374,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":1279834,"url":null,"title":"Section 376 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":445276,"url":null,"title":"The Code Of Criminal Procedure,   1973"},{"tid":1982060,"url":null,"title":"Section 450 in The Indian Penal Code"},{"tid":1569253,"url":null,"title":"The Indian Penal Code"}]}, {"numcites":3,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"rizwanur rahman","formInput":"rizwanur%20rahman"},{"value":"rizwanur","formInput":"rizwanur"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Ashok Kumar Todi vs C.B.I on 16 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33538","lastname":".............","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-16","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Ashok Kumar Todi vs C.B.I on 16 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: .............</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: K.G. Balakrishnan, P. Sathasivam</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                       IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n                           CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                               CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 81/2009\n                         (@ Special Leave to Appeal (Crl.) No. 9428/2008)\n\n\nASHOK KUMAR TODI\nAPPELLANT\n\n                                             VESUS\n\nC.B.I                                                                       RESPONDENT</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">                                              WITH\n\n                               CRIMINAL APPEAL NO. 82/2009\n                          (@ Special Leave to Appeal (Crl.) No. 85/2009)\n\n\n        Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">        The appellants are accused Nos. 1 &amp; 2 in a case registered by CBI. The appellant in\n    Special Leave Petition (Crl.) No. 9428/2009 is the father of Ms. Priyanka Todi. It is\n    alleged that the deceased Rizwanur Rahman had married Priyanka. The father of\n    Priyanka did not like the alliance and he wanted to dissuade Rizwanur Rahman to\n    keep away from the alliance. After some time the dead body of Rizwanur Rahman\n    was found in the railway track. According to prosecution, he committed suicide.\n    These appellants are arrayed as accused alleging that they had abetted the\n    commission of suicide. Thereby a charge is filed under <a href=\"/doc/92983/\" id=\"a_1\">Sections 306</a> and <a href=\"/doc/180217/\" id=\"a_2\">506</a> of IPC.\n    There is also allegations of conspiracy between the accused and a charge under\n    <a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 102B</a> is also incorporated. First accused (A-1) was taken into custody on 1-\n    12-2008 and A-2 was taken into custody on 8-12-2008. A final report in this case was\n    filed on 22nd September, 2008. These appellants moved for bail and the matter came\n    up before the Division Bench of the High Court of Calcutta. The High Court refused\n    to grant the bail and that order is challenged before this Court. We have heard\n    Learned counsel appearing for the appellants and also the Additional Solicitor\n    General appearing for the CBI.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">                                                                                     ...2/...\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                            -2-</span>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_4\">The Learned Counsel for the appellants pointed out that the trial of these cases has\nalready been stayed as one of these appellants had challenged the very registrations of\nthe case by the CBI. That matter is pending consideration before the High Court of\nCalcutta, therefore, it is alleged that the trial is likely to be delayed and the appellants\nhave to be in jail for a long period. The appellants' counsel also stated that the final\nreport has already been filed and the accused need not be detained in jail further.\nThe Additional Solicitor General strongly opposed the bail applications and also\nexplained the involvement of the accused in this case. Learned Counsel also pointed\nout that these accused, being highly influential persons, are likely to tamper with the\nevidence and may dissuade the witnesses from giving proper evidence in court.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">     Having regard to the nature of charge and also to the fact that the matter has\nalready been stayed, we feel that the accused be released on bail on some stringent\nconditions.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">The appellants are directed to be released on bail on executing bond for a sum of Rs.\n1,00,000/- each to the satisfaction of the City Sessions Court, Calcutta with two\nsolvent sureties for the like amount. The appellants shall surrender their passports if\nnot already surrendered, to the police within ten days.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">     The appellants shall not communicate with any of the witnesses and shall not\nmake any attempt to win over them. If any such allegation is there, the CBI would be\nat liberty to seek cancellation of the bail. The appellants shall not change their\npresent permanent residence without notice to\n                                                                                     ...3/-...\n</p>\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                            -3-</span>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">the SP, CBI, Calcutta. If the appellants want to vary any condition they would be at\nliberty to approach the High Court.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">  The criminal appeals are disposed of.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">\f                       .............CJI\n                      (K.G. (Crl.) No.7598 of 2008)\n\n\n\nJayaraj                                                      ...Appellant(s)\n\n\n                                         Versus\n\n\nState of Tamil Nadu                               ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                                      O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">           Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">           Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">           The Trial Court convicted the appellant under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 302</a> of the Indian\nPenal Code [for short, `<a href=\"/doc/1569253/\" id=\"a_2\">I.P.C</a>.'] and sentenced him to undergo imprisonment for life\nand to pay fine of Rs.1,000/-; in default, to undergo further imprisonment for a period\nof three months. On appeal being preferred, the High Court acquitted the appellant\nof the charge under <a href=\"/doc/1560742/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 302</a> I.P.C. and convicted him under <a href=\"/doc/1011035/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 323</a> I.P.C.\nand sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year and\ndirected him to pay compensation of Rupees fifteen thousand for being paid to the\nlegal representatives of the victim.
