Dattu</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                               NON-REPORTABLE\n\n\n\n               IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                  CIVIL APPEAL NO.446 OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP(C) NO. 550 of 2009)\n\n\n\nAnurag Kumar                                      ........ Appellant\n\n                                   Versus\n\nMohan Lal &amp; Anr.                                 ........Respondents\n\n\n\n                                   ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">  1) Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">  2) This appeal is directed against the orders passed by the High Court of\n\n     Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No.\n\n     47199 of 2007 dated 24.11.2008. By the impugned order, the court\n\n     has allowed the writ petition by quashing the order dated 01.09.2007\n\n     passed by the Additional District Judge, Court No.1, Meerut and\n\n     further has remanded the matter to the Revisional Authority to pass\n\n     fresh order in the light of observations made after affording sufficient\n\n     opportunity to the parties.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                                         1</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">\f3) The appellant is the owner of a Shop No. 570. Budhana Gate, Meerut,\n\n   where respondent no.1 is the occupant on monthly rent of RS. 400.\n\n   On 23.04.1999, an application was made by respondent no.2 before\n\n   the Rent Control and Eviction Officer stating that vacancy be\n\n   declared as the respondent no.1 has obtained allotment order by the\n\n   appellant by concealing the fact that he is already in occupation of\n\n   three other shops.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">4) The Competent Authority after obtaining a report from the Rent\n\n   Control Inspector and after having heard the parties vide its order\n\n   dated 28.09.2005 has observed that as the respondent no.1 has\n\n   obtained the possession of the disputed shop by playing fraud, and\n\n   therefore, the allotment of the disputed shop happens to be nullity and\n\n   is void, and thus the said shop is liable to be declared vacant.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">5) Neither the respondent no.1 nor the appellant challenged the order\n\n   dated 28.09.2005, thus it has become final. Appellant after\n\n   declaration of vacancy made an application for release of the disputed\n\n   shop before the Delegated Authority. The Delegated Authority after\n\n   considering the genuine and bonafide need of the appellant allowed\n\n   the release application in favor of the petitioner under sec. 16 of the\n\n   act, vide its order dated 30.11.2005.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                                                      2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f6) Respondent no.1 being aggrieved by the order filed a revision petition\n\n   before the Revisional Authority on the ground that no question of\n\n   release of the disputed shop in favor of appellant arises as the said\n\n   shop is not vacant and had been duly and properly allotted to the\n\n   respondent no.1. However, respondent no.1 did not challenge the\n\n   order of vacancy. Revisional Authority again went into details of the\n\n   case and vide its order dated 01.09.2007, declared that the property in\n\n   question was not vacant and was in occupation of the respondent no.1\n\n   as a valid allotee and the allotment in favor of respondent no.1 has\n\n   not been cancelled in accordance with provisions of law, therefore the\n\n   impugned order is liable to be set aside.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">7) Being aggrieved by the order dated 01.09.2007, appellant filed a Civil\n\n   Misc. Writ Petition before the High Court for quashing the said order\n\n   passed by the Revisional Authority.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">8) The High Court, allowed the writ petition vide its order dated\n\n   24.11.2008, quashing the order passed by the Revisional Authority\n\n   dated 01.09.2007 and has remanded the matter to the Revisional\n\n   Authority to pass an appropriate order, on the ground that Revisional\n\n   Authority has failed to take into consideration the fact, that, if the\n\n   order of vacancy has become final and it has never been challenged\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                                      3</span>\n\f   by aggrieved person then the question of allotment or question of\n\n   release in favour of the landlord cannot be raised by the person\n\n   concerned without challenging the order of vacancy unless and until\n\n   the premises in dispute is declared vacant by an authority competent\n\n   to do that is set aside. Aggrieved by this order the appellant is before\n\n   us in this appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">9) The High Court while exercising its discretionary and extraordinary\n\n   jurisdiction under <a href=\"/doc/1712542/\" id=\"a_1\">Article 226</a> has remanded the matter back to the\n\n   Revisional Authority to pass an appropriate order with certain\n\n   directions after going into the merits of the case.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">10)The basic principle of <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_2\">Article 136</a> is that if a litigant feels that\n\n   injustice has been done by a Court or any other body charged with\n\n   administration of justice, there is one superior court he may always\n\n   approach and which, in its discretion, may give him special leave to\n\n   appeal so that justice may be done: (1996) 1 SCJ 786, 803.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">11)It is not possible to define with any precision, the limitations on the\n\n   exercise of the discretionary jurisdiction vested in the Supreme Court\n\n   by the constitutional provision made in <a href=\"/doc/427855/\" id=\"a_3\">Article 136.</a> The limitations\n\n   whatever they be, are implicit in the nature and character of the power\n\n   itself. It being an exceptional and over-riding power, naturally, it has\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                                                       4</span>\n\f   to be exercised sparingly and with caution and in special and\n\n   extraordinary situations.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">12)It is well settled that though special leave is granted, the discretionary\n\n   power which is vested in the Court at the stage of the special leave\n\n   petition continues to remain with the Court even at the stage when the\n\n   appeal comes up for hearing and when both sides are heard on merits\n\n   in the appeal: (1999) 2 SCC 321.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\">13)In view of above, in our opinion although leave has been granted but\n\n   we do not find a need to exercise the discretionary powers under Art.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">   136. The matter has already been discussed by various Authorities\n\n   and the same has been remanded back by the High Court and as such\n\n   no extraordinary situation arises. It will be proper that the Revisional\n\n   Authority decides the matter again.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">14)Therefore without going into the merits of the case, we dismiss the\n\n   appeal. However, we reserve liberty to the appellant to raise all such\n\n   contentions which are available to him including certain contentions\n\n   raised in this appeal before the Revisional Authority. We direct the\n\n   Revisional Authority to adjudicate upon the matter independently\n\n   untrammeled by the observations and orders made by the High Court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">15)The appeal is dismissed accordingly. No order as to costs.\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">                                                                        5</span>\n\f                    .......................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">                    [ TARUN CHATTERJEE ]\n\n\n\n\n                    .......................................J.\n                    [ H.L. A Pasayat</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Arijit Pasayat, Asok Kumar Ganguly</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                                                       REPORTABLE\n\n                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n               CIVIL APPEAL NO.         395       OF 2009\n                (Arising out of SLP (C) No.13776 of 2007\n\n\nManaging Director, TNSTC                                 ..Appellant\n\n\n            Versus\n\n\nSuguna and Ors.                                          ..Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                            JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT, J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Challenge in this appeal is to the order passed by a learned Single\n\nJudge of the Karnataka High Court allowing the appeal filed by the\n\nclaimants-respondents. Background facts in a nutshell are as follows:\n\f      On 19.3.1998 a bus owned by the appellant-corporation was plying\n\nbetween Erode to Mysore via Nanjangud. At about 8.15 p.m. one Jayasheela\n\n(hereinafter referred to as the `deceased') who was driving two wheeler\n\nsustained injuries, because the bus dashed against the deceased who died on\n\nthe spot. Respondent No.1 the widow of the deceased and his two minor\n\nchildren filed a Claim Petition claiming compensation in terms of <a href=\"/doc/136948773/\" id=\"a_1\">Section\n\n166</a> of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 (in short the `Act'). Appellant filed its\n\nobjections denying the liability and took the stand that the accident occurred\n\nbecause of the negligence on the part of the deceased. The first Additional\n\nCivil Judge (Sr. Division) and Motor Accidents Claim Tribunal, Mysore (in\n\nshort the `MACT') awarded a sum of Rs.1,83,500/- as compensation\n\nalongwith 6% interest from the date of filing the Claim Petition.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">      Questioning quantum of the compensation, respondents Nos.1, 2 and\n\n3 filed an appeal before the High Court. The High Court fixed the quantum\n\nat Rs.4,05,500/- with interest at the rate of 6% as was directed by the\n\nMACT.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">\f3.    Learned counsel for the appellant-Corporation submitted that no basis\n\nhas been indicated for awarding the compensation. By a practically non-\n\nreasoned order, appeal has been disposed of.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">4.    Learned counsel for the respondents, on the other hand, submitted\n\nthat though the judgment is not very elaborate, yet the basis can be found\n\nout from the impugned order. In the normal course in a case where an\n\nappeal has been disposed of by a practically non reasoned order, the matter\n\nis remitted for fresh consideration. But considering the passage of time and\n\nthe limited nature of the controversy with the assistance of learned counsel\n\nfor the parties, we have gone through the records. The accident took place\n\non 19.3.1998. The deceased according to the post mortem report was aged\n\nabout 24 years. Though it was claimed that he was getting salary of\n\nRs.2,500/- p.m., there was no evidence adduced to substantiate the claim.\n\nThe MACT noticed that no evidence was adduced to substantiate the\n\nincome and, therefore, notional income of Rs.1,500/- p.m. was fixed. One-\n\nthird was deducted for personal expenses. The High Court did not indicate\n\nany reason to fix the income at Rs.2,500/- p.m. though it deducted one-third\n\nfor personal expenses.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">\f5.    In the aforesaid background, the amount of compensation is fixed at\n\nRs.3 lacs to be paid with interest at the rate of 6% p.a. from the date of filing\n\nof claim application. While working out the interest payable the amounts\n\nalready paid shall be duly taken note of and the interest would be calculated\n\non the balance amount payable.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">6.    The appeal is allowed to the aforesaid extent.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                          ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">                                          (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                                          ....................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">                                          (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 23, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                      4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":693757,"showurl":true,"citeList":[{"tid":136948773,"url":null,"title":"Section 166 in The Motor Vehicles Act, 1988"}]}, {"numcites":1,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"civil appeal","formInput":"civil%20appeal"},{"value":"slp","formInput":"slp"},{"value":"hotels","formInput":"hotels"}],"firstname":null,"title":"M/S. Further, in case the petitioner\n       submits the notorised undertaking within a period of fifteen days from\n       today, for payment of Rs. 10 lacs (Rupees ten lacs) per month for a\n       period of one year, then the possession of the seized property shall be\n       restored to the petitioner on depositing first installment of Rs. 10 lacs.\n       The remaining installments shall be paid by the 15th of each month,\n       failing which the interim order shall stand vacated automatically\n       without reference to this Court.\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">                    List in the month of December, 2008 for further orders.\"</blockquote><p id=\"p_14\">\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">             In view of the order proposed to be passed by us we need not enter into the\n\nmerit of the matter as the order as quoted above was passed ex-parte.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">             Mr. Dave, learned senior counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant\n\nsubmits that the possession of the Hotel in question had already been taken over on\n\n22.8.2008.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">             Mr. Altaf Ahmed, learned senior counsel on the other hand, submits that the\n\norders impugned before the High Court, being office orders dated 14.8.2008 and dated\n\n19.8.2008, the said orders are ex-facie illegal and without jurisdiction and, furthermore,\n\nas the possession had been obtained by the\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                           -4-</span>\n\n\n\nwrit petitioner purportedly to be in terms of Securitisation and Reconstruction of\n\nFinancial Assets and <a href=\"/doc/198257891/\" id=\"a_1\">Enforcement of Security Interest Act</a>, 2002 and in that view of the\n\fmatter the High Court cannot be said to have committed any error in passing the\n\nimpugned order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">          Be that as it may, by reason of the impugned judgment, the High Court has\n\npassed the ex-parte order in mandatory form.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">          By an order dated 25.11.2008, a Division Bench of this Court while issuing\n\nnotice, directed status quo as on that date, to be maintained by all concerned. In that\n\nview of the matter, we are of the opinion that interest of justice would be subserved if\n\nthe impugned judgment is set aside and the High Court be requested to hear out the\n\nmatter afresh, after giving an opportunity of hearing to both the parties. It is directed\n\naccordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_21\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">          While making the interim order dated 25.11.2008 passed by this Court\n\nabsolute, we would request the High Court to hear out the parties and pass appropriate\n\norder as expeditiously as possible, preferably within a period of three weeks from the\n\ndate of communication of this order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                          -5-</span>\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">          With the aforementioned observation and direction, this appeal is disposed\n\nof.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                          ..........................J\n                                          (S.B. Agrawal, G.S. Singhvi</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                  IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                       CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                          CIVIL APPEAL NO.946 OF 2007\n\n\nOrissa Electricity Regulatory Commission     ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                        Versus\n\nWestern Electricity Company of Orissa\nLimited and Ors.                              ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                         With Civil Appeal No.2309 of 2007\n\n\n\n                                    O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">Civil Appeal No.946 of 2007:\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">          By an order dated 27th January, 2006, Orissa Electricity Regulatory\nCommission (for short `the Regulatory Commission') directed issue of notice to the\nrespondents under proviso to <a href=\"/doc/132967048/\" id=\"a_1\">Section 24(1)</a> of the Electricity Act, 2003 (for short `the\nAct'), requiring them to file representations against proposed suspension of their\nlicences. Simultaneously, the Regulatory Commission appointed three special officers\nto over see working of the respondents. The appeals filed by the respondents against\nthat order were allowed by the Appellate Tribunal for Electricity (for short `the\nAppellate Tribunal') vide its order dated 13th December, 2006.         The Appellate\nTribunal set aside the order impugned in the appeals but observed that if the\nRegulatory Commission proposes to continue or initiate fresh action under <a href=\"/doc/132967048/\" id=\"a_2\">Section 24</a>\nof the Act, then it shall do so strictly in accordance with the relevant statutory\nprovisions and follow the procedure prescribed therein.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">                                                                                  ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">           We have heard the learned counsel for the parties and perused the record.\nIn our view, in the facts and circumstances of the case, the Regulatory Commission\nwas justified in issuing notice to the respondents calling upon them to file\nrepresentations against proposed suspension of their licences, but there was no\nwarrant for appointment of special officers to over see their work. Therefore, the\nAppellate Tribunal had rightly annulled the appointment of the special officers.\nHowever, it could not have set aside the order of the Regulatory Commission in its\nentirety without properly appreciating that only show cause notice had been issued to\nthe respondents and final order was yet to be passed by the Regulatory Commission.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed in-part. The impugned order of the\nAppellate Tribunal is quashed so far as it annuls the show cause notice issued by the\nRegulatory Commission under <a href=\"/doc/132967048/\" id=\"a_3\">Section 24(1)</a> of the Act. Now, it would be open to the\nrespondents to file their representations/ objections before the Regulatory\nCommission, which shall proceed to decide the matter in accordance with law without\nbeing influenced by the observations made in the order impugned in these appeals.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           Needless to say that we have not gone to the question as to whether while\nissuing notice under <a href=\"/doc/132967048/\" id=\"a_4\">Section 24(1)</a> of the Act proposing suspension of the licence, the\nRegulatory Commission could pass an order for appointment of special officer and\nthis question is left to be decided in appropriate case.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">                                                                                 ...3/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                         -3-</span>\n<p id=\"p_8\">Civil Appeal No.2309 of 2007:\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">          In view of the order passed in Civil Appeal No.946 of 2007, it is not\nnecessary to pass any further order in this appeal, but we clarify that any observation\nmade against the appellants in the impugned order shall not prejudice their cause\nbefore the Regulatory Commission.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_10\">                                                                        ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                               [B.N. AGRAWAL]\n\n\n\n                                                                        ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">                                               [G.S. Udham Singh Nagar, Uttarakhand, against the\n\n    husband of the petitioner and her relatives.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">             It is stated before us by the learned counsel for the State that a writ petition\n\n    for the aforementioned purpose has already been filed before the Uttarakhand High\n\n    Court. The issue is squarely covered by the judgment of this\n\nCourt in the case of Union of India Vs. Dharmendra Textile Processors &amp; Ors.,\n\nreported in 2008 (13) SCALE 233.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">         At this stage, learned counsel for the assessee states that he is challenging\n\nthe very levy of penalty on the facts and circumstances of the case. He seeks time to\n\nput in counter. His application is rejected for the simple reason that in this Civil\n\nAppeal, we are concerned with the quantum of penalty and not with the levy of\n\npenalty. As regards levy of penalty, the Tribunal has rejected the contention of the\n\nassessee that penalty is not leviable. However, that decision of the Tribunal has not\n\nbeen challenged by the\n\n                                                                       ...2/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                         -2-</span>\n\fassessee. Hence, our order allowing this Civil Appeal will not come in the way of the\n\nassessee challenging the order of the Tribunal on the question of imposition of\n\npenalty. The said order has been confirmed by the High Court in revision. Hence,\nthis appeal by special leave.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">           Having taking into consideration the entire pros and cons of the matter, we\nare of the view that the First Appellate Court was not justified in refusing to condone\nthe delay in filing the appeal and the High Court committed an error in confirming\nthe said order.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">                                                                                  ...2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                         -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_6\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned orders are set aside, delay in\nfiling the appeal before the First Appellate Court is condoned and the matter is\nremitted to that Court to decide the appeal on merits in accordance with law after\ngiving opportunity of hearing to the parties.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">                                                                       ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                [B.N. In a public interest litigation\n\nfiled before the High Court of Jammu &amp; Kashmir, the Division Bench of the\n\nHigh Court gave\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     -2-</span>\n\ncertain directions regarding basic infrastructure facilities which are to be\n\nprovided in the hospitals and other clinical establishments. The petitioner in\n\nthe public interest litigation alleged that many of the hospitals in the State\n\nof\n\nJammu and Kashmir are not having adequate facilities and State Authorities\n\nare not taking care to insist that basic facilities should be there in the\n\nhospitals.   It is alleged that licenses are issued for running these type of\n\ninstitutions without being any proper guidelines and requested       the High\n\nCourt to issue appropriate guidelines.     The High Court considered these\n\nmatters and directed the Chief Secretary of the State of Jammu and Kashmir\n\nto constitute a committee to be headed by Principal Secretary to\n\fGovernment, Health and Medical Education Department and comprising of\n\ntwo Principals, Government Medical Colleges at Srinagar and Jammu; two\n\nPrincipals of Government Dental Colleges at Srinagar and Jammu; two\n\nDirectors of Health Services of Kashmir and Jammu Provinces; Director,\n\nSher-i-Kashmir Institute of Medical Sciences, Soura, Srinagar and Chief\n\nEngineer of UEED, and the committee was directed to evolve and formulate\n\nsuitable criteria/norms for registration of private hospitals/nursing homes\n\nand clinical establishments/laboratories. The Committee submitted a report\n\nand also opined that the norms should be established       for   hospitals,\n\nclinics, nursing homes and\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                   -3-</span>\n\ndiagnostic centres. This was approved by the Government and issued in the\n\nForm - Norms for Registration &amp; Licensing of Nursing Homes and Clinical\n\nEstablishments-2006.    The hospitals were divided into two categories -\n\nnursing homes upto 25 beds and nursing homes above 25 beds. Detailed\n\nguidelines have been given regarding the various facilities that are to be\n\nmade available to the patients. The present appellants before us who are\n\nrunning hospitals/nursing homes/clinics have already been given licenses by\n\nthe Government.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">           The learned counsel appearing for the appellants contended\n\nbefore us that these appellants are running these institutions for the last\n\fseveral years and some of them are situated within the city limits of Jammu\n\nand Srinagar and it is difficult for them to acquire more space to provide\n\nthese facilities.   It is also contended that if these additional facilities are\n\nprovided, the expenses for health care itself will go up and ordinary citizens\n\nwill not be able to avail the benefits of these private hospitals. It is also\n\nargued that these sophisticated facilities could be provided only by few\n\nprivate hospitals which has got enormous economic power and appellants\n\nwould not be in a position to give all these facilities.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">             Learned counsel appearing for the State contended that these\n\nguidelines have been issued after considering all relevant facts and they are\n\nbasically essential for providing\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                        -4-</span>\n\nthe health care to the citizens of the State. It is also argued that if any of the\n\nhospitals/clinics or other centres do not have these facilities they can seek\n\nexemption upto 25% as provided in the guidelines.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">             Our attention was drawn to the various parameters which are\n\nlaid down in the guidelines. Care has been taken to provide facilities to the\n\npatients by the health care units.       We do not think that these norms are\n\nviolative of any rights of the appellants. However, we have noticed that all\n\nthese hospitals/clinics and other centres had been in existence for fairly a\n\nlong period and they had started these units under proper license on the\n\nbasis of   the then     existing    rules.   The   hospitals   owned   by   these\n\fappellants are lacking any of the facilities which are to be provided as per\n\nthe new guidelines, they are to be given six months time to update the\n\nfacilities in accordance with the norms laid down by the Government. If any\n\nstructure or alteration is required for hospital/building, the appellants be\n\ngiven one year time to comply with it.          If the appellants are seeking\n\nexemption of the guidelines or modification, they may file proper application\n\nto the Director of Health Services and it is for the       Director      of   Health\n\nServices to consider the individual\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                      -5-</span>\n\napplication and on hearing the appellants may pass appropriate orders\n\nregarding 25% exemption permissible as per the guidelines.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">            The appeals are disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                      ...................CJI\n                                                   (K.G. BALAKRISHNAN)\n\n\n\n                                        .....................J\n                                                 (P. SATHASIVAM\n\f                    .....................J\n                             (J.M. PANCHAL)\n  NEW DELHI;\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">JANUARY 29, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":326305,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"allotment of plots ","formInput":"allotment%20of%20plots%20"},{"value":"shammy","formInput":"shammy"},{"value":"improvement trust, ludhiana","formInput":"improvement%20trust%2C%20ludhiana"},{"value":"kabir","formInput":"kabir"},{"value":"altamas kabir","formInput":"altamas%20kabir"},{"value":"re-allotment","formInput":"re-allotment"},{"value":"displaced persons","formInput":"displaced%20persons"},{"value":"displaced","formInput":"displaced"}],"firstname":"a","title":"Baljit Singh vs Improvement Trust Ludhiana & Anr on 6 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33455","lastname":"kabir","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-06","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Baljit Singh vs Improvement Trust Ludhiana &amp; Anr on 6 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: A Kabir</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Markandey Katju</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                          IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n               CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n           Civil Appeal No.     9    of 2009\n     (Arising out of Special Leave Petition (Civil)\n                    NO.6979 of 2006)\n\n\n\nBaljit Singh                             ...Appellant\n\n\n      Vs.\n\n\nImprovement Trust Ludhiana &amp; Anr.         ...Respondents\n\n\n\n\n                     J U D G M E N T\n</pre>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">ALTAMAS KABIR,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">1.    Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.    Can a person who is a transferee of a plot of\n\n      land   allotted    to   the   transferor   by     the\n\n      Improvement Trust, Ludhiana, claim a right to\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                                                     2</span>\n\n\n     continue        with   such   allotment       even     after    the\n\n     same      is    cancelled,      particularly          when     such\n\n     transfer was effected with the approval of the\n\n     Trust, is the question for consideration in the\n\n     instant appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.   There is no dispute that on 28th October, 1982,\n\n     one Smt. Shammi Verma was allotted plot No.94-D\n\n     in   the       Development     Scheme    of     256    Acres     at\n\n     Balmik     Nagar,      Ludhiana,      under     Memo     No.9913\n\n     dated      26th    October,      1982      issued        by    the\n\n     Improvement        Trust,     Ludhiana.       Although,        Smt.\n\n     Verma deposited the amounts which were required\n\n     to   be    paid    against     such     allotment,      she     was\n\n     informed by the respondent No.1 by its letter\n\n     dated     2nd   January,      1989,   that    the     Trust    was\n\n     unable to make over possession of the plot to\n\n     her.       Subsequently,       Smt.     Verma    was    allotted\n\n     another plot, being No.91-B and an agreement to\n\n     sell was also executed in her favour.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                                                   3</span>\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.   On     11th   May,    1989,        the    appellant        herein\n\n     acquired the said plot No.91-B from Smt. Verma\n\n     and such transfer was also permitted by the\n\n     Trust.         Surprisingly, however, three months\n\n     later on 14th August, 1989, when the appellant\n\n     applied for approval of the site plan submitted\n\n     by him, he came to learn that the allotment of\n\n     plot No.91-B in favour of Smt. Shammi Verma had\n\n     been     cancelled     on     the        ground     that     such\n\n     allotment had been made by one Shri S.S. Mann,\n\n     who was not competent to make such allotment.\n\n     The      appellant         allegedly         made       various\n\n     representations       to     the    respondent       Trust    and\n\n     also    to    the   Government      and    on     consideration\n\n     thereof       the    Trust     was        directed     by     the\n\n     Government to restore the plot in question to\n\n     the appellant and consequently the allotment in\n\n     favour of Smt. Verma stood restored. It is the\n\n     case of the appellant that since the interest\n\n     of Smt. Verma devolved upon him as her approved\n\n     transferee, possession of plot No.91-B ought to\n\n     have been made over to him.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                                                4</span><p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">5.   However,    since    the     appellant     was    unable    to\n\n     obtain     any   relief    from   the    respondents,       he\n\n     filed    Civil   Writ     Petition      No.17103    of    2003\n\n     before the High Court seeking directions upon\n\n     the respondents to allot any alternative plot\n\n     to the appellant in lieu of plot No.94-D in\n\n     Balmik Nagar, Ludhiana.              While disposing of\n\n     the writ petition on 31st October, 2003, the\n\n     High Court directed the respondents to pass an\n\n     appropriate speaking order on the appellant's\n\n     representation within four months from the date\n\n     of the order upon production of a certified\n\n     copy thereof.       Pursuant to the said directions,\n\n     the Chairman of the Trust heard the appellant\n\n     on 11th February, 2004, but rejected his claim\n\n     on   the    ground    that     although     the    plot    in\n\n     question had been allotted to Smt. Shammi Verma\n\n     as a Local Displaced Person, she was not the\n\n     owner of any portion of the land acquired by\n\n     the Trust and was not a Displaced Person, which\n\n     was the eligibility criteria for coming under\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                                                  5</span>\n\n\n     the Scheme.        Even the subsequent change in the\n\n     allotment was effected by an officer who was\n\n     neither authorized nor entitled to do so.\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">6.   The decision of the Chairman of the Trust was\n\n     challenged by the appellant in Writ Petition\n\n     No.11844 of 2004, wherein various reliefs were\n\n     prayed for and in particular for restoration of\n\n     plot    No.91-B,    Rajguru    Nagar,         Ludhiana.      On\n\n     being    served     with    notice,       the    respondents\n\n     herein filed their          written statement            on 23rd\n\n     December,       2005,    claiming        that     since     the\n\n     predecessor-in-interest           of    the   appellant     was\n\n     ineligible for allotment of the plot in her\n\n     name,   the     appellant    could      not    get   a   better\n\n     right    than    she    enjoyed    in    respect     of    plot\n\n     No.91-B subsequently offered to her in lieu of\n\n     plot No.94-D.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">7.   The High Court dismissed the writ petition by\n\n     holding that the appellant did not have any\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                                                                  6</span>\n\n\n     independent    right     in   the    plot     and       as       a\n\n     transferee     his    fortunes      depended       on        the\n\n     fortunes of the transferor.            The High Court\n\n     having dismissed the civil writ petition, any\n\n     claim made by the appellant either over plot\n\n     No.94-D or plot No.94-B also stood rejected.\n\n     However, according to the appellant, since a\n\n     mistake had been committed by the respondents\n\n     themselves    at   the   initial    stage    and    various\n\n     transactions had already taken place in respect\n\n     of the plot in question, the cancellation of\n\n     the allotment which stood transferred to the\n\n     appellant with the permission of the Trust and\n\n     its authorities, was unacceptable. However, as\n\n     indicated hereinbefore, the said argument did\n\n     not   find   favour   with    the   High    Court,      which\n\n     dismissed the writ petition, which has given\n\n     rise to the present appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">8.   On behalf of the appellant it was urged that\n\n     the transfer effected in his favour with the\n\n     approval of the Trust created an interest in\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                                                                           7</span>\n\n\n     the plot in his favour which was independent of\n\n     and    not     dependent       on    the    allotment          made    in\n\n     favour of Smt. Shammi Verma.                    It was urged that\n\n     after the transfer was effected in his name on\n\n     11th May, 1989, a fresh right accrued in the\n\n     appellant's       favour       and    Smt.       Verma    ceased       to\n\n     have any interest in the plot thereafter and,\n\n     in any event, she had no subsisting right in\n\n     the     plot     on    14th     August,         1989,     when        the\n\n     allotment was cancelled.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">9.   It was also urged that the amounts deposited\n\n     for     allotment       of     the    plot       had     yet    to     be\n\n     refunded and if the respondents were determined\n\n     to     re-allot       the     plot    on     fresh       terms,       the\n\n     appellant       was    willing       to    pay    any     additional\n\n     amount that might be imposed to retain the plot\n\n     or even for a fresh allotment in his name, in\n\n     the special facts of the case.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_18\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_19\">10. The submissions made on behalf of the appellant\n\n     were     vehemently          opposed       on    behalf        of     the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                                                                      8</span>\n\n\n    respondents        and     on        their     behalf      it     was\n\n    maintained        that     since        the     predecessor-in-\n\n    interest of the appellant, Smt. Shammi Verma,\n\n    was   not      eligible    for       allotment       of   any    plot\n\n    under     the     Scheme,       the     allotment         had    been\n\n    rightly terminated and the appellant could not\n\n    derive    any     right    thereto       on    account      of    the\n\n    transfer made in his favour.                   According to the\n\n    respondents, the appellant would have to sink\n\n    or swim with the fortunes of his transferor as\n\n    no independent right had been acquired by him\n\n    by virtue of such transfer.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_20\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">11. Having      considered         the     submissions        made     on\n\n    behalf      of    the     respective          parties      and    the\n\n    materials on record, we are unable to accept\n\n    the     case     as     made    out     on     behalf      of     the\n\n    appellant.        We agree with the Chairman of the\n\n    Trust that notwithstanding the fact that the\n\n    transfer of the plot in favour of the appellant\n\n    had     been     duly    approved       by     the    Trust,     the\n\n    appellant did not acquire any independent right\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                                                                          9</span>\n\n\nin    the    plot    and        he    only       acquired      whatever\n\nrights the transferor or the original allottee\n\nhad   therein.             The       position       may       have       been\n\ndifferent      if     after           the    transfer          a        fresh\n\nallotment      had    been           made    in     favour         of    the\n\nappellant.        The defect in the allotment made in\n\nSmt. Shammi Verma's favour, on account of her\n\nineligibility         to     avail          of    the     Scheme          for\n\nrehabilitation        of        Locally      Displaced         Persons,\n\nwas     inherited          by        the     appellant          as        her\n\ntransferee.          The view taken by the Chairman of\n\nthe   Trust    in     his       order       dated      11th   February,\n\n2004 and affirmed by the High Court, cannot be\n\nfaulted.            However,         since       the    transfer         was\n\neffected     in     the    appellant's            favour       with       the\n\napproval of the Trust before the allotment was\n\ncancelled, the appellant's case could have been\n\ntreated      differently             in     the        special          facts\n\nthereof.       While the allotment of the plot was\n\nmade in Smt. Verma's favour on 28th October,\n\n1982, it was after almost seven years that the\n\norder   of    cancellation             of    such      allotment          was\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                                                                     10</span>\n\n\n    passed by the Trust, during which period not\n\n    only had the allotment been altered from one\n\n    plot to another plot, but even the transfer in\n\n    favour of the appellant had taken place.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_22\">12. We,     accordingly,         dispose      of     the    appeal    by\n\nmodifying the judgment and order of the High Court\n\ndated    30th   January,        2006,   and    the    order    of    the\n\nChairman,       Improvement       Trust,      Ludhiana      dated    11th\n\nFebruary, 2004, and directing the said Chairman to\n\nreconsider the case of the appellant in the light\n\nof the submissions made on his behalf that he was\n\nwilling to pay such additional amount as may be\n\nlevied    for     a     fresh    allotment      of    the     plot    in\n\nquestion in his favour, after giving the appellant\n\na reasonable opportunity of being heard, in the\n\nevent the said plot has not been re-allotted in the\n\nmeantime.       Such consideration must be completed by\n\nthe Chairman of the Trust within two months from\n\nthe date of communication of this order and in the\n\nevent    the     plot    in     question      has    not    been     re-\n\nallotted, the same shall not be re-allotted until a\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f                                                11</span>\n\n\ndecision is arrived at in terms of the directions\n\ngiven in this order.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_23\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_24\">13. In the facts of the case, the parties will bear\n\ntheir own costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">                                  _______________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">                                    (Altamas Kabir)\n\n\n                                  _______________J.\n</p><p id=\"p_28\">                                  (Markandey Katju)\nNew Delhi\nDated: 6.1.2009\n\f</p>","tid":954943,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"accidental firing","formInput":"accidental%20firing"},{"value":"SHIMOGA","formInput":"SHIMOGA"}],"firstname":"b","title":"M/S Malnad Traders vs M/S New India Assurance Co. Ltd on 22 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33542","lastname":"reddy","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-22","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">M/S Malnad Traders vs M/S New India Assurance Co. Ltd on 22 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: B Reddy</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Lokeshwar Singh Panta, B. Sudershan Reddy</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                      IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n            CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n             CIVIL APPEAL NO. 362 OF 2009\n         (Arising out of SLP(c) No. 9122 of 2008)\n\n\nM/s. Malnad Traders                          ...Appellant\n\n\n                            Versus\n\n\nM/s. New India Assurance Co. Ltd.                 ...\nRespondent\n\n\n\n\n                       JUDGMENT\n</pre>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">B.SUDERSHAN REDDY,J.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">     Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">2.   This appeal is directed against the judgment and order\n\nof the High Court     of Karnataka dated 17.8.2007 passed in\n\nRFA No. 959 of 2001       which was allowed in part reducing\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                    2</span>\n\n\nthe amount of damages of Rs. 1,26,055.87 granted by the\n\ntrial court to that of Rs. 48,556/- only with interest @ 6%\n\nfrom the date of suit till realization.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.     Brief facts needed for disposal of this appeal are as under:\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">4.     The appellant - M/s. Malnad Traders (hereinafter\n\nreferred    to   as    \"the   appellant   firm\")   is   a   registered\n\npartnership firm carrying on its business in Rice Mills and Oil\n\nMills at Shimoga in various buildings, godowns and open\n\nyards. On 7.12.1982, the entire premises of the appellant\n\nfirm    including     buildings,   machineries,    equipments     and\n\nstocks in trade were insured with the respondent - M/s. New\n\nIndia Assurance Company Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as\n\n\"the respondent company\") under the fire insurance policy\n\nbearing No.1229400593.             On 26.3.1983, there was a fire\n\naccident in the business premises of the appellant firm\n\nresulting in damage to the insured properties and as well as\n\ninjuries to two of its employees. On 11.4.1983, a detailed\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                 3</span>\n\n\nreport of the incident and extent of damages suffered was\n\nsent to the respondent company.               After completing the\n\nformalities,    the   Surveyor   of    the   respondent   company\n\ninspected the premises and prepared a detailed report about\n\nthe extent of damages caused to the properties of the\n\nappellant firm. Thereafter the appellant firm lodged its claim\n\nwith the respondent company amounting to Rs. 3,33,056.87\n\nas compensation for damages caused to its properties due\n\nto the fire accident along with documentary evidence. On\n\nfailure of the respondent company in settling the claim, the\n\nappellant firm served a legal notice on 5.7.1984 which\n\nremained       uncared   for   by     the    respondent   company.\n\nThereafter the appellant firm filed the suit bearing No. 61 of\n\n1986 claiming inter alia an amount of Rs. 3,33,055.87\n\ntowards damages along with interest @ 19.5% per annum\n\nbefore the Principal Civil Judge (Sr. Dn.) and C.J.M. at\n\nShimoga. The Principal Civil Judge, Shimoga decreed the\n\nsuit for a sum of Rs. 1,26,055.87 and awarded interest at\n\n6% from the date of filing of the suit till realization. The\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                4</span>\n\n\nrespondent company being aggrieved by the same filed RFA\n\nNo. 959 of 2001 before the High Court of Karnataka at\n\nBangalore which was allowed in part reducing the amount\n\nof damages of Rs. 1,26,055.87 granted by the trial court to\n\nthat of Rs. 48,556/- with interest @ 6% from the date of\n\nfiling of the suit till realization. Hence this appeal.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">5.   We have heard the learned counsel for the appellant\n\nand perused the impugned judgment and the material made\n\navailable on record. Despite service of notice none appeared\n\non behalf of the respondent company.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">6.   Appearing    on   behalf   of the    appellant,      Shri   G.V.\n\nChandrashekar, learned counsel submitted that the High\n\nCourt has committed serious error in reducing the amount\n\nof damages without assigning any reason whatsoever. It\n\nwas also submitted that the High Court was under an\n\nerroneous impression as if the appellant was seeking further\n\nenhancement of the claim and in the process made an\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                             5</span>\n\n\nobservation commenting as if the appellant manipulated and\n\naltered the documentary evidence.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_13\">7.    It is to be noted that     both the courts concurrently\n\nfound that the insurance coverage was in respect of entire\n\npremises and machinery installed therein and the policy was\n\nalive and in force on the date of fire accident. The appellate\n\ncourt even rejected the submission of the respondent\n\ncompany that the appellant under document Exhibit D-5\n\nagreed to receive a sum of Rs. 21,440/- only in full and final\n\nsettlement of the claims. The appellate court in this regard\n\ncame to the conclusion that there was no proof of full and\n\nfinal settlement of claims in terms of document Exhibit D-5.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8.   The damages claimed by the appellant firm were\n\nclassified under the following heads:-\n</p>\n<blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">     1.   Damage to building.\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">     2.   Damage to machinery\n\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_3\">     3.   Damage to electrical wiring.</blockquote><p id=\"p_15\">\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_5\">\f                               6</span>\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_16\">     In support of the claim the appellant firm relied on the\n\ndocuments viz. bills (Exhibit P-6 to Exhibit P-213) and also\n\noral evidence of PW-2 to PW-9.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_17\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">9.   PW-2 Ramachandrappa, a building contractor has been\n\nexamined who stated in the evidence that a sum of Rs.\n\n30,000/- was spent for purchase of materials and a sum of\n\nRs. 5,000/- was paid for labour charges towards the civil\n\nworks   of   the   building.   The   learned   trial   court   upon\n\nappreciation of the evidence allowed only a sum of Rs.\n\n5,000/- towards labour charges and the amount spent\n\ntowards purchase of building materials was disallowed for\n\nwant of proof. The learned appellate court construed the\n\nfinding of the trial court as if the appellant firm preferred\n\nappeal in that regard and in the process came to the\n\nconclusion that there was no proof regarding the amount\n\nspent for purchase of materials. In fact, the trial court did\n\nnot award any amount in that regard. The approach adopted\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_6\">\f                               7</span>\n\n\nby the appellate court is more or less similar in respect of all\n\nthe issues.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_19\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_20\">10. The appellate court went on upholding the findings\n\nrecorded by the trial court which actually were not in favour\n\nof the appellant firm. The whole approach adopted by the\n\nHigh Court was as if the appellant firm preferred the first\n\nappeal without any merit whatsoever.           The first appeal, in\n\nfact, was preferred by the respondent company.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_21\">11. The appellate court having upheld and accepted the\n\nreasoning of the trial court       without recording any reason\n\nwhatsoever    modified   the   amount     of    damages    of   Rs.\n\n1,26,055.87 awarded by the trial court to that of Rs.\n\n48,556/-.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_22\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_23\">12. A perusal of the trial court judgment discloses that it\n\nhad not only taken note of oral evidence but of each and\n\nevery document filed by the parties and recorded a specific\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_7\">\f                               8</span>\n\n\nfinding in respect of each of the items. The trial court held\n\nthat the appellant firm is not entitled to a sum of Rs.\n\n2,07,000/- out of the total claim of Rs. 3,33,055.87 in the\n\nfollowing manner:\n</p>\n<pre id=\"pre_2\">     1.   Item No. 71 for          Rs. 88,000.00\n\n     2.   Item No. 76 for          Rs. 30,000.00\n\n     3.   Item No. 77 for          Rs. 47,000.00\n\n     4.   Item No. 78 for          Rs. 40,000.00\n\n                    Plus                Rs.   2,000.00\n\n          Total:                   Rs.2,07,000.00\n\n\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_24\">     The reason adopted in disallowing the claims in respect\n\nof the items referred to herein above has been upheld by\n\nthe High Court but without recording any reason further\n\nreduced the amount of damages granted by the trial court.\n\nThere is no reason whatsoever based on which the High\n\nCourt could have interfered with the well                considered\n\njudgment of the trial court.       It is clear that the trial court\n\nupon appreciation of evidence upheld the receipts in exhibit\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_8\">\f                             9</span>\n\n\nP-70, P-71, P-72, P-75, P-77, P-181 and P-183. The trial\n\ncourt also relied upon exhibit P-190 and P-199.      The trial\n\ncourt relying upon exhibit P-190, exhibit P-188 and exhibit\n\nP-199 and for the detailed reasons had granted Rs. 5,000/-,\n\nRs. 8,000/- and Rs. 5,000/- respectively under the said\n\ndocuments. Total amount thus comes to Rs. 1,26,055.87.\n\nThe trial court after an elaborate consideration rightly\n\ndeducted the claim in respect of item Nos. 71, 76, 77 and\n\n78 and accordingly allowed only a sum of Rs. 1,26,055.87\n\ntowards the damages.     There is not a single reason in the\n\njudgment of the High court for reducing the quantum of\n\ndamages awarded by the trial court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_25\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_26\">13. For the aforesaid reasons, the appellant succeeds in\n\nthis appeal.   The impugned judgment of the High court\n\nmade in RFA No. 959 of 2001 is set aside and the decree\n\nand judgment of the trial court is accordingly restored.\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_9\">\f                           10</span>\n\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_27\">14. The appeal is, accordingly, allowed without any order\n\nas to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_28\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_29\">                                  ..........................................J.\n                                (Lokeshwar Singh Panta)\n\n\n\n                                   ..........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_30\">                                         (B. Sudershan Reddy)\n\nNew Delhi;\n</p><p id=\"p_31\">January 22, 2009\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_10\">\f11</span>\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_11\">\f12</span>\n\f</p>","tid":1525877,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"slp","formInput":"slp"},{"value":"jammu and kashmir","formInput":"jammu%20and%20kashmir"},{"value":"court master","formInput":"court%20master"},{"value":"sathasivam","formInput":"sathasivam"},{"value":"panchal","formInput":"panchal"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Aastha Diagnostic Clinical Lab. & ... vs State Of J&K & Ors on 29 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33824","lastname":"...................","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-29","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Aastha Diagnostic Clinical Lab. &amp; ... vs State Of J&amp;K &amp; Ors on 29 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...................</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: K.G. Balakrishnan, P. Sathasivam, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">           ITEM NO.1              COURT NO.1              SECTION XVIA\n\n\n         SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n              RECORD OF PROCEEDINGS\n\n\nPetition(s) for Special Leave to Appeal (Civil) No(s).10361/2006\n\n\n(From the judgement and order dated 19/04/2006 and 29.5.2006 in\nOWP No. 60/2006 &amp; OWP No. 112/2006 of The HIGH COURT OF\nJ &amp; K AT JAMMU)\n\n\nAASTHA DIAGNOSTIC CLINICAL LAB. &amp; ORS.                   Petitioner(s)\n\n                VERSUS\n\nSTATE OF J&amp;K &amp; ORS.                           Respondent(s)\n\n\n(With prayer for interim relief and office report)(For final\ndisposal)\nWITH SLP(C) NO. 10499 of 2006,SLP(C) NO. 12441 of 2006\n(With appln. for directions and permission to file rejoinder affidavit and prayer for\ninterim relief and office report)(For final disposal)\nSLP(C) NO. 1242 of 2007,SLP(C) NO. 14344 of 2006\nSLP(C) NO. 14345 of 2006,SLP(C) NO. 15584 of 2006\n(With appln. for exemption from filing c/c of the impugned order and c/delay in filing\nSLP and prayer for interim relief and office report)\n(For final disposal)\nSLP(C) NO. 13087 of 2006,SLP(C) NO. 13761 of 2006\nSLP(C) NO. 13737 of 2006\n(With prayer for interim relief and office report )\n(For final disposal)\nSLP(C) NO. 14296 of 2006\n(With appln. for exemption from filing c/c of the impugned order\nand and prayer for interim relief and office report)\n(For final disposal)\n\n\nDate: 29/01/2009 These Petitions were called on for hearing today.\n\n\nCORAM :\n    HON'BLE THE CHIEF JUSTICE\n    HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE P. SATHASIVAM\n    HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE J.M. PANCHAL\n\fFor Petitioner(s)     Mr. V. Hazarika, Adv.\n                            Mr. Indrajeet Gupta, Adv.\n                            Ms. S. Sharma, Adv.\n\n                            Ms. Shiva Lakshmi, Adv.\n                      For Mr. T. In a public interest litigation\n\nfiled before the High Court of Jammu &amp; Kashmir, the Division Bench of the\n\nHigh Court gave\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     -2-</span>\n\ncertain directions regarding basic infrastructure facilities which are to be\n\nprovided in the hospitals and other clinical establishments. The petitioner in\n\nthe public interest litigation alleged that many of the hospitals in the State\n\nof\n\nJammu and Kashmir are not having adequate facilities and State Authorities\n\nare not taking care to insist that basic facilities should be there in the\n\nhospitals.   It is alleged that licenses are issued for running these type of\n\ninstitutions without being any proper guidelines and requested       the High\n\nCourt to issue appropriate guidelines.     The High Court considered these\n\nmatters and directed the Chief Secretary of the State of Jammu and Kashmir\n\nto constitute a committee to be headed by Principal Secretary to\n\fGovernment, Health and Medical Education Department and comprising of\n\ntwo Principals, Government Medical Colleges at Srinagar and Jammu; two\n\nPrincipals of Government Dental Colleges at Srinagar and Jammu; two\n\nDirectors of Health Services of Kashmir and Jammu Provinces; Director,\n\nSher-i-Kashmir Institute of Medical Sciences, Soura, Srinagar and Chief\n\nEngineer of UEED, and the committee was directed to evolve and formulate\n\nsuitable criteria/norms for registration of private hospitals/nursing homes\n\nand clinical establishments/laboratories. The Committee submitted a report\n\nand also opined that the norms should be established       for   hospitals,\n\nclinics, nursing homes and\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                   -3-</span>\n\ndiagnostic centres. This was approved by the Government and issued in the\n\nForm - Norms for Registration &amp; Licensing of Nursing Homes and Clinical\n\nEstablishments-2006.    The hospitals were divided into two categories -\n\nnursing homes upto 25 beds and nursing homes above 25 beds. Detailed\n\nguidelines have been given regarding the various facilities that are to be\n\nmade available to the patients. The present appellants before us who are\n\nrunning hospitals/nursing homes/clinics have already been given licenses by\n\nthe Government.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">           The learned counsel appearing for the appellants contended\n\nbefore us that these appellants are running these institutions for the last\n\fseveral years and some of them are situated within the city limits of Jammu\n\nand Srinagar and it is difficult for them to acquire more space to provide\n\nthese facilities.   It is also contended that if these additional facilities are\n\nprovided, the expenses for health care itself will go up and ordinary citizens\n\nwill not be able to avail the benefits of these private hospitals. It is also\n\nargued that these sophisticated facilities could be provided only by few\n\nprivate hospitals which has got enormous economic power and appellants\n\nwould not be in a position to give all these facilities.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">             Learned counsel appearing for the State contended that these\n\nguidelines have been issued after considering all relevant facts and they are\n\nbasically essential for providing\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                        -4-</span>\n\nthe health care to the citizens of the State. It is also argued that if any of the\n\nhospitals/clinics or other centres do not have these facilities they can seek\n\nexemption upto 25% as provided in the guidelines.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">             Our attention was drawn to the various parameters which are\n\nlaid down in the guidelines. Care has been taken to provide facilities to the\n\npatients by the health care units.       We do not think that these norms are\n\nviolative of any rights of the appellants. However, we have noticed that all\n\nthese hospitals/clinics and other centres had been in existence for fairly a\n\nlong period and they had started these units under proper license on the\n\nbasis of   the then     existing    rules.   The   hospitals   owned   by   these\n\fappellants are lacking any of the facilities which are to be provided as per\n\nthe new guidelines, they are to be given six months time to update the\n\nfacilities in accordance with the norms laid down by the Government. If any\n\nstructure or alteration is required for hospital/building, the appellants be\n\ngiven one year time to comply with it.          If the appellants are seeking\n\nexemption of the guidelines or modification, they may file proper application\n\nto the Director of Health Services and it is for the       Director      of   Health\n\nServices to consider the individual\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">                                      -5-</span>\n\napplication and on hearing the appellants may pass appropriate orders\n\nregarding 25% exemption permissible as per the guidelines.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">            The appeals are disposed of accordingly.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">                                      ...................CJI\n                                                   (K.G. D'souza                                  ...Appellant(s)\n\n\n                                          Versus\n\n\nCorporation Bank &amp; Ors.                            ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                                       O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">              Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">              By the impugned order, the National Consumer Disputes Redressal\nCommission [for short, \"the National Commission\"] dismissed the complaint filed by\nthe appellant, in effect and substance, on the ground that the same was barred by\nlimitation.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">              A perusal of the complaint and the documents filed by the appellant shows\nthat Respondent No.3-M/s. Rao Constructions gave a post-dated cheque bearing\nNo.929131 dated 17th October, 1996, to the appellant on 17th April, 1996 for\nrepayment of the loan. The Manager of Chembur Branch of the Bank guaranteed\nencashment of the cheque. However, on 16th July, 1996, that is a day before the due\ndate of payment, the Branch Manager asked the appellant not to present the cheque.\nOn the next day, cheque No.929131 was taken from the appellant and another cheque\nbearing No.217401 dated 17th October, 1996 was issued for Rupees twenty lakhs. The\nbank gave fresh guarantee to the appellant that the cheque will be\n                                                                                  ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_4\">honoured on its presentation. The appellant presented the cheque on 10th April, 1997,\nfor encashment but it was returned on the same day with the remark \"insufficient\nfunds\". The appellant represented to the bank for payment of Rupees twenty lakhs\nby relying upon the guarantee given on 17th July, 1996. The Chief Manager of the\nBank sent communications dated November 16, 1998 and February 5, 1999 and\nassured the appellant that the matter is being looked into and they will get back to\nhim within few days. After fifteen days, the Chief Manager vide his letter dated 20th\nFebruary, 1999 denied the liability of the Bank to pay the amount of the cheque.\nThereupon, the appellant filed complaint before the National Commission on 18th\nOctober, 1999 which, as mentioned above, was dismissed as barred by time.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">              From the facts narrated above, it is clear that cause of action to file the\ncomplaint had arisen on receipt of communication dated 20th February, 1999, by\nwhich the bank denied its liability to pay the amount of cheque in spite of the fact that\nthe payment of the said sum was guaranteed. Therefore, the complaint filed on 18th\nOctober, 1999 was well within limitation and the National Commission committed\nserious error by dismissing the complaint on the ground that the same was barred by\nlimitation.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">              Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned order is set aside and the\nmatter is remitted to the National Commission which shall now dispose of the\ncomplaint in accordance with law after giving opportunity of hearing to the parties,\nwhich would obviously include opportunity to adduce evidence.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">              No costs.\n</p>\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">                                                                          ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                 [B.N. The only controversy is regarding the amount on which the interest will\n\n have to be now paid, in terms of the order passed by the District Forum, as\n\n confirmed by the State and National Forum. Challenge in this appeal is to the order passed by a Division Bench of\n\nthe Patna High Court dismissing the Writ Petition filed by the appellant.\n\nBefore the High Court, challenge was to the order passed by the Central\n\nAdministrative Tribunal, Patna Bench (in short the `CAT'). The CAT by the\n\fimpugned order negatived the claim of the appellant for appointment to the\n\npost of Extra Departmental Branch Post Master (in short `EDBPM'). CAT\n\nheld that the claim made by the appellant cannot be accepted on two\n\ngrounds; firstly, his land was encumbered and secondly he did not file the\n\noriginal certificates with regard to his qualifications. Stand of the appellant\n\nbefore the High Court was that the conclusions relating to encumbrance of\n\nland are incorrect as the encumbrance was with regard to another plot of\n\nland and not relating to the land belonging to the appellant. It was also\n\npointed out that the certificates were produced at the time of hearing of the\n\noriginal application before the CAT. The High Court held that even if the\n\nfirst ground that the land was not encumbered is accepted, the writ petition\n\nwas to be dismissed as all the relevant documents were not produced and\n\nrespondent No.6 who was appointed had filed all the relevant documents.\n\nTherefore, the petition was dismissed.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">3.    Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that the original\n\ndocuments were with the institution where the appellant was pursuing his\n\nstudies and in fact the institution had clearly certified that the original copy\n\nof the mark sheet, admit card, school leaving certificate and other\n\ndocuments submitted by the students at the time of their admission are not\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                     2</span>\n\freturned to them under an order passed by the State Government. It is the\n\nstand of the appellant that there is no requirement to produce the original\n\ndocuments.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">4.    Learned counsel for the respondent-State supported the judgments of\n\nthe CAT and the High Court.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_11\">5.    It is not disputed that the original documents were not produced\n\nbefore the authorities because the documents were with the institution i.e.\n\nRamdayalu Singh College, Muzaffarpur and the appellant was not in a\n\nposition to produce the original documents. In view of the aforesaid it is\n\nnot necessary to examine whether there is any requirement for producing the\n\noriginal documents as observed by the departmental authorities. Respondent\n\nNo.6 is continuing in his job. Therefore, without disturbing his continuance,\n\nwe direct that in case there is any vacancy in the nearby area where the\n\nappellant can be adjusted, the same can be done by the authorities after\n\nfollowing the necessary norms. The appeal is accordingly disposed of.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    3</span>\n\f                       ...........................................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">                       (Dr. ARIJIT PASAYAT)\n\n\n                       ..........................................J.\n                       (ASOK KUMAR GANGULY)\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 28, 2009\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                   4</span>\n\f</p>","tid":736268,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"firstname":null,"title":"R. Saravana Prabhu &amp; Anr vs M/S.
