SARAVANA PRABHU &amp; ANR.                                             ...     Appellant(s)\n\n\n           Versus\n\nM/S. VIDEOCON LEASING&amp;INDL.FIN.LTD.&amp;ANR.                                ...   Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n                                  ORDER\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">             Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">             This appeal is directed against the judgment and order dated 12th June,\n\n    2006 passed by the Bombay High Court in Appeal No.922 of 2005 in Summons for\n\n    Judgment No.717 of 1999 in Summary Suit No. 475 of 1999 affirming the judgment\n\n    of the learned Single Judge, granting conditional leave to the appellant to contest the\n\n    suit filed by the respondent upon depositing Rs. 3.1 crores as pre-condition for\n\n    defending the suit.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">             We have heard Mr. R.F. Nariman, learned senior\n\n    counsel, appearing in support of the appeal and from the materials, it appears that\n\n    there are several triable issues\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                     -2-</span>\n\nto be considered in the suit, which has been filed under Order 37 CPC. He has relied\n\non the decision of this Court in the case of Mechelec Engineers &amp; Manufacturers Vs.\n\nM/s. Basic Equipment Corporation, reported in 1977 (1) SCR 1060, wherein a Bench\n\nof three Judges had laid down certain propositions with regard to the grant of leave\n\nin respect of     summary trials.     The present case appears to be covered by\n\nproposition (b) of the said propositions.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">         On behalf of the respondent(s) it has been submitted that since leave had\n\nbeen obtained by the respondent herein for filing the suit under Clause 12 of the\n\nLetters Patent, that itself should be sufficient to indicate that part of the cause of\n\naction has arisen within the jurisdiction of the Bombay High Court.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">         Be that as it may, since the suit filed by the respondent does raise questions\n\nwhich, prima facie, appear to be triable, following the decision in the Mechelec\n\nEngineers &amp; Manufacturers case (supra), we are of the view that the High Court\n\nerred in directing the appellant to deposit the amount, as mentioned in the cheque.\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">         We, accordingly, allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court\n\nand grant unconditional leave to\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                     -3-</span>\n\nthe appellant to defend the suit in question. The High Court, however, is requested\n\nto take all such steps as may be possible to dispose of the suit as expeditiously as\n\npossible, but at least within a year from the date of communication of this order.\n\f              There will be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                      (ALTAMAS KABIR)\n\n\n\n                                                  ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">                                            (CYRIAC JOSEPH)\n\n\nNew Delhi,\nJanuary 05, 2009.\n</p>\f","tid":142895346,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"allotment of plots ","formInput":"allotment%20of%20plots%20"},{"value":"quota","formInput":"quota"},{"value":"huda","formInput":"huda"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Raj Dulari vs State Of Haryana And Ors on 30 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=33683","lastname":"_________________j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-30","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Raj Dulari vs State Of Haryana And Ors on 30 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: _________________J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: R.V. Raveendran, J.M. Panchal</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                             IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                  CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                 CIVIL APPEAL NO.607 OF 2009\n          (Arising out of SLP [C] No.16796 of 2004)\n\n\nRAJ DULARI                                              ... Appellant\n\nVs.\n\nSTATE OF HARYANA &amp; ORS.                                 ... Respondent\n\n\n\n                                 O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">      Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">2.    The appellant while working as a Superintendent in the\n\noffice of the Advocate-General, Haryana made applications\n\nfor   allotment   of   a   plot    under     the   Government   employees\n\nquota in Sector 25, Panchkula and for allotment of a plot\n\nunder the general category in Sector 26, Panchkula. The\n\nHaryana Urban Development Authority (HUDA), by letter dated\n\n14.11.1994   informed      her    that   she   had   been   selected    for\n\nallotment of Plot No. 817 in Sector 26 under the general\n\ncategory in the draw of lots held on 31.10.1994.                HUDA also\n\nselected her for allotment of a plot (No. 946 in Sector 25)\n\nunder the Government employees quota.\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                    2</span><p id=\"p_4\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">3.   As a person could not have allotment of more than one\n\nplot, the appellant opted for retaining the allotment of\n\nPlot No. 817 (Sector 26) under the general category, and\n\nsent a letter dated 10.3.1995 requesting for cancellation\n\nof proposed allotment of Plot No. 946 (Sector 25) under the\n\nGovernment employees quota.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">4.   HUDA, by letters dated 4.4.1995, called the appellant\n\nfor a hearing and verification of documents, stating that\n\nshe could not have more than one plot. Subsequently, HUDA\n\ncancelled the general category allotment of Plot No. 817\n\n(Sector 26) as per communication dated 20.12.1995, on the\n\nground that the appellant is not eligible for two plots and\n\nrefunded the sum of Rs.20,500/- which had been deposited as\n\nearnest money for the said plot. The appellant accepted the\n\ncancellation of allotment of Plot No. 817 (Sector 26) being\n\nunder   the   impression     that       she   will   get     Plot   No.   946\n\n(Sector 25) under the Government employees quota.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">5.   One of the requirements for confirmation of allotment\n\nof   plots    under    the     Government       employees       quota     was\n\nproduction of an Integrity Certificate from the employer\n\nwithin 90 days from the date of allotment (vide clause 10\n\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">(iii) of the Allotment Brochure).              As a criminal case was\n\npending   against     the    appellant,       she    could    not   get   the\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">\f                                       3</span>\n\nIntegrity    Certificate        within      90       days.    She     obtained       the\n\nIntegrity     Certificate        only           on    4.8.2000,            after     the\n\nconclusion of the criminal proceedings and submitted it to\n\nHUDA on 21.8.2000.         As allotment of Plot No. 946 was not\n\nconfirmed even thereafter, she approached the High Court\n\nfor relief in Civil Writ Petition No. 11208 of 2003.                                 The\n\nHigh Court dismissed the writ petition on the ground that\n\nthe    appellant,       not      having          produced          the        Integrity\n\nCertificate within 90 days from the date of allotment, was\n\nnot   entitled    to    the     plot.           The    said        order      is   under\n\nchallenge in this appeal by special leave.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\">6.    As   noticed     above,    the       appellant         was    allotted       plots\n\nboth under the general category and Government employees\n\nquota.      The      cancellation          of    allotment          under      general\n\ncategory, was on the assumption that appellant was allotted\n\nplot No.946 (Sector 25) under government employees quota.\n\nIf appellant was not entitled to allotment under government\n\nemployees quota, she was entitled to the allotment of Plot\n\nNo.817 under the general category and that could not have\n\nbeen cancelled. The appellant accepted the cancellation of\n\ngeneral category selection of Plot No. 817 (Sector 26), as\n\nshe believed that she would get Plot No. 946 (Sector 25)\n\nunder Government       employees        quota.         In     fact,      as    per   the\n\nrules, only persons who already have a plot in an Urban\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">\f                                     4</span>\n\nEstate or a confirmed allotment, are not eligible for a\n\nsecond    plot.      If   the    appellant       was     not   eligible      for\n\nallotment of Plot No. 946 under Government employees quota,\n\nshe could not have been denied allotment of Plot No. 817\n\nunder general category. Be that as it may.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_12\">7.     On the peculiar facts and circumstances, it may not be\n\njust to deny the plot to the appellant, inspite of having\n\nbeen allotted plots, both under the general category and\n\nunder the Government employees quota. In the circumstances,\n\nwe are of the view that the HUDA should accept the belated\n\nproduction     of    Integrity       Certificate         and    confirm      the\n\nallotment of Plot No. 946 (Sector 25) to the appellant.                      We\n\nmay however make it clear that in view of the delay on the\n\npart     of   the    appellant       in     production         of   Integrity\n\nCertificate, HUDA will be entitled to charge for the plot,\n\nthe price prevailing on 21.8.2000 (the date of production\n\nof     such   certificate)      instead     of     the    allotment        price\n\napplicable in 1994-95.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_14\">8.     We accordingly allow this appeal and direct the HUDA\n\nto allot Plot No. 946 (Sector 25), Panchkula, under the\n\nGovernment     employees     quota       subject    to    payment     by    the\n\nappellant,     the   price   applicable       as    on     21.8.2000.       This\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_4\">\f                                5</span>\n\ndecision   shall    not   be   treated   as    a   precedent   as   the\n\ndirection is on the special facts of          this case.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_15\">                                                 _________________J.</p><pre id=\"pre_2\">\n                                                (R V Raveendran)\n\n\n\n\nNew Delhi;                                      _________________J.\nJanuary 30, 2009.                               (J M Panchal)\n\f</pre>","tid":292693,"showurl":true,"citeList":[]}, {"numcites":0,"covertids":[],"covertitles":[],"relatedqs":[{"value":"personal hearing","formInput":"personal%20hearing"}],"firstname":null,"title":"Punjab National Bank & Anr vs O.N.Sharma & Ors on 5 January, 2009","url":"http://judis.nic.in/supremecourt/imgst.aspx?filename=34867","lastname":"...................j.","secondname":null,"publishdate":"2009-01-05","citedbyList":[],"covers":[],"docsource":"Supreme Court of India","numcitedby":0,"divtype":"judgments","doc":"<div class=\"docsource_main\">Supreme Court of India</div>\n<div class=\"doc_title\">Punjab National Bank &amp; Anr vs O.N.Sharma &amp; Ors on 5 January, 2009</div><div class=\"doc_author\">Author: ...................J.</div>\n\n<div class=\"doc_bench\">Bench: Altamas Kabir, Cyriac Joseph</div>\n\n<pre id=\"pre_1\">                                     IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n\n                            CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n\n                     CIVIL APPEAL No. 14 OF 2009\n       [Arising out of SLP(C)No.19390 of 2006]\n\n\n\n\nPUNJAB NATIONAL BANK &amp; ANR                                      ...     Appellant(s)\n\n\n          Versus\n\nO.N.SHARMA &amp; ORS                                                  ...   Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n\n                        ORDER\n</pre>\n<p id=\"p_1\">         Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">         Despite notice of the special leave petition having been served on the\n\n   respondents, who have received notice personally, there is no appearance on their\n\n   behalf. Since such notices have been served in the month of February, 2008, fresh\n\n   notices were also directed to be served, which were issued in August, 2008. Even\n\n   then, there is no appearance on behalf of the respondents and in particular\n\n   respondent No. 1, who is the contesting respondent.\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                                   -2-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">         The only question which arises for consideration in this appeal is whether\n\fthe respondent was entitled to a\n\npersonal hearing at the appellate stage when he had filed an appeal before the\n\nAppellate Authority against the order of the Disciplinary Authority, by which he had\n\nbeen awarded punishment of withdrawal of special pay as Special Assistant for 2\n\nyears under Clause 6(g) of the Bipartite Settlement arrived at between the\n\nmanagement and the workmen. Mr. Mehta, appearing in support of the appeal, has\n\ndrawn our attention to the procedure for taking disciplinary action, as was indicated\n\nin the Bipartite Settlement and has laid special emphasis on paragraph 14 of the\n\nsame which indicates that at the appellate stage, if an employee, who has been\n\ndismissed from service, asks for personal hearing, such prayer could be granted by\n\nthe Appellate Authority. In other cases, no such provision has been made.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">        Mr. Mehta submitted that at the time of the disciplinary proceedings, the\n\nrespondent was given all opportunities to defend himself and has also been given a\n\nhearing by the Disciplinary Authority. Mr. Mehta has also referred to and relied on\n\nthe decision of this Court in State Bank of Patiala Vs. Mahendra Kumar Singhal,\n\n[1994\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                    -3-</span>\n\n(Suppl.) 2 SCC 463], where in a similar situation, it was observed   that the rules\n\nof natural justice did not\n\nnecessarily in all cases confer a right to be heard personally at the appellate stage\n\nunless there was a rule to the contrary. In fact, such an observation was made\n\nfollowing the Constitution Bench decision of this Court in F.N. Roy Vs. Collector of\n\f     Customs, Calcutta, [1957 SCR 1151].\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">             The facts of the case of this appeal being similar, we are unable to sustain the\n\n     order of the High Court impugned in this appeal remitting the matter to the\n\n     Appellate Authority for giving the respondent a personal hearing.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">             We, accordingly, set aside the impugned judgment of the High Court and\n\n     remit the matter to the High Court for fresh consideration with leave to the\n\n     respondent to raise the other questions taken in the writ petition, which do not\n\n     appear to have been gone into by the High Court, since the submissions before the\n\n     High Court were confined only to the question as to whether the respondent was\n\n     entitled to a personal hearing before the Appellate Authority.\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                                   -4-</span>\n\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">             The Civil Appeal is allowed in the above terms.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">             There will be no order as to costs.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_10\"> Lalitha                                       ...Respondent(s)\n\n                                       O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">             Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">             Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">             The eviction petition filed by the appellants on the ground of default in\npayment of rent and bona fide need was dismissed by Rent Controller, Secunderabad.\nOn appeal, Additional Chief Judge, City Small Causes Court, Hyderabad, after\ndetailed evaluation of the evidence produced by the parties reversed the order of the\nRent Controller and granted eviction on the ground that the need of the appellants\nwas bona fide. When the matter was taken in revision, the High Court overturned the\nfinding of fact recorded by the appellate Court on the issue of bona fide need, set\naside the order of the appellate Court and restored the order passed by the Rent\nController. Hence, this appeal by special leave.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">             It is well settled that in exercise of revisional jurisdiction, the High Court\ncannot re-appraise the evidence and substitute the finding of fact recorded by the\nfinal court of fact unless the same is found to be perverse. In the instant case, the\nHigh Court without appreciating the limitation of its jurisdiction reversed the\njudgement of the appellate court, which, in our considered view, was legally\nimpermissible.\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">                                                                                     ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_6\">           Accordingly, the civil appeal is allowed, impugned order rendered by the\nHigh Court is set aside and the order of eviction passed by the appellate court is\nrestored. The respondent is granted time till 31st December, 2009, to vacate the\npremises in question upon filing usual undertaking in this Court within four weeks\nfrom today.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">           It is directed that in case the respondent fails to vacate the premises in\nquestion within the aforesaid time, it would be open to the decree holder to file an\nexecution petition for delivery of possession and in case such a petition has already\nbeen filed, an application shall be filed therein to the effect that the respondent has\nnot vacated the premises in question within the time granted by this Court. In either\neventuality, the Executing Court is not required to issue any notice to the respondent.\nThe Executing Court will see that delivery of possession is effected within a period of\nfifteen days from the date of filing of the execution petition or the application\naforementioned. In case for delivery of possession any armed force is necessary, the\nsame shall be deputed by the Superintendent of Police within forty eight hours from\nthe date requisition is received therefor. It is also directed that in case anybody else,\nother than the respondent, is found in possession, he shall also be dispossessed from\nthe premises in question.\n</p>\n\n\n\n<p id=\"p_8\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                [B.N. Tata Finance Ltd. now Tata Motors Ltd.                       ...Appellant(s)\n\n                      Versus\n\nN. Poongodi &amp; Anr.                                                ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n                                        ORDER\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">           Leave granted.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_2\">           In this case, vide the impugned judgment, the Monopolies and Restrictive\n\nTrade Practices Commission ('Commission' for short) has dismissed the application,\n\nC.A.No.7/2007, filed by the appellant herein for deciding the issue of maintainability of\n\nthe Compensation Application bearing No. M.A.No.7/2007 as a preliminary issue,\n\nhence, this Civil Appeal.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">           Appellant-Company is a non-banking financial institution.       Respondents\n\nhad entered into four hire purchase agreements with the appellant, the details of which\n\nare given in synopsis 'D' to the S.L.P. paper book. Disputes arose between the parties\n\nwhich went to arbitration. Two Awards were given. Ultimately the matter came to\n\nthis Court by way of Special Leave Petition and the Awards stood confirmed. In the\n\nprocess, a period of almost ten years elapsed. Pursuant\n\n                                                                            ...2/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_4\">\n\n\nCA @ SLP(C) 12422/08 contd...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                            -2-</span>\n\fto the Awards, execution proceedings, including insolvency proceedings, have been\n\ntaken. We do not wish to comment about those proceedings as the matter is sub\n\njudice.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">           Suffice it to state that after ten years, the Commission has been moved\n\nclaiming damages in which appellant herein raised the contention that it should decide\n\nthe question of maintainability of the above Compensation Application No.7/2007 as a\n\npreliminary issue.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">           According to the appellant, the said Compensation Application No.7/2007\n\namounts to abuse of process and it is this issue which the appellant wanted the\n\nCommission to be decided as a preliminary issue.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">           When the matter came for hearing, we have examined the voluminous record\n\nthreadbare. After examining the entire record, without commenting on the merits of\n\nthe case, we are of the view that the Commission has erred in holding, vide para 11,\n\nthat the question of maintainability of Compensation Application No.7/2007 is a\n\nquestion of fact and law which can be decided only when the evidence is led. It is\n\nimportant to note that in this case what the Commission ought to have done is to have\n\nexamined the scope of the arbitration proceedings. It ought to have examined the\n\npleadings before the Arbitrator before coming to the conclusion as stated hereinabove\n\nvide para 11 of the impugned judgment. The bare fact remains that\n\n                                                                        ...3/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_9\">\n\n\nCA @ SLP(C) 12422/08 contd...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_10\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_2\">                                          -3-</span>\n\nafter ten years and after the parties have gone through the entire gamut of the various\n\nproceedings, the matter has been moved before the Commission alleging unfair trade\n\npractice. There are various nuances of the concept of abuse of process, which includes\n\fmoving the Commission after ten years. None of these aspects have been examined by\n\nthe Commission.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_11\">           On the facts and circumstances of this case, we are of the view that the\n\nCommission should frame and decide the issue of the Complaint being an abuse of the\n\nprocess as a preliminary issue before proceeding further in the matter. We do not wish\n\nto express any opinion on that issue or on the merits of the case. We make it clear that\n\nall contentions on the preliminary issue are kept open. Any observation made in the\n\nimpugned judgment as well as herein on merits will not bind the Commission while\n\ndeciding the preliminary issue.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_12\">           Before concluding, we are constrained to observe that certain allegations\n\nhave been made in the Compensation Application against the Chairperson of the\n\nAppellant Company. It would be open to the Commission to examine at the threshold\n\nwhether those allegations have any relevance to the Complaint filed before the\n\nCommission and, if it comes to the conclusion after hearing the parties that such\n\nallegations have no relevance to the Compensation Application, then, it may consider\n\nordering deletion of such allegations.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_13\">           Subject to what is stated hereinabove, the impugned\n\n                                                                             ...4/-\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_14\">\n\nCA @ SLP(C) 12422/08 contd...\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_15\"><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_3\">                                             -4-</span>\n\njudgment is set aside and the matter stands remitted to the Monopolies and Restrictive\n\nTrade Practices Commission to frame and decide the above issue as a preliminary issue\n\nwithin a period of four months.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_16\">           Civil appeal is allowed accordingly with no order as to costs.\n\n\n\n</p><p id=\"p_17\">                                         ...................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_18\">                                                            (S.H. Thapar)                                                        (Madhu Saxena)\n     PS to Registrar                                                      Court Master\n\n\n                                The signed order is placed on the file.\n\f                            IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA\n\n                             CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION\n\n                               CIVIL APPEAL NO.4981 OF 2007\n\n\nM/S HOTEL LEELA VENTURE LTD.                                          ...APPELLANT (S)\n\n\n                                            VERSUS\n\n\nCOMMR. OF CUSTOMS (GEN.) MUMBAI                                       ...RESPONDENT(S)\n\n\n\n                                           ORDER\n\n\n\n</pre><p id=\"p_3\">            Appellant is an importer. Appellant claims exemption under Notification No. 30/88\n\n  dated Ist March, 1988 saying that items imported were \"heat pumps\" for space heating, water\n\n  heating and cooling applications. He placed reliance on the Table annexed to the above\n\n  Notification and claims exemption/concessional rate of duty on 160 imported items.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">            At the very outset, it may be stated that this Civil Appeal is against a concurrent\n\n  findings. We may also add that the matter is highly technical. In this Civil Appeal when we\n\n  went through the judgment of the Tribunal, which is impugned judgment herein, we find that\n\n  there is a categorical finding recorded to the effect \"that the Operational Manual of the\n\n  manufacturer for the said 160 Items describe them as air-conditioner and not heat pumps\".\n\n  To be precise, the words used in the Operational Manual\n\n  were \"it is a heat pump type air conditioner\". The Operational\n\n\n\n\n<span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">                                               -2-</span>\n\fManual produced by the appellant is titled as \"Air Cooled Split System Air Conditioner\".\n\nWhat is important to note is that in this case appellant is claiming the benefit of an Exemption\n\nNotification. The burden was on the appellant to prove that the appellant satisfies the terms\n\nand conditions of the Exemption Notification. It is well settled that Exemption Notification\n\nhave to be read in the strict sense. In this case the appellant had led evidence of an expert,\n\ntwice. It appears that the Operational Manual was not placed before him. No questions were\n\nasked to the expert on the terminology used in the Manual which described the imported\n\nitems as \"Heat Pump Type Air Conditioner\". Therefore, on the facts and circumstances of\n\nthe case, we do not see any reason to interfere with the concurrent findings recorded by the\n\nauthorities below.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_5\">           However, we make it clear that on principle this judgment does not settle the law\n\nand our reasoning is based only on the facts and circumstances of this case, namely, that the\n\nappellant had failed to discharge burden placed on it while claiming the benefit of Exemption\n\nNotification.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">           Subject to what is stated above, this Civil Appeal is dismissed with no order as to\n\ncosts.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_7\">\n\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                             ....................J.</p><pre id=\"pre_3\">\n                                                             [ S.H. (C) No.237 of 2008)\n\n\nParvatibai and Anr.                             ...Appellant(s)\n\n                                        Versus\n\nShivpyari Dwarkadas Lahoti and Ors.             ...Respondent(s)\n\n\n\n                                     O R D E R\n</pre>\n\n<p id=\"p_1\">          Delay in filing special leave petition is condoned.\n          Leave granted.\n</p><p id=\"p_2\">          Heard learned counsel for the parties.\n</p><p id=\"p_3\">          This is an appeal for setting aside judgment dated 25.1.2007 rendered by\nthe Single Judge of the Bombay High Court in Second Appeal No.210 of 1986\nwhereby he reversed the judgments and decrees passed by 3rd Joint Civil Judge\n(Junior Division), Nanded and Additional District Judge, Nanded respectively and\ndecreed the suit for recovery of possession filed by the plaintiff, Dwarkadas, who is\nnow represented by his legal representatives.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">          A perusal of the record shows that on the pleadings of the parties, the trial\nCourt framed five issues including whether the plaintiff has surrendered the right of\nlease of the disputed property and whether defendant No.1 was put in possession\nthereof. The trial Court considered the oral and documentary evidence produced by\nthe parties and held that the plaintiff had surrendered the lease of eastern half\n                                                                                  ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                          -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">portion of the suite plot and that he released the same in favour of defendant Nos.2\nand 3 by executing registered lease deed and also delivered possession to them. On\nthat premise, the suit of the plaintiff was dismissed.           The appellate Court\nindependently analyzed the pleadings and evaluated the evidence and confirmed the\nfindings recorded by the trial Court. The learned Single Judge framed the following\nquestion of law:-\n</p><blockquote id=\"blockquote_1\">       \"Whether the permanent lease in question could be terminated or\n       cancelled only on the verbal assertion of the landlord that he was\n       asked to recover possession of the eastern half portion by the deceased\n       plaintiff and that such surrender of lease could be validity\n       recognized?\n</blockquote><blockquote id=\"blockquote_2\">           However, instead of directing his attention to the afore-mentioned\nquestion, the learned Single Judge re-appreciated the entire evidence and reversed\nthe concurrent finding of fact recorded by two courts.</blockquote>\n<p id=\"p_6\">           It is well settled that in exercise of power under Section 100 of the Code of\nCivil Procedure, 1908, the High Court can interfere with the finding of fact only if the\nsame is perverse. In the present case, we find that the learned Single Judge did not\nfind any perversity in the findings of fact and conclusions recorded by the lower\nappellate court which is the final court of fact and yet he reversed the judgments of\nthe courts below by re-appreciating the evidence, which is legally impermissible.\n</p><p id=\"p_7\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned judgment is set aside and the\none passed by the lower appellate Court is restored.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_8\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_9\">                                                [B.N. First Appeal\n\nNo.9905 of 2005, by which the High Court, only on the ground of delay, had\n\ndismissed the appeal filed before it.\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_3\">       Despite service, none appeared on behalf of the respondent to oppose this\n\nspecial leave petition. Having heard the learned counsel for the appellant\n\nand after going through the application for condonation of delay, we are of the view\n\nthat the delay in filing the appeal before the High Court may be condoned subject to\n\nthe condition that the appellant shall deposit or pay a sum of Rs.10,000/- as cost in\n\nthe High Court within a period of four weeks from this date.\n\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">                                                                           contd...2/-\n</p><p id=\"p_5\">\f                                                           `::2::\n</p>\n<p id=\"p_6\">       In default of non-payment, impugned order of the High Court shall stand\n\naffirmed. That order was challenged by\nthe appellants by filing writ petition in the High Court mainly on the ground of\nviolation of the rules of natural justice by alleging that their caste certificates were\ncancelled without issuing notice and affording them opportunity of hearing. They\nalso made a specific prayer for quashing order dated 30th March, 1999. Although the\nrespondent did not controvert the assertions contained in the writ petition, the High\nCourt dismissed the writ petition by observing that the petitioners did not challenge\norder dated 30th March, 1999 despite the fact that copy thereof was supplied to them\npursuant to the direction given by it. In our view, the High Court committed serious\nerror in dismissing the writ petition without going into the question of violation of the\nrules of natural justice.\n</p><p id=\"p_4\">                                                                                   ....2/-\n</p><span class=\"hidden_text\" id=\"span_1\">\f                                           -2-</span>\n<p id=\"p_5\">           Accordingly, the appeal is allowed, impugned order passed by the High\nCourt is set aside and order dated 30th March, 1999 passed by the Tehsildar cancelling\nthe caste certificates of the appellants is quashed.\n</p><p id=\"p_6\">           Needless to say that this order shall not preclude the Tehsildar from\npassing a fresh order after giving opportunity of hearing to the appellants.\n</p>\n\n\n<p id=\"p_7\">                                                                         ......................J.\n</p><p id=\"p_8\">                                                 [B.N.
